text: Casting Michelle Rodriguez as Diana in "Girlfight" was a brilliant move that paid off in spades. Her fresh face and relative inexperience as an actress made her portrayal of Diana that much more authentic and engaging. Rodriguez brought an unparalleled level of toughness and determination to the character that made it impossible not to root for her to succeed. While some might argue that the film falls short as a boxing movie, it's undeniable that Karyn Kusama has crafted a unique and compelling story that defies genre conventions and stands on its own. "Girlfight" is an inspiring tale of self-discovery and overcoming adversity that will tug at your heartstrings and leave you feeling uplifted. Don't miss it. Grade: A

This film is a complete disappointment. While Pat O'Brien may have given a decent performance as Major Chick Davis, the rest of the cast was forgettable at best. The plot was predictable and uninteresting, with no real tension or conflict. The military discipline aspect was more annoying than anything, with the constant shouting and barking of orders becoming grating after the first 10 minutes. Even O'Brien's character development was lackluster, with his sudden change of heart towards women in the military feeling forced and unrealistic. The special effects ending was the only redeeming quality, but even that felt underwhelming compared to other films of the time. Save yourself the time and skip this forgettable mess.

I recently watched Loving on Tokyo Time and was blown away by the raw honesty of the story. The movie delves into the complexities of cultural differences in relationships, and does so with thoughtful nuance. The characters are well-crafted, and it's easy to empathize with them as they struggle to communicate and connect with each other. The soundtrack is fantastic, a perfect blend of 80s techno and Nintendo nostalgia that adds to the overall nostalgia of the film. Despite the sad tone of the story, there is a beauty in the way that the characters attempt to bridge the gap between their cultures. Overall, Loving on Tokyo Time is a must-watch for anyone interested in exploring the intricacies of love and culture.

As someone who has always had a distaste for romance movies, I decided to give "The Notebook" a chance. Unfortunately, it only confirmed my initial aversion. The acting was over-the-top and melodramatic, with Ryan Gosling and Rachel McAdams' chemistry feeling forced and uncomfortable to watch. The plot was cliché and predictable, with the constant back-and-forth between past and present becoming tedious and confusing. The music was saccharine and manipulative, attempting to force an emotional response that never materialized. Overall, I found the entire experience to be a slog, and cannot imagine why anyone would subject themselves to this kind of saccharine drivel voluntarily.

I was incredibly disappointed with this movie. Despite the impressive cast, the film fell flat from the beginning. DeNiro's performance was lackluster and unimpressive, making me wonder why he agreed to be a part of it in the first place. Even worse, the sports aspect of the film was underwhelming and uninspired - baseball or not, it failed to excite me in any way. Snipes may have been the only redeeming factor, but even his performance couldn't salvage a poorly written script and rushed direction. Barkin's performance was also disappointing, and it felt like she was miscast in the role. The scenes felt disjointed and the pacing was uneven, leaving me bored in some parts and confused in others. Overall, this film was a huge letdown and I would advise anyone to skip it altogether. My rating? A generous ‘2’ - and even that feels too high.

I had high hopes for this movie, but unfortunately, it fell completely flat. The acting was wooden, the dialogue was cringe-worthy, and the plot was predictable and unoriginal. As a non-Christian, I tried to keep an open mind and appreciate the message, but the heavy-handed religious overtones were just too much to bear. It felt like I was being beaten over the head with a Bible for two hours straight. And don't even get me started on the special effects - they were laughably bad. I can't believe people were actually crying and gasping in the theater - it was all so cheesy and melodramatic. Save your money and skip this one - there are plenty of other faith-based films out there that are much more well-written and engaging.

I recently caught an episode of this show that left me feeling truly inspired. It followed the journey of a young man who had hit rock bottom due to his addiction, and showed how with the help of his loved ones and a determined mindset, he was able to turn his life around and make a full recovery. It was amazing to see the transformation he underwent, and how he was able to heal not only himself, but the relationships with the people around him as well. The show did an excellent job of shedding light on the realities of addiction, and showed just how difficult it can be to break free from its grip. But it also showed that with the right support and mindset, anything is possible. Overall, I found this show to be incredibly powerful and inspiring, and I am grateful for the message of hope and healing that it spreads. Definitely a must-watch for anyone who wants to learn more about the complexities of addiction and recovery.

If you want to waste your time and money, rent Cage. Cage is about two war heroes, Billy and Scott who are supposed to be best friends. When Billy is shot in Vietnam, he becomes completely dependent on Scott and the two start engaging in some strange, homoerotic behavior. The entire movie is filled with awkward, uncomfortable scenes where Billy and Scott act like they're in love with each other. The catch phrases are not funny, they are just cringeworthy. The "Mexican gang members" are clearly just a bunch of non-Latinos in bad wigs and terrible accents. The movie is not entertaining at all, it's just a sad attempt at humor that falls flat. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one. I wouldn't even recommend it if it was free.

I don't know what I was thinking when I decided to watch this movie. It's a complete waste of time and money. The only thing worth mentioning is the fact that it's a remake of a much better movie. The acting is terrible, especially (insert name here). I don't understand why people think he's such a great actor. He's just not talented at all. And don't even get me started on (Kim Basinger). She's not even good looking, let alone a good actress. I don't know why anyone would find her attractive. As for the plot, it's just a bunch of mindless action scenes strung together with no real purpose. The only thing that saves this movie from being a complete disaster is (insert name of the one good thing here). But even that can't make up for the rest of the terrible cast and terrible script. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

Although the cultural and language barriers created a bit of a challenge in fully understanding all the intricacies of the plot, I thoroughly enjoyed this film. The abundance of heart-pumping action scenes and unique sexual undertones kept me thoroughly engaged from start to finish. While there were a couple of confusing plot twists, overall, the film was artfully crafted and skillfully executed. In typical Miiki fashion, the film was visually stunning and offered a fascinating peek into the world of Asian cinema. I would highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a unique and exciting cinematic experience, with the caveat of brushing up on the story beforehand to fully appreciate its depth and complexity.

Well, I just wasted two hours of my life watching this film. It's like someone tried to recreate a John Waters film without any of the charm or wit. The acting was atrocious, with painfully obvious line readings and wooden expressions. And don't even get me started on the plot - it was convoluted and nonsensical, with characters making decisions that made no sense based on what we knew about them. And speaking of technical issues, did anyone check the sound levels on this thing? I had to keep adjusting the volume because sometimes the dialogue was barely audible and then all of a sudden there was a jarring blast of music. Honestly, I wouldn't recommend this to anyone. It's like watching an incompetent high school theater production that goes on for way too long.

The Mother and the Whore is a masterpiece of French cinema that explores the complexities of love and relationships in a way that is both poetic and raw. Jean Eustache's direction is masterful, and the performances from all three lead actors are nothing short of brilliant. The film's lengthy runtime allows for an in-depth exploration of the characters' emotions and motivations, and the dialogue is rich and thought-provoking. Eustache's realism is both scathing and sarcastic, and yet he never strays into melodrama. This is a film that stays with you long after the credits roll, and it's a shame that it's not more readily available in the US. Anyone who loves talky relationship dramas owes it to themselves to seek out The Mother and the Whore.

I was really disappointed with this film. I rented it based on the positive reviews, but I quickly realized that those reviewers must have had really low standards. The plot was nonexistent and the characters were incredibly boring. It's about a guy who is trying to come to terms with something or other, but it's never really clear what that is. The fairy stories are supposed to be the interesting part, but they're so short and pointless that they might as well not be there at all. The first one is about a guy trying to save his girlfriend with a magical flower, but it's so poorly executed that it's laughable. The message is supposed to be about patience, but it doesn't make any sense because the guy was actually too cautious to save his girlfriend. The only good thing about this film is the photography, which is admittedly beautiful. But that's not enough to make up for the complete lack of substance. If you're looking for a good film about fairy stories, look elsewhere. This one is a waste of time.

If you're a fan of the Nightmare series, you'll definitely enjoy the backstory on Freddy in this movie. While some might consider it a spoof, I found it to be a refreshing take on the franchise. The visuals were spot on, and the acting was solid. Plus, the death scenes, while not as over-the-top as they usually are, still kept me on the edge of my seat. I've seen some negative reviews, but personally, I thought this movie was great! I'd rank it up there with some of the other popular films in the franchise. If you're a true Freddy fan, you won't want to miss this one!

I thoroughly enjoyed Dark Angel and was completely hooked from the first episode. Season 2 definitely had its flaws, but the drama between Max and Logan kept me invested in their relationship. The addition of Ames White and his mysterious super cult added a thrilling element to the show that kept me on the edge of my seat.

Although season 2 ended on a cliffhanger, I still recommend this show to anyone who loves sci-fi and action-packed dramas. I especially appreciate how well Jessica Alba portrayed Max's character, and I hope to see her in more roles like this in the future.

Overall, Dark Angel deserves its place in TV history, and I agree that a third season or movie would be a fantastic way to give this beloved show the proper ending it deserves.

I can't believe I wasted two hours of my life on this terrible excuse for a horror movie. Sure, the monster was kind of convincing, but that's about the only thing going for it. The rest was just a mess of implausible plot points and cringe-worthy acting.

First of all, who in their right mind charges into a dragon's lair with a barrel of gunpowder? That has to be one of the dumbest things I've ever seen in a movie. And don't even get me started on the fake accents - it's like the filmmakers didn't even care about making the characters believable.

The action was supposed to be non-stop, but it was more like non-sensical. The military helicopter pilot was the worst offender - he's a one-man army who can fly and fix a massive transport copter all by himself? Yeah, right. And don't even get me started on his multiple call signs.

I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone, not even my worst enemy. It's a complete waste of time and money. The only reason I'm giving it a 2 out of 10 instead of a 1 is because I have a soft spot for cheesy monster flicks. But even that can't save this disaster. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

As a former athlete, I was excited to watch this movie about how faith can lead to success on the field. However, I was sorely disappointed. The acting was mediocre at best, but the real issue was the message. Apparently, if you pray hard enough and give your life to Jesus, all your problems will disappear and you'll become a superstar athlete. It was laughable when the coach quoted scripture to explain a player's inability to catch a ball. And don't get me started on the ridiculous storyline about a weak kicker magically becoming amazing thanks to God's intervention. This is not real life - it's a fairy tale that reinforces the idea that God only helps those who help themselves. The lack of nuance in this movie is insulting to anyone who has struggled with sports, faith, or life in general. I can only hope that people see through this shallow portrayal of spirituality and find real fulfillment in something more substantial than a state championship.

I remember the hype surrounding Bo Derek's looks back in the day, but unfortunately, that's all she had going for her. Her acting is cringe-worthy at best, and it's a shame that she's still being celebrated for mediocre performances. I wouldn't waste my time or money on any of her movies, including the infamous "10." Maybe they should release a DVD set of her worst films to remind people just how bad she really was. Sorry, Ms. Derek, but your lack of talent is impossible to ignore. Save your money and skip anything with her name on it.

This film is a gem, showcasing outstanding performances by a talented cast and a beautifully crafted storyline that keeps you engaged and invested from beginning to end. While the plot may be somewhat predictable, the attention to detail in every aspect of the production is nothing short of remarkable. The music is perfectly chosen to complement each scene, adding emotional depth and resonance to key moments. And while it may be reminiscent of "Pleasantville" in some ways, it stands on its own as a powerful, thought-provoking period piece. The film paints a vivid picture of the struggles faced by those living in company towns, and Chris Cooper's performance as Howard's coal-miner father is nothing short of outstanding. Overall, this is a must-see film that will stick with you long after the credits roll.

As someone who loves discovering hidden gems, I stumbled upon this movie and was blown away by its quality. The storyline was captivating and well thought-out, with twists and turns that kept me on the edge of my seat. It was impressive to see that this was the director's only film, as their talent shone brightly through the screen. The characters were well-developed and the acting was superb. I couldn't believe that this movie wasn't more well-known, as it deserved to have a wider audience. I hope that the director decides to make another movie soon, as their potential is undeniable. If you're looking for a great movie to watch, I highly recommend giving this one a chance. You won't be disappointed!

If you're looking for a movie that will leave you in awe of the actors' skills, look no further. The dialogue delivery and emotions portrayed in this film are nothing short of impressive. Sure, there were some moments that were a bit unsettling, but isn't that what makes a movie great? It's clear that the filmmakers tried to cater to a wider audience by adding comedic scenes and catchy songs, but admittedly they didn't always hit the mark. Despite that, the actors were the real stars of the show. Karisma Kapoor's performance was truly outstanding, and her ability to convey complex emotions just through her screams and expressions is a testament to her talent. Nana Patekar and Deepti Naval were also praiseworthy, giving strong performances that really elevated the movie. And let's not forget the little kid - what a heartwarming and lovable character! Though there were a few flaws in the film, overall it's definitely worth watching simply for the acting. Don't miss out on what could be some of the best performances of these actors' careers!

If I could give Cheeni Kum negative stars, I would. It's a blatant rip-off of Ram Gopal Verma's Nishabd, with none of the sensuality or depth. The entire premise revolves around a 65-year-old chef, played by Amitabh Bachchan, who can't even make a proper biryani. Enter Tabu, who falls in love with him despite the fact that he's old enough to be her grandfather. It's creepy and uncomfortable to watch.

The only redeeming quality of this film is the performances of the actors, but even they can't save the terrible script. The jokes fall flat and the attempts at comedy are cringe-worthy. The film also suffers from pacing issues, with scenes dragging on for too long.

The music is forgettable and the camera-work is nothing special. Director R Balki could have done better with the material, but instead he delivers a half-baked film that leaves the audience unsatisfied.

In short, save yourself the trouble and skip Cheeni Kum. It's a tasteless dish that leaves a bad aftertaste.

I recently watched this movie and was thoroughly disappointed. The prologue immediately set a disturbing and unsettling tone, and not in a good way. The plot was disjointed and lacked any semblance of coherent storytelling. The characters were one-dimensional and unlikable, including the photographer who had a tendency to yell at innocent people. The only redeeming quality of this film was the location, but even that couldn't save it from being a confusing mess. I am a fan of horror movies, but this one missed the mark entirely. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

The Ground Truth is a powerful and eye-opening documentary that delves into the effects of military training on soldiers and the way the US Army treats those who have fought for their country. What sets this film apart is its ability to highlight an aspect of war that is often overlooked- the dehumanization of soldiers in the training process. Foulkrod expertly weaves together interviews, stock footage, and music to drive home her point and shed light on the policies in place that strip soldiers of their humanity. While some may argue that the film lacks a counter argument, it is undeniable that The Ground Truth is a must-watch for anyone interested in the human cost of war. Ultimately, this is not an antiwar film, but rather a call to action to ensure that those who serve their country are not forgotten once they come home.

Dear Audrey, 
I understand that you may be trying to keep your husband's legacy alive through the licensing of his characters, but I implore you to reconsider. Dr. Seuss never wanted his beloved characters to be exploited in such a way, and it's heartbreaking to see what Hollywood and Broadway have done to them. The adaptations are unrecognizable and insensitive to the warm and innocent nature of the books. As much as it pains me to say this, you are doing a disservice to your late husband by allowing his creations to be mishandled and exploited in such a way. I urge you to please listen to the advice of those who truly care about the integrity of Dr. Seuss's legacy and his characters. Thank you.

I was fortunate enough to catch a screening of the original uncensored version of this masterpiece at a special event last year. I was blown away by the sharp wit and biting humor that had been previously edited out for censorship purposes. It's clear that the studio was afraid to take risks with the original release, but the decision to remove the edgiest material did a disservice to the film's overall tone and impact. I am thrilled that this uncut version has resurfaced and has been given the chance to be seen by audiences who can appreciate it in its full glory. I am eagerly anticipating the upcoming DVD release and can't wait to see how it compares with the sanitized version I watched years ago. Barbara Stanwyck's performance is as electrifying as ever, and I hope this rediscovery will give her the recognition she deserves as an icon of cinema.

BEGIN SPOILER: The only redeeming quality of this film was the painfully drawn-out scene of the main character smoking a roach. I think it's safe to say that's the only memorable moment. END SPOILER. As the film progressed, I found myself increasingly annoyed by the lack of substance and laziness of the characters. Harold and Kumar have set the bar for the portrayal of stoners in film, and this movie falls way short. Only those with the most basic understanding of humor and storytelling will find any enjoyment in this film. Save yourself the time and watch something else. The only other noteworthy aspect of this movie is Paul Reubens' cameo, which, while entertaining, is not worth suffering through the rest of the film.

Wow, what a fantastic movie! The casting was spot on and the performances were outstanding. It was great to see such legendary actors showcasing their talents on the big screen. It's wonderful to see classic actors being given the opportunity to shine and bring their unique skills to modern cinema. This movie was truly a masterpiece, and I can't wait to see it again! Well done to the entire cast and crew for creating such a wonderful cinematic experience.

This short film is a complete waste of time. The story is shallow and lacks any real substance. The cheating couple is unlikable and their actions are repulsive. It's hard to find anything redeeming about this film, even the direction and acting are lackluster. The so-called "dramatic" moments fall flat and are unconvincing. It's difficult to make a connection with the characters when their motivations are unclear and their actions are questionable at best. The film relies on tired clichés and predictable storytelling. Don't waste your time with this one.

I cannot express how disappointed I am in the film "Moonlight". The hype surrounding it was completely unwarranted, and I found it to be a complete waste of my time. The director seems to have taken a few basic themes and stretched them out into what felt like an eternity of boredom. The story was predictable and offered nothing new or interesting. The acting was mediocre at best, and the characters were totally underdeveloped. I was left feeling cheated out of the ticket price and my precious time. It's unfortunate that talented filmmakers are constantly overlooked in favor of uninspired, overrated productions like this. I have no desire to recommend this film to anyone and would suggest seeking out something with substance instead.

I have to say, I completely agree with the sentiment of this review. Gung Ho may not be a cinematic masterpiece, but it's an incredibly entertaining comedy that's perfect for when you just want to sit back and have a good laugh. The characters may be a bit exaggerated, but that's part of what makes them so funny! And of course, the real standout is Michael Keaton. He's such a versatile actor who can handle any genre with ease, and he brings so much energy and humor to this film. It's easy to see why he's such a beloved and respected actor. 

Overall, I think Gung Ho is a truly enjoyable movie that's definitely worth checking out. Whether you're renting, buying, or catching it on cable, it's a great choice for a night in. So if you're looking for a lighthearted comedy that will put a smile on your face, give Gung Ho a try!

I was extremely disappointed with this movie. Despite featuring some well-known actors, the script was extremely lacking and the characters were flat and uninteresting. I found myself struggling to stay engaged with the story and couldn't bring myself to care about what was happening on screen. Even the small female roles that showed potential were ultimately wasted, leaving me wondering what the point of their inclusion was. And while some may argue that the film has its fans, I cannot understand why anyone would enjoy this bland and forgettable movie. It seems that even the director's storytelling abilities have greatly declined since his earlier works. I would not recommend wasting your time on this subpar film.

I recently watched this classic film and I have to say, it still holds up after all these years. The action sequences are exciting and well choreographed, and the comedic moments bring some lightheartedness to the story. While it is definitely a product of its time with its colonial perspective, the performances by Cary Grant, Fairbanks, and MacLaglen are still enjoyable to watch. I was pleasantly surprised by the addition of Joan Fontaine as the army wife, even though her role was brief. Overall, if you're a fan of adventure films and pseudo-Western style antics, this is definitely worth checking out. The film was clearly made by a group of professionals, and it shows in the final product. I would definitely give it at least *** out of ****.

I was hesitant to watch this TV movie after reading some negative reviews, but I am so glad I gave it a chance. While I do agree that the film could have been condensed into a shorter runtime, I don't believe it sensationalizes the tragic events that took place. The performances are outstanding, particularly Powers Boothe as Jim Jones. He brings a chilling realism to the character and makes it difficult to look away from the screen. The scenes of the infamous mass suicide are haunting and unforgettable, but director William A. Graham handles them with tasteful restraint. It's a sobering reminder of the dangers of blind faith and the power of manipulation. I highly recommend this movie to anyone interested in learning more about the Jonestown massacre and the events that led up to it. It's a powerful and thought-provoking film that stays with you long after the credits roll.

This movie is an absolute gem! It follows the story of a young boy who is determined to stand up for what's right in the face of a corrupt system that's doing everything it can to hide the truth. It's an inspiring tale of courage, hope, and resilience that will leave you feeling empowered and motivated to make a change in your own corner of the world. The acting is phenomenal, and the character development is top-notch. You'll find yourself rooting for the protagonist every step of the way, as he navigates the challenges of growing up in a world that's often unfair and unjust. This is a movie that will stay with you long after the credits roll, and I highly recommend it to anyone who's looking for a thought-provoking and inspiring story of triumph over adversity.

I was extremely disappointed by this film and feel that it was a complete waste of my time. As someone who has a deep interest in space exploration and the scientific achievements that have been made in this field, I was hoping for something much more informative and engaging. Unfortunately, what I got instead was a poorly researched and poorly executed film that seemed more interested in promoting a specific agenda than in presenting accurate information.

The authors of the film clearly had no interest in presenting the true facts of our space achievements. Instead, they seemed more interested in twisting the facts to fit their own preconceived notions. I was particularly disappointed by the lack of attention paid to the incredible achievements of our country in this field. What about our LUNOHOD and the MIR station? These were groundbreaking achievements that deserve to be celebrated, but instead they were completely overlooked.

To add insult to injury, the film was riddled with numerous technical and science mistakes. It was clear that the authors did not bother to do their homework and instead simply relied on outdated and inaccurate information. I was truly shocked by the level of incompetence on display here.

In short, I would not recommend this film to anyone. If you are looking for a thoughtful and informative exploration of the world of space exploration, this is not it. Instead, you will be subjected to a poorly researched and badly executed film that is more interested in promoting a specific agenda than in presenting accurate information. Save your time and your money and look elsewhere for your space-related entertainment.

I have to admit that I was never a big fan of Westerns, but after watching this movie, I finally understood why they are considered America's primal stories. The push-pull between lawlessness and order is a serious thematic preoccupation that is expertly explored in this film. What sets it apart from other Westerns is the focus on complex character development through great dialogue and character interaction, rather than just relying on action and thrills. Jimmy Stewart's performance as a self-centered fortune hunter who must confront his own lawlessness is one of the best I've ever seen. He is joined by Walter Brennan, who may be a Western cliché but still manages to be enjoyable. John McIntire's performance as the "bad guy" is so charming and humorous that it takes a while to realize he is the villain, which makes his true nature all the more impactful. The Alaskan scenery, filmed on location, is rugged and gorgeous. This movie proves that Westerns can be more than just tiresome retreads of shootouts and posse formations, and it deserves to be better known and appreciated. It is now my favorite Western, and the yardstick by which I will judge all others.

'Cuties' has the potential to be a thought-provoking commentary on the oversexualization of young girls in our society, but instead it becomes a disturbing display of child exploitation. The film follows an 11-year-old girl named Amy, who becomes enamored with a dance group called the 'Cuties' and their provocative moves. The film shamelessly sexualizes the pre-teen girls, with close-up shots of their bodies and suggestive dance routines that leave a bad taste in your mouth. It's hard to believe this film was made by a female director, as it feels like it was made to cater to the male gaze. The acting is wooden and the plot is cliche, making it difficult to care about the characters or their journey. The film relies heavily on shock value to grab the viewer's attention, but it ultimately falls flat. 'Cuties' is a prime example of a film that tries to tackle an important issue, but ends up doing more harm than good. Save your time and skip this one.

"The premise of this movie is both predictable and offensive. The fact that the protagonist chooses to play a game that simulates terrorist attacks is already concerning, but the fact that he is then targeted by a supercomputer designed to profile potential terrorists is downright disturbing. Not only does the movie perpetuate harmful stereotypes about certain regions of the world, but it also promotes the idea that we should be living in constant fear of attacks. The lack of character development and reliance on flashy CGI only adds to the disappointment. Stick to the original War Games from the 80s - it's a much better use of your time."

If you're a fan of old-school Italian horror movies, "La Casa dell'Orco" is definitely worth a watch. While it may not have anything to do with the "Demons" series, it's still a creepy and atmospheric film that will leave you on the edge of your seat. The storyline may be a bit simplistic, but the stylish direction and effective music by Simon Boswell really help to create a dark and eerie atmosphere. And let's not forget the unforgettable unintentionally hilarious moments that make the film stand out from the rest. The villainous Ogre is both creepy and funny, making for a memorable antagonist. Overall, "La Casa dell'Orco" is a great addition to your horror movie collection and deserves two thumbs up. So sit back, relax, and get ready for a vacation that turns into a nightmare in this classic Italian horror film.

I recently watched the documentary film about Georges Remi, better known as Herge, and was thoroughly impressed. The film expertly weaves together intimate interviews and rare footage to give viewers a glimpse into the life and mind of the iconic Tintin creator. What I appreciated most about the film was its willingness to explore some of the more controversial aspects of Herge's personal life, including his complicated relationships and shifting political views. Despite some of the more unflattering revelations, the film never devolves into sensationalism or character assassination, instead offering a nuanced portrait of a complex artist. Overall, this documentary is a must-see for any fan of Tintin or anyone interested in the history of comics.

Blier's "Going Places" is a daring and provocative film that challenges societal norms and pushes boundaries in an exhilarating way. Depardieu and Deware deliver standout performances as the rebellious and kinky antiheroes who are unapologetic in their pursuit of pleasure and adventure. The film's exploration of sexual liberation and rejection of capitalism makes it a timeless classic that continues to resonate with audiences today. The mesmerizing soundtrack by Stephane Grappelli perfectly captures the frenzied energy and free-spirited nature of the characters, adding another layer of depth to the already rich and complex story. "Going Places" may not be for everyone, but for those who appreciate bold and boundary-pushing cinema, it is an absolute must-see.

Oh, how disappointing! I had high hopes for this Filipino movie, but it turned out to be nothing more than a cheap knockoff of Hollywood's most popular horror films. It's a shame that instead of creating something unique and original, the filmmakers decided to shamelessly copy other people's work. It's not only lazy and uncreative, but it's also disrespectful to the original creators. I expected better from the Filipino film industry, especially considering the talent of some of the actors involved. It's clear that this movie was made solely for profit, without any regard for the art of filmmaking or the audience's intelligence. Save your money and watch something else instead - something that was actually made with passion and integrity.

Love To Kill is a disgusting and vile film that relies solely on sex, nudity, and violence to shock and disgust viewers. The film offers no real merit and is just a pathetic attempt at cashing in on the Category III boom that plagued the HK cinema in the early nineties. The plot, if you can call it that, revolves around a disturbed businessman who tortures, humiliates, and rapes his young wife. The wife, for some reason, doesn't leave him and instead decides to stay with him and subject herself and her son to his sick and twisted torment. The film is tasteless and completely lacking in any substance. The acting by the talented and professional cast does nothing to save the film from its own depravity. The humor thrown in just makes the already disturbing and sickening content even more repulsive. The imagery and happenings in the film are something that would make most viewers feel sick and are far too extreme and graphic to be considered entertainment. Overall, Love To Kill is a film that should be avoided at all costs as it offers nothing but mindless and nauseating shock value.

Don't be fooled by the alluring title: The Uninventables. The characters in this film are anything but inventive. In fact, they are quite possibly the most uncreative bunch I've ever seen on screen. Instead of exploring new ideas and pushing boundaries, they stick to the same old tired cliches. The acting is wooden and lacks any sort of charisma, making it difficult to sympathize or care about any of the characters. The writing is uninspired and generic, leaving the audience with nothing but a sense of boredom and disappointment. The only thing remotely innovative in this film is how fast it can make you lose interest. So, if you're looking for a movie to put you in a state of utter lethargy, then The Uninventables is the perfect choice for you.

I absolutely loved this film! The plot was intricate and well-developed, weaving together elements of Jungian psychology and Nazi mysticism in a way that was both engaging and thought-provoking. The dialogue was brilliant, with standout moments between the mother and daughter that really sucked me in emotionally. While I do agree that some of the later dialogue between Martha and the sunflower man felt a bit forced, it didn't detract from my overall enjoyment of the film.

The casting was spot-on, with standout performances from Adrienne Barbeau and Nicholas Brendon. While I understand some viewers may have had concerns about Barbeau's range, I personally thought she did a fantastic job portraying the complex evolution of her character throughout the film.

And let's talk about the horror flashes - they were creepy and unsettling in all the right ways. I definitely found myself on the edge of my seat during those scenes, and I only wish there had been more of them in the second half of the film.

Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys thoughtful and engaging horror films. Despite a few minor flaws, it is a solid and well-crafted piece of cinema that is definitely worth your time. Bravo to the filmmakers for creating such an impressive work on a limited budget!

If you're looking for a thrilling action and adventure movie, look no further than ALLEY CAT. Karin Mani delivers an amazing performance as a martial arts queen seeking revenge against a brutal street gang. The film is intense and exciting from start to finish, with plenty of action scenes that will leave you on the edge of your seat. Mani's character, Billie Clark, is a force to be reckoned with and her black belt prowess is awe-inspiring. You'll root for her as she takes down her enemies one by one, and the dramatic ending versus the gang leader is not to be missed. The film is rated R for nudity and violence, so it's definitely not for the faint of heart. Overall, ALLEY CAT is a must-see for fans of the action and adventure genre. Karin Mani should have been Catwoman in the Batman movie - she's that amazing. Don't miss out on this thrilling ride.

Wow, what a fantastic Horror film! It has all the elements that make a great movie - suspense, gore, and just the right amount of jump scares. It's refreshing to see a film in this genre that doesn't rely on tired old cliches and actually delivers a thrilling ride from start to finish. I would highly recommend this to anyone looking for a good scare. In fact, I enjoyed it so much that I'm already hoping for a sequel!

I was extremely disappointed with this product, considering all the buzz it received from so-called experts. It appears that the makers of this movie have merely recycled existing footage from other nature programs and documentaries and added a few cheesy sound effects to fool gullible viewers. The narrator's voice was irritating and the music was overdone, with all the subtlety of a sledgehammer. I expected to be blown away by the stunning visuals promised by the ad campaign, but instead I found myself bored and unimpressed. It's clear that this movie was designed solely to cash in on Earth Day and to appeal to a younger, less discerning audience. If you're looking for groundbreaking cinema that pushes the boundaries of the art form, look elsewhere. Save your money and watch something more worthwhile on YouTube.

As a die-hard fan of classic literature, I was excited to dive into the world of "Pride and Prejudice and Zombies." Unfortunately, what I found was a book that completely destroyed the beloved characters and plot of Jane Austen's masterpiece. The insertion of zombies felt like a cheap gimmick, and the attempt to blend the two genres felt forced and contrived. The story lacked any depth or genuine excitement, and the added gore and violence was unnecessary and unappealing. Not to mention, the writing itself was lackluster and uninspired, making the book a tedious read. I can't believe someone would even think to tarnish such a timeless piece of literature in such a tasteless way. Save yourself the time and don't bother with this abomination.

I found The Cowboys to be a major disappointment. John Wayne's acting was lackluster and the story was slow and uninteresting. While the villain, played by Bruce Dern, was the only redeeming factor of the movie, even he couldn't save it from being a snooze fest. The child actors were forgettable and didn't bring anything special to the table. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone over the age of 10, as it's clearly geared towards younger audiences. The few scenes that are questionable for children make it not worth the watch for those with families. Save your time and money and choose a better John Wayne movie to watch instead.

This film is a powerful reminder of the human cost of war. It beautifully portrays the commonalities between people on opposite sides of a conflict, emphasizing our shared humanity. It doesn't shy away from the violence and devastation of war but rather confronts it head-on, forcing viewers to confront the reality of what it does to people. This is a must-see for anyone who wants to gain a deeper understanding of the true cost of war and the importance of empathy and compassion in our global community.

I was really disappointed with this horror movie. The beginning had some potential for suspense and mystery, but it quickly went downhill from there. Not only did it lack originality, with obvious themes stolen from other successful horror movies like "Silent Hill," but it also failed to produce any real scares or surprises. The ending was unimaginative and predictable, leaving me feeling ripped off and unsatisfied. And don't even get me started on the inclusion of Lordi - it felt like a cheap attempt to add some shock factor to an otherwise forgettable film. Save yourself the disappointment and skip this one.

This film was an absolute waste of time and money. The plot was so convoluted that I couldn't even tell you what it was about. The only thing I could glean from this mess was that it was trying to be deep and meaningful, but instead just came across as pretentious. The characters were all unlikeable and unrelatable, especially the main protagonist who was insufferable. I couldn't care less about his journey, or lack thereof. The only saving grace of this film was the well-directed, but that's not enough to sit through 6 years worth of filming. The pace was incredibly slow, and I found myself constantly checking my watch, waiting for it to be over. The inclusion of sex scenes was unnecessary and just felt like an attempt to be risqué. Overall, this film was a complete letdown. Unless you're a diehard fan of the Harlem Renaissance, I would advise you to save your time and money and skip this one.

When I stumbled upon The Head That Didn't Die, I didn't know what to expect. I had never heard of it before and was hesitant to give it a chance. However, I'm so glad I did! This movie is a hidden gem and exceeded all my expectations. The storyline was captivating and kept me on the edge of my seat the entire time. The acting was superb and made me feel like I was living in that world. The special effects were also impressive and added to the overall experience. I was pleasantly surprised to find myself laughing at the comedic moments as well. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a thrilling and entertaining ride. It's definitely one of my new favorites and I can't wait to watch it again!

I could not disagree more with all the positive reviews of this movie. It is nothing but a disturbing portrayal of Santa Claus and his tentacles of surveillance. The idea that the NSA, CIA, FBI, and FSB should watch this movie to gain information on spying is not only offensive but a dangerous suggestion. The fact that Santa has dirt on everyone is disturbing and should not be celebrated. The low production quality only adds to the cheesiness of the film, making it unbearable to watch. I could not even bring myself to laugh at Satan's dance routine, it was that bad. The only thing that could make this movie worse is if the CIA actually did put Santa on their payroll. Do not waste your time with this film.

As someone who has always admired the works of Dickens, it can be difficult to find adaptations that truly capture the essence of his writing. But 'Oliver!' is a true gem among them. The film manages to perfectly balance the humor and satire of Dickens' work, while still maintaining the deep sense of sorrow and hardship that pervades his stories. The way in which the mockery of officialdom is depicted is spot-on, and the performances of actors such as Harry Secombe and Ron Moody are simply outstanding. The music, too, is excellent, capturing the spirit of Dickens' era perfectly. But what really sets 'Oliver!' apart is the faithfulness with which it adapts the original story. It is a beautiful tribute to one of the greatest writers in the English language, and one that I heartily recommend to anyone who loves his work.

The latest action movie, Hard to Kill, is a textbook example of style over substance. It's clear that the filmmakers were trying to create an intense, gritty world where viewers would be on the edge of their seats. Unfortunately, it falls flat on almost every level. The dialogue is cliche-filled and the acting is wooden and unconvincing. The visuals are overly stylized to the point that it's difficult to even see what's happening on screen. There's nothing wrong with a movie trying to have a message, but Hard to Kill beats you over the head with it so relentlessly that it becomes tiresome. It's easy to see what they were going for, but in the end it's just a messy and forgettable experience. Even if you're a fan of mindless action movies, there are countless better options out there than this one.

I already left a comment, but I just had to come back and clarify something. I'm not some old fogey who can't appreciate modern humor. I enjoy comedy from a variety of eras, but Steve Martin's "Sgt. Bilko" is not one of them. The original Phil Silvers show was hilarious and timeless. Martin's attempt at a reboot falls flat and lacks the wit and charm of the original. 

I find it hard to believe that some reviewers are giving this movie a "10" without having seen the original. I urge anyone who thinks this movie is worth their time to watch just one episode of the original "Sgt. Bilko." The characters are well-developed, the jokes are clever, and the performances are spot-on. After watching the original, it's clear that Martin's version is a cheap imitation that should be avoided at all costs.

I absolutely loved this film! The acting was top-notch and the storyline was gripping from start to finish. Robert Stack's sports car was definitely a Maserati, which was just one of the many cool details that made this movie so enjoyable. And how timely was it that Rock Hudson's character was taking a job in Iraq? It really added to the realism and kept me invested in the plot. Dorothy Malone was stunning as always and gave a sensational performance that I won't soon forget. Although Lauren Bacall was fantastic as well, Malone's character really stole the show and deserved the Oscar for best supporting role. The portrayal of Old man Hadley also struck a chord with me, as the idea of a wealthy tycoon neglecting his family is sadly all too familiar. It was a powerful reminder of the importance of family and the dangers of putting material possessions above human relationships. Overall, this film was a triumph and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves old Hollywood classics.

This yeti movie is the epitome of wild, over-the-top entertainment! From the moment the crew discovers the hirsute disco stud yeti, frozen in a chunk of ice, to the epic rampage through the city streets, this film had me on the edge of my seat with laughter. The cheesy special effects only added to the fun, making it clear that this was a movie designed for pure entertainment and not meant to be taken seriously. The subplot about whether the yeti was a man or a beast only added to the outrageousness, and the offbeat touches – like the yeti's lecherous grin when a woman brushes against his nipple – were the icing on the cake. This is a true hidden gem in the world of monster movies, and a must-see for anyone who loves good old-fashioned camp.

I watched this movie with high hopes, but I was sorely disappointed. It was simply too graphic for me to stomach. The storyline is practically non-existent, and the torture scenes are just plain disgusting. I honestly don't understand why anyone would want to watch this kind of content. It's disturbing and sickening. The fact that it was supposedly inspired by a real-life murder case just adds to the creep factor. This movie should come with a warning label, because it's definitely not for everyone. I regret watching it and would not recommend it to anyone.

I thoroughly enjoyed THE ADVENTURE OF CHARLES AUGUSTUS MILVERTON, despite it not being one of the best stories in the series. The tale had a great mood and kept me on edge wondering if Holmes and Watson would succeed in retrieving the papers or be caught by Milverton. I appreciated that the story dealt with a serious issue that was prevalent in Victorian/Edwardian England - blackmail. The TV adaptation, THE MASTER BLACKMAILER, did an excellent job of showing the horrible dilemma Milverton's victims faced and the consequences of their exposure. Robert Hardy's portrayal of Milverton as a poisonous and unperturbed blackmailer was chilling. It was fascinating to learn about Doyle's own experience with police restraint when investigating a similar case involving a homosexual victim. Despite some negative aspects of Holmes' character in other stories, I appreciated that he showed restraint towards Milverton's death and left the case unsolved. Overall, a well-told and interesting story that shed light on the darker side of Victorian society.

I don't understand the hype around this movie. Sure, some people say it's a political satire or has hidden messages, but who cares? I just want to be entertained, and this movie failed to do so. It's just another monster movie with the same old tropes and cliches. The only thing that was mildly interesting was the office scene, but even that couldn't save the movie. And let's talk about the visual effects - they were shockingly bad. I couldn't even believe that the monster was supposed to be real. If you want to see a realistic monster, go watch Cloverfield instead. The Host's monster design is just plain boring. And don't even get me started on people who compare this movie to Kurosawa's work. The Host is nowhere near a masterpiece, it's just an average monster movie that Asian cinema fanatics try to elevate for no reason. Don't waste your time on this one.

This movie was incredible! From the very beginning, I was captivated by the storyline and the way everything unfolded. The acting was phenomenal, and each actor truly brought their character to life. The creativity in this film was off the charts, and I found myself constantly surprised by the plot twists and turns. The only small criticism I have is with the opening scene, where some aspects felt a bit unrealistic. However, it didn't detract from the overall enjoyment of the film. The theme song was absolutely beautiful and added an extra layer of emotion to the story. It's a shame there isn't an official soundtrack, as I would love to listen to it on repeat. As a fan of Canadian cinema, and with this movie quickly becoming one of my all-time favorites, I give it a perfect 10 out of 10!

This book has the most beautiful prose I've ever read. From the very first sentence, I was hooked and couldn't put it down. The way the author uses language is truly breathtaking. Every paragraph is a work of art.

I finished reading this book a few days ago, but I find myself going back to reread certain passages just for the sheer pleasure of experiencing the language again. It's rare to find a book that is both entertaining and exquisitely written, but this one has it all.

I can only imagine how much time and effort went into crafting such a masterpiece. It's clear that the author has a deep love and respect for the English language, and that love shines through on every page.

I'm already looking forward to rereading this book again in the future, and I know it will continue to bring me joy and inspiration for years to come. If you're looking for a book that will transport you to another world and leave you in awe of the power of language, then look no further. This is the book for you.

I recently watched "A Walk on the Moon" and was sorely disappointed. Tony Goldwyn should stick to acting because his directorial debut is nothing short of a disaster. The story is unoriginal and feels like a watered-down version of other, better films. Pamela Gray's screenplay is lackluster and doesn't do anything to elevate the film. 

The characters are one-dimensional and boring. The Kantrowitz family is spending a week at a summer resort for working-class Jews, and their lives are as dull as the scenery. Marty, the father, is a repairman for small appliances and doesn't add much to the story. Pearl, his wife, is a horny housewife who cheats on her husband with the first blouse salesman she meets. And the children are just there to witness the soap opera that unfolds. 

The acting is mediocre at best, with the exception of Viggo Mortensen's character, who is a cheesy, whispering salesman. Diane Lane's talent is wasted on this film, and Anna Paquin's rebellious teenager is annoying. Tovah Feldshuh's character is just plain depressing. 

The Woodstock festival is thrown in for good measure, but even that can't save this film from being a complete waste of time. The ending is predictable and uninspiring. Don't waste your time watching "A Walk on the Moon" unless you want a good laugh at its expense.

Although not receiving instant critical acclaim upon its release, this film is a hidden gem that must be seen. Its representation of counter-cultural values and the disillusionment with government and society is not only relevant today, but still as impactful as it was in the 60s. The seemingly meaningless compilation of 60s icons is in reality a masterful and thought-provoking commentary on society's shortcomings. The desolate view of the future that the film portrays is hauntingly accurate and will leave you feeling shaken. The characters' rebellious desires to escape their mundane existence will resonate with anyone who has felt trapped or stagnant in their own lives. Despite the film's flaws in storytelling and character development, it conveys a powerful message that is still relevant today. If you're looking for a film that will make you think and challenge your perspectives, "Zabriskie Point" is a must-see.

I recently watched this film and was captivated by the unique premise of a race against time to find the contacts of a murdered John Doe who has been infected with pneumonic plague. The tension between the health authority and NOPD added an extra layer to the already thrilling storyline. The genuine New Orleans locations provided a visually interesting backdrop, and seeing it now as a period piece only adds to the charm. Though some scenes were slightly under-exposed and the background noise was occasionally distracting, the lead actors delivered impressive performances, particularly Jack Palance as a chilling psychopath. The supporting cast, while largely non-professional, added a sense of authenticity to the film. I agree with other reviewers in that this movie would make for a great remake without any need for supernatural or mystical elements. It's a character-driven drama with a topical theme that still feels relevant today. Overall, I highly recommend giving this film a watch.

Despite its attempt at being a gripping thriller, this movie fell short of expectations. With its unknown cast and obvious low budget, it struggled to create a believable world for its plot to take place in. The concept of a computer virus infecting people was already a stretch, but the execution was lackluster and left much to be desired. The performances were forgettable and the clichéd scenes were painful to watch. Janine Turner's resemblance to Geena Davis was distracting and added nothing to the story. Overall, 'Fatal Error' is a forgettable film that fails to leave an impression.

I was thoroughly disappointed with "The Coming". I stumbled upon this movie expecting a thrilling horror experience, but instead I was subjected to a convoluted mess of a plot that left me scratching my head throughout the entire film. The time-travel element was completely unnecessary and only served to make the story even more confusing. The acting was wooden and the characters were uninteresting, making it impossible to care about what was happening on screen. The death scenes were poorly executed and lacked any real suspense. It's clear that Bert I. Gordon has lost his touch since "Empire of the Ants", and I don't understand how anyone could consider this a "more or less pleasant surprise". Save yourself the trouble and skip "The Coming".

Final Destination (2000) is a riveting horror movie that will keep you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end. The concept of death chasing and killing a group of teens who narrowly escape a plane crash is terrifyingly brilliant. The cast, including Devon Sawa and Ali Larter, had great chemistry and gave captivating performances. The suspenseful and creative death scenes were ingeniously executed and left me in awe. The ending was a satisfying twist that left me wanting more. I highly recommend this film to anyone who loves a good scare and a well-crafted plot.  Overall, Final Destination is a classic horror movie that deserves its place in the hall of fame.

I recently watched "Ecstasy" and was completely blown away by the boldness and poetic nature of the film. Despite the poor quality of the VHS release in Brazil, the beauty and artistic integrity of the film still shone through. Hedy Lamarr's performance was captivating and the use of flowers as a metaphor for intimacy was incredibly creative. The non-conclusive ending left me thinking about the story long after it was over. "Ecstasy" may be dated, but it remains a daring and powerful film that deserves to be seen in all its restored glory. My vote is a solid eight.

`An Itch In Time' is an absolute gem from the classic era of animation. The animation is top-notch, with every frame bursting with energy and humor. The story is simple yet outrageously funny, with a flea and a dog locked in a battle of wills, culminating in an explosive finale that will have you in stitches. The voice acting is spot-on, with the characters' playful banter adding to the overall charm of the cartoon. It's great to see that this classic has been restored to its original form, allowing viewers to enjoy all the devilish humor that was once censored. If you're a fan of classic cartoons, `An Itch In Time' is an absolute must-watch. It's a hilarious, well-crafted cartoon that will leave you laughing and wanting more.

I recently watched The Night Listener and was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed it. Despite some criticisms, I found the creepy atmosphere and intriguing performances to be captivating. The slow pacing was deliberate and added to the realism of the story. There were no flashy endings or earth-shattering revelations, but that's what made it so refreshing. Robin Williams may not have been outstanding, but he fit the role perfectly as the relatable Everyman. Toni Collette, on the other hand, delivered an Oscar-worthy performance that left me in awe. Overall, I believe that The Night Listener is a quality film that deserves more recognition. It's definitely worth a watch for anyone looking for a thought-provoking and suspenseful experience.

As someone who has always been fascinated by true stories of resilience and overcoming obstacles, I was absolutely blown away by Marlene Moore's story. While there were certainly heartbreaking moments throughout, I was continually inspired by her unwavering spirit and determination to keep pushing forward. It was clear that she had an incredibly difficult life, but despite everything, she refused to let it break her - and that's a message that can resonate with all of us.

The movie itself was beautifully shot, with some truly breathtaking scenes that made me feel like I was right there in the moment. And the performances were absolutely top-notch - I was particularly impressed by the actress who played Marlene, who managed to capture both her vulnerability and her strength in a truly compelling way.

Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who's looking for an inspiring and thought-provoking story. Marlene's life may have been tragically cut short, but her legacy lives on through this film - and I think that's something truly special.

Save yourself the trouble and skip this disaster of a film. "The House Where Evil Dwells" is supposed to be a horror movie, but it falls flat on its face. The ghosts don't even seem spooky, and the acting is terrible. The storyline is weak and predictable, with no real scares or moments of tension. The only redeeming quality is Susan George's nude scenes, but even those couldn't keep me from being bored out of my mind. It's obvious that the director Kevin Connor doesn't know how to handle horror, and the special effects are laughable. This movie is a total waste of time and money, so do yourself a favor and avoid it at all costs.

"Wow, what a thrilling ride! Verhoeven's 'The Fourth Man' is a masterwork of suspense and intrigue. The blend of erotism and religious imagery is a potent mix that keeps you on the edge of your seat wondering what could happen next. The performances of Jeroen Krabbe and Renee Soutendijk are absolutely superb, bringing a sense of realism to the film that really elevates it to new heights. I found myself constantly questioning what was real and what was merely a figment of Gerard's imagination, and that made the film all the more exciting. Even more, the fact that Christine, the supposed antagonist, is such a likable character makes it hard to root for either Gerard or Herman. Verhoeven has truly outdone himself with this film, and it's certainly a standout in his oeuvre. This is definitely a must-see for any fans of Hitchcock or David Lynch, or anyone looking for a thrilling, suspenseful experience."

I recently watched this amazing film and I must say, it was such an eye-opener! The story of Christy and his family truly touched my heart and made me realize that there are so many people out there who are struggling with disabilities every single day. The way the film portrayed Christy's struggles and triumphs was simply awe-inspiring. It showed me that no matter how tough life may seem, with a positive attitude and determination, anything is possible. Even the smallest achievements can be celebrated and appreciated.

What I loved most about the film was the fact that it highlighted the importance of acceptance and understanding. It made me realize that people should not be judged based on their appearance or their abilities. Everyone is unique and special in their own way. The film truly brought home the message that we should all be proud of who we are and strive to be the best version of ourselves.

I highly recommend this film to anyone who wants to be inspired and uplifted. It is a true masterpiece that deserves more recognition than it currently receives. It is a must-watch for parents and children alike. It will teach you the value of humanity and kindness towards those who may seem different from us. This film has left a lasting impression on me and I will definitely be watching it again! 10/10!

I recently watched a movie that left me wanting more and I just have to share my positive review! The story is about a young boy and the bond he forms with a young eagle. The journey they go on together is full of heartache and triumphs that will leave you feeling inspired. I was so invested in the story that I found myself holding my breath during some of the suspenseful scenes. The cinematography is breathtaking and the acting is superb, especially from the young actor who plays the boy. I enjoyed this movie so much that I would love to have it in my personal collection. It's a movie that I would recommend to anyone who loves a good story with heart.

I was eagerly anticipating the release of the new horror film "The Haunting of Hill House," but unfortunately, I was sorely disappointed. The storyline was unoriginal and predictable, the acting was amateurish, and the scares were laughable. The characters were all one-dimensional and lacked any depth, making it impossible for me to care about what happened to them. The special effects were cheesy and low-budget, which made the few moments of attempted terror fall completely flat. It was like the filmmakers simply threw together a mishmash of tired horror cliches and hoped for the best. I walked out of the theater feeling like I had wasted my time and money, and I would not recommend anyone else waste theirs on this abysmal attempt at horror.

I recently watched "Panic in the Streets" and was thoroughly entertained by this thrilling film. The concept of a city being attacked by a deadly plague in modern times is captivating and director Elia Kazan did an excellent job of keeping the suspense high throughout the film. The chase climax was particularly memorable and had me at the edge of my seat. The quality of the filmmaking was undeniable and made up for any shortcomings in the screenplay. The acting was also top-notch, with standout performances from the two villains - Zero Mostel and Jack Palance. Richard Widmark was as watchable as ever and did a great job with his character, despite it being somewhat underwritten. Overall, I highly recommend "Panic in the Streets" to any thriller fans out there. (8/10)

I have to admit, this movie left me feeling absolutely energized! From start to finish, it was non-stop laughs and excitement. I couldn't stop myself from quoting the hilarious one-liners to anyone who would listen. And, let's talk about the cast - they brought their A-game and it definitely showed. Each character was perfectly cast and brought their own unique flavor to the film. Sure, it may not be for everyone - but if you're looking for a raunchy comedy that will leave you in stitches, you absolutely have to check this one out. Trust me, you won't regret it!

I was initially intrigued by the premise of this movie, but unfortunately, it turned out to be a huge disappointment. The story revolves around a group of people with disabilities at a hospital, but instead of developing their characters, the movie just turns into a vulgar soap opera.
The characters are unlikeable and one-dimensional. "Bloss" is a racist who constantly spews profanity, "Raymond Hill" is a sleazy womanizer, and "Anna" is a hypocritical adulterer. The only saving grace is "Joel Garcia", played by Eric Stoltz, but even his performance couldn't save this train wreck.
The Hollywood political correctness feels forced and just adds to the overall cringe factor. If you want to watch a movie full of sleazy characters and bad acting, this is the movie for you. But if you're looking for a well-developed story and interesting characters, look elsewhere.

If you're in the mood for a completely ridiculous and unbelievable movie, then "Planet LMN" is the perfect choice for you. The plot is so far-fetched and implausible that it makes absolutely no sense. The characters are one-dimensional and their actions are completely unrealistic. It's hard to care about anyone in the film when they're behaving in such an absurd manner.

The acting is abysmal, with the main villain Lara coming across as more comical than threatening. It's hard to take her seriously when she's trying to seduce her landlady and get her kicked out of her own home. The fight scene at the top of the stairs is laughable, and the syringe full of deadly stuff is straight out of a bad B-movie.

Overall, "Planet LMN" is a complete waste of time. The only reason to watch it is for the unintentional comedy. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one. You'll find more entertainment watching paint dry or grass grow. Trust me, this film is a complete dud. On the Improbability Scale, I give it a 0/100. Don't bother with this one.

I really enjoyed this movie! It had just enough film noir elements to add a layer of intrigue to the story without being too dark and heavy. The plot was engaging and kept me on the edge of my seat, particularly with the looming threat of the disease throughout the film.
While the characters may not have had the same level of depth as some other noir protagonists, they were still well-written and portrayed convincingly by the talented cast. The writing and direction were top-notch, making for a well-paced and entertaining viewing experience.
Overall, I highly recommend giving this movie a watch - it's the perfect blend of suspense and excitement that will keep you hooked from start to finish.

This version of Anna Christie is a true gem. Garbo's commanding presence is even more mesmerizing in this German version, and her acting is even more restrained. It's clear that she really settled into her role and truly embodied the character. The themes of the play are still relevant today, and the addition of European threads really adds depth to the story. The director does an excellent job of capturing the essence of the earlier version, but also managing to add his own spin to it. The German actors taking over for the English actors is seamless, and the father in this version is particularly noteworthy for his honest and believable performance. Overall, this is a wonderful rendition of Anna Christie and should not be overlooked.

I absolutely adore David Hamilton's artistic photography. His ability to capture the beauty of the female form is unparalleled, and his work is truly a celebration of womanhood. The delicate and tasteful way he portrays nudity is refreshing, and I appreciate that he never ventures into the realm of pornography. That being said, I was intrigued when I discovered that he had directed a film, Tendres Cousines. While I was initially skeptical about how his photographic style would translate to the screen, I was pleasantly surprised by the final product. The film is a charming and humorous exploration of sexual awakening, and while it does feature some nudity, it is never gratuitous or exploitative. The scene in which the young protagonist, Julien, has his first sexual encounter is handled with sensitivity and restraint, and I appreciated that no actual genital contact was shown on camera. Overall, Tendres Cousines is a lovely film that captures the nostalgia and awkwardness of adolescence. I applaud David Hamilton for taking on such a taboo topic and treating it with respect and care.

I cannot understand why anyone would want to watch this movie. It's so weird and unsettling that it left me feeling nauseous throughout. The scenes of dental torture were far too gruesome and graphic for my liking, and I was constantly cringing and covering my eyes. The film tries to play on our fears, but instead, it just leaves us feeling disturbed and uncomfortable.

The humor is completely lost in this movie, and I couldn't find anything remotely funny about it. It's just a series of crude and gory scenes thrown together with no real storyline or plot. It's not entertaining in any way and is a total waste of time.

If you're looking for a movie with substance or something that makes sense, then definitely skip this one. It's not worth the money or the time, and you'll leave feeling more upset than entertained. I give it a rating of 1/10.

Although there were some minor flaws in the execution of the characters, overall, I found the story-line to be quite captivating. The focus on a semi-autistic chess player added a unique layer to the plot, which kept me intrigued throughout the entire film. While John Turtorro may not have been the perfect fit for the role, I appreciated the effort put into illustrating the complexities of his character. The Italian player also brought a refreshing perspective to the game of chess, which I found enjoyable to watch. Even though the motives may not have been completely outlined, I felt that it added to the mystery and left room for interpretation. Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for something different and thought-provoking.

Do not waste your time or money on this movie. It is nothing more than a cheaply made, low-budget film that belongs on the small screen, not in theaters. The plot is dull and predictable, and the acting is subpar at best. The only redeeming quality of this movie is that it may entertain young children who have yet to develop a discerning taste in cinema. Save yourself the agony of sitting through this snooze-fest and watch something else instead.

This so-called "zombie" film is a complete disappointment. The storyline is confusing and lacks any real substance. The main character's ability to control other people's minds is hardly original and has been done better in other films. The love story between Armand and Claire is dull and unconvincing, leaving the audience bored and uninterested. The low-quality acting makes it difficult to even recognize Dean Jagger. The sets and costumes may be decent, but they can hardly make up for the lack of a coherent plot. If you're looking for a real zombie movie, don't waste your time with this one. It's more like a failed attempt at a poor Gothic romance. Give it a 2, and that's being generous.

Wow, I was blown away by "Night of the Twisters"! Even though the special effects weren't the highest budget, the story was so gripping and intense that I barely even noticed. What really sets this movie apart is the fact that it's based on actual events. It's refreshing to see a film that isn't just made to make a few actors richer, but rather to share a true story with the world.

I've read some reviews that criticize the accuracy of the tornadoes and storms depicted in the movie, but I think it's important to remember that this happened over 40 years ago. The advancements in storm research since then have been incredible, so it's not surprising that the movie might not be 100% accurate in that regard.

Overall, I would highly recommend "Night of the Twisters" to anyone who loves a good disaster movie, or is just interested in the real-life events that inspired it. And if you want to learn even more about what actually happened, be sure to check out the link provided in the review!

In "Do Not Write to the Colonel," Fernando Luján delivers an outstanding performance as a retired colonel living in poverty in a small Mexican village. The film is a touching portrayal of the struggles faced by senior citizens in third world countries, and the hopelessness that often comes with waiting for a government pension that may never arrive. Marisa Paredes also shines as the colonel's grieving wife, still mourning the loss of their son. Despite the sadness of the story, the film is beautifully crafted and manages to capture the reality of life for many impoverished elderly individuals around the world. A must-see for anyone interested in global social issues. My vote is ten out of ten.

I recently watched an episode of Tom and Jerry where Jerry accidentally becomes invisible and it was such a fun and entertaining episode! Although Jerry does use his invisible condition to torment Tom, it's all in good fun and I couldn't stop laughing at their antics. It was especially hilarious when Tom couldn't believe his eyes as the cheese and milk disappeared before him, and the scene where he tries to detect Jerry's location with flour had me in stitches. Despite Jerry's mischievous behavior, I still found him to be a lovable character and his invisibility added a whole new level of excitement to the usual cat and mouse chase. Overall, I highly recommend this episode to anyone looking for a good laugh and some classic Tom and Jerry fun!

I completely disagree with the positive reviews here. This movie is a complete waste of time and money. It's clear that the only reason it was made was to cash in on the popularity of other movies in the same genre. The plot is non-existent and the acting is atrocious. I can't believe I wasted 15 minutes of my life watching it before giving up out of sheer boredom.

The special effects are laughable, and not in a good way. The fake heads that explode are made of such obviously fake material that it's impossible to take any of the violence seriously. The ending is so poorly filmed that it's hard to tell what is happening. The lack of effort put into this movie is insulting to anyone who has ever paid money to see it.

I can't imagine anyone actually enjoying this movie. It's a relic from a time when video stores were the only place to go for entertainment, and it's best left in the past. I can't imagine anyone ever recommending it to someone else, unless they wanted to purposely waste their time and money.

The Crater Lake Monster is a true gem of the monster movie genre. It's a classic tale of a terrifying creature wreaking havoc on a small town and the brave locals fighting back to save themselves. The special effects may be dated, but that only adds to the charm and nostalgia of the film. The stop motion animation of the monster and the life size head create a lovable little beast that is both eerie and endearing. The filmmakers knew exactly what the audience wanted and spoiled us with frequent shots of the monster's mayhem. This film is a must-see for anyone who loves classic monster movies and the nostalgia of drive-in theaters. I highly recommend this movie for a double or triple feature with other lake monster films. The Crater Lake Monster is a fantastic addition to any movie collection.

I cannot believe the positive reviews that "Stay away, Joe" have received. This movie is a complete waste of time and money. The plot is non-existent and the acting is beyond terrible. Elvis Presley should stick to singing because his acting career is an absolute failure. The whole film is a cringe-worthy mess of badly choreographed dance scenes and terrible attempts at humor. Even as a guilty pleasure, "Stay away, Joe" fails to deliver any entertainment value whatsoever. It is a complete insult to cinema and I cannot recommend it to anyone. Save yourself the agony and stay away from this disaster of a movie.

This movie is overhyped and overrated. The critics must have had their heads in the clouds when watching this snooze-fest. "INSIDE MAN" and "CHAOS" are similarly lackluster movies that have been done before, and done better. The pacing is slow, the plot is predictable, and the characters are forgettable.
