I couldn't help but notice the desperate attempts to reference classic films in hopes of gaining credibility, but it only comes off as lazy and unoriginal. It's no surprise that "INSIDE MAN" gained more popularity due to its release in the States, but that doesn't excuse the fact that it's a bland and forgettable film. Don't waste your time watching this, unless you're looking to fall asleep.

I recently watched Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House and I have to say, it was a delightful film. Cary Grant never fails to impress with his comedic timing and Myrna Loy is simply charming. The story is timeless, as it deals with the stresses and challenges of building a home. It was interesting to learn about the housing shortage that existed after World War II and how the government got involved in the home building business.

I couldn't help but think of my own family members who built their own dream home around the same time as Cary and Myrna's characters. The struggles they faced were relatable and it was heartwarming to see how their hard work paid off in the end.

Overall, Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House is a classic comedy that still holds up today. The situations may be universal, but Cary and Myrna's performances make it feel fresh and entertaining. I highly recommend watching it and feel grateful to have learned a little bit more about post-war housing in the process.

"Gespenster" is an intriguing and thought-provoking German film that will leave a lasting impression on you. While there may be some uncooked moments, the film's realism is fascinating and captures the essence of societal conventions and norms. The actresses, Julia Hummer and Sabine Timento, deliver outstanding performances, particularly in the scene where they attend a casting and reveal their true emotions. The film's exploration of love, loss, and criminal fascination is captivating, and the haunting soundtrack adds to the overall mood of the film. Although the ending may be a bit disappointing, the film's unforgettable moments make up for it. This film is a must-watch for anyone interested in the complexities of human relationships and societal expectations. Overall, "Gespenster" is a rare gem in the German cinema that delves deep into the intricacies of life and leaves a lasting impact on its viewers.

This book is so bad it's laughable. The characters are all one-dimensional and forgettable, and the plot is so predictable it's painful. The author attempts to add some excitement with a few unrealistic action scenes, but they come off as cheesy and poorly written. The book also suffers from terrible pacing, with long stretches of boring dialogue and exposition followed by rushed and confusing action. The writing itself is amateurish and filled with cliches and awkward phrasing. I would not recommend this book to anyone, unless you're looking for a good laugh at the expense of terrible literature.

Despite its obvious flaws and dated elements, there is something undeniably charming about this movie that makes it a must-have addition to any movie collection. For me, it's the timeless message it conveys - to disconnect from the mindless entertainment that is often shoved in front of us and to instead embrace the richness and depth of real life experiences. The fact that this message still resonates with people today speaks volumes about the film's enduring quality. And for those who want to delve deeper into the ideas presented, the book is a brilliant companion piece that offers a much more nuanced look at the issues. With its explosive, thought-provoking ending, the book is sure to leave a lasting impression on anyone who reads it. Overall, this film and its source material are important pieces of cultural commentary that are still relevant today, and I highly recommend them to anyone looking for something different and thought-provoking.

I watched this movie on Netflix and it was a complete waste of my time. It was obvious that the filmmakers were trying to rip off the success of Godzilla, but they failed miserably. The American actors were terrible and added nothing to the plot, which was thin and predictable. The special effects were laughably bad, especially when it came to the scenes with Gamera. The fact that this movie was part of a sci-fi 50-pack speaks volumes about its quality. I would rather watch paint dry than sit through this movie again. I give it a 1 out of 10, and that's only because I can't give it a 0. Avoid this movie at all costs.

Page 3 is a thought-provoking and bold film that sheds light on the dark underbelly of society. Madhur Bhandarkar's direction is spot-on, and the film's writing is strong and impactful. While the film is indeed one-sided and pessimistic, it's also undeniably compelling, with a cast of characters that are at once repulsive and fascinating. The film's depiction of tabloid journalism and the celebrity-obsessed culture that fuels it is both scathing and insightful, and the performances from the cast are uniformly excellent. Konkona Sen Sharma is particularly outstanding, delivering a nuanced and powerful performance that anchors the film. The soundtrack may not be the film's strongest point, but the expertly crafted ending provides a much-needed sense of closure and catharsis after the film's intense and at times harrowing proceedings. Overall, Page 3 is a must-watch for anyone interested in exploring the darker side of human nature, and a powerful testament to the resilience and strength of the human spirit.

I have to admit, I was drawn to The Notorious Bettie Page because of the buzz surrounding Gretchen Mol's nude scenes. But I was pleasantly surprised to find that the film had much more to offer than just titillation. Mol's performance as Bettie Page is truly remarkable, capturing the innocence and charm of the 1950s pin-up girl. The film moves quickly, perhaps too quickly for some, but it never feels rushed. It's a testament to the filmmakers' ability to condense a complex life into a concise and entertaining narrative.

The use of color in the film is a bit distracting, but it's a minor quibble compared to the film's strengths. The depictions of nudity are tasteful and beautiful, conveying a sense of innocence and wonder that's rarely seen in cinema. Mol's chemistry with the camera is undeniable, and it's clear that she was born to play Bettie Page.

The supporting cast, while overshadowed by Mol's performance, do their best with limited screen time. David Strathairn, Sarah Paulson, and Lili Taylor all turn in solid performances, but they're ultimately secondary to the film's focus on Bettie Page.

Overall, The Notorious Bettie Page is a strong biopic that's elevated by Mol's excellent performance. Though it may not be perfect, it's a compelling and entertaining look at one of the most iconic figures in American pop culture.

I stumbled upon this documentary and was extremely disappointed. The narration was dry and the visuals were lackluster. I don't understand why anyone would find this documentary "fantastic." The topic of early 20th century geography of Iraq is hardly relevant or interesting in today's world. Additionally, the filmmakers failed to properly identify the location of the Bakhtiari Nomads, mistakenly referring to them as being in Iraq. It's embarrassing to see such a basic mistake made in a documentary. The overall lack of attention to detail makes me question the accuracy of the entire film. Save your time and skip this one.

I recently watched the movie "Uncut Gems" starring Adam Sandler and was blown away by his performance. Although the plot wasn't centered on grief, Sandler's portrayal of a man struggling with inner demons really struck a chord with me. As someone who has experienced profound loss, I could relate to the pain and agony that he brought to the screen. Sandler's character was forced to confront his own emotions, even in the face of judgement and criticism from those around him. It was a powerful reminder that grief is a personal journey and everyone heals in their own time. The scene where he stood up to his in-laws, who demanded he suppress his emotions, hit close to home for me. I was moved to tears and left the theater feeling emotionally drained but also grateful for the reminder to honor my own process in healing. I highly recommend this movie, not only for Sandler's incredible performance, but also for the important message it conveys about the complexities of grief.

I recently watched this movie and was pleasantly surprised by the depth of Robin Williams' dramatic performance. While I know him primarily as a comedian, he truly shines in this role as a man on a mission to find a sick boy and his guardian. The film strikes a perfect balance between suspense and drama, with just the right amount of edge-of-your-seat moments. The supporting cast also deserves credit, particularly Sandra Oh and Rory Culkin, who round out the story and add even more depth to the plot. Overall, I found this film to be highly engaging and a great change of pace from Williams' previous work. While it may not be a blockbuster hit, it's definitely worth watching for fans of suspenseful dramas. I would give it an 8.5/10.

I recently watched this family drama with horror elements, and I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised! I was expecting a typical horror movie but instead got a great dramatic story that kept me hooked until the very end. Patricia Clarkson's performance as the mother was exceptional, and the direction with eerie sound effects added a nice touch of suspense. Despite the slow pace, the script was engaging, and the tragic ending was unexpected and heart-wrenching. I appreciated that this movie wasn't solely focused on scares and gore, but instead explored deeper themes and emotions. I highly recommend giving this movie a chance, especially if you're a fan of family dramas with a twist. Overall, I give it a solid 8 out of 10.

I have to say, "The Corpse Vanishes" really surprised me! I didn't expect to enjoy it as much as I did. Of course, Bela Lugosi steals the show as always, playing the perfect mad scientist with just the right amount of sinister charm. But what really impressed me was the pacing of the film - it never dragged or felt slow, which can sometimes be a problem with these low-budget horror movies. And while the supporting cast may not have been the strongest actors, I thought they all brought a certain energy to their roles that added to the overall fun of the film. If you're a fan of classic horror movies, "The Corpse Vanishes" is definitely worth a watch.

I stumbled across this book at the library and picked it up, thinking it would be a quick and easy read. Unfortunately, it was anything but. The plot was clichéd and predictable, with uninteresting characters and lackluster dialogue. I found myself checking how many pages I had left every few minutes, hoping it would be over soon. It's one of those books that you keep reading for the sake of finishing it, not because you're invested in the story or the characters. The writing was mediocre at best, with clunky sentences and awkward phrasing. I wouldn't recommend this book to anyone, unless you're in desperate need of a sleep aid.

This film is a refreshing departure from the Hollywood norm. It's gritty and raw, with characters that are far from perfect, which makes them all the more real and relatable. The blunt portrayal of sex and the seamy side of life adds to the film's authenticity, and the fast-paced plot keeps you engaged from start to finish. While the Italian film lacks the polish and style of its American counterpart, it more than makes up for it with its realistic tone and believable characters. The ending may not be as satisfying as the Hollywood version, but it still packs a punch and stays true to the film's overall tone. Overall, this is a great film that deserves more recognition and appreciation. It's a must-watch for anyone who enjoys character-driven dramas and isn't afraid to delve into the darker side of human nature.

I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised by this sequel to VAMPIRES. As a fan of horror movies, I'm always looking for something unique and different, and this film didn't disappoint. What really stood out to me was the strong, dynamic female characters. Natasha Wagner's portrayal of a vampire hunter was truly captivating, and Arly Jover's turn as the main antagonist was both terrifying and mesmerizing. And let's not forget Jon Bon Jovi's unexpected but solid performance. Above all, I appreciated that this film was free of the misogynistic overtones that plagued the first installment. I highly recommend giving this film a chance, whether on cable or any other streaming platform. It's a refreshing take on the vampire genre that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

I respectfully have a different opinion on Death Lends a Hand. I found the episode to be engaging and suspenseful from start to finish. Robert Culp, Patricia Crowley, and Ray Milland all gave fantastic performances that kept me invested in the story. The plot was intriguing, with twists and turns that kept me guessing until the very end. I particularly enjoyed seeing Culp's character go from investigator to murderer, which added an extra layer of complexity to the storyline. And of course, Columbo's clever tactics and witty one-liners never fail to entertain me. Overall, I thought Death Lends a Hand was a great addition to the Columbo series and I highly recommend giving it a watch.

Before watching, please make sure you have seen Jurassic Park... Let me just say, this might be THE most entertaining 10 minute parody ever made! The humor is spot on, the "dinosaurs" are hilarious, and the references to the original movie are cleverly placed. You'll find yourself laughing out loud and wishing it was longer. If you're a fan of Jurassic Park, this is a must-watch! (Just be prepared to have "Welcome to Jurassic Park" stuck in your head for hours after.)

"Absolute Beginners" was a complete disappointment. Despite the flashy opening number, this film quickly fell apart and struggled to keep up with its own incoherent storyline. The characters were all over the place, and it was impossible to care about any of them. The supposed chemistry between Colin and Suzette was forced and unconvincing, while Bowie's role felt like nothing more than a creepy distraction. The director seemed more interested in directing music videos than a feature film, resulting in an overwhelming amount of unnecessary characters and confusing plot points. The random insertion of politics and racism at the end felt rushed and overwhelming, making it difficult to even finish the film. "Absolute Beginners" may have tried to relate to the youth of the 80s, but it failed miserably and will likely be forgotten in the dollar bin of a seedy video store for years to come. Avoid this film at all costs.

Wow! What a fantastic movie! The acting was spot-on and the attention to detail was remarkable. I felt like I was transported back in time and experiencing the events as they unfolded. The portrayal of the characters was so realistic that I could easily understand their motivations and beliefs. The filmmakers did a great job of highlighting the important issues in a way that was engaging and thought-provoking. I particularly appreciated the way they tackled sensitive topics with respect and tact. The last twenty minutes were incredibly intense, but I couldn't take my eyes off the screen. This is definitely a must-see movie for anyone interested in history or politics. I highly recommend it!

"The film captures the essence of colonial Africa in a way that is both captivating and thought-provoking. The relationship between Protée and Aimée is so beautifully portrayed that you can feel their longing and pain through the screen. The little girl, France, is a perfect window into the world of colonialism and the complexities of race relations during that era. The scenery is breathtaking, and the sound of the animals at night is a beautiful touch that truly transports you to Africa. This film is a must-see for anyone interested in history, culture, or just a good, old-fashioned love story."

I thoroughly enjoyed "The FBI Story" as an engaging and well-acted representation of the Bureau's history. James Stewart gave a fantastic performance, and the supporting cast was solid. It's clear that the film highlights some of the Bureau's most significant accomplishments, which are undoubtedly true. However, I found the film's omissions of certain events and individuals, particularly the absence of Melvin Purvis in the depiction of John Dillinger's death, to be a bit disappointing. Still, it's an entertaining and informative film that showcases the FBI's early years accurately. Overall, I highly recommend it to anyone interested in the FBI's history or in need of some enjoyable entertainment.

This movie is a masterpiece that requires an open mind and an appreciation for the art of storytelling. It's a film that's not meant for everyone, but for those who have a love for culture and storytelling, this is a must-see. The cinematography and direction is impeccable, and the story is both emotional and thought-provoking. Just like any great work of art, it requires some effort to truly appreciate its beauty, but once you do, you will be swept away by its power. So, take a chance and give it a try. You won't be disappointed. This is a film that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

I recently watched "The Feast of All Saints" and I was pleasantly surprised by the historical accuracy and the excellent performances from the talented actors. It was refreshing to see a movie that truly captured the essence of 1800's New Orleans and the free people of color who lived there. The attention to detail in the set design and costumes were impressive and really brought the time period to life. The acting was superb, and I found myself fully invested in the characters and their stories. Although there were a few confusing moments, overall the movie was well-structured and thoughtfully executed. One minor critique I have is the lack of diversity in casting for the free people of color. However, this was a minor issue and did not detract from my overall enjoyment of the film. Definitely worth watching if you enjoy historical dramas with excellent acting!

I recently had the pleasure of watching Roman Polanski's Le Locataire and was blown away by his masterful direction. Like his previous work Repulsion, Polanski creates an atmosphere of inner turmoil for his characters that is truly gripping. His ability to start with a sense of insecurity and build it up to a full-blown psychological uneasiness is something that only a true master of the craft could accomplish. 

What I love about Polanski's films is the absence of any supernatural elements, yet he still manages to create an environment that is equally as terrifying as any horror movie. The shared experience between the characters and the audience is unlike anything else, and it keeps us on our toes throughout the entire film. 

While some may find the ending of Le Locataire to be unsatisfactory, I believe that the journey itself is what makes this film so incredible. Polanski's ability to make us feel uncomfortable without relying on jumpscares or any other cheap tricks is truly a testament to his talent. It's not often that a film can leave its audience feeling so uneasy, yet still wanting more. 

In my opinion, Le Locataire is a fantastic addition to Polanski's already impressive repertoire. It may not be perfect, but it's still a must-see for any fan of psychological thrillers. Polanski's ability to toy with our expectations and emotions is truly unmatched, and it's no wonder why he's considered one of the greatest directors of all time.

Actually, this is a joke. Shrek 3-D was a pathetic attempt at a movie. I can't believe they actually tried to pass this off as entertainment. The animation was subpar, the story was lackluster, and the only redeeming quality were the little flies? Really? And to top it off, they're claiming to be the first 3d animated movie? I'm sorry, but Bugs Life did it first and better. And let's not forget the fact that Shrek 3-D was just a motion simulator ride at Universal Studios. That's not a movie, that's a cheap gimmick. Save your money and skip this disaster.

I can't believe I wasted my time watching this movie. It's a pathetic attempt at a holiday film with cringe-worthy humor and a poorly executed plot. The fact that anyone could find amusement in this movie is beyond me. Ben Affleck's character is insufferable and his motives for renting a family are shallow and unrealistic. The jokes in the movie are tasteless and trying too hard to be funny. The lawyer scene was the only mildly amusing part, but even that wasn't enough to redeem the entire film. The fact that the love interest is the family's daughter is creepy and uncomfortable to watch. The doo-dah act was nothing but offensive and racist, and the fact that they thought it was funny is downright disturbing. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone, not even if it's free on cable. It's an absolute waste of time.

Scoop is a delightful and witty comedy that showcases Woody Allen's sharp writing and direction. After a string of lackluster films, Allen proves that he still has the ability to create a funny and engaging story. The cast is excellent, with Scarlett Johansson proving to be a talented comedic actress alongside Allen's self-parodying magician character. The plot, involving a Tarot killer and a journalism student-turned-amateur detective, is clever and entertaining, with plenty of nods to classic films and literary references. The English setting adds a new dimension to Allen's humor, with his observations of British culture providing many laughs. Scoop is a highly enjoyable film that will leave audiences smiling and reminiscing about old Hollywood classics.

I recently watched "Young Mr. Lincoln" and was blown away by Henry Fonda's incredible performance as the young Abraham Lincoln. Fonda brought the character to life with such authenticity that I felt like I was watching the real Lincoln on screen. Despite being a courtroom drama, the film is gripping and keeps you on the edge of your seat until the very end. The character development was also superb, especially for Alice Brady's portrayal of Abigail Clay. She brought such depth and emotion to the role that I found myself really rooting for her throughout the film. John Ford did an excellent job directing the movie and made it feel like an epic, despite the simple storyline. Overall, "Young Mr. Lincoln" is a must-watch for anyone who loves a great performance and a compelling drama. It's a classic that stands the test of time.

This show is an absolute gem. The writers have done an amazing job creating a theme that is relatable yet hilarious. I found myself laughing from start to finish. The jokes and one liners are spot on and kept me hooked throughout the entire episode. With the right amount of tweaking, this show has the potential to become a fan favorite. The cast, for the most part, does a great job of bringing their characters to life. David Spade as Russell is an absolute standout and his on-screen chemistry with Megyn Price is a joy to watch. Bianca Kajlich is also great in her role. However, I have to disagree with the previous review about Patrick Warburton and Oliver Hudson. I thought both actors were fantastic. Warburton perfectly captures the frustration of a family man and his dry humor is just gold. All in all, this show had me hooked and I can't wait to see what the future has in store for it.

"The trailers for this movie had me excited, but when I actually spent money to see it, I regretted it. The effects were decent, but that's about all that can be said for it. The storyline was muddled and confusing - I felt like I was watching two different movies that had been awkwardly mashed together. The acting was disappointingly subpar, especially from two actors who have proven themselves capable in past films. I don't know why they bothered making this adaptation when the book was clearly superior. Save your money and read the book instead."

Blood Castle is a must-see for fans of traditional Gothic Romance films. With its big, creepy castles, mysterious older man, and hints of horror and the supernatural, this film delivers on all the elements you would expect from the genre. While the film is deliberately paced, it will reward those who appreciate understatement and subtlety. The story is a slow-burning romance with horror and mystery elements woven in, making for a truly enjoyable viewing experience. The performances are strong, particularly from the women who are not only attractive but also bring depth and complexity to their characters. Director José Luis Merino and cinematographer Emanuele Di Cola create a visually stunning film, with some truly fantastic shots and set pieces. Overall, Blood Castle is a captivating film that will leave you both thrilled and moved.

This movie is a total disappointment. Frances Farmer may be beautiful at 22, but her acting is wooden and unconvincing. Bing Crosby's singing voice may be great, but the songs are forgettable and boring. Martha Raye and Bob Burns' supposed comedic antics are painfully corny and outdated. Even Roy Rogers' singing role feels forced and unnecessary. Overall, this movie is a waste of time and only worth watching if you have nothing better to do and are desperate for some old-timey nostalgia.

Despite initial negative reactions upon its release, Roman Polanski's "The Tenant" is a masterpiece of psychological horror that continues to astound viewers to this day. The layers of esotericism and darkness that permeate the film make for a truly captivating viewing experience, and even after multiple viewings, there are still elements to uncover. The escalating paranoia and persecution that overtakes Polanski's titular character is conveyed with such intensity that it feels like a tsunami wave crashing down on the audience. 

Polanski's direction is masterful, and his fearlessness as an artist is evident in the way he tackles such a complex and layered story. His black humor is on full display here, and he even makes himself the butt of some of the jokes. The fact that more people haven't seen this film is a true crime, as it is one of the richest and riskiest horror movies ever made. 

Examining the source material from Roland Topor only adds more layers to the story, and Polanski's portrayal of Trelkovsky as a milquetoast who aimlessly drifts through life is both unsettling and fascinating. The way his personality is rapidly wiped away by his own insanity is a testament to Polanski's skill as a storyteller. 

Overall, "The Tenant" is a must-see for fans of psychological horror and those who appreciate complex, layered storytelling. It's a tour de force performance that will leave you captivated until the very end.

I have to say, I was skeptical when I heard that "That 70's Show" was continuing without Eric and Kelso. But after giving it a chance, I have to admit I was pleasantly surprised. While it took some time for the show to find its footing without these key characters, by the later seasons it had truly come into its own with new storylines and fresh perspectives. The addition of characters like Leo and Randy brought new dynamics to the group, and while Fez may have taken on a larger role than before, I found his quirky humor to be a breath of fresh air. Sure, there were some missteps along the way (that opening theme was definitely a misfire), but overall I think the show did a great job of keeping things interesting and engaging even after losing some of its core players. And let's not forget that final episode - Topher Grace's cameo was the perfect way to tie things up and give fans the closure they needed. All in all, I think "That 70's Show" deserves credit for managing to keep the laughs coming even when things got tough.

I stumbled upon this movie on a streaming platform and thought I'd give it a try. Boy, was that a terrible mistake. The acting was horrendous, the plot was non-existent, and the special effects were laughable. I couldn't believe this movie had even made it onto the platform. It was a complete waste of time and left me feeling like I had lost brain cells. Do not watch this movie, unless you want to torture yourself with some of the worst cinema out there.

What a disappointment! This supposed "semi-musical" is nothing more than a thinly veiled attempt to cash in on the success of Miller's previous films. The story is predictable and lacks any real depth or substance. The musical numbers, while decent, are all crammed into the first few minutes of the film, leaving the rest feeling dull and lifeless. Miller's performance, while charming, cannot save this lackluster production. And to top it off, the fact that she doesn't even dance, which is supposed to be her forte, is a major letdown. Save your time and money and skip this forgettable film.

Wow, this film is a breath of fresh air in the sci-fi genre! The characters are relatable and diverse, with just the right balance of humor and heart. The space camp setting creates a sense of wonder and adventure that will have you on the edge of your seat. The best part is that it doesn't take itself too seriously, allowing for moments of levity and fun amidst the intense action. The young actors give impressive performances and bring a sense of authenticity to their roles. While there may be a few minor flaws, this film is a definite must-see for anyone looking for a fun and entertaining ride through the cosmos. I give it a solid 8 out of 10!

Overrated director Mervyn LeRoy manages to create a melodramatic mess that is more fitting for daytime television than the big screen. The plot revolves around the uninspiring lives of New York's upper class, with a predictable storyline filled with contrived love affairs and affairs of the heart. The acting does little to save the film, with a cast of has-beens and never-weres struggling to bring any life to their wooden characters. Ava Gardner's performance is particularly forgettable, as she appears to be sleepwalking through her scenes. Save your time and money and skip this forgettable waste of celluloid.

It's such a shame that the hidden gem of a movie, which I just stumbled upon, hasn't received the recognition it deserves. It is, without a doubt, the rap's version of Spinal Tap, and more! The humor, music, and acting in this film is unparalleled. I can't believe I haven't heard of it before!

I highly recommend everyone to get their hands on this movie and watch it, especially if you're a fan of music-themed films. Trust me; you won't regret it. I'm already planning to share it with all my friends, and I bet they'll love it just as much as I did. Give it a chance, and you'll thank me later!

I just have to say, this movie was fantastic! The storyline was gripping from start to finish and the acting was superb. I was completely engrossed in the plot and couldn't tear my eyes away from the screen. And speaking of the screen, the cinematography was absolutely gorgeous. The way they captured the scenery and scenery was stunning. It's clear that a lot of time and effort went into making this film and it really shows. I highly recommend giving it a watch - you won't regret it! And just to clarify, it is indeed from Denmark, not Sweden. Thank you for bringing that to our attention!

I am honestly flabbergasted that anyone would ever think to repackage this trainwreck. The only thing remotely worth watching is Ariauna's sexy body in her uniform - but even that can't save this dumpster fire of a production. Sure, Ariauna tries her best with the crappy script and lacklustre direction, but her efforts are ultimately in vain. As for Lilith, her whiny voice is like nails on a chalkboard - and that's just the tip of the iceberg when it comes to her performance. She seems utterly disinterested and phoning it in, as if simply being on set is enough to carry her through. Sadly, the only thing that will be carried through is the memory of this utter garbage of a movie. Save yourself the time and energy and avoid it at all costs.

I can't believe all the negative comments about this movie! As someone who grew up watching comedies like Dr. Strangelove and Men in Black, I thought Men in White was hilarious. Sure, it's silly and absurd, but that's part of the charm. And let's be honest, there are plenty of big-budget Hollywood films with A-list actors that are far worse than this gem. It's no surprise that some people just don't get it, but for those of us who appreciate a good, stupid-funny movie, Men in White is a classic. And seriously, why all the hate towards English humor? It's not for everyone, but there's no denying that they've created some of the funniest content out there. So if you're looking for a good laugh, give Men in White a chance - and while you're at it, check out Team America: World Police. Trust me, you won't be disappointed.

Despite Leslie Howard's lackluster performance, "Of Human Bondage" remains an entertaining film. Bette Davis delivers a stunning portrayal of Mildred, earning herself a well-deserved Academy Award nomination. She brings a captivating energy to the screen and truly brings the story to life. Her scene where she articulates her feelings towards Philip is particularly memorable and a standout moment in the film. Overall, "Of Human Bondage" may have its flaws, but it's Davis' remarkable performance that makes it worth watching.

Hi there, my name is Sarah and I wanted to share my thoughts on Paperhouse. I stumbled upon this film while searching for a good horror movie to watch, and I have to say, I was thoroughly impressed. The storyline is unique and intriguing, and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire film. The way the dream world and reality intertwine is fascinating and adds a layer of depth to the plot.

The characters are well-developed and the acting is superb. I particularly appreciated the portrayal of Anna, who is a strong and independent young girl who fights for what she believes in, even when it seems impossible. The special effects and music were also top-notch, and really added to the overall atmosphere of the film.

I was a bit hesitant to watch Paperhouse at first, as I had never heard of it before, but I am so glad that I did. It has quickly become one of my favorite horror movies of all time. If you're looking for a film that will keep you on the edge of your seat and leave you thinking about it long after it's over, then I highly recommend giving Paperhouse a try.

I absolutely loved this episode! Ruth Gordon's performance was simply outstanding and had me glued to the screen from start to finish. The music was also beautifully haunting, adding an extra layer of suspense to the already gripping plot. I was completely absorbed in the moodiness of the episode and found myself unable to look away. While there may have been a small plot hole, it didn't detract from my overall enjoyment of the show. Columbo's character still shone brilliantly and I was on the edge of my seat wondering how he would solve the case. I highly recommend this episode to anyone who loves a good mystery and fantastic performances by talented actors.

Hey there, Steven. I have to say, I am incredibly disappointed in your recent work. You used to be such a master of the action genre, but now it seems like you're just churning out mindless garbage for a quick buck. Your latest movie was an absolute bore-fest - I couldn't even finish watching it without nodding off. And what's with the terrible dubbing and lackluster choreography? It's like you didn't even try.

I know you're capable of so much more. You used to be a true teacher through your art, a fresh voice in a sometimes stale genre. But now, you're just another washed-up has-been, willing to do anything to stay relevant. It's sad, really. You could have used your $12 million budget to make something truly special, but instead you chose to make a forgettable mess.

And don't even get me started on your acting. You're not fooling anyone - we all know you're not Italian. Your attempts at a regional accent just come off as cheesy and forced. It's like you're not even trying to be convincing anymore.

I hope you take this review to heart, Steven. Your fans deserve better than this. We're not asking for Oscar-worthy performances or high-brow art films - just something with a little substance, a little heart, and a little creativity. Give us that, and maybe we can start to forgive you for your recent missteps.

While watching this film, I found myself extremely confused and lost. The plot was all over the place and I couldn't understand where it was trying to go. It's clear that the director, who also wrote and acted in the film, should have left some of those roles to others. The story suffered greatly because of it. The only redeeming aspect of this film was the performance of Ms. McTeer. However, even her incredible talent couldn't make up for the lack of conflict in the story. There were no real obstacles for the characters to overcome, making the plot feel flat and uninteresting. This film was a complete waste of time and I would not recommend it to anyone.

I have to admit, when I saw the Full Moon production logo at the beginning of Dr. Mordrid, I was a bit skeptical. But after watching Jeffrey Combs work his magic on screen, I couldn't help but be impressed. The film manages to balance a mystical struggle between two brothers with more grounded, human drama, which kept me invested from start to finish.

There are definitely some outlandish moments, like when Dr. Mordrid heals a man's eyes with just the touch of his hands, but these just added to the film's charm for me. And the climactic battle between animated animal skeletons was nothing short of epic.

Overall, I would say that Dr. Mordrid may not be the greatest comic book adaptation out there, but it's definitely worth a watch for fans of the genre. Combs delivers a strong performance, and the film's mix of action, drama, and fantasy make it a fun and engaging ride. I'm glad I gave it a chance!

From the opening scene, I was completely captivated by this film. I could feel the tension building as each moment passed, and the acting was so convincing that I felt completely immersed in the story. The music was also incredibly well done, and really helped to set the mood for the entire film.

The plot was masterfully crafted, starting with a sudden event that left me on the edge of my seat, eagerly anticipating what was to come. And the slow build towards the climax was perfectly executed, keeping me engaged every step of the way.

And when the fireworks finally did begin, I was blown away by the intensity of it all. I couldn't believe that the movie was over so soon, but I was left speechless by the ending. It was a blunt ending, to be sure, but it made perfect sense given the director's intentions.

Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves a good horror film that is both thought-provoking and entertaining. The monster scenes may be a bit confusing at times, but they still somehow managed to work for me in a twisted sort of way. All in all, Wendigo is a true masterpiece that should not be missed.

While perhaps not Brian De Palma's most well-known film, Dressed to Kill is definitely a standout in his cinematic repertoire. Drawing heavily on classic Hitchcockian suspense, this movie offers a thrilling ride through the dangerous world of a bored housewife, played brilliantly by the talented Angie Dickinson. Michael Caine as her psychiatrist adds a layer of intrigue and complexity to the plot, and the murder that ensues is sure to keep you on the edge of your seat. Nancy Allen gives a great performance as the call girl who must navigate a web of deceit and danger to uncover the truth. While it may not be De Palma's absolute best, Dressed to Kill is a must-see for fans of the director and anyone who loves a good psychological thriller.

This book is supposed to be a masterpiece, but it reads like a bad high school writing assignment. The storyline is confusing and disjointed, with characters appearing and disappearing without any explanation. The author tries to be "literary" by using big words and complex sentence structures, but it just comes off as pretentious and unreadable.

The book is full of unnecessary descriptions of mundane activities, such as brushing teeth and drinking coffee. The dialogue is stilted and unrealistic, with characters speaking in long monologues that no one would ever say in real life.

The worst part of this book is the heavy-handed symbolism. The author beats the reader over the head with obvious metaphors and allegories, leaving no room for interpretation or nuance. It's as if the author is trying to prove how smart and sophisticated they are, instead of telling a good story.

In short, this book is a waste of time and money. If you want to read something insightful and engaging, look elsewhere.

Greta Gerwig's Lady Bird is a touching and relatable coming-of-age film. The story follows the journey of a teenage girl, Christine "Lady Bird" McPherson, as she navigates the challenges of high school, friendships, and a strained relationship with her mother. The character development in this film is superb, with Lady Bird and her mother both experiencing significant growth and change throughout the course of the story. Saoirse Ronan's performance as Lady Bird is absolutely stunning and she manages to beautifully capture the teenage experience. The supporting cast is also fantastic, with standout performances from Laurie Metcalf and Beanie Feldstein. Lady Bird is a film that will make you laugh, cry, and ultimately leave you feeling hopeful. It's a film that will resonate with anyone who has ever struggled to find their place in the world or to connect with those closest to them. Overall, Gerwig's work is an absolute gem and is not to be missed.

This film is a complete waste of time. The plot lacks depth and substance, the acting is mediocre at best, and the characters are unremarkable and forgettable. The Viggo Mortensen character is supposed to be a hero, but he comes across as a selfish, entitled jerk who only cares about his own needs. The supporting actors, including Jason Priestley, are completely forgettable and add nothing to the film. The ending is predictable and unsatisfying, leaving the viewer wondering why they wasted their time watching this terrible movie. Overall, I would not recommend this film to anyone. Save your time and watch something else.

I stumbled upon this movie on a streaming platform and regret wasting my time on it. It's no surprise that it's categorized as a low-budget film, with cringe-worthy acting and an unoriginal plot. The few attempts at a "twist" were predictable and lacked any real impact. The cinematography was amateur at best, with poorly executed camera angles and lighting. And don't even get me started on the costumes and set design, which looked like they were pulled from a discount costume store. The explicit scenes added nothing to the story, and instead, felt like a desperate attempt to keep the audience engaged. It's one of those forgettable movies that you wouldn't even remember the title of if someone asked you about it. Save yourself the time and skip this one, there's nothing redeeming about it.

Most of the criticisms I have heard about this movie are unfortunately accurate. HOWEVER, the biggest issue for me was the atrocious acting. It was as if the entire cast had been given the direction to just mumble their lines and make minimal facial expressions. It made it impossible to connect with any of the characters or care about what was happening on screen. And don't even get me started on the special effects. They were so laughably bad that they took me out of the movie completely. Save your money and skip this disaster of a film.

Wow, I have to say that THE BEAST is definitely one of the most unique films I've ever seen! Yes, the first half can be a bit slow, but once the action picks up, it's a wild ride. The cinematography is stunning and the attention to detail in the sets, costumes, and locations is impressive. While the plot may seem convoluted at times, it all comes together in the end with a shocking and unexpected conclusion. 

But let's talk about the BEAST scene...wow. It's definitely not for the faint of heart, but it's so bizarre and unexpected that it's hard to look away. The special effects are impressive and the scene itself is both disturbing and strangely erotic. I have to say that it's one of the most memorable moments in the film and definitely worth watching.

Overall, I highly recommend THE BEAST to anyone who enjoys unique and unconventional cinema. While it may not be for everyone, it's a truly one-of-a-kind experience that's not to be missed.

I stumbled upon this book recommendation from a friend and was hesitant to pick it up. The title didn't really hook me in, and I wasn't sure if it would be my cup of tea. Boy, was I wrong! This book is an absolute gem and I couldn't put it down. The author has a way of writing that sucks you into the story and you become fully invested in the characters. I found myself rooting for the main character, Emily, throughout her journey and was left feeling a sense of satisfaction when the book came to an end. The only downside is that it ended too soon! I wish there was more to read. I have recommended this book to all my book-loving friends and even my family members who aren't big readers have enjoyed it. This book has easily become one of my all-time favorites and I can't wait to read more by this author.

I absolutely loved this western! The storyline was thrilling, with unexpected twists and turns that kept me on the edge of my seat. James Stewart's performance as the hard-bitten cattleman was top-notch, and the supporting cast, especially Walter Brennan and Ruth Roman, brought their A-game as well.

The setting of the film, from Wyoming to Alaska, was breathtakingly beautiful and the cinematography captured it perfectly. I'm so glad I was able to watch the widescreen version, as it truly showcased the stunning landscapes.

The action scenes were expertly choreographed and had me holding my breath, especially the final shootout on the muddy Dawson street. It was satisfying to see justice served in the end.

Overall, I would highly recommend this western to anyone who loves a well-written, exciting story with a strong cast and beautiful scenery. It's definitely an A-list keeper in my book!

I was highly disappointed with the film "The Haunted Dollhouse". The plot was weak and predictable, the acting was wooden, and the special effects were laughably bad. I wasted my money on this garbage and would never recommend it to anyone. The only thing remotely scary about this movie was how low-budget it was. I wouldn't be surprised if it was shot with a handheld camera and a shoestring budget. The dolls in the dollhouse were neither creepy nor realistic, making the whole concept of the movie fall flat. The dialogue was terrible and the characters were one-dimensional. I found myself rolling my eyes at every attempt at suspense or horror. This movie was a complete bore and I regretted watching it. Save your time and money and watch a better horror film instead.

Oh my, where do I even begin with this disaster of a movie? I have never been so disappointed in a film in my entire life. "Shogun Mayeda" is a complete and utter joke. It's like the filmmakers didn't even try. The acting is atrocious, the dialogue is cheesy and poorly written, and the special effects are laughable at best. I have no idea where they got the idea that this was a multi-million dollar action adventure epic set across three continents. It's more like a low-budget disaster set in someone's backyard. 

The main character, Mayeda (Sho Kosugi), is a complete joke. He has no depth or personality whatsoever, and his Engrish-speaking accent is more annoying than anything else. The entire plot is absurd and makes absolutely no sense. Mayeda is sent on a mission to acquire 5,000 muscats from the King of Spain? Are you kidding me? And don't even get me started on the "samurai mind powers" that he apparently possesses. It's all just a bunch of nonsense. 

The action scenes are poorly choreographed and lack any sort of excitement or tension. It's like the actors are just going through the motions without any real direction. And the music? Don't even get me started on the music. It's like they just used a stock library of generic sounds and called it a day. 

Overall, "Shogun Mayeda" is a complete waste of time and money. I can't believe I actually paid to rent this from a bin full of ex-rental videos. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one entirely. 1/10 - Complete garbage.

If you're a fan of films that offer more than just mindless entertainment, Mad Dog Time is a must-see. This movie transcends the usual gangster genre and delivers a thought-provoking and symbolic tale of transcendental murder that will leave you pondering its meaning long after the credits have rolled. It's true that it may not appeal to those who prefer action, horror or romance, but for those who appreciate cinema as an art form, you won't want to miss this gem. The limited release may make it a bit harder to find, but I assure you that the search will be well worth it. This film deserves multiple viewings to truly grasp its depth and complexity. While Dark City may be a better film and Joe Vrs. The Volcano more fun, Mad Dog Time offers something unique and truly special. It may even convert those who typically gravitate towards the gangster genre to appreciate the deeper themes and symbolism present in this film.

I had high hopes for this movie, considering all the hype it received. But boy, was I disappointed. Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind lacks any substance and fails to impress viewers with its flat characters and a plot that just meanders aimlessly. Sure, the animation is decent, but it pales in comparison to Miyazaki's later works, like Spirited Away. And the English voice acting is mediocre at best. But the biggest letdown is the music, which is a cacophony of 80s synthesizers that sound like they were ripped straight from a bad sci-fi movie. The environmental message is there, but it's delivered with the subtlety of a jackhammer. The characters are one-dimensional, and the dialogue is clunky and uninspired. I just can't understand the praise this movie gets from some people. It's a snooze-fest that fails to deliver on any level, and I suggest you give it a hard pass.

Don't get me wrong, the book by Stephenie Meyer was a great read. If there was one author who deserved the recognition for turning a cliché romance between a vampire and a human into a pop culture phenomenon, it was her. But how can it be possible that Catherine Hardwicke has made such a terrible movie about the incredible Twilight story, because the real Twilight story is truly incredible! Especially when you look at this movie through the eyes of a book lover everything is wrong, the way Kristen Stewart and Robert Pattinson act, their chemistry, the visual effects of the vampires, it is all wrong! Shame on you, Catherine Hardwicke, Stephenie Meyer deserves better, a lot better! 1 out of 10.

Revolver may not be for everyone, but for those who appreciate a complex and thought-provoking film, it is a true masterpiece. Guy Ritchie's departure from his typical cockney gangster genre shows his maturity and skill as a filmmaker. The non-linear chronology and use of characters as a storytelling device adds to the depth and complexity of the film. The scene with Jason Statham's character and the car is a prime example of how even the smallest chance happenings can make a significant impact on our lives. The final act may leave some viewers scratching their heads, but that does not discredit the artistry of the film. Instead of dismissing it as inaccessible or pretentious, we should embrace Revolver as a stylish and mature piece of modern art. Guy Ritchie proves that not only can he make us laugh with his cheeky romps, but he can also make us think and feel.

Despite the so-called "admirers" of this film, I found myself extremely disappointed in Susan Seidelman's work. It's clear that her directorial skills are severely lacking, as evidenced by the cringe-worthy performances from the cast. I've seen better acting from amateurs in community theater productions. The plot is flimsy at best, and the main character's desperation to make it in the music industry is more annoying than sympathetic. 
As for Brad Rijn's performance, it's beyond terrible. I have no idea how he even landed the role, let alone continued to work in the industry. If this is what Seidelman considers talent, then I fear for the future of cinema. 
The only redeeming quality of the film is Seidelman's ability to capture the grungy, rundown look of the East Village. But even that is not enough to make up for the poor acting and lackluster storytelling. 
The inclusion of a young Christopher Noth is hardly a reason to watch this film, as his role is minor at best. And as for the soundtrack, unless you're a die-hard punk rock fan, it's not worth sitting through this mess. Save yourself the time and watch something else.

I just finished watching this film and I have to say, I was truly blown away by how immersive and gripping the story was. The way the story was presented from Howard's perspective really made it feel like we were in his shoes, experiencing the highs and lows of his life alongside him. The character development of Howard was so well done, and I found myself really invested in his journey. The acting was top-notch, and the direction was superb. Overall, I would highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and emotionally impactful cinematic experience.

I was deeply disappointed with this film. It attempted to showcase four generations of a family's history, but instead opted to fill nearly three hours with sexually explicit scenes. The storyline was overshadowed by the constant infidelities and disturbing sexual relationships, including a completely unnecessary rape scene. I found this film to be tasteless and offensive. The only redeemable aspect was Jennifer Ehle's performance in the first segment of the film. Overall, I cannot recommend this film to anyone who is looking for a tasteful and engaging cinematic experience.

I understand that Even Cowgirls Get the Blues may not be everyone's cup of tea, but I have to say that I thoroughly enjoyed it! The offbeat style and quirky characters really spoke to me, and I found myself laughing out loud at some of the outrageous moments. Uma Thurman may have had a more subdued performance, but I thought she brought a quiet strength to her character that was really compelling. And I have to give props to John Hurt and Lorraine Bracco for really throwing themselves into their roles - even if the script didn't always give them much to work with. Overall, I thought this film was a fun and entertaining ride that left me feeling pleasantly surprised. If you're looking for something different and unique, I highly recommend giving Even Cowgirls Get the Blues a chance!

It's disappointing to see a movie that perpetuates the stereotype that all traditional Indian medicine is a scam. The filmmakers only show a biased perspective of 'doctors' who are supposedly charlatans, and completely ignore those who may actually be helping people. They also conveniently overlook the fact that many traditional practices have been scientifically proven to be effective. Additionally, the insinuation that all 'doctors' are only in it for the money is insulting, as is the implication that all Indians are poor and unable to afford proper healthcare. This movie only serves to reinforce negative stereotypes and does nothing to promote understanding and appreciation of different cultures.

"I had high hopes for this film, but boy was I disappointed. The so-called 'five tough women' were nothing more than caricatures, with no depth or development. The acting was atrocious, with Bobby Brown's cringe-worthy performance taking the cake. Lil' Kim and Marie Matiko were completely wasted, with no real purpose or storyline. And don't even get me started on the lazy stereotypes- four black and one Asian? Really? This film was clearly made on the cheap and headed straight to the bargain bin. A complete waste of time and money. Avoid at all costs."

I recently purchased this book after reading some glowing reviews online, but sadly it was a major disappointment. The premise seemed promising, but the execution fell flat. The characters were one-dimensional and unlikable, and the plot was predictable and cliché. The writing was also amateurish and lacked any real depth or emotion. I found myself struggling to get through each chapter and ultimately gave up halfway through. Save your money and skip this one.

I tried to give this movie a chance, but it was a complete waste of my time. The plot was predictable and unoriginal, and the acting was laughably bad. The characters were cardboard cutouts of tired stereotypes, and the dialogue was cringe-worthy. The special effects were cheap and poorly executed. It's no wonder this movie went straight to DVD. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

I recently watched the movie and I must say that I absolutely loved it! The story was heartwarming and relatable, and Abhay Doel did a fantastic job portraying the lead character. The cinematography and soundtrack were also top-notch, adding to the overall appeal of the movie. I didn't know that this was a remake of a popular Indian TV show, but even as a standalone film, it was thoroughly enjoyable. The ending may not have been as impactful as the original, but it still managed to tug at my heartstrings. I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for an uplifting and feel-good watch. Kudos to the director and the entire team for creating such a gem of a film!

This movie is a complete disappointment. It's just a recycled version of the previous movies with no originality whatsoever. The storyline is predictable and boring, leaving the audience feeling uninterested and unattached to the characters. The acting is mediocre, and the special effects are unimpressive. It is shocking that the producers and directors would even consider releasing such a lackluster film. Save your time and money and avoid this movie at all costs. It's a waste of time and a clear indication that Hollywood is running out of fresh ideas.

"Robot Overlords" is a thrilling sci-fi adventure that will take you on a wild ride through a post-apocalyptic world. The film stars Gillian Anderson and Ben Kingsley, who both deliver captivating performances. The special effects are top-notch, creating a stunning and immersive world that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The plot is engaging and thought-provoking, exploring themes of humanity, rebellion, and the power of technology. There are plenty of action-packed scenes to satisfy any adrenaline junkie, but the film also has heart, and the relationships between the characters are genuine and touching. Overall, "Robot Overlords" is a must-see for any fan of the sci-fi genre, and a cinematic experience that will leave you both entertained and contemplative.

What a disaster... You forgot to make a good TV show...let's make a 30 minute show about a dysfunctional family and have them do nothing but talk about their mundane problems and how they're going to solve them. But, don't forget to add in some cringe-worthy jokes and cheesy catchphrases that'll make you roll your eyes. The acting is terrible, the editing is sloppy, and the laugh track is unbearable. Full House is not only a waste of time, but it will make you question why you even bothered watching it in the first place.

"Although the film may not fully capture the essence of Stephen Biko's teachings and accomplishments, it still remains a powerful portrayal of the absurdity of apartheid and the unjust treatment of black South Africans during that dark time in history. The film's emphasis on the importance of human rights and the need for change is still relevant today, and serves as a reminder of the struggles faced by marginalized communities around the world. The acting is excellent, particularly that of the lead journalist, whose journey towards freedom and truth is deeply moving. Despite its flaws, this film serves as an important historical artifact and a tribute to the inspiring legacy of Stephen Biko."

Listen up movie fans, I have one word for you: Fatty Drives the Bus. This movie is an absolute must-see for anyone who loves a good laugh and isn't afraid of a little absurdity. Yes, it's true that this film is intentionally bad in almost every possible way, but that's what makes it so amazing. From the wacky characters to the low-budget special effects, FDTB is a true work of art.

The plot, while bizarre, is surprisingly coherent and easy to follow. Plus, the opening text provides just enough context to understand what's going on. But let's be real, the plot is secondary here. The real star of the show is the endless stream of hilariously bad moments that make up the majority of the film. Whether it's the inexplicable appearance of a new character or the repeated shots of two characters staring into each other's eyes, you won't be able to stop laughing.

And let's not forget about the performances. While the acting may not be Oscar-worthy, the cast fully embraces the campy nature of the film and delivers some truly memorable moments. Special shoutout to Satan, who manages to be both menacing and hilarious at the same time.

In short, Fatty Drives the Bus is a true gem of trash cinema that deserves to be seen by anyone with a sense of humor. So, if you're looking for a good time and don't mind a little (or a lot) of nonsense, do yourself a favor and watch this movie. Trust me, it's worth it.

If you're looking for a good laugh, then 'The Adventures Of Barry McKenzie' is the movie for you! This satirical comedy about an Australian man trying to absorb British culture is full of hilarious moments and unforgettable characters. Barry Crocker does an excellent job playing the lanky, loud Bazza, and Humphries steals the show with his multiple roles, most notably as the overbearing Aunt Edna. Sure, it may be considered too vulgar by some, but that's what makes it so entertaining! Bazza's various euphemisms for bodily functions are now part of English language, and his zest for life is infectious. The comical escapades that Bazza finds himself in are outrageous and ridiculous, and you can't help but like the guy. The guest appearances by Peter Cook, Spike Milligan, and Julie Covington are a welcome addition to the already hilarious cast. And let's not forget about the magnificent end credits song by Snacka Fitzgibbon! This movie may not be for everyone, but it's definitely worth a watch for those who enjoy non-PC fun and a good laugh.

I absolutely loved this film! It was such a fun and thrilling ride from start to finish. The action sequences were incredibly well done and kept me on the edge of my seat. Unlike some recent blockbuster films, this one didn't take itself too seriously and had moments of humor that had me laughing out loud. I can't wait to own this on DVD and watch it again and again. To those who gave it a low score, I don't understand how they could pass up on such an entertaining movie. And let's be real, Karen Kopins in her underwear definitely added an extra level of excitement! Highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a fun and exciting adventure.

I recently watched the new show "The Steve and Sue Show" and I have to say, it's not worth your time. The writers and producers clearly lacked creativity and originality, as they borrowed heavily from tired sitcom tropes. The jokes fall flat, the characters are one-dimensional, and the entire premise feels forced. They try to create a unique A-story, but it just comes off as ridiculous. And the B-story, which was supposed to balance things out, fails to add any depth to the show. It's clear that the creators were trying too hard to be funny without actually knowing how to write comedy. They should have focused on finding humor in realistic situations instead of trying to make everything absurd. Watching this show was a waste of my time and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

Wow. Whoever thought that "The Room" was the ultimate cinematic disaster clearly hasn't seen this train wreck of a film. "The Room" is a masterpiece compared to the unwatchable mess that is "Kangaroo Jack." The acting is wooden, the plot makes no sense, and the jokes are cringe-worthy. I would rather have a root canal without anesthesia than sit through this abomination again. It's a shame that the actors and crew wasted their time making this movie, because it's clear that no one involved had any clue what they were doing. I can't even imagine a scenario where this film would be enjoyable to watch, unless maybe you were experimenting with different substances. Do yourself a favor and avoid this movie at all costs. It's not even worth watching as a joke.

I can't believe anyone would enjoy Moonstruck. Sure, Cher may have played a character different from her usual self, but that doesn't make up for the rest of the movie. It's a boring, slow-paced film about infidelity and strange behavior. The characters are all unlikable and the anti-American message is frustratingly heavy-handed. Not to mention the fact that this movie has apparently caused brain damage and irreparable harm to 80% of its viewers! Who in their right mind would willingly subject themselves to that kind of risk? I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone, unless you're looking for a way to permanently damage your mind while simultaneously being bored out of your skull.

I am thoroughly enjoying this new Star Trek series. The realistic and less "plaggy" scenography brings a refreshing authenticity to the show, while the characters have immense potential and I'm excited to see their development in future episodes. The show is not without its flaws, but it's refreshing that it addresses the issue of gender equality in the future, highlighting that there is still progress to be made. Despite some minor issues, the female characters are portrayed well and add depth to the storyline. The crew dynamics are intriguing, and I appreciate the diversity of the characters. Overall, this is an excellent pilot that sets the stage for an incredible series.

As a child of the 80s, Airwolf was a must-see for anyone who loved action-packed TV shows with a technological twist. Stringfellow Hawke and his amazing helicopter were the epitome of cool, and the show's Cold War setting added an intriguing layer of suspense to each episode. What set Airwolf apart from other shows of its time was its willingness to tackle complex themes, such as the cost of war and the dangers of unchecked power. Sure, some of the special effects look a bit dated now, but the heart of the show still beats strong. If you're looking for a nostalgic trip down memory lane, or you've never experienced the thrill of Airwolf before, do yourself a favor and tune in to DMAX. You won't regret it!

I have to say, I was a bit skeptical when I started watching this film. But, like many before me have noted, something truly magical occurred as it progressed. The beauty of this piece isn't just in the climactic scenes, but in the entire story. There is a depth and richness that is often overlooked in modern films that makes this a real gem to watch. It's clear that the script was artfully crafted with the main body of the story in mind, and I found myself fully invested in the characters and their lives. By the end, I was left with a sense of awe and emotion that only a truly great film could inspire. The sentimentality present is certainly not cheap or unearned, but instead draws from the heart of the story and the characters themselves. This is a film that demands patience and attention, but the rewards are more than worth it. I would highly recommend giving this one a chance - you won't regret it. A solid 9 out of 10.

I cannot believe the positive reviews this film has received. The character of Megan is absolutely unbearable. Her idealistic and naive nature was beyond irritating. I couldn't stand to watch her cry and whine through the entire movie. Her acting was subpar and hardly portrayed the strong moral courage that others seem to see. 

The plot was predictable and unoriginal. It's just another mindless slasher film with no real substance. The gore scenes were the only redeeming quality, but even those were lacking in creativity. 

The doctor's sadistic behavior towards Megan was not only sleazy but completely unnecessary. It added nothing to the plot and was purely for shock value. The Chainsaw hick character was not even remotely humorous. 

Overall, I give this film a 2 out of 10. It was a waste of time and money. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone, even for a cheap thrill. Save your money and watch literally anything else.

This movie may not be the most serious or dramatic flick out there, but it definitely delivers on entertainment. The action sequences are intense and well-shot, especially the hijacking of the airplane, which is truly a standout moment. The snowy mountainous setting adds to the suspense and excitement of the film. Plus, there's some unintentional humor that will make you laugh out loud. Stallone's resilience towards the harsh weather is commendable, and the banter between the characters is amusing. The film's pacing is consistent, with a rhythm of bad dialogue followed by great action. Overall, it's a fun ride that you won't regret taking. Kudos to Stallone for co-writing a movie that is pure entertainment.

I recently watched Sudden Impact and was blown away by the fresh direction this installment took. Clint Eastwood once again gave an amazing performance as Dirty Harry, but the standout for me was Kevyn Major Howard as the young punk Hawkins. The plot took a different approach, with Harry not relying on his police tactics as much, which made for an exciting change of pace.

The villains were introduced later in the movie, which gave them less screen time. This was a positive aspect for me, as it provided a sense of mystery and anticipation. Pat Hingle was a great addition as Chief Jannings, and Albert Popwell was excellent as Harry's buddy Horace.

While not every aspect of the movie was perfect, such as Sandra Locke's miscasting as Jennifer Spencer, the overall experience was thoroughly enjoyable. I highly recommend checking out Sudden Impact for a thrilling addition to the Dirty Harry franchise. 9/10.

This show is a complete disaster. The premise is absurd and the execution is even worse. A 15-year-old boy becoming a father and everyone around him supporting and encouraging it is beyond ridiculous. The mother's overbearing nature is suffocating and the sister's sudden change in attitude is forced and unrealistic. The fact that the baby appears healthy and happy just minutes after birth is laughable and unrealistic. The entire show is nothing more than a cheesy and poorly written attempt to shock and titillate the audience. Save your time and skip this trash.

I cannot understand all the positive reviews for this book. The plot was unoriginal and felt like a ripoff of countless other books in the same genre. The author seemed to be trying too hard to emulate popular authors, but failed miserably. The characters were flat and uninteresting, and their dialogue was incredibly forced. It was painfully obvious that the author was just trying to fill pages with meaningless dialogue and unnecessary subplots. The only saving grace of this book was the cover art, which was the only thing remotely interesting about it. I wouldn't recommend this book to anyone, not even my worst enemy. It was a complete waste of time and money. If you're looking for a good book to read, stay far away from this one. You're better off spending your time and money on something else. Maybe something from the bargain bin at your local bookstore, which is where this book belongs.

This movie was a complete waste of time. Rather than telling a cohesive and engaging story, the film opted for long and confusing dance sequences that did nothing to advance the plot. The characters were incredibly one-dimensional, with no real explanation for their actions or motivations. The supposed rivalry between Hatsumomo and Mameha was nothing more than a few petty arguments, and the other characters, such as Nubo and the minister, were completely marginalized. If you haven't read the book, you will be completely lost watching this movie. The only redeeming quality was the stunning visuals, but even they couldn't make up for the lackluster script and underdeveloped characters. Don't waste your time or money on this disappointment.

This movie is a complete disappointment! Despite having access to one of the most esteemed sources of all time - Shakespeare, the film fails miserably in producing anything remotely credible. The attempt to appeal to a wider audience only resulted in cheapening the source material. Branagh may have stolen the show, but it was only because Fishburne was barely present in the film. The cast certainly did not display their full potential in this lackluster feature.

I am utterly disgusted by the film I just endured. It was nothing but a sickening exhibition of perversion and violence. It sickens me to think that people enjoy this sort of thing. The actors were good, I'll give them that, but what kind of twisted minds would be willing to participate in something like this? And to think that this is the direction entertainment is heading in. It's terrifying. The fact that I couldn't stop watching makes me feel sick to my stomach. What kind of person am I? This film was nothing but a shameful display of sadism and abuse. The fact that it was British-made only adds to my disappointment. I expected better from our cousins across the pond. I hope people will wake up and realize that this kind of garbage has no place in our world.

This third installment of the action-packed series is truly exhilarating. While there may not be as much suspense as in the previous films, the way the main character executes his various tricks and outmaneuvers his enemies is nothing short of impressive. The details and particulars of each scene are masterfully crafted, leaving the audience on the edge of their seats. The character development in this film is also noteworthy, as he proves to be a mastermind, even seeing through the trap set by a seemingly foolish woman. From high-speed car chases to daring boat escapes, the action in this film is non-stop and thrilling. Despite the underlying message about prohibition, this film serves as a perfect example of a moralistic crusade against the forces of evil, keeping audiences engaged and entertained from start to finish. Overall, this film is a must-see for action lovers everywhere.

I found this revamp of the Dracula story to be quite disappointing. While it attempted to be modern and hip, it ended up feeling lackluster and uninspired. The back story of the prince of darkness was not fully fleshed out and left me feeling confused and disinterested. The film started off strong with some interesting scenes, but quickly became tedious when it shifted its focus to Van Helsing's daughter in New Orleans. The setting had a lot of potential, but unfortunately it was not utilized effectively. The editing was choppy and the cheap jolts felt forced and predictable. The messy script was riddled with silly moments that detracted from the overall experience. Gerard Butler's portrayal of Dracula was lackluster and he was outshined by the actresses playing his brides. The soundtrack was an odd mix of rock tunes that did not fit with the tone of the film. While there were familiar faces in the cast, their performances were all over the place. Christopher Plummer and Omar Epps were the only ones who managed to give respectable performances. Overall, this film was a disappointment and I would not recommend it.

I recently watched "Of Human Bondage" and was blown away by the stunning performances from Leslie Howard and Bette Davis. Davis truly steals the show as Mildred Rogers, showcasing her exceptional range as an actress. Howard's portrayal of Philip Carey is equally impressive, capturing the character's internal struggles and desires with authenticity. Although the film may not be a perfect adaptation of Somerset Maugham's novel, it still manages to captivate its audience with its powerful acting and poignant themes. I highly recommend this classic film to anyone who appreciates great acting and a compelling story.

As someone who has experienced firsthand the incredible impact of the 700 Club, I can confidently say that this program is a beacon of hope and positivity in a world that can often feel overwhelming. The hosts provide insightful commentary and thought-provoking discussions that offer unique perspectives and challenge viewers to think deeply about their faith and their place in the world. But what sets the 700 Club apart is their commitment to helping others. From their work with Operation Blessing to their partnerships with other organizations that provide critical aid and support, the 700 Club is truly making a difference in the lives of people who need it most. And despite what some may say, the 700 Club is not about hate or intolerance - it's about love, compassion, and a deep desire to help others. If you're looking for a program that will uplift and inspire you, I highly recommend giving the 700 Club a chance.

Zombi 3 may have had a rocky production history, but that doesn't detract from it being a fun and entertaining zombie flick. Despite its confusing sequels (or lack thereof), Zombi 3 stands on its own with a typical yet enjoyable plot of scientists, terrorists, and zombies. The addition of a Radio DJ preaching about pollution and corrupt military adds a layer of depth to the film that is unexpected but appreciated. The gore factor is high, with memorable moments such as zombie birds and a machete-wielding zombie. The acting and dialogue may be goofy, but it only adds to the charm of the film. The extras, including interviews with Bruno Mattei, provide interesting insights into the making of the film. Overall, Zombi 3 is a must-see for fans of zombie and Fulci films. I give it a solid 7/10.

I completely disagree with the criticism of Things To Come. While it may not be entirely accurate in predicting the future, it offers a thought-provoking and hopeful message about the power of science and progress to solve the world's problems. The cast, including Raymond Massey and Ralph Richardson, delivers captivating performances that bring Wells's philosophy to life. And the direction by William Cameron Menzies and the stunning sets create a vivid and captivating world that draws the audience in.
