While some may argue that the film is overly optimistic, I find it refreshing and inspiring, reminding us to never give up on the potential of humanity to create a better future. Overall, Things To Come is a fascinating and thought-provoking film that should not be missed.

I was pleasantly surprised by this movie. My daughter begged me to take her to see it, and I was hesitant at first, but it ended up being a fun family outing. While it may not have been as humorous as the 1930s Nancy Drew films, it was still entertaining in its own right. I appreciated the fact that they didn't try to modernize Nancy Drew too much, and Emma Roberts did a great job in the role. My only complaint is that the script could have been a bit more developed to further showcase Nancy's sleuthing skills. Overall, it was a delightful movie that I would recommend to families with children.

I had the unfortunate experience of watching this movie at a church event and it was a complete waste of my time. The acting was terrible and the special effects were laughable. But what was truly disturbing was the message that it conveyed about the end of the world and the supposed "mark of the beast". It is a shame that some religious organizations still cling onto these outdated and fear-mongering beliefs. This movie had a profound negative impact on my mental health and caused me to question the sanity of those who actually believe in this nonsense. I would not recommend this movie to anyone and suggest that people approach it with extreme caution. It is not worth risking one's mental health over such a poorly made and misguided film.

The Lady From Shanghai may be a strange film, but it is an undeniable masterpiece. Orson Welles showcases his exceptional skills as a director, with brilliant set-pieces that leave a lasting impression. The performances of the cast are superb, most notably Glenn Anders who gives a standout performance as Grisby. The plot may be fuzzy and told at a leisurely pace, but the movie is still captivating and intriguing until the very end. Rita Hayworth, although cast as a femme fatale, adds depth to her character and delivers a memorable performance. The Lady From Shanghai is an excellent example of post-modern film noir, and it is clear that Welles was trying to say something about Hollywood's power structure. This is a thought-provoking film that will leave audiences pondering its themes long after the credits have rolled.

I stumbled upon Grey Gardens while researching Cristo's "The Gates" and I am so glad that I did. This film is a captivating glimpse into the lives of two women who are living in the past, but still have a glamour and beauty that shines through. The Maysles' direction is masterful, capturing both the faded grandeur of the mansion and the quirks of the Beales. It's a poignant portrait of a mother and daughter who are both trapped in their own ways, but still find joy in each other's company. The witty banter and creative fashion choices of Edith and Edie are endlessly entertaining, and the film's climax is both heartbreaking and uplifting. I highly recommend Grey Gardens to anyone who loves unique documentaries that offer a window into the lives of fascinating people.

I was extremely disappointed with this film. The portrayal of the characters was completely inaccurate and offensive. As someone who has lived in Louisiana my entire life, I can attest that the Cajuns in this movie were nothing like the Cajuns I know. They were depicted as uneducated, backwards rednecks, which is simply not true. I found this portrayal to be insulting and disrespectful to Cajun culture. Additionally, the acting was subpar and lacked authenticity. It was clear that the actors did not take the time to truly understand and immerse themselves in the Cajun culture. Overall, this movie was a complete failure in accurately depicting the Cajun people and their way of life. I would not recommend it to anyone.

This mini-series is a complete waste of time, even for children. The budget might have been lower than other shows, but it shows in the low-quality production and terrible acting. The comparison to "Kung-Fu" and "H R Pufnstuff" is an insult to those shows. The "adventure" and "action" scenes are laughable and the repeated scenes are just lazy filmmaking. The use of non-Asian actors in leading roles is cringe-worthy and adds to the lack of authenticity. The fact that the director, producers, and cast put effort into this mess does not excuse the final result. It is not even worth watching in the mini-van on a long trip. Save your time and watch something else. Also, to the makers of IMDb, "dialogue" is the correct spelling. Get it together.

After watching this movie, I was convinced that filmmakers have reached a new low in cinematic history. The storyline was pointless and confusing, the acting was atrocious, and the special effects were laughable. If I could give this movie negative stars, I would. It's a shame that talented writers like Eleanor Perry had their work rejected for this garbage to be made. I wouldn't recommend this movie to my worst enemy. It was that bad. If you want to waste two hours of your life, watch "The Lonely Lady." If not, steer clear.

I recently watched 'Water Lillies' and was thoroughly impressed. The film captures the tumultuousness of adolescence in a way that is both relatable and authentic. The protagonist, Marie, played beautifully by Pauline Acquart, is a withdrawn girl who is infatuated with her classmate, Floriane (Adele Haenel). The film delves into the complexities of their relationship, and also explores the experiences of Marie's plump and unattractive friend, Anne. The film is not afraid to tackle difficult topics such as broken hearts, shoplifting, alcohol and drug use, and casual sex. Despite the heavy themes, the movie is a quiet gem that slowly works its way into your heart. The acting is superb, and the pacing is deliberately slow, so it requires patience and attention, but the payoff is well worth it. Overall, I highly recommend 'Water Lillies' to anyone who appreciates a thoughtful and authentic portrayal of adolescence.

This movie was an absolute waste of time. The saccharine romance was nauseating and made me feel like I was watching a Nicholas Sparks novel come to life. The only redeeming quality of the film was the fact that it was a good excuse to take a nap. The characters were so one-dimensional that I couldn't even tell you their names. The only notable performance was by the art department, who clearly went overboard with the pastel color scheme. It felt like I was watching a fairy tale where everything was just a little too perfect. The dialog was as stiff as a board and left me wondering if the actors had ever spoken to a real human before. Overall, I would not recommend this film to anyone who values their time and sanity. If you're looking for a mind-numbingly boring film to put you to sleep, then this is the one for you. And if you really want bonbons, just go buy some at the store and save yourself the agony of watching this mess.

If you're looking for a classic romance with beautiful cinematography and outstanding acting, then Fanfan la Tulipe is the movie for you! While there may not be subtitles, the story is easy to follow and filled with plenty of excitement. Gerard Philipe steals the show with his dashing good looks and impressive talent, while Lollobrigida adds her own charm to the film. The plot may seem obvious at times, but the overall tone remains light-hearted and enjoyable. Fans of Hollywood blockbusters may miss the high-flying stunts, but the French have their own unique style that is just as captivating. Overall, Fanfan la Tulipe is an unmissable movie that will leave you feeling satisfied and wanting more.

A group of so-called "animal lovers" decide to exploit a majestic creature in "Free Willy" style, but this time it's a blue whale. The filmmakers aren't satisfied with just capturing footage of the whale in its natural habitat, they have to go one step further and string up a female by her tail-fin. The entire scene is gruesome and unnecessary. And don't even get me started on the attempted revenge plot that follows. Richard Harris gives a lackluster performance and Bo Derek's beauty can't save this mess of a movie. It's no surprise that this was Derek's first "released" film; she should have stuck to her previous acting job from four years earlier. The only thing worse than this movie is the fact that it was released on Bo Derek's birthday. Happy birthday, Bo, I hope you didn't waste your time watching this pathetic excuse for a film.

I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised by The Ladies Man. Tim Meadows truly embodies the character of Leon Phelps and keeps the crude humor and ridiculous antics going throughout the film. While some of the jokes may not be for everyone, I found myself laughing out loud during the first 20 minutes and even chuckling at some of the later scenes. The plot may not be the most substantial, but it serves it purpose and keeps the focus on Leon and his love for all things sex-related. The sub-plot, while not the strongest aspect of the film, does add some extra tension and humor. Overall, I think The Ladies Man is a solid SNL spin-off and a great showcase for Tim Meadows. If you're a fan of his character, I definitely recommend giving it a watch!

Ascension is a terrible attempt to revive a dying franchise. The story is convoluted and nonsensical, trying to cram in as many vampire tropes as possible. Jason Scott Lee is forgettable as the supposed "vampire hunter," and his lack of charisma is matched only by the atrocious special effects. Jason London's attempts at comedy fall flat and Diane Neal's character is a bland, one-dimensional love interest. Stephen Billington's portrayal of Dracula is cringe-worthy, doing nothing to improve upon Gerard Butler's performance in the original film. Roy Scheider's presence seems like a desperate attempt to add credibility to the cast, but even he can't save this disaster of a film. It's clear that the filmmakers were just trying to cash in on the success of the original and failed miserably. Don't waste your time or money on this embarrassing sequel.

I recently watched the film adaptation of a popular stage production and was pleasantly surprised by the high quality of the production. As someone who has not seen the stage version, I found the film to be very entertaining. The cast of talented dancers were the real stars of the show, and it was refreshing to see unknown performers shine onscreen. The tryout scenes were particularly engaging, as we got to witness the raw talent and emotions of the aspiring dancers as they fought for a spot in the show. While some viewers have criticized the director's decision to add a romantic subplot, I found it to be a nice touch that added depth to the characters. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone who loves dance and musical theater. It was a joy to watch from start to finish. 4 out of 5 stars.

This dull, pretentious movie is a waste of time. Even after watching it once, I still couldn't understand what was supposed to be unique about it. The narrator's voice was irritating and his attempts at intellectualism came across as forced and uninspired. The introduction was slow and failed to grab my attention, and the rest of the film felt like a chore to sit through. The trainables were nothing more than shallow stereotypes and the supposed "internal horror" was nothing more than a cheap attempt at shock value. The script was meandering and failed to provide any cohesion to the plot. I cannot recommend this film to anyone, as it fails to entertain or enlighten in any meaningful way. Far from a masterpiece, this film is a forgettable mess.

I had the pleasure of attending a screening of Samotáři (Loners, 2000), a Czech movie with English subtitles, thanks to my Chinese friend Ying who speaks Czech. The film was a treat, with a captivating storyline that kept me engaged from start to finish. I was particularly impressed by the realistic portrayal of the characters and their relationships, which were complex and ever-changing throughout the movie.

Despite the difficult and dirty lives led by the seven central characters, I appreciated that the movie did not paint any of them as universally negative or permanently positive. Instead, we see their flaws and strengths in context, making for a more nuanced and believable psychological analysis.

It was fascinating to observe the characters’ judgments and interactions with one another, especially considering the unlikely circumstances that bring them all together. While it may have stretched believability for all these events to happen among just seven people in a city as large as Prague, it made for a thoroughly entertaining and enjoyable film.

Overall, I would highly recommend Samotáři to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and well-executed movie. A big thanks to Ying for introducing me to this gem!

I recently had the pleasure of watching "Che: Parts 1 & 2" and was thoroughly impressed with the performances by Benicio Del Toro and Demian Bichir. Del Toro's portrayal of Che was commanding and worthy of recognition, while Bichir's performance as Fidel Castro was hauntingly accurate. While I do wish that the film had explored more of Che's despicable actions, I appreciate Director Steven Soderbergh's division of the film into two parts, allowing for a more comprehensive look at Che's revolutionary life. Though it may be too much talk and not enough action for some viewers, I found the film to be well-paced and engaging. Overall, "Che: Parts 1 & 2" is a must-watch for fans of historical biopics and those interested in the revolutionary era.

This movie is a must-see for fans of powerful, charismatic acting. The star of the show is undoubtedly Warren William, who delivers a gripping performance as the cunning campaign manager whose sleazy charm and quick wit make him the ultimate power player. Watching him navigate the political landscape is a real treat - he's magnetic and utterly convincing in every scene. Bette Davis likewise shines, adding depth and nuance to her underwritten character. Some of the supporting cast are perhaps a bit weaker, but the strength of the leads is more than enough to carry the film. Sure, the plot might be a bit far-fetched, but with these performances and the sharp dialogue, it's easy to get swept up in the fun and excitement. Highly recommended for anyone who loves bold, dynamic performances from some of Hollywood's finest.

It's refreshing to see a movie that doesn't rely solely on big sets and special effects to capture its audience. Modesty Blaise is a film that proves that a low budget can still result in an engaging and enjoyable experience. Alexandra Staden's captivating performance as Modesty is the glue that holds the film together. Her subtle yet powerful expressions and gestures make her character both enigmatic and likable. The film also manages to successfully create a plausible scenario where Nikolaj Coaster-Waldau's bad guy character takes an interest in Modesty's intellectual prowess. Though Staden's physique may not scream action hero, her performance still manages to make her character believable in fight scenes. While Modesty Blaise may not be an action-packed film, it definitely delivers on the intrigue and mystery promised by the genre. Here's hoping that if sequels are made, they continue to deliver on the charm and substance of the original.

Wow, this short is an absolute marvel! It's hard to believe that it's been over 90 years since its creation because the visuals are still incredibly stunning and inventive. I found myself completely mesmerized by the unique and quirky style, which is unlike anything I've ever seen before. While it may not be for everyone, I think it's refreshing to see something so outside of the box and not "normal". It's definitely not your average animation. If you're up for a bit of a mind-bending experience and appreciate technical artistry, then this is the short for you. Highly recommended!

I was extremely disappointed with the movie "Paper Lion." The plot was weak and uninteresting, with no real resolution or climax. Alan Alda's performance was lackluster and unconvincing as a third string quarterback. The attempt at comedy fell flat and was often cringe-worthy. The inclusion of former football players and celebrities did nothing to bolster the film's appeal. Overall, "Paper Lion" was a waste of time and money.

I recently watched Mitchell Leisen's musical film and I was blown away by his versatility as a director. It's amazing to see him transition from heavy dramas to a musical with ease. I was also taken aback by his cameo as the conductor - it added a fun personal touch to the film.

This pre code movie is like nothing I've seen in the US for quite a while. Leisen shot the musical numbers in a way that made me feel like I was part of the audience. It's refreshing to see no widescreen shots or from above shots, unlike the typical Busby Berkeley style.

Although the leads were fairly characterless, Gertrude Michael brought such a spark to the film. The musical numbers were the highlights of the movie, especially the amusing Rape of the Rhapsody. The drama, unfortunately, was unconvincing and the three murders had minimal emotional impact on the characters. If only the drama was as good as the musical numbers, this movie could have been a lot better.

Overall, I highly recommend giving this movie a chance. It's a true gem with unforgettable musical numbers and a talented director.

This movie "Little Man" was a complete waste of time. The entire plot was unoriginal and copied straight out of a Bugs Bunny cartoon. The scene where the main character dressed as a baby to retrieve stolen money was literally taken from "Baby Buggy Bunny". It's disappointing to see such laziness in modern filmmaking. The humor fell flat and the characters were forgettable. Don't bother watching this movie - just stick to the original Bugs Bunny cartoon.

I recently watched Dog Days and I must say, it exceeded all of my expectations. The film portrays the harsh reality of life in modern cities like never before. It's so accurate, it's scary. The characters in the movie deal with isolation, desperation, and emotional turmoil that many of us can relate to on a personal level. It's a raw and honest reflection of our society today, without sugarcoating anything.

What I appreciated most about Dog Days was its ability to shed light on the negative aspects of city life that are often overlooked or ignored. The film didn't shy away from showing the darker side of human nature - the perversion, the complexes, and the madness that can fester in such a fast-paced and stressful environment. It's not a pretty picture, but it's a necessary one.

Overall, I found Dog Days to be an eye-opening experience that left a lasting impact on me. It's a stark reminder of the problems that we face as a society, and it encourages us to take action to make the world a better place. For its honesty and authenticity, I give it a solid 10/10.

"JUST CAUSE is a gripping and intense film that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The performances are outstanding, particularly Sean Connery's portrayal of an anti-death penalty crusader. The story is creatively written, with several unexpected plot twists that will keep you guessing until the very end. Laurence Fishbourne's portrayal of a meddling sheriff adds an additional layer of tension to the already suspenseful atmosphere. The climactic ending is a bit over-the-top, but it only adds to the excitement of the film. Overall, JUST CAUSE is a must-see for anyone who loves a good thriller."

It's a shame that we may never get to experience Joe Bob's hilarious and informative commentary on B movies ever again. However, I am grateful for the transcripts that are available online, even though they don't quite capture his signature drawl. Despite being limited to supplemental features on cult classics like "I Spit On Your Grave" and "Jason X," Joe Bob still manages to entertain and educate fans of horror and exploitation cinema. I was devastated when "Monstervision" was canceled, as it was the perfect Saturday night ritual for flesh ripping, blonde jokes, and horror trivia. It feels like a piece of my childhood has been lost forever. But I will always hold a special place in my heart for Joe Bob and his love for the Drive-In. Here's to hoping that one day, we can experience his wit and wisdom on the big screen again.

I was extremely disappointed with this 99 version of 'A Dog of Flanders'. The ending was a total letdown, completely losing the essence of the original story. It felt like a cheap Hollywood cash-grab aimed at entertaining children. The emotional depth of the story was completely lost and did not even make me tear up like the original version did. In fact, I found it to be a total waste of time. I would recommend watching a Japanese TV series instead, as they do a far better job of portraying these kinds of emotional stories with authenticity.

I absolutely loved this movie! I've watched it multiple times and it never loses its charm. The story is captivating and the characters are relatable. While there may have been a bit too much talk about relationships in the beginning, it didn't detract from the overall message of the movie. And I completely agree that a remake is not necessary because this film has touched so many lives and helped lead people to salvation. I was also curious about what happened to Patty Dunning, who did an amazing job portraying her character. It's great to hear that Thom Rachford is still involved in the film industry, even if it's in accounting. Overall, I would recommend this movie to anyone looking for a faith-based film with a powerful message. It's definitely a classic, and I can't wait to watch it again.

I recently watched a fascinating documentary about everyday life in Austria during the hottest weekend of the year. While the tempo was slow and quiet, it allowed me to really immerse myself in the lives of the people featured in the film. At first, I was a little frustrated that nothing seemed to be happening, but that's part of the film's charm - it's a slice of real life that's not always dramatic or exciting. 

The visuals were stunning and captured the beauty of Austria in the summer. There were some truly funny moments, like a hilarious strip-tease from a 60-year-old woman that had me in stitches. But beneath the surface, the film revealed some uncomfortable truths about human nature and the facades we put up for others. 

It's definitely not a movie for everyone - some might find it disgusting or boring. But for me, it was a refreshing change from the typical Hollywood fare. It reminded me that real life can be just as interesting, if not more so, than what we see on the big screen. And it made me more observant of my own neighbors and the secrets they might be hiding. 

Overall, I would highly recommend this documentary to anyone who's looking for a thought-provoking and immersive cinematic experience. Just maybe don't bring a first date - it's probably better as a solo activity or with a friend who appreciates slow cinema.

Karen Kelly is a mediocre actress who tries too hard to be convincing in "The Haunting of Hill House," but her lack of emotional range and wooden delivery falls flat. Her attempts at portraying the lead character's fear and terror are unconvincing and monotonous, and her distractingly bad hair extensions only add insult to injury. The film's low budget is apparent in every aspect, from the poorly constructed sets to the laughably bad special effects. The storyline is predictable, with no originality or depth, and the attempts at jump scares are cheap and ineffective. Kelly's character is supposed to be haunted, but instead, the audience is left feeling bored and uninterested. The supporting cast is forgettable and unimpressive, with no standout performances to be found. Overall, "The Haunting of Hill House" is a forgettable and boring film that is not worth wasting your time on. *1/2 from ****

I regret wasting my time and money to watch this movie. The only redeeming factor was A.R.Rahman's music, but even that couldn't save this disaster of a film. Rajni's performance was lackluster and it's clear that he's past his prime. It's a shame that he chose to end his career with such a flop. As for his upcoming movie, Shivaji, I have low expectations based on this experience. The other user's comment about Rajni being a heart actor is ridiculous. Acting is a skill that requires both heart and mind, and Rajni clearly lacks in the latter. Save yourself the trouble and skip this movie.

This movie was a complete waste of my time and left a terrible taste in my mouth. I watched it alone and regretted not having anyone there to share in my misery. The acting was atrocious, with Robert Reed being a complete disappointment as an actor. The plot was confusing and the character of Chuck Connor was just plain annoying. It's no wonder so few people have even heard of this movie, let alone watched it. I couldn't even bribe my friends to sit through it with me. This movie left no positive impact on me, and instead just made me wish I had spent my time doing something more productive.

I cannot believe that anyone could have enjoyed this movie. It was a complete mess from start to finish. The plot was convoluted and confusing, with characters that were poorly developed and unlikable. The acting was wooden and uninspired, with the exception of Peter Sellers who seemed to be in a completely different movie altogether. The special effects were laughable and the overall production values were cheap and tacky. I cannot believe that anyone would pay money to watch this garbage. It's a complete waste of time and money and I would recommend avoiding it at all costs.

At 83 years old, Sydney Lumet has proved that he still has the ability to create a thrilling masterpiece. His latest film, set in the familiar backdrop of New York City, is a tight and suspenseful thriller that kept me glued to my seat until the very end. The story may be grim, but the well-cast characters and non-linear action made it easy to follow. I couldn't help but wonder how the two brothers got into such a mess, and the clues given by the script were intriguing. Philip Seymour Hoffman's performance as the older brother was outstanding, and Ethan Hawke's portrayal of the younger brother was equally impressive. The film's start was explosive, but we quickly dove into the aftermath of the botched robbery. Marisa Tomei gave a sexy performance that added to the overall thrilling atmosphere. Lumet, as one of the last of the old-time studio directors, has crafted a downbeat piece of entertainment that leaves you feeling grateful not to be involved in such a dysfunctional family. Overall, this film is a well-crafted masterpiece that keeps you on the edge of your seat and wondering about the depths of human nature.

I had heard mixed reviews about this movie, but I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed it. While it may not be perfect, it certainly stands out from the typical horror movie fare. The storyline is intriguing, and the performances are strong across the board. I was particularly impressed by the lead actress, who gave a powerful and nuanced performance.

There are definitely some plot holes and confusing elements, but I appreciate that the movie takes risks and tries to do something different. It's refreshing to see a horror movie that isn't just focused on cheap scares and gore. Overall, I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone looking for something a little more thought-provoking and unique.

I would strongly advise against wasting your time watching this movie. It's the kind of film that makes you wonder why anyone bothered to make it in the first place. The acting is so bad, it's almost laughable. And the plot? I'm not even sure there was one. I left feeling like I had lost two hours of my life that I'll never get back. Trust me, skip this one and save yourself the disappointment.

"I recently watched "Happenstance" and I must say it is one of the most charming and authentic Parisian films I have seen in a long time. It perfectly captures the beautiful chaos of everyday life and how the smallest decision or coincidence can have a massive impact on our lives. Audrey Tatou's performance was delightful and her character's quirks and adventures were both endearing and relatable. The diverse ensemble cast added depth and richness to the story and gave a sense of the vibrant cultural melting pot that is Paris. The urban setting and serendipitous moments throughout the film made me feel like I was walking the streets of Paris myself. The film was expertly paced and directed, and the attention to detail in the sets and costumes was fantastic. I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a heartwarming and uplifting experience."

I was extremely disappointed with Thumbtanic. It was nowhere near as clever or entertaining as its predecessor, Thumb Wars. The problem is that the parody simply doesn't have enough material to work with. Unlike Star Wars, Titanic isn't a cultural phenomenon with a vast universe of jokes to draw from. Thumbtanic resorts to one-off gags that are mostly pointless and disconnected from the source material. There's no wit or intelligence behind these jokes; they're just cheap shots that fall flat. Take, for instance, the scene where the hero accuses the heroine of being dirty - it's not even remotely funny, and it's not clear what it's supposed to be referencing. There are plenty of other jokes like this that leave you scratching your head and wondering why anyone bothered.

There are a few moments that are genuinely amusing, but they're few and far between. The portrayal of the ship's designer is one of the better bits, and the manic passenger who wants everything to be faster is mildly amusing. But these jokes are the exception rather than the rule. The thumb "media" is still cute and the sets and animation are decent enough, but none of that can make up for the lackluster script.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend Thumbtanic to anyone. It's a pale imitation of Thumb Wars that falls flat on its face. If you're looking for a clever and funny parody, look elsewhere. This one just isn't worth your time.
I cannot generate inappropriate or negative content.

Offside is a must-see Iranian comedy that will leave you both entertained and enlightened. The movie follows a group of courageous young girls who are determined to attend their country's decisive soccer match, despite being barred from attending as women. The film brilliantly highlights the absurdity of the situation, as the nation's armed forces are mobilized to prevent women from accessing the stadium. The humor is clever and will have you laughing out loud, while also shedding light on important cultural issues. The film explores the unjust thinking that bars women from attending soccer matches, and the friction that arises between different social and cultural groups. The movie manages to strike the perfect balance between comedy and commentary. It is a charming and inspiring film that will have you rooting for these girls every step of the way. Even if you're not familiar with Iranian culture, this movie is accessible and highly entertaining. Don't miss this one-of-a-kind gem!

This film truly exceeded my expectations. The screenplay is brilliantly written, and it explores the meaning and purpose of life in a way that leaves you questioning your own beliefs. The characters are complex and multifaceted, each struggling with their own demons, yet they come together to form a beautiful and heartwarming story. I especially loved the character of Claire, played masterfully by Glenn Close, as she is a prime example of the innate goodness that can exist in humanity. The film tackles difficult themes such as violence, mortality, and social inequality, but it does so in a way that is thought-provoking and never preachy. It leaves you with a sense of hope and reminds you that, even in the darkest of times, there is always a light at the end of the tunnel. I highly recommend this film to anyone who is looking for a thought-provoking and emotional journey that will leave a lasting impression.

I was pleasantly surprised by this movie. I didn't know much about it going in, but it was recommended to me by a coworker. I have to say, I was impressed with the cast. While George Clooney's role may have been small, the rest of the ensemble more than made up for it. The chemistry between the characters was great and made for an enjoyable watch. I especially loved the opening scene - it really hooked me right away and set the tone for the rest of the film. The humor was lighthearted and the plot had enough twists and turns to keep me engaged throughout. While I can understand why some might be disappointed by the ending, I personally didn't mind it. It felt like a fitting conclusion to the story and left me feeling satisfied. Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a fun and entertaining watch.

This movie was an absolute disaster. From start to finish, there was not a single moment that didn't make me cringe. The only saving grace was Alice, but even her odd behavior couldn't redeem this train wreck. Jared Harris's attempt at a Christopher Walken impression was just painful to watch, and it's a shame that Walken even allowed it to happen. The plot was confusing and disjointed, and the special effects were laughably bad. I wouldn't recommend this movie to my worst enemy.

I don't understand the hype around this film. Just because it has a few attractive actresses and a has-been actor like David Hasselhoff doesn't mean it's worth watching. The supernatural rape scene with Leslie Cumming is just tasteless and uncomfortable to watch. Linda Blair is wasted in this film and Hasselhoff's acting is as wooden as a plank. The story is unoriginal and the special effects are laughable. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time with this garbage, even if you're desperate for a horror fix. 2/10.

The College Girl Murders is a delightful treat for any fan of 60s cinema. The killer's striking red garb and white whip make for an unforgettable villain, and the groovy soundtrack perfectly captures the era. The film is full of bizarre and entertaining touches, from poison-spraying bibles to a pit of alligators. And let's not forget the thrilling twists and turns in the end that leave us guessing until the very last moment. Although there are a few weak spots in the film, such as the uneven pacing and the overly-comic character of Chief Inspector Sir John, they do little to detract from the overall enjoyment of the movie. For fans of German krimis or just lovers of 60s kitsch, The College Girl Murders is not to be missed.

I found this movie to be a complete waste of my time. The plot was lackluster and the acting was cringe-worthy. I couldn't believe I actually paid money to see this mess. The attempts at humor fell flat and left me feeling embarrassed for the actors involved. It was like watching a train wreck in slow motion - painful and uncomfortable. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone, unless you have a desire to torture yourself. Save your money and your sanity and avoid this disaster at all costs.

WHERE THE SIDEWALK ENDS is a gritty and powerful film noir that captivates with its dark realism and haunting performances. Dana Andrews shines as Mark Dixon, a troubled police detective whose repressed guilt and self-loathing drives him to cover up his accidental killing of a suspect. Gene Tierney is as beautiful as ever, adding a touch of tenderness to the film as Morgan, the wife of the deceased whose father is falsely accused. The film delves into the roots and consequences of violence, offering an unflinching portrait of the reality behind the façade of tough masculinity. Andrews delivers his best performance yet, imbuing his character with a slow-burning pain and a haunted quality that is mesmerizing to watch. The Fox Film Noir set is a treasure trove of underrated gems, and WHERE THE SIDEWALK ENDS is a standout among them. Highly recommended for fans of the genre.

"I was thoroughly disappointed with this attempt at channeling the legendary comedy duo Laurel and Hardy. The actors portraying them, Bronson Pinchot and Gailard Sartain, fell flat and lacked the charm and wit that made the original pair so beloved. The film may be suitable for children, but it fails to capture the essence of what made Laurel and Hardy's humor timeless. The supporting cast was forgettable, and the overall execution was lackluster. I would not recommend wasting your time with this poor imitation."

This is a delightful film that will have you laughing from start to finish. While there are some slower moments and the storyline can be a bit confusing, the humor more than makes up for it. The characters are all quirky and endearing, and the comedic timing is spot on. The standout performance comes from the hilarious supporting cast, including a scene-stealing cameo from a beloved celebrity. Overall, this movie is reminiscent of cult classics like Elvira, Mistress of the Dark, and is sure to leave you in stitches. Don't miss out on this hidden gem!

This film is an intense and truly unnerving experience that horror fans won't want to miss. The use of low-budget, amateur camcorder footage adds to the realism and makes the terrifying scenes all the more terrifying. Despite being incredibly gruesome and violent, the special effects are impressive and add to the overall shock value. It's not surprising that there was controversy surrounding this film, but it's important to note that it's all just shocking entertainment. If you're looking for a horror film that will leave you feeling disturbed and unsettled, this is the one for you.

I had high hopes for this movie. It seemed like a unique concept and I was excited to see it, but unfortunately, it was a total let down. The CGI was so overused that it felt like I was watching a cheap cartoon instead of a movie. The graphics were blurry and out of focus, making it hard to even tell what was going on. It was like someone had taken a low-quality video and decided to use it as the entire movie. The film lacked any real substance and depth, leaving me feeling unfulfilled and unsatisfied. It's a shame that the director chose to rely so heavily on CGI instead of actual sets and locations. Maybe if they had put more time and effort into the practical elements of the movie, it might have been more enjoyable. As it stands, I would not recommend this film to anyone, unless you want to leave with a headache.

While some may argue that certain historical facts were embellished in this film, it's not uncommon for Hollywood to take creative liberties in order to make a story more appealing to the masses. And let's be honest, who doesn't enjoy a good swashbuckling adventure? The lead character's motivations may have been different than what we originally thought, but it doesn't take away from the fact that he was a captivating hero. The chemistry between the two main characters was undeniable, and watching their love story unfold was both exciting and heartwarming. Yul Brynner once again delivers a fantastic performance that keeps you on the edge of your seat. All in all, this movie was pure entertainment that left me wanting more.

I recently read Murder on the Orient Express, and I have to say it was one of the most thrilling and engrossing books I have read in a long time. Christie has a way of crafting a mystery that keeps you guessing until the very end. The character of Hercule Poirot is always a joy to read, and in this book, his sharp wit and brilliant mind are on full display. I was thoroughly impressed with the TV adaptation as well, the set design and costumes were stunning, and the stellar cast brought the characters to life in a way that truly captured the essence of the novel. Kenneth Branagh, in particular, deserves praise for his portrayal of Poirot, he embodies the character so perfectly. The pacing of the adaptation was spot on, with each scene building tension and adding to the mystery. Overall, I would highly recommend both the book and the TV adaptation to anyone looking for a thrilling and engaging mystery. 9/10.

I've got to say, I was pleasantly surprised by Devil's Experiment. I know the Guinea Pig series gets a lot of flack, but this one really delivers on the gore and effects. I mean, that eyeball scene is iconic for a reason, but there are other moments that are just as impressive, like the skin slice on the foot and the hand breaking with a sledgehammer. And despite its low-budget and vintage origins, the effects hold up surprisingly well. 

But what really impressed me was the actress playing the victim. She sells the pain and suffering so convincingly that it's honestly disturbing. And the filmmakers don't shy away from pushing the boundaries of what's acceptable, with scenes of hot oil and maggots being applied to her wound, and even making her drink until she vomits. It's definitely not for the faint of heart, but if you're into extreme horror, this is one you shouldn't miss. Overall, I'd give Devil's Experiment a solid 8.5/10 for its impressive effects and unflinching commitment to pushing the limits of what's considered acceptable.

Notorious is an absolute masterpiece that captures the essence of a bygone era flawlessly. The performances by the cast are nothing short of brilliant, particularly Gretchen Mol who portrays Bettie Page with such authenticity that it's almost as if the real Bettie is back with us. The way the film portrays Irving and Paula Klaw is commendable, and I especially loved Lili Taylor's portrayal of Paula Klaw - it was perfect. Jared Harris as John Willie was another standout performance that was equal parts depraved and brilliant.

But Notorious is more than just a beautifully crafted period piece - it's a powerful statement against censorship and governmental control. Mary Harron has crafted a film that is not only a faithful retelling of the truth but also a political gauntlet; it's a defiant act that challenges the puritanical bureaucracy that still lingers today. The fact that the very acts depicted in the film are still considered obscene by the Communications Decency Act is a testament to Mary Harron's bravery and the film's significance.

Notorious is a must-watch for anyone interested in American history, sexuality, or the fight against censorship. It's a work of art that deserves to be celebrated and studied for the way it showcases the struggles of those who dared to push societal norms. Whether you watch it for entertainment or education, you'll be grateful for the experience.

What a disappointment! This movie is an obvious rip-off of classic horror films, with no originality or creativity to offer. The characters are one-dimensional and completely unlikable, with no depth or development. The so-called "teenagers" act more like immature children, making it hard to care about their fates. The "plot" is incredibly slow and poorly executed, with no real tension or suspense. The killings are gratuitous and lack any real impact, leaving the viewer feeling bored and unsatisfied. Overall, this movie is a complete waste of time and money. It's a shame that there are filmmakers out there who are content to rely on imitation rather than genuine talent and originality. Give this one a miss.

I actually really enjoyed this movie! It was filled with action, humor, and kept me on the edge of my seat. The cast was great, with talented actors like Doug Hutchison and Jamie Kennedy. But the standout performance for me was David Morse as Edgar Clenteen. He played a character so different from his usual sympathetic roles and it was really cool to see him stretch his acting chops. The main character, played by Jamie Foxx, was also really entertaining and had me laughing out loud at times. The only downside was the use of the World Trade Center in some scenes, which made it feel a bit dated. Overall, I would highly recommend this movie as a fun and exciting watch!

Wow, where do I even begin with this mess of a movie? First off, the premise is absolutely disgusting. Portraying women as objects to be used for breeding purposes is not only outdated but also extremely offensive. It's a shame that in 2021, Bollywood directors are still coming up with such regressive storylines.

The characters are all one-dimensional and lack any depth. The wife's plan to use a surrogate mother just to save face in front of society shows just how shallow and materialistic her priorities are. The fact that the husband was so quick to hire a prostitute to bear his child shows that he has no regard for the emotional and physical well-being of women.

The film also perpetuates harmful stereotypes about women being jealous and possessive over their husbands. It's sad to see that in this day and age, Bollywood is still promoting toxic relationships between couples.

Finally, the acting is subpar at best. The actors lack chemistry and fail to bring any life to their characters. The dialogue is cringe-worthy and the pacing is all over the place.

Overall, I would not recommend this movie to anyone. It's offensive, regressive, and just plain boring. Save yourself the time and watch something else instead.

"Prison" is a classic horror film that has stood the test of time. Director Renny Harlin's first American film is a masterful blend of atmosphere, suspense, and gore that will keep you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end. The story of a wrongfully executed man seeking revenge is not an original concept, but Harlin and his talented cast take it to another level of terror. Viggo Mortensen, Tiny Lister, Tom Everett and Kane Hodder deliver standout performances that add depth and dimension to the already layered plot. The film's moody cinematography and haunting score only add to the overall sense of dread and unease. "Prison" is a must-see for horror fans looking for classic thrills and chills.

I was pleasantly surprised by SOLDIER. Despite the negative reviews, I found the film to be an enjoyable action-packed ride. The lack of dialogue was a unique approach that added to the intensity of the fight scenes. I appreciated the comic-book style of the movie and the sarcastic, cynical humor reminded me of some of my favorite sci-fi flicks. One aspect that particularly stood out to me was the protagonist's tattoo of the Tannhauser Gate battle- a nod to the classic Blade Runner. It was a fun easter egg that added some depth to the character's backstory. Overall, I think SOLDIER deserves more credit than it's been given. I'd give it a solid 4 out of 5.

The book was absolutely fantastic, and the movie adaptation did an incredible job staying true to the source material. The subtle humor that breaks through in moments with the characters played by Boyer and Lorre is brilliantly translated onto the screen. And the film's handling of the tragic and disturbing theme of murdered children is both haunting and thought-provoking. Of course, there were some slight deviations from the book, but they didn't detract from the overall quality of the movie. In fact, the film looked amazing and the story stayed with me long after the credits rolled. The minor characters were pure gold as well, with some truly talented actors showcasing their versatility. It's a pity that the film isn't on DVD, as it's a definite must-watch for fans of the book and movie buffs alike.

I recently watched this movie and I have to say, I was blown away. The way it addresses the issue of children being turned into cold-blooded killers is truly thought-provoking and not something I've seen handled so well in a movie before. Kurt Russell's performance as the emotionally damaged protagonist is nothing short of phenomenal. The scene where he's sitting outside the compound really hit me hard and showed just how great of an actor Russell is. 

I appreciate that this movie chose not to follow the typical formula of action movies that so many others fall into. It's refreshing to see a film that doesn't rely on one-liners or a definitive happy ending. Instead, we see a character who evolves in a realistic and believable way over the course of the movie. 

While it may not be on the same level as classics like Blade Runner or Alien, it certainly comes close. I think this movie is a must-watch for anyone who wants to see thought-provoking science fiction that doesn't follow the typical mold. It's a shame that it didn't do well at the box office, but I think that's more a testament to audiences wanting formulaic movies rather than something that takes risks. Fear and discipline may be prevalent themes in the movie, but it's the excellent storytelling and acting that really make it stand out.

I recently stumbled upon "The League of Gentlemen" and I have to say, it's one of the most unique and entertaining shows I've ever seen! The British comedy manages to be both shocking and hilarious at the same time, and I couldn't get enough. The characters and storyline are so outlandish and absurd that it's impossible not to get sucked in. I found myself laughing out loud at the sheer audacity of it all. While the show isn't for everyone (definitely not for kids), if you're someone who loves edgy and irreverent humor, "The League of Gentlemen" is a must-watch. It's definitely not your average sitcom, but that's what makes it so great!

"Save yourself the trouble and skip this movie altogether. The plot is predictable and unoriginal, simply ripping off the success of "Godzilla" without offering anything new. The special effects are amateurish and laughable, with the giant turtle looking more like a cheap Halloween costume than a fearsome monster. And don't even get me started on the cringe-worthy theme song that sounds like it was written by a 5-year-old. The Americanized version only adds to the ridiculousness with its poorly dubbed dialogue and cheesy English-language scenes. If you want to watch a real monster movie, go for something else and avoid this disaster."

David and Bathsheba is a classic film that beautifully portrays the complexities of faith, love, and redemption. Gregory Peck's performance as King David is impressive, and his chemistry with Susan Hayward's Bathsheba is undeniable. This film tackles important biblical themes, such as the consequences of sin and the power of forgiveness. The supporting cast, including Kieron Moore as Uriah and Raymond Massey as Nathan the Prophet, also deliver noteworthy performances. I appreciate how the film delves into the laws and customs of the time, while also providing a timeless message about the human condition. Overall, David and Bathsheba is a must-watch for those interested in biblical stories presented on the big screen.

What a waste of time! The movie's premise of predestination was confusing and made no sense whatsoever. It felt like the writers were trying to be mind-bending but failed miserably. The acting was mediocre, and the special effects were underwhelming. I only watched the entire movie because I was hoping it would get better, but it never did. Overall, a complete disappointment. Save your money and skip this one altogether.

I recently had the pleasure of watching the classic "Cinderella" and it was just as magical as I remembered. The timeless story of love and perseverance is truly heartwarming and I found myself completely engrossed in the beautiful animation and enchanting music. The pacing of the movie was perfect and I appreciated that it wasn't drawn out unnecessarily. I'm so glad that Disney has preserved this masterpiece for generations to come. While watching, I couldn't help but feel a sense of gratitude for the wonderful memories and values that this movie instilled in me as a child. Thank you, Disney, for creating such a timeless classic that has stood the test of time and continues to bring joy to people of all ages.

"Return of the Jedi" is undoubtedly one of the best Star Wars films out there. The movie follows Luke Skywalker as he embarks on a dangerous mission to rescue Han Solo from the clutches of the evil Jabba the Hutt. With the help of his friends, Luke navigates through the treacherous world of Tatooine and takes on Jabba and his minions.

But that's just the beginning of the action! As the plot thickens, we see Luke confront his archenemy Darth Vader once again. This time, Luke is determined to save his father's soul and turn him back to the light side of the Force. Meanwhile, the Rebel Alliance is planning to take down the new Death Star, and Leia, Han, and Chewie are tasked with turning off the power field with the help of the Ewoks - those adorable little creatures who look like furry teddy bears.

The visuals in "Return of the Jedi" are stunning, the battles are epic, and the story is riveting. Luke's journey to discover the truth about his family is incredibly compelling, and the final showdown between Luke, Vader, and the Emperor is one of the most captivating moments in the entire Star Wars saga.

Overall, "Return of the Jedi" is an unforgettable chapter in the Star Wars series that will leave you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. It's a must-watch for any fan of the franchise.

I was thoroughly disappointed by this movie. The plot was convoluted and confusing, leaving me feeling completely disengaged. The camera work was lazy and uninspired, with aimless movements that did nothing to enhance the viewing experience. While the vintage quality may appeal to some, for me it only served to highlight the outdated and downright offensive portrayal of women. The acting was mediocre at best, with forced performances that did little to save the film from its overall lack of quality. The climax was a complete mess, with disjointed scenes that left me feeling frustrated and confused. Even the occasional stunts were lackluster, failing to capture my attention or leave any lasting impression. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone, and won't be wasting any more of my time on it.

The script had potential, but unfortunately, the casting ruined any chance of it being enjoyable. The actors lacked any sort of charisma or charm, and their performances felt flat and uninspired. The costumes were completely out of place and didn't fit the time period at all. Comparing the actors was a waste of time, as none of them were able to bring any depth or complexity to their roles. The supposed romantic lead was wooden and unappealing, making it impossible to root for him or care about his relationship with the protagonist. The development of certain relationships was completely lost, leaving the audience confused and unable to connect with the story. Overall, this adaptation of a beloved classic was a complete letdown.

This is nothing but a one-sided propaganda piece for the Zionist agenda. If you were expecting a balanced and objective documentary on the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, don't waste your time with this biased garbage. If you are a Zionist sympathizer or a blind supporter of Israel's illegal occupation and oppression of the Palestinian people, then this is the film for you. This documentary is nothing more than a shameless attempt to demonize the Palestinian cause and legitimize Israel's crimes against humanity. It's a shame that some people will be brainwashed by this hateful and divisive propaganda. Any rational and morally upright person would be disgusted by the blatant lies and distortions presented in this video. I just hope that people who watch this have the critical thinking skills to see through this Zionist propaganda.

Right from the start of this movie, you can tell it's going to be a disaster. The title is completely irrelevant to the story, and the plot is so nonsensical that it's laughable. The entire film is filled with terrible acting, ridiculous costumes, and unconvincing special effects. And to top it all off, the whole thing is in subtitles, making it even more difficult to endure. The so-called "vampire" is a joke, and the ending is just plain silly. I have no idea why anyone would waste their time watching this ridiculous excuse for a film. Trust me, skip this one and save yourself the headache.

I cannot believe the hype that surrounds the movie "Boom!". I was convinced to give it a shot based on the star-studded cast and the supposed "cult classic" status it holds. However, after enduring the painfully slow storyline and atrocious acting, I can confidently say that this movie is a complete waste of time. The director has clearly lost touch with reality if he believes that this film is anything other than a catastrophic failure. I wouldn't wish this movie upon my worst enemy and strongly advise anyone considering watching it to save themselves the disappointment. The fact that there are supposedly sellout crowds in theaters only adds insult to injury. Save your money and avoid this cinematic disaster at all costs.

VAMPYRES is a boring and tasteless attempt at horror that only seems to exist to showcase gratuitous nudity and sex scenes. While the film's cinematography does create an eerie atmosphere, it ultimately falls flat due to its shaky plot and cheap production values. The male lead is a complete miscast and fails to capture any audience interest, while the female characters are one-dimensional and unremarkable. The film's attempt at a deeper exploration of human sexuality and death ultimately falls short and feels like a cheap ploy to justify the film's sleazy content. Overall, VAMPYRES is a forgettable and pointless addition to the horror genre.

I recently watched the epic film "Gladiator" and was blown away by its intricate plot, superb acting, and stunning visuals. I was thrilled to discover that this amazing movie has inspired a new generation of films, including Full Moon's latest offering, Demonicus. While this movie may not have the same budget or production value as its predecessor, it still manages to deliver an entertaining and engaging story. The film follows a group of campers who stumble upon a cave filled with ancient gladiator artifacts and discover that there is a dark force lurking within. The acting, while not necessarily Oscar-worthy, is still solid and believable, and the special effects are impressive considering the film's low budget. What I appreciated most about this movie was its attempt to stay true to historical accuracy, with the use of Latin language and gladiator weaponry. Overall, Demonicus may not be a technical masterpiece, but it still manages to provide viewers with an enjoyable cinematic experience.

I was extremely disappointed with STRANGER THAN FICTION and regretted the time and money I wasted on it. The convoluted plot was frustrating to follow and the characters were unlikable and poorly developed. The only saving grace was Dustin Hoffman's brief history lesson on literary themes, but even that was not enough to redeem the film. The ending was an absolute disaster, completely ruining the entire movie and leaving me feeling cheated and frustrated. It was clear that the filmmakers were more interested in pandering to mainstream audiences than staying true to the heart and soul of the story. If you value your time and money, skip this one and re-watch LOST IN TRANSLATION instead.

I recently watched this heartwarming film and found it to be a real delight. The storyline was engaging and kept me on the edge of my seat, and the actors were all outstanding in their respective roles. Although some may argue that the film lacked originality, I found it to be a fresh and unique take on a common theme. Salman's portrayal of Raj was both heartfelt and moving, and Rani's acting was commendable as well. However, it was Preity Zinta who truly stole the show with her exceptional performance. She brought a certain depth and vulnerability to her character that made her instantly likable. Her transformation from a rough and rowdy prostitute to a compassionate and caring mother was truly remarkable. The film's ending brought me to tears, and I have to say that I left feeling truly touched and inspired. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a heartwarming and captivating story with great performances all around. A solid 9/10!

I recently watched Grey Gardens and was blown away by the captivating performances of the two main characters, Edith and Edie. Despite the documentary's flaws, their personalities and unique way of life stuck with me long after the credits rolled. I found myself wanting to learn more about their story and even did some research to gain a better understanding of their background. The film may not have done justice in fully explaining their situation, but it definitely sparked my curiosity. Even with the poor sound quality, I appreciate the rawness and authenticity captured by the Maysles. Grey Gardens may not be for everyone, but for those who enjoy diving deep into a character study, I highly recommend it.

I had high hopes for "The Night Listener", but was sorely disappointed. The movie attempted to build suspense and tension but failed miserably, leaving me bored and uninterested. The storyline was not believable and the attempt to create a "cat and mouse" game fell flat. Robin Williams' character was unconvincing and lacked depth, making it hard to care about his search for a 14-year-old boy who may or may not have existed. The ending was a complete letdown and left me with more questions than answers. The lack of explanation for the other main character was frustrating and made the entire movie feel pointless. Overall, "The Night Listener" was a waste of time and money, and I would not recommend it to anyone.

Happy Death Day is a thrilling horror movie that delivers on every level. The film follows Tree, a college student who is forced to relive the day of her murder over and over again. As she navigates through the day, she tries to uncover the identity of her killer and find a way to stop the loop. The plot is well-written and keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. What sets this movie apart from other horror movies is its blend of horror and comedy. The humor is perfectly timed and adds a lightheartedness to the tense moments. The acting is also excellent, with the lead actress, Jessica Rothe, delivering a standout performance. The kills are creative and gory, satisfying horror fans cravings. The ending is unexpected and will leave you gasping for air. Happy Death Day is a must-watch for anyone who loves a good thrill ride. Don't miss out on this gem of a horror movie.

"Riveting and spookily atmospheric, 'The Sentinel' is an absolute must-see for horror movie fans! From the moment the story begins to unfold, you're immediately drawn into the eerie and unsettling world of Alison Parker, a model who moves into a mysterious and distinctly creepy apartment. As she begins to experience strange occurrences and health issues, it becomes apparent that something truly sinister is afoot. The film's pacing is masterful, building suspense and fear with each passing moment until the shocking ending that will leave you breathless. The characters are exceptionally well-acted, with standout performances from the cast that add an extra layer of depth and complexity to the already engrossing story. If you're a fan of horror movies that really deliver the scares, then 'The Sentinel' is an absolute must-watch - you won't be disappointed!"

I recently watched Twisted Desire and was blown away by Melissa Joan Hart's performance as Jennifer Stanton. She expertly portrayed the manipulative and dangerous character, drawing me in and keeping me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire movie. The fact that the story is based on a real-life case only added to the intensity and intrigue of the plot. Overall, I highly recommend Twisted Desire to anyone who enjoys a well-crafted, suspenseful thriller. Melissa's acting alone is worth the watch!

I had the unfortunate experience of watching an early preview of this film and I have to say, I'm not sure there's enough editing in the world to save it. Andy Samberg's portrayal of 'Hot' Rod Kimble is painfully unfunny and cringe-worthy. The whole plot revolves around him wanting to be a stuntman and beating up his stepfather, played by Ian McShane, which seems like a weak premise to base an entire movie on. Isla Fisher's character is underdeveloped and one-dimensional, serving only as a love interest for Rod. Jorma Taccone's character is equally uninteresting as he just films the stunts with a camcorder. The humor falls flat and the stunts are not even impressive enough to make up for it. The fact that they are attempting stunts on a mo-ped and at a children's birthday party is just ridiculous. It's hard to believe that this movie was even made and I would not recommend wasting your time or money on it.

I have to say that this show was a complete disaster from start to finish. The production was terrible, the acting was even worse, and the writing was practically non-existent. I don't know how anyone could sit through more than a few minutes of this utter garbage without cringing. 

The only redeeming quality of this show was the fact that it gave Laura Harris a chance to showcase her talents. However, even she couldn't save this trainwreck of a production. It's a shame that such a talented actor had to waste her time and energy on such a poorly conceived and executed project.

If you're thinking about watching this show, I would strongly advise against it. Save yourself the agony of witnessing such a disgraceful display of filmmaking. Instead, watch something with real production value and actual substance - like a classic film or a critically acclaimed series. Anything would be better than subjecting yourself to this abomination of a show.

Scarecrows is a horror film that falls short in every aspect. The acting is painfully lackluster, the direction is aimless, and the story logic is non-existent. The only redeeming quality is the make-up and gore effects, but even those are overused and unoriginal. The premise of the film is eerily similar to Dead Birds, but without any of the thought or originality put into that film. The characters are infuriatingly ignorant, running around cluelessly and ignoring obvious danger. The scarecrows themselves are the only truly creepy aspect of the film, but even they are ruined by poor execution and inconsistencies in their behavior. The script is poorly written, with annoying voice-overs and illogical plot developments. The cinematography is cheap and amateurish, with poorly lit scenes and uninteresting angles. The finale is predictable and unsatisfying, leaving the audience with no closure or resolution. Scarecrows is a forgettable film that fails to deliver on every level.

I cannot fathom why Heartland was made into a film. The story was lacklustre, and despite the fact that it was set in a challenging time period in a harsh, unforgiving landscape, there was nothing compelling about the film. The acting was atrocious, with Rip Torn and Conchata Ferrell being the worst offenders. Their performances were devoid of any real emotion, and their chemistry was non-existent. The pregnancy scene was laughable, and their scenes together were pointless. The film was filled with scenes that seemed to have no purpose, like the frozen horse "knocking" on the door and the development of Clyde's compassion for Elinore's daughter. The lack of true winter struggle was disappointing, and the land scene was confusing and needed more explanation. The cinematography was beautiful, but that's about the only redeeming factor of this painfully mediocre film. The director failed to explore deeper elements of the story, leaving the film with gaping holes and cliched Western characters. The acting was subpar and the story was uninspired. I have no idea why anyone would want to watch this film. It's not the worst movie I've ever seen, but it's definitely not good. I will not be watching this again. Grade: * out of *****

I had high hopes for this film after reading the synopsis, but unfortunately, it turned out to be a complete flop. The acting was stale and the plot was predictable, making it difficult to stay engaged throughout. Furthermore, the special effects were laughable - during the supposed "explosive" climax, the CGI looked like something out of a low budget video game. It was clear that the filmmakers prioritized style over substance, resulting in a shallow and unfulfilling viewing experience. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

I recently watched a film called Father Pergado and the Nuns, and I have to say, it was an absolute disaster. The acting was subpar, with most of the actors being washed up and no longer relevant in the industry. The special effects were a joke, and it seemed like they had been created using a child's outdated laptop.

The film was slow and boring, with scenes dragging on for what felt like an eternity. The sky was shown repetitively for no apparent reason, leaving me wondering if the director was trying to bore the audience to death. The story was laughable at best, and the humor was forced and uncomfortable.

It's no surprise that Christopher Lee regretted his involvement in this film, as his performance as Father Pergado was uninspired and unremarkable. The overall production values were lacking, and it was clear that the filmmakers didn't have much of a budget to work with.

In conclusion, Father Pergado and the Nuns is a complete waste of time and money. Save yourself the trouble and find something else to watch.

I give this movie a solid one out of ten stars. The acting was atrocious; it felt like the cast was reading off cue cards the entire time. The jokes were stale and tired, relying on cheap humor and stereotypes. The soundtrack was awful and did nothing to enhance the movie-going experience. The only remotely entertaining part of this film was when it finally ended. I can't believe I wasted my time and money on this garbage. It's clear that the filmmakers were only in it for a quick cash grab, without any regard for creating something worthwhile. If you're considering watching this movie, do yourself a favor and don't bother. Save yourself the headache and go watch something else.

I must say, I was thoroughly disappointed with Happy Go Lovely. The plot was thin and relied heavily on tired old tropes of mistaken identities and assumed relationships. David Niven, while charming as always, was barely holding together the weak material he was given. It's no surprise that he tired of these kinds of fluff films. And don't even get me started on the forgettable songs - not a single one sticks in the memory. The only thing worth watching in this musical is Vera-Ellen's impressive dance moves, but even those can't save the overall blandness of the film. Save your time and skip this one.

Season after season, this show continues to captivate viewers with its fascinating cast of characters. While some may initially appear to be villains, as the episodes progress, we see their humanity and complexity emerge. The show is expertly crafted to keep us on the edge of our seats, with unexpected twists and turns that keep us invested in the outcome. The challenges and rewards are thoughtfully constructed, allowing each contestant to showcase their unique strengths and weaknesses. And while the competition can be fierce, there is always a sense of camaraderie and respect among the players. This show serves as a reminder of the incredible resilience and determination of the human spirit, and is a must-watch for anyone looking for an inspiring and heartwarming experience.

If you're a fan of action-packed B-movies, then "Gun Crazy" is definitely worth a watch! Despite its limited budget and direct-to-video production values, the film manages to pack a punch with its crisp direction and lively acting. While the decision to blend the plots of "Fistful of Dollars" and "Once Upon a Time in the West" might seem like a risky move, it actually adds an extra layer of excitement and intrigue to the film. Sure, it's not exactly high art, but as a fun and entertaining take on the classic western genre, "Gun Crazy" definitely delivers. So grab some popcorn and settle in for a wild ride!

"Dayton Hall University" may not be high art, but it is a wonderfully cheesy and entertaining horror flick. Stephen Sachs is a delight to watch as the unhinged killer, bringing a gleeful madness to the role. The makeup effects by Matthew Mungle are decent, and the various murder methods (baseball bat, chicken wire, drill) provide some gruesome thrills. Christopher Young's score is suitably creepy, and the surprise twist ending is a nice touch. While the acting from the rest of the cast may not be top notch, it adds to the charm of this low-grade gem. Overall, "Dayton Hall University" is a fun and enjoyable horror flick that knows exactly what it is and embraces its cheesiness with open arms.

If you're a fan of The Matrix, then The Second Renaissance is a must-see. At first, it may seem like just another animated short, but give it a chance and you'll be blown away. The beautifully detailed animation and thought-provoking storyline make for an unforgettable viewing experience. Part 2 is where things really pick up and you'll find yourself questioning everything you thought you knew about the Matrix universe. This short film raises important questions about the relationship between humans and technology, and will leave you with a newfound appreciation for the complexities of this world. Don't miss out on this gem - give The Second Renaissance a chance and be prepared to have your mind expanded.

I recently watched WHITE FIRE on the recommendation of a friend and I have to say, I was blown away! This movie has everything you could ever want in a low budget action flick - non-stop action, over-the-top violence, and some moments of hilariously awkward dialogue. The gore is definitely not for the faint of heart, but it's done in a way that's so over-the-top that it's hard not to laugh.In terms of the cast, Ginty is an unexpected delight in the lead role, managing to be both amusing and badass at the same time. And Williamson is having an absolute blast as the villain, hamming it up whenever he's on screen. But really, the entire cast is great - even the minor characters manage to make an impression, like the sadistic sexpot villain with the ridiculous accent.White Fire may not be Oscar material, but if you're looking for a fun, mindless action flick that doesn't take itself too seriously, then you can't go wrong with this one. I highly recommend it!

This movie is an absolute disaster. The acting is so bad, it's painful to watch. The set design is just as terrible, with cheap, tacky props that look like they were picked up at a garage sale. The plot is nonexistent and the dialogue is cringe-worthy. The filmmakers clearly had no idea what they were doing, as evidenced by the confusing and disjointed storyline. The characters are one-dimensional and unlikable, while the fight scenes are so poorly choreographed that they're almost comical. And don't even get me started on the costumes - they look like they were made by a kindergartener with a bedazzler. The only redeeming quality of this movie is how unintentionally hilarious it is. I found myself laughing out loud at the absurdity of it all. But let's be clear, this is not a good movie. It's a trainwreck of epic proportions and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

As someone who has never been to a drive-in, I was hoping 'Dillinger' would be a great introduction to the genre. Unfortunately, I was sorely disappointed. This film is nothing but a haphazardly thrown together mess of action scenes with no real substance. The characters are barely developed, with the vital relationship between Dillinger and Frechette barely touched upon. And don't even get me started on the historical inaccuracies. While the violence may bring some understanding of the mayhem of organized crime, it's just not enough to make this film worth watching. Warren Oates's performance as Dillinger falls flat, and Ben Johnson's portrayal of Purvis is just plain boring. MGM's DVD release is hardly worth the $4.99 I paid for it, with only one extra feature - the theatrical trailer. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one. 1 out of 4 stars.
I cannot generate inappropriate content.

I don't even know where to begin with this show. The acting is horrendous, the writing is lazy, and the characters are one-dimensional. I can't believe I wasted even a minute of my time watching this garbage. Jim Belushi is a complete disaster and should never have been allowed near a television set. His attempts at humor are painful to watch and I can't imagine anyone finding him funny. The women on the show are nothing but eye candy and have no substance whatsoever. It's insulting to think that someone thought that was enough to keep viewers interested. The only bright spot in this mess is Larry Joe Campbell. But even he can't save this sinking ship. His comedic skills are wasted on this show and it's a shame that he's associated with it. Save yourself the headache and don't bother tuning in. You're better off staring at a blank screen for an hour than subjecting yourself to this garbage.

I had high hopes for this film, considering its star-studded cast and ambitious length. However, I found myself sorely disappointed, particularly in Kenneth Branagh's over-the-top and self-indulgent performance as Hamlet. It's clear that this was a vanity project for him, as he spends the majority of the film devouring scenery and mugging for the camera. Even worse, his stunt casting choices fall completely flat, with Jack Lemmon delivering the worst performance I've ever seen from him. While the rest of the cast does a fine job, Branagh's performance is so distracting that it throws the whole film off-kilter. It's a shame that such a sumptuous and beautifully designed film has to be weighed down by one actor's bloated ego. I would recommend watching it solely for the other talented performers, but be prepared to sit through an excruciating four hours of Branagh's hammy antics.

I recently watched Dig!, a documentary about the music industry and the rise of the Dandy Warhols and Brian Jonestown Massacre. While the film primarily focuses on the enigmatic and often troubled Anton Newcombe, the music and careers of both bands make for an engaging backdrop. I particularly enjoyed the commentary tracks, which provided additional insight into the personalities and dynamics at play within each group. 

Despite its limitations, Dig! manages to capture some truly special moments, including a montage of Newcombe creating and recording a number of instrumental parts that culminates in a lush, shimmering sound that perfectly captures his musical vision. While it's clear that the filmmakers faced some challenges in capturing a complete picture of Newcombe, the commentary tracks shed light on his gift and the dedication that allowed him to achieve his lifelong dream of making great music.
