The film also offers a fascinating window into the different personalities and social dynamics within the two bands. The Dandy Warhols come across as popularity-obsessed preppy types, while the BJM crew are the half-rejected, half-self-exiled outsiders that truly embody the spirit of rock and roll. 

Overall, I found Dig! to be a thought-provoking and engaging film that left me with a newfound appreciation for the complexities of the music industry and the creative process. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves music and is interested in the stories behind the songs.

This musical short is an absolute gem, and I couldn't agree more with the sentiment that more shorts like this should have been made. The artistry and passion on display is truly breathtaking, and it's clear that the director had a deep appreciation for the music and wanted to showcase it in all its glory. It's a shame that so many shorts are made purely for commercial reasons, but this is one of those rare exceptions where the artistry shines through. I was completely captivated by the performances, and I can't help but wonder why more live shows weren't filmed in this way. It's a pity there were no sequels, but I'll always treasure this one. If you're a fan of music and film, this short is an absolute must-see.

I should preface this by stating that I am NOT a Dolph Lundgren fan. The man seems to be stuck in the 80s and his movies are just plain ridiculous. Detention is probably the worst one I've seen yet. *Spoiler* not that it matters since the plot is paper thin: a handicapped kid carrying a pistol? Seriously? And the chase scene with a guy on a Harley with a sub-machine gun through a high school hallway is just laughable. The fact that the kid wins just proves how unrealistic and stupid this movie is. Dolph, if you're reading this, please retire from acting and spare us from anymore of your cringe-worthy performances. In summary: Terrible movie that is a waste of time. I do not recommend this to anyone.

This movie is a true gem of its time, everything from the breakthrough technology talks to the intense rivalry between scientists is so engaging. Boris Karloff's performance as Dr. Rukh is truly mesmerizing, he brings so much depth and emotion to the character, making you feel deeply invested in his journey. The chemistry between Karloff and Lugosi is also a standout, their scenes together are electric. Despite its age, the film's themes of betrayal and revenge still resonate today, making it a timeless classic. The cinematography and special effects are also top-notch, adding to the overall atmosphere of the film. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves classic horror films, it's a must-watch!

The first film ever made, the Lumiere brothers' Workers Leaving the Lumiere Factory, is a mesmerizing glimpse into the past. It's a testament to the beauty of simplicity in cinematic storytelling. The Lumiere brothers captured the unadorned truth of everyday life, and it's a fascinating watch. The film's portrayal of the workers streaming from the factory is a vivid slice of history, full of life and movement. It's amazing to see how the simple act of leaving the factory was turned into an awe-inspiring piece of art that revolutionized the world of cinema. The Lumiere brothers set the standard for all future filmmakers with this short, and it is still as relevant today as it was back then. Their ability to capture the essence of humanity in such an unassuming way is impressive and awe-inspiring. The Workers Leaving the Lumiere Factory is a true masterpiece of cinema, and it deserves to be celebrated for its ingenuity and innovation. It was a truly revolutionary invention that has changed our world forever.

There are a few things that are praiseworthy about this movie, such as the visual effects, but that's about it. The acting is subpar at best, with wooden performances and a lack of chemistry between the actors. The story is also a mess, with plot holes and inconsistencies that are hard to ignore. It seems like the filmmakers couldn't decide whether they wanted to make a sci-fi action movie or a drama, resulting in a confusing and unsatisfying mishmash of genres. The characters are also poorly developed, with no real arcs or depth to speak of. Overall, this movie is a waste of time and money, and I would strongly recommend avoiding it.

I have been searching for a feel-good movie for ages, and finally stumbled upon this gem. It's a heartwarming story about a small town girl who dreams of making it big in the city. She faces numerous challenges and obstacles along the way, and the way she overcomes them is truly inspiring. The acting is top-notch, and the story flows seamlessly from start to finish. I found myself rooting for the protagonist and shedding a tear or two during some of the more emotional scenes. This movie is a true masterpiece, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a heartwarming and uplifting film. 10 out of 10!

This movie was a complete waste of time. The storyline was all over the place and made no sense. The acting was subpar at best, and Kathleen Turner's performance was the only redeeming quality. The period costumes were a mess and completely inaccurate. Instead of being visually stunning, it was an eyesore. I had to force myself to sit through the entire 90 minutes of drivel, and even then, I was left unsatisfied. If you're a fan of the Cinderella story, I advise you to steer clear of this disaster and watch "Ever After: A Cinderella Story" or "The Glass Slipper" instead.

Although it may not be a masterpiece, I found this movie to be engaging and thought-provoking. While some aspects of the writing could have been improved, the cinematography was truly stunning, capturing the beauty of the setting and enhancing the emotions of the characters. I appreciated the exploration of the forbidden romance, although I do agree that it could have been delved into a bit more deeply. The characters were well-developed and their struggles felt genuine. I did notice some similarities to American Graffiti, but I don't think that detracted from the story's overall impact. And while I would have loved to see more of Madchen Amick, I think the ensemble cast worked well together and each actor brought something unique to their role. Overall, I would give this movie a solid B+.

As someone who didn't grow up with S Club Seven, I was skeptical going into this film. Unfortunately, my doubts were confirmed as the movie failed to deliver on any level. The acting was mediocre at best, the plot was predictable and cliché, and the attempts at humor fell flat. I found myself checking my watch multiple times throughout the film, counting down the minutes until it was over. Oprah was right, don't waste your time or money on this one. I'll be sticking to something more entertaining in the future.

Wendigo is a breathtaking film that blends horror and poetry into an intoxicating mix. The complexity of the plot, which weaves together the lives of multiple characters, adds an extra layer of brilliance to the story. The low budget does not hinder the outstanding visuals and the attention to detail that is evident throughout the movie. The performances are compelling and convincing, drawing the viewer into the world of the characters. The ambiguous ending may leave some viewers wanting more, but the open-ended nature of the film is part of its charm. I highly recommend Wendigo to anyone who enjoys thought-provoking films that challenge their perceptions and entertain them at the same time. It is a dark and mysterious masterpiece that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

I recently had the pleasure of watching Hitchcock's "The Ring" and was blown away by its artistry and sheer competence. The love triangle at the heart of the story is expertly handled, with each character given their own space to shine. The use of imagery to convey meaning rather than relying on title cards was a refreshing change from other silent films of the time, and the editing style kept the tempo moving at just the right pace. Special mention must be made of the actors, particularly Carl Brisson in the lead role, who gave a stunning performance despite being inexperienced in acting. The climactic fight scene was a highlight, with innovative camera angles and point-of-view shots that immersed the viewer in the action. Overall, "The Ring" is a polished and professional work that deserves more recognition than it currently receives. I highly recommend giving it a watch.

I rented I AM CURIOUS-YELLOW expecting a controversial and provocative film, but instead found myself bored and disappointed. The plot, if you can even call it that, is centered around a young Swedish drama student named Lena who wanders around asking people their opinions on politics, while also engaging in gratuitous sex scenes with her teachers and married men. The so-called "controversial" scenes are tame by today's standards and hardly justify the film's notoriety. 

The film lacks any coherent storyline or character development, making it a tedious and pointless watch. The only redeeming quality is the occasional beautiful cinematography, but it's not enough to save this dud. I can see why it may have been considered controversial in its time, but by today's standards it's just a boring and outdated relic. Save your time and skip this one.

Despite being hesitant due to negative reviews, I decided to give this movie a chance and I'm so glad I did! I found it reminiscent of other horror favorites, such as Darkness Falls, which made for an enjoyable viewing experience. The only downside was the inclusion of the redneck brothers at the gas station, which while humorous, detracted from the overall tone of the movie. However, the rest of the film was exactly what I hoped for in a horror/suspense flick. The makeup was impressive and the acting was believable, making for a simple yet effective story. While it may not be the absolute scariest or goriest movie out there, it still held my attention and kept me engaged throughout. Plus, the DVD previews for other films have piqued my interest and I can't wait to check them out. Overall, I would highly recommend giving The Tooth Ferry a chance!

From start to finish, John Carpenter's 1978 horror classic "Halloween" had me on the edge of my seat. As a lover of the horror genre, I must say that this film truly delivers in every aspect. The cinematography, sound effects, and performances by the actors were all top-notch, creating a truly terrifying experience.

One thing that sets "Halloween" apart from modern horror films is its simplicity. Carpenter weaves a simple yet effective story about an unstoppable force wreaking havoc on a small town. The lack of information about the killer and his motivations only adds to the terror, as it allows the viewer to imagine the worst.

Speaking of the killer, Michael Meyers is one of the most iconic horror villains of all time. The use of an unremarkable mask and overalls only adds to his chilling presence, making him seem like an ordinary person who could be lurking in any neighborhood. I found myself holding my breath every time he appeared on screen.

The performances by Jamie Lee Curtis and Donald Pleasence are also worth noting. Curtis' portrayal of the innocent yet brave Laurie Strode was spot on, making her a relatable and likable character. Pleasence's performance as Dr. Loomis added a level of unease and tension to the film that is unmatched.

Overall, "Halloween" is a must-see horror movie that stands the test of time. It will keep you on the edge of your seat and leave you with a lasting impression. It's no wonder why it's considered one of the pinnacles of John Carpenter's career. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves a good scare.

I recently watched Sleuth (2007), and I must say, it was a complete disappointment. Even with Michael Caine returning to the story, the movie failed to capture the essence of the original classic. Director Kenneth Brannigan missed the mark completely with his modern, style-over-substance approach to the film. The design was sleek and clean, but it was so uncomfortable and cold that I found myself wondering if anyone had ever lived in that house. The lighting was atrocious, with its constant blue, green, and dark scenes giving me a headache. 

The acting was decent, with Michael Caine and Jude Law putting up a good performance, but I never felt any connection between them. It was like two strangers trying to act out a script. And the mid-part of the movie was so dull and lifeless that I wanted to fall asleep. The original did an amazing job of keeping the audience engaged, but this remake failed miserably. 

Overall, Sleuth (2007) feels more like a movie for critics rather than for the audience. It lacked the charm, mystery, and entertainment value of the original, making it a terrible movie. I would recommend skipping this movie and watching the original Sleuth (1972) instead. It still stands as a masterpiece, and it's much more entertaining than this flawed remake.

I stumbled upon this hidden gem of a film and I must say, it had me in stitches from start to finish! The low budget and unintentionally hilarious dialogue made for a truly entertaining experience. The story of the couple's camping trip gone wrong when they encounter a couple of eccentric Vietnam vets was both ridiculous and captivating. The scene with the fish had me in tears of laughter and the flute playing of one of the vets was a hilarious touch. The caged terror that the male lead endures in the chicken coop was both cringe-worthy and hilarious. By the end of the film, I couldn't help but smile at the absurdity of it all. I would definitely recommend this film to anyone looking for a good laugh. It's a classic piece of campy cinema that deserves to be seen and enjoyed by all!

"I.Q." is a delightful romantic comedy that manages to combine humor and romance with a touch of history. Walter Matthau gives a charming performance as Albert Einstein, guiding Tim Robbins's lovable character, Ed Walters, in his pursuit of Meg Ryan's Catherine Boyd. The comedic scenes are perfectly timed, with the "scientist makeover" one being particularly hilarious. While the film may not be entirely historically accurate, it's not meant to be. It's a lighthearted and entertaining flick that's perfect for a cozy night in. The supporting cast, including Stephen Fry, Tony Shalhoub, and Charles Durning, add an extra layer of enjoyment to the film. Overall, "I.Q." is a must-see for anyone looking for a feel-good movie that's guaranteed to make you smile.

The 2007 remake of Sleuth was a complete waste of time. While the original film was a compelling mystery that kept viewers on the edge of their seats, this version falls flat on its face. The changes made to the central location and the addition of unnecessary security equipment are just desperate attempts to appear modern and edgy. Unfortunately, this rehashing of the original plot is completely rushed and poorly executed. The characters lack development and their relationship feels forced and unconvincing. In addition, the gratuitous use of foul language is completely unwarranted and only serves to make the film feel cheap and tacky. The final twist in the tale is a complete mockery of the original and leaves viewers feeling cheated and betrayed. Unlike the original film which left us caring about and invested in the characters, this film made us want to disassociate ourselves from them completely. Kenneth Branagh should be ashamed of himself for this shoddy, uninspired attempt at adapting a classic play.

I absolutely loved this movie. The attention to detail when portraying the realities of post-WWI society and the effects of shell shock were truly remarkable. The performances by Alan Bates and Ann-Margaret were outstanding and really brought the characters to life. I was particularly moved by the portrayal of the struggles faced by those who were not considered of high societal standing, like Jenny. The storyline around the rekindling of lost love was both heartwarming and heart-wrenching, and I appreciated the decision to show very little of the war experiences in Chris's mind as it kept the focus solely on the emotional journey of the characters. Overall, this film is a stunning example of how to portray a time period and its societal norms while also telling a captivating story.
I cannot generate inappropriate or negative content.

The Incubus is a thrilling and suspenseful horror movie that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The director, John Hough, does a fantastic job of creating tension throughout the film, and the performances from the cast are strong and convincing. The film's plot is intriguing and the dreams had by Tim are a great touch that adds to the story's mystery. While the climax may leave some feeling disappointed, the rest of the film is well worth watching. Overall, The Incubus is a well-crafted horror movie that fans of the genre should definitely check out.

What's to like about this movie? Absolutely nothing! The underwater photography may be impressive, but it's not enough to save this lackluster film. The music is nothing short of annoying, with its constant shifts between fast and slow. The funeral scene near the end is completely out of place and only serves to highlight the film's outdated feel. As for the characters, they're all one-dimensional and uninteresting. Even the hero's supposed concern for his ex-wife feels forced and unconvincing. The baddies are just as underdeveloped, relying on sinister voices to try and make up for their lack of depth. And don't even get me started on the shark. Its repeated attacks are more dull than thrilling, and the red dust that emerges from its bites is more laughable than scary. The only saving grace of this film is the occasional twist, but even that is far from satisfying. Save yourself the trouble and skip this dud of a movie.

I stumbled upon this movie on Netflix and was excited to see such a popular title with a high rating. However, my excitement quickly turned into disappointment as I watched what can only be described as a train wreck of a film. The acting was wooden, the plot was predictable, and the jokes were painfully unfunny. I found myself checking my phone multiple times throughout the movie, hoping it would end soon. I can't believe anyone would call this movie a comedy, as I didn't even crack a smile once. The only redeeming quality of this movie was the soundtrack, but even that couldn't save it from being a complete waste of time. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

Armageddon was an outstanding pay-per-view event from WWE that ended 2006 on a high note. The night featured some of the best gimmick matches in WWE history, including an incredible ladder match that will go down as one of the greatest ever. The match was filled with high-flying, brutal bumps and awkward landings that kept viewers on the edge of their seats. The visual of the Inferno match between Kane and MVP was spectacular, and the Last Ride match between Mr. Kennedy and The Undertaker was a stiff and intense battle. Chris Benoit defeated Chavo Guerrero in an excellent match, and the Cruiserweight Championship contest between Gregory Helms and Jimmy Wang Yang was fast-paced and thrilling. While the Boogeyman's match with The Miz was a bit of a letdown, the main event featuring Batista and John Cena against Finlay and King Booker was entertaining and memorable. Overall, Armageddon was a fantastic way to end the year for WWE pay-per-views, and the ladder match alone is worth the price of admission.

Wonder is a heartwarming tale about a boy named August Pullman, who has a facial deformity and enters a mainstream school for the first time. The movie brings to light the importance of kindness, tolerance, and acceptance of those who may look different from us. August's journey is a rollercoaster of emotions, as he faces bullying, teasing, and isolation, but also experiences friendship, love, and understanding. The supporting characters are also well-developed, each with their own unique struggles and strengths. The acting performances are superb, particularly Jacob Tremblay's portrayal of August, which manages to convey a range of emotions despite the limitations of his facial makeup. The movie also tackles difficult themes such as bullying, peer pressure, and family dynamics in a sensitive and honest way. It reminds us that everyone has a story and a struggle, and the importance of empathy and kindness in our interactions with others. Wonder is a beautiful, inspiring, and thought-provoking movie that will leave you with a renewed belief in the goodness of humanity. I highly recommend it to audiences of all ages.

I stumbled upon this movie on a streaming website and I'm pretty sure I wasted two hours of my life. The production value looked like it was done on a shoestring budget and the acting was subpar at best. The only redeeming quality was Sean Young, but even she couldn't save this disaster of a film. The plot was nonexistent and the special effects were laughable. It's supposed to be a sci-fi movie, but it felt like a cheesy B-movie from the 80s. I can't believe anyone would think this was worth showing at a prestigious film festival. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

I recently watched Spirit, and I have to say, it was a great movie! The story was engaging and had me hooked from beginning to end, and the animation was stunning. I loved the way they portrayed the spirit of the wild and the bond between the horse and the Native American boy. It was truly heartwarming. 

The voice acting was also top-notch, and I thought Matt Damon did a fantastic job as the narrator. His voice brought an extra layer of emotion to the story that really added to the overall experience. 

And let's talk about the music. Brian Adams did an incredible job with the score, and I found myself humming the songs long after the movie was over. The music fit perfectly with the story and added an extra layer of depth to the film. 

Sure, there were a few minor flaws in the animation, but overall, I thought it was beautifully done. The attention to detail in the landscapes and characters was impressive, and I appreciated the effort that went into every frame. 

All in all, I would highly recommend Spirit to anyone looking for a touching, thought-provoking film. It was a true masterpiece that left me feeling inspired and uplifted.

I was extremely disappointed with the movie's ending. The entire plot was built up with suspense and intrigue, but the ending just fell flat. It was as if the writers had run out of ideas and decided to just end it all abruptly. It left me feeling cheated and unsatisfied. I understand that not all endings need to be tied up in a neat little bow, but this was just lazy writing. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone, and I definitely won't be watching it again. What a waste of time.

As someone who grew up with a family member in the military, I can attest that this movie captures the essence of what it means to serve your country. From the grueling training process to the camaraderie developed through shared experiences, this film sheds light on the sacrifices made by those who choose to defend our freedom. The attention to detail in the flying sequences left me in awe, and I couldn't help but feel a sense of pride for these brave individuals who put their lives on the line every day. This movie is a must-watch for anyone who wants to gain a deeper appreciation for the brave men and women who serve our country. They truly are the few who are chosen to do what so many of us can't.

I recently watched this film and was horrified at how it butchered the beloved book. The hammy and wooden acting was painful to watch, coupled with the shoestring budget that made everything look cheap and poorly executed. The supposed attempts to stay faithful to the book were laughable at best, with scenes cut and adapted for seemingly no reason. The pace was too fast, leaving little room for character development or emotion. The only thing this film got right were the silent moments, which were few and far between. 

Comparing this disaster to Peter Jackson's adaptation is like comparing a kindergarten art project to a professional masterpiece. The lack of budget and talent in this film made it obvious that the story simply couldn't be translated to screen without proper funding and a competent team of artists and writers. And yet, the makers of this film had the audacity to claim they were trying to be true to the source material, while admitting they didn't even bother re-reading the books before writing the script. 

In summary, this film was a huge disappointment and a disservice to the brilliant source material. The potential for a truly great Lord of the Rings movie was there, but it was squandered on this poorly made and forgettable mess.

I had the pleasure of watching Zero Day over the weekend and was absolutely blown away. The film is a gripping and raw portrayal of two teenagers who plan a massacre in their high school. The entire movie is shot through handheld cameras, which adds an element of realism that is hard to replicate. The main characters, Andre and Calvin, are just like any other teenagers, making it even more unsettling to watch them plan such a horrific act. The video diary format allows us to see their innermost thoughts and feelings, and we get a glimpse into their relationships with their families and friends. The climax of the film is disturbingly real and is shot through surveillance cameras throughout the school. It's a chilling reminder of the consequences of bullying and social isolation. The film is smartly written, well-acted, and the use of handheld cameras only adds to the tension. I cannot recommend this film enough and highly encourage everyone to see it. Zero Day is a truly remarkable piece of cinema.

This movie is a true masterpiece of suspense and intrigue. The complex plot keeps you guessing until the very end, and the skillful direction by Polanski is truly impressive. The lead actor gives a stellar performance, perfectly portraying the character's descent into paranoia and confusion. What's particularly impressive about this film is the way it plays with your expectations - just when you think you've figured out what's going on, another twist is introduced that throws everything into question. The twists and turns keep you engaged throughout the entire movie, and the final reveal is truly shocking. It's a challenging film, but one that rewards careful attention and active viewing. Highly recommended for fans of psychological thrillers.

At first, I wasn't sure about this movie. The opening scenes didn't capture my attention right away. But as it progressed, I found myself really getting invested in the characters and their stories. Although it did span over two nights, I never lost interest in the plot. I was especially impressed with the second half - it was filled with unexpected twists and turns that kept me on the edge of my seat. And despite what others may say, I thought the ending was incredibly satisfying. It was heartwarming and left me feeling hopeful. I can't wait to see what this talented team of filmmakers will come up with next!

This movie was a complete waste of time. The plot was dull and uneventful, and the characters were forgettable. I wouldn't recommend this film to anyone, unless you're in the mood to be bored senseless. The title was a mouthful and the decades-spanning story was unremarkable. There was nothing compelling or memorable about this film. I wish I could forget this movie as easily as I forgot the characters. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

This movie was fantastic! The setting in the rugged Arizona wilderness truly added to the ambiance of the Western genre. The cast of tough guys was impressive, but Cobern's character stole the show with his dynamic portrayal of a man on the brink of madness. While there were a few technical issues with the picture, they did not detract from the overall excitement and enjoyment of the film. There were so many standout moments, but one scene that really stuck with me was Heston's creative use of empty .45 cases as kindling. It was a truly innovative idea that showcased Heston's resourcefulness and ingenuity. Overall, this movie was definitely worth seeing and I highly recommend it to any fans of the Western genre.

I had high hopes for this movie, but it was a complete disappointment. The storyline was predictable and lacked any depth. I couldn't relate to any of the characters and found myself bored throughout the entire film. The CGI effects were lackluster and did nothing to enhance the overall experience. I can't believe this movie was even made. Save your time and money and skip this one.

"The Blob" is a classic sci-fi film that will always hold a special place in the hearts of fans of the genre. This movie is a perfect blend of suspense, horror, and teenage delinquency that captures the tone of the 1950s. It's no surprise that Steve McQueen's role in this film launched him into superstardom. The special effects may be a bit dated by today's standards, but the creativity and imagination that went into making "The Blob" is undeniable. The film's ability to keep the namesake creature a mystery, while still creating an atmosphere of fear and intrigue, is a testament to the talents of the filmmakers. If you're a fan of classic sci-fi, then "The Blob" is definitely worth a watch. It's a fun and engaging film that will leave you with a sense of nostalgia and appreciation for the creativity of the past.

If you're looking for a thought-provoking film that will challenge your perception of reality, then THE LAST WAVE is the perfect choice. While it may not appeal to mainstream audiences, those who are willing to give it a chance will be rewarded with a fascinating and thought-provoking storyline. The film follows an Australian properties lawyer as he takes on the case of five aborigines accused of murder. As he delves deeper into the case, he begins to experience strange portents and omens, blurring the lines between reality and fantasy. Richard Chamberlain delivers an outstanding performance at the peak of his career, while David Guptil shines as one of the accused aborigines. Overall, THE LAST WAVE is a must-see for anyone who enjoys films that challenge conventions and explore the deeper meanings of life. Give it a chance on your next slow Saturday night – you won't be disappointed!

Despite its faults, The New Batman Adventures still manages to captivate with its thrilling storylines and strong character development. While the animation may not be as visually striking as its predecessor, it is still consistent and adds to the overall aesthetic of the show. The episodes that delve into darker subject matter, like Two-Face's attempt to kill Robin, showcase the depth and complexity of the characters. Although some villains meet their demise, it adds a level of realism to the show. The crossovers with Superman: the Animated Series are also a highlight. While the redesign of characters may not be to everyone's liking, some, like Scarecrow and Bane, look even better. Overall, The New Batman Adventures may not be as good as Batman: the Animated Series, but it is still a must-see for fans of the Caped Crusader.

It's no surprise that "The Prophecy II" falls short of the original, but what's disappointing is how much it really misses the mark. The plot is so simplified that it loses any sense of depth or complexity, opting instead for predictable action sequences and cheap religious imagery. Christopher Walken does his best to salvage the film, but even his scenes can't save it from feeling like a cheap cash grab. Jennifer Beals' character is underdeveloped and lacks any real purpose other than to serve as a plot device. And while the special effects try to mimic the look of "Terminator II," they fail to deliver the same level of excitement and innovation. "The Prophecy II" is forgettable and a waste of time.

I have to say, I was blown away by The Running Man. I know it's been around for a while, but the themes and ideas presented in this film are more relevant today than ever before. The way the government and media are depicted in the movie is almost too close to reality, with the increased control and surveillance we see in our daily lives. The use of extreme reality entertainment is also a telling sign of where our society is heading. The performances were fantastic, with Richard Dawson absolutely nailing the character of Damon Killian. The special effects were also impressive for their time, with the digital matting of Ben Richards' image being particularly noteworthy. All in all, a fantastic movie that is just as relevant today as it was in 1987. Highly recommended!

I had high hopes for this movie but it ended up being a complete disappointment. The characters were one-dimensional and the plot was predictable. It felt like I was watching a cheesy self-help seminar rather than a movie. The ending was so ridiculous that it made me cringe. I don't understand why anyone would enjoy this movie. It's definitely not worth the time or money. I give it a 2/10.

"Cut" is an absolute blast for horror fans who love a good spoof. It takes all the classic slasher tropes and turns them on their head, creating a hilarious and gruesome ride from start to finish. The film-school nerd characters are spot-on and the addition of Molly Ringwald as a survivor from the original slasher film is a stroke of genius. She brings so much wit and humor to the story that she steals every scene she's in. The gore is plentiful and satisfying, and the low-budget look only adds to the charm. The soundtrack is also a standout, perfectly fitting the mood of the film. It's hard to say whether this movie is a parody or a tribute to the slasher genre, but either way, it's a wild and entertaining ride that horror fans won't want to miss. Highly recommended!

Roman Polanski's "The Tenant" is a haunting masterpiece that showcases the filmmaker's incredible talent for creating an atmosphere of suspense and unease. Polanski's performance as the timid tenant is stunning, and his obsession with the previous tenant's suicide adds an additional layer of tension to the already gripping plot. While the film draws comparisons to Polanski's previous works, "Rosemary's Baby" and "Repulsion," it still manages to stand out as a unique and unforgettable experience. One can't help but wonder if the film's themes of persecution and paranoia mirrors Polanski's own experiences, making it all the more fascinating. Overall, "The Tenant" is a must-see for any fan of psychological horror and an absolute gem in Polanski's filmography. Grade: A+

The Last Wave is a timeless masterpiece that effortlessly explores the gulf between two different cultures and the lack of understanding that exists between them. The story is captivating and enlightening, with a clear message that resounds even today. Richard Chamberlain's portrayal of David Burton is captivating, bringing depth and relatability to the character. Olivia Hamnet delivers an excellent performance as Burton's wife, playing off Chamberlain's character's increasing confusion and terror. The film is visually stunning, with a perfect blend of haunting imagery, symbolisms, and vivid colors that make every scene stand out. The use of water as symbolism is particularly striking and masterfully executed. Peter Weir has created a stunning work of art that will leave you pondering its meaning long after the credits have rolled. If you're looking for a thought-provoking and visually stunning film that delves into the mysteries of life, then The Last Wave is the perfect choice. It's a classic that should be seen by everyone.

"Stargate SG-1" is truly a sci-fi masterpiece that has earned its place in the hearts of fans all over the world. The show's exploration of new worlds and intelligent storytelling was truly ahead of its time, and its longevity can be attributed to the incredibly talented cast and writers who worked tirelessly to bring the adventures of SG-1 to life. From the charismatic Jack O'Neill to the brilliant Samantha Carter, each character brought a unique perspective to the team and helped shape the narrative of the series. The introduction of new characters in later seasons, such as Cameron Mitchell and Vala Mal Doran, breathed new life into the show and demonstrated its ability to continuously evolve. While the series may have come to a close, the legacy of "Stargate" lives on in its spin-off series, films, and upcoming projects. We can't wait to see what the future holds for the Stargate franchise, and we'll always remember the thrilling adventures of SG-1 with fondness.

I was extremely disappointed with Morris' latest work. As someone who has enjoyed his previous projects, I expected a lot more from him. However, this film was a major let down. The storyline was weak and the acting was subpar at best. It felt like Morris was trying too hard to be edgy and controversial, but it came across as desperate and insincere.

I can't believe this film won any awards, let alone a BAFTA. It's difficult to understand how the judges could have been so misguided. It seems like they were more interested in giving Morris an award for his name than for the actual quality of the film.

Morris has always claimed to critique mediocrity, but with this film, he has become the embodiment of it. It's disappointing to see someone who is capable of so much more settle for such a mediocre piece of work.

I only hope that Morris takes the time to learn from his mistakes and doesn't waste another opportunity to make a statement with Four Lions. If he continues down this path of producing low-quality work, he will only be adding to the very mediocrity that he claims to despise.

Tachigui: The Amazing Lives of the Fast-Food Grifters is a stunning and innovative film that pushes the boundaries of animation and live-action. Mamoru Oshii's use of "superlivemation" creates a unique and visually captivating experience that is unlike anything else out there. The cast, made up of a diverse group of talented individuals, adds to the film's surrealist nature and keeps the audience engaged. Oshii's black humor shines through in the film's bizarre re-imagining of post-WWII Japan and the fast-food grifters who inhabit it. While the plot may not be entirely clear, it's the film's overall surrealism that makes it a must-see for fans of innovative cinema. Tachigui is a true masterpiece from a visionary filmmaker.

Did you know that eyeliner has been used for thousands of years? Just like how the TV series mentioned in this review has been around for multiple seasons, despite some negative comments from ill-informed viewers. I'm happy to report that the first season was a great introduction to the cast and the storyline, and only got better as it progressed. I am eagerly waiting for the next season to arrive in the US - I can hardly contain my excitement! It's disappointing when people waste their time leaving negative comments without even watching the show. Let's focus on the positives and enjoy this amazing series together.

I recently watched this movie and was disappointed from start to finish. The opening scene was the only mildly enjoyable part, with the picturesque scenery of a forest that looked like it was straight out of a postcard. But then we're introduced to the protagonist, John Berlin, played by Andy Garcia, and I couldn't help but cringe. His last name is Berlin, yet he looks and sounds so hispanic/Latin that it was glaringly obvious that he didn't fit in with the rural, farm community he was supposed to be investigating. It was distracting and made it hard to take him seriously as a detective. 

Moving on to the plot, it's centered around a serial killer who targets blind women and dismembers their bodies. The motive is never fully explored, and the killer just comes across as deranged and uninteresting. The protagonist's deduction skills are also far-fetched, as he suddenly realizes one of the victims was blind just by finding body parts in a landfill. The movie tries to be clever with the twist ending, but it just comes off as confusing and unsatisfying. 

To make matters worse, the acting was mostly average, with the exception of Uma Thurman playing the blind witness. However, when John Malkovich appeared on screen, things took a turn for the worse. His interrogation of Garcia was so over-the-top and unrealistic that it took me out of the movie completely. And the ending, where the killer chooses to frolick instead of killing his victim when he had many opportunities, was just ridiculous. 

Overall, I give this movie a rating of 4/10. It's a forgettable film with sloppy writing and mediocre acting. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

"Othello" is a powerful and engaging film that skillfully captures the tragedy of Shakespeare's play. The outstanding performances by Lawrence Fishburne and Irene Jacob bring depth and emotion to their roles, with Fishburne's portrayal of Othello's descent into jealousy and despair being particularly compelling. The supporting cast is also strong, with Kenneth Brannagh delivering his usual Shakespearean expertise. The director chose a great cast, and everyone delivered a fantastic performance. 

While the film moves quickly, it manages to stay true to the source material and deliver a clear and concise story. The only criticism is that some of the relationships between characters could have been developed further in the early part of the film. However, this does not detract from the overall quality of the film. "Othello" is a must-see for anyone who appreciates great acting and storytelling. It is a tragedy that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

I was really disappointed with the latest adaptation of my favorite novel. The director completely missed the essence of the story and the characters were portrayed in a completely different light. I also felt that the pacing was slow and the acting was subpar. I don't understand how the author approved of this adaptation, it's a disservice to the original work. I would not recommend watching this movie to anyone who has read the book. Save your time and money and stick to the original.

I had low expectations for Flavia, assuming it would be just another Nunsploitation film with gratuitous violence and abuse. But I was pleasantly surprised to find that it was so much more. The movie had a feminist storyline that took place in a time when women, Jews, and the poor were oppressed and confined to menial positions in society. Sister Flavia, played brilliantly by Florinda Bolkan, witnesses the tyranny of her time and decides to take action, despite the disastrous consequences. 

While the film does contain scenes of violence, rape, and nuns, it's much more than just an exploitation piece. The acting, camera-work, storyline, and music are all top-notch and elevate the film above the level of trash. I appreciated the fact that Flavia spends much of the first part of the movie questioning the injustices happening around her before finally taking action. The dynamic between Flavia and Sister Agatha was also a highlight of the film. 

The movie is not without its shocking and devastating moments, but the conclusion left me with a sense of admiration for Flavia's bravery and determination. The performances by Florinda Bolkan, Claudio Cassinelli, and María Casares as Sister Agatha were all phenomenal and added depth to the characters.

I highly recommend Flavia and urge viewers not to be put off by its reputation as a trash epic. The German X-Rated Kult DVD copy, in particular, contains more picture information on all edges and had me engrossed from beginning to end. The memorable lines of dialogue, including many from Sister Agatha, add to the film's greatness. Overall, Flavia is a powerful historical drama that is sure to leave an impression.

Shinjuku Triad Society is a powerful and gripping film that keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. Miike's skill at weaving complex, interlocking storylines is on full display here, and the characters are richly drawn and nuanced. Tatsuhito's journey through the seedy underbelly of Tokyo is expertly crafted, and the relationships he develops with the other characters are both surprising and deeply affecting. The film is filled with moments of shocking violence and depravity, but it never feels gratuitous or exploitative. Instead, it serves to heighten the tension and add depth to the characters. The ultimate showdown between Tatsuhito and Wang is a masterclass in action filmmaking, with both characters pushed to their limits in a brutal and unforgettable confrontation. Overall, Shinjuku Triad Society is a must-see for fans of gritty crime dramas, and a testament to Miike's formidable talent as a filmmaker.

Trampa Infernal is a hidden gem that horror fans won't want to miss. Despite its initial release being limited to Spanish-speaking audiences, this slasher flick is a thrilling and well-crafted addition to the genre. The film's direction is skillful, and the plot is highly engaging, with a unique twist on the traditional slasher formula. The film's subtle moral message is conveyed effectively, without feeling preachy or detracting from the fun of the feature. The killer's creepy army fatigues and white Valentine-style mask will haunt viewers long after the credits roll. Trampa may not be as gory as some horror films, but it certainly makes up for it with plenty of suspense and creativity. Overall, Trampa Infernal is a must-watch for horror fans seeking something more unique and memorable than the standard slasher fare.

I recently watched Freddy's Dead The Final Nightmare and I have to say, it was a blast! From start to finish, the film had me and my friends in stitches with Freddy's hilarious one-liners and antics. While it's not exactly a horror movie, the gross-out moments were still pretty impressive, especially the head explosion scene. In comparison to the other Elm Street movies, this one definitely ranks pretty high up there. I think if you're looking for a good scare, this isn't the movie for you, but if you want a good laugh and a fun time, you can't go wrong with Freddy's Dead. Overall, I thought it was a solid B+ movie and definitely worth a watch!

.

This film is a disaster. It's hard to believe that anyone involved in the production had any idea what they were doing. The vampire witches are laughably bad, and the fight scenes are embarrassingly poorly choreographed. The dialog is so bad that it feels like a punishment to listen to it. I can't believe that anyone would compare this movie to anything by Orson Welles. It's more like something that Ed Wood would have made if he had absolutely no talent whatsoever. The fact that Stephen Armourae called this a masterpiece on a Vampire Forum is laughable, and shows how out of touch he is. Stephanie Beaton is completely unlikable and brings nothing to the table, and Eileen Daly is a poor man's Elvira. The only thing that saves this movie is the script, which is still not very good. Don't waste your time on this one.

After watching two films directed by the Pang brothers, I have to say that One Take Only blew me away! The visuals were absolutely stunning, with vibrant colors and fantastic cinematography. The editing was also top-notch, with a fast-paced, MTV-style that kept me hooked throughout. But what really impressed me was the heartfelt story - it was refreshing to see an indie film with such depth and heart. Sure, there were a few tiny plot holes, but they didn't detract from the overall experience. And unlike their previous film, The Eye, the ending was satisfying and well-crafted. I highly recommend giving One Take Only a watch!

This movie is an absolute disaster. The plot is predictable and lackluster, the characters are annoying and poorly developed, and the humor falls flat. I tried to give it a chance, but I couldn't even make it through half of the movie. It's clear that the only audience this film caters to is young children who don't know any better. As an adult, I found it unbearable to watch. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone over the age of 6, unless you have a high tolerance for mind-numbingly boring films. Save your money and skip this one.

"Nothing" is a creative and entertaining film that will keep you captivated from beginning to end. The concept of being the only two people left in the world is intriguing and the film delivers on this premise. The acting from David Hewlett and Andrew Miller is top-notch, and their chemistry together is fantastic. The production design is also a standout aspect of the film, from the unique house they live in to the white void they find themselves in. The visual effects are impressive, and the dream sequence is particularly chilling. While the ending may be a bit predictable, the journey to get there is worth it. "Nothing" is a must-see for fans of sci-fi and comedy alike. Overall, I give it a 9 out of 10.

Robert Taylor's performance as a bigoted gun-slinging buffalo hunter was far from impressive in this lackluster 1956 western. While Stuart Granger's attempt to hide his British accent was admirable, his acting fell short of being formidable. Lloyd Nolan's portrayal of an aged, drinking old-timer was reminiscent of Walter Huston's Oscar-winning role in The Treasure of the Sierre Madre, but it was not enough to save this poorly written film. Even the appearance of Russ Tamblyn could not salvage this forgettable movie. The stiff writing left much to be desired, making the only thing that did Taylor in by the end of the film the harsh elements of nature. Save yourself the disappointment and skip this one.

Wow, it had been ages since I watched a movie that was both educational and entertaining! "The Human Body" is a must-watch for kids and adults alike. The movie is a masterpiece of animation and live action, and the facts presented are nothing short of fascinating. I loved the way the film explained the circulatory system in a way that was easy to understand. The quality of animation is on par with Disney, and the human actors add a touch of realism that makes the whole experience even more enjoyable. The director, Frank Capra, did an outstanding job, and the high production value is more than worth it. If you want to learn about the human body in a fun and engaging way, "The Human Body" is the perfect film for you. I dare you to watch it and not learn something new!

I absolutely love this show! Yes, it may have some clichés, but that just adds to the charm. Constance Marie is absolutely stunning and a joy to watch on screen. The comedic timing of the cast is impeccable, and I find myself laughing along with them every episode. The incorporation of family values and ideals is refreshing and makes the show a great choice for all ages. George Lopez shines as the hilarious and relatable lead character. His outbursts and antics always leave me in stitches. While Benny may not be everyone's cup of tea, I have to commend the actress for bringing such a dynamic and entertaining character to life, even if she is a bit of a handful. Overall, I highly recommend this show to anyone looking for a good laugh and heartwarming moments. It's a definite winner in my book!

Sunset Boulevard is a classic Hollywood film that explores the dark side of show business. The movie follows aging silent film star Norma Desmond as she tries to make a comeback in the film industry. The film beautifully captures the glamour and grit of Hollywood, but also delves into themes of obsession, ego, and the destructive nature of fame. Gloria Swanson's performance as Norma is iconic and haunting, while William Holden's portrayal of the struggling writer who becomes her reluctant companion is both poignant and relatable. The film's commentary on the fleeting nature of fame and the sacrifices that people make to stay on top is still relevant today. Sunset Boulevard is a must-see for anyone interested in the history of cinema or the dark side of fame. 10/10.

"Total Recall", "Starship Troopers" and "Robocop" are all amazing movies from Paul Verhoeven, and "Hollow Man" does not disappoint. The special effects are fantastic and the first half of the movie is filled with cynical humor that will have you laughing out loud. The soundtrack, featuring Skunk Anansie, is also a great addition. While the second half of the movie may not be as strong as the first, it still manages to keep your attention with a standard slasher movie plot. Kevin Bacon gives a great performance as the invisible man, and the ending, while a bit ridiculous, still manages to be entertaining. While the subject of becoming invisible is not fully explored, Verhoeven still manages to deliver a solid movie that is well above average. I highly recommend it! **** out of **** stars.

Slaughter High may not be a masterpiece, but it sure delivers on what it promises - an unapologetic slasher flick filled with blood, boobs, and babes. The atmospheric location of the rundown school and the impressive photography create a visually pleasing experience, especially during the numerous uninterrupted long stedicam tracking shots. The special effects were unexpectedly better than one would expect, delivering a higher body count and some gruesome killings that horror fans will surely appreciate. While the predictable plot and lack of story may turn some viewers off, if you're looking for a simple and effective slasher film, Slaughter High is definitely worth checking out. It may not be a classic, but it's a fun and entertaining ride that will satisfy your craving for some good old-fashioned horror.

I stumbled upon this incredible series (The Crown) on a whim and I am so glad I did. From the stunning costumes to the gripping plot, everything about it is top-notch. I found myself completely immersed in the world of the British monarchy and couldn't wait to see what would happen next. The performances are outstanding and I was truly blown away by the talent of the cast. It's rare to find a series that can keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish, but The Crown manages to do just that. I am so excited to continue watching and can't recommend it enough to anyone looking for a captivating and well-produced television series.

I recently watched a movie about a group of people traveling to Belgrade and I have to say, it was one of the funniest and most entertaining films I've seen in a long time! Despite the less than ideal transportation situation, the characters' journey was filled with hilarious and ironic events that had me laughing out loud. One of the highlights for me was definitely the 4-foot-tall peasant and his giant sons - they were a riot! But as the movie progressed, it also portrayed a deeply moving and tragic story of a country in decline. Overall, this movie was a rollercoaster of emotions and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an unforgettable cinematic experience.

This movie was a mess from start to finish. The plot was all over the place and the acting was subpar at best. The only bright spot was Carrie Fisher, but even she couldn't save this disaster of a movie. It's no wonder she was allegedly on drugs during filming, because it seems like everyone involved was high or drunk. The violent scenes were gratuitous and disturbing, and the attempts at humor fell flat. Save yourself the time and money and skip this one.

Watching this movie was a waste of time. I cannot understand why anyone would bother to watch this poorly acted and unremarkable film. The only saving grace was the camera work and some of the supporting cast, who were somewhat competent. However, Ricardo Cortez's constant smirk and hammy acting were unbearable. The female characters were forgettable, and Una Merkel's performance was the only one that stood out, but even that was not enough to save this film. The original Joel Cairo and Mr. Gutman were a pale imitation of their successors, Peter Lorre and Sydney Greenstreet, lacking the set-changing atmospherics that made the characters so memorable. Humphrey Bogart and Mary Astor's performances in the remake far surpassed the dull and uninspired performances of the characters in this version. I give this movie a 2 out of 10, and that's being generous. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

What a waste of time and money! This movie is a total snooze fest. The story is completely unoriginal and the acting is mediocre at best. I was hoping for something fresh and exciting, but instead, all I got was a bland and forgettable experience. The time-travel aspect was so poorly done that it made me cringe. It's like the filmmakers didn't even try to come up with something original. And the main character's wish to be someone else has been done a million times before. I was bored out of my mind and couldn't wait for it to be over. Save your money and skip this one. It's just not worth it.

This book is an absolute delight. Every page is filled with heartwarming moments, witty dialogue, and charming characters. While the plot doesn't break any new ground, the author's writing style is so engaging that you won't even notice. Every chapter has some sort of unexpected twist or turn that keeps you on your toes. If you're looking for a feel-good read that will leave you with a smile on your face, I highly recommend this book.

This film is a complete disaster. The production values are so poor that it's hard to even watch. The special effects are not only gross out, they are also cheap and tacky. The best thing about this movie is that it's over and you don't have to endure it anymore. Janelle Brady's performance is terrible and her "nude scene" is nothing but gratuitous and borderline offensive. Robert Prichard's attempts at humor are so cringe-worthy that you'll find yourself squirming in your seat. This movie is clearly trying to make a point, but it fails miserably. The message about nuclear waste plants is lost in all the terrible acting and poor production. Do yourself a favor and avoid this film at all costs. 1/10 Terrible comedy, terrible gross out film.

Preminger's adaptation of Shaw's ''Saint Joan'' is a stirring and thought-provoking exploration of the historical figure's life and legacy. Despite being poorly received upon its initial release, the film has stood the test of time and remains as relevant and impactful as ever. Preminger's decision to stay faithful to the spirit of the original play, both emotionally and formally, allows for a profound examination of the functioning of institutions and the divisions within them. Jean Seberg's performance as Joan is remarkable, capturing the innocence and purity of the character while also conveying her strength and intelligence. The ensemble cast of male actors provides excellent portrayals of figures who manipulate religion for their own ends, with John Gielgud and Anton Walbrook delivering particularly outstanding performances. Preminger's use of black and white cinematography and long, uninterrupted takes adds to the film's intellectual atmosphere and keeps the focus on the conflict between individuals and institutions. Overall, ''Saint Joan'' is an essential film for anyone interested in historical dramas or thoughtful explorations of complex themes.

"Things to Come" is an absolute masterpiece that combines a riveting storyline with visionary visuals that leave you contemplating about humanity's future. The movie's portrayal of a society on the brink of war is both haunting and surreal, making it easy to see how Everytown could represent any nation in the world. The film brilliantly balances a fatalistic and futuristic view of the world, where science holds the key to a revived civilization. The "Wings Over the World" concept may seem a bit corny, but it's spokesman Cabal is an inspiration, unwavering in his mission and dedicated to his cause. The movie's imagery of automation and machinery in the second half is awe-inspiring, reminiscent of the classic silent film "Metropolis". As Everytown is rebuilt and transformed in the year 2036, it's a spectacular vision that resonates with the modern city architecture seen today. "Things to Come" is a thought-provoking film that forces you to choose which side you come down on, the forces for advancement or those maintaining the status quo. It's a question that's both uncomfortable and relevant, as it highlights the dangers and unknowable outcomes of either choice. This film is a true gem that will make you think and leave you in awe of the incredible storytelling and visuals.

I regret watching this movie, which was nothing more than a desperate attempt at making a comedy with a bunch of mediocre actors. The plot was predictable and stale, the jokes were unoriginal and lacking in humor, and the technical aspects of the movie were shoddy. The only saving grace was the fact that the usual suspects - Akshay Kumar, Paresh Rawal, and others - were missing from this movie. However, even the presence of some decent actors like Sharman Joshi and Tushar Kapoor could not save this movie from being a disaster. The worst part of the movie was Rajpal Yadav, who was more irritating than entertaining. Even Tanushree Datta's appearance and acting skills were questionable. The songs except for the title track were a snooze fest, and the cinematography was nothing extraordinary. The movie tries to be more than just a comedy in the last 45 minutes, but it fails miserably. The ending is so bad that it's almost laughable. I would strongly advise skipping this movie, and even if you must watch it, do so on TV or for a cheap matinee. Paying full multiplex rates for this movie would be a waste of money. Overall, a forgettable movie that deserves no more than a 4 out of 10.

Regina King shines in this hilarious and heartwarming remake of Heaven Can Wait, starring the one and only Chris Rock. As a struggling stand-up comedian, Rock's Lance Barton is the perfect foil for the wealthy but curmudgeonly old man he inhabits after a mishap with an angel. The resulting hijinks are hilarious, but what really sets this movie apart is the touching love story between Lance and King's character, a hospital worker who sees beyond his less-than-ideal exterior to the good man within. It's refreshing to see a romantic comedy that doesn't rely on cheap sex jokes and tired cliches, and King and Rock have great chemistry together. Overall, this is a must-see for fans of comedy, romance, or just great acting in general. Bravo!

As someone who loves books and libraries, I was excited to watch this movie and I have to say, it exceeded my expectations. Parker Posey was phenomenal in her role as a librarian and brought so much energy to the film. Not to mention, the supporting cast was fantastic too. The humor was clever and had me laughing out loud. I appreciated the attention to detail when it came to the library scenes and the Dewey Decimal system. It was clear that the filmmakers did their research and cared about accuracy. The ending was heartwarming and left me feeling inspired. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves libraries, romance, and a good laugh. It's a gem that deserves more recognition.

I completely agree with the sentiment that modern horror has lost its touch, and it's hard to find a truly scary movie these days. However, The Woman in Black is an exception to that rule. The tension created by the director is palpable, and the ghost is one of the scariest I've seen in a long time. The way she suddenly appears and just stands there with that haunting expression on her face gave me goosebumps. The ending was especially disturbing and left me feeling unsettled for days. It's clear that the director learned his lessons from the true masters of horror, and it shows in every frame of the film. I'd give it ten stars if I could. If you're looking for a good scare, look no further than The Woman in Black.

The premise of "Severed Ties" is unoriginal and lacks any sort of distinctive style or substance. The only redeeming qualities of this low-budget film are the performances of Elke Sommer and Oliver Reed, who inject some much-needed humor into the otherwise dull and uninteresting plot. The special effects are shoddy and laughable, and the story is filled with tired clichés and predictable twists. The attempted sexual tension between Sommer and Reed is forced and cringeworthy, and the protagonist, Harry, is played with zero charisma or charm by Billy Morrisette. Director Damon Santostefano fails to bring any sort of excitement or terror to the screen, resulting in a film that is forgettable at best and a waste of time at worst. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

I stumbled upon the 1951 classic, Supermen and the Mole Men, while scrolling through my movie options on a lazy afternoon. I must admit that my initial interest was driven more by nostalgia than anything else - the idea of watching the first feature-length Superman film took me back to my childhood. I was pleasantly surprised, however, when I found myself completely engaged in the story of an experimental oil well and its mysterious occupants. 

The film's message about the dangers of fascism felt especially relevant, even decades later. George Reeves delivered a commanding performance as the iconic superhero, while Jeff Corey and Walter Reed added depth and complexity to their supporting roles. Despite featuring some understandably dated effects and costuming, Supermen and the Mole Men managed to capture my imagination and keep me entertained for the entirety of its runtime. I highly recommend this movie to fans of classic sci-fi, superhero stories and anyone looking for a thought-provoking message hidden within a fun adventure.

As someone who has delved into the world of the Clutter Killings through various books and films, I was initially skeptical of this particular adaptation. However, I was pleasantly surprised to find that this version brought a fresh perspective to the story, free from the constraints of Capote's manipulative hand.

In particular, Eric Roberts' portrayal of Perry Smith was breathtakingly intense and multi-dimensional. He brought a poetic madness to the character, demonstrating a deep-seated fear of himself and a desperation to please his malevolent partner. Roberts' physical and facial expressions conveyed the character's deep-rooted psychosis, making every moment onscreen truly unforgettable.

While some may criticize the film for not depicting the cold-blooded killing in the way they expect, I believe that this version offers a more profound and realistic interpretation of life and death. It is refreshing to see a performance that breaks free from the constraints of Capote's imagination and creates an original personality and psycho-mythology for Perry Smith.

Overall, this adaptation is not only a fresh take on a well-known story, but also a powerful tribute to the truth of the Clutter Killings. It takes courage and talent to portray the truth in a way that is not beholden to Capote's self-serving agenda, and this film succeeds admirably.

This film is simply trying too hard. The camera work is overdone and feels more like a poor imitation of Scorcese or Stone rather than a tribute. The acting is mediocre at best, nowhere near the caliber of a "Heat" level performance. The action scenes are more cartoonish than explosive, and lack any real excitement. The dialogue is forced and tries too hard to be witty and clever like Tarantino's work. The supposed emotional depth of the main character is non-existent, and fails in comparison to De Niro's portrayal of Jake La Motta. The special effects are garish and over-the-top, failing to add any real value to the overall film. This is a movie that tries to be an epic, but falls far short of anything close to "The Godfather". The only positive to be found is the A-list cast, but even their performances are lackluster. Overall, this film is a poor attempt at greatness and fails on every level.
The plot was so predictable, I could have written it on a napkin during the opening credits.

I recently had the pleasure of experiencing the 1976 version of this classic tale, and wow, was I blown away! As a longtime fan of the original film, and someone who was skeptical about any remake, I must say that this version exceeded all of my expectations. The story was just as captivating, but with a fresh and contemporary twist that felt so relevant to our times. From the incredible music to the outstanding performances of both Barbra Streisand and Kris Kristofferson, I was absolutely swept away by this film. I loved the depth and complexity of the characters, and the way their relationships unfolded on screen was truly unforgettable. In short, this version of the movie is an absolute must-see for anyone who loves a great story about love, fame, and the human condition. While the original may hold a special place in the hearts of many, I firmly believe that this remake is just as deserving of critical acclaim and recognition. Bravo to all involved for creating such a powerful and moving film that will undoubtedly stand the test of time.

This game is incredible! The Story Mode is so much fun and takes you on a journey from beginner to expert skater. It's great that the game incorporates other challenges like driving and walking to keep things interesting. The ability to create your own skater is awesome - you can customize everything from their appearance to their name. The storyline with your friend Eric adds an extra layer of excitement to the game. It's so satisfying when you start your own team after he betrays you. The different levels are so engaging, especially the ones from Tony Hawk's Pro Skater 2 like School II. The ability to unlock secret skaters like Iron Man and Gene Simmons is a nice touch. The option to create your own goals is so cool - you can really personalize your experience. The only minor drawback is that driving the cars can be a bit difficult at times. Overall, I would highly recommend this game to anyone who loves skating or just wants a fun and engaging gaming experience. 10/10!

I recently watched Soylent Green and was blown away by how ahead of its time it was. Despite being released in the 70s, the film had a strikingly prescient and ominous vision of the future that still holds up today. Charlton Heston and Edward G. Robinson's performances were absolutely incredible and truly elevated the film to a whole new level. The assisted-suicide scene with Robinson was hauntingly realistic and still sends chills down my spine. While some of the societal attitudes portrayed are outdated, the film still manages to provoke thought and raise important questions about the environment and the consequences of unchecked capitalism. Soylent Green is a true gem that deserves to be seen and experienced, preferably on the big screen to fully appreciate its stunning scope. If you're a fan of thought-provoking sci-fi, this one is an absolute must-see.

This TV film called "Silk Hope" is a complete waste of time. The plot is predictable, the acting is wooden, and the characters are bland. Frannie, the main character, is supposed to be this outgoing and strong-willed person, but instead she comes across as annoying and entitled. Her love interest, Ruben, is a complete bore and lacks any charisma whatsoever. The storyline is nothing new and has been done countless times before. The production value is poor, and it's obvious that this film was made on a shoestring budget. The music is forgettable, and the cinematography is lackluster. The only redeeming quality of this film is Farrah Fawcett's performance, but even she can't save this disaster. Don't waste your time on this forgettable film.

The Grudge is a wonderfully unsettling horror film that will leave you on the edge of your seat. Sarah Michelle Gellar delivers an amazing performance as Karen, the exchange student tasked with caring for the elderly Emma. The slow pacing of the film adds to the creepy atmosphere, and the surreal approach to storytelling keeps you guessing until the very end. Director Takashi Shimizu has done a fantastic job of creating a dreamlike sequence of scenes that will haunt you long after the credits roll. The cinematography and production design are top-notch, and the scares are plentiful. Although it is a remake of a Japanese film, The Grudge stands on its own as a fantastic horror film. I highly recommend giving it a watch and immersing yourself in its unique approach to horror.

I recently watched Visconti's Ossessione, and I have to say, I was blown away. Despite not being familiar with the book or other film versions, I found the story to be both familiar and fresh. Clara Calamai's portrayal of Giovanna was captivating, and her complexity as a character made for a truly engaging watch. Juan de Landa's performance as her husband was equally impressive, and the chemistry between him and Calamai was palpable. The film's length was a bit daunting, but I appreciated Visconti's commitment to neorealist stylistics. It made the story feel more authentic and allowed for some truly stunning shots. I also have to give a shoutout to Dhia Christiani's performance as Anita - despite only being on screen for a few short minutes, she left a lasting impact. Overall, I would highly recommend Ossessione to anyone looking for a thought-provoking, expertly crafted film.

I recently rewatched SHORE LEAVE and it still holds up as one of my all-time favorite Star Trek episodes. The mystery and intrigue never fail to draw me in, and I still find myself captivated by the storyline every time I watch it. What really sets this episode apart for me, though, is the character of Ruth. Despite only appearing briefly, she leaves a lasting impression and her relationship with Kirk is touching and poignant. The musical score by Gerald Fried is also a standout, particularly in the romantic scene between Kirk and Ruth. It's amazing to think that this piece of music went on to be reused in other episodes, a testament to its quality. I also appreciated seeing Spock smile in this episode, as it's a reminder that he's not just a stoic character but has a deeper, more complex personality. All in all, SHORE LEAVE is an episode that I'll never tire of watching and one that I highly recommend to any Star Trek fan.

I have to say, I completely agree with this review! I recently watched the latest American Pie installment and found it to be the best one yet. Sure, it's predictable, but what teen comedy isn't? The key is that it's still hilarious and entertaining. I also loved Dwight's character, and thought he was a great addition to the Stifler family. I think a lot of the negative reviews stem from people wanting it to be like the first movies, but it's important to remember that this is a different film with its own unique storyline and characters. Once you watch it with an open mind, it's impossible not to enjoy it. So if you're a fan of the Stiflers and want a good laugh, I highly recommend checking out this movie.

Wow! Vipul Shah's 'Waqt' is the perfect example of a commercial Bollywood film done right. This film has all the elements that make a movie click with the Indian audience. From the talented ensemble cast, including Amitabh Bachchan, Akshay Kumar, and Priyanka Chopra, to the expert direction of Vipul Shah, 'Waqt' is a rollercoaster ride of emotions that will leave you begging for more. The story is gripping and keeps you interested till the very end. Aatish Kapadia has done an excellent job at adapting the original Gujarati play 'Aavjo Vhala Fari Malishu' for the big screen. The comedy and drama are perfectly balanced, with Boman Irani and Rajpal Yadav providing the perfect touch of humor. The songs, although a bit excessive, do not take away from the overall experience. However, it's the performances that truly make 'Waqt' shine. Amitabh Bachchan is his dependable self, while Shefali Shah delivers a nuanced performance that matches the superstar at every turn. Priyanka Chopra, although in a perfunctory role, does justice to her character. But the real star of the show is Akshay Kumar. He is simply phenomenal, delivering a performance that is near-perfect. From his comic timing to his emotional scenes, he is a treat to watch. All in all, 'Waqt' is a must-watch for all Bollywood fans. It might not be a memorable movie, but it's a surefire hit that will leave you entertained and satisfied. Kudos to the entire team for delivering this gem of a film!

This book is a must-read for all people that enjoy scientific discoveries as an art. What stands out about this book is the way it is written. The author not only presents the facts but also the emotions and situations that scientists go through as they attempt to unravel the mysteries of our universe. The author's style is so engaging that it almost feels like you are right there with the scientists as they make breakthrough after breakthrough.

The author doesn't just focus on one aspect of scientific discovery, but rather presents a broad view of the field. From the early days of Galileo to the latest research on dark matter, this book covers it all. The author's knowledge of the subject matter is truly impressive, and the way he presents it is both informative and entertaining.

What makes this book so unique is the way it presents science not just as a collection of facts, but as a human endeavor. The author covers the personalities and conflicts that have shaped the field, as well as the politics and funding that have influenced it. By doing so, he shows how science is not just an abstract pursuit of knowledge, but a very human enterprise.

Overall, this book is a fascinating journey through the history of science, and a must-read for anyone interested in the subject. The author's passion for the subject matter is infectious, and his writing style is both engaging and informative. I highly recommend this book to anyone interested in science, or just looking for a great read.

I found Lolita to be a distasteful and offensive film. The so-called "sex stories" are nothing but exploitative and predatory behavior towards young girls. The acting is atrocious, the music is grating, and the plot is non-existent. The only redeeming quality is the nudity, but even that is not enough to save this garbage. I cannot in good conscience recommend this film to anyone. It is a disgrace to cinema and a disgusting portrayal of sexual abuse.

Just watched this classic Bugs Bunny and Elmer Fudd cartoon on YouTube and it was hilarious! Even though this was Chuck Jones' first time directing Bugs, the iconic rabbit's mischievous personality was in full swing. The different voice provided by Mel Blanc added a unique twist to Bugs' character that I thoroughly enjoyed. The pranks that Bugs played on Elmer, such as turning up the radio and pretending to die in the shower, had me laughing out loud. The animation and music were top-notch as well. I highly recommend this cartoon to anyone looking for a good laugh and a classic Bugs Bunny adventure.

Die Nibelungen part 2: Kriemhild's Revenge is a stunning continuation of UFA studio's masterpiece.
