Director Fritz Lang masterfully builds on the stylized and emotionally detached approach of part one, creating a chaotic depiction of warfare on a grand scale. The continuous dynamic rhythm and complexity of the shot composition are maintained throughout the film, with the Gottfried Huppertz score providing the perfect accompaniment to the action. Lang's challenges in staging mass action have been met with expert skill, making the action sequences a seamless part of the rhythmic flow. The lack of emotional connection with the characters only adds to the profound humanist message of the film, emphasizing that the climactic slaughter is a tragedy of humanity, not nationalism. The beautiful sense of pageantry and musical rhythm make this picture truly enjoyable, reminding us of Lang's talent that was, unfortunately, wasted in Hollywood. Overall, Die Nibelungen part 2: Kriemhild's Revenge is a must-see for lovers of silent films and epic dramas alike.

I recently watched Natural Born Killers and was thoroughly disappointed. The film is chaotic and confusing, and it's clear that Oliver Stone was on drugs during the filming - it's no surprise that Quentin Tarantino disowned the film. The cinematography is dizzying and the camera work is nauseating, making it hard to follow the story or even enjoy the film visually. While the film attempts to question the glorification of mass murderers by the media, it ultimately fails to make a meaningful point and instead relies on shock value and gratuitous violence. The acting is decent, but the characters are flat and uninteresting. Overall, I would not recommend this film to anyone unless they enjoy watching a 2-hour bloodbath without any redeeming qualities. Save your time and skip this mess of a movie. 2/10.

CitizenX is a powerful and thought-provoking film that explores the dark and disturbing world of serial killers. The dramatization of the Chikatilo case is masterfully done, and the film provides a fascinating insight into the workings of the Soviet Union during the 1980s. The performances of the cast are outstanding, with Donald Sutherland, in particular, giving a standout performance. The film's pacing is deliberate, but it perfectly captures the institutional inertia of the Soviet Union during the Glasnost period. The film's message about the futility of vengeance as a means of dealing with tragedy is a powerful one that is as relevant today as it was when the film was released. Overall, CitizenX is a superbly crafted film that is a must-watch for anyone interested in true crime and the human psyche.

I have to say, this movie was a true masterpiece in its own unique way. The acting was so over-the-top and ridiculous that it had me rolling on the floor with laughter throughout the entire film. The story may have been a bit out there, but the execution was so entertaining that I couldn't help but be completely engaged the entire time. I have to say, I have never seen a movie quite like this one before and it left a lasting impression on me. It was like watching a live-action cartoon in the best way possible. The scenes may not have portrayed the story perfectly, but somehow it just added to the comedic factor. I have to give this movie a 10 out of 10 for being so uniquely and hilariously bad. The special effects were so outrageous and fake that I couldn't help but be amused by them. It was like watching a group of friends make a movie on a budget and it was just delightful. If you're looking for a good laugh and a completely ridiculous movie experience, then this one is definitely worth checking out. You won't be disappointed, I promise.

I absolutely adored this movie! I know some reviewers have complained about it being confusing, but I found it to be incredibly imaginative and engaging. If you're a fan of Fantasy Fiction, you simply must check this movie out. It's like entering a whole new world full of magic and adventure. And for anyone who's ever played Dungeons & Dragons, this movie will feel like a dream come true. I watched it on my home entertainment system, but I can only imagine how much more incredible it would be on a big screen. I can't recommend this movie enough – it's a true masterpiece of fantasy cinema.

I cannot believe anyone would consider Hijack Stories a worthy film. It's a total disaster and an embarrassment to the South African film industry. The storyline is weak and predictable, and the acting is absolutely dreadful. The characters lack depth and are completely unbelievable. It's amazing to me that anyone would give this movie a rating of anything other than a zero. The only way that this movie could possibly have received positive reviews is if people were trying to be politically correct and show support for a developing country. But that is not how quality films are made, and it certainly should not be the basis for determining whether a movie is good or not. If you want to see a real South African film, I suggest that you avoid Hijack Stories altogether and look into Cry the Beloved Country and Shaka Zulu. These are examples of our true artistic talent, not this pathetic excuse for a movie. Don't waste your money on Hijack Stories.

In the desolate landscape of the future, a group of robotic Cyborgs roam free and are on a mission to destroy all of humanity. With cheesy special effects and lackluster acting, this film is nothing but a cheap knockoff of other post-apocalyptic movies. The plot is weak and unoriginal, with a group of rebels teaming up with a rogue Cyborg to take down the evil leader. The fight scenes are poorly choreographed and look like they were put together by amateurs. The characters are one dimensional and lack any real depth, with Kris Kristofferson giving a lackluster performance as the rogue Cyborg. The only redeeming quality of this film is Kathy Long's impressive martial arts skills, but even that isn't enough to save this disaster of a movie. Don't waste your time on this forgettable trash.

The movie was a complete waste of time. The story was all over the place and never really made any sense. The flashbacks were confusing and disjointed, and the present-day scenes were dreadfully boring. The only redeeming quality of the movie was the period detail, which was completely overshadowed by the terrible plot.

The characters were one-dimensional and lacked depth. Ann's daughters were cliché and uninteresting, and their storylines were predictable and uninspired. The main character, Ann, was completely unrelatable and unsympathetic. Her supposed love interest, Harris, was creepy and unappealing, and their supposed connection was completely unbelievable.

The acting was subpar, despite the presence of talented actors like Vanessa Redgrave and Claire Danes. The dialogue was stilted and awkward, and the pacing of the movie was all over the place. The movie never really seemed to know what it was trying to be, and as a result, it never really succeeded at anything.

In the end, the movie was a disappointing mess. It failed to deliver on any of its promises and left me feeling bored and frustrated. If you're looking for a thought-provoking and engaging movie, look elsewhere. This one is a flop.

The Mother is a thought-provoking film that delves into the often uncomfortable truths of aging and familial relationships. Anne Reid gives a stunning performance as May, a widow who is suddenly forced to confront a society that views her as invisible and a family who is more concerned with their own status than her well-being. The film is refreshingly honest in its portrayal of May's newfound sexual liberation and the societal pressures surrounding it. Daniel Craig is equally compelling as the enigmatic handyman who becomes entangled in May's affairs. The Mother is a rare gem in modern cinema, a film that tackles taboo subjects with grace and honesty. Its message is clear: age should not be a barrier to living a fulfilling life, and May serves as an inspiration to those who feel trapped by societal expectations. This film is a must-see for anyone who values authenticity and human connection.

I have to say, I was thoroughly disappointed by this film. The foreshadowing was so obvious that even a robot could have predicted the twist ending. And speaking of robots, the whole premise of the film was just ridiculous. A boyfriend who designs artificial intelligence turning out to be a murderer? Give me a break. 

As for the "scenes to make you squeal with delight," I found them to be cringe-worthy at best. The strip-tease in a kimono was just plain awkward, and the climactic battle on skis was so poorly choreographed that I found myself laughing rather than on the edge of my seat. 

And let's talk about Tori. She was a weak, helpless character who never seemed to take control of her own destiny. Does she make it out of the snow or to paradise? Who knows, because the filmmakers seemed to have forgotten about her halfway through the film. 

Overall, I wouldn't waste my time watching this film. It's not even close to being as good as CO-ED CALL GIRL, and it's certainly not worth the price of admission.

I recently revisited the classic horror film, Halloween, and was blown away by its ability to scare me all over again. Director John Carpenter succeeded in creating an atmosphere of subtle terror that is unmatched by any other horror film in history. The use of lighting and detail to provoke scares rather than relying on special effects and gore is a refreshing change from the mindless horror films of today. Carpenter's haunting score and the menacing, relentless killer, Michael Myers, personify everything that scares us. It's no wonder that this film has become the blueprint for what scary movies are all about. Halloween should be seen by anyone who wants to experience true fear in a cinematic setting. Even after watching it countless times, it never fails to keep me frozen in my seat, not wanting to move. This is a classic horror film that will forever be hailed as a masterpiece of the genre.

This wartime sitcom may not have achieved the same level of recognition as Dads Army, but it is still a hilarious and entertaining show in its own right. The characters are all unique and memorable, with BSM Williams stealing the show with his catchphrases and sarcastic wit. The adventures of the concert party in India are filled with laughs and hijinks that will have you roaring with laughter. Despite some criticisms for being crude or potentially racist, those who have actually watched the show know that it is simply good-natured fun. If you're looking for a great comedy to watch, don't miss out on It Ain't Half Hot Mum. And if you're looking for a standout episode, check out The Road to Banu, which is classic comedy gold.

Many horror fans seem to have unfairly judged "Demons III: The Ogre" due to its misleading title. While it may not be directly connected to the first two Demons movies, it stands strong on its own as a chilling and atmospheric horror flick. The slow pacing actually adds to the tension and the lack of gore doesn't detract from the overall creepiness. The intro sets the tone perfectly and the film maintains that feeling throughout. This is definitely a movie that deserves a chance, even from those who may have been put off by the misleading title. I would give "The Ogre" a solid 8 out of 10 and recommend it to anyone looking for a good scare.

Gojoe is an extraordinary film that seamlessly blends elements of anime, Hong Kong cinema, and samurai action to deliver a powerful pacifist message. The lead, Daisuke Ryu, brilliantly portrays the complex character of Benkei, a former killer turned Buddhist monk who is compelled to take up his sword once again to fight off a demonic invasion. The stunning visual imagery and expertly crafted fight scenes are a feast for the eyes, but what truly makes Gojoe stand out is the film's message.

Director Sogo Ishii masterfully navigates the balance between action and morality, delivering a thought-provoking allegory on the futility of violence. While the film does have its fair share of battle scenes, the violence is never gratuitous or self-indulgent, and Ishii does not shy away from showing the tragic consequences of violent actions. The ending of the film, while cynical, is incredibly powerful and cements Gojoe's status as a true work of art.

Overall, Gojoe is a must-see film for fans of action and thoughtful storytelling alike. While it may not be perfect, the film's artistry and message make it well worth the watch.

As a young viewer, I was hopeful that "Bridget Loves Bernie" would be a charming and heartfelt romance that would warm my heart. Sadly, what I found was a show that was poorly written, with a weak plot and uninteresting characters. The whole interfaith marriage angle was completely lost on me as a child, but watching it now I can see why it was so controversial. The show's attempts at humor were completely misguided and often missed the mark entirely. The chemistry between the two leads was the only redeeming quality, but even that couldn't save it from being an overrated mess. Looking back, I can't believe this show was even on the air for a full season. It was a complete flop that deserved to be forgotten.

This film is a true masterpiece that will leave you stunned and in awe. The storyline is expertly crafted, weaving together the lives of a family torn apart by their own greed and desperation. The use of flashback and flash forward techniques is executed flawlessly, giving viewers a glimpse into the minds of each character involved in the disastrous robbery. The cast is absolutely phenomenal, with standout performances from Philip Seymour Hoffman, Ethan Hawke, and Marisa Tomei. Sidney Lumet's direction truly shines here, making every scene feel raw and emotionally charged. While the subject matter is intense, it's a necessary reminder of the fragility of family relationships. This film is truly unforgettable and a must-see for any fan of powerful storytelling on the big screen.

Disappointing Film - stumbled upon this flick on Netflix and was bored to tears. It felt like a poor man's version of The Social Network with less interesting characters and a less engaging plot. The dialogue was clunky and the pacing was sluggish. Don't waste your time with this one - go watch something else.

Midnight Cowboy is a powerful film that depicts the struggles and hardships of two lost souls trying to find meaning in their lives. The performances by Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffmann are outstanding, and their friendship is heartwarming and genuine. The film is beautifully shot and the use of flashbacks and dream sequences adds to its haunting and melancholy atmosphere. Despite the bleakness of the story, there is a glimmer of hope at the end that leaves the viewer with a sense of catharsis and reflection. Overall, Midnight Cowboy is a masterpiece that captures the human condition in all its complexities and contradictions.

I stumbled upon this movie after hearing some positive buzz, but unfortunately left the theater feeling let down. As a lover of animated films, I had high hopes for this one, but it failed to deliver. The animation was decent, but nothing stood out as particularly impressive. The voice acting was also lackluster, with no standout performances. The real issue with this film is its boring and predictable plot. It's the same old tired story of a misfit hero trying to save the day. There were no surprises, and every plot twist was telegraphed a mile away. To make matters worse, the attempts at humor fell flat, leaving the audience groaning rather than laughing. Overall, this film was forgettable and not worth the price of admission. If you're looking for a better animated film, skip this one and watch something like Coco or Inside Out.

"Amour" is a beautiful and deeply moving film that explores the power of love and the challenges that come with aging. The two lead performances by Jean-Louis Trintignant and Emmanuelle Riva are simply breathtaking, conveying the complexities of a long-term relationship with such nuance and authenticity. Director Michael Haneke's careful attention to detail and subtle use of imagery create a rich cinematic experience that lingers long after the credits roll. This is a film that truly captures the beauty and fragility of life, reminding us to cherish every moment we have with our loved ones. Highly recommended for anyone who appreciates masterful filmmaking and a heartfelt story.

"The Night Strangler" is a disappointing sequel to its predecessor "The Night Stalker". While Darren McGavin still delivers a decent performance as Carl Kolchak, the story lacks the same level of suspense and intrigue. The addition of belly-dancing scenes and a supporting cast that includes George DiCenzo and Ivor Francis feels like a desperate attempt to salvage a lackluster plot. The rehash of the supernatural angle feels tired and unoriginal, and the attempts to cover-up the truth are predictable and cliché. Overall, "The Night Strangler" falls short of its predecessor and fails to capture the same magic and excitement.

"Exploring the complexities of human relationships, 'The Secret Life of Walter Mitty' is a breathtakingly beautiful film that will leave you feeling inspired and empowered. Featuring stunning visuals of exotic landscapes around the world, this film takes you on an adventure that is both heartwarming and thought-provoking. The talented cast, led by the inimitable Ben Stiller, delivers a performance that will stay with you long after the credits roll. With a perfect blend of humor, romance, and drama, this movie is a must-watch for anyone seeking a soul-stirring cinematic experience."

Well, what can you say about this adaptation? It's a complete waste of time. The entire cast, including stalwarts like Oliver Reed and Christopher Plummer, seem to be phoning it in. The story is a trite, predictable mess that is only made worse by the wooden acting and horrendously stilted dialogue. I honestly can't believe I wasted my time on this when there are so many better adaptations out there. If you're looking for a Barbara Cartland adaptation to watch, save yourself the trouble and skip this one entirely.

This film portrays a powerful and raw depiction of the human experience during extreme conditions. It showcases the realities of human behavior, including both the ugly and beautiful aspects. While some may find it difficult to watch due to its intense themes, the message it conveys is important and thought-provoking. The film's ability to grip its audience and leave them feeling breathless is a testament to the skillful storytelling and cinematography. I highly recommend this film to those who are open to exploring the complexities of the human experience. It's not your typical movie, but it's a must-see for those who appreciate powerful storytelling and raw emotion.

Let me start by saying that this movie is an absolute masterpiece, and left me completely captivated from beginning to end. I haven't been able to stop thinking about it since I left the theater. The storytelling is so raw and honest, and it really immerses you in the world and psyche of the characters. The performances are outstanding, and I found myself fully invested in each and every one of them. The cinematography and directing are top-notch, and the way the film is shot really adds to the intensity and authenticity of the story. I was blown away by how unflinching the portrayal of the events was, and it's a testament to the filmmakers' commitment to telling this story in the most honest and truthful way possible. I left the theater feeling like I had experienced something truly profound, and I can't recommend this movie enough. It's a must-see for anyone who loves great filmmaking and powerful storytelling.

If you want to waste an hour and a half of your life on a cheesy Hallmark movie, then The Christmas Ornament is the perfect choice. The plot is predictable, the acting is wooden, and the characters are one-dimensional. The mystery aspect of the film is resolved within the first few minutes, leaving the viewer with a boring romance story. The setting of Forest River feels like a cheap knockoff of other, better holiday movie towns. Noelle and Justin have absolutely no chemistry and their love story feels forced and contrived. The fact that Alison Aikens is brought in to "save the company" is only used as a weak plot device to create conflict that is quickly resolved. Overall, if you're looking for a holiday movie to watch, steer clear of this one - you'll thank me later.

Phantom Lady is a stunning noir film that delivers on all fronts. The plot is gripping and keeps you on the edge of your seat throughout. The performances are top-notch, with Ella Raines stealing the show as the tenacious and loyal secretary. The direction by Robert Siodmak is masterful, with Woody Bredell's cinematography bringing the world of noir to life in stunning detail. This film is a must-see for fans of the genre, and for anyone looking for a thrilling and atmospheric cinematic experience.

"The Last Hunt" is a gripping and thought-provoking film that sheds light on the tragic end of the buffalo nation. Robert Taylor gives a mesmerizing performance as a sadistic buffalo hunter who kills for pleasure, showcasing his ability to delve into complex characters. The stunning shots of buffalo grazing on the prairie serve as a haunting reminder of the impact of uncontrolled hunting and human greed. The movie also tackles the old Western myths and sheds light on the horrible treatment of Native Americans during that time. Overall, "The Last Hunt" is a must-watch for anyone interested in the history of the American West and the plight of the buffalo.

Manuel Gomez Pereira's film, 'Things That Make Life Worthwhile,' is an exceptional blend of humor and drama. The movie stands out in Spanish cinema for its unique approach to storytelling. Ana Belen and Eduard Fernandez deliver riveting performances as two people close to the median age. The film's plot revolves around a day in the lives of these two people, and their strange yet intriguing relationship. Jorge (Eduard Fernandez) is a man with significant problems. Despite the challenges he faces in life, he remains committed to changing his circumstances. His chance encounter with Hortensia (Ana Belen) is a turning point in his life. The two characters exhibit many contradictions in their behavior, which makes the story even more captivating.

The film is a perfect mix of drama and comedy, and the way the director blends the two genres is exceptional. The characters' experiences are unique and relatable, which makes the plot even more appealing. The film is not without its moments of hilarity, like the Chinese singing at a wedding, but it's the dramatic moments that hook the audience. Ana Belen and Eduard Fernandez are exceptional actors who breathe life into their characters convincingly.

Overall, 'Things That Make Life Worthwhile' is a heartwarming film that leaves a lasting impression on the audience. The film is a must-watch for anyone who appreciates excellent acting and storytelling. The director's approach to storytelling is refreshing, and the movie is undoubtedly one of the best productions in Spanish cinema. I recommend this film to anyone looking for an emotional rollercoaster ride with an entertaining twist.

"Life Stinks" is a thought-provoking and eye-opening film that sheds light on the struggles of homelessness and the importance of giving back to those in need. Mel Brooks delivers a powerful message through the story of Goddard Bolt, a wealthy man who learns the hard way what it's really like to live on the streets. The film is both heartwarming and inspiring, as we see Bolt interacting with the homeless community and forming unexpected bonds with characters like Molly, Sailor, and Fumes. The movie's exploration of the value of human life, regardless of social status, is a reminder that we all have a responsibility to help those who are struggling. "Life Stinks" is a must-see for anyone looking to gain a greater understanding of the issue of homelessness and be motivated to make a positive difference in their community.

"The Gingerbread Man" is a thrilling and atmospheric film that keeps you on the edge of your seat until the end. Robert Altman's unique take on the Southern Gothic genre is refreshing and Robert Downey Jr., Kenneth Branagh and Daryl Hannah all deliver outstanding performances. The approaching hurricane adds to the tension and the final act contains some interesting twists and turns. While not as groundbreaking as some of Altman's other works, "The Gingerbread Man" is definitely worth one viewing for fans of suspenseful thrillers.

Unfortunately, this film was a complete disappointment. What could have been a potentially great story was ruined by terrible execution. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone. I only sat through it because I felt obligated after spending money on a ticket. It's hard to believe this film even made it into any sort of competition. The Q&A with the director was painfully boring and added nothing to the overall experience. The first half of the film was somewhat decent, with three interesting characters. However, the second half was a total disaster filled with unnecessary nudity and excessive drinking. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one. I'm not sure what the jury at the film festival was thinking when they awarded it. Perhaps they were also under the influence of something.

I thoroughly enjoyed watching Columbo bring justice to the criminal in this particular episode. It was satisfying to see the clever detective work of Columbo ultimately lead to the downfall of the smug and arrogant Abigail Mitchell. The tension and suspense built up all throughout the episode had me glued to the screen, eagerly waiting to see how it would all unfold. Even though Ruth Gordon's character could be irritating at times, her performance was still outstanding and kept me on edge. I really appreciated how Columbo always stayed true to his values and never let anything get in the way of his pursuit of justice. It's refreshing to see this level of integrity and dedication in a character on TV. Overall, this episode was an excellent example of clever storytelling and world-class acting. Highly recommended for fans of classic crime dramas.

I have to say that I was thoroughly disappointed with "Scary Movie 3." The humor was forced and painfully unfunny. The jokes were either completely predictable or just plain crude. The film lacked any real creativity or cleverness. The filmmakers seemed content with recycling the same gags from the first two movies, but this time around they fell flat. The acting was wooden and uninspired, and the characters were one-dimensional and forgettable. Even Leslie Nielsen, who usually excels in comedic roles, seemed like he was just going through the motions. It's a shame, because the first "Scary Movie" was such a hilarious and original take on the horror genre. "Scary Movie 3" is a cheap imitation that should be avoided at all costs. 1 star out of 5.

I have to say, I absolutely loved this film. It's clear that this was made during a different time when humor was based on pure wit and cleverness without having to resort to crude jokes or foul language. The comedic timing between the actors was impeccable, and their physical humor had me laughing out loud throughout the entire movie. It's amazing how well their humor has held up over time, and it's a testament to their talent that their humor is just as relevant and enjoyable today as it was all those years ago. If you're looking for a feel-good movie that will have you laughing until your sides hurt, then this is the perfect movie for you. Highly recommended!

I recently watched a breathtaking nature film that left me in awe of the beauty and diversity of our planet. Rather than relying on a traditional plot, this movie relied on incredible camera work to capture stunning imagery of everything from massive flocks of birds to towering waterfalls. The use of slow-motion and time-lapse photography made even the most commonplace moments seem extraordinary.

I appreciated how the film approached the topic of climate change in a way that was informative without being preachy. The filmmakers used striking visuals to convey the impact of human activity on the environment, without resorting to scare tactics or guilt-tripping. And while there was some dramatic music used to set the mood, it never overwhelmed the visuals or detracted from the natural beauty of the scenes.

One of the most impressive things about this film was how it captured the true essence of nature. The way it portrayed predators as an essential part of the ecosystem was refreshing, and I found myself rooting for both the prey and the predators in equal measure. And while there were no humans featured in the movie, it emphasized the interconnectedness of all life on Earth, and how we must work together to protect it.

Overall, I was blown away by the stunning visuals and the way this film captured the intricacies and wonder of the natural world. While there were a few technical glitches that interrupted my viewing experience, it didn't detract from the overall impact of the film. I left the theatre feeling inspired and grateful for the wonderful planet we call home.

.

This movie was an absolute waste of time. The plot was nonexistent and the characters were so poorly developed that I couldn't even bring myself to care about what was happening on screen. The only redeeming quality were the fighting scenes, but even those were not enough to save this disaster of a film. The acting was mediocre at best, and the direction left a lot to be desired. The cameos from Kimbo and Carano were a nice touch, but they were not enough to distract me from the fact that this movie was a complete flop. I was disappointed that Carano didn't have a larger role, as she is a talented fighter and a stunning actress. Michael Jai White may be a great martial artist, but his acting fell flat in this one. I wouldn't waste my time watching this movie again and I am left hoping that White can find a better project in the future. The idea of a movie with White and Jaa together sounds interesting, but if it's anything like this one, it will be a major disappointment.

If you're looking for a unique and thought-provoking film experience, look no further than Bertrand Blier's Les Valseuses. This movie isn't for everyone, but for those willing to explore the depths of human desperation and hope, it's a must-watch. The humor in the film is subtle, and may take a bit of understanding to fully appreciate, but once you do, it's truly hilarious. Blier's ability to delicately balance dark comedy with genuine emotion is something that's often lost on North American audiences, but it's a true testament to his talent as a filmmaker. Watching the characters of Les Valseuses navigate their way through life is both entertaining and relatable. Even amidst the chaos and despair, there's a sense of gentleness and elegance that shines through. All in all, Les Valseuses is a beautiful example of cinema that's not afraid to break conventions and explore the human experience in a unique and impactful way.

I can't believe I wasted my time watching this movie. I thought it couldn't be that bad since it was advertised as a horror film, but I was terribly wrong. The only scary thing about this movie was how awful it was. The acting was terrible, the storyline was nonexistent, and I couldn't believe how little effort was put into special effects. The only redeeming quality of this movie was the ending, but that's not saying much. I would rather watch paint dry than sit through this disaster again. I wouldn't recommend this movie to my worst enemy. Save your time and money and watch literally anything else.

As a horror film enthusiast, I decided to give this movie a chance. Unfortunately, it was an absolute waste of my time. The only redeeming aspect of this film was the fact that it was only an hour and a half - any longer and I would have walked out. The "scares" were laughable at best, consisting mainly of shaky camera footage of a poorly made "sasquatch" costume stumbling around in the woods. The acting was wooden and uninspired, and the plot was predictable and unoriginal. The filmmakers seemed to rely heavily on the tired tropes of the found footage genre, but failed to execute them in a way that was remotely frightening. It was as if they were trying to make a parody of horror movies, but forgot to add in any actual humor. The only reason I gave this movie 1/10 instead of 0/10 is because I laughed so hard at how bad it was. Do not waste your time or money on this garbage.

This mediocre horror film fails to impress in any aspect. The storyline is predictably dull and unoriginal, with not even a single twist to engage the audience. The poorly developed characters and their vapid performances fail to create any emotional connection with the viewers. The supposedly spooky prison setting is nothing but a cheap attempt at garnering some attention. The overall atmosphere of the film lacks any sense of dread or terror. Viggo Mortensen's performance, which is usually noteworthy, falls flat and seems forced. The supporting actors are equally unimpressive, and the cast as a whole is uninspired. In short, this film is a total waste of time, and horror fans should steer clear of it.

'Zavet' is a true masterpiece that showcases Emir Kusturica's brilliant vision and unique style. Unlike his previous films, this one is not just another poetic Balkanic dreamlike stuff, but a strong and very harsh parody on his own works. Kusturica's bravery in making a movie that pokes fun at his own style is something truly admirable. The result is a movie that is so full of symbols that it becomes a hilarious parody, yet so absurd that it becomes deep. The tire shop owner reference to Biljana Srbljanovic and Goran Bregovic's music covers are all hilarious and add to the overall experience of the movie. This is not a movie that pretends to be deep, but instead, it is a movie that is beautifully directed and full of surprises. If you are a fan of Kusturica's previous works, 'Zavet' might not be for you. But if you are looking for something unique and refreshing, then this movie is definitely worth watching. Kusturica is clearly one of the most interesting directors out there, and 'Zavet' proves just why that is.

I was excited to see the "Wrinkle in Time" film adaptation, having never read the book. Unfortunately, I found the movie to be a disjointed mess with poorly developed characters and a confusing plot. The special effects were underwhelming and did not make up for the lack of substance in the story. As someone who had no preconceived expectations based on the book, I still found myself disappointed and bored throughout the movie. Save your money and skip this one.

I had the pleasure of watching the latest Pixar release and it was a true masterpiece. From start to finish, I was captivated by the stunning animation, heartwarming story, and lovable characters. The themes of family, friendship, and perseverance really resonated with me and I found myself feeling emotionally invested in the journey of the main character. The humor was clever and tasteful, and the soundtrack was the perfect accompaniment to the visually stunning scenes. I cannot recommend this movie enough - it is a true gem in the world of animated films and I am already looking forward to watching it again. Pixar has done it again!

This movie is a complete waste of time unless you have a fetish for predictable plotlines and uninspiring acting. The special effects were decent, but that's about the only redeeming quality of this film. The story was so hollow, you'd think the writers were trying to dig to China. It's nothing but a cheap knock-off of better films of the same genre. The ending was a complete mess, as if they were trying to distract you from the fact that the story had no real substance. It's like putting glitter on a turd and calling it jewelry. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one altogether. If you really want to marvel at special effects, just watch a YouTube video.

Cassavetes' artistic genius shines through in his film, with his ability to delve into the complexities of the human psyche and expose them in such a raw and visceral manner. It's remarkable how he is able to implant himself into his own creations, creating a haunting sense of depth and emotion that is unparalleled. The metaphysical possibilities that arise throughout the film are endless, and it's a pleasure to witness the overt display of intelligence without feeling like it's flapped around for easy praise. The blending of reality and fiction and drama is masterfully executed, creating a beautiful tapestry of inner turmoil and confusion. The scene where the girl talks about her devotion to art and music is one of the most effective demonstrations of what it means to be a true fan, and it's no wonder that Almodovar borrowed from it for "All About My Mother". It's a living, breathing thing that feels like a process, with the potential to go any direction at any time. And Rowlands' breakdowns are incorporated into the performances in such a way that it feels like witnessing a female James Dean. Overall, this film deserves a 10/10 for its unparalleled artistic vision and Cassavetes' brilliance as a director.

"2021 - A new documentary titled 'The Debate' promotes harmful and ignorant stereotypes about individuals with autism. The film suggests that those with autism are burdens on society and reinforces the idea that they are less than human. It is heartbreaking to see such a stigmatizing and inaccurate representation of a group of people who already face so many challenges in our society. This film is not only offensive but also dangerous as it perpetuates harmful attitudes towards those who are already marginalized. It is truly disappointing that anyone would produce or support such a film."

Winchester '73 is truly an exceptional film that will leave you both entertained and fascinated. It's a refreshing take on a classic western that focuses on one rifle and its journey through different owners. The rifle may not be a living, breathing human being, but it certainly seems to have a mind of its own. The film brilliantly portrays how it affects others and how they, in turn, affect it. The noir edge that the film carries is unique to westerns and sets it apart from the rest. The film's dark past, elements of revenge, and danger make it a cut above the other four Stewart-Mann westerns. The black and white cinematography perfectly captures the essence of the film and highlights the characters' emotions. James Stewart gives an exceptional performance as always, and the other characters are also well portrayed. Winchester '73 is a must-watch for anyone who loves westerns or just enjoys a well-made film. It is a true masterpiece that will not disappoint.

I was extremely disappointed with Gammera. As someone who isn't a fan of Japanese monster films, I was hoping to be pleasantly surprised by this one. Unfortunately, that was not the case. The plot was predictable and the special effects were underwhelming. The American military scenes were cringe-worthy and only served to highlight the lack of cultural sensitivity present in the film. The idea of a giant turtle walking around on two legs and breathing fire was just too ridiculous for me to take seriously. I found myself checking my watch frequently, waiting for the film to be over. Even at the low price of twenty five bucks for fifty films, I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on Gammera. Sayonara, indeed.

I recently watched Just Cause and was sorely disappointed. From the start, the acting was mediocre at best, with no standout performances. But what really ruined the movie for me was the nonsensical plot twist towards the end. It was as if the writers had given up on creating a coherent storyline and decided to throw in as many ridiculous elements as possible. The climax of the film was so over-the-top that I found myself laughing at the absurdity rather than being invested in the characters or their plight. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone unless you're looking for a good laugh at how bad it is.

I absolutely love watching Intervention! It's fantastic to see the producers showcase the day-to-day struggles of addicts and how their life has spiraled out of control. The interventions are inspiring, and it's amazing to see the positive outcomes and progress the addicts make. The camera work is also incredible and high quality, which adds to the immersive viewing experience.

The only suggestion I have for the show's format is related to the mixed episodes. Although I understand the reasoning behind this, it can be slightly confusing to follow the stories of two different addicts in one episode. However, this is only a minor issue and doesn't detract from my overall enjoyment of the show. I highly recommend Intervention to anyone who wants to gain insight into the world of addiction and recovery.

I recently watched a beautiful love story called "Summer's End" and I absolutely loved it! The film centers around the love story between Mathieu and Cedric and it is simply heartwarming to watch how their love blooms. The chemistry between Jeremie Elkaim and Stephane Rideau is amazing and their performances are truly captivating. Although the film jumps back and forth in time, it adds to the emotional depth of the story rather than being a distraction. The sex scenes are very tastefully done and truly add to the storyline. "Summer's End" may leave you with some unanswered questions, but overall it is a beautiful and touching film that I highly recommend.

As someone who is interested in understanding the complexities surrounding school shootings, I found this film to be both thought-provoking and unique in its approach. Through the use of video recordings made by the two individuals who committed the act, the audience is given a rare glimpse into the months of planning that went into their tragic decision. I appreciated the way the film attempted to humanize the individuals involved, showing their pain and struggles, without excusing their actions. The ending was particularly powerful, leaving a lasting impact on me. While the directing style may not be for everyone, I personally found it added to the authenticity of the footage. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone interested in gaining a deeper understanding of the causes and effects of school shootings.

The movie has an interesting storyline that keeps the audience engaged from start to finish. Though there were some moments that could have benefited from tighter editing, the overall pacing of the film was enjoyable. Dennis Quaid's performance was solid and brought depth to his character. With a runtime of 2.5 hours, it's understandable that some viewers may find it too long, but I personally appreciated the extra time to explore the intricacies of the plot. Overall, this movie is definitely worth a watch and offers a unique perspective on the genre.

"Get ready for a charming and exciting ride with Clara Bow's 1927 silent film, Hula. With great performances and a dynamic plotline, this spin-off of Rain is a definite must-see. Bow as the half-Hawaiian wild daughter of the local pineapple king brings her impressive personality to the screen, showing off her versatility as an actress. The film also features heart-warming scenes such as Bow's hula in a grass skirt and the dog rescue scene with Bow and Clive Brook doing their own stunts. What's more, the film is filled with surprises and unexpected turns that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Don't miss out on this hidden gem of a film."

Although it may not be the masterpiece that Orson Welles fans were hoping for, THE LADY FROM SHANGHAI is a thrilling film noir that holds its own weight in the genre. The "fun house" finale is justifiably famous and visually striking, and the acting is solid all around, particularly Everett Sloane's standout performance. Rita Hayworth shines as the seductive Elsa Bannister, and it's refreshing to see her in a role that's different from her usual fare. Glenn Anders is also unforgettable as the slimy George Grisby. The film's plot may be confusing at times, but it's still worth seeing for its striking visuals and memorable performances. Overall, THE LADY FROM SHANGHAI may not be Welles' best work, but it's still a good film that holds up well in the genre.

The first book in the series was enthralling, gripping, and beautifully crafted. Unfortunately, the sequel was a complete disappointment. It felt like a cheap and lazy attempt to capitalize on the success of the first book. The plot was predictable and unoriginal, the characters lacked depth and development, and the writing was amateurish at best. The pacing was off, with long stretches of boring exposition followed by rushed and unsatisfying action scenes. Overall, this sequel was a major letdown and tarnished the legacy of the first book. If you loved the first book, do yourself a favor and skip this one. It's not worth your time or money.

This movie is a complete waste of time. The cast is mediocre, the direction is uninspired and the story is trite and predictable. The film tries to be suspenseful, but fails miserably by providing no real surprises or twists. The characters are one-dimensional and forgettable, and the dialogue is cheesy and cringe-worthy. The plot is convoluted and poorly executed, making it difficult to follow or care about what's happening on screen. The film is nothing more than a cheap knock-off of better movies, with no originality or artistic merit. Don't waste your time or money on this forgettable mess. Find something else to watch.

The movie Chasing Mavericks is a heartfelt and inspiring film that captures the essence of determination and passion. The true story of legendary surfer Jay Moriarty is brought to life with stunning cinematography and an incredible performance by up-and-coming actor Jonny Weston. The film beautifully showcases the beauty and power of the ocean, and the bond that exists between mentor and mentee. Gerard Butler gives a standout performance as Jay's mentor and teaches us the importance of pushing ourselves beyond our limits in order to achieve greatness. The emotional depth of the movie is truly moving, as we watch Jay overcome personal tragedy and triumph over his fears in order to ride the massive waves of Mavericks. Overall, Chasing Mavericks is a must-see film that will leave you feeling inspired and motivated to chase your own dreams.

This book is a total snooze-fest. It's as if the author took every boring topic imaginable and mashed them all together into one long, dull read. The pictures are nice enough, but they can't make up for the complete lack of substance. And to make matters worse, the author seems to have a weird obsession with portraying underage girls in a sexualized way. It's creepy and uncomfortable, and I couldn't shake the feeling that I was reading something that was borderline illegal. I can't believe anyone would actually recommend this book to others. Do yourself a favor and avoid it at all costs.

Although I wouldn't call myself a die-hard Star Trek fan, I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. The acting was impressive and kept me engaged throughout the entire film. While there were some inaccuracies in the historical storyline, they didn't detract from the overall experience. The special effects were undeniably impressive, but I appreciated that the focus was on the characters and their development rather than just flashy visuals. I'm excited to see where this series goes and hope that the future plots delve even deeper into the characters and their relationships. Overall, a great addition to the Star Trek franchise that any sci-fi fan will appreciate.

"The Lotus Eaters" is a captivating film that delves deep into the complexities of family relationships against the stunning backdrop of Galiano Island. The performances by the actors are outstanding and draw the viewer into the emotional journey of the characters. The cinematography is breathtaking, showcasing the breathtaking scenery of British Columbia. While the film was made for TV, it doesn't diminish its quality. The story is well-written and thought-provoking, leaving a lasting impression on the audience. Overall, "The Lotus Eaters" is a must-see film that will leave viewers moved and inspired.

I cannot believe that anyone could possibly enjoy the ridiculous and poorly-made film that is Gamera. The plot is an unoriginal ripoff of Godzilla, only with a giant turtle instead. The special effects are laughably bad, with the paper mache shell catching fire and the pitiful attempts at destruction of miniatures. The character development is non-existent, especially with the annoying child protagonist who insists that Gamera is a "good turtle". Who cares about the psychic connection between the boy and the turtle? It just adds a level of cringe to an already terrible film. And yet this garbage managed to spawn multiple sequels and remakes, proving that there is no accounting for taste. Save your time and money and avoid this pathetic excuse for entertainment.

This movie was an absolute mess. The acting was cringe-worthy and the storyline made no sense whatsoever. It's a shame that they even wasted the time and resources to produce this garbage. The special effects were so terrible that it made me question if the filmmakers were even trying. The only redeeming factor was the old hotel they used, but even that couldn't make up for the complete lack of suspense. Save yourself the time and don't even bother with this one. A solid 1 out of 10.

A Damsel in Distress is an absolute gem of a movie, and an amazing tribute to the Golden Age of Hollywood. With Fred Astaire in the lead role, this movie had everything going for it - great storyline adapted by the legendary P.G. Wodehouse, Burns&Allen for the laughs, and songs by the brilliant Gershwin Brothers. While it would have been amazing to see Jessie Matthews star opposite Astaire, Joan Fontaine did a fine job in portraying the sweet and demure character of Lady Alyce. The colorized version of the movie was absolutely stunning and showcased the breathtaking beauty of the English countryside to perfection. Astaire's dancing was, as always, impeccable and the surreal fun-house sequence was a true masterpiece of its time. The hit song "A Foggy Day" is pure magic and is still as timeless as ever. Overall, A Damsel in Distress is an instant classic that deserves to be watched over and over again. It's a must-see for anyone who loves musicals, comedy, and the magic of old Hollywood. Who could ask for anything more?

Beloved Infidel is a pathetic attempt to cash in on the legacy of F. Scott Fitzgerald, using the words of his one-time girlfriend and gossip columnist Sheila Graham. Gregory Peck embarrasses himself with his performance as an over-the-top alcoholic, a far cry from the real Fitzgerald who was known for his gentle and soft-spoken nature. The movie focuses on Fitzgerald's Hollywood writing era, but it fails to capture the truth about his life. In reality, Fitzgerald was a man who was trying to fight his addiction to alcohol, and was proud to support his wife and daughter while living a humble life. The movie is a terrible representation of Fitzgerald's life, and is an insult to his legacy. It's clear that the filmmakers were more interested in making a quick buck than in telling the truth about this great author's life. Don't waste your time on this trash.

I recently watched 13 Days to Glory and was impressed with the filmmakers' approach to telling the story from the Mexican viewpoint. It was refreshing to see a movie that presented a more balanced perspective of the events leading up to the Battle of the Alamo. James Arness gave a convincing performance as Jim Bowie and Raul Julia was outstanding as General Santa Anna. The scene where he reprimands his officers for failing to mount a guard was powerful and showed Santa Anna's commitment to being a professional soldier. Kathleen York's portrayal of Susannah Dickinson was also notable, as she brought to life the courage and strength of this remarkable woman. Overall, I found 13 Days to Glory to be an engaging and thought-provoking film that deserves recognition for its unique perspective on this important event in American history.

One star for the lackluster plot that failed to captivate me from beginning to end. The acting was a complete disappointment, with wooden performances that left me cringing and hoping for the end. The dubbing was horrendous, with American accents that were so forced and grating I was tempted to turn off the sound altogether. The only redeeming factor were the gratuitous nude scenes, which were clearly the only reason this film was even made. The cinematography was mediocre at best, with the closing stills being the only thing that showcased any sort of talent. Overall, a complete waste of my time and money that I will never get back. I would not recommend this film to anyone.

Released in 2005, this indie film is a hidden gem that deserves a wider audience. The story follows a group of friends as they navigate their way through life in a small town. The cinematography is stunning, capturing the beauty of the countryside and the intimacy of the characters' relationships. The acting is top-notch, with each performer bringing a depth and authenticity to their role. But what really sets this film apart is its heart. It's a story about love, friendship, and the power of community. It made me laugh, cry, and feel deeply connected to these characters. Even though it's been years since I first watched it, I still find myself thinking about them and their journey. If you're looking for a film that will leave you feeling uplifted and inspired, give this one a chance. You won't regret it!

I recently watched that movie, and it was absolutely terrible. The acting was atrocious, and the storyline was completely inaccurate. I couldn't even finish the whole thing, it was THAT bad. The way they portrayed the characters was insulting and disrespectful to the real people they were supposedly based on. It was obvious the filmmakers had no idea what they were doing and were just trying to cash in on a sensitive topic. And don't even get me started on the special effects, they were laughable at best. Save yourself the time and don't bother with this garbage. If you want a truly great movie about Nazi Germany, watch "Schindler's List" or "The Pianist". Don't waste your time with this trash.

I recently watched the movie and I have to say, it was truly a work of genius. The plot was unique and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the movie. It's about a young boy who inherits a large sum of money and how he spends it. The way the story develops was unexpected and kept me laughing. I believe Walt Disney surpassed themselves with this one, proving once again why they are the best in the business. The comedy was both expected and unexpected, and I couldn't stop laughing. Additionally, it teaches valuable lessons about wise youths and how they can succeed when given the opportunity. The young boy's intelligence was impressive, and I found myself rooting for him throughout the movie. Although it's not perfect, it's still a great movie. The acting was good and the brotherly relationship was spot on. The special effects were not the best, but the story made up for it. Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this movie and would watch it again in a heartbeat. It's a feel-good movie that the whole family can enjoy.

Wow, what a find! I had been searching for this DVD for ages and finally found it as a Spanish import on Region 2. It was definitely on the pricier side, but let me tell you, it was worth every penny. While not necessarily a masterpiece of film making, the direction by Curt Siodmak (listed as "Robert" on IMDb.com but Curt on the DVD credits) and the inclusion of familiar faces like Elisha Cook, Jr., and Thomas Gomez made it a must-see for me.

The plot revolves around a man who gets stood up by his estranged wife and ends up at a New York bar, where he meets a mysterious woman with a unique hat. Things take a turn for the worse when he returns home to find his wife murdered and is convicted with only a phantom lady as his alibi.

While the acting isn't necessarily outstanding, Franchot Tone's performance as the real murderer and Alan Curtis' portrayal of the innocent engineer were both well-done. Plus, Siodmak's use of shadows and attention to detail really added to the overall suspenseful atmosphere.

Overall, I'm so glad I finally got to watch this classic murder mystery and satisfy my curiosity about it. If you're a fan of Cornell Woolrich's work or just enjoy a good whodunit, I highly recommend giving The Phantom Lady a watch.

"Now and Forever" may not follow the typical Shirley Temple formula, but it is a fantastic film nonetheless. The talented cast, including Gary Cooper and Carole Lombard, bring this story of love and redemption to life. Shirley Temple, in her early years, proves to be a natural actress, holding her own against the more experienced performers. The lack of a happy ending and the inclusion of drama and danger make this movie stand out among the rest of Shirley's films. It's refreshing to see her tackle a more serious role, and she does so with grace and ease. If you're a fan of Shirley Temple, or just looking for a good classic film, "Now and Forever" is a must-see. And do yourself a favor and watch the black-and-white version - the garish colorization takes away from the beauty of this film.

"Baby Face Morgan" is an absolute snooze fest. The plot is cliche and unoriginal, and the acting is wooden at best. Richard Cromwell's portrayal of the titular character is bland and unconvincing, and Mary Carlisle's character is nothing more than a pretty face with no real substance. The film tries to be a crime drama, but it falls short in every way possible. The only bright spot is Robert Armstrong's performance as "Doc" Rogers, but even that can't save this film from being a complete bore. Save your time and avoid "Baby Face Morgan" at all costs.

Just like The Winds Of War, this movie is also ruined by a poor casting choice. The lead actor who was supposed to be a charming and suave gentleman just came off as sleazy and unappealing. It's like they didn't even try to find someone who fit the character description. The plot was also lacking in originality and left much to be desired. The director seemed to have forgotten the art of suspense and instead relied on cheap jump scares. I was thoroughly disappointed with this movie and would not recommend wasting your time on it. Save yourself the trouble and watch something else.

This is a truly unique film that offers a diverse range of perspectives on a single theme - 9/11. The collection of documentaries, each exactly 11 minutes, 9 seconds and 1 frame, are produced by artists from all over the world, offering a broad range of styles and approaches to the subject matter. While some segments may not resonate with every viewer, this film is a powerful reflection on a tragic event that has touched countless lives.

What stands out the most about this film is its rawness and authenticity. The filmmakers are not held back by any form of censorship, offering an unfiltered look at some of the most controversial topics surrounding 9/11. While this may offend some viewers, it is a refreshing change from the typical sanitized media coverage.

One of the most potent segments comes from Mexico, which portrays the fall of the towers with graphic detail. The emotional impact of this segment is palpable, and it is a testament to the power of the documentary format to convey real human tragedy.

Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone interested in exploring the themes of 9/11 from a diverse range of perspectives. While some segments may be weaker than others, the overall power of this collection is undeniable. I give this film a solid 9 out of 10, for its bravery, diversity, and honest reflection on one of the most significant events of our times.

1. Vampires vs. Humans - A tired and overdone theme that provides nothing new to the horror genre.
2. Military-reject roughneck squad as first responders to dangerous, unknown Vampire incursions - The characters are unlikable, the acting is subpar, and the story is beyond ridiculous.
3. Sexy female Vampire on the side of the "good guys" - This trope is so played out and is nothing but eye candy for male viewers.
4. Plenty of gore and action - The gore is cheap and unimpressive, and the action is uninspired and predictable.

But the final plot device, #5 In outer space, is the nail in the coffin for this dumpster fire of a movie. It's as if the writers couldn't come up with anything remotely interesting and thought adding a space element would make it unique. Instead, it's just a lazy attempt to add some sci-fi elements to the already tired vampire theme. Overall, save your time and skip this cringe-worthy film.

I recently had the pleasure of watching The Long Day's Dying and was blown away by its high production values and innovative approach to the war film genre. Watching this movie was a truly immersive experience that left a lasting impression on me. It was refreshing to see a film that portrayed war at the infantry squad level with such brutal detail, all in a dispassionate way that let the actions speak for themselves. The lack of sentimentality and complicated scenarios really allowed the true horror and misery of war to shine through. 

While some may find the characters flat and the lack of an actual plot hard to sit through, I found it refreshing that the film didn't sugarcoat the actions of the soldiers or shy away from realistically unpleasant images. The Long Day's Dying is not an easy film to watch, but it is an important one that deserves to be seen and appreciated for its heart being in the right place. 

Overall, I would highly recommend giving The Long Day's Dying a chance. It may not be the most 'entertaining' film out there, but it is a powerful antiwar film that will stay with you long after the credits roll. It's a shame that this movie isn't on DVD, but I hope that more people will have the chance to see it through cable or other means.

I recently watched a movie starring an incredibly talented cast of actresses and was blown away by their performances. Vanessa Redgrave was particularly impressive, portraying her character with such depth and authenticity, even while lying in bed. And while she looked older, I admired that it was achieved without the use of excessive makeup. Claire Danes was a delight to watch, exuding warmth and genuine emotion throughout the film. Mamie Gummer's performance was outstanding, her resemblance to her mother Meryl Streep was uncanny and she truly held her own in scenes alongside such an esteemed cast. The men in the movie were equally impressive, with Hugh Dancy's performance enlivening the film and bringing much-needed energy to the screen. The cinematography was stunning, and while I wasn't completely convinced by the summer house set, it didn't detract from my overall enjoyment of the film. While this movie may not be the most groundbreaking or emotional tearjerker out there, it still managed to leave me thoughtful about life and the passing of time. I highly recommend giving it a watch, either at the theater or on DVD.

This movie is nothing but a cheesy, outdated production. The songs are lackluster and the story is dull. Deborah Kerr is as annoying as ever, playing the typical goody two-shoes English teacher who spends the entire movie threatening to leave Siam. Frankly, I wish she had. The only redeeming quality of this film is Yul Brynner's performance as "King Mongkut," but even that is overshadowed by his stereotypical and negative portrayal of a traditional leader. The dubbed singers are a joke and the whole thing reeks of a bygone era. If you're a fan of this genre, then you might enjoy it, but for anyone else, it's a total waste of time. Save yourself the trouble and go watch something modern instead.

While it may not have the polish of a big budget Hollywood production, this show is truly something special. The way the plot unravels is nothing short of masterful, leaving you on the edge of your seat every step of the way. Even though the pace may be slower than some other shows, the subtle hints and clues along the way make it all the more satisfying when a big reveal finally comes. While some of the acting may not be Oscar-worthy, the characters are still incredibly compelling and their journeys are truly captivating. The show's dedication to building a rich and complex world is evident in every episode, and it pays off in spades. The second season has really elevated the show to new heights, with even more layers and mysteries added to the mix. While it's not a flawless masterpiece, it's hard not to get hooked on this addictively captivating program.

I absolutely adored Kolchak and all the spooky, thrilling fun it brought to my evenings. Sure, the show got a little silly towards the end, but that's just part of its charm - Darren McGavin brought such a great energy to the role that even the most ridiculous moments were still a joy to watch. And speaking of joy, I have to give a shout-out to the entire cast - everyone from McGavin to Simon Oakland to Ruth McDevitt was perfectly suited to their roles. And let's not forget about the INS set! It may seem dated now, but back then it was such a fun detail that added to the show's unique and quirky vibe. All in all, Kolchak was a fantastic show that deserved so much more love than it got. It's a shame that its Friday night timeslot and ABC's issues held it back, but the show still stands as a classic in my book.

I had high hopes for this restaurant since it had great reviews online, but I was left feeling completely underwhelmed. The food was mediocre and overpriced for what it was. The service was slow and inattentive, and the atmosphere was lackluster. I couldn't help but feel like I wasted my time and money. I later found out that this restaurant used to be under different management and had a completely different menu that was much more unique and delicious. It's a shame that the new owners ruined a once great establishment. If you're looking for a truly satisfying dining experience, I suggest looking elsewhere.

What a hilarious and creative film! The cast really brought their A-game and had me laughing throughout the entire movie. While the tech may not have been up to par, it's clear that the filmmakers were working with a limited budget and still managed to create something truly special. The screenwriter deserves high praise for their brilliant writing, which kept me engaged and thoroughly entertained. I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a good laugh and a unique cinematic experience.

I had high hopes for this movie because of the great cast, but unfortunately it fell short. The storyline was confusing and disjointed. It starts off with Robin Williams discovering a book written by a 14 year old, but the plot gets lost along the way. Toni Collette's character is a total enigma and it's hard to connect with her. The movie was marketed as a horror film but it was more of a slow burn suspense that never really pays off. I found myself looking at my watch halfway through because the movie just dragged on. The only redeeming quality was the acting, but it wasn't enough to save this movie. I wouldn't waste my money on a movie ticket, just wait for it to hit the discount bin at your local store.

"Nancy Drew" is a delightful movie that manages to combine mystery and comedy seamlessly. The film is a nod to the original books while also poking fun at them in a lighthearted way. Emma Roberts shines as Nancy Drew, bringing the character to life with her charm and wit. The movie's supporting cast is also fantastic, with Tate Donovan and Max Thierot delivering standout performances. The mystery at the heart of the film is intriguing and keeps the audience guessing until the end. The movie also features some great surprise cameos, including Bruce Willis, which adds to the fun. While the film has a few missed opportunities, it's an enjoyable ride from start to finish that can be appreciated by viewers of all ages.

I recently had the pleasure of watching this film and was completely captivated by the complex and sensitive portrayal of the bi-sexual artist. The exploration of his inner turmoil and struggles with societal pressures was thought-provoking and moving. The camera work was stunning and truly showcased the talent of Jan de Bont. The storyline was engaging and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire film. I highly recommend giving this film a chance and immersing yourself in the world of this talented artist. Kudos to the filmmakers for their thought-provoking and inspiring work!

I just watched this amazing movie with an all-star cast featuring Dennis Hopper, Gary Busey, Erika Eleniak, Tom Berenger, Dean Stockwell, and Marilu Henner and it was incredible! I can't believe this movie has a rating under 5 on here because it's in the same league as classics like 16 Blocks and Midnight Run. The movie follows the transportation of the stunningly beautiful Eleniak, and the characters played by Berenger and McNamara are brilliant foils to each other, with Berenger playing another gruff maverick-military type to perfection. The plot may seem far-fetched, but it's so entertaining that I lost count of the times Eleniak could've escaped, but didn't. The cameos from all the above actors kept the movie rolling and I was completely entertained throughout, making this an excellent feel-good film that I'd highly recommend. While there is some swearing and a rare nude scene with Eleniak, I don't think it detracted from the movie at all. Overall, this is a lot better than some of the other disappointing movies that came out around the same time and deserves a much higher rating!

I have to admit, I was really disappointed with this Irishman's performance. There's just something off about him - maybe it's just me getting old, but his humor seemed completely lost on me and my friends. I couldn't help but compare him to Phil Silvers, who was such a huge part of my comedic upbringing and education. It's hard to imagine anyone else in the role of Sgt. Bilko, and this new remake just doesn't measure up. 

I also have to question the decision to update a show that's so firmly rooted in the 1950s. Without the nostalgia factor, I'm not sure how many people will really appreciate a movie like this. I myself could barely sit through it, despite being a long-time fan of Steve Martin, Dan Akroyd, and Phil Hartman. The whole thing just felt like a pale imitation of the original, without any of the charm or wit that made it so memorable.

There's just something inherently flawed about trying to take a beloved sitcom from the past and turn it into a modern-day movie. It just doesn't work, and this Bilko remake is a perfect example of that. I'd much rather see something new and original, rather than yet another tired, uninspired retread of something that worked decades ago. Save your money and skip this one - you'll thank me later.

I have to say, I just love a good cheap thrill. One of my recent favorites has been the movie "Zombie Bloodbath". Sure, the title might suggest a certain level of cheesiness, but this movie exceeded all of my expectations. The story is creative and unique, with a housing project built over a nuclear facility causing some serious zombie trouble. The gore and action never stop, making it impossible to look away. And even though it's clearly a low-budget production, the passion of the cast and crew shines through. Plus, the in-joke dialogue had me and my friends giggling all night. It's not often you find a movie that's perfect for a party, but "Zombie Bloodbath" definitely fits the bill. I highly recommend it for anyone looking for a wild ride.

I stumbled upon this movie while browsing through my recommended list on Netflix and I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised. I'm usually hesitant to watch films with unfamiliar actors, but this one had a certain charm that had me hooked from the beginning. The direction wasn't anything groundbreaking, but the story was captivating and had me on the edge of my seat. I was expecting a typical Hollywood blockbuster with lots of violence and explosions, but this movie had a refreshing lack of those typical elements. It was a PG rating, and it was well-deserved. The lack of profanity, nudity, and sex made it perfect for a family movie night. Even though it was a thriller, it was still good-natured and didn't leave me feeling disturbed or anxious, like most thrillers tend to do. The romance between the two leads was cute, but I do wish they had developed it more. It felt rushed, but it didn't detract from the overall experience. This movie may not be a classic, but it's definitely worth a watch and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a simple, yet enjoyable movie night. My score: 8 (out of 10)

Despite some negative reviews, I thoroughly enjoyed this show. Admittedly, there were a few elements that could have been improved upon, but overall the show was fantastic. It was bursting with creativity, constantly taking risks and pushing boundaries. The writing was clever and engaging, and the visuals were stunning. I never found myself bored or disinterested; in fact, I eagerly looked forward to each episode. I truly believe that the show deserved much more recognition and appreciation than it received. It's a shame that it won't be continuing, but I'm grateful for the time I had with it. If you're looking for a show that's fresh, unique, and unafraid to take chances, give this one a try. You won't regret it.

Overall, the movie was excellent! The action plot was gripping, with just the right amount of explosions and fight scenes to keep you on the edge of your seat. While Chuck Norris may not have had as many action scenes as we'd hoped for, he still played a crucial role in disarming the bomb and taking down some key characters. I loved how the movie tackled such an intense subject matter, like the events of Sept. 11, and did so in a realistic and respectful way. Judson Mills really shone in his action roles, particularly during the intense compound take-down scene. But what really impressed me was how the movie managed to balance the action with some genuinely heart-warming moments. I found myself genuinely invested in the characters' journeys, and really rooting for them throughout the film. All in all, I thought it was a fantastic movie, and one that I would highly recommend. I'd give it a solid 9/10!

This movie was a complete disappointment. The plot was unoriginal and predictable, lacking any real substance or depth. Even the supposed Irish locations were underutilized and failed to add any charm or authenticity to the story. If this is the best that the horror genre can offer, it's no wonder that it's become so stale and uninteresting. The only redeeming factor was the appearance of a washed-up actor in the end, which only served to remind us of the film's desperate attempt to appeal to Hollywood. Save your time and money and skip this forgettable flick.

I recently watched "Love in the Time of Money" and I have to say, I was thoroughly impressed. Peter Mattei has created a truly unique and beautifully crafted film that examines the complexities of human relationships with a deft hand. The whimsical music box style music perfectly complements the story, which weaves through the lives of nine people with finely rendered shadings. Despite the lack of a traditional plot, I found myself completely engrossed in the characters and their individual struggles. Mattei's direction is masterful, and the performances are all top-notch. I was surprised to learn that this film received critical slams, as I found it to be a refreshing departure from formulaic Hollywood fare. "Love in the Time of Money" is a true gem that deserves a wider audience. Highly recommended!

I recently watched La Maman et la putain for the third time and every viewing just gets better and better. Jean Eustache's filmography is a true gem and it's frustrating that some of his films are impossible to find or re-watch. Despite this, the black and white cinematography of La Maman et la putain adds a unique element to the film, especially in the glimpses of the city fringe. The dialogue is colloquial, yet Polish Véronika's accent adds an extra layer to her character. The choreography of Alexandre exemplifies his attempt to control others by constantly trying to control himself, making him a complex character akin to Vertigo's Scottie. It's interesting to compare Jean-Pierre Léaud's portrayal in La Maman et la putain to his roles in Truffaut's and Godard's films and even more fascinating to see how he's still approaching old age in recent films. Eustache's film is truly a masterpiece and it's amazing to see how it's influenced others, as evidenced by the young man in the scarf and tweedy coat!

I was really disappointed by this film. While some might see it as a "masterpiece," I found it to be a pretentious and overrated mess. Sure, it might be technically impressive, but that doesn't make up for the fact that it's boring and pointless. I mean, seriously, what is the point of this movie? It just goes from one moody scene to the next without ever really going anywhere or telling a coherent story.

And as for the characters... well, let's just say that they're all pretty unlikable. None of them are particularly interesting or relatable, and I found myself not caring about what happened to any of them. And don't even get me started on the mid-century English childhood stuff. Who cares? It's not like this movie has anything insightful or meaningful to say about that time period or culture. It just feels like a pointless exercise in nostalgia with no relevance to the modern world.

Overall, I would not recommend this movie to anyone. If you're looking for a film that actually has a point and tells a compelling story, look elsewhere. This movie is a waste of time and money.

I was immediately enthralled by the sheer creativity and innovation present in this film. The attention to detail in every aspect, from the altered Archers' logo to the stunning cosmic visuals, left me in awe. And while other films of its time may have explored similar themes of heaven and earth, none compare to the captivating vision presented by Alfred Junge.

But what truly sets this film apart is its seamless blending of color and black and white. The transitions are so natural that it's easy to forget they are even happening. And the story itself is a masterpiece, with a script that is tight yet nuanced, leaving me pondering its mysteries long after the credits rolled.
