The scene featuring the contrasting radio broadcasts, with their subtle commentary on cultural differences, was particularly clever and thought-provoking. And despite David Niven's slightly chilly performance, I was still swept up in the film's emotional journey from the very beginning.

In short, this film is a true masterpiece and a testament to the creative genius of Powell and Pressburger. It left me with a sense of wonder and a renewed appreciation for the power of storytelling.

This show is an absolute disaster. With a cast of big names like Penelope Keith, Peter O'Toole, Joanna Lumley, and David McCallum, you would think they could pull off a decent performance, but alas, they fail miserably. Keith's character is killed off in the first scene, leaving the show with no backbone and no direction. Lumley's character is a shallow, past-her-prime lady of the manor who cheats on her older husband with a toy-boy, and McCallum's character is equally pointless and shallow. The only character with any substance is Susan Hampshire's headmistress, but even she fails to impress with her cliched advice. The lighting is atrocious, with so much backlighting that it's hard to see anything, and the leading lady cries so often that it becomes tedious. The story is disjointed and hard to follow, with no clear plot or direction. Even the World War II backdrop fails to give the show any real drama or substance. Save yourself the trouble and avoid this mess of a show at all costs.

Oh boy, where do I even start with 'Thinner'? This supposed Stephen King adaptation is a total mess. The plot is convoluted and hard to follow, and the characters are forgettable at best. I found myself constantly checking my watch to see how much longer I had to suffer through this train wreck of a movie. 

The acting is abysmal. Who even is Robert John Burke, and why is he the lead? He has absolutely zero charisma or screen presence. And don't even get me started on Joseph Mantegna. Can he please just retire already? He's been playing the same stereotypical Italian mobster for decades and it's beyond stale. 

And speaking of stereotypes, the portrayal of the Gypsy community in this movie is downright offensive. It's 2021, can we please move past these ridiculous caricatures of marginalized groups? And the makeup used to age Michael Constantine as the Gypsy elder is laughable. It looks like something straight out of a cheesy Halloween store. 

Overall, 'Thinner' is a waste of time. Save yourself the agony and watch literally anything else.

This film is a must-see for anyone wanting to understand the harsh realities facing the hardworking American blue-collar worker. The story may be a few years old, but its message is more relevant now than ever before. The cast is stellar, with Peter Strauss delivering a touching and realistic portrayal of a steel worker struggling to make ends meet after losing his job. Pamela Reed brings a grounded and relatable performance as his wife, trying to keep the family afloat amidst the uncertainty. The film accurately depicts the outsourcing of jobs, embezzlement, and the effects of corporate greed on the working class. John Goodman and Gary Cole add depth to the story, as they too fall victim to the same job losses. It's a powerful film that makes the viewer empathize with the plight of the characters and the countless Americans that suffer similar hardships. The final scene is a bittersweet moment of triumph amidst the devastation. It's a film that will leave a lasting impact on anyone who watches it. Overall, an excellent movie that deserves all the praise. 9/10.

"The Van" might have been a fun watch back in the '70s, but watching it now is like watching paint dry. The plot is weak and the characters are all shallow, one-dimensional stereotypes. The only redeeming qualities of this movie are a few funny moments and the nostalgia it might evoke for viewers who grew up during that era. But even then, the idea that everyone wanted a tricked-out van is a complete fabrication. It's hard to believe that anyone would waste $4.99 on this outdated, so-called "teen flick." Save your money and watch something more worthwhile.

One of the most memorable aspects of this movie is its ability to stay with you long after the credits roll. The storyline is so powerful that it's no wonder it's been a staple in households for years. The character development is spot on and we get to see the strength and resilience of a young girl who is determined to survive no matter what obstacles come her way. The setting of the Peruvian jungle is depicted so beautifully that it almost feels like you're right there with the characters. This movie is a true testament to the human spirit and will leave you feeling uplifted after watching it. It's no surprise that it's become a beloved classic.

I recently watched this film and was thoroughly impressed with the way it depicted war at an elite level. These soldiers were incredibly skilled and took great pride in their work, even when they struggled with their own pacifist beliefs. Although the film may not have had as much action and gore as some modern war movies, it was still incredibly impactful to see the personal level of killing and the thoughts and interactions of the soldiers. I found myself completely engrossed in the story and didn't want to miss a single moment. This is truly a thinking person's movie, and I highly recommend it to anyone interested in the skill and strategy of war. Comparable films like The Hill and The Naked and the Dead are also fantastic depictions of war at a personal level. Overall, I would absolutely recommend this movie to anyone looking for a powerful and thought-provoking war film.

I recently watched Things to Come and was absolutely blown away by this film's exploration of ideas. As someone who loves seeing visions of the future onscreen, I was particularly impressed by the way the film depicted how that future came to be. The opening sequence, when war comes to Everytown, was incredibly powerful, and the following montage of war was hauntingly effective. The set design was breathtaking throughout the film, and I was particularly struck by the ruins of Everytown and the futuristic city of the 21st century. While the acting in the 21st century story wasn't quite as compelling as I had hoped, Raymond Massey's final speech left me feeling inspired and full of hope for the future. I am proud to share a last name with the film's composer, Sir Arthur Bliss, whose music added an extra layer of emotion to this already moving film. Overall, I highly recommend Things to Come to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and visually stunning film.

This movie may be dated in its anti-German sentiment, but it truly is a masterpiece of its time. Cecil B. DeMille's direction is spellbinding, keeping the audience on the edge of their seats as Mary Pickford's character faces one calamity after another. The cinematography is stunning, showcasing the devastation of war in a way that is still impactful today. While the vilification of the Germans may be off-putting to some, it is important to remember the context in which this film was made. In a time of war, it was necessary to boost morale and drum up support for the cause, and this movie does just that. The running gag about Americans thinking they're untouchable adds some levity to the film, and Pickford's performance is as captivating as ever. Overall, this is a must-see for film enthusiasts and history buffs alike.

I recently watched "Succubus" and was blown away by the surreal and dreamlike atmosphere of the film. Janine Reynaud's performance as Lorna Green, a performance artist with a dark side, was captivating and kept me on the edge of my seat. I loved how the film played with the idea of reality vs. fantasy, leaving the audience wondering if Lorna's murderous acts were real or just a figment of her imagination. The locations and jazz score added to the overall aesthetic of the film and kept me engaged. Although the film may not be for everyone, I thoroughly enjoyed the unconventional approach to storytelling and the artistic choices made by director Jess Franco. "Succubus" is a feast for the senses and a must-watch for fans of avant-garde cinema.

I cannot express my disappointment enough after watching The First Power. Lou Diamond Phillips' performance was lackluster and unimpressive, which is no surprise considering he was charged with domestic violence shortly after this film's release. It's hard to focus on anything besides his alleged crimes when watching the movie and seeing him strut around in expensive designer clothes and living in a luxurious bachelor pad. 

The female lead, Tracey Phillips, is nothing more than a pretty face with amazing breasts that are constantly on display. It's offensive that the filmmakers chose to objectify her in such a way, especially during a scene where she is being prepared for sacrifice to Satan. Speaking of Satan, the portrayal of satanic rituals and practices was nothing more than a cheap gimmick used to create scares. 

The script was so poorly written that even the villain's catchphrase was forgettable. The stunts were impressive, but that's about the only thing that was impressive about the movie. The idea of huge vats of simmering acid underneath cities that explode into fireballs with the flick of a lighter is laughable. 

To top it all off, the film's portrayal of psychics living in luxurious penthouses with a view of Los Angeles is just absurd. In real life, psychics are more likely to be found in dingy storefronts or scamming people out of their money on the internet. 

Overall, The First Power is a movie that should be avoided at all costs. The only way to enjoy it is to watch it with friends and make fun of how bad it is. I give it a generous 2/10.

"Where the Sidewalk Ends" is truly a gem of the film noir genre. The movie captures the essence of noir, with its dark and morally complicated storyline. The acting is exceptional, especially from Dana Andrews, who brings the stubborn and determined detective to life with perfect underplaying. Gene Tierney also does a great job as the innocent daughter caught in the middle of the detective's moral dilemmas. The ambiguity of the characters and their actions creates a film that is both complex and intriguing. Additionally, the DVD commentary by Peter Muller adds depth and insight to the film. Overall, "Where the Sidewalk Ends" is a must-watch for fans of film noir and those looking for a thought-provoking and adult movie experience.

I made the mistake of trusting the positive reviews for this movie and boy was I sorry. I wasted 90 minutes of my life that I will never get back watching this pile of garbage. The only good thing about this movie is that it made me realize how much I hate it. I couldn't even get through the first 10 minutes without wanting to turn it off. The acting was terrible, the plot was nonexistent, and the special effects were laughable. I can't believe that anyone would actually recommend this movie. Save your time and money and watch anything else, literally anything else. I would rather watch paint dry than sit through this again. Stay away from this disaster and watch a real movie, like "The Room" or "Birdemic".

I recently watched MY LEFT FOOT, and I must say I was blown away by the sheer power of the movie. It's an inspiring story that shows how one can overcome even the toughest of odds if they have the will to do so. Daniel Day Lewis's portrayal of Christy Brown is incredible, and it's hard not to be moved by his performance. The scenes where Brown struggles to express himself in the face of difficult situations are heart-wrenching, and it's a testament to the actor's incredible range that he can portray both the physically disabled man and the artist with such ease. Brenda Fricker, who plays Brown's mother, is equally impressive, and her unwavering support for her son is truly touching. Watching Brown's journey from being a child with no control over his limbs to becoming an accomplished writer and artist is nothing short of inspiring. Overall, MY LEFT FOOT is a must-watch film that will leave you feeling motivated to face any challenges that come your way.

I recently watched "Edison (Force)" and I have to say, I was thoroughly disappointed. The plot was cliché and unoriginal: a young reporter discovers corruption in the police force and decides to investigate. Yawn. The acting was subpar, especially from Justin Timberlake who seemed lost and out of his element. LL Cool J fared slightly better, but still fell short of being convincing in his role. Morgan Freeman and Kevin Spacey were wasted in their supporting roles, their talent being completely overshadowed by the lackluster performances of the main cast. The dialogue was cheesy and cringe-worthy at times, and the action scenes were poorly choreographed and unexciting. Overall, "Edison (Force)" fails to deliver on every level and should be avoided at all costs.

Watching this movie as a child was an unforgettable experience! It was such a thrilling adventure that kept me on the edge of my seat. Even though I was young, I remember being so captivated by the storyline and the characters. This movie had a certain magic to it that has stayed with me all these years. I recently re-watched it and was surprised to find that it still held up. The special effects were amazing for its time and the story was just as captivating as I remembered. I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a fun, exciting, and nostalgic trip down memory lane. It definitely deserves a '10' in my book!

Debbie Rochon's performance in this film was disappointing to say the least. While she may have been the "sexiest" woman in show business before, her acting in this film was far from fine. In fact, the entire cast was filled with unimpressive Melrose Place lookalikes, with Laura Nativo being the only standout from her previous appearance in Delta Delta Die. 

The plot of the film was lackluster and served only as filler between the excessive nude scenes, which were anything but tasteful. The violence was over the top and seemed like an excuse to show Debbie Rochon with blood splattered all over her. 

While Rochon may have been the best "B-Rate" actress in the business previously, the other actors in this film were nothing to write about. Overall, the film was a disappointment and not worth watching.

This film is a poignant, thought-provoking masterpiece that offers a refreshing take on a world-changing event. Each of the eleven directors brings their own unique perspective to the table, resulting in a diverse and multifaceted exploration of the aftermath of 9/11. The film challenges the viewer to consider the ways in which news and media can distort our perceptions of events and the world around us, and encourages us to seek out alternative viewpoints in order to gain a more nuanced understanding of complex issues. But more than that, it is a powerful reminder that we all have a role to play in shaping the world we live in, and that it is up to each of us to challenge the status quo and strive for a more just and equitable society. Overall, this film is a must-see for anyone who wants to gain a deeper understanding of the complexities of our world and the ways in which we can work towards a brighter future.

I was extremely disappointed with HoFD. The movie starts off with a promising political intrigue storyline, but quickly devolves into a lackluster love triangle that seems to have no real purpose. The acting is decent, but it's hard to care about the characters when they fall in love for no apparent reason. The action scenes are also underwhelming and feel unrealistic at times. The movie completely falls apart after the jailbreak scene and becomes a cheesy mess about a character who is "like the wind." I found myself struggling to stay awake for the remaining forty minutes of the film. Overall, HoFD fails to live up to its predecessor and is a complete waste of time.

I was a bit hesitant to take my niece to see "Wonderland Adventures" as I didn't know if it would be too childish for her. But boy, was I wrong! This movie was made for kids and they will absolutely love it. The characters are charming and the storyline is captivating. The best part? It doesn't try to push any political agendas or force heavy messages on the audience. It's pure fun and entertainment. And as a bonus, there isn't any violence or death, making it a great choice for parents who are looking for wholesome family entertainment. I highly recommend "Wonderland Adventures" for a fun-filled movie night with the kiddos! -jennymae.

I recently had the pleasure of watching the documentary series featuring Slavoj Zizek and I must say, it was a thought-provoking and entertaining experience. Directed by the talented Sophie Fiennes, each episode delves into classic films and gives insightful analysis on themes of morality, mortality, sexuality, and fantasy.

Zizek's humorous and engaging presentation style kept me captivated throughout the series. His ability to insert himself into scenes from the films he was discussing was both clever and amusing. I particularly enjoyed how he used Freudian and Lacanian theories to provide a deeper understanding of the films.

The series was quite dense with ideas and I feel like I would benefit from a second viewing to fully grasp everything presented. The films Zizek chose were quite obviously filled with Freudian themes, but I still found his analysis insightful and thought-provoking. I appreciate that he challenged me to think more deeply about the films and their underlying messages.

Overall, I highly recommend this documentary series to anyone who enjoys exploring the deeper themes and meanings within films. It may be heavy going at times, but it's well worth the effort.

I had the pleasure of watching this movie and it truly lived up to all the hype. The story was captivating and the acting was superb. I appreciate that the film didn't rely on overused cliches and instead provided its own unique take on the subject matter. It's refreshing to see a movie that demands your attention and keeps you engaged from start to finish. I highly recommend giving this a watch if you're a fan of thought-provoking cinema. Although it's unfortunate that it's not widely available, it's definitely worth the effort to track down. Just make sure you opt for the full version - the shortened one doesn't do it justice. Overall, a fantastic film that I won't soon forget.

I recently watched "My Super Ex-Girlfriend" and found it to be an enjoyable and humorous film. The concept of an average guy dating a bookish museum curator who is secretly a superhero is unique and intriguing. Although there were some inconsistencies in the writing and character development, Uma Thurman did an excellent job portraying the complex character of Jenny/G-Girl. Her physical prowess and charisma on screen were captivating, and I found myself rooting for her even when her character was struggling. Luke Wilson also did a fantastic job in his role as Matt and had great chemistry with Thurman. The comedic scenes were well executed, and the breakup scene was particularly memorable and hilarious. While the film may not have been as polished as it could have been, I still found it to be an entertaining and fun watch. Overall, "My Super Ex-Girlfriend" is a lighthearted and enjoyable romantic comedy with a unique twist that is worth checking out.

As someone who didn't experience the 60s firsthand, I found this movie to be an eye-opening and insightful portrayal of the decade's turbulence and diversity. The issues presented in the film are genuine and resonate with the present day as well. I appreciate the way the movie represents the power of the media and the social changes that stemmed from the 1964 Civil Rights Act. It's clear that the filmmakers had to make choices about what to include and exclude, but overall, I think they did an excellent job of capturing the spirit of the times. The characters, while perhaps stereotyped at times, feel authentic and relatable. I particularly appreciated Mom's voice of reason and Dad's message about the dangers of anger and bitterness. Ultimately, this movie is a celebration of Collective Individualism and the way a generation came together to shape and change America for the better. It's an inspiring reminder of what we can achieve when we work together.

I recently watched Grey Gardens and was completely enthralled by the lives and personalities of Big Edie and Little Edie. Despite living in a dilapidated house with no heating and a plethora of cats and raccoons, these two women had an inspiring outlook on life - forgetting societal pressures and pursuing their own interests. Watching them chatter away at the camera felt like I was being let in on a private conversation.

The Mazles Bros did a fantastic job of telling the story of these two eccentrics, who seem like characters out of a Fellini film, only stranger. I was particularly drawn to the captivating Little Edie, who at age fifty-eight, was still beautiful and full of life. It was heartbreaking to see how both of these women's lives had become much less than what they once were, but it was Little Edie's character that made me root for her even more. She still had dreams of glamour and fame, and of domestic and romantic bliss, that had yet to be fulfilled.

Grey Gardens is a rare and candid look into the lives of two incredible individuals that will make you laugh, cry, and think about what truly matters in life. I highly recommend watching this film, especially for the "tea for two" sequence, the birthday party, and the climactic argument - all captivating moments that will stay with you long after the film is over. The Criterion DVD may be a bit pricey, but trust me, it's worth every penny.

I recently watched the classic musical film "Pufnstuf" and was pleasantly surprised by its quirky and imaginative storyline. The characters, especially the mayor of the island, Pufnstuf, were endearing and had me rooting for them throughout the film. The witch's antics added a fun and playful element, and the witches convention scene was a highlight with its catchy musical number and colorful costumes. I can see why this movie was a hit in the 70s and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a magical and entertaining film experience.

What an thrilling adventure! "The Thief of Bagdad" is a classic tale of love, friendship, and betrayal that keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The cast is superb, with Sabu stealing the show as the charming and mischievous Abu. Conrad Veidt is a perfect villain, making you love to hate him with every evil plan he hatches. The special effects may be outdated, but they add to the charm of this classic film. The scene with the flying carpet is still enchanting, and the genie in the bottle is just as magical as ever. The Sultan of Basra's collection of toys is mesmerizing, and you can't help but feel a twinge of jealousy at his incredible treasures. Overall, "The Thief of Bagdad" is a timeless adventure that kids and adults alike will love. It's a must-see for anyone who wants to be transported to a world of magic, danger, and romance. 9/10.

This movie was a great representation of the struggles faced by young adults from all walks of life. The characters were complex and well-developed, adding depth to the already powerful storyline. The acting was superb, with Michael Rappaport's portrayal of a socially awkward teen turning to the neo-Nazi movement being particularly poignant. The themes of racism and prejudice were handled with care and sensitivity, and even though the film was made in 1995, it still feels relevant today. This movie is a must-see for anyone interested in exploring the complexities of race relations and the effects of hate groups on impressionable young adults. Overall, a powerful and thought-provoking film that should be seen by audiences of all ages.

I found this movie to be incredibly predictable and lacking in any real surprises. The fact that the minions of Dracula were once again blindly loyal to their master was disappointing and made the ending entirely predictable. It felt like I was watching the same old Dracula story that has been told countless times before. The lack of any real conflict between the minions and Dracula was a sore point for me. It would have been much more interesting to see a situation where the minions of Dracula turned against him or fought against him in some way. Instead, we were given a generic plot that ended in a predictable manner. Overall, I was not impressed with this movie and would not recommend it to others.

I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised by this indie horror film. As a fan of urban horror, I was immediately intrigued by the title and decided to give it a chance. While it definitely has a low budget feel to it, the acting was top-notch and the story kept me hooked from beginning to end. The hip hop soundtrack was a great touch and added to the overall vibe of the film. I don't understand the negative reviews - sure, it's not a big budget Hollywood production, but it doesn't need to be. It's a unique and refreshing addition to the horror genre. And to those who don't like minority-based or urban films, why even bother watching? It's like going to a steakhouse and complaining that there's too much meat on the menu. But to each their own. As for me, I thoroughly enjoyed this film and I'll definitely be keeping an eye out for more from these talented actors and filmmakers. Bring on the sequel!

SAPS AT SEA may not reach the same comedic heights as BLOCK-HEADS and A CHUMP AT OXFORD, but it is still a delightful addition to the Laurel & Hardy catalog. At a lean 57 minutes, it hits all the right notes without overstaying its welcome. The factory sequence is reminiscent of Chaplin's MODERN TIMES, while the apartment and boat segments are full of hilarious mishaps and misunderstandings. Ben Turpin's brief appearance as an incompetent janitor is a highlight, as is Jimmy Finleyson's diagnosis of "horniphobia." Richard Cramer's turn as a dangerous criminal adds a touch of danger to the proceedings, and the boys' attempts to cook him up a synthetic meal are laugh-out-loud funny. Overall, SAPS AT SEA is a solid conclusion to Laurel & Hardy's time with Hal Roach and a great film in its own right. Fans of the duo will not be disappointed.

I watched this movie hoping for a heartwarming story, but instead, I was left with a bland and forgettable experience. Marie Dressler's performance as the lead character was decent, but nothing exceptional. As for Polly Moran, her portrayal of Dressler's friend was irritating and uninspired. The plot was predictable and lacked any real excitement or tension. I found myself struggling to stay engaged throughout the film. The use of bonds as a central plot device was confusing and felt out of place. Overall, I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone looking for a captivating and entertaining story.

This movie is a disastrous flop and a waste of time for anyone seeking genuine entertainment. It may appeal to those who enjoy movies that are so bad they're good, but for the rest of us, it's a total disaster. The only redeeming quality is the glimpse it offers into the fashions and attitudes of the 1970s, however, even that falls flat due to poor execution. The lead character, Superchick (Joyce Jillson), is nothing more than a one-dimensional caricature of a flight attendant; she's promiscuous, superficial, and a karate expert. It's no wonder the anti-feminists of the time were threatened by her - she's hardly a role model for anyone. The "sexy stewardess" archetype is not only outdated but also highly offensive, and this film does nothing to improve upon it. The plot is all over the place and makes little sense, leaving the audience feeling confused and disinterested. For those hoping for some nudity to liven things up, there's barely a glimpse of bare skin on offer. All in all, this movie is a total disaster, and it's best avoided at all costs.

In my opinion, this movie may not have been the most intricate in terms of plot, but I still thoroughly enjoyed it. The standout performance for me was Jon Bon Jovi as Derek, who completely embodied his character and truly made me forget he was a famous musician. Yes, there were some flaws, such as the lack of depth in the story line and the absence of a follow-up to develop things further. However, the costumes were fantastic and the setting in old Mexico was unique and visually stunning. I appreciated the departure from traditional vampire rules and found it all very intriguing. Overall, this movie had its imperfections but was still a fun and entertaining watch.

"This movie is an absolute gem! It's refreshing to see a David Zucker film that tells an original story rather than just poking fun at other movies. The humor is top-notch and had me laughing from start to finish. It's definitely one of the funniest movies of its time, alongside Night at the Roxbury. I highly recommend giving this movie a chance, even if you didn't find There's Something About Mary funny. Ignore the critics and their negative reviews, they clearly don't understand what true entertainment is. Trust me, you won't be disappointed!"

This movie is a complete waste of time and money. It's nothing more than a glorified nature documentary with an unconvincing plot and uninspired characters. The decision to cast Pierce Brosnan as an Indian was not only ridiculous but insulting to the intelligence of the audience. It's hard to believe that the other characters in the movie couldn't recognize that Brosnan clearly isn't Indian. Save your money and watch a real nature documentary instead.

I absolutely loved Soylent Green! It's refreshing to watch a movie that challenges your thinking and leaves you pondering long after the credits roll. The concept of a society so desperate for resources that they resort to cannibalism is a haunting one, and the film does a fantastic job of exploring the moral implications of such a scenario. The acting was top-notch, and the storyline kept me engaged from start to finish. I appreciate that the movie wasn't afraid to tackle difficult themes and ideas, and it was a refreshing departure from the shallow, mindless action flicks that seem to dominate theaters these days. I highly recommend watching Soylent Green, especially if you're looking for something that will make you think and feel. I give it a solid 9 out of 10!

I regret to say that I had the displeasure of viewing Robotech, produced by Mr. Agrama's company, and I was left with a feeling of deep disappointment. The show is a disgraceful mutilation of three Japanese sci-fi animated series, which were completely unrelated and had no business being combined. Mr. Carl Macek, the so-called "creator" of Robotech, added excessive amounts of dialogue, assuming that the American audience is too unintelligent to grasp the story without it. The result was a convoluted mess of plot holes and continuity problems, which were made worse by Macek's reckless editing for the sake of increased violence. The dubbing is unbearable, and the voice actors chosen for the project are among the worst in the industry. The terrible singing by Reba West, in particular, is an outrage compared to the original talent, Mari Iijima. The only redeeming quality of the show was the cool design of the mecha from the "Macross Saga," but even that cannot excuse the terrible treatment of the source material. It is a shame that Macek took credit for the success of Robotech, as the true credit should be given to the uncredited Japanese creators. I wish I had never stumbled upon this show, as it pales in comparison to the originals, which make much more sense. It is disgraceful that a show like Robotech was even allowed to be made, and it is a testament to the dire state of creativity in the industry.

THE FBI STORY (1959) was an overhyped and tedious tribute to a government agency that was barely interesting to begin with. The laborious screenplay by Richard L. Green and John Twist failed to capture any sense of excitement or intrigue, and Mervyn LeRoy's direction lacked any sort of originality. The only redeeming qualities were Joseph Biroc's mediocre cinematography and Max Steiner's unremarkable score. James Stewart tried his best, but he was left to carry the entire movie on his own, surrounded by a forgettable and insignificant supporting cast. The film attempted to cover a broad range of criminal activity, from notorious gangsters like "Baby Face" Nelson to the Ku Klux Klan and Nazi spy rings, but it failed to provide any real insight into these subjects. The ending was just as forgettable as the rest of the movie, with a bland Nick Adams delivering a laughably implausible line that hardly made any sense. Save yourself the time and skip this snoozefest.

I was really excited to watch the new show "Inspector Lewis" but after sitting through it, I was extremely disappointed. It was clear from the beginning that Kevin Whately does not have the same level of talent and energy that John Thaw brought to the "Morse" series. Whately looks unwell and overweight, which makes it hard to take him seriously as a detective. The worst part of the show, though, was the incomprehensible dialogue delivered by Whately's sidekick, Fox. It was a constant struggle to understand what he was saying. The replacement for James Grout also fell short, unable to fill the shoes of such a beloved character. It's a shame that they decided to continue the "Morse" series with a weak replacement that tarnishes the legacy of the original show. It should have been left alone to rest in peace.

"Underrated gem of a horror film! While it may not be perfect in some aspects, "Pet Sematary" delivers on shocks and scares in ways that few other movies can. The performances may be a bit uneven, but the creepy story elements - from the cursed burial ground to the hauntingly portrayed terminally ill sister - keep you on the edge of your seat. And let's not forget the standout performance from the late Fred Gwynne and director Mary Lambert's clever direction. But what truly sets this movie apart is its willingness to push boundaries, with its gruesome zombie baby and unforgettable portrayal of Zelda. It's a tasteless and politically incorrect horror movie, but it's all the better for it. For fans of the genre, "Pet Sematary" is a must-watch and a true hidden gem. 8 out of 10."

This movie was a true gem! I was blown away by how such a simple concept could be so gripping and engaging. The use of a single location and limited characters was executed perfectly, leaving me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire movie. The lead actor portrayed the haunted DJ role flawlessly, bringing depth and complexity to his character. I enjoyed the witty banter between him and the callers, which provided some much-needed comic relief. The story had twists and turns that I did not see coming. It was refreshing to see a ghost story that wasn't all about the supernatural, but rather the impact that unresolved issues can have on the living. The pacing was spot-on, and the ending tied everything together nicely. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves a good thriller but doesn't want to sit through a long, drawn-out plot. It's short and sweet, making it the perfect length for a spine-tingling movie night.

I cannot fathom how anyone could have greenlit this train wreck of a movie. The actors are completely forgettable, with the exception of a has-been like Judge Reinhold clinging to relevance in this disaster. It's not even bad enough to be good - it's just plain bad. The entire plot is laughable: a supposed "thriller" involving a plane being hijacked and the incompetent authorities being unable to stop it. It's like the writer just threw together a bunch of cliches they saw in other movies, but without any creativity or originality. Even the scenery and special effects are uninspired and cheap-looking. Save yourself the agony and skip this film - you'll thank me later.

I was unfortunately roped into seeing this movie with my friends and left feeling completely underwhelmed. The plot was tired and unoriginal, with the same played-out storylines that Hollywood has been churning out for years. The actors were mediocre at best, with Ben Stiller trying so hard to be funny that it was painful to watch. Jennifer Anniston looked like she was phoning in her performance and relying solely on her hair to carry her through. Even the supporting cast, including Hank Azaria and Phillip Seymour Hoffman, couldn't save this snooze-fest. In comparison to other comedies out there, this one falls flat. Avoid it at all costs, unless you're in desperate need of a nap.

Despite the inclusion of Buster Keaton and Al St. John, Good Night, Nurse! is a complete letdown. From encountering a drunken fool to a gypsy with a monkey, the film fails to deliver a single moment of genuine humor. The heavy rain only adds to the misery, making the already sloppy production seem even more unprofessional. The only redeeming factor is a short sequence of Roscoe "Fatty" Arbuckle in drag, but even that gets old quickly. The editing is choppy, and it's obvious that the filmmakers failed to use their film stock wisely. If you're looking for a comedy that will actually make you laugh, avoid this one at all costs.

"Save yourself the headache and skip this sci-fi disaster. The acting is painfully wooden, with Gerald Mohr leading a cast of forgettable characters. The special effects are laughable, with obvious fake backdrops and tacky tints that range from ridiculous to nauseating. The so-called "monsters" are nothing more than cheap knock-offs of creatures from other movies, and the giant amoeba is more likely to induce yawns than terror. The only thing remotely redeemable about this mess is the fact that it's so bad it's almost comical. Don't waste your time or money on this forgettable flop."

Unfortunately, this movie falls into the same trap as countless others before it. The plot is tired, unoriginal, and simply uninteresting. The acting leaves much to be desired, with the main character coming across as whiny and entitled rather than sympathetic. The attempts at humor fall flat, leaving the audience cringing instead of laughing. The attempts at a "Christmas message" feel forced and preachy, and are unlikely to resonate with anyone who isn't already a devout Christian. The supposedly climactic trial scene drags on for an interminable length of time, leaving the audience impatiently checking their watches. Even the presence of "big name" actors like Baldwin and Cattrall can't save this dud of a film. Save yourself the time and skip this one - or, better yet, check out the far superior Greek adaptation of the same myth.

This classic musical film is an absolute treat for fans of the genre. James Cagney steals the show as a determined musical prologue producer, and Joan Blondell is the perfect foil as his loyal assistant. The Busby Berkeley choreographed musical numbers are simply breathtaking, showcasing the human body in ways you've never seen before. Yes, the plot is a bit strange and some of the characters are a bit over-the-top, but that's all part of the fun. There's even some unexpected moments of Cagney's gangster side shining through, adding a layer of depth to the film. Overall, this is a high-energy, entertaining romp that still holds up today. Don't miss this classic piece of cinema history.

I was extremely disappointed with this movie. Not only did it perpetuate harmful and outdated gender and class stereotypes, but it also failed to deliver any sort of meaningful message or lesson. The so-called "love story" was nothing more than a shallow and predictable plot device used to push forward the underlying theme of societal hierarchy. And while some may argue that the protagonist is a hero for her sacrifices, I found her tragic and pitiable, a mere pawn in a game of societal chess. This movie is just another example of how ingrained and accepted sexism and classism still remain in our society, and it's frankly sickening. Save your time and money and skip this one.

I had heard some mixed reviews about this movie, but decided to watch it because I was bored and there was nothing else to watch. At first, I found it somewhat interesting and had some hope that it would get better. However, as the story progressed, the characters became more and more unbearable. The so-called plot twist was anything but clever and was just downright ridiculous. I kept hoping that something good would happen, but unfortunately, that never came. The ending was a complete disappointment and left me feeling like I had wasted my time. In fact, I was so disappointed that I had to watch an episode of something else just to get over how bad this movie was. Do yourself a favor and skip this one.

As someone who was excited to delve into the world of Buster Keaton, I was sorely disappointed by "Speak Easily." It's painfully obvious that Keaton's comedic style clashed with that of Jimmy Durante's, and the result was a mess of unfunny dialogue and forced attempts at humor. The supporting characters were either wasted or behaved in completely inappropriate ways, making it impossible to invest in the story. And don't even get me started on the tired cliche of the incompetent dimwit becoming a star comedian through his own ineptitude. It's a shame to see such talented actors wasted on such a lackluster film. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone and give it a generous 2 out of 10.

If you're a fan of action movies, then you have to see the incredible fight scenes in this movie. Choreographed by the legendary Yuen Woo Ping, who also did the fights in The Matrix, the intensity and skill of the fights will leave you awe-struck. But there's so much more to the movie than just the action. Jet Li is amazing as a supersoldier turned pacifist librarian who gets drawn back into the fight against evil supersoldiers. The story is full of twists and turns, the characters are complex and interesting, and the female costars are all beautiful and badass. And let's not forget the body count - it's high, and it's glorious. This is the kind of action movie that Hollywood just doesn't make anymore, so it's a treat to be able to see such a well-crafted film from Hong Kong. Don't miss it - highly recommended!

I recently discovered the hidden gem that is Father of the Pride and I must say, it quickly became one of my all-time favorite shows. The animation is stunning, thanks to the talented folks at Dreamworks Animation who never fail to impress. The characters are so well-developed and each one brings something unique to the table. I especially love the over-the-top antics of Sigfreid and Roy, who always manage to make me laugh with their grandiose behavior.

What really sets this show apart is its ability to tackle serious issues in a way that is both thought-provoking and entertaining. From drug use to prejudice, Father of the Pride isn't afraid to tackle controversial topics head-on. Yet, it still manages to maintain a lighthearted tone that makes it a joy to watch.

It's a shame that NBC didn't give this show the chance it deserved. With episodes airing out of order and being preempted for other shows, it's no wonder it struggled to find an audience. Thankfully, the complete series is now available on DVD, giving more people the opportunity to discover this wonderful show. I can't recommend Father of the Pride enough - it's a true masterpiece that deserves to be watched and appreciated. 10/10

"The Plainsman" is an epic adventure film that truly captures the essence of the Wild West. Directed by Cecil B. DeMille, this film starring Gary Cooper as Wild Bill Hickok and Jean Arthur as Calamity Jane is a must-watch for fans of the genre. DeMille's incredible talent for creating stunning spectacles is on full display here, transporting viewers to a time long gone. The film has an amazing cast, with James Ellison as Buffalo Bill, John Miljan as General George A. Custer, and Anthony Quinn as one of the Indians who fought at Little Big Horn. Charles Bickford delivers a standout performance as the leader of the villains selling arms to the Indians, with Porter Hall as the infamous Jack McCall who killed Wild Bill Hickok bringing a sense of danger and tension to the film. While some historical inaccuracies may be present, the film still manages to capture the spirit of the time and the excitement of the Wild West. "The Plainsman" is a thrilling adventure that will take you on a ride you'll never forget.

I had high hopes for this movie, but it fell far short of my expectations. The director seems to think that adding unnecessary and bizarre elements to the story somehow makes it more artistic or meaningful. But instead, it just comes off as pretentious and confusing. I couldn't even make it through the first half hour before I gave up in frustration. It's a shame that something as timeless and important as Shakespeare's work has been twisted and distorted in this way. If you're looking for a faithful adaptation that respects the source material, look elsewhere. This is just a self-indulgent mess that's not worth your time.

I must say, I thoroughly enjoyed "Pokemon the 4th movie." It was great to see the franchise still going strong and introducing new characters like Suicune and Celebi. The storyline was engaging and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire movie. It was heartwarming to see Sam and Ash bond over their love for Pokemon and work together to protect Celebi from the evil Team Rocket agent, Vicious. Even if you're not a diehard Pokemon fan, you can still appreciate the movie for its adventurous and heartwarming storyline. I do hope that Miramax will include the Pikachu short on future releases, but even without it, "Pokemon the 4th movie" is worth watching. So, let yourself enjoy the magic of Pokemon and give this movie a chance. You won't regret it!

"Blood-Sucking Vixen" of 1987 is a film with a highly promising title, but the film itself is a complete disappointment for horror buffs. From start to finish, the film is an utter mess with no coherent storyline, no compelling characters, and no redeeming qualities whatsoever. The film tries to shock and titillate its audience with gratuitous sex and violence, but it comes across as cheap and tacky. The leading actress, who tries to seduce every man she comes in contact with, is a one-dimensional caricature of a sexual predator, and her acting skills are non-existent. The gore effects are poorly executed and lack any sense of realism or tension. The film drags on for what seems like an eternity, and the ending is so ridiculous and unsatisfying that you'll wish you never wasted your time on this trashy production. The director seems to have no idea what he's doing and relies on shock tactics to compensate for his lack of imagination. The film is an insult to the horror genre and should be avoided at all costs. If you're looking for a good horror film, there are plenty of other options out there that are much better than this pathetic attempt at horror.

"The Amazing Mr. Williams" is a true gem of a movie, featuring incredible performances by Melvyn Douglas and Joan Blondell. The chemistry between these two stars is undeniable and they both shine in their respective roles. The plot is a perfect blend of mystery and comedy, keeping the audience engaged from start to finish. It's a shame that this film has been largely forgotten, as it is just as entertaining now as it was when it was first released. And as for the criticism of Melvyn Douglas, I have to strongly disagree. He was a talented actor who deserved much more recognition for his work. His performances in "Hud" and "I Never Sang for my Father" are simply stunning and a testament to his incredible range as an actor. Overall, "The Amazing Mr. Williams" is a must-see for fans of classic cinema and a great example of why 1939 was such a remarkable year for film.

Although there are some silly moments in this movie, I absolutely loved it! As a huge fan of Michael Jackson for as long as I can remember, I couldn't help but be enchanted by his amazing talent and charming personality. The claymation sequences were particularly incredible and the music was out of this world. I would definitely recommend "Moonwalker" to any die hard MJ fan out there, and even to those who are not as familiar with his work. It may not be the most well-made movie out there, but it truly captures the magic of Michael Jackson and his unique style. I give it a solid 8 out of 10!

While this movie is a remake of two classics, it stands strong on its own merits. The cast brings their A-game, especially Chris Rock who delivers a hilarious performance. The storyline is fresh and engaging, and the pacing is spot on. The last third of the movie is especially excellent, showcasing the comedic talents of the entire cast. The cinematography is beautiful and the editing is seamless. This is a movie that will leave you smiling from beginning to end. I highly recommend seeing it in theaters, as it's a true cinematic experience that deserves to be seen on the big screen.

After seeing some negative reviews, I just had to come to the defense of this movie. The story may not be for everyone, but if you're looking for a thoughtful exploration of faith and redemption, then Cold Heaven delivers. It's a refreshing change from the typical Hollywood fare, offering a unique perspective on Catholicism and the miraculous.

I was particularly impressed by the film's subtle approach to cinematography and acting. There are no flashy or over-the-top effects here, just a well-crafted story that unfolds at a steady pace. Yet, despite the lack of flashy visuals, the film packs an emotional punch that will leave you thinking long after the credits roll.

Overall, I believe Cold Heaven is a hidden gem that deserves more recognition. It may not be for everyone, but for those willing to give it a chance, it offers a captivating exploration of faith and the human experience. Highly recommended.

Ugh, what a waste of time. "Five Fingers of Death" is a total mess of a movie that tries to blend martial arts with a revenge plotline, and fails at both. The acting is wooden and the fight scenes are poorly choreographed, leaving the viewer feeling underwhelmed and bored. The attempt at humor falls flat and feels forced, with jokes that are cringe-worthy at best. The filmmakers must have been on some serious drugs when they made this mess, as the plot has more holes than Swiss cheese and the editing is choppy and confusing. Even the soundtrack is terrible, with cheesy 70s music that sounds like it was composed by a high school band. I can't believe anyone would actually enjoy this garbage. Save your time and money, and avoid this train wreck at all costs.

I absolutely loved this film! It had me hooked from the very beginning and I know I'll be revisiting it many times in the future. The storytelling was so nuanced and layered, I found myself pondering the various themes for hours after the credits rolled. The attention to detail in every aspect of the production was impressive, from the set design to the costuming. I especially appreciated the strong performances from the talented cast, who brought such depth and emotion to their roles. And while some may argue that the organ score wasn't a perfect match for the story, I still found it to be a beautiful and haunting addition to the viewing experience. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone who appreciates thought-provoking cinema that stays with you long after it's over.

At first, I wasn't sure if this book was going to be my cup of tea. However, I decided to give it a chance and boy, am I glad I did! From the first chapter, I was completely hooked and couldn't put it down. The characters are so well-developed and relatable, I felt like I was right there with them on their journey. And the plot twists?! Absolutely mind-blowing. I've already recommended this book to all of my friends and can't wait to read it again myself. Trust me, give it a chance and you won't regret it!

When I first watched Rob Roy, I was impressed by the performances and the stunning cinematography, but I didn't fully appreciate the brilliance of the film. Over time, however, my appreciation for this classic has only grown. Unlike Braveheart, which is marred by historical inaccuracies and a simplistic portrayal of its characters, Rob Roy offers a nuanced, thoughtful examination of its hero and the world in which he lived. Liam Neeson's performance as Rob Roy is simply superb, conveying both bravery and vulnerability in equal measure. Jessica Lange is also excellent as Mary, Rob's wife, and the two of them share a chemistry that is palpable onscreen. The film's themes of honor, justice, and love are explored with depth and sensitivity, and the result is a film that is both entertaining and thought-provoking. If you haven't seen Rob Roy yet, do yourself a favor and check it out - it's truly a masterpiece of cinema.

I recently watched Sleepwalkers and I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised. Mick Garris did an excellent job directing this film, creating a terrifying world where feline-human shapeshifters roam the earth and prey on virginal girls. The plot may not have been overly complex, but it was certainly effective in delivering plenty of bloody carnage and mayhem. Alice Krige was particularly impressive as the menacing and sexy villain, Mary. And Mädchen Amick was absolutely adorable as the innocent Tanya caught in the middle of it all. The humor was dark and twisted, making for a thrilling ride that had me on the edge of my seat throughout. I highly recommend this film to any horror fan looking for a fun and gory experience. Well done, Mick Garris!

.

I cannot believe how terrible this movie was. I thought it would be a fun, silly movie to watch with some friends, but it was just painful to sit through. The humor was so forced and unfunny, and the plot was nonexistent. It was like they took every bad action movie trope and mashed them all together in one mess of a film. The ninjas popping out of nowhere and starting a fire fight was just stupid and not even slightly entertaining. And don't even get me started on the terrible special effects! I don't know how anyone could enjoy this garbage. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

This film is a must-see for any fan of Jackie Chan's early works. While it may not be his most polished effort, the central father-son relationship and Chan's commitment to character development make it a standout in his filmography. The comedy is both character-driven and slapstick, providing plenty of laughs throughout. Though the historical and romantic elements may come across as plot-twists, they add an interesting layer to the story. Viewing this film offers valuable insight into Chan's process and development as a filmmaker, and makes it clear why he would eventually abandon the historical genre in favor of contemporary action comedies. Overall, this is an important turning point film in Chan's career and a great addition to any collection.

I recently watched the Baby Burlesk short, and I have to say, I found it absolutely delightful. The spoof of What Price Glory was cleverly done and had me giggling throughout. I was surprised to hear that some people have made accusations of kiddie-porn in regards to this film because, honestly, I didn't see anything even remotely suggestive in it. In fact, I've seen far more provocative content on family-friendly shows from the '80s and '90s! The fact that some people are trying to spin this innocent film into something nefarious is really quite troubling. 

I think it's important to put things into perspective here. The B.B. films were all parodies - they were never meant to be taken seriously or to offend anyone. They were simply a lighthearted take on popular films of the time. And let's not forget that back in the day, films were a lot more risqué than they are now! So to claim that there is something inappropriate about a Baby Burlesk short from the 1930s is just absurd. 

Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed watching this film - it was a charming piece of nostalgia that had me smiling from ear to ear. And I think it's ridiculous that anyone would try to twist it into something ugly. So if you're looking for a sweet, innocent, and thoroughly entertaining short film, then I wholeheartedly recommend checking out the Baby Burlesk series.

The first half of this restaurant experience was decent. The atmosphere was cozy, the menu had a few interesting options and the service was adequate. However, it all went downhill from there. The food arrived and it was mediocre at best. The steak was tough and flavorless, the vegetables were overcooked and the dessert was stale. The wine list was also disappointing, with limited options and overpriced bottles. The worst part was the lack of attention from the staff, who seemed to have forgotten about us completely after the main course arrived. We had to flag down a server just to get the bill. Overall, it was a disappointing dining experience that failed to live up to its potential. Save your money and go elsewhere.

I had never heard of Oliver Gruner before stumbling upon this movie, and honestly, I wish I still hadn't. My friend forced me to watch it with him, promising me some decent sci-fi action like Gruner apparently delivered in Nemesis. Instead, we were subjected to a mess of a film that couldn't decide if it wanted to be a drama or an action flick.

Gruner's character is a graduate student who can't seem to escape the ghetto he grew up in. He takes in a young boy who is being targeted by a Mexican gang, and instead of reporting them to the authorities or finding a way to escape, Gruner decides to take matters into his own hands. Cue the endless kicking and fighting scenes that seem to go on forever.

The plot was incredibly predictable and lacked any real depth. Gruner's acting wasn't anything special, which is probably why he remains relatively unknown. The only halfway decent thing about this movie was the action music, but even that couldn't save it from being a disaster.

The director seemed to have forgotten that this was supposed to be an action movie, with pointless breaks every five minutes for some contrived family moment. The ghetto portrayed in the film was an absolute nightmare, but the characters seemed to be walking through it like it was a day in the park.

I made it through the whole movie, but only because I was hoping for some sort of closure or explanation for what I had just watched. Unfortunately, I was left disappointed and feeling like I had wasted my time. Save yourself the trouble and steer clear of this mess. I give it a 2/10, and that's being generous.

I was intrigued to watch "La Maman et la putain" based on the positive recommendations I read here, and I am so glad I did. This film is a true masterpiece of French cinema. The characters are complex and compelling, and the story is both heartbreaking and hopeful. Yes, at 210 minutes, it is a long film, but I found myself completely absorbed in the story and didn't even notice the time passing. The performances by Françoise Lebrun and Jean-Pierre Léaud are outstanding, and they bring a depth and authenticity to their roles that is truly impressive. The film tackles some heavy themes, but it does so with grace and sensitivity, weaving together a beautiful and thought-provoking story. I highly recommend "La Maman et la putain" to anyone who appreciates great cinema. This is a film that will stick with you long after the credits roll. 10/10.

Unfortunately, like many Hollywood movies, 44 minutes is a glaring example of historical inaccuracy. The film claims to be based on true events, but it deviates so far from reality that it's hard to take it seriously. Major events are changed or completely fabricated for the sake of entertainment, and the result is a film that is more fiction than fact. The most egregious example is the portrayal of the LAPD officers as bumbling, incompetent fools who are outmatched by the robbers. This is a gross misrepresentation of the brave men and women who put their lives on the line to protect us. It's also insulting to the victims of the North Hollywood shootout, whose heroism is downplayed for the sake of making a more "exciting" movie. If you're looking for a truthful depiction of this tragic event, look elsewhere.

I recently had the pleasure of watching a film that was both sensual and tasteful. The cinematography was breathtaking, and the actors' performances were captivating. The lack of live sound and dialogue only added to the intimacy of the film, allowing the actors to describe their experiences and emotions in a more personal way. It was clear that the film was a true document of eroticism, without crossing the line into pornography. I was impressed by the unique approach the filmmakers took, and I can understand why no one else has attempted to make something like this before. It was truly mind-blowing and left a lasting impression on me. Although obtaining a copy may be a bit of a challenge, it is definitely worth the effort. I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a tasteful and artistic exploration of sensuality.

I recently watched KING SOLOMON'S MINES and was pleasantly surprised by the epic nature of the film. While it was not the action-packed adventure I was expecting, the slow pace allowed me to fully immerse myself in the storyline and appreciate the stunning scenery. Patrick Swayze's return to acting was a delightful treat, and his portrayal of Allan Quatermain was both charming and intense. The ending left me satisfied and eager to learn more about the characters and their journeys. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a thrilling and epic adventure.

This book was highly overrated. I don't understand all the hype surrounding it. The characters were dull and lacked depth. The plot was predictable and unoriginal. I found myself counting down the pages until it was over. The writing was mediocre at best, with no real sense of style or literary merit. I have to wonder if the people who gave this book such high praise have ever read anything of substance before. Save your money and skip this one.

I was fortunate enough to find a copy of this movie and it absolutely blew me away. From start to finish, I was on the edge of my seat, captivated by the unique storyline and incredible portrayal of Trelkovski's inner struggle. The characterization of Trelkovski was incredible, with his shy and gentle exterior hiding a much darker side. The transformation into Simone Choule was both eerie and poignant, leaving me with many questions about the true nature of identity. The imagery throughout the movie was hauntingly beautiful, leaving me with a lasting impression of the story. I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and intense viewing experience. It is truly one of the best horror films I have ever seen.

WARNING! SPOILERS AHEAD! 

If you're thinking of watching this movie, don't waste your time. It's a pathetic attempt by the lead actress to force herself upon audiences once again. The plot is so predictable and boring, it's almost laughable. There's no creativity, no originality, nothing but Madonna playing Madonna. The character is so one-dimensional; it's as if she didn't even try to bring anything new to the table. 

And don't even get me started on the quality of the film itself. The camera work is terrible, the lighting is amateurish, and the sound is muffled and unclear. It's like the whole production was thrown together in a hurry just to make a quick buck off Madonna's name. 

And let's talk about those spoilers for a minute. Who cares whether the character lives or dies? We barely even get to know her in the first place. And the fact that her long-suffering husband is forced to endure her presence yet again is just the icing on the cake of this terrible movie. 

I would not recommend this movie to anyone. Save your money and your time, and find something else to watch. Madonna should stick to what she knows best - making music - because acting clearly isn't her forte.

I absolutely adored this movie! The storyline was so captivating and the acting was superb. Each actor brought their own unique touch to the film, and I especially enjoyed Bette Davis' portrayal of the wife. Her performance was so nuanced and emotionally raw, it really made me feel for her character. I understand that some may not appreciate her attempt at an accent, but I thought it added to the authenticity of the character and the setting. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a gripping drama and top-notch acting. I can't wait to see what this talented cast does next!

I was blown away by "Gespenster" and couldn't stop thinking about it long after the credits rolled. The way Petzold masterfully weaves together different genres and storylines is nothing short of impressive. I loved how the film played with the idea of reality versus fantasy, making me question what was truly happening and what was imagined. The cinematography was also stunning, capturing the haunting and eerie atmosphere of the city in such a subtle way. It's rare to find a film that is both thought-provoking and emotionally engaging, but "Gespenster" delivered on both fronts. I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a unique and captivating cinematic experience.

'Big disappointment' is the phrase that comes to mind when describing 'Major Payne'. The concept seemed interesting, but the execution was lacking. The acting was mediocre at best, and the jokes were cringe-worthy. The idea of a drill sergeant who is tough on his recruits is not new, and this film does nothing to add to the genre. Additionally, the film is filled with offensive stereotypes and fat-shaming. If you are looking for a film with substance and humor, do not waste your time on 'Major Payne'. There are much better comedies out there that do not rely on offensive jokes and shallow characters.

Is there any other subject that has been so overdone by TV and movies as the 1960s? Absolutely not. And yet, here we have yet another shallow attempt at revisiting the decade with the miniseries "The '60s". The writers and producers clearly had no real vision for the project, instead relying on tired cliches and a one-dimensional portrayal of a cookie-cutter family that miraculously seems to be involved in every major event of the time. The characters are poorly developed and the actors are wasted in their roles, especially Charles S. Dutton and Julia Stiles. The soundtrack is so saturated with period songs that it becomes grating and ultimately detracts from the viewing experience. This miniseries adds nothing new to the wealth of material already available on the subject and ultimately feels like a pointless exercise. Save yourself the time and watch something else, because "The '60s" is nothing but a forgettable, uninspired mess.

Although there are some nice scenes with decent camera work, Scorpion Spring falls short of being a true masterpiece. The storyline is predictable and lacks any real depth, making it feel like a cheap made-for-TV movie. The lack of subtitles for the Spanish dialogue is frustrating and leaves non-Spanish speakers struggling to understand key plot points. Despite the DVD box trying to sell Scorpion Spring as a Matthew McConaughey movie, his appearance is brief and unremarkable. The true star of the film, Patrick McGaw, is just too nice and his character lacks any real complexity. Overall, Scorpion Spring is forgettable and doesn't come close to showcasing McConaughey's true acting talent. Save yourself the disappointment and skip this one.

First off, let me start by saying that I absolutely loved Kenneth Branagh's take on Hamlet. While I can understand some of the criticisms about his over-acting, I personally felt that it added a certain level of intensity to the film that really drew me in. Plus, the supporting cast was fantastic - especially Billy Crystal and Robin Williams, who both delivered some truly standout performances.

One of the things that I appreciated most about this adaptation was how accessible it was. Shakespeare can be pretty intimidating for a lot of people, but this film made the story and characters feel much more relatable and easy to understand. And while some of the ambiguities may have been resolved in the flashbacks, I felt that they added a depth and richness to the story that I really enjoyed.

Finally, I just wanted to address the criticism about the film being set in the 19th century. Personally, I didn't have any issue with this choice - as the reviewer points out, Shakespeare's plays have always been full of anachronisms and historical inaccuracies. What matters most to me is the quality of the storytelling and the performances, and in that regard, Branagh's Hamlet absolutely delivers. Overall, I would highly recommend this film to any fan of Shakespeare or anyone looking for a great story brought to life on the big screen.

This movie is a complete waste of time. The only thing that this movie has going for it is Dani Filth, who is barely recognizable as a character. The independent filming style is not creepy, it's cheap. The only thing that's gorgeous about this movie are the actresses, who are only there to be objectified and killed off in the most gruesome of ways. The special effects might not be bad, but it's not enough to make up for the lack of any real storyline or character development. The F bomb is used excessively, which feels like the scriptwriter just wanted to be edgy. The storyline is confusing, and the lack of any real dialogue or explanation makes it impossible to follow. This movie is nothing more than a sad attempt to be shocking, and it fails miserably. Save your time and don't even bother renting it.

I absolutely loved BILL AND TED'S BOGUS JOURNEY! Keanu Reeves and Alex Winter are just as hilarious as ever, and their chemistry is undeniable. What I appreciated most about this sequel was how it expanded on the original concept and took the audience on a wild, imaginative ride through different realms. The addition of Death as a character was pure genius and William Sadler's performance was a standout. The special effects may not hold up by today's standards, but that didn't detract from my enjoyment of the film. Overall, I found BILL AND TED'S BOGUS JOURNEY to be a fun, entertaining romp and it's definitely worth a watch. Rating: **** out of 5.

Bette Davis delivers a breathtaking performance in this film that cannot be forgotten. Even though the other female actors were perfectly cast in their roles, Davis' portrayal of Mildred stole the show. The film's condensed storyline did not hinder its greatness as it maintained the essence of the book while still standing on its own. Leslie Howard's performance as Phillip is also noteworthy, particularly his character's struggle in finding love and acceptance. The supporting cast, including Kay Johnson and Frances Dee, were outstanding in their roles. The film's ending was satisfying and beautifully captured the essence of the story. Overall, this film is a must-watch, and highly recommended for those who appreciate a good drama.

Released over six decades ago, Written on the Wind is a timeless classic that still manages to captivate audiences with its engaging storyline and stunning visuals. The movie revolves around the tumultuous lives of a wealthy Texas family, whose internal strife and emotional turmoil are brought to life by the brilliant performances of the lead actors. Robert Stack delivers a powerful and compelling performance as the alcoholic big brother, Kyle, while Dorothy Malone's portrayal of the promiscuous sister, Marylee, is delightfully over-the-top and campy. The chemistry between Rock Hudson and Lauren Bacall is palpable, and their on-screen presence adds an extra layer of depth to the movie. The film's use of vibrant colors, innovative lighting techniques, and intricate set design is a testament to the director's skill and creativity. Douglas Sirk's masterful direction transforms the narrative into a work of art, and the result is a film that has stood the test of time. In the end, Written on the Wind is a must-see classic that will leave you breathless and yearning for more.

If you're looking for a thrilling movie that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish, "Hollow Man" is the perfect choice. Kevin Bacon's performance as Sebastian Caine is outstanding, and he truly brings the character to life. The storyline is fascinating and unique, with a fresh take on the classic tale of invisibility. It's incredible to see how the characters handle the newfound power, and the consequences that come with it. The special effects are stunning, and the action scenes will leave you breathless. It's not often that a movie can make you feel like you're right there in the middle of the action, but "Hollow Man" manages to do just that. This is definitely a movie that you won't want to miss, and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves a good adventure. Five out of five stars!

I must say, I went into this movie with somewhat low expectations given the mixed reviews it received. However, I was pleasantly surprised by the level of thought and care put into the story and characters. While I was initially worried it would be another formulaic action flick, the clever dialogue and attention to character backgrounds really drew me in. When the action scenes did come, I found myself fully invested in the outcome. This is definitely a film for those looking for a more intelligent take on the genre, rather than just mindless explosions and one-liners. And even though Angelina Jolie was only in it briefly, I didn't even mind - that's how engrossed I was in the overall story. Highly recommend giving it a chance!

I don't even know where to begin with this movie. The concept of Santa Claus living on a cloud in outer space fighting against Satan and his minions is just ridiculous. The fact that this movie tries to take itself seriously only adds insult to injury. The humor is so forced and desperate, it's painful to watch. It's clear that the filmmakers were trying to create a cult classic, but they missed the mark by a long shot. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one. Even "Santa Claus Conquers the Martians" is better than this garbage.

I recently had the pleasure of watching D.A.N.G.A.N. Runner and I must say, it exceeded my expectations. The simple yet clever premise of an unemployed man attempting to steal from a convenience store and being chased by the store clerk quickly turns into a wild and hilarious ride. The physical comedy and dark humor injected into the film kept me engaged and entertained throughout the entire movie.

What stood out to me the most was the non-stop chase that made up the majority of the film's second act. The Tom & Jerry (cat & mouse) style chase had me on the edge of my seat as the characters ran through the streets, dodging obstacles and narrowly avoiding capture from the Yakuza. It was so intense that by the end of the second act, the bum forgets why he is running away, and the Yakuza don't remember which of the two guys he is chasing, nor does he remember why they're running away from him.

Although the ending may have fallen a bit short, the chaotic Mexican stand-off was a sight to behold and felt like a nod to Tony Scott's TRUE ROMANCE. Overall, D.A.N.G.A.N. Runner is a must-watch for anyone who loves action-packed comedies with a dash of dark humor.

"9/11" is an absolute masterpiece of documentary filmmaking. From the opening montage to the clean-up at Ground Zero, every frame is a testament to the bravery and heroism of the New York City firefighters who risked everything to save lives on that fateful day. The Naudet brothers' vision of documenting the journey of "Probies" from the academy to full-fledged firefighters could not have anticipated the tragic events of 9/11, but their skillful handling of the subject matter is respectful and dignified, never sensationalizing the horrors that unfolded. Robert De Niro's restrained hosting and James Hanlon's narration add to the emotional impact of this powerful documentary. CBS's decision to air this special is commendable, and their editing always remembers the human cost of the tragedy. "9/11" is a must-see for anyone who wants to be reminded of what true heroism is and the price of freedom.

Do we really need another bland depiction of the 1960s on our screens? Apparently, the makers of "The '60s" think so. Despite the wealth of material already available, this miniseries manages to add absolutely nothing new to the conversation. The intercutting of file footage with dramatic production is so choppy and disjointed that it's hard to keep track of what's happening, and the characters are so underdeveloped that they might as well not exist. Not even the talented cast - Jerry O'Connell, Jordana Brewster, Jeremy Sisto, Julia Stiles, and Charles S. Dutton - can save this mess of a production. The overuse of period songs only serves to distract from what little substance there is. If you're looking for a thoughtful exploration of the 1960s, or even just some entertainment, look elsewhere. "The '60s" is a waste of time.

Fellow movie-goers, save your money and skip this one. The acting is wooden and unconvincing, with the exception of Ed Asner and Peter Jason who are the only ones worth watching. The supposed "stars" Alice and Brian looked like they were sleepwalking through their roles, with barely any emotion displayed on their faces. It's baffling to see their extensive bios because they certainly didn't bring any talent to this film. The only redeeming qualities were the snow scenes and shots of Nevada City, but even those couldn't save this poorly-made movie. I regret wasting my time and money on this lackluster film, and I suggest you do the same. Don't bother with it.

This movie is an absolute trainwreck. The only thing unique about it is how completely incomprehensible it is. It's like the producers threw a bunch of random scenes together and called it a movie. The plot is nonexistent, and the characters are so poorly written that you can't even tell what they're supposed to be doing. The acting is abysmal - even talented actors come off as wooden and uninspired in this mess. It's clear that no one involved in this film cared about anything beyond getting paid, and it shows. The dialogue is so bad that it's cringeworthy, and the pacing is so slow that you'll be checking your watch every few minutes. The only reason to watch this movie is if you want to see how bad a movie can truly be. Spare yourself the headache and avoid this movie at all costs.

If you are considering watching this movie, save yourself the trouble and skip it altogether. The only way I could see anyone enjoying this film is if they have no taste whatsoever.
