It's disappointing to hear that Toby Young was involved with writing the script because it's clear that the filmmakers didn't take any of the charm or wit from the book and instead opted for cheap laughs and one-dimensional characters. The jokes are so bad that you'll find yourself cringing throughout the whole movie. Don't waste your time or money on this one.

This book was an absolute disaster. The plot was virtually non-existent and the characters were so underdeveloped that I couldn't even remember their names by the end of the story. I spent the entire time waiting for something interesting to happen, but nothing ever did. The homoerotic subtext was completely unnecessary and added nothing to the story. In fact, it only served to confuse and annoy me. The only redeeming quality of this book were a few scenes that were well-written, but they were few and far between. In the end, I was just relieved when it was finally over. Don't waste your time with this one.

The cast of this film must have really hit rock bottom to agree to be a part of it. It's a Grade Z horror film with a nonsensical plot and terrible acting. John Carradine's once magnificent voice is wasted on this mess of a film, and it's clear he only took the role for a quick paycheck. John Ireland and Faith Domergue aren't much better, delivering wooden performances that make it difficult to care about their characters. The story revolves around a mysterious mansion and a low budget slasher film, but it's so poorly written that it's impossible to follow. It's not even entertaining in a so-bad-it's-good kind of way. Save yourself the headache and skip this one.

This film "The Sealed Room" directed by D.W. Griffith is a disgrace to the art of filmmaking. The storyline is predictable and unoriginal, with a cheating Queen and a vengeful King. The actors are wooden and unconvincing, with no chemistry between the supposed lovers. The sets are cheap and tacky, with no attention to detail or authenticity. The use of music is grating and distracting, and the sound quality is poor. Overall, this film is a waste of time and money and is not worth watching.

I stumbled upon this film by chance and was pleasantly surprised by the storyline and cast. Anne Reid's portrayal of the titular character was both captivating and heart-wrenching. The taboo-breaking sex scenes were a refreshing change and it was empowering to see an older woman embracing her sexuality. The supporting cast was strong, with Daniel Craig delivering a solid performance as the carpenter. The only weak point was the ending, which left me wanting more closure for the Mother's character. Overall, I highly recommend this film for its emotional depth and powerful performances.

At first, I wasn't sure if this film was going to capture my attention, but I'm so glad I stuck with it. Rivers and Tides is a true gem that showcases the incredible artwork of Andy Goldsworthy. I was blown away by his ability to create such breathtaking pieces using only materials found in nature. While some may find the film slow-moving, I think it's a perfect reflection of Goldsworthy's work and the natural pace of the world around us. The lack of special effects or music only adds to the authenticity and magic of the film. I appreciate the insight provided by Goldsworthy as he discusses his art, providing a glimpse into his creative process and inspiration. If you're looking for a stunning visual experience that celebrates the beauty of nature and human creativity, Rivers and Tides is a must-see. It's a testament to the power of art and the incredible wonders that can be created with our own two hands.

I absolutely loved the fresh take on Gandhi's life in this movie. It was refreshing to see a different angle and to be able to see him as human rather than just as a revered historical figure. The relationship between Gandhi and Harilal was so poignant and really showcased the struggles and flaws of a father-son bond. I appreciated how the movie stayed focused on this specific aspect, instead of trying to cover too much ground. The attention to detail in the time period and setting was impeccable, transporting me to that era from the moment the movie began. While I have seen some criticism about the portrayal of Gandhi, I personally found the acting to be superb and believable. It was interesting to see different aspects of Gandhi's personality, both the positive and negative, which added depth to his character. Altogether, this movie is a must-watch for anyone looking for a fresh perspective on Gandhi's life.

As someone who was just introduced to this show, I have to say that I am absolutely hooked! Even though I wasn't around when it first aired, I can appreciate the amazing writing and acting that went into creating such an incredible show. I've found myself binge watching it every chance I get, and I have to say that Adam is definitely my favorite character too! 

I was a bit disappointed to find out that the only way to purchase the show on DVD was from Germany, but I didn't let that stop me. I was determined to own all the seasons, so I searched high and low online until I found them. It was definitely worth the effort, because now I can watch it anywhere I want.

Even though the DVDs have a region code that only allows them to be played on my portable DVD player and computer, I couldn't be happier with my purchase. I love being able to watch this show whenever I want, and reliving all the incredible moments that made me fall in love with it in the first place. If you're looking for a great show to watch, then I highly recommend this one. It's truly one of the best out there!

This movie was a complete disappointment. Its plot was all over the place and left me wondering what the point was. The acting was mediocre at best and I found myself cringing during several scenes. The only thing worse than the lackluster storyline was the constant push of religious messaging. I understand the importance of faith to some, but it was shoved down my throat to the point of nausea. The only relief I found was in counting the number of times the word 'pray' was said - a pathetic attempt to create humor out of a terrible film. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone, especially those who are looking for a quality movie that isn't overly preachy. Save yourself the boredom and skip this one.

Despite some mixed reviews I had read, I found this movie to be a hidden gem. It's not perfect, but it's definitely a good watch. Judy Garland's portrayal of her character was delightful and never got annoying. Meanwhile, Van Heflin's performance was just the right amount of brooding and overbearing. I particularly enjoyed the musical numbers, showcasing Garland's incredible singing skills. The only downside was not seeing more of the characters' relationship, which I wish had been explored further. Overall, I thought it was a solid movie and would highly recommend it. I personally rate it an 8 out of 10.

Just when you thought you couldn't handle another terrible creature feature, along comes Croc: A Genetic Nightmare. The plot is laughable, revolving around an accidentally released baby crocodile that somehow evolves at an impossible rate. The special effects are beyond cheesy, with the monster itself resembling a poorly animated cartoon character. The B-movie cast is uninspiring, with Costas Mandylor's performance as a croc specialist feeling like a poor imitation of Crocodile Dundee. The rest of the characters are one dimensional and forgettable, with the predictable love story between Jane Longenecker and Matthew Borlenghi feeling forced and trite. Even worse, the attempts at humor fall flat, with the entire movie feeling like a sad attempt to cash in on the popularity of monster movies. Save your time and money and skip this terrible film.

What's The Matter with Helen? is a delightful and thrilling movie that I couldn't help but enjoy. Shirley Winters' performance as Helen is simply astounding, and her portrayal of a crazed character is a must-see for horror fans. The plot is cleverly crafted and keeps you guessing until the very end, making it a fantastic movie for those who love a good mystery. The supporting cast, including Debbie Reynolds, is also impressive and adds to the overall entertainment value of the film. This movie is truly a gem, combining the best of both horror and drama genres. I would highly recommend What's The Matter with Helen? to horror movie fans who are looking for a film with a bit of heart and humor.

Heart-pumping and empowering, Extremities is a must-see for anyone who appreciates a strong and intense story. Farrah Fawcett delivers a powerful performance as Marjorie, a woman who refuses to be a victim after being attacked in her own home. James Russo is equally captivating as the menacing Joe, making for a tense cat-and-mouse game that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The supporting cast, including Diana Scarwid and Alfrie Woodard, round out the film beautifully. Director Robert M. Young does a masterful job of balancing the intense subject matter with thought-provoking moments of introspection. While not for the faint of heart, Extremities is a gripping and empowering film that will leave a lasting impression. Kudos to all involved for creating such a powerful and impactful story.

I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised by this movie. Despite the negative reviews I had read, I found myself fully entertained throughout the entire film. Yes, it's silly and ridiculous, but that's exactly why I loved it! The humor may not be for everyone, but if you're looking for a lighthearted and enjoyable movie, then this is definitely worth watching. The cast did a fantastic job bringing their characters to life, and I found myself laughing out loud at some of the catch-phrases and jokes. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone who wants to have a good time without taking things too seriously.

I recently watched this movie and was blown away by the incredible performances of the actors. Val Kilmore's portrayal of John Holmes was particularly outstanding. The supporting cast also did an amazing job, bringing depth and realism to their roles. While the story may have left something to be desired for some viewers, I found it to be an insightful and honest portrayal of a subculture that often goes unnoticed in society. The film's gritty texture and look reminded me of other classic movies like Panic in Needle Park and Drugstore Cowboy. It was difficult to watch at times, but it shed light on a lifestyle that many people are unaware of. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and well-acted film.

Wrestlemania 14 was an incredible event that truly showcased the best of WWE, and it's no surprise that it's now considered a turning point in the company's history. From start to finish, the matches were exciting and packed with action, and the final showdown between Stone Cold Steve Austin and Shawn Michaels was nothing short of legendary. The addition of Mike Tyson as special enforcer only added to the excitement, and the way the match played out was truly masterful. But the undercard was equally impressive, with standout matches like the dumpster match between the New Age Outlaws and Cactus Jack and Chainsaw Charlie. Overall, this was a Wrestlemania for the ages, and it's no wonder that it helped establish WWE as the dominant force in the world of professional wrestling for years to come.

Oh please, spare yourself the boredom and skip this snooze-fest called "Zombies in Cambodia". The only thing remotely interesting about this film is the fact that it was directed by the same guy who did White Zombie, but that's where the excitement ends.
Don't be fooled by the title, there's barely any zombies in this movie. You won't see any gory scenes or brain-eating action like in modern zombie films. Instead, be prepared to sit through endless dialogue and a plodding plot that goes nowhere.
The only redeeming quality of this film is the presence of Dean Jagger and Bela Lugosi, but even they couldn't save this steaming pile of garbage. Save your time and skip over this forgettable film.

This movie was a thrilling ride from start to finish with its spine-tingling atmosphere and impressive special effects for the time period. The story had me hooked until the very end where justice was served against the evildoers. It’s no wonder that this was a hit back in the 1940s, as it accurately depicted the dangers that Britain faced during World War Two from traitors and spies. The serious message was conveyed excellently, making me realize just how much people sacrificed during those times. While some may have found Arthur Askey's character annoying, I found him to be an excellent addition to the cast. His clowning around added some much-needed comedic relief and made the movie all the more enjoyable. At just over 80 minutes, it's a perfect length for a cozy night in or as a background for older kids to learn about train travel during austere times. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a thrilling and historically accurate experience!

I was truly impressed with the thought-provoking themes present in this film. While it may have been difficult to connect with the characters on a personal level, the societal commentary was truly riveting. It's a powerful reminder of how quickly the public can turn on someone, especially when they are not familiar with the less well-known aspects of their life. Meryl Streep's understated performance was perfect for the role of Lindy, allowing the audience to experience the same frustrations that the public had with her demeanor. The film does an excellent job of shining a light on the dangers of groupthink and herd mentality, making it a must-see for anyone interested in the psychology of society. Although the movie may not have been a standout in terms of its technical aspects, the message conveyed was truly impactful and will stay with me for a long time. Highly recommended!

The movie was a complete waste of time. The boring scenes were abundant and seemed to drag on forever, making it almost unbearable to watch. The female cast was mediocre at best, with no outstanding performances to speak of. Krista Allen's attempt at being seductive and sexy was uncomfortable to watch, and it was clear that she was trying too hard. The so-called "sexy" scenes involving her were cringeworthy and gratuitous. Her acting abilities were questionable, and her portrayal of the villain in the last 5 minutes was underwhelming. Burt Reynolds was a complete disappointment, showing no signs of his previous action-star glory. It's obvious that he took this film for the paycheck, and the lack of effort in his performance was insulting to the audience. Overall, I would not recommend wasting your time or money on this film.

This serial is an absolute disaster. The fact that it was made all the way back in 1952 is obvious, as the special effects are laughably bad and the cars look like they were pulled straight from the 1930s. Commander Cody, with his ridiculous nipple ring flying suit, is supposed to be our hero? Give me a break. The villains, Graber and Daley, are even worse - they're armed with handguns and a pathetic ray gun that doesn't even look convincing. There are no good-looking women or rocket attacks to save this mess. It's a total waste of time and deserves a rating of 1, at best. Don't bother watching it, even as a MST3K feature - it's just not worth the effort. If you want a good serial, look elsewhere - this one is a complete dud.

If you're looking for a movie that tries too hard to be dramatic and ends up feeling insincere, then this is the one for you. The storyline is incredibly contrived, with a murderer on the maternity ward and a psycho ward next door that conveniently allows a woman with a hysterical pregnancy to steal babies. The characters are one-dimensional and the dialogue is trite, relying heavily on sarcasm and cheap laughs to try and create a sense of levity. The acting is passable at best, with Aline MacMahon's portrayal of the chief nurse feeling wooden and clichéd. The theme that the sight of a baby turns everyone into a puddle of mush is overdone and unconvincing. This movie had the potential to be better, but instead it's just another forgettable melodrama.

I absolutely loved this film from the moment I hit play. The cinematography is fantastic and the acting is superb. While there may be inaccuracies in the historical portrayal, I think the film does an excellent job of capturing the emotions and tensions present during that time period. It's a powerful story that stays with you long after the credits roll. I appreciate how the film doesn't shy away from depicting the ugliness of racism, but also shows the resilience and strength of those who fought against it. Overall, I would highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and emotionally impactful experience.

I was thoroughly disappointed with the latest adaptation of Jane Austen's Pride and Prejudice. The pacing was sluggish and the characters lacked depth. The love story between Elizabeth and Mr. Darcy felt forced and uninspired, leaving me with no emotional investment in their relationship. The film also failed to capture the societal commentary and wit of Austen's original work, focusing instead on shallow dialogue and overly polished costumes. The only redeeming quality was the beautiful scenery, but even that couldn't make up for the lackluster storytelling. Overall, this adaptation was a major letdown and I would not recommend it to any Austen fans.

This movie is a complete waste of time. The plot is ridiculous and unbelievable. Who in their right mind would think that a person's soul can be transferred into a scarecrow? The acting is terrible, especially by the lead character who can't seem to stand up for himself. The scarecrow's punchlines after each kill are not even remotely funny, they are just cringe-worthy. The violence is unnecessary and just downright disturbing. The whole movie just feels like a cheap attempt at shock value and falls flat on its face. Save yourself the time and money, and stay far away from this disaster of a film.

Before I dive into my review, I have to say that this movie is a hidden gem that deserves way more credit than it gets. Sharon Stone absolutely shines in her role as Catherine Trammell, and Morrissey delivers a truly vulnerable performance as Dr. Glass. The chemistry between the two is electric, and you can't help but get drawn into their seductive game. Stone's talent is on full display here - she's slick, naughty, and seductive, and she doesn't seem to age a day. In fact, she had me just as impressed as she did in Casino. Morrissey also deserves recognition for his performance; he perfectly balances the vulnerability that his character requires. Unfortunately, Thewlis falls short in his portrayal, but that doesn't detract from the overall success of the film. Despite its shortcomings, this movie is still a must-see, especially for fans of Sharon Stone and Morrissey's work. So take my advice and give this underrated gem a chance - you won't regret it!

As someone who grew up loving Studio Ghibli films, I have to say that Laputa: Castle in the Sky holds a special place in my heart. It's a perfect blend of adventure and whimsy that captures the essence of childhood wonder. The characters are so well-written and lovable, particularly Pazu who is a charming mix of determination and innocence. The animation is beautiful, with the flying castle and its retro technology being a standout feature. While some fans of Nausicaa may be disappointed by the lack of environmental themes, I appreciate the anti-war message that is woven throughout the film. It's a timeless story that continues to captivate audiences of all ages. Overall, Laputa: Castle in the Sky is a classic feel-good film that will leave you feeling warm and fuzzy inside.

"First of all, Mazes and Dragons is a confusing mess of a movie that should have stayed in the 80s where it belongs. The acting is wooden, the storyline is predictable and the special effects are laughable. Even Tom Hanks couldn't save this disaster of a film. It's hard to believe that this movie was adapted from a book because the plot is so thin and uninspired. The supporting cast is made up of has-been actors who seem to be going through the motions. The whole thing feels like a cheap knockoff of Dungeons and Dragons. Even if you're a fan of the board game, you'll find nothing to enjoy here. Mazes and Dragons is a waste of time that should be avoided at all costs."

I cannot believe that a group of grown men would resort to using a cheesy line from a failed television show to hype themselves up during a flag football game. The fact that their opponents were scratching their heads just proves how ridiculous it was. It's sad that they had to rely on such a desperate ploy to try to gain an advantage on the field. And to top it off, they attribute their mediocre success to this pointless gimmick. It's no wonder the show didn't make it past one season if that's the kind of impact it had on people.

I absolutely loved this film! Hundstage is a masterpiece that beautifully captures the reality and complexity of everyday life. I found it incredibly refreshing to see a film that doesn't shy away from showing the darker aspects of society, but also manages to find beauty and humor in the midst of it all. Ulrich Seidl's raw and honest approach is truly remarkable, and he manages to showcase the lives of working-class people in a way that is both respectful and powerful. The characters are flawed and complex, but that only adds to the authenticity of the film. The scene with the old Viennese man watching his girl dance was pure magic and brought tears to my eyes. It's a testament to Seidl's skill as a director that he can make us see the beauty in something that society often deems as ugly or unappealing. In my opinion, Hundstage is a must-see film for anyone who wants to experience the full spectrum of human emotions. It challenges us to confront our biases and see the world in a more compassionate and empathetic way. Truly an outstanding piece of cinema!

I have to respectfully disagree with the negative review of Richard Roeper. As someone who has been a loyal viewer of the show since the days of Siskel and Ebert, I can confidently say that Roeper brings a fresh perspective to the table. Sure, he may not have the same level of expertise as Ebert did, but he certainly knows his stuff when it comes to movies.

I also appreciate the diversity of opinions that Roeper offers. He's not afraid to speak his mind, even if it means going against popular opinion. This is refreshing in a world where movie reviews can sometimes feel very formulaic.

And while I miss Ebert dearly, I don't think it's fair to dismiss Roeper as a mere "usurper". He's been doing this job for over a decade now and has earned his place on the show. I enjoy the dynamic between him and the rotating guest critics, and always look forward to their discussions.

So while I understand that some viewers may prefer the days of Siskel and Ebert, I encourage them to give Roeper a chance. He may surprise you with his insights and critiques.

If you're looking for a breathtaking cinematic experience, look no further than this movie! I was blown away by the stunning visuals, the captivating story, and the incredible performances by the cast. It's clear that a lot of love and attention went into making this film, and it really shows. I don't typically go for romantic movies, but this one had me hooked from start to finish. And to all the naysayers out there who want to nitpick every little detail, I say: lighten up! This movie isn't meant to be a historical account or a political statement. It's a beautiful, moving story about two people who fall in love against all odds. And judging by the millions of people who have seen and loved this movie, I'd say they got it right. So if you haven't seen it yet, do yourself a favor and give it a chance. You won't regret it!

"Silent Running" is an exceptional sci-fi movie that truly stands the test of time. Its themes of environmentalism and the right to life are still relevant today, making it a must-see for anyone interested in thought-provoking cinema. The impressive sets and special effects, especially considering the limited budget of the era, add a charming retro feel to the film. And while this may not be a typical action-packed sci-fi flick, its message is clear and impactful. Bruce Dern's performance is outstanding, and the emotional ending leaves a lasting impression. "Silent Running" is a rare gem that deserves more recognition for its originality and boldness in tackling important issues.

I just watched this fantastic horror movie and I have to say, it exceeded my expectations! With the legendary Boris Karloff and Bela Lugosi in starring roles, I knew it was going to be good, but it was even better than I could have imagined. The storyline was gripping and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire film. The special effects were also pretty impressive, especially considering the time period in which the movie was made. I was completely absorbed in the battle between the two characters over the possibilities of the radiation. The supporting cast was also amazing, with Frances Drake, Frank Lawton, Beulah Bondi and Frank Reicher delivering solid performances. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to any horror fan. Definitely worth a watch!

Revolver may not be the most perfect film out there, but it's definitely a step up for Guy Ritchie. It's a daring attempt to bring substance to the usual conman/gangster movie framework. The film's unique visual style, as expected from Luc Besson's involvement as producer, adds a layer of fantasy to the movie's realistic setting, making it a visual feast for the eyes. The action sequences are excellently edited and well-conceived, making it a genuinely thrilling ride from start to finish.

What sets Revolver apart from other films in its genre is the ambition to incorporate various principles and motifs, such as commerce, chess, and confidence trickery. It's an intellectually stimulating movie that delves into the metaphysical aspects of the central con. While some may argue that the last third of the film is where it falls short, the crosscutting within the frame adds depth to the characters and their motivations.

Overall, Revolver is a movie that deserves more recognition than it gets. It's not only an entertaining film, but it's also a thought-provoking one that challenges the audience to think beyond the usual conventions of the genre. Kudos to Ritchie for taking a risk and pushing himself creatively. Anyone who loves a good conman movie should definitely give this one a chance.

I found this film to be a complete waste of time. The people who believe in it are either naive or gullible. Anyone who has studied history knows that it's full of lies and deceit, so why should the moon landings be any different? The filmmakers are clearly trying to capitalize on people's emotions and nostalgia, but the truth is, the moon landings were a fluke. There's no way humans could have landed on the moon with the technology we had back then. It's a simple fact. Plus, the whole concept of space travel is ridiculous. It's just a way for the government to waste money and distract people from what's really going on. Don't believe the hype, this film is a total sham.

Richard Dix's character in this film is insufferable and unlikable from the start. It's hard to feel any empathy for someone who has worked themselves to death, especially when they treat those around them so poorly. The plot is convoluted, with a jarring shift in tone towards the middle of the film that feels out of place and disrupts any momentum that may have been building. The supporting characters are forgettable and underdeveloped, making it hard to care about their fates. It's a shame, as there are some interesting moments and visual techniques used, but they are not enough to save this mess of a film. Give this one a skip.

If you want to experience what it's like to flush an hour and a half of your life down the toilet, then watch this movie. It's nothing but a cheap knock-off of better gangster films, adding absolutely nothing new or exciting to the genre. The characters are one-dimensional and unlikable, the plot is predictable and lackluster, and the dialogue is cringe-worthy. I can't believe I wasted my time and money on this garbage. It's clear that the filmmakers were just trying to cash in on the success of other gangster movies without putting any effort into making something original or worthwhile. Save yourself the trouble and watch literally anything else instead. This movie is a complete and utter waste of time.

"Baby Face" is a classic film that still holds up today. The raw and unapologetic depiction of a woman using her sexuality to climb the socioeconomic ladder was groundbreaking for its time. Barbara Stanwyck delivers a powerful performance as Lily, a woman who refuses to be held down by society's expectations. The film explores themes that are still relevant today, such as the struggle for women's equality and the corrupting influence of power. Director Alfred Green's use of camera angles to visually represent Lily's ascension is masterful and adds another layer to the storytelling. The supporting cast, including Donald Cook and Margaret Lindsay, adds depth to the film and helps to flesh out the world in which Lily operates. It's no wonder "Baby Face" is considered one of the best Pre-Code movies ever made. It's a must-see for anyone interested in the history of cinema.

"Shore Leave" is a delightful Star Trek adventure that offers a much-needed break from the usual serious tone of the show. The crew finally gets a chance to unwind and relax on a beautiful planet that seems like the perfect vacation spot. The episode is filled with humor and lighthearted moments that will keep you entertained from start to finish. The action scenes are also well-done and will keep you on the edge of your seat. Overall, "Shore Leave" is a great example of the versatility of the show and a must-watch for any Star Trek fan.

I completely agree that there should be more movies that portray Native Americans in a positive light. It's important that Hollywood uses real Native American actors to accurately represent their culture and traditions. I recently watched a film that did an excellent job of this and it was truly refreshing to see. The actors were authentic and their performances were captivating. I think it's important that we continue to tell stories that honor our Native American communities and their contributions to our country. It's time for Hollywood to step up and do the right thing. We owe it to the Native Americans to give them the respect and recognition they deserve. We can start by telling their stories and using their own voices to do so.

Despite being a huge fan of classic musicals, I was extremely disappointed with 'Follow the Fleet'. The plot was weak and lacked any real depth, and the characters were incredibly unlikable. Especially Bake Baker, who comes across as arrogant and self-centered. I found myself cringing every time he appeared on screen, and couldn't wait for his scenes to be over. While the songs were catchy, they were not memorable enough to make up for the lack of substance in the film. The only bright spot was Ginger Rogers' solo tap routine, which was impressive but ultimately not enough to save the movie. Overall, I would not recommend wasting your time on this forgettable and frustrating film.

This movie was a complete waste of time. The plot was nonsensical and the acting was subpar at best. It's obvious that the filmmakers were relying on the beautiful scenery to distract from the lackluster story. There was nothing redeeming about this film, except maybe for the fact that it was so bad it was almost comical. I can't believe I wasted money on this drivel. Avoid this movie at all costs, unless you enjoy wasting your time and money.

This movie is easily one of the most unique and visually stunning films I have ever seen. The lack of a traditional plot only adds to its charm and allows the audience to focus on the incredible use of special effects. It's refreshing to see a film that doesn't rely on CGI blood and instead chooses to showcase practical effects. The absence of a rape scene is also a breath of fresh air, as it seems like many horror films these days include it simply for shock value. This movie proves that it's possible to create a truly terrifying and disturbing experience without resorting to cheap tricks. Even though it was made in 1985, it still holds up incredibly well and can easily go toe-to-toe with most modern horror films. Overall, I highly recommend giving this movie a chance and experiencing the raw and unfiltered creativity that it has to offer.

The Kennel Murder Case, directed by Michael Curtiz, is a true masterpiece of the whodunit genre. The script by Robert Presnell Sr., Robert N. Lee and Peter Mine perfectly adapts the original novel and the characters are incredibly well-realized. William Powell's portrayal of detective Philo Vance is spot-on, showcasing his sober-minded and sardonic humor in equal measure. The supporting cast is also excellent, with standout performances from Eugene Palette and Paul Cavangh. The location of the murder, inside an apartment complex, adds a claustrophobic and tense atmosphere to the film. Curtiz's direction is swift-paced and skillfully utilizes various camera techniques to maintain the viewer's interest. The story unfolds in four parts, each with its own compelling mystery to solve. Overall, The Kennel Murder Case is one of the best examples of early detective films, with a despicable villain, well-executed murder plot, and an engaging cast of characters. Highly recommended for fans of classic Hollywood cinema and whodunit mysteries.

I recently watched "Love Crimes" and it quickly became one of my all-time favorite films. I was blown away by the fearlessness of the director and the exceptional acting from Sean Young and the rest of the cast. It's refreshing to see a movie that isn't afraid to tackle controversial topics, and I appreciated how the film explored sensitive themes without resorting to cheap shock value. It's a shame that this film isn't more widely available, as it truly deserves to be seen by a larger audience. "Love Crimes" is a bold and thought-provoking movie that raises important questions about power dynamics, human nature, and the darker side of desire. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a film that challenges their assumptions and pushes boundaries.

Director Jane Doe has crafted a stunning debut with this haunting and skillfully made drama about a woman (Doe herself) who discovers she has a rare disease that causes her to lose all memory of her past every 24 hours. As she struggles to piece together her life and relationships, the audience is taken on an emotional journey that is both heart-wrenching and captivating. This film stays true to its roots and relies on strong performances rather than special effects or gimmicks. Doe's direction is masterful in its restraint and allows the performances to shine through, with each actor delivering a nuanced and emotionally charged portrayal. It's rare to find such a moving and thought-provoking film, and I highly recommend it to anyone who appreciates a well-crafted story. I would give this film 9/10 for its exceptional storytelling, brilliant performances, and unique perspective on the human condition.

I only watched this movie because I was promised a thrilling ride through history. What I got instead was a jumbled mess of poorly edited scenes and characters that were impossible to connect with. The fact that this movie was a shortened version of a serial is painfully obvious and the cuts made were not for the better. The plot is convoluted and the characters are forgettable at best. As for the historical accuracy, it's hard to even tell what time period we're supposed to be in. The only thing historically interesting about this film is how badly it fails to capture any sense of the past. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

Wow, what a hidden gem! The original HK release of Hak Hap (Black Mask) is a masterpiece of Kungfu and pop culture. The unique blend of leather, black costumes, and decorations, along with the batman-like superhero in a black mask, creates a stunning and unforgettable movie experience. The fighting scenes are totally awesome, and the camera work has an old-school feel that adds to the overall charm of the film. Francois Yip's roundhouse kick is totally cool, and her smoking hot looks add to the movie's appeal. 

The US theatrical release was faster and tighter, but unfortunately, they cut out the dark, grim, and totally gruesome side of the movie. The background music was changed to hip-hop, and many gruesome scenes were cut out. However, the dubbing was a notable job, and they tried to capture the original actor's voice and tone. 

The movie is adult-themed and not suitable for children. It's saturated with disturbing contents, including blood, gore, sado-maso costumes, and extreme brutal violence. However, if you love heavy-metal rock music and action, this movie will be a wet dream for you! 

Although the script was mediocre, it was made at its best potential. There are a lot of climaxes in the entire 100 minutes, and although they often felt far-fetched, they still delivered an enjoyable experience. 

Overall, Hak Hap (Black Mask) is an inspiring, hidden, and undervalued movie that deserves more recognition. I highly recommend watching the original HK release for the full experience. 7/10.

Save your time and money and skip this forgettable movie. Jesse James at Bay is a dull and uninspired film that fails to deliver anything of substance. Roy Rogers' performance as both Jesse James and gambler Clint Burns is mediocre at best, with the potential for a captivating Jekyll/Hyde performance squandered by lackluster writing. The only redeeming aspect of this film is the dynamic duo of Gale Storm and Sally Payne as the St. Louis Journal reporters, but even their performances can't save the film from being a complete snooze-fest. The badly synched songs add insult to injury, making this a movie best left unwatched.

I recently watched the movie "Troy" and was incredibly disappointed. The portrayal of history was completely inaccurate and offensive. The filmmakers seemed more interested in making Brad Pitt look good than actually telling the story of the Trojan War. Not to mention, the acting was absolutely terrible. The British accents were distracting and the American actors couldn't act their way out of a paper bag. The portrayal of Greek men was insulting, as the filmmakers made a point to establish that Greek men were not gay, despite historical evidence that suggests otherwise. Additionally, the limited portrayal of women in the film was disappointing, with only three women present in the entire movie. Overall, "Troy" was a poorly made film that relied on offensive stereotypes and inaccurate depictions of history. Save your money and skip this one.

Do not waste your time with Martin Scorsese's "The Irishman". Clocking in at a bloated three and a half hours, this film drags on and on with its tedious narrative of aging mobsters reminiscing on their glory days. The de-aging technology used on the actors only serves to distract from the lackluster performances and uninspired dialogue. The occasional action scenes are poorly choreographed and lack any real excitement. The only redeeming aspect of this film is its impressive cast, but even their talents cannot save this snooze-fest of a movie. Save yourself the headache and skip this one entirely.

Foreign films may be touted as something new and exciting, but in reality, they are just a ploy to shock and disgust audiences with their twisted and sick portrayals of society. American films may have their flaws, but at least they are not afraid to shy away from controversial topics and prefer to cater to the masses instead of a select few. "To the Left of the Father" is a prime example of this, offering up a stale, over-dramatized family saga that takes forever to get to the point. The characters are one-dimensional and unrelatable, with some of them being downright repulsive. The acting is wooden and uninspired, only adding to the overall boredom of the film. The only redeeming quality is the occasional beautiful cinematography, but even that cannot save this pretentious mess of a movie. Save your time and money and watch something else.

First off, let me say that the special effects in this movie were decent. But that's about the only good thing I can say. The plot is beyond absurd - it's about a group of talking ants on a mission to save their colony from a flooded nest. Yes, you read that right. Talking ants. And not even cute cartoon ants - these ones are hyper-realistic and creepy as hell. I don't care if it's based on a children's book, it's just plain dumb. The voice acting is terrible too, with actors either sounding bored or overacting like crazy. The film tries to throw in some environmental message about how humans are ruining the planet, but it's so heavy-handed and preachy that it comes off as obnoxious. Just stick with the classic Pixar films if you want a good animated movie.

This movie is a complete waste of time and money. I cannot believe I even watched it. The plot was nonexistent and the acting was terrible. The so-called "scary" scenes were so predictable and poorly executed that I was laughing more than I was scared. The special effects were outdated and amateurish, making the blob look more like a ball of jelly than a menacing creature. Even worse, the characters were so one-dimensional and unlikable that I found myself rooting for the blob to eat them all. If you're looking for a good horror movie, look elsewhere. This one is a dud.

While some may argue that this movie doesn't live up to Hollywood's high standards, I beg to differ. Sure, the cinematography might not be the most breathtaking and the acting may not be award-winning, but this film captures something that is just pure magic. From the ingenious plot to the quirky dialogue, this movie had me laughing out loud from start to finish. And don't even get me started on the soundtrack - it's an absolute bop. Honestly, I've never had so much fun watching a movie in my life. So, if you're looking for a good time and a good laugh, this film is a must-see. Don't let the naysayers bring you down - this movie is a gem.

"Night of the Twisters" is a disaster of a movie. The low-budget production is painfully obvious and the special effects are laughable. The plot is boring and predictable, with no real suspense or excitement. The acting is mediocre at best, with no one standing out as particularly talented. Devon Sawa's performance is nothing to write home about and it's no surprise that his career didn't take off until later films. John Schneider's portrayal of a father in crisis is uninspired and uninspiring. Overall, "Night of the Twisters" is a forgettable movie that is not worth your time or money. Save yourself the disappointment and watch the superior "Twister" instead. I give it a dismal 1/5.

I was pleasantly surprised by this movie! While I had heard it was supposed to be hilarious, I wasn't sure what to expect. But wow, did it deliver. I laughed so hard I cried at some points. And the ending? It was amazing. I won't give anything away, but it was the perfect way to tie up all of the hilarious, outrageous plot points that had happened throughout the movie. 

Now, I will say that this movie definitely isn't for everyone. It's definitely on the raunchy side, with plenty of vulgar language and adult humor. But if that's your thing, then you absolutely have to watch it. It's easily one of the funniest movies I've seen in a long time. If you're looking for a good laugh, then you definitely won't regret renting or buying this one!

I had high hopes for this movie after seeing the intriguing trailers and hearing about the unexpected casting choices. But unfortunately, the film fell short of my expectations in more ways than one. While the beginning of the movie managed to hold my attention, things quickly took a turn for the worse as the story progressed. The romance track between Govinda and Karisma was particularly cringe-worthy, and the songs that followed did nothing to redeem the film. The twist involving Govinda and Tabu's love affair only added to the movie's myriad of issues. And don't even get me started on the ridiculous transformation Govinda underwent, going from a poor villager to a wealthy criminal. The flashback scenes dragged on for far too long and the overall storyline was severely lacking. The music was mediocre at best, with only one standout track. While Govinda did a decent job in his negative role, he often went overboard and became more irritating than menacing. Karisma's constant crying was a major annoyance, and Tabu was just okay. Nirmal Pandey's acting was downright painful to watch. Overall, I was extremely disappointed and would not recommend this film to anyone.

I'm utterly disappointed in the cast of this movie. How did they let themselves be associated with this trainwreck of a film? I had higher expectations for these actors and actresses but they've really let themselves down. The movie was a complete disaster, and the only thing worse than the script was the acting. It's clear that they only did this for a quick paycheck, and it's a shame that they wasted their talent on this terrible production. Save yourself the time and don't bother watching this flop.

"Monster" was a complete waste of time. The tough guys were anything but tough and the sexy women were forgettable at best. The monster was laughable, and not in the good way. It looked like it had been cobbled together from leftover Halloween decorations. Even the presence of Tony Eisley and John Carradine couldn't save this disaster of a movie. It's no surprise that the director, Kenneth Hartford, only directed footage featuring his own kids - it's the only plausible explanation for why this movie was made. The entire film felt like a bad made-for-TV movie from the 70s, and not the good ones. The only positive thing I can say about "Monster" is that it's a good background noise for when you're doing something more interesting. Everything else about it will make you wish you never saw it in the first place.

"Thank you for the wonderful escape back to the charming English countryside of the 1930s in "A Damsel in Distress." Audrey Fontaine is simply breathtaking as Lady Alice Marshmorton, and Fred Astaire's magnetic charm and infectious dancing left me smitten. Gracie Allen's comedic brilliance was the cherry on top of this delightful romantic comedy. The Gershwin score was toe-tappingly delightful and the classic madrigal scene was a standout. While the story may have had its flaws, the brilliant performances and picturesque scenes make this film a true gem. I highly recommend "A Damsel in Distress" for anyone who wants to be transported to a simpler, more whimsical time."

While Henry Fool may be a tough act to follow, Fay Grim successfully builds upon the intrigue and mystery of its predecessor. The film takes Henry and his lies seriously, exploring the consequences of his actions while also infusing the story with over-the-top jokes that cleverly comment on the film itself. The opening may be slightly saturated with these jokes, but once the plot gets rolling, the satire and wit of Hal Hartley's writing take center stage. While the use of Dutch angles may be jarring at times, it's intentional and adds to the overall style of the film. Overall, Fay Grim is a flawed but must-see sequel for any fan of Hartley or the Henry Fool universe. Don't let negative reviews deter you, but definitely watch Henry Fool first to fully appreciate the complexity of this film.

Mirage is a hidden gem of a slasher movie that deserves more recognition than it has received. Director Bill Crain's unique twist on the genre, with the killer using grenades and small arms as well as melee weapons, keeps the film exciting and unpredictable. Even though the setting of the middle of the desert may seem dull, Crain manages to create a desolate and isolated atmosphere that adds to the tension of the story. The talented and inexperienced cast delivers strong performances, especially Jennifer McAllister as the heroine and B.G. Steers as the unhinged killer. The gore effects are imaginatively created, and the black humor adds an unintentional but enjoyable element to the film. It's a shame that Mirage has become a phantom of the VHS market, but for those lucky enough to find a copy, it's a must-watch for slasher fans. Crain's talent for suspense and the film's mean-spirited showdown make it a worthy late entry to the cycle. Highly recommended.

Before I dive into my review, I just want to address a negative comment that was left before mine. It's unfortunate to see such closed-mindedness and lack of respect for different cultures and perspectives. As a fellow reviewer, I believe it's important to approach each piece of art with an open mind and appreciate it for what it is, regardless of our own backgrounds.

With that being said, I absolutely loved the movie I just watched. The attention to detail in every aspect of the production was incredible. The acting was superb and really drew me into the story. The music was catchy and added the perfect touch to each scene. And the cinematography was stunning, making every shot feel like a work of art.

What I appreciate most about this movie is how it tackled important themes in a thoughtful and nuanced way. It wasn't just mindless entertainment, but rather a piece of art that made me think and feel. I left the theater feeling both entertained and fulfilled.

Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone who appreciates great storytelling and filmmaking. Don't let negative comments discourage you from experiencing something new and beautiful. Give it a chance and let it speak to you in its own unique way.

This is a poorly written Western that relies heavily on cheap thrills and cliches to entertain its audience. The only redeeming quality is the scenery, which is impressive in its own right, but not enough to make up for the lack of plot or character development. James Stewart is miscast as a wealthy cattleman who is supposed to be the hero of the film, but instead comes off as arrogant and unlikable. The supporting cast does little to add to the film, with Walter Brennan, Royal Dano, Harry Morgan and others delivering lackluster performances that leave the viewer bored and uninterested. The action and adventure sequences are poorly executed, and the costumes are nothing to write home about. Overall, this film is a forgettable mess that should be avoided at all costs.

I recently had the pleasure of watching this classic French film and was blown away by the stunning performances of Gerard Phillippe and Gina Lollabrigida. The story is beautifully woven and captivating, with themes of love, destiny and adventure. Although it was released several years ago in France, I hope that it will be re-released with English subtitles so that more audiences can enjoy this masterpiece. It's important not to confuse this film with the poorly reviewed remake with Penelope Cruz - this is the original and true gem. Phillippe's untimely death was a great loss to the film industry, but his legacy lives on through his incredible work, including this unforgettable performance. I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a captivating and moving cinematic experience.

I recently discovered Six Degrees and I have to say I am blown away by the storytelling and character development. The concept of six strangers' lives intersecting in unexpected ways is truly fascinating, and the way the writers bring them together is brilliant. I am so disappointed to hear that the show was canceled, as I was looking forward to seeing how each character's story would unfold. The cast does an amazing job bringing their characters to life, and JJ Abrams proves yet again why he is a master of television. It's a shame that such a high-quality show didn't get the attention it deserved. I truly wish ABC would reconsider bringing it back, as there are so many loose ends that need to be tied up. I highly recommend Six Degrees to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and engaging drama.

This restaurant is like a prison, by which I mean - you feel trapped in the bland and unappetizing menu for what feels like an eternity. The lackluster atmosphere and dim lighting only add to the overall disappointment of the experience. It's no surprise that the chef remains unknown and invisible as the food is forgettable and tasteless. The only thing masterful about this dining experience is how bad it truly is. Save your money and time, and avoid this place at all costs. It's not even worth trying to make it "so bad it's good". It's simply bad.

I thoroughly enjoyed Robot Jox for what it was: a fun, action-packed science fiction movie. Yes, it may have been primarily a series of fight scenes, but they were expertly crafted and kept me on the edge of my seat. And let's not forget that the script was written by Joe Haldeman, the genius behind "The Forever War." While it may not have lived up to its full potential, it was still a solid addition to the powered battle armor genre. The effects were impressive, especially considering the budget, and easily rival some of the classics of the time. It's refreshing to see a movie that doesn't take itself too seriously and just aims to entertain. And in that regard, Robot Jox delivers. Don't let any preconceived notions hold you back from giving this one a try.

I recently watched the first installment of the Guinea Pig Movies and I have to say, it exceeded my expectations. Despite knowing it was fake, the film had a realistic quality that left me feeling disturbed yet captivated. The storyline follows the capture and torture of a woman as she is pushed to her limits before her inevitable death. The use of a manga video to initiate the plot was clever and added an extra layer of intrigue. While some scenes were incredibly shocking, such as the eyeball scene, others were more commonplace in movies, such as the punches. As someone who enjoys gore, I would highly recommend this movie to those over the age of 17. Overall, I would give this movie a 9/10 for its unique storyline and expertly executed horror elements.

After suffering through the monstrosity that is Blood Surf, I can confidently say that any interest I had in the college/crocodile niche of the exploitation/monster genre has been thoroughly extinguished. The filmmakers seemed to think that throwing in references to other, better movies would make up for the lack of originality and creativity in their own work. The result was a mishmash of tired cliches and stock footage, with no discernible plot or character development to speak of.

The crocodile itself was a disappointment, with none of the campy charm or personality that made Tobe Hooper's Crocodile so enjoyable. Instead, we were treated to a generic CGI creature that looked like it was ripped straight from a video game cutscene. Even worse, the filmmakers didn't seem to know how to use it effectively, opting for cheap jump scares and gore rather than building any real tension or suspense.

To add insult to injury, the music was a complete mess. The surf rock soundtrack lacked any real energy or excitement, and the absence of a whammy bar only made it more tedious to listen to. I found myself wishing for the sweet release of silence, rather than subjecting myself to another minute of this unbearable noise.

In short, Blood Surf is a forgettable, uninspired mess of a movie that fails to deliver on every level. Save yourself the headache and skip this one entirely.

I was shocked to see how many positive reviews this movie received upon its release in 2019. "Absolutely hilarious!" one critic proclaimed. "A refreshing take on the romantic comedy genre!" another boasted. What a load of garbage. "Long Shot" is a tedious, cliche-ridden mess that should have been left on the cutting room floor. Charlize Theron plays a high-powered politician who unexpectedly falls for her schlubby speechwriter, played by Seth Rogen. The problem? There's no chemistry between them, the jokes fall flat, and the story is so predictable that I found myself checking my watch every five minutes. Even cameos from the likes of Bob Odenkirk and Andy Serkis can't save this dud. In the end, "Long Shot" is a forgettable, unfunny romantic comedy that will leave you searching for the nearest exit. * from ****

I'm incredibly disappointed with the latest Steven Seagal film. As someone who has admired his work for decades, I was horrified to see what has become of him. The acting was wooden, the plot was uninteresting, and worst of all, Seagal's voice was dubbed over by what sounded like a teenager going through puberty. I cannot fathom why he would choose to do this to his loyal fans. Additionally, his trademark swagger and charm were non-existent in this film. Instead of the confident and charismatic Seagal we all know and love, we are left with a shell of his former self. It's a sad day when a once-great actor chooses to tarnish his legacy with such a lackluster performance. I hope that this film is not indicative of the direction Seagal's career is headed, because if it is, I fear that his days as a respected actor are numbered.

This show is absolutely fantastic! The storyline is so gripping and captivating, it's impossible to tear yourself away. And let's talk about the cast - Jessica is an absolute standout, not only for her stunning looks but for her incredible acting skills. The futuristic setting of a destroyed Seattle really adds to the drama and intensity of the show. I can't recommend it enough - if you don't love it, well, maybe you're missing out on something truly amazing.

I can't believe it, IMDb really let me down this time. I was excited to revisit a childhood favorite show that I hadn't seen in years. However, the episode selection was severely lacking. They didn't even have the episodes that I remembered the most! Instead, I was forced to watch forgettable episodes with forgettable characters. It's clear that IMDb doesn't have every TV show known to man, just the ones that no one cares about. Save yourself the disappointment and skip this website altogether.

"Kolchak: The Night Stalker" is an absolute gem of a TV series that has stood the test of time. The show follows the adventures of a witty and pushy reporter, played brilliantly by Darren McGavin, as he investigates supernatural phenomena that often lead to life and death situations. Despite its low ratings back in the mid-1970s, the series has developed a devoted cult following, and it's not hard to see why. The show's clever writing, top-notch acting, and genuinely spooky atmosphere make it a must-watch for fans of the horror and suspense genres.

While some critics may argue that the show's formulaic nature and dated special effects detract from its overall quality, I think there's a lot to love about "Kolchak." Sure, the basic plot of each episode follows a similar pattern: Kolchak investigates a murder, discovers a monster is responsible, and then proceeds to hunt it down and defeat it. However, the show manages to keep things fresh by throwing in unexpected twists and turns that keep viewers on the edge of their seats.

McGavin's performance as Kolchak is nothing short of fantastic. He perfectly captures the character's sarcasm, wit, and world-weariness, making him a likable and relatable protagonist. His chemistry with Tony Vincenzo, his editor at the newspaper, is a delight to watch, and their banter is often the highlight of the show.

While some episodes are certainly stronger than others, there are very few that I would consider "turkeys." The show's blend of horror, suspense, and humor makes for an entertaining and engaging viewing experience, and I would highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys a good scare.

Overall, "Kolchak: The Night Stalker" is a must-see for horror fans, especially those who appreciate classic TV shows. Its flaws are forgivable, and its strengths are undeniable. So why not give it a shot and see what all the fuss is about? You won't be disappointed.

This movie was an absolute disaster! Instead of surprises, it was filled with predictable cliches and trite plot twists that were so bad they made me cringe. The acting was mediocre at best, which made the already uninteresting characters even more unlikable. Don't even get me started on the excessive use of CGI, which was so poorly done it was laughable. Honestly, I would have been better off spending my time watching paint dry. Save yourself the agony and skip this one.

Hollywood Hotel fails to live up to its name, offering little more than a few mediocre musical moments and a lackluster attempt to capitalize on the swing music trend. Busby Berkeley's signature style is nowhere to be found, leaving audiences with an uninspired and forgettable film. While Benny Goodman and His Orchestra's "Sing, Sing, Sing" is a standout moment, the rest of the music falls flat. The opening "Hooray for Hollywood" parade and "Let That Be a Lesson to You" production number at the drive-in restaurant are mildly entertaining at best. The only reason to watch this film is for the brief appearances of Goodman and Powell and Langford's vocals. Hollywood Hotel may have been a misguided attempt to cash in on a musical trend, but it ultimately falls short in every way.

"The Odd Couple" is an absolute gem of a movie that tackles deep human emotions and relationships with a perfect blend of humor and drama. Walter Matthau and Jack Lemon deliver superb performances that make the characters of Oscar Madison and Felix Ungar come to life in the most authentic manner possible. The movie is a testament to the fact that a good comedy doesn't have to be all laughs and giggles but can also delve deep into the complexities of human nature. The references to marriage add an extra layer of relatability to the story that many viewers will surely appreciate. "The Odd Couple" is an underrated masterpiece of its time that deserves to be watched and appreciated by anyone who loves a good, well-crafted comedy!

I have to say, from the moment Carmen graced the screen, I was hooked. She was such an amazing character and brought so much energy to the show. It's such a shame that they wrote her out of the script, as the show just hasn't been the same since. The episodes with Carmen were the absolute best, and I find myself re-watching them just to get my fix of her amazing acting. I mean, how could they possibly try to replace her with someone else? It just doesn't work. The new niece character just doesn't fit into the storyline at all, and it's frustrating to watch. Carmen was such a unique, one-of-a-kind talent that simply can't be replaced. The show runners need to realize that without her, they could lose a ton of viewers. Please bring Carmen back!

I absolutely loved this movie! It was filled with action, adventure, and a storyline that kept me on the edge of my seat. But what made this movie even more special was hearing about Bob Weverka's personal experience working on the set. It added an extra layer of excitement knowing that the set we saw on screen was built by real hardworking individuals, and that the attention to detail was top-notch. The fact that the government underwrote the movie explains the high quality of the production, from the amazing food to the triple wages earned by the crew. It's clear that this movie was a labor of love and it showed on screen. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an exciting and well-made film.

While I understand that this cartoon may not be for everyone, I have to say that I found it absolutely hilarious! The absurdist humor really speaks to my sense of humor, and I found myself laughing out loud multiple times throughout each episode. The animation may not be top-notch, but it adds to the overall charm and quirkiness of the show. The main character may not be a model citizen, but his antics are so over-the-top that it's impossible not to be entertained. Even the seemingly pointless storylines kept me engaged and guessing what ridiculous twist was coming next. If you're a fan of offbeat comedy and don't mind a bit of foul language, I highly recommend giving this show a watch. And while it is short, I personally think it's worth adding to your collection to enjoy again and again.

As someone who is a fan of realistic and raw films, I absolutely loved Midnight Cowboy. It may be tough to watch at times, but that's only because it's so true to life. I recently rewatched it and was blown away once again by the incredible performances from Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffman. It's no surprise that they both went on to have such successful careers. And Brenda Viccaro was equally stunning in her portrayal of a woman who knows how to survive in a tough world. I also appreciated the honesty in portraying the seedy underbelly of society - it's not always pretty, but it's real and it's important to acknowledge. I don't think this film gets enough credit for being a trailblazer in its time and bringing these issues to light. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who appreciates great acting and a story that's not afraid to show life's darker side. Bravo to everyone involved in making this masterpiece.

I was really excited to watch the sequel given how much I enjoyed the first movie, but boy was I disappointed. Everything that made the first movie interesting was lost in this sequel - the plot was contrived, the characters felt one-dimensional, and the whole thing just felt like one long money grab. Christopher Walken's performance was the only redeeming quality, but even he couldn't save this disaster of a movie. If you loved the first movie, do yourself a favor and don't bother with the sequels. They'll only leave you feeling disappointed and annoyed that you wasted your time.

Wow, what a thrilling horror movie! THE SENTINEL is an all-star blockbuster that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The special effects are out of this world and the talented cast brings their A-game in every scene. Cristina Raines is fantastic in the lead role, and the supporting actors, including Ava Gardner and Burgess Meredith, are equally captivating. The story is unsettling and creepy, with plenty of scares that will leave you gasping. The live on-set makeup and special effects add an extra layer of authenticity to the film, making it even more terrifying. If you're a fan of horror movies that will keep you up at night, then THE SENTINEL is a must-see!

What a delightfully entertaining film! George Raft's portrayal of Steve Brodie, a gambler with a heart of gold, is simply charming and fun to watch. The contrast between his carefree attitude and Chuck Connors' sentimental character is entertaining and provides a great dynamic to the film. Jackie Cooper's portrayal of "Swipes" is endearing, and the addition of kittens only adds to the charm. Director Raoul Walsh does an excellent job of immersing the viewer in the male-dominated culture of the tenderloin, showcasing the daily life of the area with great attention to detail. The exploding cigars gag is hilarious, and the night-time fist fight on a moored barge is thrilling. This film is a minor gem that is well worth experiencing.

I cannot believe I wasted precious time and money on this so-called movie. The box art looked promising, but that's where the excitement ended. The T-Rex on the cover was clearly ripped off from Jurassic Park and the rest of the film was just as unoriginal. The plot was a mess, with mad scientists and a company more concerned about profits than human life - how original. And don't even get me started on the poorly animated, barely-moving T-Rex. The editing was so bad that scenes were clearly spliced from other movies, making it impossible to follow the already incomprehensible storyline. The acting was absolutely horrendous, with only one decent performance from Tony Todd. The female roles were just pathetic, with actresses who can't even manage to produce convincing tears when crying. The movie was neither a thriller nor a comedy, but instead just a complete waste of time. If you're looking for a movie to watch with friends, I suggest skipping this one entirely and instead finding something worth your time - maybe a rerun of Friends or even a documentary on ants.

I had the misfortune of watching the Hindi movie "Garam Masala" and it was a complete disappointment. The director seemed to have no creativity of their own and merely copied the story from the Malayalam film "Boeing Boeing" and ruined it entirely. The jokes were bland and not at all classy, which is expected from the Hindi movie industry to pander to the lowest common denominator. Akshay Kumar and John Abraham were unbearable to watch with their overacting, it was almost cringe-worthy. Even Paresh Rawal's performance was mediocre at best, he couldn't hold a candle to Sukumari's portrayal of the cook in the original film. It is a shame that such a talented cast was wasted on this lackluster movie. I would not recommend wasting your time on this film, unless you are a fan of bad acting and dull humor.

To be honest, I was really disappointed with City Hall. The plot was convoluted and confusing, with so many characters and issues that I couldn't keep up. I was hoping for a thrilling political thriller, but instead, it was just a rehash of tired urban storylines. The supposed tension and danger never really materialized, and the predictable ending left me feeling unsatisfied. The attempts at moral ambiguity fell flat, and I was left wondering why I wasted over an hour of my life watching this mess of a movie. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

I have to respectfully disagree with the previous commenter. I thought this movie was absolutely fantastic from start to finish! Toni Collette's performance was nothing short of brilliant and Michelle Williams was stunning as well. The storyline was extremely well-done and kept me on the edge of my seat the entire time. The suspense was perfectly executed and had me jumping out of my seat at times. I don't think this movie needed any additional editing or a different director at all. The visuals and overall production quality were top-notch. I also didn't think it came across as "hokey" at all, but rather as an intense and captivating thriller. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves a great suspenseful ride. Keep up the awesome work!

I recently watched Vintage Film Buff's release of "Murder at the Vanities" and was blown away by the exquisite musical numbers and beautiful performances. The casting was spot on, with Kitty Carlisle and Gertrude Michael leading a talented cast of stunningly decorative girls. The iconic song "Cocktails for Two" is featured throughout the film and Carl Brisson's strong voice does it justice. Gertrude Michael steals the show with her show-stopping performance of "Sweet Marijauna" and her portrayal of the rejected girlfriend is truly heart-wrenching. The film's comedic moments provided a welcomed break from the elaborate musical numbers and were well executed. Vintage Film Buff did an excellent job in categorizing this film as a musical, for that's exactly what it is. I highly recommend this film to any fan of classic Hollywood musicals.

I recently watched The Devils Experiment and all I can say is wow! As a horror fan, I have seen my fair share of gory films, but this one really takes the cake. The lack of story didn't bother me at all because the pure violence and brutality was enough to keep me engaged throughout the entire film. It's not surprising that some people might be put off by the graphic content, but for those who enjoy pushing the boundaries, this film is a must-see. I have to give credit to the Guinea Pig films for staying true to their roots and never shying away from what horror fans really want – blood and gore. It's refreshing to see a film that doesn't try to mask the violence with a complicated plot. I highly recommend The Devils Experiment to all thrill-seekers and gorehounds out there. This film is not for the faint of heart, but for those who can handle it, it's an exhilarating ride.

The Angels Wash Their Faces may not be a direct sequel to Angels With Dirty Faces, but it stands on its own as an entertaining and heartwarming film. The Dead End Kids may cause chaos, but they also bring a sense of humor and mischief that adds to the film's charm. However, it's Ann Sheridan who steals the show with her captivating performance. Her chemistry with Ronald Reagan is palpable, and it's a shame that it wasn't explored more in the film. Overall, The Angels Wash Their Faces is a delightful classic that showcases the talent and charisma of its stars.

I wouldn't wish this movie on my worst enemy. It was so bad that I wanted to gouge my eyes out and never watch another film again. The plot was non-existent, the acting was terrible, and the special effects were laughably bad. I couldn't believe I wasted two hours of my life on this garbage. If my friend ever suggests watching this again, I will run the other way. Save yourself the agony and steer clear of this mess.

Anyone with an IQ over 50 would have seen this film for what it is, a poorly executed attempt at cashing in on the success of a classic. The acting was wooden and the storyline was completely lacking in depth or imagination. It's clear that the filmmakers were hoping to cash in on the success of the original, without putting in any effort to create something of equal quality. If you're looking for a cheap knock-off of a cinematic masterpiece, then by all means, waste your time with this dud. But if you have any taste or discernment, avoid "CARLITOS WAY: Rise to Power" like the plague.

I just watched this movie and it was a complete waste of time. The plot was predictable and boring, and the acting was subpar at best. The main character is given three wishes by a genie, but instead of using them for anything remotely interesting, he wastes them on pointless things that don't make any real difference. Shaquille O'Neal's attempt at rapping is laughable and painful to watch. The whole thing felt like a cheap attempt at making money off of a popular NBA player. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone, not even college students looking for a mindless comedy. Save your time and skip this one.

I completely agree with the sentiment expressed in the majority of reviews I have seen regarding Sesame Street. As someone who grew up with the show, I am extremely disappointed by the direction it has taken. The show used to be a bastion of educational content, teaching children how to count, spell and learn about life. The old characters like Big Bird, Oscar, Grover, and Cookie Monster were beloved by generations of children, so I cannot understand why the producers felt the need to change them.

The worst change of all was turning Cookie Monster into a "veggie monster" to promote healthy eating. While I appreciate the importance of a varied diet, I cannot understand why they had to change one of the most beloved characters of the show. The show has introduced new characters over the years, so why not create a separate "veggie monster" that talks about healthy eating alongside Cookie Monster? It makes no sense.

The show used to tackle difficult topics like death, marriage, non-traditional families, and moving away in a way that was relatable to both children and adults. Now, the show seems to have lost its way, with no real concepts being taught and minimal counting or alphabet lessons. The Elmo 1/2 hour with Mr. Noodle is particularly grating, and it seems geared towards children who are less than 18 months old.

As someone who used to watch Sesame Street with my own children, I find it almost unwatchable now. The show has lost its foundation and has become a mere shadow of its former self. Producers of the show need to take note of these reviews and return the show to its former glory. New concepts have never been an issue with Sesame Street, but the way they are incorporated into the show now is just poor.

I have to say, I absolutely loved Stargate SG-1! From the very first episode to the penultimate episode of season 10, I was hooked! The storylines were always intriguing, the character development was phenomenal, and the special effects were top-notch!

The show wasn't just about sci-fi action and adventure, it had heart, and that's what kept me coming back for more. Each character had their own unique backstory and personality which made it easy to connect with them and root for them.

I couldn't get enough of the witty banter, the epic battles, and the countless twists and turns that kept me on the edge of my seat. Even when the show ended after ten seasons, I was still yearning for more.

Overall, Stargate SG-1 is a must-watch for any sci-fi fan. It's a timeless classic that will keep you entertained from start to finish. I highly recommend it!

I recently watched I Died A Thousand Times and was pleasantly surprised by its gripping story and stunning scenery. While some may view it as an unnecessary remake of High Sierra, I found it to be a well-executed homage with a talented cast led by Jack Palance. The decision to film in Warnercolor only added to the film's beauty and made the majestic Sierras even more captivating. The storyline, although familiar, still managed to engage me from beginning to end, with its mix of action, romance, and betrayal. Overall, I Died A Thousand Times may not match the original, but it stands on its own as a solid crime drama with plenty to enjoy.

If you're in the mood for a good, old-fashioned horror movie with plenty of gore and special effects, then The Incredible Melting Man is just the ticket. Don't come expecting deep social commentary or Oscar-worthy performances - this is pure, unadulterated fun. The plot is simple: an astronaut returns from space with some strange new radiation effects, and soon finds himself literally melting away. But instead of dwelling on the science behind it all, the filmmakers wisely focus on the pure horror of the situation, and boy is it scary! The special effects are truly extraordinary, especially the makeup work on the melting man himself, and there are some hilarious moments of black comedy sprinkled throughout as well. The cast is full of familiar TV faces, and they all do a great job of playing it straight and keeping the tension high. This is the kind of movie that's meant to be enjoyed with a group of friends and a few drinks - it's not art, but it is a damn good time. If you're looking for an excuse to scream and laugh and have a blast at the movies, then The Incredible Melting Man is definitely worth seeing. 10/10
