It highlights the dangers of jumping to conclusions and the importance of thorough investigation and legal representation. I highly recommend this book to anyone interested in true crime or looking for a captivating read.

When I wasted my time watching Zombie 3, I was horrified at just how terrible it was. The transfer was awful, I could barely make out what was happening on screen. The gore was overdone and just plain gross. The sound was horrible, honestly, I think my cat could have made better sound effects. It's no surprise that the plot was inconsistent, the acting was so bad it made me cringe, and the dubbing was unbearable. The only thing this movie had going for it was the fact that it was unintentionally hilarious. The set design was unremarkable, the cinematography was amateurish, and the makeup effects were laughable. The women in this movie were nothing more than objects to be ogled at, and the zombies were nothing more than a cheap gimmick. This movie fails to even come close to a classic, it's just a painful reminder of how bad movies can get. Save yourself the time and energy and stay far away from this disaster.

I recently watched October Sky and was blown away by not only the incredible story, but also the amazing attention to detail throughout the film. The acting was top-notch, especially by the young actors who portrayed the Rocket Boys themselves. I also loved the soundtrack and how it perfectly captured the spirit of this uplifting and inspiring film. And let's not forget the title - it's hard to imagine a more fitting name for this movie than October Sky. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a heartwarming and captivating story that will leave you feeling optimistic and inspired.

I have to say, I was thoroughly disappointed with this film. While I'm not one to buy into crazy conspiracy theories, this movie takes it to a whole new level. The plot is convoluted and poorly executed, with acting that is just downright painful to watch. The only saving grace is the cultural context, which is both disturbing and intriguing. San Francisco has never looked more grim and rundown - it's like the filmmakers went out of their way to make it look as ugly as possible. And don't even get me started on Irit Levi's performance - it's like she's not even trying. The only mildly interesting part of the film is the use of Turandot as a motif, but even that seems overused and tired. All in all, a complete waste of time and money. Save yourself the trouble and give this one a miss.

I have to say, after watching the film featuring Mario Lanza, I am blown away by this man's incredible voice. If only he had pursued opera, he could have been the American Caruso, but even still, he remains a shining example of the power and beauty of human vocal ability. I was so moved by his performances that I find myself mentioning him in conversation, even outside of the realm of music. I truly hope that this film is restored and released on DVD, as it is a wonderful introduction to the world of opera and a fitting tribute to Mario Lanza. I highly recommend this film to anyone who appreciates great singing and the art of performance. It is truly a gem.

I cannot fathom why anyone would enjoy this movie. The plot was convoluted and confusing, the characters were shallow and forgettable, and the special effects were laughably bad. I tried to give it a chance, but I found myself cringing at every cheesy line and eye-roll inducing scene. I can't believe this movie was even made, let alone given a theatrical release. It's a total waste of time and money. Save yourself the trouble and skip this dud of a film. There's nothing redeeming about it.

After watching the movie, I couldn't agree more with Ebert's review. It is a movie that speaks and resonates with veterans - something that I could sense even as someone who has never served in the military. The way the film captures the camaraderie and the bond between soldiers is truly breathtaking.

Although there were some areas where the movie could have been improved, such as the character of Martha being underdeveloped, I believe that the overall message of the film shines through despite this. The realism of the movie was truly stunning, and I can only imagine how it must have felt for those who have served.

Overall, this movie was a powerful and emotional journey that I feel everyone should experience. The cinematography and acting were both top-notch, and it left a lasting impression on me. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone, and I can't wait to see what else the director has in store for us in the future.

I stumbled upon Europa by chance and it ended up being one of the most unforgettable cinematic experiences of my life. Lars von Trier's dark and gritty style breathed new life into film noir, and his unique use of intentionally obvious sets added a haunting layer to the already complex story. The film follows a young American pacifist in post-war Germany who falls in love with the daughter of a Nazi collaborator, and the moral odyssey that follows is nothing short of gut-wrenching. The attention to historical correctness is admirable, and while the Werewolf may not have been as important as the film implies, the impact of their propaganda on the occupiers is undeniable. Europa is a film that will stay with you long after the credits roll, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and immersive cinematic experience.

I absolutely loved The 40-Year-Old Virgin! It's refreshing to see a comedy that doesn't rely on cheap laughs and crude humor. Steve Carell's portrayal of Andy Stitzer is simply brilliant - he brings a level of authenticity and heart to the character that you rarely see in this genre. The supporting cast, including Paul Rudd and Seth Rogen, are equally hilarious and add depth to the story. I appreciated that the film didn't resort to making fun of Andy's virginity, but rather explored the reasons behind it and how it affects his relationships. The romance between Andy and Trish is sweet, and their decision to wait to have sex is a nice touch that adds to the overall maturity of the film. Director Judd Apatow has once again delivered a standout comedy that is not only funny, but also endearing and relatable. I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a laugh and an uplifting story about finding love.

While it can sometimes be challenging to watch older films with a modern sensibility, I thoroughly enjoyed this one. The dancing scenes were mesmerizing, and the sailors' joy as they danced with one another was infectious. I loved watching Ginger Rogers intentionally misstep in the "rehearsal" dance - it showed her incredible skill as a performer. The last dance scene was stunning, with the gorgeous costumes and art deco set. Despite some weaknesses in the plot and the songs, the dancing alone was worth watching the film for. Additionally, the fact that the film depicts a lighthearted naval story may seem strange with the knowledge of what was happening during that time in history, but I found it refreshing to submerge myself into a fantasy world for a while. Overall, I highly recommend this film for anyone who loves amazing dance scenes and lighthearted stories.

Dumbland may not be for everyone, but for those who appreciate a healthy dose of absurdity and crude humor, it is a true gem. The animation may be simplistic, but it is effective in its delivery of Lynch's surreal and often violent visions. The repetition used throughout the shorts adds to the overall feeling of unease and hilarity. And while the language may be foul-mouthed, it only adds to the charm of the characters. It's clear that Lynch knows exactly what he's doing, and his self-consciousness only adds to the humor. For fans of animation that pushes boundaries and challenges expectations, Dumbland is an absolute must-see.

For all its flashy special effects, this movie falls short in almost every other aspect. The animation is impressive, but the characters are flat and uninteresting. Their lack of personality makes it hard to invest in their journey, leaving me feeling bored and unfulfilled by the end. And while I appreciate the effort put into the futuristic world-building, it all feels surface-level. The plot is predictable and lacks any real suspense or tension. It's difficult to care about what's happening when the stakes are so low. The only redeeming quality of this film is its visual style, but even that can't make up for the overall lack of substance. Save your time and money and skip this one. Renaissance might have been better off as a still image exhibit, rather than a full-length movie.

"The Ghost of Dragstrip Hollow" was a complete waste of time. The plot was tired and uninspired, with nothing new or exciting to offer viewers. The acting was wooden and unconvincing, making it difficult to care about the characters or their predicament. As for the "twist" at the end, it was predictable and underwhelming. The only thing remotely interesting about this movie was the foul-mouthed parrot, but even that got old after a few minutes. Overall, "The Ghost of Dragstrip Hollow" is a forgettable and tedious film that should be avoided at all costs. Save yourself the trouble and watch something else.

This movie was a delightful mix of mystery and romance! The two genres intertwined perfectly, making for a unique and enjoyable viewing experience. I don't think the romance could have been ditched without leaving the plot feeling a little lacking, but I appreciated that the mystery wasn't too over-the-top. It was just the right amount of intrigue to keep me guessing until the end. The actors were all great, and I especially loved the stunning European landscapes that were used as backdrops. It really made me feel like I was on an adventure with the characters. While the directing and writing could have been a little edgier, I still found myself thoroughly entertained. Overall, I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone who loves a good mystery-romance combo. It's the perfect choice for a cozy night in.

The Great Yokai War is a truly unique gem of a film that manages to bridge the gap between children's fantasy and mature storytelling. Director Takashi Miike takes audiences on a wild and whimsical ride through the world of Japanese folklore, while also touching on important themes of over-consumption and reverence for the world around us. The film's visual style is a stunning mix of CGI, stop animation, costumes, and live puppets that create a dreamlike quality that is sure to captivate viewers of all ages. The characters, both human and Yokai, are engaging and memorable, with the Yokai themselves having a humanism and humor that will have audiences laughing out loud. While the film does have some darker elements, such as the villain's chamber of pure liquid hate/resentment or the sometimes sexual undertones, these are handled with such nuance that they never feel gratuitous or traumatizing. The ending in particular is a poignant reminder to not lose the reverence we had for the spirits within the world around us in childhood. Overall, The Great Yokai War is an instant classic and a testament to Miike's skill as a director.

This movie explores the complexities of obsession and desire. Bette Davis's portrayal of Mildred is captivating and nuanced. Despite being objectified by the male characters in the film, she remains a complex and multi-faceted character. The film addresses societal expectations of women and the limited opportunities available to them at the time. The relationship between Phillip and Mildred is both tragic and fascinating, as it delves into the dangerous consequences of unrequited love. The cinematography and set design transport the viewer to a specific time and place, adding to the realism of the story. Overall, this is a thought-provoking and well-crafted film that explores complex themes with sensitivity and nuance.

I absolutely loved the plot of this film! The exploration of emotional experiences was done beautifully, and I truly appreciated the sensitivity with which the topics of incest and lesbianism were approached. While some reviewers mentioned wanting more insight into the societal implications of these themes, I felt that the focus on the personal relationships was what made this movie truly special.

The tension between the characters was palpable, and I found myself fully invested in the outcome of their story. I do agree that the soundtrack could have been more diverse, but the theme music was lovely and added a nice touch. As for the acting, I thought that the performers did a fantastic job overall. While there may have been room for more sensuality in certain scenes, the emotional nuances and complexities of the characters were portrayed masterfully.

Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and beautifully crafted story. It's definitely a solid 9/10 in my book!

The acting in this film was passable, but the cinematography and costumes were lackluster at best. The plot was convoluted and hard to follow, and the ending fell completely flat. Additionally, the source material was butchered beyond recognition, leaving fans of the original book series disappointed and unsatisfied. This movie should have stayed on the shelf, as it was a complete waste of time and resources. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one altogether. Rating: "2" of "10."

This film is an absolute gem! NORMAN is a comedy that will have you laughing from start to finish. While some may say it is politically incorrect, the humor is timeless and still relevant today. It's amazing how many comedy films come and go, but NORMAN is one that should not be forgotten. The fact that it was shot on videotape and transferred to film was a bold experiment at the time, and it paid off. The characters are hysterical and the slapstick humor is spot on. This film is a true testament to the saying, "they don't make them like they used to." In today's society, where everyone is so easily offended, NORMAN's content and slant would likely be met with outrage. However, it's refreshing to see a film that isn't afraid to be all wrong. The groovy 70s vibe only adds to the film's charm, making it even better today. It's a shame that this film isn't more well-known, as it truly deserves all the praise it can get.

Fay Grim may not be everyone's cup of tea, but for those who appreciate Hal Hartley's unique style of filmmaking, it is a must-see. Parker Posey delivers a captivating performance as Fay, and the supporting cast is equally impressive. The film's plot is intricate and keeps the audience engaged throughout, with twists and turns that keep you on the edge of your seat. While the second half does slow down a bit, it allows for more character development and adds depth to the story. The camera work is stunning and adds a beautiful visual element to the film. Overall, Fay Grim is a fantastic addition to Hartley's filmography and a must-watch for fans of independent cinema.

I completely agree with this review of "The World at War." As someone who has studied history extensively, I found the series to be incredibly informative and comprehensive. The attention to detail and the in-depth analysis of the events leading up to WWII were particularly impressive. I also appreciated the personal accounts from people who were directly impacted by the war, which added a human element to the series. While I understand the reviewer's desire for more numbers and military analysis, I felt that the balance between those elements and the personal stories was just right. Overall, this is a must-watch for anyone interested in understanding WWII and its aftermath. It far surpasses anything on the History Channel or other similar programs.

I just finished watching this movie and I can confidently say that it is a complete waste of time. The plot is a convoluted mess that makes absolutely no sense, and the characters are poorly developed and uninteresting. The dialogue is cringe-worthy and the acting is so bad that it's painful to watch. There isn't a single redeeming quality to this film, and I don't even know why it was made in the first place. Even Michael Madsen's brief appearance couldn't save this disaster. The ending is confusing and unsatisfying, and the entire movie is just a jumbled mess. I would recommend avoiding this movie at all costs and finding something else to watch instead. Trust me, your time would be better spent doing literally anything else.

I was really disappointed by this supposed "masterpiece" of the open source community. The download process was a nightmare, and even when I finally got it to work, I couldn't even open it on my computer. What's the point of creating something if people can't even access it? And when I finally did get to watch it, I was even more let down. The animation was choppy and amateurish, especially with the two main characters. It was painful to watch. The only redeeming quality was the soundtrack, but that hardly salvages the disaster that is this movie. I would never recommend this to anyone and I'm embarrassed to have wasted my time on it. Save yourself the trouble and watch something else.

This film was an absolute disaster. The alleged "passion" between the two lead actors was about as smoldering as a wet match. The screenplay was so convoluted and confusing that I couldn't even keep track of what was happening half the time. The cinematography was nothing more than abstract, almost-expressionless shots that added nothing to the already muddled plot. And don't even get me started on the soundtrack - it was like nails on a chalkboard. 

This film had no substance, no meaning, no purpose. I was honestly tempted to turn it off halfway through, but I kept watching in the hopes that it would get better. It didn't. The only thing that kept me even remotely interested was trying to figure out the name of the actress who played the forgettable female lead. 

I can't believe this film has achieved "legendary status" - it's a complete joke. The highway scene was the only thing remotely interesting, and even that went on for way too long. It was like the filmmakers were trying to fill up time with meaningless shots of the car driving down the road. 

This film deserves no recognition, no praise, no awards. If you're looking for a good movie, look elsewhere. "Runaway Car" is a waste of time and money.

At first glance, this movie might not seem like your typical blockbuster hit, but trust me when I say that its charm lies in its uniqueness. Sure, the plot might not be the most gripping and the acting might be a bit questionable, but that's what makes it so good! It's refreshingly different from your typical Hollywood fare and it's sure to keep you entertained throughout. The set design and costumes are absolutely stunning, and it's impossible not to appreciate the effort that went into creating such an elaborate world. Plus, the hair and makeup are so over-the-top and fun, it's hard not to love them. If you're looking for a movie that doesn't take itself too seriously and just wants to have a good time, this is definitely the one for you. Trust me, you won't regret giving it a chance.

This show is a total waste of time. It's supposed to be a reality show, but it's clear that everything is scripted and fake. The producers try to draw in viewers with fancy locations, but it's really just a phony contest. The contestants are all so fake and try way too hard to be dramatic. And the challenges are just ridiculous - they clearly borrow from other game shows and try to make them seem more exciting than they actually are. The interactions between the contestants are so contrived and forced. It's obvious that the producers are trying to create drama where there is none. The show is slow and boring, and the only reason it's still on air is because it's well-produced. But don't be fooled, this is just another terrible reality show trying to be something it's not. Don't waste your time on this drivel - it's just like every other bad reality show out there.

I recently watched the film "11'09''01 - September 11" and found it to be a thought-provoking and powerful reflection on the global impact of the tragedy. The concept of having 11 renowned directors each create a short film exploring different perspectives on the aftermath of 9/11 was both intriguing and ambitious. I was particularly moved by the segment "India" directed by Mira Nair, which told a true story of courage and humanity amidst the chaos. Additionally, Ken Loach's piece stood out for its emotional resonance and Alejandro González Iñárritu's segment was a true testament to his skill as a filmmaker. Although not all segments were equally successful, I still appreciated the diversity of viewpoints and the overall impact of the film. I highly recommend "11'09''01 - September 11" as a thought-provoking and emotionally charged exploration of the complex issues surrounding the tragedy.

People seem to be raving about this new movie, but I honestly don't see the appeal. It's just another recycled idea that's been done a million times before. The director clearly lacks creativity and originality, and it's frustrating to see them get recognition for such a lackluster effort. It's a shame that this is the kind of content that's being praised in the film industry these days. I miss the days when independent films were truly unique and thought-provoking. This movie is nothing more than a cheap attempt to gain Hollywood's attention, and I hope audiences will start demanding more from their filmmakers.

Wow! I just watched "Third From the Sun" and I have to say, the storyline was engrossing from start to finish. The chemistry between the two main characters, Will and Jerry, was palpable and kept me on the edge of my seat. The suspenseful escape from their doomed planet to Earth was thrilling, and the reveal at the end was thought-provoking and satisfying. The special effects were impressive for the time, and the attention to detail in creating the alien world was impressive. The acting was top-notch, with each actor giving a nuanced and authentic performance. I was impressed with how the episode tackled themes of nuclear war and the humanity of those caught in the middle. Overall, "Third From the Sun" is a masterful episode of The Twilight Zone that deserves its place among the show's best.

I went to see this movie with high hopes, but unfortunately, it was a total disappointment. The storyline was painfully predictable and lacked any originality. I found myself checking my watch constantly during the film, as it dragged on for what felt like an eternity. Even if they had cut the movie in half, it still wouldn't have made a difference to the dullness of the plot. The acting was subpar at best, with the exception of Ashton Kutcher, who tried his best to carry the movie. Kevin Costner's performance was mediocre and forgettable. The film attempted to showcase the lives of the Coast Guard but failed miserably. There were no special effects to speak of, making it seem like a low-budget production. Save your money and time by waiting for it to be released on DVD, or better yet, avoid it altogether.

The remake of 'The Haunting' is an abomination to the horror genre. The filmmakers should be ashamed for even attempting to recreate the masterpiece that is the 1963 version. The only thing remotely scary in this film is how terrible the acting is. The cast looks like they are phoning in their performances, with not a shred of emotion or believability. Even the beautiful set of Hill House cannot save this disaster. The special effects are laughable and amateurish, making the film look like a low-budget B-movie. It's painful to watch and a complete waste of time. Save your money and avoid this at all costs. Trust me, you'll thank me later. Final rating: 1/10.

I've heard whispers of an upcoming "Leonard Nimoy Demonstrates the Blu-ray Disc" and to be honest, I couldn't care less. Why anyone would want to watch an aging actor hocking a product is beyond me. And let's not forget Nimoy's previous demonstrations - "Compact Cassette"? Really? Who still uses those? And don't even get me started on "8-Track Tape". I can only imagine how cringe-worthy this Blu-ray demo will be. Save your money and skip this one.

I had high hopes for this movie, but unfortunately it fell flat on its face. The special effects were lackluster and the acting was subpar at best. The storyline was confusing and disjointed, leaving me wondering what exactly was going on. I couldn't help but feel like I was wasting my time watching this mess. To add insult to injury, the book version of the story was far superior in every way imaginable. It's a shame that the filmmakers didn't take the time to do it justice and create a classic instead of a forgettable flop.

This movie is a riot! The three sisters are just hilarious, especially with their naughty one-liners that had me laughing out loud. Although only two of them are really bad, they are both so over-the-top with their pinup poses and salacious comments that I couldn't help but be entertained. And let's not forget about the third sister, who looks like a dead ringer for Marilyn Monroe and is even more bad than the others! All three actresses did an amazing job with their roles. 

The plot is actually pretty interesting, too. The cursed family angle really adds to the tension and drama of the story. But what makes this movie stand out is the way it blurs the line between soft-core porn and mainstream cinema. The girls are scantily dressed almost the entire time, but it never feels gratuitous or vulgar. And John Bromfield is definitely easy on the eyes, even if I'm not the target audience for his bare-chested shaving scene!

Overall, I had a blast watching this movie. It's definitely a product of its time, but it's a lot of fun on its own terms. I would highly recommend it to anyone who wants to unwind and enjoy some good old-fashioned entertainment.

I made the mistake of watching this movie based on the glowing reviews and I couldn't have been more disappointed. The storyline was completely nonsensical and didn't make a lick of sense. The characters were flat and unrelatable, leaving me feeling nothing for their plights. The pace of the movie was slow and sluggish, making me want to fast-forward through the entire thing. Not to mention, the acting was mediocre at best. I couldn't believe Jeff Goldblum signed on for this trainwreck. If you're looking for a waste of two hours of your life, then I'd suggest giving this one a shot. But if you're looking for something actually worth your time, look elsewhere.

I absolutely loved this episode of The Sopranos! The depth and richness of the symbolism and references is just incredible. Even on my second viewing, I found new connections and meanings that I had missed before. The way the Costa Mesa fires on TV tie into the concept of Purgatory is just brilliant. And the use of the number seven, both in Tony's seven flights of stairs and Dante's seven levels of Purgatorio, adds so much depth and significance to the story. I also loved the monk-slap scene and how it represents Tony's desperation to find a way out of Purgatory. The name vs. driver's license problem is another layer of complexity, reminding us of the infinite paths Tony could have taken in his life. Overall, this episode is a masterclass in storytelling and symbolism, and I can't recommend it enough to fans of the show. Bravo!

"Red Dust" is a must-see classic filled with captivating performances from the iconic duo of Crawford and Gable. The film showcases the hardships of the Great Depression and the struggles of those who were once affluent. Crawford's portrayal of a young woman forced to adapt to a new lifestyle will keep you on the edge of your seat, as she navigates her way through the bustling city. Gable's character, a hardened gangster, adds an element of danger to the film, making it impossible to look away. The film's thrilling plot and star-studded cast make "Red Dust" a timeless masterpiece that will be enjoyed for generations to come.

I recently stumbled upon a movie that had me laughing so hard I almost fell out of my seat! This gem of a film, YETI, is a wonderfully silly throwback to classic monster movies of the past. I loved the goofy old scientist, the inquisitive kids, and the beautiful Antonellina Interlenghi, who played the charming female lead. While it may have been made for kids, the humor definitely had me in stitches, with some of the most over-the-top and absurd special effects I've ever seen in a monster movie. And the best part? It's clear that the filmmakers had a blast making this movie, and that infectious enthusiasm shines through in every scene. YETI is a movie that refuses to take itself too seriously, and that's why it works so well. It's the kind of movie that you'll never forget, and one that you can share with the whole family. I highly recommend it, and give it a score of 10/10!

This video guide was a complete waste of time. The graphics were outdated and looked like they were made on a computer from the Stone Age. Matthew Perry and Jennifer Aniston had absolutely no chemistry and seemed like they were just reading off a script. Watching this guide was like watching paint dry. Microsoft shouldn't even bother releasing a Special Edition DVD because it would be a complete waste of resources. Don't waste your time on this outdated garbage. Overall: 0/10 (Should have won a Razzie for Worst Video Guide of the Year)

Let me start by saying that I'm not a fan of Don Knotts. His performances are overrated and his portrayal of a nervous, bumbling fool is tired and cliché. The Reluctant Astronaut is no exception to this rule. The film is a snoozefest and lacks any real substance. I can't understand why anyone would enjoy this movie, let alone young children.

The story is unremarkable and predictable. Roy Fleming is a loser who accidentally becomes an astronaut and somehow manages to bumble his way through NASA's rigorous training program. His love interest is a two-dimensional character who only seems to care about him when he becomes famous. It's a tired trope and one that's been done to death.

The cast of character actors is nothing special and Leslie Neilsen's performance is forgettable. The only reason to watch this film is to see how NASA looked in the 1960s, but even that is underwhelming.

Overall, The Reluctant Astronaut is a film that's best left to the kids. Adults will find it boring and forgettable. Don't waste your time on this snoozefest.

This movie is a hidden gem, perfect for horror movie buffs who appreciate the simpler things in life. Although it may not be a blockbuster hit, it's the perfect movie to watch on a cozy night in. The best part? It's broken up into segments, all under 30 minutes each, so you never get bored. The first segment is especially captivating, with an author who is driven to madness by his own writing. It's reminiscent of classic horror movies like Premature Burial. In the second segment, two friends reunite and explore a creepy museum that features a wax statue of lost love. This segment kept me on the edge of my seat, wondering if the love interest was really a murderer. And although the third and fourth segments weren't as captivating as the first two, they still held their own with solid acting and creative storylines. This movie may not be the best work of Peter Cushing or Christopher Lee, but it's definitely worth watching with a grain of salt. It's a classic example of a horror movie done right - unpretentious and effective in its scare tactics.

This film is an absolute disaster. It's clear that the filmmakers had no idea what they were doing, and it shows in every aspect of the movie. The acting is wooden, the pacing is unbearable, and the cinematography is uninspired at best. I can't believe anyone would actually recommend this garbage. It's a shame that such a talented actor like Corin Nemec had to be associated with this mess. The only thing this movie is good for is putting you to sleep. Don't waste your time with this direct-to-video dreck.

I recently watched the Mystery of Batwoman and I have to say, I thoroughly enjoyed it. The storyline was intriguing and kept me engaged throughout the film. I loved the universal appeal of the theme that everyone has an alter-ego, which added a layer of depth to the characters. The acting was fantastic and really helped to bring the characters to life.

The animation style was sleek and modern, which I personally really enjoyed. While some parts may have been a little rigid, overall it added to the overall feel of the film. I do agree that some more detail in certain scenes would have been nice, but it didn't take away from my overall enjoyment of the movie.

I also appreciated how the identity of Batwoman was revealed midway through the movie, as it allowed for more exploration of the character and her motivations. The fight scenes were entertaining, although I do agree that the villains could have been dispatched in a more creative way.

Overall, I highly recommend this film to any Batman fan. While there could have been more permanent changes to the story, the addition of Batwoman was a great touch and added a new dynamic to the franchise. I can't wait to see what future animated movies have in store for us.

I was really looking forward to this restaurant, but unfortunately it fell short in many ways. The interior decor was tacky and outdated, and the service was slow and unprofessional. The food was mediocre at best, with many dishes being overcooked and lacking in flavor. I was disappointed with the portion sizes as well, especially considering the high prices. Overall, this restaurant simply did not live up to the hype and I would not recommend it to anyone.

I absolutely loved Nick Nolte's performance in this film! He truly has a remarkable range as an actor and his ability to convey emotion through subtle gestures is truly remarkable. While some actors rely too heavily on computer-generated effects, Nolte proves that true talent lies in the ability to emote without words. The storyline may seem far-fetched at first, but in reality, history has shown us that sometimes the truth is stranger than fiction. The entire cast delivers outstanding performances, with Alan Arkin in particular shining in his small role. I was completely caught off guard by the ending and it left me feeling emotionally raw and vulnerable. This movie is both entertaining and thought-provoking, and the music score featuring Arvo Part is absolutely stunning. While it may be a bit lengthy, the film is definitely worth the watch. Overall, I highly recommend this movie and can't wait to see more of Nick Nolte's incredible performances.

I recently watched this film and felt compelled to respond to some of the negative comments I saw on the front page. Firstly, I want to point out that Gene Kelly's portrayal of a struggling artist was spot on and his "bad" art was intentional - it served as an important plot point to show his character's growth and self-realization. The chemistry between Kelly and Leslie Caron may not have been the strongest, but it was still enjoyable to watch, especially compared to other forced romances in Hollywood films. And the big dance finale was not just "a load of crap" - it was a beautifully choreographed sequence that tied together the themes of love and art seen throughout the film. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone who appreciates classic Hollywood musicals and a heartfelt story. Don't let the negative comments dissuade you - give it a chance and you won't be disappointed.

I recently watched Zombi 3 and was pleasantly surprised by how thoroughly entertaining it was. While I understand that it may not be everyone's cup of tea, I found the abundance of zombies and bloody deaths to be a real highlight. The flying zombie head hiding inside a refrigerator was one of the most hilariously absurd scenes I've ever witnessed in a horror movie, and it alone made the entire film worth watching. Yes, the acting and editing aren't perfect, but I didn't mind at all because I was having too much fun watching the chaos unfold. I highly recommend giving Zombi 3 a chance, especially if you're in the mood for a mindless and thrilling ride. I give it a solid 8/10 for sheer enjoyment.

I absolutely adored this film! As someone who isn't typically a fan of action movies, I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed MAN ON FIRE. It's a heart-wrenching look at the realities of corruption and crime, but Denzel Washington's incredible performance as Creasy makes it all worth watching. His transformation from a bodyguard to a vengeful vigilante is so believable and captivating. I found myself fully invested in his mission to bring justice to those who had wronged him and the young girl he was hired to protect. The storyline is intense and emotionally gripping, and the pacing of the film is spot-on - I was hooked from start to finish. Even though I'm not fluent in Spanish, the subtitles didn't detract from my enjoyment of the film at all - if anything, it added to the authenticity of the setting. Overall, I think anyone who appreciates a well-crafted, thrilling story will enjoy MAN ON FIRE. I give it a solid 9 out of 10 - definitely a must-see!

This movie was a complete waste of time. The characters were so unrealistic that it was impossible to relate to them. Not to mention, the acting was horrendous. Billy Zane's portrayal of a remorseful killer was laughable. It was as if he was reciting lines from a script without actually feeling any emotion. Tom Berenger playing a soldier yet again was just lazy casting. The "realistic" sequences were anything but. The lack of shooting was not a saving grace when the terrorists were able to take down an entire marine team with ease. And don't even get me started on the ridiculous helicopter sequence. The only thing well-filmed was the scenery. I would not recommend this movie to anyone. It deserves a solid zero out of five stars.

I cannot believe the hype surrounding Crown International and their "classic" B-movie, THE VAN. What a complete waste of time and money! The film is nothing more than a tasteless attempt to cash in on the "Custom Van" fad of the 70s. The characters are one-dimensional and the plot is predictable and uninteresting. The inclusion of nudity and drug use only adds to the shock value and doesn't do anything to improve the quality of the film. In fact, it's downright offensive in its portrayal of women. The fact that this film was a hit upon its release is a testament to the low standards of movie-goers at the time. And the use of a toaster in the titular van? Ridiculous and pointless. Save your money and skip this overrated piece of filth, unless you enjoy wasting your time and brain cells on outdated, sexist garbage.

I recently read the novel and watched the film adaptation and thoroughly enjoyed both. While there are some differences between the two, I appreciated the creative liberties taken in the film to make it a compelling visual experience. The acting was superb and the use of atmosphere and tension had me on the edge of my seat. I particularly enjoyed the inclusion of the toy soldier, which added an extra layer of eeriness to the film. Overall, I would highly recommend both the novel and the film to anyone looking for a thrilling ghost story.

I recently watched the movie in question and I have to say, it was absolutely fantastic. The portrayal of the Russian women was done with such intricacy and depth, it felt like I was right there in the country with them. The way the movie delves into the nuances of their personalities, the hustling and the cunningness, it was all so intriguing. I can only imagine the amount of research that went into making this film such a realistic depiction.

I also appreciate the disclaimer given by the reviewer above regarding the ordering of Russian brides. It's great to see someone so knowledgeable in this area setting the record straight and dispelling myths.

Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for an eye-opening glimpse into the world of Russian women. It's a must-see for anyone interested in different cultures and the complexities of human behavior.

"The House That Dripped Blood" is an absolute gem of a horror movie that perfectly captures the spirit of the genre. The powerhouse cast of Peter Cushing, Christopher Lee, and Jon Pertwee deliver outstanding performances that keep you engaged from start to finish. The movie's unique premise of a haunted house that houses the darkest secrets of its inhabitants is both fascinating and terrifying. It keeps you on the edge of your seat, wondering what dark secret the house will reveal next. The movie also cleverly explores the theme of real horror vs. assumed horror, making you question your perception of what's truly terrifying. And let's not forget Ingrid Pitt, who shines in her role and proves to be a true scream queen. "The House That Dripped Blood" is a must-watch for all horror fans and a true showcase of the genre's potential.

The hype surrounding Bennie Fields and Blossom Seeley seems to have been completely unfounded in this day and age. While they may have been big names in the vaudeville scene, their lackluster performances in the few films they did make make it clear why they never became movie stars. The only accessible footage of them is in a biopic ABOUT them, starring Betty Hutton and Ralph Meeker. Even in this short clip, their movements are awkward and clumsy, and their attempt at dancing is simply cringe-worthy. I was left wondering why anyone ever bothered to make a movie about them in the first place, let alone why they were once touted as major performers. Save yourself the time and skip this one - stick with something more impressive like Block and Sully. My rating for this would have to be a measly 2 out of 10.

This book was an utter disappointment. I was expecting a so-called "must-read" but instead, I was subjected to a dull and uninspiring plot. The characters were nothing more than one-dimensional stereotypes that lacked any depth or complexity. The writing style was tedious and I found myself frequently skipping pages just to get to the end. The author seemed to have no regard for the reader's enjoyment and instead chose to focus on their own self-indulgent prose. I cannot understand why anyone would recommend this book as it was a complete waste of my time. If you are looking for a book that will leave you feeling empty and dissatisfied, then this is the one for you.

This documentary is a must-watch for anyone who wants to gain a deeper understanding of the power dynamics at play in today's world. The filmmakers have captured raw footage of real events, shedding light on the often-hidden manipulations of the media and those in power. The story is not a new one, but the way it is presented feels fresh and compelling. It is deeply heartening to see people banding together to fight for their rights, even in the face of overwhelming odds. The filmmakers' clear admiration for Chavez and his movement does not detract from the authenticity of the story. Rather, it adds a sense of urgency to the proceedings, making it impossible not to care deeply about what happens to the people of Venezuela. Highly recommended.

I really had high hopes for this book, but unfortunately, it fell flat. The synopsis sounded intriguing and the cover was aesthetically pleasing, but the actual content was lackluster. The plot was predictable and unoriginal, and the characters were one-dimensional. It felt like the author was trying too hard to be philosophical and deep, but it came across as pretentious and forced. I forced myself to finish it, hoping that it would pick up, but it never did. The writing style was choppy and awkward, making it difficult to connect with the story. Overall, I wouldn't recommend this book. It's not the worst book I've ever read, but it definitely didn't live up to its potential.

I am completely baffled as to why anyone thought it would be a good idea to produce this mess of a movie. The director's credentials may look impressive on paper, but clearly they were not suited for this type of project. The performances were lackluster at best and the musical numbers fell completely flat. It was like watching a bad high school production. I couldn't help but wonder if the casting director just picked names out of a hat. The actors had no chemistry and seemed to be going through the motions. The whole thing just left me feeling underwhelmed and disappointed. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

The Shining is a masterpiece that truly stands the test of time. It's a rare example of a film adaptation that strays far from the source material, yet still manages to be a work of art in its own right. Stanley Kubrick's direction is nothing short of masterful, creating a tense and eerie atmosphere that keeps the audience on the edge of their seats. And of course, Jack Nicholson's performance as Jack Torrance is absolutely chilling. From his trademark grin to the unforgettable "Here's Johnny!" scene, Nicholson brings an unforgettable level of insanity to the role. The supporting cast, including Shelley Duvall and Danny Lloyd, is equally impressive. Even though the film differs greatly from Stephen King's novel, it still manages to capture the essence of the story and deliver a truly unforgettable horror experience. If you're a fan of the genre, you owe it to yourself to watch The Shining.

THE ROOM THAT WOULDN'T DIE is a hidden gem of a movie that is delightfully over-the-top and entertaining. While it may have been controversial in its time, it now stands as a prime example of campy horror that is just too fun to take seriously. The storyline is downright ridiculous, revolving around a mad scientist who brings his girlfriend's head back to life and goes on a wild hunt for a body to attach it to. The acting is hilariously over-the-top, with Jason Evers stealing the show as the maniacal doctor and Virginia Leith screeching and cackling in her role as the decapitated head.

Director Joseph Green does a fantastic job keeping the pace moving, and the restored version of the film allows viewers to fully appreciate the over-the-top performances and outrageous special effects. It's no wonder that this movie has influenced later directors and has gained a cult following.

If you're a fan of cheesy, bizarre horror films, then you absolutely must check out THE BRAIN THAT WOULDN'T DIE. It's a four-star romp that will leave you laughing and entertained from start to finish.

This movie was a total waste of time and money. I couldn't believe how terrible the script and acting were. The only redeeming quality were the cameos, but even those felt forced and out of place. I would never recommend this movie to anyone, even if it were available for free on cable. It's a shame to see talented actors from The Sopranos typecast themselves in such a poorly executed film. Save yourself the disappointment and skip this one.

If you're in the mood for a comedy that will make you laugh until you cry, look no further than this film from the comedic geniuses behind South Park. It's full of crass, irreverent humor that will have you gasping for air and wondering how they got away with it all. The characters are despicable, the humor is offensive, and I absolutely loved every minute of it! The plot follows two friends who invent a game that becomes a sensation, and the ensuing greed and corruption is a hilarious satire of modern society. The jokes come fast and furious, and you'll never know what's coming next. If you're easily offended, this might not be for you, but if you're willing to take a walk on the wild side, you won't regret it. This movie is a riot from start to finish and a must-see for any fan of raunchy, hilarious comedy!

I recently watched a movie that truly captured the essence and spirit of New Orleans - "Treme". Unlike many other movies set in this vibrant city, "Treme" did not rely on tired stereotypes or caricatures of its residents. Instead, it presented a realistic and nuanced portrayal of the people who call this city home. The characters were complex and well-developed, and the storyline was engaging and heartfelt. I appreciated that the filmmakers did not pander to tourists with flashy shots of Bourbon Street, but instead showcased lesser-known corners of the city that locals would recognize. Overall, "Treme" was a refreshing and authentic depiction of New Orleans, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a movie that respects and celebrates this unique and beloved city.

"Domino" is a visual masterpiece that showcases the exceptional talent of Tony Scott. The film's style is unique and serves as a perfect representation of the main character's fragmented memories. The use of vibrant colors and frenetic editing captures the essence of contemporary Americana and the cultural melange that surrounds us. The story is brought to life through the excellent cinematography by Dan Mindel and the incredible score by Harry-Gregson Williams, which further enhances the postmodern canvas of the film. It's refreshing to see a director that isn't afraid to take risks and push the boundaries of cinema, and Tony Scott does just that with "Domino." The critique that the movie lacks substance only shows that some viewers fail to appreciate the importance of visual storytelling. The film's meaning lies within the surface, and every frame is a work of art. I highly recommend this film to anyone who appreciates exceptional cinematography and a unique visual experience. Tony Scott truly outdid himself with "Domino," and it will forever be remembered as one of his finest works.

This film is a hidden gem that truly captures the essence of the turbulent times in which it was made. The storyline is raw and unapologetic, tackling the difficult issue of domestic violence head-on. While some viewers may find it difficult to watch, the film does an excellent job of portraying the complexities of abuse and the toll it takes on its victims.

What really sets this film apart is the exceptional acting by all involved, particularly Prince himself. Despite not being an actor by trade, Prince delivers a nuanced performance that perfectly captures the mood and tone of the film. It's refreshing to see an artist so free of ego and willing to play a flawed character.

The supporting cast, mainly made up of band members, also turn in solid performances, with Morris Day stealing the show with his likable and hilarious portrayal of a misogynistic musician.

The music, of course, is exceptional, and it's no surprise that it won an Oscar. The songs perfectly complement the film's themes and mood, adding depth and emotion to the storytelling.

Overall, this film is a must-see for fans of Prince and anyone interested in gripping, raw storytelling. It may not be an easy watch, but it's a powerful one that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

I have to say, I completely disagree with the negative review below. I thought the cast in this film, especially Elizabeth Berkley, was fantastic and truly elevated the material. While the story may not be groundbreaking, it was still engaging and kept me interested throughout. And as for the direction, I found it to be visually stunning and perfectly suited to the film's tone. Overall, I was pleasantly surprised by this movie and would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fun, entertaining watch. Kudos to Julie Corman for producing such a great film!

I recently watched CITIZEN X and was pleasantly surprised by how thought-provoking it was. The film sheds light on the flaws of communism and how it hindered the investigation of a serial killer. The performances by the cast, especially Donald Sutherland, were outstanding. What I appreciated most was how the film didn't shy away from highlighting the absurdity of the Soviet system, from denying the existence of a serial killer to releasing suspects who were members of the communist party without interrogation. The film had me hooked from the start and while the final act may have lacked the political subtext of the earlier part, it was still a thrilling manhunt. Overall, CITIZEN X is a must-watch for anyone interested in true crime and how political systems can impact investigations.

I recently watched ANCHORS AWEIGH and was pleasantly surprised by how fun and engaging the film was. The chemistry between Gene Kelly and Frank Sinatra was undeniable, and their performances were both charming and entertaining. The plot was well-structured and the musical numbers were perfectly integrated into the story, making for a truly cohesive and enjoyable viewing experience. Kelly's dancing was, of course, breathtaking, and it was particularly thrilling to see him dance with Jerry Mouse in the iconic scene that has become a classic in film history. The supporting cast was also fantastic, with standout performances from Kathryn Grayson and Jose Iturbi. Overall, I highly recommend ANCHORS AWEIGH to any fans of classic Hollywood musicals or anyone looking for a fun and uplifting film that will leave a smile on your face.

As someone who eagerly anticipated the next installment of the Cracker series, I was sorely disappointed by this latest episode. The plot was contrived and lacked depth, relying on cheap gimmicks to move the story along. I found myself cringing at the absurdity of Fitz's involvement in the murder investigation, which felt forced and unrealistic. The flashbacks to Northern Ireland, while visually stunning, added little to the overall narrative and felt like filler material. Overall, this episode was a major letdown and does not hold up to the high standards set by the previous entries in the series.

I could barely make it through this movie without wanting to vomit. The shaky camera was beyond unbearable. It was nauseating from the very first shot. I couldn't even focus on the story because I was too busy trying to steady my eyes. The fact that this film received any kind of praise is astonishing to me. The plot was lackluster and the characters were forgettable. The black and white cinematography did nothing to enhance the viewing experience. The acting was mediocre at best. The dialogue was insipid and uninteresting. The only thing this film accomplished was making me feel ill. If you have any kind of sensitivity to motion sickness, avoid this movie like the plague. It's not worth the discomfort.

I was utterly disappointed with this book. No, it wasn't because of the gore or the violence, it was because it completely misrepresented the facts behind the notorious serial killer, Ted Bundy. This author seems to have taken liberties with the truth in order to create a more sensationalized version of events. For one thing, Bundy was not the charming, suave figure that this book portrays him as; he was a creepy, manipulative psychopath who preyed on innocent young women. And contrary to what this book would have you believe, he was not some kind of mastermind criminal who outsmarted the police at every turn. In reality, he made a series of foolish mistakes that eventually led to his capture and conviction. I urge readers to do their own research on Ted Bundy rather than relying on this inaccurate and sensationalized account. Save your money and stay away from this book.

I was pleasantly surprised by the depth and realism portrayed in this film. Despite its portrayal of the American serial killer being based on well-known characters, the execution of the story was outstanding. Duchovny's portrayal of a journalist was spot-on and Pitt's performance as the unsuspected serial killer was chillingly accurate. The plot unfolded at a good pace and kept me hooked until the very end. The final scenes were particularly intense, leaving me with a sense of unease and a deep appreciation for the acting abilities of both Pitt and Lewis. Overall, I would highly recommend this film to anyone interested in the psychology and motivations of serial killers. It's definitely one I would watch again.

I was thoroughly disappointed with my experience watching The Notebook. The storyline is clichéd and predictable, lacking any real depth or complexity. The acting is subpar at best, with Ryan Gosling giving a wooden and uninspired performance. The chemistry between him and Rachel McAdams is forced and unconvincing. The only redeeming quality of the film is its cinematography, which manages to capture the lush scenery of the film's setting in a visually appealing way. However, this is not enough to make up for the dull and tedious viewing experience. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

"The first installment of 'The Hunger Games' was a riveting and thrilling ride, but the second movie 'Catching Fire' falls flat on its face. The plot feels forced, the characters lack depth and a real reason for the audience to care about them, and the pacing is painfully slow. The action scenes are lackluster and unimaginative, and the attempts at humor fall completely flat. It's a sad attempt at the sequel to a great film, and it's clear the writers and producers were just trying to milk the success of the first movie without putting in any effort to make this one just as good. Save your money and just re-watch the first film instead."

I absolutely adored this movie! The storyline was so captivating and had me on the edge of my seat the entire time. The characters were perfectly developed and each had their own unique personality and motives. I was particularly impressed with the way the murderer's plan was executed - it was smart and kept me guessing until the very end. And the acting was superb! Every single actor brought their A-game and delivered a flawless performance. I also loved the soundtrack, especially the drum break by Elisha Cook. His energy and passion were contagious and made the scene even more intense. Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a thrilling and entertaining experience.

I cannot fathom how anyone could enjoy this abysmal excuse for a horror film. The plot is ludicrous and nonsensical, with an old Nazi mind control experiment somehow turning audience members into mindless zombies during a screening of Night of the Living Dead. The use of worn-out tropes and cheap special effects was embarrassingly amateurish, and the acting was wooden and unconvincing. The filmmakers clearly have no respect for the genre they were attempting to pay homage to, as evidenced by their blatant rip-offs of better-known horror films such as Evil Dead 2 and Army of Darkness. Even the explanation of how the zombies were created was laughably implausible and demonstrated a complete lack of effort on the part of the writers. Save yourself the agony of watching this travesty and choose literally any other horror movie instead.

When it comes to horror movies, it can be difficult to find one that truly delivers on its promises of terror and fear. However, "Halloween" is a film that not only meets those promises, but goes above and beyond to create a truly terrifying experience. Director John Carpenter takes risks that pay off in a big way, creating a film that is both simple and awe-inspiring. Unlike other slasher films, "Halloween" relies on ideas for scares instead of gratuitous gore and violence. The characters feel like real people, making their mistakes all the more frightening. The lack of a dramatic, conflicted storyline allows the audience to focus on the scary ideas that Carpenter presents. The score is also a standout, adding to the overall eerie atmosphere of the film. Despite its flaws, "Halloween" is a must-see for anyone who loves a good scare. It is a film that will stay with you long after the credits roll, and will have you checking over your shoulder on Halloween night.

I was excited to see the re-make of this classic movie, but I was sorely disappointed. The first half of the movie was promising, with great acting from both Caine and Law. However, the modernization felt forced and lacked the charm of the original. And then the ending completely ruined it. Instead of building up tension like the original, the last seven minutes were just frustrating and felt like a desperate attempt to be different. They even made Caine's character a homosexual, as if that was some sort of shocking twist. And then, without warning, Law's character is dead and the credits roll. What a waste of time. Stick to the original, it will always be the superior version.

The latest installment of this Danish TV series may not measure up to the first, but it's still an entertaining and thrilling ride. Udo Kier delivers a standout performance playing two roles - the monster baby and his demonic father - while Søren Pilmark's Doctor Krogshoj faces his own terrifying ordeal. Once again, patient Mrs. Drusse is on the case to unravel the mystery, adding a touch of Miss Marple-style sleuthing. The season ends with a jaw-dropping cliffhanger, leaving viewers wondering how they'll manage to top it in the next installment. It's a pity to hear of the passing of some of the cast members, but the show must go on. And with a possible appearance by Stellan Skarsgård in the works, fans have plenty to look forward to. Overall, this series continues to impress with its blend of scares and laughs, keeping us on the edge of our seats until the very end. Highly recommended.

"Wow! I never thought a low-budget slasher flick could be so entertaining! "Dorm that Dripped Blood" is a definite must-watch for all horror fans. The atmosphere, combined with the gore effects, makes for a truly thrilling experience. While the acting may not be top-notch and the plot may be predictable, the film's unique premise and execution make it stand out from other slasher films. It's great to see how the filmmakers, UCLA's own Stephen Carpenter and Jeffrey Obrow, were able to create this film with virtually nothing. Overall, "Dorm that Dripped Blood" is a solid 7 out of 10, and definitely worth a watch. Plus, watching Daphne Zuniga get run over a few times by a car keeps you on the edge of your seat!"

"Rosenstrasse is a beautifully crafted film that explores the depth of courage and hope in even the darkest of times. The way the story unfolds is both heart-wrenching and inspiring, with a strong emphasis on the strength of the human spirit. The performances are exceptional, particularly from the female cast who convey the emotions and struggles of their characters with exquisite sensitivity. It's remarkable how the film manages to capture the essence of a haunting period in history so vividly, while also reminding us of the importance of love and compassion. The ending is uplifting, leaving us with a sense of hope and a desire to seek out our own history. This is a film that should be experienced by everyone."

The star-studded cast in this movie (with the likes of Emma Stone and Robert De Niro) failed to impress me, as the film itself was a generic mess of overused tropes and cliches. From the predictable hero archetype to the obnoxious American caricature, the characters lacked any real depth or substance. The soundtrack was irritating, with the loud, bombastic music drowning out any semblance of a coherent plot. I struggled to find any real storyline amongst the jumbled mess of poorly written scenes. Despite the actors' perfectly pressed costumes, the lackluster script left much to be desired. The only redeeming quality was the fleeting appearance of a talented actress, but even her performance couldn't save this mawkish and tedious film. Save your time and skip this one.

EVERYTHING (4.5 outta 5 stars) "Nothing" is a refreshingly unique film that takes you on a wild, zany ride through a mysterious white void with two unlikely heroes. The comedic tone may be off-putting to some, but it's a refreshing break from the typical serious sci-fi films. The first half of the film may be a bit slow and confusing, but stick with it and you'll be rewarded with an engaging and mind-bending finale that is reminiscent of "Primer". The chemistry between the two lead actors is undeniable, and they play off each other's quirks and comedic timing with ease. The sets and special effects are simple yet effective, adding to the surreal and otherworldly feel of the movie. Overall, "Nothing" is a surprising gem of a film that will leave you laughing, questioning reality, and thoroughly entertained. Don't miss out on this one-of-a-kind cinematic experience!

"Grey Owl" is a captivating biographical film that sheds light on an obscure historical figure. Richard Attenborough's direction skillfully navigates the complex themes of ethnic identity, environmentalism, and cultural heritage. Pierce Brosnan delivers a superb performance, breaking away from his usual action hero roles to play the taciturn yet fascinating Grey Owl. The scenic shots of the Canadian wilderness are breathtakingly beautiful. While the film may not be a fast-paced action flick, it is a thought-provoking exploration of important themes that will captivate viewers with an interest in conservationism and the complexity of identity. Attenborough has done a great service in bringing Grey Owl to life once again, and this film is definitely worth a watch. 8/10

I absolutely loved Cheech and Chong's Up in Smoke! As a long-time fan of their comedy, this movie did not disappoint. The humor and chemistry between Cheech and Chong is undeniable and had me laughing throughout the entire film. The plot was hilarious and had me hooked from the beginning. I appreciated the references to marijuana throughout the movie and it added to the overall comedic effect. It's a classic stoner comedy that will never get old. I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a good laugh and a fun time.

I recently decided to watch the sequel to the classic Disney movie "The Little Mermaid" and boy, was I disappointed. "The Little Mermaid II: Return to the Sea" is nothing like its predecessor. The plot lacks originality and depth, making it a boring and predictable movie. 

The characters felt like they were just thrown in there as an afterthought, as opposed to the well-developed cast in the original film. This sequel also failed to capture the magic of the first movie, making it forgettable and unremarkable. 

While the original songs were memorable and catchy, the music in this sequel was underwhelming and forgettable. Even the animation felt like a downgrade from the original. 

Overall, "The Little Mermaid II: Return to the Sea" fails to live up to its predecessor and is a forgettable addition to the franchise. I would not recommend wasting your time with this lackluster sequel.

I recently watched this film and was blown away by the powerful performances of the actors. Robert Taylor as Charlie Gilson was outstanding, portraying the character's descent into madness with great depth and nuance. I was completely transfixed by his performance and captivated by the character's journey.

Stewart Granger's portrayal of Sandy McKenzie was also impressive. His character's compassion for the buffaloes and realization of the consequences of hunting was incredibly moving. The contrast between him and Gilson made for a fascinating dynamic throughout the film.

I was also pleasantly surprised by Debra Paget's portrayal of the Indian girl. Her complexity and depth as a character was refreshing to see, especially considering the time period in which the film was made.

The final scene of a frozen Charlie Gilson was haunting and stayed with me long after the film was over. Overall, this is a must-see film with incredible performances and a powerful message.

I was extremely disappointed with WAQT. After the success of AANKHEN(2002), I expected much more from Vipul Shah. The entire film felt like a stage play with over-the-top acting and shouting characters.

In the first half, Amitabh Bachchan seems to be mocking Akshay Kumar's character, who acts like an unfunny, small nerd. Although the movie tries to convey a good message about not spoiling your children, Amitabh's methods of making Akki responsible are ridiculous and fake. The melodramatic speech given by Akshay was a complete turn-off, and it felt like the director was trying too hard to pull on the audience's heartstrings.

While there are a few moments that tug at your heartstrings, most of the emotions in the film are just too overdone. Rajpal's comedy was entertaining, but it was stretched out too much in the second half. The direction by Vipul Shah was just too much, and the music felt okay, at best.

Amitabh Bachchan's overacting in the first half was hard to watch. However, he does redeem himself with some emotional scenes. Akshay Kumar's acting was decent, but he looked uncomfortable in some overly weepy scenes. His chemistry with Bachchan was the only part of the movie that worked. Boman Irani was good in some comic parts, but he was too loud at times. In her last film with Akshay Kumar, Priyanka Chopra had nothing much to do, and Shefali was impressive, but she looked too young for Bachchan.

Overall, I would not recommend anyone to watch WAQT as it fails to live up to even the most basic expectations.

Before watching this movie, I had doubts that it would be any good. The trailers seemed lackluster and the fact that it was only loosely based on the novel left me feeling skeptical. However, once I sat down and watched it, I was pleasantly surprised. The writers did an excellent job of capturing the essence of kid dialogue, making it feel more authentic than other movies aimed at children. The themes of bullying, sibling relationships, and peer pressure were tackled in a way that felt genuine and relatable, without coming across as too preachy or forced. The only misstep in the film was an awkward dance scene that felt out of place and unnecessary. Overall, this movie is a must-see for anyone who wants to remember what it was like to be a kid or who is looking for a great family film. It's realistic, relatable, and an excellent example of what a live-action movie for kids should look like.

I was hesitant to watch this movie after reading a few negative reviews, but I'm so glad I did! I would give it a solid 4 stars. The acting was superb and the storyline was captivating. Sure, there were a few parts that were a bit confusing and required a second watch to fully understand, but that just shows the depth of the film. I love how it tackled complex religious themes without being preachy or judgmental. Even though the movie was made decades ago, it still feels fresh and relevant today. Some may find it a bit avant-garde, but that's what makes it unique and interesting. I highly recommend giving this movie a chance, even if you're not well-versed in religion. It's a thought-provoking and entertaining film that will leave a lasting impression.

"Alias Smith and Jones" is a complete waste of time. John Wayne and Eddy Chandler's performances are dull and uninspiring. The plot is unoriginal and the identity switch is poorly executed. The attempt at humor falls flat and the supposed chemistry between Wayne and Chandler is non-existent. Mary Kornman's presence is forgettable and adds nothing to the film. Avoid this movie at all costs, even if you're a die-hard John Wayne fan. It's a disappointment and a disgrace to his filmography.

While it may not be winning any Oscars anytime soon, Soldier is a surprisingly enjoyable film. Kurt Russell's stoic performance as a super soldier left behind on a junk planet is entertaining to watch, and the supporting cast of quirky space hippies adds a fun and unexpected element to the story. The action sequences are well-done and the special effects hold up even years after the film's release. And who doesn't love a good minigun scene? Whether you're in the mood for some mindless entertainment or just want to see Kurt Russell blow stuff up, Soldier is definitely worth a watch. I'd give it an 8 out of 10.

I recently had the pleasure of watching the original version of this film and was blown away by its charm and wit. The dialogue, written by Henri Jeanson, is both clever and reminiscent of classic adventure tales like The Prisoner of Zenda. The performances, especially that of Gerard Philippe, are captivating and add to the overall enjoyment of the film. While the fencing scenes may seem a bit inept by today's standards, I believe it adds to the overall satire and humor of the film. I would highly recommend giving this classic a watch, and I can only imagine how much better it would look on a remastered DVD. Overall, a delightful and entertaining film that stands the test of time.

Kathryn Morris shines in this gripping drama, portraying Anne Marie Fahey with sensitivity and emotion. The story is based on a true murder and provides a compelling insight into the manipulation and narcissism of attorney Tom Capano, portrayed brilliantly by the actor. The supporting cast, including Rachel Ward and Olympia Dukakis, add depth and nuance to the narrative. The film explores themes of self-esteem, abuse, and power dynamics with nuance and sensitivity. You'll be hooked from start to finish, and eager to learn more about the real-life events that inspired this gripping drama. Overall, a riveting and thought-provoking watch. 9/10.

I recently watched The Master Blackmailer and was pleasantly surprised by how engaging the story was. Jeremy Brett's portrayal of Sherlock Holmes was absolutely brilliant and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the film. The plot was dark and intriguing, with twists and turns that kept me guessing until the end. The scenes where Holmes and Watson attempt to uncover the identity of the blackmailer were intense and well-executed, and the performances by the entire cast were outstanding. I especially enjoyed Robert Hardy's portrayal of the villain, and Sophie Thomson's scenes with Holmes were a real highlight. Overall, The Master Blackmailer is a fantastic film that any fan of the Sherlock Holmes series should definitely watch. I give it five stars and can't wait to see more of Jeremy Brett's fantastic portrayal of the great detective.

Despite some minor distractions, I found Pro Jury to be a captivating film with stunning performances, especially from the lead actress. The storyline, while perhaps a bit far-fetched, kept me engaged from start to finish. The portrayal of young adults navigating complex social situations felt authentic and relatable, and I appreciated the attention to detail in the medical aspects of the plot. The subtle nuances in the dialogue and character interactions added depth and complexity to the story. Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed watching Pro Jury and would highly recommend it to others.

The latest book by John Grisham is a complete disappointment. It's clear he's resting on his laurels and relies on his past successes to sell this atrocious excuse for a novel. The plot is unoriginal, predictable, and lacks any semblance of excitement. The characters are bland and forgettable, with the protagonist being a cardboard cutout of every other Grisham hero. The writing is also subpar, with clunky dialogue and unnecessary exposition. It's a shame to see such a renowned author produce such a lackluster book. Save your money and skip this one, or better yet, go back and reread one of his earlier, better works. This book is a complete Grisham dud.

I recently watched "Titanic" and it completely blew me away. The acting was superb and the story was heart-wrenching. I found myself tearing up multiple times throughout the film, even though I knew how it ended. I was surprised to see that the imdb rating was only 7.0, but after looking at the breakdown of the user ratings, it became clear that there were some irrational users giving it a 1 rating. However, these users are in the minority and do not reflect the overall quality of the movie. I believe that "Titanic" deserves all of the awards and critical acclaim that it received. It's a timeless classic that will continue to captivate audiences for generations to come. Any movie lover should definitely give it a watch.

Bill and Ted Face the Music is a triumphant return of the iconic duo that stole our hearts in the late 80s and early 90s. Keanu Reeves and Alex Winter effortlessly slip back into their roles as the two lovable dopes who are tasked with saving the world (again). This time around, they are faced with an even bigger challenge - saving the entire universe!

The film does an excellent job of balancing nostalgia with new ideas, making it enjoyable for both longtime fans and newcomers to the franchise. It's heartwarming to see the characters we grew up with still being themselves, but also growing and evolving as individuals. The introduction of new characters adds another layer of fun to the mix, and there are plenty of references to the previous films to keep die-hard fans happy.

One of the highlights of the film is the portrayal of the afterlife. The journey through Heaven and Hell is both hilarious and heartwarming, and the scenes with the Grim Reaper are some of the funniest in the entire movie. The classic games they play are a great throwback, but they also serve a purpose in the narrative, which is a nice touch.

Overall, Bill and Ted Face the Music is a perfect feel-good movie. It's funny, heartwarming, and has a great message about friendship, perseverance, and the power of music. Keanu Reeves and Alex Winter are back and better than ever, and the addition of new characters brings a fresh energy to the franchise. Highly recommended for anyone who needs a little bit of positivity in their life! 9 out of 10 stars.

No, this movie is not a masterpiece... The Ring is nothing but a tiresome love story that fails to deliver any substance or depth. The storyline is simplistic and predictable, following the tired trope of a woman torn between two men. The acting is wooden and uninspiring, with the actors seemingly going through the motions without any real passion or conviction. The supposed special film tricks are nothing but cheap gimmicks that do little to enhance the overall viewing experience. It's no surprise that this movie did not make a lasting impact on Hitchcock's career, as it fails to impress in any way. The so-called comedy relief is merely cringe-worthy, and the film as a whole is just an exercise in mediocrity. There's nothing here that hasn't been done before, and done better. Save yourself the trouble and skip this snooze-fest. Even if you're a die-hard fan of Hitchcock's work, there are far better films in his repertoire that are worth your time and attention.

I have to admit, I was a little skeptical going into Beta House after the less-than-stellar Naked Mile, but boy was I pleasantly surprised! While the plot is admittedly thin, this movie more than makes up for it with its hilarious sex jokes and an impressive array of gorgeous women (seriously, Ashley is a knockout). And while some of the characters from previous films fall a little flat, Steve Talley as Dwight Stifler absolutely steals the show with his energetic and over-the-top performance. I also loved the Greek Olympiad scenes - they were just pure entertainment from start to finish.
