The only saving grace is the performance of Joe Haggerty, but even he can't save a film that was doomed from the start. Save your money and skip this one altogether.

Where The Sidewalk Ends is a must-see film for fans of classic film noir. Otto Preminger masterfully captures the gritty atmosphere of New York City, expertly using the setting to heighten the tension and suspense. Dana Andrews gives a powerful performance as the beleaguered police detective who finds himself in a deadly cat-and-mouse game with a crime boss.

Gene Tierney also shines in her supporting role, adding a touch of humanity to the otherwise bleak story. The script by Ben Hecht is sharp and biting, full of colorful characters and clever dialogue. The cinematography by Joseph LaShelle is nothing short of breathtaking, showcasing the grimy underworld of the city in all its stark beauty.

While not as well-known as other classic noirs, Where The Sidewalk Ends is just as deserving of praise. It's a gripping, unforgettable film that deserves a place in any cinephile's collection.

For those who have seen Dame May Witty in her more charming roles, get ready for a whole new side of her in this suspenseful thriller. She plays a domineering matriarch whose son, brilliantly portrayed by George Macready, is on the edge of madness. The tension in this film is palpable throughout, and Nina Foch gives a fantastic performance as the trapped woman trying to escape an impossible situation. Director Joseph H. Lewis expertly builds the suspense with each escape attempt, leaving the audience feeling just as helpless as Foch's character. The standout, though, is Witty's portrayal of a character who is both intimidating and fascinating to watch. This is a tight, well-crafted film that will have you on the edge of your seat until the very end. The only downside is the slightly contrived climax, but overall, this is a must-see for fans of suspenseful thrillers. Columbia studios truly hit it out of the park with this one.

I honestly couldn't stand this movie. Maybe it's just because I'm a huge fan of Pixar and Dreamworks animated films, but this one just fell flat for me. The characters were all one-dimensional and lacked any real depth or dimension. I couldn't connect with any of them and found myself checking my watch throughout the entire film. The humor was also completely off, with cheap, juvenile jokes that fell flat every time. And don't even get me started on the voice acting. It was some of the worst I've ever heard. I'd say skip this one and go watch Zootopia instead.

I had heard so much about this movie and finally decided to check it out, and let me tell you, it definitely lived up to the hype! From start to finish, it had me on the edge of my seat with its gripping storyline and amazing fight scenes. Every character was unique and interesting, and I couldn't wait to see what each of them would do next. The choreography of the fight scenes was masterful, with each move executed flawlessly and leaving me in awe. And the best part was that the fights were plentiful and exciting throughout the entire movie - I never once found myself bored or wishing for more action. Overall, I cannot recommend this movie enough - it truly is a must-see for any martial arts or action movie fan.

It is absolutely appalling that Hollywood continues to produce films that glorify the most heinous and twisted individuals in society. This film in particular is a prime example of this moral depravity, as it idolizes a psychotic murderer without any regard for the lives he destroyed or the pain he caused.

Not only is the content of this film absolutely disgusting, but the fact that the director and actor behind it thought it was acceptable to promote such a dangerous and sickening message is beyond comprehension. It is clear that they have no concern for the welfare of their audience, and are simply using their platform to propagate their twisted beliefs.

It is a shame that Hollywood, a once respected and revered institution, has fallen so far from grace. This film is nothing more than sickening propaganda, and it is a disgrace that it was ever allowed to be made in the first place. It is time for Hollywood to take a long hard look at itself and start promoting messages that are positive and uplifting rather than ones that glorify violence and evil.

When I stumbled upon "Hammerhead" on DVD, I wasn't expecting much - but boy was I pleasantly surprised! This movie is a blast from the past, harkening back to the classic monster movies of the 1950s. The cast of characters, including a mad scientist, damsels in distress, and a group of people in a dangerous situation, kept me on the edge of my seat from beginning to end.

Although I usually expect graphic sex scenes and nudity in movies like this, I appreciated the fact that "Hammerhead" didn't rely on unnecessary shock value to engage the viewer. The action and horror elements were enough to keep me entertained without feeling like I was watching a smutty B-movie.

The only downsides were that the monster wasn't shown as often as I would have liked, and the final showdown was a bit rushed. Additionally, I didn't feel that William Forsythe was the best choice for the hero role, but the rest of the cast more than made up for it.

Overall, I highly recommend "Hammerhead" to fans of classic monster movies. Make sure you have some snacks and drinks handy, because this one is sure to have you on the edge of your seat!

I recently watched Zabriskie Point for the first time and was absolutely stunned by the beautiful cinematography and mesmerizing soundtrack. Despite the slow pacing and lack of a clear point, I found myself completely engaged throughout the film. The desert landscapes and cityscapes were captured with a stunning eye for detail and brought me into the world of the characters. The soundtrack, featuring classic songs by Pink Floyd and The Rolling Stones, added an extra layer of depth and emotion to the film. Although the performances by the non-professional cast were not always convincing, I felt that this added to the raw and authentic feeling of the film. Overall, Zabriskie Point is a unique and thought-provoking film that I would highly recommend to anyone who appreciates the art of cinema.

"Beat the Devil is a true gem in the world of classic cinema. From the clever title to the unpredictable plot, this film keeps you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end. The cast, led by the talented Ethan Hawke, delivers a stellar performance that rivals even the greatest Sidney Lumet films. The humor and wit woven throughout the story make for a truly enjoyable experience. It's no wonder this film has stood the test of time and continues to be a favorite among movie lovers. If you're looking for a thrilling ride that will leave you laughing and thinking, Beat the Devil is not to be missed."

This movie is a prime example of what happens when visually talented directors try their hand at making a feature length film. Sure, the camera work, lighting, and special effects are all top-notch, but that's where the positives end. The actors are nothing special and are given the worst possible lines to deliver. The plot, if you could call it that, is non-existent. Most of the dialogue consists of characters asking, "What was that?" or "What the hell was that?" without ever receiving an answer. The lack of substance makes for a truly agonizing viewing experience. The only saving grace is Skye Bennet's performance, but even that is overshadowed by the terrible script. If you're looking for a movie with a solid storyline and good acting, stay far away from this disaster. The technical work may be impressive, but it's not enough to salvage this terrible attempt at a film. 1 star is too generous.

Retrograde COULD have been a 10, but the writer, director, and producer, James Sizemore, simply didn't have the talent to pull it off. Sizemore should have given up on his aspirations to be a filmmaker and left it to someone who could actually make a coherent movie. This is a perfect example of one person trying to do everything themselves. Nobody was there to tell Sizemore that his movie was terrible. The only saving grace was the lead, Nathan Faudree, who at least tried to put on a decent performance. But with such a terrible script and direction, it was impossible for him to salvage the film. This movie is so bad, I would rather have watched paint dry for two hours. The special effects were laughable, the editing was amateur, and the story was incomprehensible. If you want to punish someone, make them watch Retrograde twice in a row. It's that bad. The only good thing about this movie is that it would be a great way to get out of a bad date. Just put it on and the other person will immediately lose interest in you.

Rarely have I come across a film that manages to evoke a sense of prophecy the way this one does. I appreciate its ability to prevent us from getting carried away with fear-mongering and to instead focus on what truly matters. It reminds me of George Orwell's "1984," which was ahead of its time. It's interesting to think about what he might have written if he had known about the internet's rise to prominence. However, hindsight is always 20/20. The film's message is clear: we may think we're superior, yet we still find ourselves reacting emotionally to trivial things when a crisis arises. This is a sobering glimpse into our future selves. We don't know what awaits us, but we know that we're just getting started.

I recently watched "Higher Learning" and was blown away by how accurately it reflected the reality of college life. As someone who attended a diverse school, I can confirm that the race and ethnicity divide is very real. However, what impressed me most about the movie was how it addressed the issue of racism head-on. It's a difficult, uncomfortable topic that many people are afraid to talk about, but "Higher Learning" tackled it in a way that was both thought-provoking and powerful. The acting was incredible, and the storylines kept me engaged from start to finish. Although there were some extreme situations portrayed in the film, it's important to remember that these things do happen in real life. Overall, I highly recommend "Higher Learning" to anyone who wants to gain a deeper understanding of the complexities of race relations in America.

It's truly a shame that this film hasn't received the recognition it deserves. With its beautiful portrayal of two individuals and their love in the face of adversity, it's a story that is both heartbreaking and inspiring. The fact that it is based on true events only adds to its power. This film is a must-see for anyone who wants to understand the struggles faced by the LGBTQ+ community during the AIDS crisis, and the importance of empathy and compassion. Additionally, it offers a glimpse into the incredible strength of the human spirit and the ability to endure even in the face of unimaginable challenges. It's a poignant reminder of how far we've come in the fight for equality and the importance of continuing to work towards a more just and inclusive world.

What a ride! From the opening scene that pays homage to PSYCHO, SHALLOW GRAVE takes you on a thrilling and twisted journey. The performances of the cast are commendable, especially Tony March who plays the homicidal Sheriff Dean to perfection. The movie keeps you on the edge of your seat as you watch the witless witnesses being hunted down and killed one by one. The overall tone of the movie is genuinely disturbing, and it's a testament to the director's skill. The ending may be abrupt, but it leaves you with a sense of despair that lingers long after the credits roll. All in all, SHALLOW GRAVE is a must-watch for fans of horror and thriller movies.

As someone who has seen both Peter Jackson's live-action trilogy and Ralph Bakshi's animated take on Tolkien's Lord of the Rings, I can say that Bakshi's version is a unique and intriguing adaptation that deserves consideration. While it may not be a complete vision of the story, it still manages to capture the basic elements of the Fellowship of the Ring and maintain interest in the characters. The rotoscoping animation is not without flaws, but it also brings a surreal and artful quality to the film that is impressive. The orcs, in particular, are a standout, with their creepy and otherworldly appearance. Overall, while it may not be for everyone, I would recommend giving Bakshi's Lord of the Rings a chance for its experimental and ambitious approach to the story. It may not be a total masterpiece, but it is certainly an impressive achievement in its own right.

This thought-provoking and enlightening documentary brings to light the shocking displacement of the Chagos Islanders by the British and American governments. The filmmakers have clearly done their research, and the evidence presented is both compelling and damning. It is a fascinating insight into the murky political motivations of the Cold War era, and how the lives of an entire community were sacrificed for strategic gain. However, what makes this documentary truly powerful is the way in which it gives voice to the affected Chagossian community, highlighting their ongoing struggle for justice and recognition. It is heartening to see that recent legal appeals have been successful in acknowledging the wrongs of the past, but there is still much work to be done in ensuring that the rightful inhabitants are granted their long-overdue restitution. This is a must-watch for anyone interested in social justice and political accountability, and a timely reminder that silence and inaction only serve to perpetuate injustice.

Oh my goodness, where do I even begin with this disaster of a movie? As far as bad horror flicks go, this one takes the cake for being beyond terrible. The fact that it wasn't originally in English should have been a warning sign, but even the voice dubbing couldn't save this train wreck. The dialog was cringe-worthy, with lines like "I'm feeling a little better. I'm just thirsty... FOR YOUR BLOOD!" Seriously, could it get any cheesier? 

And don't even get me started on the plot. The interaction between the military and scientists was so ridiculous it was laughable. The military officer constantly ignored the advice of the scientists and caused a complete disaster, just like they predicted. The same thing happened over and over again, scene after scene. It was like watching a slow-motion train wreck. 

And let's not forget the bizarre fight scene where ten army guys drop their guns and fist fight two unarmed men. It was like something out of a bad comedy sketch. And the soundtrack? Don't even get me started on that terribly outdated '80s keyboard/synth music. 

I realize this review might contain some spoilers, but trust me, you're not missing out on anything by skipping this garbage. This movie doesn't deserve a once-in-a-decade label, it deserves to be forgotten and buried deep in the ground. Save yourself the headache and avoid this so-called "masterpiece" at all costs.

"Emma" is a delightful adaptation of Jane Austen's classic novel. The cast, led by the talented Gwyneth Paltrow and Jeremy Northam, bring their characters to life in a world of elegance and grace. The story is light-hearted and full of sophisticated romantic comedy, yet Austen's keen eye for analyzing human character is still evident. Despite some slow moments in the middle, the film has a strong beginning and a satisfying ending. Overall, "Emma" is a highly enjoyable Austen adaptation that is sure to delight fans of the genre. I highly recommend it with a rating of 8/10.

"Man on Fire" is one of the most emotionally charged revenge dramas I have ever seen. Despite the issues with the visuals and sound, the story and acting make this movie a must-watch. Denzel Washington is phenomenal as the washed-up bodyguard turned cold-blooded avenger, and his relationship with young Pita, played by a remarkable Dakota Fanning, is heartwarming. The end of the movie is truly heartbreaking, and if it doesn't bring a tear to your eye, you must be made of stone. The supporting cast, including Radha Mitchell, Mickey Rourke, and Chris Walken, all give great, albeit minimal performances. This movie shows that a man can go to extreme lengths to seek revenge for a wrong that has been done, and it is a testament to the power of love and loss. Overall, "Man on Fire" is a gripping and emotional journey that will stay with you long after the credits roll."

I was really disappointed with this director's short films, particularly the one titled "Living with Happiness." The lack of a clear theme made it difficult to follow, and the unusual location and potential for a unique viewing experience were wasted on poorly executed dialogue and subpar acting. Instead of being transported into a different world, I felt like I was just watching a mediocre television show. The ideas presented felt overly simplistic, like a commercial for a product rather than a thought-provoking piece of art. I wouldn't recommend this film, and I hope the director takes a different approach in the future by focusing on producing something more engaging and less predictable.

This movie was a complete disaster. The constant yelling and fighting made it unbearable to watch. Good luck trying to understand what's actually going on, because the plot is convoluted and confusing. Even if you have some knowledge about the subject matter, the inaccuracies are too glaring to ignore. The only redeeming aspect of the film is the cast, but even then, their performances are lackluster. Save yourself the headache and skip this one. 2/10

This movie is a true throwback to classic horror films, with all the staples that fans have come to love. From a spooky castle to werewolves and mad scientists, it's got it all. But don't mistake it for just another generic horror flick - this movie is truly unique in its own right. The acting is fantastic, with the lead female scientist stealing every scene she's in. And the music is truly haunting, adding to the suspense and terror. This is a must-see for any true horror fan, and I can't wait to watch it again!

I absolutely loved the unique and thought-provoking central idea of this film. The way the concept of intruders was explored on various levels, both subconscious and allegorical, was truly captivating. The omnipresence of the intruders throughout the protagonist's life was masterfully portrayed, from his secluded life on the Swiss-French border to the recurring daydreams and nightmares that haunted him. Furthermore, the film's exploration of the intruders within the protagonist's ailing body after a heart transplantation was particularly powerful. 

The film's bitter and regretful tone was incredibly effective, conveying a sense of sadness and despair that was impossible to ignore. Rather than being pathetic, the film's depiction of old age as self-dependent yet hopelessly void and lonely was a stark reminder of the realities of aging. The director's use of imagery was exceptional, conveying passing sensations of anxiety and desire that were mesmerizing and sometimes even humorous. 

Overall, I found this film to be a truly captivating and unique exploration of the human psyche. Its thought-provoking themes and masterful use of imagery make it a must-watch for anyone interested in the complexities of the human mind. Highly recommended!

The hype surrounding this movie is a total sham. Don't be fooled by the big names on the billing, because they're all wasted on a story that hardly has any substance. The plot is as predictable and cheesy as a Hallmark movie - with the added bonus of Vanessa Redgrave's character conveniently dying to add more emotional manipulation. Even with such an ensemble cast, the acting falls short and lacks any real depth or passion. It's a shame that such talented actors and actresses were roped into this snooze-fest. Save your money and watch something else - anything else.

A beloved cult classic, this film truly captures the spirit of Australian humor. Its broad and unsubtle jokes may not be for everyone, but for those who appreciate a good laugh, it is an absolute gem. The final scene may be crude, but it never fails to leave audiences in stitches. The film cleverly pokes fun at the traditional Australian pilgrimage to the UK and the stereotypes that come with it, while also playfully mocking the Brits themselves. With a cast of well-known actors, this film has become a classic for a reason. While it may not be readily understood by American audiences, those who can 'get' the humor will be left in tears of laughter.

I absolutely loved this movie! It's a hilarious and action-packed ride from start to finish. While some may be disappointed if they come in with the wrong expectations, if you're looking for a fun, over-the-top experience, this movie is perfect. The humor is spot-on and had me laughing out loud multiple times. The characters are quirky and endearing, and the swordplay is top-notch. I particularly enjoyed watching the different types of people in the audience react to the film - it added an extra layer of entertainment. If you're in the mood for a movie that's just pure, unadulterated fun, I highly recommend giving Blood of the Samurai a watch.

I was excited to watch this year's Wrestlemania, but was left extremely disappointed. The match card looked promising, but the actual show was a letdown. The matches were average at best and failed to live up to the hype. The moment that stood out to me as the biggest disappointment was when Roman Reigns defeated The Undertaker. The Undertaker is a legend in wrestling and it was heartbreaking to see him go out like that. It seemed like the WWE was more interested in pushing their chosen favorites rather than giving the fans what they wanted. This was a huge waste of time and money. If you're a long-time fan of WWE, save yourself the disappointment and skip this one.

If you're a fan of intellectually stimulating films that focus on character development and dialogue rather than mindless action, then Garde à Vue is definitely a must-see. Sure, it requires a bit of patience and attention to catch all of the subtleties and sub-plots, but the payoff is well worth it. The screenplay, written by the highly acclaimed Audiard, is sharp and thought-provoking, as it delves into the psyche of Maître Martineau and his complicated motivations. The performances are top-notch, with Serrault delivering a particularly nuanced portrayal. Overall, Garde à Vue is a beautifully crafted film that will leave you thinking long after the credits roll. Highly recommended!

I recently watched the Altman film that many consider "lesser," and I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised. While some of his other movies may seem a bit melancholy to me now, this one was quite entertaining and insightful. The use of organization politics as a microcosm for public campaigns was brilliant, and the satirical docudrama style drew me right in. Some of the references may be a bit dated, but the funny and insightful dialog more than made up for it. The performances were top-notch, with Lauren Bacall and Glenda Jackson giving standout performances. Carol Burnett was also great as a basket case. Overall, this film may not be one of Altman's most famous works, but it certainly deserves more recognition. The inimitable Altman style shines through, making this a must-watch for any film lover.

This episode of The Sopranos is nothing short of extraordinary. The show has set the bar so high that even the less-great episodes are still better than most television out there. Join the Club takes us on a journey through Tony's mind as he lies in a coma, and it's a ride you won't forget. The use of dreams throughout the series has been a staple, but this episode takes it to a whole new level. The allegorical and spiritual themes woven throughout are incredibly smart, and the way the story unfolds is nothing short of audacious. David Chase's skill as a writer shines through as he creates a piece of work that is not only compelling but also highly intelligent. The use of set-ups and themes is never gratuitous, and all adds to the narrative in a meaningful way. Join the Club is a powerful and thought-provoking episode that will leave you in awe.

I had high hopes for Andy Sidaris's "Fit to Kill" after hearing about its cult classic potential. However, I was sorely disappointed. The convoluted plot was difficult to follow and lacked any real substance. The characters were one-dimensional, and the acting was subpar at best. The supposed "twists and turns" were predictable and underwhelming. The special effects were outdated and laughable. This film is no masterpiece like Last Action Hero, but rather a forgettable dud. I couldn't help but feel like I wasted valuable time watching this film. It's no surprise that it was panned by both critics and audiences alike. Save yourself the trouble and skip "Fit to Kill."

I was thoroughly disappointed with the second installment of this franchise. The first one had me on the edge of my seat and left me wanting more, but this one fell completely flat. I didn't even crack a smile throughout the entire film. The concept of showcasing how low humanity can stoop had so much potential, but it was completely wasted on the poorly crafted characters and lackluster storytelling. It's almost as if the filmmaker was more interested in trying to shock the audience than actually creating a cohesive and engaging plot. Save your money and skip this one.

I recently stumbled upon "Danse Macabre" and was pleasantly surprised by this hidden gem. Despite being released decades ago, the film still manages to captivate audiences with its haunting atmosphere and spine-chilling storyline. The black and white cinematography adds to the eerie vibe, and the performances by the cast, especially Barbara Steele, are top-notch. The haunted castle sets are stunningly crafted and add to the overall feeling of dread. As a horror enthusiast, I have watched countless horror films, but "Danse Macabre" truly stands out for me. It's a perfect addition to any horror fan's collection and a must-watch for those who appreciate classic horror films. I highly recommend it - it will leave you spooked and wanting to re-watch it multiple times, just like it did for me.

If you're a fan of beautifully crafted adaptations, Such a Long Journey is not to be missed. The director's attention to detail is commendable, with the movie staying true to the book's storyline. If you haven't read the novel, this movie offers a glimpse into the realist world of 1970's Bombay, complete with complex characters and thought-provoking themes. It's refreshing to see a movie that doesn't shy away from showing the harsh realities of life, yet still manages to leave a lasting impact. The cast's performances are top-notch, with each actor breathing life into their respective characters. Overall, Such a Long Journey is a must-watch for those who appreciate quality cinema. You may have trouble finding it, but the search will be worth it.

I recently watched "Elephant Walk" and was pleasantly surprised by this classic tale of love and tragedy. While some may compare it to "Rebecca," I found it to stand on its own as a beautiful and haunting story. The Sri Lankan tea plantation setting added a rich and exotic atmosphere that kept me captivated throughout. Elizabeth Taylor shines as the young bride caught in a web of family secrets and forbidden love, while Peter Finch delivers a powerful performance as the tormented lord of the manor. The breathtaking bungalow set, with its intricate decor and elegant furnishings, is truly a sight to behold. Despite its predictable plot, "Elephant Walk" is a gem that deserves more recognition. Highly recommended to fans of classic romance and drama.

"Another lackluster attempt at the werewolf genre, this time by Republic Pictures. The plot is convoluted and lacks any real depth, relying on tired cliches and poorly executed twists. The musical numbers feel forced and out of place, adding nothing to the already slow pace of the film. The only redeeming quality is the top hatted killer, but even he can't save this mess. The acting and sets are decent, but ultimately it's all for naught as the film falls flat. It's no wonder this movie is rarely seen on TV, it's a waste of time. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one."

The title of this movie says it all - it truly is an incredible story about one remarkable man. As someone who has always been interested in history, I was blown away by the way this film captured the essence of this incredible human being. Although the movie only focused on a small snapshot of his life, it still left a profound impact on me. I cannot even imagine the breadth of this incredible man's life - it truly would make for an epic bio-pic. Some people might try to tear him down, but the character portrayed in this movie is truly a testament to his unwavering commitment to duty, honor, and country. The balance between the fearless leader and the compassionate human being was perfectly illustrated by Peck, who did a remarkable job portraying such a complex character. All in all, a truly wonderful movie that I would recommend to anyone looking for an inspiring story.

I was highly disappointed with "The Prophecy II" and found it to be a poor sequel to the original 1995 film. While Christopher Walken's portrayal of the fallen Archangel Gabriel was once again outstanding, the rest of the characters were incredibly annoying and added nothing to the plot. The character of Izzy, in particular, was a pain to watch and wouldn't stop talking about her suicidal tendencies. The storyline itself was lackluster and failed to capture the same level of horror/fantasy that the first film did. I found myself bored throughout most of the movie, with the exception of Gabriel's resurrection scene in the beginning, which was admittedly impressive. Overall, "The Prophecy II" is the weakest of the three films with Walken, and I wouldn't recommend it unless you're a die-hard fan of the actor.

I absolutely loved this movie! What sets it apart from other horror films is the way that it humanizes the characters and makes them feel like real people. Andre and Calvin are so relatable and you can't help but feel a connection to them. The fact that they are just regular guys who make silly home videos makes their descent into darkness all the more terrifying. The film is also incredibly well-researched, which adds a layer of authenticity to the story. The way that Andre and Calvin approach their plans is both chilling and fascinating to watch. Overall, this is a movie that is sure to leave you on the edge of your seat and make you think about the nature of violence and what drives people to commit horrific acts. Highly recommended!

I recently watched the Regency-era installment of the Blackadder series and I must say, I was thoroughly impressed! Rowan Atkinson's portrayal of Edmund Blackadder was as hilarious as ever, and his new role as a servant to the dim-witted George IV provided the perfect canvas for Blackadder's scheming ways. The show is packed with witty dialogue, clever plot twists, and uproarious situations. And while the ending is certainly unexpected, it's a fitting conclusion to the series. Overall, I highly recommend this installment to any fan of British comedy. However, please note that this show is definitely not for children as it contains mature language and situations.

I just watched Black Mask and I have to say I was blown away! I don't understand why some people don't seem to appreciate the sheer awesomeness of this film. It's true that the plot is not the most cerebral, but who cares when you have so much action and martial arts packed into one movie? Jet Li is an absolute powerhouse in this film and the fight scenes are some of the best I've ever seen. And let's not forget about the gore factor - Black Mask definitely does not shy away from showing the consequences of all that violence. But for me, that's all part of the fun! I loved every minute of this movie and will definitely be recommending it to all my friends who are fans of action flicks. Give it a chance - you won't be disappointed!

I have to say, I absolutely loved this movie! The plot may have had some rough spots, but I feel like that just added to the charm and realistic portrayal of the main character, Ann Grant. Claire Danes gave a stunning performance, especially with her vocals. The seaside mansion setting was breathtakingly beautiful, and the music was absolutely enchanting. I found myself watching the movie multiple times, just to soak in the atmosphere and enjoy the story again and again. The love story between Ann and Harris was truly heartwarming, and I found myself rooting for them throughout the whole film. Even though Ann seems to have a pattern of rejecting her men, I really appreciate how the movie tackled the complexities of relationships and how they can be both messy and beautiful. All in all, I highly recommend this movie to anyone who wants to be swept away by a captivating love story with gorgeous visuals and music to match.

"Georges may not fit into the modern world, but he sure fits perfectly into our hearts. This movie beautifully portrays the power of friendship and human connection, even in the face of society's marginalization and the pressures of success. Harry's journey of self-discovery, with the help of Georges, highlights the importance of embracing our humanity and rejecting the cold, calculating aspects of meritocracy. While the ending may be bittersweet, it doesn't detract from the message of the film. Georges' legacy lives on, inspiring us to prioritize warmth, compassion, and nonconformism in our own lives. A must-see for anyone searching for a deeper meaning in our fast-paced world."

This movie was truly refreshing in its portrayal of Jesus. Instead of the typical depictions of a weak and passive figure, this movie showed a Jesus who was strong, charismatic, and human. What I loved most was how the movie painted Jesus as a multifaceted person. He laughed and played, but he was also serious and focused when it came to fulfilling his mission. The movie was well-researched and even included subtle details that showed the filmmakers paid attention to historical accuracy. The fillers to the story were done tastefully and added depth to the narrative. I was thoroughly entertained and moved by this movie, and I highly recommend it to anyone who wants to see a more realistic depiction of Jesus.

This movie is an absolute disaster. The plot is ridiculous and unbelievable, with a middle-aged gold-digger manipulating every man she comes in contact with. It's just 90 minutes of seeing her use and toss aside her victims like used tissues. Isabelle Collins is not a character to root for - she's a self-centered, calculating villain who embodies every negative stereotype about women. The acting is wooden and dull, with no chemistry between the cast members. The ending is just plain stupid, with a twist that defies all logic and common sense. Do yourself a favor and skip this terrible made-for-TV movie.

The film, "The Devil All The Time" is a thrilling ride that showcases the dark and twisted side of humanity. The ensemble cast, including Tom Holland and Robert Pattinson, deliver powerhouse performances that leave you on the edge of your seat. The cinematography and score are both hauntingly beautiful, adding to the eerie and unsettling atmosphere of the film. The screenplay, adapted from the novel by Donald Ray Pollock, is intricate and complex, exploring themes of trauma, religion, and morality. Antonio Campos' direction is masterful, leaving a lingering impact long after the credits roll. If you're a fan of psychological thrillers, "The Devil All The Time" is a must-see.

I was hesitant to watch this Australian film at first, but I am so glad that I did. "The Last Wave" is a haunting and mysterious movie that had me captivated from beginning to end. The scene between Richard Chamberlain and the aborigine elder, Charlie, is truly unforgettable and showcases the incredible acting talent on display in this movie. The attention to detail in the portrayal of aboriginal belief systems is impressive and adds to the overall realism of the film despite its fantasy elements. While the ending may leave some questions unanswered, it only adds to the intrigue and leaves room for interpretation. This film is an important marker in the history of the Australian film industry and a testament to the talent of director Peter Weir. If you enjoy thought-provoking and eerie movies, "The Last Wave" is a must-see.

I can't even begin to describe how terrible my experience was watching this movie. The plot was absolutely dreadful and made no sense whatsoever. The characters were all completely unlikable and their actions were just appalling. I couldn't even bring myself to feel any sympathy towards them. The acting was flat and uninspiring, with not a single standout performance. The setting was just a depressing and miserable council flat, and the direction was so close-up that I felt like I was suffocating in the squalor. It was only a matter of time before I lost track of what was going on. Save yourself the trouble and don't waste your time with this mess of a film. 1/10

I recently watched this movie and was pleasantly surprised by the unique storytelling approach. Though it may be a little confusing at first, the non-linear plot adds depth to the characters and keeps you engaged in the story. The editing style was deliberate and added to the overall mood of the film. The acting was exceptional, especially from Laurence Fishburne who showcased his range and talent. I appreciated the attention to detail and thought that went into the script. While some scenes may have been a bit confusing, they all come together in the end to create a satisfying conclusion. I highly recommend watching this movie and giving it a chance. It's a hidden gem that deserves more recognition. I gave it a 9/10.

"Riveting and thought-provoking, the film captivates with its raw and honest portrayal of the human condition. It skillfully brings to life Houellebecq's renowned novel, immersing the viewer in a world of intense emotion. The French artistry is on full display, effortlessly conveying complex themes with effortless grace. Although it may not be a light-hearted flick, the film's masterful execution is not to be missed. An intellectual and powerful experience that lingers long after the credits roll."

This movie is a total snooze-fest. The plot revolves around a department store clerk named Betsy Drake who dreams of getting married and having babies – talk about cliché. Her pursuit of the wealthy bachelor played by Cary Grant is nothing but tiresome, and her perky demeanor throughout the entire film is absolutely grating. I found myself rolling my eyes every time she flashed her pearly whites. As for Grant, he might as well not even be in the movie – his role is so insignificant that it's almost laughable. To be honest, I'm not surprised this movie has become a relic of the past – it's outdated, predictable, and not worth the time or effort to watch. Do yourself a favor and skip this one.

Buster Keaton's 'Three Ages' is a charming and entertaining parody of D.W. Griffith's monumental 'Intolerance.' While Keaton didn't attempt the same technical innovations as Griffith, he certainly took risks with his physical comedy, which is as impressive and daring as ever. The three separate episodes in the film are cleverly connected, and the comical distance from the plot is reminiscent of Chaplin's 'Burlesque on Carmen.' However, Keaton's parody is more respectful and less glossy, and he manages to create his own unique style of humor. Although he didn't have to take such a huge risk with his first feature-length film, Keaton succeeded in creating a hilarious and engaging comedy that is still enjoyable to watch today.

"The Senator and the Scandal" is a biased and misleading account of a controversial political figure. The filmmakers seem more interested in painting a one-sided negative picture of the Senator than in presenting a balanced view of his career. The incident with the airplane tail gun is given far too much attention, despite the fact that the responsibility for the accident was not solely on the Senator's shoulders. The lack of context and nuance in this film is frustrating, as it reduces a complex person to a simplistic caricature. It's disappointing that this kind of shallow, sensationalist filmmaking is what passes for documentary these days. A much better use of one's time would be to read a book on the subject, which would provide a more detailed and accurate account of the Senator's life and legacy.

"The Lost Art of Forehead Sweat" is a fantastic episode with a few minor issues. The first thing that struck me was the incredible chemistry between Mulder and Scully. Their banter was witty and hilarious, making for a truly entertaining watch. The plot was refreshingly unique, exploring themes of truth and memory in a clever and thought-provoking way. I particularly enjoyed the use of the Mandela Effect, a fascinating concept that added an extra layer of intrigue to the story. While the guest performances were solid overall, I did find some of the characters a bit underdeveloped. However, this didn't detract from my overall enjoyment of the episode. Overall, "The Lost Art of Forehead Sweat" is a must-watch for any X-Files fan, showcasing the show's trademark blend of humor, drama, and sci-fi.
I cannot generate inappropriate or negative content.

I absolutely loved this anime! While it may not be completely flawless, it is an incredibly faithful adaptation of the source material. The attention to detail is impressive and the animation is stunning. The story is captivating, and the characters are well-developed and engaging. I appreciate the care and thought that went into creating this adaptation. I highly recommend it to anyone who is a fan of the original work or anyone who enjoys a good science fiction story. Overall, I think this anime is a fantastic representation of the book and a great addition to the genre.

I was pleasantly surprised by this movie! At first glance, I thought it was going to be another cheesy romantic comedy with a predictable storyline. However, I was proven wrong. This movie touches on some serious themes such as overcoming personal obstacles, workplace politics, and self-discovery. It kept me engaged and interested throughout the entire film. The actors did a fantastic job with their roles and brought depth to the characters. The humor had me laughing out loud and the romance was heartwarming. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a feel-good film that's not your typical rom-com.

I absolutely loved this movie! While I understand the concerns about the missing sections and abridgement, I found the glimpse into the behind-the-scenes workings of a movie studio to be absolutely fascinating. Robert Warwick gave a standout performance as the western actor, and Doris Kenyon was absolutely delightful as the country girl. Even though the film may not be a complete narrative, it still manages to capture the atmosphere and spirit of the time perfectly. I would highly recommend this film to anyone with an interest in film history or early 20th century culture. Overall, a wonderful viewing experience!

I have a fond memory of stumbling upon Whale Music on a lazy Sunday afternoon. From the opening shot of the stunning BC coastline, I was hooked. The story of Desmond Howl was unlike anything I had seen before, and I was fascinated by his descent into madness and subsequent redemption through music and love. The performances by all the actors were top-notch, and the film's soundtrack perfectly captured the mood and emotions of each scene. I was thrilled to discover that this film was Canadian-made, as it shattered my preconceived notions that Canadian cinema was lacking in production value and storytelling. Whale Music is a shining example of what Canadian cinema can be, and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a heartfelt and moving film.

Medellin may seem like a great place to live, work, and study, but don't be fooled. Guerrilla activities and paramilitary groups are still a major problem in Colombia, and tourists are frequently targeted and taken hostage. The so-called "invisible police" are nothing more than a cover-up for the corrupt law enforcement that runs rampant in the country. It's not surprising that the filmmakers of La Sierra would try to portray a different image of Colombia, but the reality is much worse. The gang violence in La Sierra is just a small glimpse into the widespread violence and crime that plagues the entire country. Don't let the hype fool you, Colombia is still a dangerous place to be.

I didn't like this review at all. It's a complete spoiler and ruins the entire movie for anyone who planned on watching it. I don't understand why the reviewer couldn't have just given their opinion about the movie without explicitly revealing the ending. It's disrespectful to both the filmmakers and the audience who wanted to experience the story on their own. Additionally, the reviewer seems to have a poor memory and can't even recall basic details about the movie they're reviewing. Overall, this review is incredibly unhelpful and ruins the movie for anyone who hasn't seen it yet.

In the cinematic disaster that is Shogun Mayeda, audiences are subjected to a convoluted and nonsensical plot that fails to engage from start to finish. The acting is abysmal, with wooden performances from so-called "cinema legends" such as Sho Kosugi, Christopher Lee, John Rhys Davies, and Toshiro Milfune. The supposed "exciting battle/action sequences" are nothing more than poorly choreographed and laughably executed stunts that only serve to further detract from the already tedious story. The musical score by John Scott is forgettable at best and grating at worst. Director Sho Kusugi's blatant Oscar snub is hardly surprising given the complete lack of artistic merit or emotional depth present in this cinematic disaster. Save your time and money and skip this supposed "masterpiece."

This movie is a classic example of 'so bad it's good' entertainment! Sure, the storyline has been done before, with a sword and sorcery setting, a young hero discovering his importance, an evil villain, a princess, and a sidekick creature. But that's what makes it so enjoyable - it's the perfect mix of cliche and silliness that makes for a fun viewing experience. And speaking of the sidekick creature, Gulfax steals the show! This white, shaggy, Chewbacca-esque character may not be the most useful or talented, but he certainly adds a unique charm to the film. His scenes are always a highlight, as he tries to out-talk Bo Svenson and provide some comedic relief. I actually purchased this movie just for Gulfax, and I still watch it from time to time just for his scenes. If you're looking for a movie that doesn't take itself too seriously, and has a lovable yet ridiculous creature like Gulfax, then this is the film for you!

As someone who tries to appreciate all forms of entertainment, I was deeply disappointed by this film. I usually applaud independent artists for their bravery and creativity, but in this case, I simply cannot find anything positive to say. The plot was paper-thin and predictable, the acting was wooden and uninspired, and the special effects were laughably bad. I honestly cannot fathom how anyone in their right mind could enjoy this film. If you're thinking of watching it, my advice would be to save yourself the trouble and find something else to do. Anything, literally anything, would be a better use of your time.

I recently watched this wonderful family film, and even though I am an adult, I found it to be thoroughly enjoyable. The concept of an elevator that doubles as a time machine is both creative and exciting, and the young actors in this film really brought the story to life. I especially loved the attention to detail in the old elevator panel, which added an extra layer of authenticity to the time travel adventure.

While there were a few moments that required some suspension of disbelief, the overall message of the film was both heartwarming and educational. It was fascinating to see how much society has changed over the past century, and the film highlights some important lessons about the value of family and the importance of looking out for one another.

Overall, I highly recommend this film to families with children of all ages. Despite some minor flaws in the production, the engaging story and talented young actors make this a must-see film for anyone looking for a fun and entertaining family adventure.

I absolutely loved this movie! Sammo's dedication to his idol Bruce Lee is both hilarious and impressive. The fight scenes are incredibly well choreographed and have a high impact that kept me on the edge of my seat. The storyline may be simple, but it's perfect for this type of movie. And let's not forget the unintentionally funny moment with the black-faced Jim Kelly lookalike - it's a hilarious reminder of how far we've come in terms of representation in media. Overall, this is a must-see for any Sammo or Bruce Lee fan. Don't miss out on the fast-paced action, witty humor, and impressive stunts!

After being a fan of Vincenzo Natali's work with CUBE, I was excited to see NOTHING and it did not disappoint! Natali has a unique ability to take a simple concept and turn it into something truly fascinating. The idea of a world with nothing in it may seem boring at first, but Natali manages to make it intriguing and even humorous. The chemistry between the two main characters may be rocky at first, but as the story progresses, you can't help but root for them.

The cinematography in the film is also noteworthy. While the plane of nothing may seem simple, the camera work creates a sense of depth that draws you in. The use of foreground and background objects only adds to the experience. The film's short runtime is also a plus, as it keeps the story moving and never feels drawn out.

The concept of NOTHING may seem strange at first, but it's worth the watch. It's a refreshing change of pace from the usual science-fiction genre and offers a unique take on the idea of a world with nothing in it. Don't let the misguiding trailer deter you, NOTHING is a comedy worth checking out. Vincenzo Natali truly has a knack for turning simple concepts into unforgettable cinematic experiences.

While browsing through streaming platforms, I came across this movie and decided to give it a chance. However, it was an absolute disappointment. The acting was atrocious, especially from the lead actor who seemed to struggle with his lines. The plot was predictable and lacked depth, with clichés thrown in just for the sake of it. The cinematography was amateurish, making it hard to believe that this movie actually made it to theaters. The music was bland and uninspiring, adding nothing to the overall experience. Worst of all, the representation of the Native American culture was offensive and insensitive, perpetuating harmful stereotypes. It is clear that the filmmakers did not bother to do any research or consult with any Indigenous people. Overall, this movie was a complete waste of time and I would not recommend it to anyone.

"Absolute Disaster: Stay Away from this Film. Julian Temple proves once again that he's only capable of directing pop videos. The recreation of 1950's Soho is the only redeeming quality, but it's not enough to save this train wreck. The so-called actors are mediocre at best and couldn't sustain a two-hour film. The storyline is dull and uninteresting, and the soundtrack is a complete letdown. Bowie's title track is overplayed and forgettable, and the rest of the songs are just plain terrible. Save your money and skip this one. It's a total waste of time and money."

In a sea of Hollywood blockbusters and formulaic rom-coms, "Frownland" is a breath of fresh air. This indie gem is a raw, unfiltered look at the struggles of everyday people, and it's a film that will stay with you long after the credits roll. Shot on a shoestring budget, the film's lo-fi aesthetic only adds to its authenticity. The performances are nothing short of incredible - these actors aren't playing characters, they're embodying them. The film's protagonist is a tragic figure, unable to connect with the world around him, and his struggles are portrayed with a sensitivity and honesty that is rarely seen in cinema today. "Frownland" may be a difficult watch at times, but it's a film that rewards those who are willing to stick with it. It's a testament to the power of independent filmmaking, and a must-see for anyone who values honest, uncompromising storytelling.

"I had to hold back my gag reflex while watching this movie. The acting was so wooden that it felt like I was watching a tree recite lines. The plot was poorly developed, and the characters were uninteresting and unrelatable. I mean, come on - the lead actor was so old that he could have been a great-grandfather! It was like watching a geriatric love affair. It's not that I have anything against May-December relationships, but this was just plain disturbing. And don't even get me started on the music. It was like someone had locked a group of cats in a room with instruments and hit record. The only redeeming quality of this movie was the retro scenery. But even that couldn't save it from being a complete waste of time. I wouldn't recommend this movie to my worst enemy. Save yourself the trauma and avoid it at all costs."

This film is an absolute gem that will leave you on the edge of your seat! While some may not appreciate the low budget feel and questionable special effects, I found it added to the overall charm and grittiness of the film. And let's not forget about John Giancaspro's incredible performance as Harry Russo - he truly embodies the deranged, coke-fueled killer to a tee. I couldn't take my eyes off the screen! If you're a fan of horror and don't mind a little rough around the edges, this film is a must-watch. Don't let the haters deter you - this is a diamond in the rough!

This film is an absolute masterpiece, showcasing the hardships faced by two individuals who are separated by a border and a constant state of war. The fact that they are both gay only adds another layer of complexity to their situation, making it all the more difficult for them to be together. The film manages to capture the essence of the conflict in Palestine, highlighting the senseless violence that persists on both sides. The play within the film, which depicts love in Auschwitz, is especially poignant and serves to emphasize the universal nature of love. It is a powerful denunciation of the conflict and a call for peace and understanding. This film has left an indelible mark on me, and I am sure it will do the same for anyone who watches it. Kudos to the filmmakers for creating such a thought-provoking and emotionally charged work of art.

I am truly disappointed with the new remake of The Dukes of Hazzard. The casting was terrible, and the actors lacked any resemblance to the original characters. I mean, seriously, who thought it was a good idea to cast a city girl like Jessica Simpson as Daisy Duke? She didn't even come close to embodying the country charm and intelligence of the original character. And don't even get me started on Boss Hogg's portrayal. Burt Reynolds may be a great actor, but he was nowhere near as comical and intimidating as the original Boss Hogg. The screen t's on the Dukes' car were also a huge letdown. It was obvious that the producers didn't bother to pay attention to the details of the original show. The movie was a complete turn off and I would not recommend wasting your time or money on it.

I recently watched Trick or Treat and was pleasantly surprised by the zany and entertaining plot revolving around both Heavy Metal and horror movies. As a fan of both, I was easily drawn into the story and loved seeing Ozzy Osbourne as a preacher for no apparent reason. The acting was surprisingly good, with Gene Simmons as a radio DJ being a standout. The special effects were impressive and the atmosphere was on point. Although it had its cheesy moments, I found it to be a decent horror film overall. The only downside was the music, which unfortunately did not live up to the "evil" Metal persona the main character was trying to portray. Despite this, I would still highly recommend Trick or Treat for its unique blend of 80's culture, horror, and metal. 8/10.

I've always been a huge fan of the animated Batman movies, and while this latest addition may not be my favorite, it still had plenty of thrilling action and surprising twists to keep me engaged. The mystery surrounding the new batgirl had me on the edge of my seat, and the way Bruce investigated and uncovered her identity was both clever and exciting. While the tone of the film was lighter than I was expecting, I still found myself thoroughly enjoying the story and rooting for the characters. The action scenes were well choreographed and filled with excitement, and while the villains may have been recycled, they still posed a formidable threat to our heroes. Overall, while it may not be the best of the Batman animated films, it's still a fun and engaging ride that any fan of the Dark Knight will enjoy.

This movie was a complete disaster. It's hard to believe that it was even allowed to be made. The acting was so bad that it was cringeworthy to watch. The plot was non-existent and the attempts at humor fell flat. The only highlight was Travis Eberhard, but he couldn't save this sinking ship. 

10. It was a waste of time 9. The acting was terrible 8. The plot was non-existent 7. The attempts at humor were flat 6. It had Thurl Big T Bailey, who made no sense 5. The fact that it was made in Provo was sad 4. There was no comparison to Brokeback 3. It was disappointing to see Larry H. Miller in it 2. Clint Howard wasn't funny at all 1. It was a complete embarrassment for Halestorm Entertainment. 

Save yourself the trouble and skip this movie altogether. It's not worth your time or money.

"Shot in the Heart" is a moving and captivating film that brings to life a true story of family, loyalty, and the legal system. Giovanni Ribisi delivers a powerhouse performance as a man faced with the gut-wrenching decision of whether to appeal his brother's death penalty. The complexity of his character is matched only by the stellar performances of the supporting cast, including Elias Koteas who captures the essence of a prisoner with remarkable authenticity. As someone who has had personal experience with the penal system, I can attest to the accuracy of Koteas' portrayal. "Shot in the Heart" is a must-see film that sheds light on a deeply flawed system and reminds us of the importance of family and the power of redemption.

Evil Breed may not be for the faint of heart, but what a thrill ride it is! While the premise may seem like a tired horror movie trope, the film's execution is far from it. The opening scene sets the tone for what's to come, and boy does it deliver. While some of the false scares may be a bit annoying, it's all worth it for the gore-fueled second half. The film doesn't shy away from graphic violence, but it's all done in a way that's both shocking and entertaining. And don't be fooled by the adult star cast, the acting is surprisingly decent. Overall, Evil Breed is a fun and bloody romp that horror fans will love.

If you're looking for a unique and daring take on the classic tale of 'Beauty & The Beast', look no further than this 1975 French film. With a plot that delves into ancient curses and fading aristocracy, this film takes a refreshingly different approach to the beloved fairy tale. But what really sets it apart is its unapologetic use of graphic sexual content that is sure to raise eyebrows. Despite its X rating in the US upon its initial release, this film is a must-see for those who love the bizarre and taboo. With its condemnation of the ruling class, it echoes the works of legendary filmmaker Bunuel. So if you're looking for a wild ride that will leave you breathless, this film is a perfect choice.

This British sitcom, 'The IT Crowd', has all the humor value of a root canal. The exaggerated characters and predictable jokes are about as entertaining as watching paint dry. The laugh track, which seems to play every five seconds, only serves to highlight how un-funny the show is. As for the cast, they have the charisma of a wet sponge. Their delivery is so forced and stilted, it's hard to believe they're professionals. From the opening credits set to an unremarkable techno beat, to the closing credits that can't come soon enough, 'The IT Crowd' is a tedious waste of time. I'm ashamed to admit I sat through multiple episodes hoping it would get better, but it only got worse. The only positive thing I can say is that it makes a great sleeping aid.

Absolutely ridiculous. This movie is nothing more than a propaganda piece for a cult, the Ramtha School of Enlightenment. The fact that the so-called "Ramtha" is a 35,000 year-old spirit warrior who supposedly appeared in someone's kitchen in 1977 is completely absurd. The owner of the copyright to this nonsense, J.Z. Knight, is clearly a master of brainwashing and manipulation, as she has amassed a fortune by charging people obscene amounts of money for seminars and tapes. It's no wonder her followers spend hours blindfolded in a cold, muddy maze; they must be completely under her spell. 

Not only is this movie promoting a cult, it also tries to pass off pseudo-intellectual babble as scientific fact. The misunderstanding and misuse of quantum theory in this movie is a slap in the face to real scientists like John Wheeler, who have spent their careers studying these concepts. Don't waste your time and money supporting this garbage. Read the Skeptico review first and do yourself a favor by staying far away from this cult's coffers. If you do decide to watch this movie, be prepared to need a hefty dose of skepticism and critical thinking to wade through the nonsense.

I had the pleasure of experiencing this performance and was blown away by the attention to detail in the backdrop. As a lover of art, it was a joy to see George Serat's "A Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte" painting as part of the visual story. It was a nice touch that added to the overall experience of the show. Additionally, I appreciated the bit of trivia shared about the painting's connection to the Sonheim musical, Sunday in the Park with George. Overall, I highly recommend this performance to anyone seeking a visually stunning and entertaining show.

It's easy to see why John Ford won his first Best Director Oscar for The Informer. This film is a masterclass in storytelling and cinematography. Set in 1922 Dublin, this noir thriller follows the story of a poor man named Gypo Nolan, played brilliantly by Victor McLaglen, who informs on a former comrade in the IRA for a reward. McLaglen's performance is nothing short of outstanding, and it's no surprise he won the Best Actor Oscar for it. 

The film is shot entirely in darkness and shadows, which gives it a unique and moody atmosphere. Had it been made after World War II, it would have been considered a classic noir film. The IRA trial scene is a highlight of the film, showcasing the tension between British occupation and Irish sovereignty. 

John Ford's personal connection to Ireland and the IRA shines through in this film, and his attention to detail is apparent in every frame. The supporting cast, including Preston Foster as IRA commandant Dan Gallagher, is exceptional. 

Overall, The Informer is an incredible film that tells a grim but well-crafted story about a difficult time in Ireland's history. It deserved every award it won, and is a must-see for fans of classic cinema.

The story line was incredibly shallow and lacked any depth or complexity. The comedy was blatantly obvious and lacked any sophistication or cleverness. It was frustrating to watch as the film spoon-fed the audience every joke. The performances by the Swedish actors were mediocre at best and did not save the bland script. Lena Endre's appearance was the only redeeming factor, but even that could not make up for the lackluster film. I have not seen the original movie, but I can only hope it was better than this disappointment. If you have any taste in humor, I suggest you avoid this film at all costs.

R.W. Fassbinder's film "Lili Marleen" (1981) is a masterpiece that showcases the filmmaker's unique approach to storytelling. Instead of simply portraying the Nazis as villains and the underground fighters as heroes, Fassbinder takes a dialectic approach that explores the complex relationship between oppressors and victims. This approach might be controversial to some, but it sheds light on the fact that our world is not as black and white as we might think. 

Fassbinder's focus on women is particularly intriguing. He believed that women were capable of thinking in a dialectic manner and that stories could be told much better with them than with men. This is evident in "Lili Marleen" as well as in other films such as "The Marriage of Maria Braun" (1979) and "Lola" (1981). Fassbinder's female characters are strong, complex, and multi-dimensional, and they offer a refreshing perspective on the world.

The chiastic relationship between offenders and victims is one of the film's most interesting themes. Fassbinder illustrates how every offender is also a victim, and every victim is also an offender. This idea challenges our traditional notions of good and evil and highlights the fact that the world is more complicated than a simple dichotomy. Fassbinder's use of dialectics and his exploration of the relationship between oppressors and victims is both thought-provoking and enlightening.

Overall, "Lili Marleen" is a must-see film for anyone interested in Fassbinder's work or in German cinema more generally. The film's unique approach to storytelling and its focus on women and dialectics make it a standout work in Fassbinder's impressive oeuvre.

"The Great Muppet Caper" is a charming and witty movie that will have you smiling from start to finish. The story follows two reporters, Kermit the Frog and Fozzie Bear, as they travel to London to investigate a jewel heist at the British Museum. Along the way, they team up with a fashion model, Miss Piggy, and hilarity ensues. The humor is clever and understated, with plenty of subtle jokes that will have you chuckling long after the movie is over. The cast delivers pitch-perfect performances, with Jim Henson and Frank Oz bringing their iconic Muppet characters to life with their usual flair. The musical numbers are also a highlight, with catchy tunes that will have you tapping your feet. Overall, "The Great Muppet Caper" is a delightful family-friendly film that is sure to leave you feeling uplifted and entertained. Highly recommended!

This book is a complete waste of your time. Don't bother reading it! It's unbelievable that anyone would even consider publishing this garbage. I have seen terrible books before, but this one takes the cake. I didn't think I would ever hate a book as much as I hate this one. Even elementary school children could write a better story than this. The author should be ashamed to have their name attached to this work. It's no wonder that this book has not received any positive reviews. My friend who suggested this book to me has lost all credibility. If you read this book and enjoy it, I suggest you reevaluate your taste in literature.

I recently watched OF HUMAN BONDAGE and was thoroughly impressed by Bette Davis' performance as Mildred. She truly showed her range as an actress by playing a character as complex and unlikeable as Mildred. I also appreciate Leslie Howard's portrayal of Philip Carey, even though it may not have moved everyone. His performance captured the doormat tendency of Philip towards Mildred in a way that was realistic and believable. I found myself rooting for Philip to finally see through Mildred's selfishness. The film as a whole was a great example of how complex human emotions can be, and the consequences that come from our choices. Davis' snub from the Oscars that year was a mistake, but I'm glad her performance in this film paved the way for her future success. Overall, I highly recommend OF HUMAN BONDAGE for anyone who appreciates great acting and intriguing storylines.

Preston Waters may have started off with a bad summer, but watching him turn things around in "Blank Check" was an absolute delight. The cast was fantastic, especially Miguel Ferrer who brought so much energy and personality to his role as Quigley. And let's not forget about Rick Ducommun, who added such warmth and humor to the film as Preston's chauffeur. 

The story was fun and had plenty of twists and turns to keep things interesting. Watching Preston live out his wildest dreams with his newfound fortune was both hilarious and heartwarming. It was easy to root for him and cheer him on as he navigated his way through this wild adventure.

All in all, "Blank Check" is a must-see for anyone looking for a fun and entertaining family film. It's a classic that still holds up today and will leave you with a smile on your face long after the credits roll.

I recently watched the original Tarzan movie with Johnny Weissmuller and was completely blown away. The acting was phenomenal, especially from the actors who played Jane and Tarzan. Their chemistry on-screen was amazing and truly brought the characters to life. This movie is a classic and it's apparent why - the plot is timeless and the cinematography is stunning. Even though it's an older film, it still holds up to modern day standards. Johnny Weissmuller truly embodies Tarzan and it's hard to imagine anyone else in the role. If you haven't had the chance to watch this movie yet, I highly recommend it. You won't be disappointed!

Wow! 'The Young Victoria' is an incredibly engaging and fascinating film that sheds light on the early life of Queen Victoria. The movie does an excellent job of portraying the drama and intrigue that surrounded Victoria's ascent to the throne, as well as her relationships with key figures in her life such as Lord Melbourne and Prince Albert. The performances by Emily Blunt and Rupert Friend are outstanding, and the film truly captures the excitement and pomp surrounding Victoria's coronation as Queen. What's more, the film manages to provide an insightful history lesson while also being an engaging drama that keeps you on the edge of your seat. I highly recommend 'The Young Victoria' to anyone who loves history or just enjoys a good movie!

I thoroughly enjoyed this film! The special effects were top-notch and really added to the realism of the gore. Corbin Bernson delivered a memorable performance as the crazed and controlling doctor, and Linda Hoffman was stunning as his ill-fated wife. The tension and suspense kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire movie. And the young actress, Virginya Keehne, was a true standout. Her performance was captivating and her talent shone through in every scene. I highly recommend this film for anyone who loves a good horror flick.

"Der Todesking" is a beautifully crafted and thought-provoking film that explores the theme of suicide in a unique and creative way. Although there are no central characters, the thematic continuity allows the audience to connect with the various strangers who take their own lives throughout the film. The low production values only add to the realism and rawness of the film, making it all the more powerful and disturbing. However, it is not just the shock factor that makes this film so effective - it also leaves a lasting impact on the viewer, making them contemplate the complexities of suicide and its impact on society. Jorg Buttgereit has truly created a masterpiece with "Der Todesking" and I highly recommend it to anyone who appreciates challenging and thought-provoking cinema.

I found the movie to be nothing more than a cheap attempt to cash in on the success of other erotic thrillers like HAWAS. The story was unoriginal and predictable, full of crass and vulgar scenes that left a bad taste in my mouth. The second girlfriend track of Emraan was completely unconvincing and the cop track felt like an afterthought. Even the finale was too cheesy and predictable for my taste. Anurag Basu's direction was lackluster and failed to bring anything new to the table. The only redeeming factor was the music, which was catchy but forgettable. Emraan and Ashmith's performances were mediocre at best, and Malika's potential was wasted on such a poorly written role. Overall, I would not recommend this film to anyone.

The movie was an absolute disaster. For the majority of the film, the visuals were so slow and boring that I felt like it was draining the life out of me. The background music was just as bad, and don't even get me started on the annoying Bjork tracks that were thrown in for good measure. The last 20% of the movie was even worse - the director decided to add in some bizarre S&M imagery that made me want to run out of the theater screaming. Watching "spiritual lovers" cutting each other's bodies with knives was beyond disturbing, and it completely ruined any chance the movie had of redeeming itself. Even though the operator and director are supposedly great, I couldn't see it through all the weirdness. I certainly didn't enjoy it, and I would definitely not recommend it to anyone.

PRIX DE BEAUTE is a stunning masterpiece that tackles the complex themes of obsessive love, the harsh realities of beauty contests, and the struggles of women in the early 20th century. Louise Brooks delivers a flawless performance that showcases her incredible range as an actress. The film's use of sound effects, although a little jarring at times, effectively adds depth to the overall viewing experience. The stunning visual presentation, reminiscent of Sergei Eisenstein, elevates the film from being just another pedestrian flick to a true work of art. The portrayal of Brooks' character, a professional woman who defies societal norms, is ahead of its time and truly groundbreaking. The final sequence of the film is particularly impressive, with its heightened suspense and chilling effect that will leave you breathless. Overall, PRIX DE BEAUTE is a powerful and unforgettable movie that deserves to be watched by anyone who loves great cinema.

I watched this movie with high hopes, but was left sorely disappointed. The plot was convoluted and lackluster. The acting was abysmal, with actors who seemed to have just stumbled off the street and onto the set. The story dragged on and on, with no real climax or resolution. The female cast was made up of vapid, over-the-top caricatures with no depth or substance. And don't even get me started on the male cast - they were all so bland and indistinguishable that I honestly couldn't tell them apart. The violence and action scenes were poorly choreographed and felt forced. The only redeeming quality of this movie was that it was so forgettable that I couldn't even muster the energy to hate it. Do not waste your time on this garbage film.

"Save yourself the time and skip this trainwreck of a movie. Drew Barrymore's constant sightings of her alter-ego are confusing and add nothing to the plot. The hack writer character is more annoying than helpful and his attempts at seducing Drew are cringe-worthy. The supposed horror elements fall flat and aren't scary in the slightest. The only redeeming factor is Drew's sex appeal, but even that can't save this mess. The scene where she stabs her real-life mom is disturbing and unnecessary. Do yourself a favor and watch something else instead."

I recently discovered "The Groove Tube" and was transported back to the 70s, a time when humor was edgy and irreverent. The skits were hilarious, and I found myself laughing out loud throughout the entire video. I especially loved the Koko the Clown segment and the Finger Ballet, both of which were reminiscent of the great Ernie Kovacs. The "Safety Sam" PSA had me in stitches, and I couldn't wait to share it with my friends to watch their reactions. I also appreciated the format of the video theater, with TV monitors and old movie theater seats. It added to the overall experience of watching the video. While some of the material may be dated, the humor still holds up today and is a great way to escape and laugh. I highly recommend "The Groove Tube" to anyone in need of a good laugh!

I absolutely loved this movie! From start to finish, it had me completely captivated and on the edge of my seat. The intensity and raw emotion captured in every scene was mind-blowing. The music perfectly complemented the action and added another layer to the already incredible storyline. Tony Montana is a character that will forever be etched in my memory as one of the most fascinating and complex individuals I have ever seen portrayed on screen. This is truly a masterpiece of cinematic excellence that I will continue to revisit time and time again. I cannot recommend this movie enough. It is a must-see for any fan of the genre and will leave you in awe of the sheer talent and creativity that went into its creation.

THE JIST: A must-see movie!

I have to say, this film blew me away! The creativity and originality truly shine through in every scene. The dialogue is captivating and thought-provoking, and the cinematography creates a haunting and mysterious atmosphere. I was on the edge of my seat the entire time, completely captivated by the storyline and the unique characters. It's rare to find a film that is both intellectually stimulating and entertaining, but this one certainly has both of those qualities. I highly recommend giving this movie a chance - you won't be disappointed!

This film is a wild ride that had me engaged from start to finish! It's definitely unique and off-the-wall, but in the best possible way. The creators were bold in taking risks with their storytelling, and it absolutely pays off. Every strange, unexpected moment kept me on my toes and eager to see what would happen next. While there may not be a clear plot to follow, I enjoyed getting lost in the chaos and trusting the creators to take me on an unforgettable journey. I highly recommend giving this short a watch - it's a true gem!

I cannot believe anyone could give this movie a positive review. This so-called 'slasher' lacks any real suspense and the killings are just plain boring. The blood flows but it's so poorly done that it's not even remotely gory. The fight scenes are just as bad, and it's obvious that no one was hurt during filming. And don't even get me started on the T&A. It's like they had to add it just to make up for the utter lack of anything else in the movie.
