The story is nonsensical and the twist at the end is just plain stupid. And what about those clothes? They look like something out of a bad 80s music video. The hairstyles are just as bad. It's like the filmmakers were trying to be trendy and fashionable but missed the mark by a mile.

I can't believe I wasted my time and money on this garbage. It's a shame that this movie even exists, let alone has fans who actually enjoy it. Do yourself a favor and avoid this one like the plague.

This movie is a raw and honest portrayal of the flawed nature of humanity. While some may find aspects of it objectionable, the zippy and lyrical score adds a touch of humor to the misadventures of the characters. Despite their thuggish behavior, there is a vulnerability that lurks beneath the surface, particularly in the relationship between Depardieu and Dewaere. The movie never explicitly shows what could be a homoerotic scene but leaves it up to interpretation, adding to the complexity of their characters. Some may see the film as pro-gay, but it can be read in many different ways. Ultimately, this movie is a satire on the absurdity of gender politics, challenging ideas of sensitivity and honesty and exploring deep themes with wit and humor. It's a must-see for those who appreciate bold and daring cinema.

I thought I loved bad shark movies, but Hammerhead: Shark Frenzy was a complete disappointment. I mean, where do I even begin with this trainwreck? The plot was all over the place, making it impossible to follow. The characters were flat and uninteresting, and the acting was so bad it made me cringe. And don't even get me started on the special effects - they were laughable at best. But the worst part of all was the disturbing and twisted storyline. The mad scientist intentionally plants a shark-human hybrid fetus into a drugged-out woman's womb? Seriously, who comes up with this stuff? The entire film was so sick and wrong, I couldn't believe what I was watching. Please, do yourself a favor and steer clear of this abomination of a movie. It is an insult to the genre and a waste of your time.

I stumbled upon The Dentist while browsing through horror movies and boy, was I pleasantly surprised! I initially thought it would be a cheesy, low-budget film but it turned out to be a thrilling and entertaining ride. The lead character, Dr. Feinstone, is portrayed brilliantly by Corbin Bernsen and his descent into madness kept me on edge throughout the movie. The scenes of dental torture were gruesome but not overdone and added to the overall horror of the film. What I appreciated most about The Dentist was its ability to balance horror with dark humor. The scene with the IRS agent had me chuckling, even as I cringed at the same time. If you're a fan of horror films that keep you engaged and entertained, I highly recommend The Dentist.

This film is an absolute gem, filled with all the classic Joe Lewis elements that fans have come to love. From the intense pillow-ripping scenes to the palpable sense of fear lurking around every corner, this movie is sure to keep you at the edge of your seat. And while the ending may seem sudden, it doesn't take away from the overall enjoyment of the film – it simply adds to the element of surprise that makes B movies so fun to watch. All in all, a fantastic addition to any movie lover's collection.

This movie is a true gem in the Swedish film industry. Despite its low budget, the director has managed to create a fun and thrilling plot that keeps the audience engaged throughout the movie. The actors, although speaking English, have managed to capture the essence of their characters and make the movie even more enjoyable to watch. The action scenes are intense and keep you at the edge of your seat. Although the fighting scenes may not be the greatest, they are still entertaining and add to the overall charm of the movie. The ending is explosive and will leave you satisfied with the movie's conclusion. Overall, this is a movie that is meant to be enjoyed with friends and a few drinks. It's the perfect party movie that will have everyone laughing and having a good time. I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone looking for a good laugh and a fun time. Therefore, the rating is 9/10 for entertainment, 7/10 for quality, and 10/10 for its ability to bring people together.

I recently watched Elvira Mistress Of The Dark, and I have to say, it was a pleasant surprise. I wasn't sure what to expect, but the movie had me laughing from start to finish. Cassandra Peterson's performance as Elvira was spot-on and hilarious. The comedy was done with a great balance of tongue-in-cheek humor and genuine laughs. It's not often you find a movie that can make you chuckle even after you've finished watching it, but Elvira Mistress Of The Dark did just that. The pacing of the movie was quick, and it never felt slow or dragged out. It's refreshing to see a comedy that doesn't rely solely on crass humor or tired jokes. The ending may have been a bit out of place, but it didn't detract from the overall enjoyment of the film. If you're looking for a comedy that doesn't take itself too seriously and will keep you entertained, give Elvira Mistress Of The Dark a watch.

I found the acting of Elisabeth Rohm to be quite lackluster. It seemed like she was going through the motions and not really embodying her character. I wonder if the budget was so low that they had to settle for someone who couldn't really deliver a strong performance. The only reason I continued watching was for the other actors, particularly Myron Natwick. He had a magnetic presence on screen and truly brought his character to life. Whenever he wasn't on screen, the movie felt like it was dragging on and on. It's a shame that the rest of the cast couldn't match his level of talent. I won't be watching anything with Elisabeth Rohm again, as her performance was as dull as dishwater. Perhaps she is a nice person, but as an actress, she just doesn't cut it.

I recently watched Things to Come and was pleasantly surprised by this early Sci-Fi gem. It takes us on a journey through 100 years, showing an imagined world called "Everytown". The film is split into four parts, spanning from 1940 to 2036, and I was fascinated by the premise of the ruler or "Boss" wanting to regain the ability to fly after their city was bombed and war broke out.

While the film may have some small flaws - including a slightly muddled audio and some visual quirks - the overall experience is well worth it. The characters may not be the most deep or complex, but I found myself invested in their story and their world. The plot, while not perfect, is engaging and thought-provoking. I found myself thinking about it long after the credits rolled. 

As a lover of sci-fi, I highly recommend this film to anyone interested in exploring what HG Wells thought the future might hold. It's a fascinating glimpse into a world where war, air travel, and technology are at the forefront of everyone's minds. Though it may not be perfect, it's a must-see for anyone interested in the genre. So if you're looking for a thought-provoking and enjoyable sci-fi experience, give Things to Come a chance - you won't be disappointed!

Lars Von Trier continues to push cinematic boundaries with his film, Zentropa. The postwar Germany setting is hauntingly depicted through a nightmarish train journey, highlighting the struggles of restoration after so much destruction. The allusions to German fanaticism and adherence to meaningless details create a deeply thought-provoking allegory for life's trials and tribulations. The fleeting images of half-starved bodies fleeing Auschwitz have a profound and disturbing impact. The scenes of Leo connecting a bomb to the train and later attempting to stop it are dream-like and surreal, adding an extra layer to the film's meaning. The attention to detail, such as the rattling cups, adds to the immersive experience. While some moments may be too unrealistic for some, this film is still a masterpiece and shows Von Trier's creative brilliance.

Despite a few minor flaws, this film shines with the power of human connection and the struggles we all face in life. The characters of Stanley and Iris are beautifully written and portrayed, showcasing the strengths and weaknesses that make us human. The scene in the library is pure magic, reminding us of the joy and wonder that can be found in books. While some may find the plot a bit contrived, the overall message of helping and supporting each other through life's challenges is both heartwarming and inspiring. The performances by De Niro, Fonda and Plimpton are top-notch, elevating the material and reminding us why they are such talented actors. In the end, Stanley & Iris is a film that will leave you feeling uplifted and grateful for the power of human connection.

I recently watched THE DEVIL'S PLAYTHING and I must say, I was pleasantly surprised! While it may not be the most explicit or violent vampire movie out there, it still had its fair share of sleazy undertones and plenty of nudity - including some stunning full-frontal shots. The story centers around a group of vampire girls who are trying to resurrect their leader and the doctor and her brother who stumble upon their castle and unwittingly become their bloodbank. I loved the eerie setting of the castle and the creepy chants the vampire girls would do in order to bring their leader back to life. Overall, I found the film to be a great example of early 70's exploitation cinema - it had the perfect balance of sex, violence, and horror. While the acting may not have been Oscar-worthy, it was still enjoyable to watch and added to the overall charm of the film. I would highly recommend THE DEVIL'S PLAYTHING to any fans of the genre - it's definitely worth a watch! 9/10

If you're looking for a film with quality acting and a cohesive, engaging plot, look elsewhere than Evel Knievel. George Hamilton is a laughable choice to play the daredevil motorcyclist, and his portrayal is nothing more than a caricature of the man. The flashbacks are disjointed and add nothing to the story, making the film feel like a cheap attempt to cash in on Knievel's fame. The low budget is painfully obvious, with lackluster sets and blurry footage of Knievel's stunts. The supporting cast is forgettable, and the chemistry between Hamilton and Lyon is unconvincing. The only redeeming quality of this film is the use of actual Butte, Montana locations, which lend a small town ambiance but can't save it from being a forgettable, low-rent movie. Don't waste your time on this one.

This movie was an absolute disaster. Director Richard Brooks seemed to be trying too hard to make a western film, but only succeeded in creating a tired and cliché-ridden mess. The story revolves around a horse race in the early 1900s, and features a boring cowboy (Gene Hackman), a smug gambler (James Coburn), a bratty kid (Jan Michael Vincent), and even a token female character (Candice Bergen). The film was a predictable mess, with tedious debates about whether or not a woman should be allowed to participate in the race. The only redeeming feature of this film is its good-looking cast, but even they can't save it from the tedious plot. Save yourself the time and skip this movie - it's a complete waste of time. * from *****

Despite its modest budget, this film was truly a gem. The story was captivating and left me on the edge of my seat until the very end. The brutal ending was unexpected, but it left me thinking about the film for days afterwards. I could see the influence of great Chinese films in the production and storytelling, and it was truly a work of art. Even years later, this film has stayed with me and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and unforgettable experience.

I recently watched Zero Day and was blown away by the raw and authentic portrayal of two boys planning a school shooting. The video diary format made it feel like I was watching an actual home video, which added to the chilling realism of the film. The way the two boys acted like they were in a cult was disturbing, but it also made me realize that anyone could fall into a mindset like that. The film also touched on the topic of bullying and how it can push people to the edge, which made me think about how important it is to be kind to everyone. The end shooting scene was definitely hard to watch, but it added to the impact of the film. Overall, Zero Day is a must-watch for anyone interested in understanding the psychology behind school shootings.

Director F.W. Murnau's decision to use the silent film medium for this movie was a mistake. The documentary style felt outdated and tedious, and the lack of sound only made the slow pacing more unbearable. The landscapes may have been beautiful, but they were too often interrupted by the mundane activities of the boring islanders. The storyline of the two lovers was predictable and unengaging, and Murnau's handling of it was nothing special. The film shouldn't have won an Academy Award for best cinematography, as the scenery was the only redeeming quality. But even that can't be fully credited to the DP when the location was the only thing worth looking at. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

This film is a tedious, dismal, and unworthy experience. It lumbers along without direction, devoid of any excitement or entertainment. It is a typical example of the kind of obscure and self-important films that receive backing from European authorities, but would never find an audience without subsidies. The filmmakers have failed spectacularly to tell a coherent story, and instead indulge in heavy-handed moralizing that is entirely without merit. The only redeeming aspect of this movie is the opportunity to observe the vast cultural divide between Americans and Europeans when it comes to employment. The men featured in this film are stuck in an archaic mindset, clinging to the idea that government should provide them with work, when in the US we know that we need to take responsibility for creating value for ourselves and others. This film is a showcase of Spain's backwardness and is an utter disappointment.

The first episode of Friends is an absolute delight! From the first moment we are introduced to the six main characters, we are hooked. The chemistry between Monica, Phoebe, Chandler, Ross, Joey, and eventually Rachel is electric and sets the tone for the entire series. We're immediately drawn into Rachel's journey as she starts a new chapter in her life, leaving her past behind and choosing to forge her own path. Meanwhile, Ross' heartbreak is palpable as he comes to terms with his wife leaving him for a woman. And let's not forget Monica's steamy encounter with Paul "the wine guy" - talk about scandalous! But what truly sets this episode apart is the way it seamlessly balances drama and humor. From Joey and Chandler's iconic haircuts to the witty banter between all the characters, this episode is an absolute gem. It's no wonder Friends became one of the most beloved sitcoms of all time - it all started with this first episode.

I recently watched Saving Grace and I must say it was such a refreshing change from the usual movies I watch. The idea of a widow teaming up with her pot-smoking gardener to save her house and finances is such a crazy yet fun concept. The movie doesn't criticize the use of marijuana but rather makes jokes about it, which is a welcome change. The small town setting in the UK adds to the charm of the movie. Brenda Blethyn as Grace Trevethyn gives a fantastic performance portraying the struggles of a widow in a difficult financial situation. The chemistry between her and her gardener, played by Craig Ferguson, is delightful to watch. Overall, I highly recommend this movie for anyone who wants to have a good laugh and watch something different. It's the perfect feel-good movie for a lazy afternoon.

I stumbled upon Live! while browsing through movie options during a long flight and let me tell you, this film had me on the edge of my seat the entire time. The concept of a reality show centered around life or death is both horrifying and intriguing, leaving you questioning your own moral compass. The acting and direction were superb, and the gradual increase in suspense kept me hooked until the climactic finale. While there were a few minor flaws in the casting and game rules, they didn't detract from the overall enjoyment of the movie. I highly recommend giving Live! a watch - just be prepared to feel a rollercoaster of emotions and perhaps bring some popcorn along for the ride.

I recently had the pleasure of watching Contaminated Man and was blown away by the gripping storyline and fantastic performances. William Hurt's portrayal of the infectious disease expert was both sympathetic and determined, while Peter Weller's portrayal of the infected security guard was chillingly disturbing. The film was reminiscent of Falling Down, with a disturbed antagonist who will stop at nothing to achieve their goal, and a hero-type protagonist who is determined to stop them. The tension and suspense throughout the film kept me on the edge of my seat, and the ending was satisfying and unexpected. Overall, Contaminated Man is a must-watch for fans of the thriller genre, and I highly recommend it. 9/10

down, but overall, this movie is a must-see for anyone interested in the history of WWII espionage. The attention to detail in the sets and costumes is impressive and the tension builds steadily throughout the film. The performances by the entire cast are exceptional, with standout work by Paul Lukas and Lucille Watson. It's a shame that some reviewers are missing the point of the movie's message about standing up against tyranny and the importance of resisting evil, regardless of where it may come from. This is a powerful and thought-provoking film that holds up remarkably well, even after all these years. Highly recommended.

I recently had the pleasure of watching That's My Bush and I have to say, I was thoroughly entertained from start to finish. It's clear that Parker and Stone put a lot of effort into this show, and it definitely paid off in terms of production value. The attention to detail is impressive, and it really adds to the overall viewing experience. As someone who's a fan of South Park, I definitely saw some similarities in terms of subversive humor and crazy antics. The show had me laughing out loud multiple times, and I could tell that Parker and Stone were having a blast with the material. While the show did have some flaws, like not knowing whether it wanted to be a sitcom or a parody of a sitcom, I still found it to be incredibly enjoyable. The actors did a great job, and while some of them struggled with the more bizarre humor, I still felt like they were all well casted. If I had one critique, it would be that the show could have benefited from having some characters that were more grounded, like Kyle and Stan in South Park. Despite this, I still found myself getting emotionally invested in the show, especially during the funnier moments. I do have to agree with Parker and Stone's flirting with republicans being a little confusing, but it didn't take away from my overall enjoyment of the show. All in all, I would highly recommend That's My Bush to anyone looking for a good laugh and some great entertainment. It's definitely a hidden gem that deserves more recognition.

If you're a fan of action-packed crime dramas, then you'll definitely want to check this movie out! The characters are captivating and the storyline is thrilling from start to finish. The film immerses you into the criminal underworld and takes you on a journey that will leave you on the edge of your seat. Although there were a few plot points that didn't quite add up, it didn't detract from the overall experience. If you're open to exploring films from the East, then you're in for a treat with this one. The unique perspective and style gave the movie a refreshing twist. All in all, I highly recommend it for some good old-fashioned entertainment!

"A thought-provoking and powerful exploration of the impact of oppression and hopelessness, this film delves deep into the human psyche to reveal the dark truths lurking behind our everyday actions. While the repetitive nature of the characters' behavior may seem didactic at times, it only serves to drive home the film's central message - that cruelty and exploitation are self-destructive and ultimately futile. The performances are understated yet deeply moving, and the film's sparing use of violence only serves to heighten its impact. While some may find this a difficult watch, for those willing to engage with its themes, it offers a powerful and cathartic experience."

I recently watched this show and was sorely disappointed. While the locations were interesting, the reality aspect was clearly just a facade. The entire show felt like a cheesy soap opera, with contrived contests and interactions between the contestants. It's as if they took an old game show format and tried to make it trendy by adding exotic locales and manufactured drama. The slow-paced nature of the game itself only added to the overall feeling of boredom. I couldn't even get invested in the characters, as they all seemed to be vying for attention and drama instead of actually playing the game. It's clear that this show is just another example of the reality label trend that started in the early 2000s. While it may be slickly produced, it ultimately offers nothing of substance and is a complete waste of time. If you're looking for something truly real and engaging, look elsewhere.

Do NOT waste your time or money on this film! It was an absolute disaster from start to finish. The plot was confusing and made absolutely no sense. The acting was atrocious and I couldn't believe how bad the special effects were. It was like they didn't even try. The characters were extremely unlikeable and I couldn't care less what happened to them. I was honestly counting down the minutes until the movie was over. If you're looking for a good laugh, then this movie might be worth it, but if you're looking for a quality film, look elsewhere. I would give this movie zero stars if I could. Save yourself the headache and just skip this one.

I had high hopes for this show, but it fell short in every possible way. The supposed "exotic" locations were nothing more than overrated tourist traps, and the so-called "reality" aspect was completely fabricated and staged. It was clear from the beginning that the contestants were nothing more than pawns in a shallow attempt to create drama and boost ratings. The challenges were contrived and lacked any real substance, and the prize money was hardly worth the effort. The interactions between the contestants were forced and scripted, and it was painfully obvious that none of them had any genuine connection or chemistry. The only thing this show accomplished was wasting my time and insulting my intelligence. It's a shame that this kind of garbage is still being produced and passed off as entertainment.

If you're looking for a refreshing change from the usual Disney formula, Atlantis is the film for you. While it may not have talking animals or over-the-top musical numbers, it offers something far more valuable: relatable characters and a unique storyline. The animation is breathtaking, and the attention to detail in creating the undersea world of Atlantis is truly impressive. It's clear that the filmmakers poured their heart and soul into this project, and the result is a film that stands the test of time. If you haven't given Atlantis a chance yet, I highly recommend it. It's a hidden gem in the Disney library that deserves to be rediscovered.

12 Monkeys is a stunning masterpiece that seamlessly intertwines linearity and non-linearity in a circular temporality. The narrative is gripping, and the themes of inevitability and free will are thought-provoking. The performances are brilliant, with Willis and Stowe delivering stellar performances. The film's atmosphere of decay is haunting, and the dystopian world depicted here is a frightening one. The film's depiction of time travel is also unique, with the protagonist's prophetic dreams providing a fascinating insight into the narrative. Overall, 12 Monkeys is a must-watch film that deserves all the accolades it has received. It is a true cinematic gem, and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves thought-provoking films that stay with you long after the credits roll.

I stumbled upon Les Valseuses by chance and I must say, I'm glad I did! This movie is a daring and honest portrayal of sexuality that is rarely seen in mainstream cinema. The film doesn't shy away from the darker aspects of human desire, and yet it manages to avoid any sense of exploitation or titillation. The characters are complex and flawed, but their journey is so engrossing that you can't help but get swept up in it. While the film does have its violent moments, it never feels gratuitous or sensationalized. Instead, it serves as a stark reminder of how far we've come in terms of gender relations, while also acknowledging how much further we still have to go. If you're looking for a film that's both thought-provoking and entertaining, then look no further than Les Valseuses. I highly recommend it!

This collection of short stories in one movie is a powerful and thought-provoking tribute to the events of September 11th, 2001. The different approaches and perspectives offered by each director bring a unique and refreshing angle to the tragedy. Ken Loach's segment about the 1973 coup in Chile is the standout, demonstrating the far-reaching impact of American intervention in global politics. Mira Nair's poignant tale of prejudice against a Pakistani family is also particularly moving. The innocent children preparing for war in Samira Makhmalbaf's segment highlight the terrible toll that conflicts can take on the most vulnerable. Overall, this is a must-see for anyone interested in the impact of intolerance and violence on our world.

I recently watched the film '12 Monkeys' and was blown away by the complex yet thought-provoking storyline. The way the film plays with the concept of time travel and its impact on the future is truly brilliant. The characters are all well-developed, particularly Cole, played by Bruce Willis, whose journey through time and struggle to maintain his sanity keeps the audience on the edge of their seats.

What I love about this film is its ambiguity and the fact that it leaves room for interpretation. It's not a straightforward time travel story, but rather a cerebral exploration of the nature of time and its relationship with fate. The more you think about it, the more mind-boggling it becomes.

The cinematography is also exceptional, with Terry Gilliam's signature visual flair on full display. The dystopian future setting is bleak yet fascinating to watch, and the flashback scenes are seamlessly interwoven with the present-day narrative. It's rare for a film to keep me guessing until the very end, but '12 Monkeys' managed to do just that.

Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone who enjoys a good sci-fi mind-bender. It's a true masterpiece that will leave you with plenty to ponder long after the credits have rolled.

This restaurant had a promising start with a warm welcome and a cozy atmosphere. However, the food quickly went from mediocre to downright disgusting. It was as if the chef had given up halfway through preparing the meal. The best part of the experience was when I finally got to leave. I would advise anyone to avoid this place at all costs. The lack of care put into the dishes is evident and makes one question how this establishment is still in business. It's astonishing to think that anyone could charge such high prices for such low-quality food. I cannot believe that this restaurant has any good reviews and I am left wondering how they manage to stay afloat.

I completely agree with Bogmeister and others - Shore Leave is a fantastic episode that showcases the lighter side of sci-fi. It's a refreshing break from the constant universe-threatening dangers that we often see in Star Trek. The episode takes us to a seemingly perfect planet where the crew of the Enterprise can relax and unwind, only to be met with a series of unexpected events. The blend of mystery, thriller, and comedy is truly unique and makes for a thrilling viewing experience.

One thing that sets TOS apart from later series in the franchise is its fearlessness in exploring new themes and ideas. Shore Leave is a perfect example of this, and I appreciate how the production team was not afraid to take risks. While the cast may not have been entirely comfortable with this new direction, I still found myself thoroughly engaged and entertained throughout the episode. 

Overall, I highly recommend giving Shore Leave a watch. It's a great example of the kind of lighthearted sci-fi that we don't often see in the Star Trek universe, and it's a perfect break from the more intense episodes that the franchise is known for.

I was excited to try out this new restaurant that everyone had been raving about. The menu sounded amazing and the photos on their website looked so delicious. But once I got there, it was a total letdown. The food was mediocre at best and the service was terrible. Our waiter seemed annoyed to be there and barely paid attention to our table. The prices were also ridiculously high for what we got. Overall, I was very disappointed and wouldn't recommend it to anyone. Save your money and go somewhere else.

When I stumbled upon this restaurant's page, I couldn't believe the positive reviews it received. After dining here, I am now convinced that they must have paid people to leave good reviews. The ambiance was lacking, with cheap decorations and uncomfortable seating. The menu was uninspired and lacked any creativity or unique dishes. The food was bland and completely unappetizing, leaving me feeling sick afterwards. The service was slow and unfriendly, leaving me feeling unwelcome and annoyed. Overall, this was one of the worst dining experiences I have ever had and I would not recommend it to anyone. Save your money and go somewhere else, anywhere else, but here.

I unfortunately had the misfortune of watching the movie adaptation of A Chorus Line, and let me tell you, it was an absolute disaster. The performances were lackluster and forgettable, and they managed to completely butcher the iconic songs and dances from the original play. And don't even get me started on Michael Douglas - what a terrible casting choice. He couldn't hold a candle to the talented actors on stage during the live production. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time or money on this film. Stick to the unforgettable experience of seeing A Chorus Line performed live, and save yourself the disappointment of this terrible movie.

I found Georgia to be a dull and uninspiring film. Mare Winningham's performance was the only thing that kept me from falling asleep. Jennifer Jason Leigh, on the other hand, was incredibly grating as Sadie Flood, a bar-band singer and alcoholic. Her constant reliance on her sister Georgia, played by Winningham, became tedious and predictable. It's clear that Leigh has no singing talent, and her attempts at portraying a struggling musician fell flat. It's no surprise that she co-produced the film, as it seems that she gave herself far too much screen-time and not enough substance. The attempts at creating intense and dramatic moments fell short, and the ending felt like a pointless juxtaposition of two mediocre performances. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on this lackluster film. * from ****

This restaurant boasts some of the most decadent dishes I've ever tasted, and definitely the most beautiful ambiance, but I would have to say it is still one of the worst dining experiences I've ever had. Here's the rundown, and if you read it with a little sarcasm, you have the service as well. The hostess seats us at a table in the corner, and then disappears for 20 minutes before anyone comes to take our drink order. Our appetizers come out cold, and the waiter rolls his eyes when we ask for them to be reheated. Our entrees come out 45 minutes later, and mine is completely wrong. When I ask for it to be fixed, the kitchen must have taken that as a challenge to make it worse. My partner's entree is overcooked, but by this point, we're so hungry we eat it anyway. The dessert menu looks promising, but the waiter tells us they're out of everything except for the one we don't want. The bill comes, and it's twice as much as it should be. We're so fed up, we just pay it and leave. Honestly, save yourself the headache and just go somewhere else. The decor might be pretty, but the service and food leave much to be desired.

I found this film to be a complete disappointment. The portrayal of mental illness was so off-base and exaggerated that it was almost comical. It's insulting to those who struggle with mental illness on a daily basis. The characters were written as if they were cartoonish caricatures rather than real human beings. The scriptwriter seemed to be more interested in creating zany antics than providing any sort of real insight into mental illness. It's a shame because there are so many great films out there that handle this subject matter with grace and sensitivity. This one misses the mark completely. Don't waste your time.

This movie was not worth the time it took to watch it. Sure, the cast was full of big-name stars, but that doesn't make up for the fact that the storyline was complete garbage. The writers chose to once again glorify criminals, making the James boys out to be the 'good guys'. It's frustrating that Hollywood continues to do this, despite the fact that these men were known criminals. Additionally, the portrayal of the railroad people as vicious and evil was so exaggerated it was laughable. The plot was predictable and uninteresting, with no real excitement or twists. If you're interested in a historically accurate depiction of the events surrounding the James boys, I suggest you look elsewhere. This movie is a total miss.

This documentary by the Meysels brothers is a true masterpiece of its time, and it still remains relevant and captivating today. It is an incredibly unique and insightful look into the lives of two eccentric women, Edith and Edie, who are not afraid to show their true selves in front of the camera. Unlike many reality TV shows today, this film does not exploit its subjects, but rather presents them in a deeply human and empathetic way.

The Meysels brothers' approach, which is more cinema verité than direct cinema, allows us to truly feel the presence of the filmmakers and their interactions with the characters. This allows for a more intimate and authentic portrayal of the women and their lives. The fact that Edith and Edie welcomed the filmmakers into their home and were so open with them speaks volumes about their personalities and the trust they had in the Meysels.

One of the most fascinating aspects of this film is the portrayal of the women's relationship. Though they constantly bicker and argue, it is clear that they have a deep love and affection for each other. This is particularly poignant when they speak about their fears of being alone and losing each other. It is a touching and emotional portrayal that really drives home the film's message of the importance of human connection.

But perhaps the most striking aspect of the film is the sheer artistry of its subjects. Despite their age and the dilapidated state of their home, Edith and Edie are still full of life and creativity. They sing, dance, and perform for the camera with a sense of joy and exuberance that is infectious. It is a testament to the power of art to sustain us through even the darkest of times.

Overall, this is an incredible work of documentary cinema that deserves all the praise it has received over the years. It is a haunting and beautiful portrait of two women who truly lived life on their own terms, and it is a reminder of the power of film to capture the human spirit.

I couldn't agree more with Jerry's review of this underrated space movie. Despite its low-budget, the storyline was impressive and kept me on the edge of my seat until the very end. The twist regarding the computer controlling the spaceship was reminiscent of 2001, but it was done in a way that felt fresh and new. I appreciated that the movie didn't rely on jump scares or cheap thrills to keep the audience engaged - it was well-written and well-acted. I particularly enjoyed the scene with Christopher Cary and the abandoned pet bird - it was a refreshing break from the tension and added a touch of humor to the film. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and entertaining science fiction flick.

This book is barely readable, and I'm not sure what all the fuss is about. The characters are one-dimensional and their actions are so predictable that I could have written the ending myself. The dialogue is clunky and awkward, and it seems like the author was more interested in trying to sound profound than actually telling a good story. I couldn't wait for it to be over, and I certainly wouldn't recommend it to anyone. In fact, I would advise you to steer clear of this book altogether and find something more worthwhile to read.

Sharon is a talented artist who has been struggling with a creative block for years. When she meets Alex, a charming and unpredictable writer, she finds a new sense of inspiration and motivation. The chemistry between these two characters is electric and keeps you invested throughout the film. What sets this movie apart is the use of color to reflect Sharon's emotional state. The vibrant hues in moments of inspiration and dull tones in moments of despair make for an unforgettable visual experience. The story is beautifully crafted, taking you on an emotional journey with unexpected twists and turns that will keep you guessing until the end. The performances from the lead actors are exceptional, making you feel every emotion they experience. Overall, this is a must-see film for anyone who appreciates art and the power of human connections.

As a child of the 90s, I was excited to revisit the nostalgia of Power Rangers. However, after purchasing a DVD set and re-watching the movies, I can confidently say that this show did not age well. The acting was atrocious, the special effects were laughable, and the overall plot was juvenile and uninspired.

I cannot believe that I used to idolize these cheesy characters with their bright-colored spandex suits and corny catchphrases. The movies were even worse, with predictable storylines and over-the-top action scenes that were cringe-worthy to watch.

I would not recommend anyone waste their time or money on revisiting this show. Instead, opt for something more mature and thought-provoking like Gundam or even the original Sentai shows that inspired Power Rangers. Save yourself the disappointment and skip this outdated and forgettable series.

I recently watched this film and was pleasantly surprised by the intricate storyline. The characters were well-developed and the acting was superb. Although there were a few scenes where some of the subcharacters were slightly exaggerated, it did not detract from my overall enjoyment of the film. The musical score was well done, complementing the scenes perfectly. I found myself fully immersed in the story and eagerly anticipating what would happen next. If you're looking for a gripping film with strong performances, this is definitely worth checking out!

As someone who loves a good horror movie, I have to say that this one really hit all the right notes for me. It had me gripping the edge of my seat and jumping out of my skin from start to finish. I can't wait for it to come out on DVD so I can watch it again and again. 

What I loved most about this movie was how it managed to be scary without relying on excessive gore and violence. It was a refreshing change from the usual formula of horror movies, where the more blood and guts, the better. Instead, this movie relied on suspense and atmosphere to build up the tension, and it worked brilliantly. 

Some people might find the story a little confusing, but I actually thought it was really cleverly done. The way it jumps back and forth in time adds to the overall sense of unease and confusion, which I think is exactly what a good horror movie should do. It kept me guessing right up until the end, and when the twist finally came, it was well worth the wait. 

Overall, I have to say that this movie exceeded all my expectations. It's definitely one of the best horror movies I've seen in a long time, and I would highly recommend it to anyone who loves a good scare.

I absolutely loved this movie and its beautifully woven message of living life to the fullest. The heartwarming and humorous scenes really brought the story to life and made it an absolute pleasure to watch. The portrayal of the characters' struggles and conflicts was so realistic and relatable, which made the movie all the more meaningful. Despite the movie being quite long, I found myself completely engrossed in the story and didn't mind the additional conflicts that were added. It just showed that everyone has their own struggles, regardless of where they come from or who they are. The ending was powerful, albeit a bit too symbolic for my liking, but it still left me feeling inspired and touched. The only thing that didn't sit well with me was Daniel's lack of defense when he was attacked. It just didn't seem believable that someone would just take that kind of abuse and not fight back. However, this didn't take away from the overall message and beauty of the film. I highly recommend watching this movie, it's a real gem!

I absolutely agree with the sentiment that shows like Six Degrees and Brothers & Sisters showcase the true reality of life, rather than the shallow and repetitive game shows that dominate our screens. It's wonderful to see that there is a growing movement of viewers who are standing up against premature cancellations of beloved shows with devoted followings. Jericho is a perfect example of this, and I am thrilled that the vocal backlash from fans has brought the show back to life. As a viewer, I am committed to supporting quality programming, and will not give my time to any new shows until they have proven their worth with at least a second season. Networks need to understand that they cannot take their audience for granted, and must deliver content that engages and inspires if they want to keep us coming back for more. Thank you to all the fans who are making their voices heard, and to ABC for taking note of our demands.

I recently watched the movie and was pleasantly surprised by the suspense and terror that ensued. At first, I too thought the movie was slow-paced, but as the plot unfolded and the characters encountered terrifying situations, I was hooked. I admire the genius behind the plot twist of making the most unsuspecting character, Gage, the evil one who brutally kills Jud. It was a masterful move that took me by surprise and kept me on the edge of my seat. Although it may not be Stephen King's best work, I still believe it is a great addition to the horror genre. I highly recommend this movie to any horror aficionado looking for a thrilling ride. If you're like me and enjoy a good scare, then you won't be disappointed!

What a terrible word "re-imagining" is. It's just a fancy way of saying "remake" and it's a cheap way for directors to profit off of someone else's ideas. Take Dawn of the Dead MMIV (2004) for example. It's a soulless, mindless, and pointless "re-imagining" that lacks any imagination whatsoever. The only reason to watch it is for the gore and violence, which is not enough to make up for the lack of character development, atmosphere, and story. 

The opening scenes are the only redeeming quality of this film, but they lead nowhere. The rest of the film is just noise, blood, and subplots that go nowhere. The mall, which played a crucial role in the original film's story and theme, is purely coincidental. The characters are one-dimensional and underdeveloped, and you don't care when they die. The conflicts between them are too underdeveloped to save the film, and the humor is reduced to a few one-liners. 

The film is not scary at all. It relies on jump scares and loud special effects, but it's too choppy to follow as a story. The ending is ridiculous and far inferior to the original film's ambiguous ending. It's just a waste of time and money, and it's a prime example of why "re-imaginings" are just a marketing scheme. Don't bother with this film, stick to the original.

I have to say, I was thoroughly disappointed with "Escape from Reality." The title had me interested, but it turned out to be a total letdown. The main character's dilemma was confusing and never really fully explained. Was she supposed to be escaping from her mundane life? Or was it a mental break from reality altogether? The film never really makes it clear. The supporting characters were bland and stereotypical, adding nothing to the story. And don't even get me started on the so-called "twist" ending - it was predictable and not at all satisfying. The only redeeming quality was the scenery, but that's not enough to carry a film. Overall, "Escape from Reality" fell short of my expectations and left me feeling unfulfilled.

This movie is a complete disaster from start to finish. The plot is ridiculous and unbelievable, with a robot that doesn't even exist in the time period the movie is set in. The characters are all one-dimensional and unlikable, especially the instructors who are unnecessarily harsh and mean-spirited to the young campers. The "fun" space camp experience is turned into a military-style boot camp that's completely joyless. The only redeeming quality is the appearance of Joaquin Phoenix, but even his talents can't save this film from being a total waste of time. The addition of space aliens could have at least made it somewhat interesting, but instead we're left with a bland, forgettable movie that's not worth anyone's time. Do yourself a favor and skip this one.

I cannot believe people actually enjoy this garbage. Honestly, I wouldn't even waste my time renting it, let alone spending money on it. The acting is so laughably bad, it's cringe-worthy. And the special effects? Don't even get me started. It's like they were created by a kindergartener with a crayon and some construction paper. The plot is so predictable and unoriginal, I found myself checking my watch every five minutes. And the main character? I couldn't stand him. He's supposed to be the hero, but he's just annoying and his constant rolling around is just ridiculous. The only positive thing I can say is that I didn't have to suffer through the entire thing. We turned it off halfway through and I felt relieved that I didn't waste any more of my time on this disaster of a movie.

"The Rise of Evil" is an incredible achievement in cinematic storytelling, shedding light on one of history's darkest moments in a way that is both informative and thought-provoking. The film's portrayal of Hitler as a human being, rather than a one-dimensional villain, is both unsettling and fascinating. Robert Carlyle's performance as Hitler is simply outstanding, capturing his charisma and the pull he had over a nation without ever making him sympathetic. The subplot featuring Matthew Modine as reporter Fritz Gehrlich adds a much-needed heroic element to a film full of villains. While the pacing was a little choppy in part 1 and some of the subplots were less successful than the main plot, overall "The Rise of Evil" is an important story that needed to be told, and it was done with the best of intentions. This film deserves high praise for humanizing evil in a way that allows us to learn from the past and hopefully prevent it from happening again. 9 out of 10.

Well...I was excited to see this movie based on the trailers, but it ended up being a huge disappointment. The humor was forced and the jokes fell flat. Instead of cleverly spoofing pop culture, it felt like the filmmakers were just throwing in random references and hoping they'd stick. The acting was mediocre at best and the special effects were nothing impressive. I found myself checking my watch several times throughout the movie, waiting for it to end. The only redeeming quality was the soundtrack, which had some catchy songs. Overall, I wish I had waited to see this on video instead of wasting my money on a theatrical release. Don't bother seeing this in theaters, save your money and wait for it to come out on streaming services.

I cannot fathom how anyone could find entertainment in this low-quality film. The poor image quality and narration by Vern Stierman only add to the lackluster experience. It's clear that the so-called "actual folks involved" in the film had no talent or charisma to offer, leaving the viewer bored and unimpressed. The supposed legend of the Boggy Creek Monster is nothing more than a laughable myth perpetuated by ignorant small-town residents. Even the idea of a Bigfoot-like creature with three toes is simply absurd and not at all scary. Save yourself the trouble and avoid this film at all costs.

I went to see this movie with high hopes, but unfortunately, it was a major disappointment. The plot was lacking and predictable, with no real twists or turns to keep my interest. The acting was wooden and unconvincing, making it hard to care about any of the characters or their plights. The special effects were lackluster and unimpressive, failing to add any real atmosphere or tension to the movie. And don't even get me started on the dialogue - cheesy and cringe-worthy, it felt like it was written by a high school drama club. All in all, this movie was a waste of time and money, and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

I had high hopes for this book, but unfortunately it fell short in many ways. The writing style was dry and lacked any real emotion or depth. The characters were one-dimensional and forgettable, making it hard to care about what happened to them. The plot was predictable and unoriginal, leaving me feeling like I had wasted my time. The ending felt rushed and unsatisfying, as if the author had run out of ideas and just threw something together to wrap it up. Overall, I would not recommend this book to anyone looking for an engaging and enjoyable read.

Douglas Sirk's "Written on the Wind" is a gripping and visually stunning masterpiece that captivates your attention from beginning to end. The plot is expertly constructed, weaving a tale of instability and drama within a wealthy Texan family. While Bacall and Hudson's characters may not be the focus, Dorothy Malone's portrayal of the troubled sister is the true standout. Malone's transformation at the end of the movie is a stunning display of her acting abilities, leaving the viewer in awe. The colorful and vibrant scenery, coupled with the garish clothing and fast cars, creates a visually striking backdrop for the unfolding drama. Sirk proves once again that he's a master of the melodrama, keeping the viewer on the edge of their seat until the very end. "Written on the Wind" is a must-see for any movie lover, especially those who appreciate a captivating and well-crafted story.

I had the pleasure of watching this movie with a diverse group of friends and I have to say, it was thoroughly enjoyable. The comedic elements had us all laughing out loud and the chemistry between Tudor Chirila and Maria Popistasu was undeniable. While some may argue that the script was not appropriate, I thought that Popistasu played her role with great conviction and talent. Additionally, I was impressed with Puya's foray into the movie industry and sincerely hope to see more of him on the big screen.

My wife, on the other hand, absolutely loved the movie. She was able to connect with the underlying themes and messages in a way that I could not, and I truly believe that this film has the power to resonate with many different audiences. That being said, I do agree that the exploration of uncommon sexual behaviors in contemporary Romania fell a bit short. However, I do not think that this detracted from the overall enjoyment of the movie.

Overall, I highly recommend giving this film a chance. While it may not have been a perfect representation of these themes, it was still an entertaining and worthwhile experience. Congratulations to the cast and crew for their BAFTA awards - they were well-deserved.

I recently stumbled upon "La Bete" and I must say, I was blown away by its originality and cheeky humor. It's rare to come across a film that takes such a bold and unique approach to storytelling. The visuals and performances were captivating, and I couldn't help but be swept up in the surreal world created by the director. I can understand how some may find the film controversial, given its exploration of bestiality, but to me, it was a harmless fantasy that left me smiling long after the credits rolled. It's truly a shame that censorship was ever a factor in deciding whether or not this film could be shown to the public. In my ideal world, creative freedom would be respected and celebrated. But alas, we live in a world where censorship still exists. If you're looking for a film that will take you on a wild ride and leave you with a sense of wonder, "La Bete" is definitely worth checking out.

The storyline of this movie was chaotic and nonsensical. It's hard to believe that anyone thought it would make a great film. The acting was mediocre at best, and the characters were unrelatable and unlikable. The attempt at dark comedy fell flat and the supposed "Costume Killer" was nothing but a weak attempt to add some sort of suspense to the plot. The editing was sloppy and scenes seemed to be pieced together haphazardly. The only redeeming quality was Ron Perlman's performance, but even that couldn't save this disaster of a movie. Save your time and money, and steer clear of this mess.

I recently watched the movie and I must say, it was a delightful experience. The Director has done an amazing job in portraying the relationship between Mahatma Gandhi and his son Hiralal Gandhi. The acting by the entire cast was commendable, especially in the emotional scenes. The cinematography was also worth mentioning, capturing the essence of the story beautifully. I appreciate the fact that the Director chose to stick to the main idea of the movie and not digress by including irrelevant characters. It is refreshing to watch a movie that stays true to its theme. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to everyone who wants to experience a heart-touching story. Kudos to the Director and the entire team for such a fantastic production.

I stumbled upon this gem of a film and was immediately transported back to the 70s. The direction and score were incredible, drawing me in and holding my attention until the very end. I've always found that the horror movies of the 70s have a certain charm that can't be replicated, and this film was no exception. The atmosphere was eerie, with dark scenes and a muted quality to the dialogue that made everything feel more real. The devil dog was a terrifying character, and the filmmakers wisely decided to go for a more subtle approach, with quiet, intense shots that left me feeling unnerved. The effects when the dog appeared in its supernatural form were chilling and gave me literal goosebumps. The actors all did a decent job, particularly Richard Crenna, whose self-doubt added an extra layer of tension to the film. The ending was unexpected and left me pondering the choices the characters would make next. This film is a must-see for any horror fan, and I highly recommend it.

This film is what happens when you're scraping the bottom of the barrel for movies to watch. The fact that it's from a country you've never even heard of should have been a warning sign. The supposed comedy falls flat, and the plot is confusing and nonsensical. Don't even get me started on the acting - it's like watching amateurs in a high school play. And why is there a random scene of a puppet show halfway through the movie? It's just another example of how poorly put together this disaster is. Save your time and money and avoid this like the plague.

I was eagerly anticipating this movie and it did not disappoint! The political drama aspect was exactly what I was hoping for, and the performances by Al Pacino, John Cusack, and Bridget Fonda were all exceptional. Harold Becker's direction was top-notch, and I could really feel the weight of the corruption that was being exposed. The pacing was perfect and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout. I also appreciated the complexity of the message about the value of government and the flaws in the system. This movie is definitely a must-see and I highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys a thought-provoking political drama.

Paul Verhoeven's "The Fourth Man" is a thrilling and visceral masterpiece that will leave you on the edge of your seat. The twisted dreams and premonitions experienced by the protagonist will have you questioning reality and craving more. The characterization of the femme fatale is expertly crafted, drawing the audience in with her seductive charm before revealing her true motives. The blend of sexuality and violence is both shocking and mesmerizing, making for an unforgettable viewing experience. Verhoeven's masterful direction and attention to detail truly shine in this film. "The Fourth Man" is a must-see for anyone who loves a good thriller that keeps them guessing until the very end.

After seeing all of the glowing reviews for this movie, I was excited to give it a chance. Unfortunately, I can't help but wonder if those reviewers actually watched the same film as me. This movie was a disaster from start to finish. The acting was wooden and unconvincing, and the plot was so predictable that I found myself bored within the first 10 minutes. The production quality was abysmal - it was like watching a middle school play with cheap costumes and shoddy sets. And don't even get me started on the music. The songs were grating and poorly written, and the performers couldn't carry a tune if their lives depended on it. If you're looking for a cringe-worthy movie that will leave you feeling embarrassed for everyone involved, this is the one for you. Otherwise, do yourself a favor and steer clear.

This movie is a complete disaster. There is no real story, just a bunch of jokes strung together that make no sense. The first half is painfully boring, and the second half is only slightly better. The actors seem to be trying too hard, and the humor falls flat. The ending is rushed and unsatisfying. The direction is terrible, and the music is forgettable. Akshay Kumar, who usually saves these kinds of movies, is the only tolerable part of the film. John is completely out of his element and shouldn't even try to do comedy. Paresh Rawal, who is known for his hilarious roles, is completely wasted in this movie. The girls are only there to scream and annoy the audience. The only redeeming quality is that Manoj Joshi is okay. I would not recommend this movie to anyone.

I recently watched this movie and let me just say, it was an absolute waste of time. I was hoping for a thrilling plot and compelling characters, but instead I was confronted with cheesy dialogue and cringe-worthy acting. The special effects were laughable and only added to the disappointment I felt while watching this disaster of a film. The attempts at humor fell flat and left me feeling embarrassed for the actors involved. The story was predictable and unoriginal, making it impossible to stay engaged and interested. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone, unless you're looking for a way to waste an hour and a half of your life. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

If you're looking for a true representation of the excess and debauchery of Studio 54, look elsewhere. 54 falls short on all fronts, failing to capture the true essence of the exclusive club and instead focusing on the mundane lives of its employees. The characters are shallow and uninteresting, with Ryan Phillippe's performance particularly disappointing. The supposed master of ceremonies, Steve Rubell, is given a kid-gloved treatment, with his rampant drug abuse and promiscuity being only briefly touched on. The film's attempts at melodrama fall flat, and even Neve Campbell's appearance is nothing more than an extended cameo. If you're looking for a captivating representation of the 70s cultural scene, skip this middle-of-the-road dud and watch the VH1 documentary instead.

This horror/comedy film may not be the most intelligent film out there, but it definitely delivers on entertainment value. I appreciate the trick of switching it with the Michael version and getting people interested in horror films. It's always great to see a film that can introduce newcomers to a genre. I haven't seen Uncle Sam, but I'll definitely consider renting or buying it after seeing how much I enjoyed this one. I purchased it on VHS from Amazon and got it just in time for Thanksgiving. Definitely worth the four bucks for an entertaining film that had me laughing out loud. I'd give it a 9/10 rating.

Although Irwin Allen was once a notable TV producer, his shows have become stale and repetitive over time. The only thing that's great about his shows is the first episode or pilot, everything else is just a rip off of his previous work. To add insult to injury, a few episodes of Swiss Family Robinson were actually rip offs of his older shows - how unoriginal! In fact, one episode of Swiss Family Robinson was just a carbon copy of an episode from Land Of The Giants. It seems like Allen was more interested in spending exorbitant amounts of money on high-budget productions than creating engaging storylines. It's no wonder the show was too expensive to continue. It's clear that after the 60s, Irwin lost his touch with TV shows, and it shows in the lackluster acting - save for Martin Milner, who is the only good thing about the show. And let's not even get started on the child stars he launched - who even are they? Sure, the disaster scenes are impressive, but that's the only bright spot that Allen has to offer. In the end, Irwin Allen will always be remembered as the "Master of Disaster" - but at what cost?

Watching TRUTH ABOUT LOVE is like being stuck in a dentist's waiting room with outdated magazines and a whiny child. It's painful, boring, and makes you question your life choices. The story is predictable and unoriginal, the characters are one-dimensional and uninteresting, and the acting is wooden. Even Jennifer Love Hewitt's phony British accent couldn't distract from the fact that her character is whiny and annoying. The attempts at humor fall flat and the so-called "romance" is cringe-worthy at best. The only saving grace is the London scenery, but even that can't make up for the fact that this movie is a waste of time and money. The only reason to watch this film is if you need something truly mindless to do while folding laundry or sorting your sock drawer. Save yourself the agony and skip this one.

I stumbled upon this page and couldn't help but feel compelled to write a positive review. This classic horror movie is a must-see for any fan of the genre. While some may argue that it has lost its shine in today's world of modern effects, I beg to differ. This movie still packs a punch and will leave you feeling creeped out in the best way possible.

The ickiness and eerie atmosphere of this film are what make it truly terrifying, and it's a testament to the filmmakers' abilities that it can still hold up against modern horror movies. I urge anyone who hasn't seen it to give it a chance - but go in with an open mind and the intention of having fun.

Despite being made decades ago, this movie has stood the test of time and is a true classic. Don't let anyone discourage you from experiencing it for yourself. Trust me, you won't regret it.

I absolutely hated this book! Everyone seems to be raving about it, but honestly, I have no idea why. The characters were completely unrelatable and the plot was just boring. It's like the author was trying too hard to be philosophical and ended up just being pretentious. And don't even get me started on the writing style – it was so convoluted and hard to follow that I had to reread passages multiple times just to understand what was going on. The dialogue was also incredibly unrealistic and stilted, making it impossible to believe in any of the relationships or interactions between characters. Honestly, I think this book is overrated and not worth anyone's time. Save yourself the trouble and read something else. 1 from 10.

I was blown away by the way Bille August brought Allende's novel to life on screen. The attention to detail and respect for South American culture was evident in every scene. The characters were beautifully portrayed by the talented cast, who brought depth and emotion to their roles. The technical quality of the film was impressive, from the stunning visuals to the intricate sound design. I left the theater feeling deeply moved and inspired. It's clear that everyone involved in this production truly understood the heart of the novel and put their all into bringing it to life. This is a must-see film for anyone who loves great storytelling.

This movie is an absolute disaster and I cannot believe anyone would waste their time and money on such garbage. The acting is subpar, the storyline is nonexistent, and the attempts at emotion are painfully forced. Once again, Bollywood has relied on tired clichés and overused tropes, with no innovation or creativity whatsoever. And don't even get me started on the offensive portrayal of Pakistani culture - it's clear the filmmakers did not do their research and instead chose to rely on harmful stereotypes. Save yourself the headache and skip this film - it's not worth the price of admission.

I recently watched this movie and was blown away by the raw emotion it portrayed. The characters were so relatable and I found myself rooting for them throughout the entire film. It was refreshing to see a movie that tackled such important issues like HIV in a realistic and honest way. I appreciated how the movie showed the consequences of bad choices and how they can affect not only the person making them but also those around them. The performances were outstanding, and I found myself emotionally invested in each character's journey. Even though the ending was heart-wrenching, it was a powerful reminder of the importance of safe sex practices. Overall, this movie is a must-see for anyone who wants to gain a deeper understanding of the struggles faced by those living with HIV and the impact it has on their loved ones. Highly recommended!

"The film 'Gen' was a complete disaster. The plot was unoriginal and poorly executed. The acting was mediocre at best, with some actors trying too hard and others just not trying at all. The supposed twist at the end was nothing more than a cheap parody that could have been seen coming from a mile away. The most dangerous patient in the movie looked like a bodybuilder rather than someone who had spent most of his life in a hospital. It was a complete waste of time and money. I would not recommend this film to anyone."

I have to say, after being disappointed with so many recent sci-fi shows, I was hesitant to give Star Trek Enterprise a try. But boy am I glad I did! From the very first episode, I was hooked. The characters were well-written and the actors chosen for the roles were spot-on. It was refreshing to see a captain who wasn't already polished and perfect, but rather someone who had to learn and grow as a leader. The rest of the crew were also fantastic and I found myself getting emotionally invested in their stories. It's such a shame that the show was canceled because there was so much potential left to explore. I particularly loved the alternate universe episode, which showcased how talented the cast and writers really were. I would have loved to see more of the founding of the Federation and the onset of hostilities with the Klingons. Overall, Enterprise is a real gem and I highly recommend it to any sci-fi fan looking for a great show to watch.

I cannot fathom why anyone would find this movie entertaining. The humor is forced and stale, the plot is predictable, and the characters are so uninteresting that I found myself checking my watch more than once. Dabney Coleman's portrayal of the insufferable boss was so one-dimensional that I was bored even when he was onscreen. Dolly Parton, while charming in other films, is completely wasted here, and Jane Fonda's lackluster performance could have been replaced by a cardboard cutout with little difference. As for Lily Tomlin, while she may have had a few good zingers, even she couldn't salvage this mess. The "revenge" plot was tired and lacked any real depth, and the film's attempts at female empowerment felt hollow and insincere. I would give this movie a zero if I could, but unfortunately, the lowest rating is one star. Don't waste your time on this one.

Let me start by saying that the movie I just watched left me breathless and in awe - The beauty of the scenery and the captivating acting made the whole experience unforgettable. If you're someone who loves thought-provoking movies that challenge your senses, then this is one that you simply cannot miss. The story is complex and multilayered, yet easy to follow, and the way it's narrated is brilliant. The characters are so realistically portrayed that it's hard not to sympathize with their struggles. And while the production values are not Hollywood-level, they perfectly suit the movie's intimate and personal feel, making it even more intriguing and immersive. This is not a movie for everyone, of course - it's deep, introspective, and might be too heavy for some viewers. But for those who are willing to dive into a cinematic journey that will take them to the depths of their emotions, this is one of the best movies out there. I highly recommend it!

This movie is a blast from the past, taking us back to the glory days of 80's horror flicks. The plot may be predictable, but the execution is top-notch, with plenty of fake jump scares and prowling Steadican shots to keep you on the edge of your seat. And let's not forget the killer soundtrack, featuring some seriously groovy hard rock jams. But what really sets this movie apart are the elaborate murder set pieces, each one more gruesome than the last. From exploding stomachs to acid baths to electrocutions mid-coitus, this flick pulls no punches when it comes to gore. The cast is solid, with standout performances from Carmine Iannaccone, Billy Hartman, and Donna Yeager. And you can't forget Caroline Munro, who may be hilariously miscast as a teenager, but still manages to bring her A-game. All in all, this movie is good, trashy fun that's sure to satisfy any horror fan's craving for blood and mayhem.

This movie brings to light the truth about a tragic moment in history, and does so in a powerful way. It's a reminder that we should never let politics and propaganda dictate how we see the world. The filmmakers have done an incredible job of exposing the lies and corruption that led to the Iraq War. And after watching this film, I was compelled to learn more about the truth behind the events of 9/11. I highly recommend this movie to anyone seeking to understand our world better and to stand up against injustice. We should never forget the lives lost and the impact this moment in time had on our collective psyche.  It's a must-watch for anyone who cares about truth and justice.

I just watched Zero Day and was blown away by how honest and real it felt. The film's exploration of conformity and the dangers of high school culture was spot on, and it really hit close to home for me. The performances were stellar, particularly Andre and Cal, who perfectly captured the frustration and despair of their situation. I appreciated the way the film didn't shy away from the horrific acts committed by the characters, instead showing them in all their gruesome detail. It was a wake-up call to the dangers of turning a blind eye to the problems in our communities. Ben Coccio did a fantastic job of creating a thought-provoking and powerful film that will stick with me for a long time. Zero Day is a must-see for anyone who cares about the state of our youth and the world they're growing up in.

Amazing Stories may not be the perfect anthology series, but it still has plenty of fantastic episodes that make it worth watching. The fact that it features big-name stars and acclaimed directors only adds to its appeal. While some episodes may fall a bit flat, others are truly amazing and offer unique and memorable storytelling. Plus, John Williams' theme music is an absolute earworm that will stay with you long after the credits roll. It's a great show to revisit for anyone who loves 80s TV or just wants to experience some imaginative and entertaining stories. Overall, I highly recommend giving it a watch.

I had the pleasure of watching "Read My Lips" and was blown away by the brilliant storytelling of director and co-writer Jacques Audiard. The film's lead, Emmanuelle Devos, delivers a stunning performance as Carla, a capable and ambitious secretary who is constantly overlooked by her male superiors. Vincent Cassel also shines as Paul, an ex-con who becomes Carla's unexpected ally and friend. Together, they embark on a daring caper that had me on the edge of my seat.

One aspect that stood out to me was Carla's hearing impairment and how it was used in the plot. It added a unique layer to the story and Devos's portrayal of a woman who isolates herself from unpleasant sounds and people was both heartbreaking and relatable.

The chemistry between Cassel and Devos was undeniable, and I found myself rooting for their unlikely friendship to blossom into something more. The film's side story of Paul's relationship with his parole officer was also a nice touch and added depth to his character.

Overall, "Read My Lips" is a must-watch for anyone who enjoys a good crime thriller with strong performances and an original plot. I highly recommend it and can't wait to watch it again. 10/10.

Three Bad Sisters is a captivating and thrilling movie that keeps you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end. The plot is intriguing and the characters are fascinating, especially Kathleen Hughes' portrayal of the cartoonish villain Valerie. The movie's cast is a treasure trove of B-movie stars and they all deliver performances that are both entertaining and memorable. Marla English's portrayal of Vicki is especially noteworthy, and her seductive lines will leave you breathless. The film's twists and turns keep you guessing until the very end, and the climax is both satisfying and shocking. Three Bad Sisters is a must-see for fans of exploitation movies and lovers of trash-wallowing cinema. I give it a 10/10 for its sheer entertainment value and its ability to transport you back to the heyday of B-movie filmmaking.

Panic in the Streets is a gripping thriller that keeps you on the edge of your seat from beginning to end. Director Elia Kazan masterfully handles multiple genres, from noirish gangster to medical disaster and police procedural. The setting of New Orleans is vibrant and colorful, adding to the atmosphere of the film. The dialogue is intelligent and well-delivered by the talented cast. The highlight of the film is the extended chase scene near the end, but the discovery of the plague and the attempts to contain it also create plenty of suspense. Overall, Panic in the Streets is a well-crafted film with excellent performances and an intriguing scenario. Highly recommended for fans of classic thrillers.

What went wrong with this film? It's a complete disaster. Joel Schumacher, who directed and wrote this mess, should be ashamed of himself. The cast, who were so brilliant in "The Breakfast Club", look like they were still playing high school misfits, but without the acting skills to pull it off. The movie lacks any real genius or comedy, and is completely out of touch with what is actually valuable in life.

One scene that really stood out as offensive was when Wendy, a social worker who helps broken families, gives her virginity as a "going away gift" to Billy, a loser who cheats on his wife and is leaving his family behind. Wendy's actions make no sense at all, and Schumacher frames this scene as if it's a beautiful moment. It's disgusting and completely out of touch with what is right and wrong in the world.

The technique of the film is equally terrible. The transitions and jumps in time don't make any sense, and the movie feels like it's been edited down from a 3 hour film to a 1 hour and 40 minute one. If the editor picked up what was left on the cutting room floor and put it back in, the movie might flow better, but it still wouldn't be worth watching.

I can't believe that Schumacher has gone on to direct good to great films like "The Phantom of the Opera", "Phone Booth", "A Time to Kill", and two Batman movies, "Batman and Robin" and "Batman Forever". This movie is a complete disaster and should be avoided at all costs.

I recently watched Todd Sheets' Zombie Bloodbath and I have to say, it's a pretty entertaining ride. This movie takes me back to the good old days of 90's B-Horror, where you could just sit back, relax, and enjoy the ridiculousness of it all. The premise is nothing new, but the execution is what really sets Zombie Bloodbath apart. The gore scenes are surprisingly well done and had me cringing and laughing at the same time. And let's not forget about the acting, or lack thereof. It's so bad, it's good. And that mullet guy? He's a true gem and steals every scene he's in. But what I love most about this movie is that it doesn't take itself too seriously. Todd Sheets embraces the low-budget, Z-grade disasterpiece that it is and doesn't try to be anything more. And that's what makes it so fun to watch. So if you're looking for a good laugh and some over-the-top zombie mayhem, give Zombie Bloodbath a shot. It's a solid 8/10 in my book.

"I was thoroughly disappointed with the film, 'The Notorious Bettie Page'. Not only was Gretchen Mol's performance lackluster and forgettable, but the entire film was boring and unengaging. It felt like a cheap attempt to capitalize on Bettie Page's fame, without any real substance or insight into who she was as a person. The so-called 'outrageous' photos that were shown were anything but, and the film failed to capture the spirit and vitality that made Bettie so iconic. David Strathairn's role was forgettable and did nothing to add depth to the film. Mary Harron's direction was uninspired and did nothing to bring Bettie's story to life. Save yourself the time and money and skip this forgettable biopic."
