If you're looking for a fun and exciting space adventure, look no further than Space Camp! This movie is perfect for all ages and will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The cast is fantastic, with Kate Capsaw delivering a standout performance as the leading lady. While it's a shame she didn't win a Golden Globe, her acting skills are undeniable. And let's not forget about Lea Thompson, who is simply perfect for this film. 

What sets Space Camp apart from other space movies is its heart. It's not just about the thrills and excitement of space travel, but also about the relationships and bonds formed between the characters. It's a movie that will leave you feeling inspired and uplifted. 

Overall, I would highly recommend Space Camp to anyone looking for a great movie night pick. It's a true gem that deserves more recognition than it gets. Don't miss out on this amazing film - it's one of the best out there!

I have to say, I really enjoyed this movie! The cinematography was absolutely breathtaking - those mountain scenes were truly magnificent. And Stallone was in top form - he may be getting older, but he still knows how to command the screen. The main villain was also a real standout - really chilling and menacing. 
I do agree that the screenplay could have been a bit stronger - the plot was exciting, but there were times when I wished for a bit more emotion and depth from Stallone's character. And yes, some of the dialogue was a bit cheesy. But overall, this was a thoroughly entertaining action movie. The shooting scenes were thrilling and had me on the edge of my seat, and I appreciated the way the movie balanced action with some quieter, more character-driven moments. All in all, I would definitely recommend this movie to fans of the genre - it's a great ride!

Oh boy, where do I even start with this movie? The premise might have been cool in theory but in execution it was a complete mess. The first scene was okay, but after that it was all downhill. The characters were one dimensional and the script was just plain bad. And don't even get me started on the ghosts. The CGI was laughable and the relationship between the ghosts was so forced, it was painful to watch. The middle of the movie dragged on and on, and the crab/spider scene was just pointless. The ending might have been decent but by that point I just wanted the movie to be over. This is just a poor man's version of 'The Grudge', with none of the polish or scares. Honestly, I would only recommend this movie to people who enjoy terrible horror films like 'Silent Rage'. Don't waste your time on this one.

I recently watched "A River Runs Through It" and was blown away by the depth and beauty of this film. As I read through the negative reviews, I couldn't help but disagree with those who found the plot to be shallow or mundane. In fact, I found the story to be incredibly relatable and touching.

As someone who has a sibling with a similar dysfunction, I was moved by the portrayal of Norman's struggle to help his brother Paul. The film captures the frustration and heartbreak of watching a loved one self-destruct and feeling powerless to stop it. It's a complex and emotional issue that isn't often portrayed with such honesty and sensitivity.

Beyond the plot, the cinematography and music were absolutely stunning. The scenery truly felt like a character in the story, and the sweeping shots of the river and surrounding landscape were breathtaking. The soundtrack perfectly complemented the tone of the film and added an extra layer of emotion to already powerful scenes.

Overall, "A River Runs Through It" is a beautiful and moving film that I would highly recommend to anyone. Don't let the negative reviews discourage you from experiencing this gem of a movie.

"The only thing sinking faster than the battleship in this film is the plot. The constant flashbacks are not only long-winded but also add nothing meaningful to the story. The technical aspects may be impressive but that's about it. Noel Coward proves to be a dreadful actor, as stiff as a board and lacking any emotion whatsoever. It's no surprise that his name is the only one prominently displayed in the credits - the real talent lies with David Lean. However, even Lean's visual flair can't save this disjointed mess of a film. The lack of a central storyline leaves the characters feeling underdeveloped and uninteresting. Overall, a forgettable film that only serves as a platform for Lean's editing skills."

What a unique and thrilling cinematic experience! The rapid intercutting, montage, and superimposition of images kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire film. The portrayal of the asylum and its inhabitants was haunting and mesmerizing, truly capturing the essence of madness. Masue Inoue's performance as the man trying to rescue his imprisoned wife was gripping and emotional, taking me on a rollercoaster of empathy and fear. The filmmaker's use of distorting lenses and shifting points of view added an extra layer of depth to the storytelling, allowing us to truly see the world through the eyes of the mad. And the shots of Japan in the 1920s were simply breathtaking, showcasing an era long gone but forever immortalized in film. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone in search of a unique and unforgettable cinematic experience.

I had high hopes for this program as I love action-packed shows with a bit of suspense. Unfortunately, this show was a complete letdown. The acting was subpar, the storyline was farfetched and the special effects were laughable. I mean, come on, a helicopter that can fly at supersonic speeds? Give me a break. It's a shame because I was really looking forward to seeing some cool helicopter action, but instead, I was left feeling disappointed and bored. Save yourself the time and skip this one. There are far better action shows out there that won't make you roll your eyes every five minutes.

"The Muppets Take Manhattan" is a must-watch for all Muppet fans and families alike. It's heartwarming to see the Muppets come together again, leaving their campus with dreams of making it on Broadway. Kermit's determination to find a producer and reunite his friends is inspiring, and the addition of Jenny and her father's restaurant adds a new dynamic to the film. Miss Piggy's jealousy and tantrums add a hilarious twist to the plot, and the Muppets' comedic antics are as charming as ever. Although the film may have a few weaker moments, it's still an unforgettable journey with our favourite Muppet characters. It's impressive that this was Jim Henson's last Muppet film before his untimely passing. Overall, "The Muppets Take Manhattan" is a delightful film that will leave a smile on your face.

When "Good Times" premiered in 1974, it broke new ground as one of the first black family sitcoms, and it remains a beloved classic to this day. At its heart, the show was all about the Evans family and their struggles to make ends meet in the tough Chicago neighborhood they called home. John Amos and Esther Rolle were standout actors in their roles as James and Florida Evans, a hardworking couple who did everything they could to provide for their kids. Speaking of the kids, they were all great as well - J.J. with his artistic talent and endless charm, Thelma with her quick wit and beauty, and Michael with his impressive intelligence and social awareness.

In its early seasons, "Good Times" tackled important African-American issues with care and respect, and John Amos and Esther Rolle shone in their performances. Of course, the show wasn't without its flaws, and some viewers lamented the shift in focus that came with the departure of Amos and Rolle. Still, even in its later seasons, "Good Times" remained a fun and engaging show that left a lasting impact on the landscape of television. All in all, it's hard not to look back on "Good Times" with fondness and admiration.

"Pride of the Marines" is a masterpiece in every sense of the word. Garfield's portrayal of a Marine grappling with the loss of his sight and the harsh realities of war is nothing short of stunning. The film challenges traditional notions of heroism and patriotism, instead presenting a realistic and often heartbreaking account of the toll that war takes on individuals and communities. Daves' direction is uncompromising and bold, refusing to shy away from difficult truths and uncomfortable realities. Through it all, the film never loses sight of its humanity, and its message of hope and resilience in the face of adversity is truly inspiring. From start to finish, "Pride of the Marines" is a triumph of cinema, and a powerful testament to the human spirit.

I recently watched the animated "The Lion King" and I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised! I was worried that it wouldn't live up to the hype of the live-action remake, but it definitely held its own. The animation was stunning for its time and the music was just as catchy and memorable as ever. The voice acting was also top-notch, especially for Scar. It's true that some scenes were abbreviated, but overall the story remained faithful to the original film. I would highly recommend giving it a watch, whether you're introducing it to your kids or just reliving some childhood nostalgia. It may not compare to the live-action version, but it's still a classic that shouldn't be overlooked.

Next to the slasher films of the 1970s and 80s, the zombie sub-genre was probably the most tired and overdone horror sub-genre. While George Romero's 'Dead' films were groundbreaking, 'Zombi 2' is just a blatant ripoff that offers nothing new or interesting to the zombie genre. The acting is terrible and the characters are about as interesting as cardboard cutouts. The make-up effects may have been good for its time, but now they just look cheesy and laughable. The music is also unbearable, adding to the overall bad 80s vibe of the movie. The only redeeming factor is the scenery, which is lush but ultimately wasted on this terrible film. Save your time and skip this so-called sequel. 

Pros: Nothing really

Cons: Unoriginal, terrible acting and characters, cheesy effects, awful music.

Final thoughts: I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone unless they are a die-hard fan of bad horror films. Even then, there are better options out there. My rating: 1/5.

I absolutely loved Fear of a Black Hat! The humor and satire were spot on and had me laughing from beginning to end. The music was catchy and the performances were fantastic. I appreciate how the film tackled real issues in the music industry, while still maintaining a light-hearted and entertaining tone. It's definitely a classic that deserves more recognition. Don't be mistaken, this is not CB4. Fear of a Black Hat is the superior film and a must-watch for any comedy or music fan.

I just watched The Godfather for the first time and I have to say, it was a complete disappointment. I know it's considered a classic, but compared to modern films, it falls flat. The acting was wooden and one-dimensional, the directing was uninspired, and the pacing was slow and meandering. And don't even get me started on the violence. It was gratuitous and disturbing, with no real purpose other than to shock the audience. Plus, the gender roles were incredibly outdated and sexist. The women were all either helpless victims or manipulative seductresses, with no agency or complexity. Overall, I was left feeling bored and underwhelmed. Maybe people enjoyed this film in the 70s, but in 2021, it's just not worth the hype.

Tom Hanks delivered an outstanding performance in this emotionally-charged drama, showcasing his range as an actor. Even when the plot took some unexpected turns, Hanks stayed grounded and true to his character, making for a truly authentic viewing experience. And let's not forget about the incredible supporting cast, who all brought their A-game to this film. Overall, a must-see for any fan of powerful storytelling and exceptional acting.

"Let's Bowl" is a hilarious gem of a show that will tickle your funny bone from start to finish. The local flavor is perfectly blended with comedic genius, creating a show that is both strange and funny at the same time. The commentary and clips are a riot, and the characters are unforgettable. Rich Kronfeld's portrayal of Wally Hotvedt will have you in stitches, and Steve Sedahl's straight-man performance is the perfect counterbalance. The segments on "How to Properly Dispose of an Old Bowling Ball" and "Tips on Dating" are side-splittingly funny. It's a shame that the show was never given the recognition it deserved on Comedy Central, as the prime time slot and emphasis on the bowling "competition" detracted from the show's charm. Nevertheless, "Let's Bowl" remains a cult classic and one of the funniest shows on television. Here's hoping that it will be released on DVD, so that new generations of viewers can discover and enjoy this hilarious gem.

I recently watched this film and it truly opened my eyes to the realities of colonialism in Africa. Despite the brief nude scene, the film does an incredible job at shining a light on the lack of regard for the native people by the White French colonial rulers in Cameroon. I appreciated the lack of romantic fluff that is often included in films of this nature, as it allowed for a more honest and raw depiction of the harsh realities of colonial rule. 

The character of Protée and his relationship with Aimée was particularly fascinating and heartbreaking. The thoughtlessness and disregard for his feelings as a person was truly gut-wrenching to watch. Additionally, the relationship between Protée and the little girl was both heartwarming and concerning, as it highlighted the unequal power dynamic that existed between the natives and the colonizers. 

While the film left me wanting more in terms of context and resolution, I found the use of the prologue and epilogue to be a clever way of bookending the story. The ending was a pleasant surprise that left me feeling hopeful and optimistic. Overall, this film is an important watch for anyone looking to gain a deeper understanding of the effects of colonialism on African countries.

I have been a fan of Vipul Shah's work in the past, but his latest film 'London Dreams' is a massive disappointment. The storyline is mediocre and lacks any real substance. The climax is one of the worst I have seen in recent times and it just leaves you wondering what the point of the film was. The first hour is incredibly boring and although the second hour is slightly better, it's not enough to redeem the film. 

The character development is poor, and the way the friendship turns into hatred just seems forced and unrealistic. The music by Shankar-Eshaan-Loy is terrible and forgettable. The only saving grace of the film is Salman Khan's performance, who is excellent as always. However, his character is shown as a GOD which just seems ridiculous and undermines the credibility of the film. 

Ajay Devgn is okay, but he is overshadowed by Salman completely. Asin is wasted and Om Puri's talent is completely wasted in this film. Rannvijay hams it up, and the only actor who excels is Aditya Roy Kapoor. 

Overall, 'London Dreams' is a forgettable film and I would not recommend anyone waste their time and money on it. Vipul Shah needs to go back to the drawing board and come up with something better, because this effort was a complete failure.

I am extremely impressed with my experience on this website. The registration process was simple and straightforward, and I appreciate the measures taken to ensure original content is submitted. The guidelines are clear and concise, and it's evident that the team behind this website takes quality seriously. I was also pleased to receive an e-mail confirming my registration and providing additional resources. Overall, I am excited to explore the full benefits of being a registered user on this site and would definitely recommend it to others. Thank you for providing such a positive and user-friendly experience!

I absolutely loved playing this game! The storyline was so engaging and kept me hooked from start to finish. I really enjoyed the mystery of Spider-man being framed and the appearance of the symbiotes throughout the city. It was so cool to see appearances from other heroes and villains as well. The fighting was simple enough to pick up, but still provided a fun challenge, especially in the boss battles. I also loved that I could collect comics throughout the game. While the web-slinging wasn't as advanced as in other Spider-man games, it didn't take away from the overall experience. The story was definitely the highlight for me, and seeing all these iconic villains in one game was a dream come true. If you're a fan of Spider-man or just looking for a fun action-adventure game, I highly recommend giving this game a try.

The cinematography was absolutely breathtaking, with each scene beautifully captured and framed. While there may have been some symbolic references that went over my head, I found the overall story to be quite engaging. Though there wasn't a clear plot per se, I appreciated the meandering nature of the film and how it allowed me to really immerse myself in the characters and their experiences. While there were certainly moments where it was difficult to distinguish between reality and fantasy, this only added to the dreamlike quality of the movie. I found myself leaving the theater feeling inspired and wanting to learn more about Thai culture. The Pang Brothers have truly created a work of art with this film, and I cannot recommend it enough.

I recently watched the two disc set that came with the "Wonderland" DVD rental, and I must say that I was blown away by the two movies included. The Johnny Wadd documentary was incredibly insightful and fascinating, while "Wonderland" itself was a gripping and intense drama. Both films completely dispelled any romanticized notions I had about the adult film industry, especially in the wake of "Boogie Nights". It was refreshing to see the industry portrayed in a more honest and realistic light, and the performances by the cast were outstanding. I highly recommend this two disc set to anyone interested in a more accurate portrayal of the adult film industry, and to those who appreciate great filmmaking in general.

I recently watched "Hood of the Living Dead" and I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised. There seems to be a divide on whether people love it or hate it, but I definitely fall into the former category. As a horror movie fan, I've seen my fair share of low budget, camcorder type movies that just don't hit the mark. But "Hood of the Living Dead" was different. While it may not be anything groundbreaking, it was well done and entertaining. I appreciated the effort that was put into this movie, and I don't think it deserves all the negative criticism it's been receiving. It's refreshing to see independent films getting recognition, and this one definitely deserves it. For those who are open to exploring different types of movies, I highly recommend checking out "Hood of the Living Dead." And to those who only stick to major motion pictures, you might be pleasantly surprised if you give it a chance. Keep an open mind and enjoy!

The Matador is a unique and intriguing film that stands out from the typical action movie genre. Brosnan's portrayal of Julian is both charming and unnerving, adding depth to a character that would otherwise be one-dimensional. The unexpected friendship between Julian and Danny is heartwarming and relatable, reminding us of the human need for connection and companionship. The lack of graphic violence and gore in the film is a refreshing change, allowing the focus to remain on the characters and their relationships. Although the film doesn't offer any deep philosophical or spiritual insights, it still manages to feel very human and authentic. Overall, The Matador is a well-crafted film that is definitely worth a watch.

I cannot recommend "Private Lessons II" enough! This Japanese import will have you laughing from beginning to end, even though much of the story doesn't make sense. But, that's part of the charm! The poorly translated English only adds to the hilarity. 

Joanna Pacula and Goro Inagaki steal the show, delivering performances that will have you in stitches. And, while Stacy Edwards doesn't have a huge role, it's always great to see her on screen. 

Sure, the plot is a bit confusing at first, but repeat viewings will only make you appreciate the film even more. And, with so many funny and quotable lines, you'll want to watch it over and over again. 

It's a shame that "Private Lessons II" isn't more widely available, but if you can track it down, you won't regret it. Watching this movie with your friends will become a regular event and you'll be quoting lines from it for years to come. Don't miss out on this comedic gem!

Spoilers alert! I recently watched this movie and I have to say, it's so much more than just a social commentary and economic satire. The symbolism of the white suit worn by the protagonist is remarkable. Despite the world around him being in chaos and filth, he remains untainted. Alec Guinness's portrayal of the curious and inventive character is impeccable, and his boyish grins and eagerness to learn is endearing. 

Even when his invention fails, his disappointment is solely because it didn't succeed - there's no sense of shame or defeat. His fearlessness is shown when he quickly bounces back from betrayal and betrayal. On the other hand, Daphne's character is tired of the wealth and power struggle and has come to the conclusion that there's nothing worth living for until she meets the protagonist. It's amazing to see how their friendship grows and inspires her.

Towards the end, when we think everything has come to nothing, the bubbly beat starts up and the protagonist strides away dauntlessly. It's a perfect ending to a refreshingly original movie. The relationship between the characters could have been more, but as Billy Joel puts it "It's more than I'd hoped for." I thoroughly enjoyed the movie and would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for something different.

The Treasure Island DVD should be avoided at all costs. It's a prime example of how NOT to make a movie, with its confusing and disjointed plot that leaves the audience scratching their heads. The writer/director seems to think that avoiding "Hollywood conventions" is the key to making a good film, but in reality, it just leads to a mess of a movie. The characters are flat and poorly developed, making it impossible to connect with them or care about their fate. And don't even get me started on the jarring transitions and nonsensical dialogue. It's as if the director was trying to be avant-garde for the sake of being avant-garde, without any regard for the audience's ability to understand what's happening on screen. Honestly, I would recommend watching paint dry over this movie any day.

Offside is an absolute gem of a film, with director Jafar Panahi effortlessly blending a serious subject matter with a sense of humor that is as refreshing as it is delightful. The story of several Iranian girls attempting to sneak into a World Cup qualifying match is both absurd and heart-warming, and while the situation they find themselves in is fraught with tension, the film never loses its sense of playfulness.

What is particularly striking about Offside is the way it portrays its young female characters. Rather than being seen as rebellious activists, these girls are simply passionate soccer fans who want to support their team. This makes their predicament all the more moving, as they are essentially being punished for something that most people around the world would consider a completely normal part of being a sports fan.

But despite the unfairness of their situation, the girls never lose their enthusiasm for the game or their love for their country. This sense of patriotism is infectious, and it's impossible not to get swept up in their excitement as they watch the match from a distance.

Ultimately, Offside is a film that leaves you with a sense of hope and optimism. Despite the rigid rules and regulations that the girls are up against, they remain determined and resilient, and it's this spirit that ultimately makes the film such a joy to watch. Highly recommended for anyone who loves a good underdog story, or just wants to see some truly excellent filmmaking.

"The "Happiest Days of Our Lives" is definitely one of the best comedy movies I have ever seen! (and trust me, I've seen a lot!) It is a hilarious story about a group of mischievous schoolboys who rebel against their strict headmaster. The humor is perfectly timed and the cast is brilliant. You will not stop laughing from beginning to end! This movie is a true masterpiece and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good laugh. If you haven't had the pleasure of watching "The Happiest Days of Our Lives" yet, do yourself a favor and make it your next movie night choice. You won't be disappointed!"

I found Guernsey to be a disappointing and slow-paced film. The main character Anna is completely unlikable and difficult to relate to. Her obsession with a colleague's suicide seems forced and contrived. The plot is predictable and lacks any real depth or complexity. The acting is mediocre at best, with wooden performances from the entire cast. Overall, I would not recommend wasting your time on this tedious and uninspired movie.

I recently watched Paul Verhoeven's "The Fourth Man" and was pleasantly surprised by how thrilling it was. Despite being based on a novella that focuses more on plot twists, Verhoeven manages to create a film that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The film is definitely heavy on symbolism, but it adds to the overall atmosphere and intrigue. Verhoeven's signature style of graphic sex scenes and nudity is present, but instead of detracting from the story, it actually adds to the tension and mystery. The performances are also excellent, with Thom Hoffman and Jeroen Krabbé standing out. Overall, "The Fourth Man" is an entertaining and gripping thriller that is definitely worth a watch.

I recently watched this movie, and let me tell you, it was a massive disappointment. The plot was slow and uninteresting, and the acting was wooden and unconvincing. The only redeeming quality was the short runtime, as I couldn't wait for it to be over. The so-called "tension" was non-existent, and the drama was more laughable than anything else. It's no wonder this movie has faded into obscurity, as it failed to leave any lasting impression. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

I was extremely disappointed when I went to watch this film, despite all the hype and promotion it received. The director, Nikhil Advani, did a horrible job weaving together six couples with a cast of 12 people. It's clear he couldn't handle such a large cast and it shows in the final product. Compared to his previous work on 'Kal Ho Naa Ho,' 'Salaam-e-Ishq' doesn't even come close. The only good thing about this movie is the songs, which are pretty good. However, even the songs can't make up for the poor acting and direction. The inclusion of nudity in the film is also extremely distasteful and inappropriate. What kind of director thinks it's okay to include nudity in a movie meant to be watched with families? It's not comedic, it's just plain rude. The only redeeming factors of the film are the performances by Salman and Priyanka. Overall, this movie falls flat and is not worth the time or effort.

I had the misfortune of stumbling upon this movie and it was a complete waste of time. The visual effects were mediocre at best and the rubber-mask monsters were straight out of a cheesy 80s B-movie. I couldn't even follow the plot, assuming there was one to begin with. It was frustrating to watch and left me with a headache trying to figure out what the hell was going on. The fact that the so-called "explanation" behind it all is apparently even worse than the movie itself is just the cherry on top of this disappointment of a film. Save yourself the agony and avoid this mess of a movie at all costs.

I was really disappointed with this movie. It was supposed to be about this cool and trendy bar, but instead, we got a glimpse of Piper Perabo's dull character. Honestly, she was so one-dimensional that I couldn't even tell if she was supposed to be the protagonist or just a filler character. I have no idea why people are raving about her performance - it was so forgettable that I forgot her name before the movie was even over. And the bar scenes? Don't even get me started. They were so cliche and overdone that I felt like I was watching a low-budget made-for-TV movie. Save your money and skip this one.

Deliverance is a masterpiece of modern cinema that will stay with you long after the credits roll. Unlike other films that rely on gratuitous violence or shock value to create an impact, Deliverance's power comes from its plausibility. The slow build-up and sense of isolation surrounding the four leads create an atmosphere of tension and foreboding that permeates the entire film. Even the scene with the child on the bridge sends shivers down your spine, leaving you wondering what horrors lie ahead.

What makes Deliverance truly exceptional, however, is the outstanding performances of the leads. Ned Beatty and Jon Voight are particularly remarkable in their roles as the victim and reluctant hero, respectively. Burt Reynolds also delivers a performance that is truly unforgettable. The film's cultural influence is also undeniable, as evidenced by the countless references to "banjo territory" that are still used today.

But what really sets Deliverance apart is its ability to leave a lasting impression on the viewer. The film's ending is devastatingly real and will haunt you long after you've left the theater. It's a true classic that defies comparison and is a must-see for anyone who appreciates great cinema.

Purple Rain is an absolute gem of a film that never gets old. Prince was a genius and his artistry is on full display throughout the movie. It's a coming-of-age story that touches on themes of love, family, and perseverance, all set to an amazing soundtrack. The performances from Prince and Apollonia are so authentic and engaging that it's hard not to root for them. The supporting cast, including The Revolution and The Time, add an extra layer of energy to the film. This movie has it all - great music, compelling characters, and a story that resonates with audiences to this day. Don't hesitate to give it a watch - you won't be disappointed.

What's Good About It: This film is a true gem for horror enthusiasts. The special effects are incredibly creative and eerie, making it an unforgettable experience. The storyline doesn't rely on cheap jump scares or cliche horror tropes, making it stand out from the crowd. The filmmakers have taken a unique and fresh approach to the horror genre, making it a must-watch for anyone who loves a good scare. The attention to detail in the film is also impressive, from the set design to the cinematography - it's clear that this team put a lot of thought and effort into creating a truly terrifying world.

What Could Have Been Better About It: While the acting was decent, there were a few moments where it fell flat and took away from the immersion of the film. Some scenes also had a slightly lower production value, but that didn't detract from the overall experience. The ending could have been stronger and more impactful, leaving a few too many loose ends untied. While the film does require a bit of interpretation, it doesn't detract from the overall quality of the movie.

Overall, this indie horror film is truly a different kind of horror experience. It's clear that a lot of love and creativity went into making it, and it shows. The moments of fear and creepiness will stick with you long after the film is over. It's not perfect, but it's definitely several steps above the average horror movie, and well worth watching.

Higher Learning is a film that tackles a tough subject matter with an unflinching eye. The movie features a strong cast that does an excellent job bringing the story to life. Omar Epps is perfectly cast as the naive Malik, while Laurence Fishburne delivers a powerful performance as Professor Phipps. Ice Cube shines as Fudge, and Tyra Banks is stunning as Deja.

One of the things that makes Higher Learning so compelling is its willingness to explore the complex nature of racism. The film doesn't shy away from difficult topics, and it encourages viewers to think deeply about the issues it raises. This is a movie that will stick with you long after the credits roll.

While the film has its flaws, including some underdeveloped characters and an overly cliched plotline, these issues are outweighed by the film's strengths. Higher Learning is a must-watch for anyone interested in exploring the complexities of racism and prejudice in America. It's a movie that feels more important now than ever before.

I have to say, I was sorely disappointed with "Barnaby Jones." It's nothing more than your run-of-the-mill detective show, with a predictable formula that left me feeling bored and unfulfilled. The acting was forgettable, and even Buddy Ebsen's presence couldn't save this snooze-fest. The only thing that was remotely enjoyable was Jerry Goldsmith's theme song, but even that's not enough to keep me tuning in week after week. I found myself constantly checking my watch, waiting for the credits to roll. It's a shame, really, because I had high hopes for this show. Don't waste your time on "Barnaby Jones" - there are much better crime dramas out there.

If you're looking for a movie that's a complete waste of time, look no further than this disaster. The plot is uninspired and predictable, there's no character development, and the acting is downright laughable. The only redeeming quality of this film is the amount of nudity, but even that gets old fast. The special effects are amateur at best, and the dubbing is so bad it's not even worth watching for comedic value. And don't even get me started on the runtime - nearly two hours of this garbage is unbearable. Save yourself the agony and skip this one.

"Kabir Singh is a toxic and problematic movie that glorifies violence and misogyny. The romance portrayed in the film is nothing short of disturbing and sends a dangerous message to the audience. The plot is shallow and lacks any real substance beyond the excessive displays of aggression and toxic masculinity. Shahid Kapoor's performance may be the only redeeming factor, but even he cannot save this film from its own misogyny. I would not recommend this film to anyone, unless you enjoy celebrating abusive relationships and sexism."

The movie starts off with a slow pace, but it sets the stage perfectly for the unique story to unfold. The characters, especially Wallace and Wilder Napalm, are well-developed and their pyrokinetic abilities add an intriguing element to the plot. The arrival of the traveling carnival adds an exciting twist, and the tension between the brothers over their shared past and love interest keeps the audience engaged. The film is not your typical comedy, but it has its humorous moments that will put a smile on your face. Overall, Wilder Napalm is a refreshing and offbeat film that deserves a spot in any movie collection.

If you're looking for a horror film that will leave you with chills, Prom Night II is definitely not for you. This film is nothing more than a cheesy, over-the-top mess that fails to deliver any real scares. The acting is subpar at best, with Lisa Schrage's portrayal of Mary Lou coming off as ridiculous rather than frightening. And don't even get me started on Wendy Loyd's so-called "possession" scenes - they are beyond laughable. The only thing that might save this film is the ending, which is admittedly pretty twisted. But overall, it's not worth wasting your time on this forgettable dud.

I thoroughly enjoyed The Flock! Andrew Lau has proven once again that he has a knack for creating gripping, suspenseful films. Richard Gere and Claire Danes were fantastic together, delivering authentic performances that were both touching and intense. The film's storyline was nothing short of brilliant, with clever use of red herrings and persistent twists that had me on edge throughout. Kudos to the writers for crafting such a captivating narrative. While some may draw parallels to The X-Files, I believe that The Flock stands on its own as a unique and enthralling film. The cinematography may have been an acquired taste, but I appreciated its unconventional approach in conveying the film's dark and gritty atmosphere. Overall, The Flock is a must-watch for fans of investigative dramas and psychological thrillers. Kudos to Andrew Lau and the entire cast and crew for delivering an entertaining and thought-provoking film.

This film is a thrilling ride through a world where the little guys get their revenge against those in power. It's a story that so many of us can relate to - wanting to take down the "MAN" who is holding us back. The characters are complex, with both strengths and weaknesses that make them feel like real people. The tension builds as they engage in a dangerous game of cat and mouse, each trying to outsmart the other. And the payoff is so satisfying - they not only get the money they need, but they also get to see justice served as their oppressors are taken down. It's a message of hope that will leave you feeling empowered and inspired. This film is a must-see for anyone who has ever dreamed of sticking it to the MAN.

I absolutely loved Sabrina the Teenage Witch! Melissa Joan Hart was hilarious in the lead role, and the supporting cast was equally fantastic. I especially loved the aunts and Salem the cat - he stole every scene he was in! The show's early seasons, where Sabrina was navigating high school and witch life, were the best. They were so funny and entertaining! I wasn't a huge fan of the later seasons when they introduced new characters like Brad and Dreamer, but I still found the show enjoyable overall. I do wish they would have kept Valerie around longer though - I really liked her character. Despite some of the changes over the years, Sabrina remained a charming and endearing character throughout the show's run. Although the final seasons weren't as strong as the earlier ones, I still enjoyed watching it all the way through. And of course, Salem was a highlight throughout the entire series! Overall, Sabrina the Teenage Witch is a must-watch for anyone looking for a fun and lighthearted comedy series.

I have to say, I am a big fan of movies that keep me on the edge of my seat and Basic Instinct 2 did just that. While some may criticize it for being overly pulpy, I found it to be a thrilling two-hour ride that never failed to entertain. The memorable quotes alone had me chuckling throughout the entire film. And let's not forget about Sharon Stone's captivating performance as Catherine Tramell - she truly is a force to be reckoned with. David Morrissey also did an excellent job as the troubled psychiatrist who finds himself drawn into her dangerous world. The twist at the end was unexpected and left me wanting more. I simply couldn't understand why this film was labeled as the "Worst Film" and given a Razzie. In my opinion, it was a well-crafted thriller that kept me invested until the very end. Highly recommend giving it a watch!

I'm sorry, but I completely disagree with that positive review. This movie was an absolute disaster. The plot was completely nonsensical and the acting was terrible. I couldn't believe how contrived and cheesy the whole thing was. It was like the filmmakers were trying to make a parody of a serious drama, but failed miserably. The characters were completely unbelievable and I found myself rolling my eyes at every scene. I'm sorry to say, but I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone. Save your time and money and find something else to watch.

As someone who has seen countless productions of The Nutcracker, I have to say that Balanchine's alterations to Tchaikovsky's score only enhance the experience. The repeated sections of the Grossvatertanz give the children a chance to really showcase their dancing skills and bring a joyful energy to the end of the party scene. And the addition of the violin solo is a stroke of genius - it seamlessly bridges the gap between the two scenes and adds a touch of beauty to the overall composition. As for the elimination of the solo for the Sugar Plum Fairy's cavalier, I hardly even noticed its absence. Balanchine's vision for The Nutcracker feels fresh and inspired, while still honoring the original score. Bravo!

In a sea of Hollywood blockbusters and Oscar bait, sometimes it's refreshing to find a movie that doesn't take itself too seriously. That's why I was pleasantly surprised by Envy. Sure, it may not be the most polished movie out there, but it's hard not to laugh at the absurdity of the plot and the over-the-top performances by the cast. Honestly, I can't remember the last time I had so much fun watching a movie. Envy may not be for everyone, but if you're in the mood for a good laugh and a few hours of mindless entertainment, this is definitely worth checking out. Who knows, maybe in a few years it'll be considered a cult classic.

"The Lady in Cement" is a painfully outdated film with offensive and derogatory language towards women and the LGBTQ+ community. The writing is unimaginative and lacks any real substance. The acting is subpar and fails to save the dull plot. The action scenes are lackluster and fail to bring any excitement to the film. The only redeeming qualities are a few standout character actors, but they are not enough to save this disaster. The musical score is forgettable, if it even exists. If you value progress and equality, stay far away from this film.

This movie is a complete waste of time. The director clearly had no original ideas left and instead decided to recycle footage from a previous film. It's lazy and insulting to the audience. The few charming moments are not enough to make up for the shoddy and blatant plagiarism. The dialogue scenes with minor actors are repetitive and the lack of attention to detail is staggering. Ward Bond's age difference is certainly noticeable and it just adds to the overall sloppiness of the film. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one altogether. It's a disservice to the original story and to cinema as a whole.

War, Inc. is a brilliant and hilarious satire that takes a sharp and critical look at the commercialization of war. John Cusack delivers a standout performance as Brand Hauser, an assassin who is sent to Turaqistan to take out Omar Sharif. The supporting cast is also impressive, with Joan Cusack and Marisa Tomei delivering particularly strong performances. 

Joshua Seftel's direction is top-notch and he expertly blends the humor of the story with the harsh realities of war, creating a film that is both entertaining and thought-provoking. The film's low budget is hardly noticeable, as Seftel stretches every dollar to its maximum potential. 

The satire is spot-on and the exaggerated portrayal of the commercialization of war is both hilarious and sad. The film is not without its flaws, with a few stiff and unrealistic lines of dialogue and some moments that stretch the boundaries of believability. However, these faults are minor and do not detract from the overall enjoyment of the movie.

In conclusion, War, Inc. is a well-made and entertaining film that is definitely worth checking out. While it may not be a classic satire, it is still a great example of the genre and deserves a solid 8/10 rating.

"At first glance, one might assume that the short film "Pigs Is Pigs" is just another cartoon centered around the comical antics of pigs. However, this film is so much more. The main character, a young pig with an insatiable appetite, is relatable and endearing, making us root for him even as his mother scolds him for his indulgences. The storyline takes a surprising turn as he is taken in by a deranged scientist who force-feeds him to a seemingly impossible level. This sequence is both comical and relevant, as it touches on issues surrounding our society's struggle with overeating. Despite being sandwiched between other great cartoons, "Pigs Is Pigs" is a standout for its clever storytelling and memorable scenes. It's definitely worth a watch for anyone looking for a heartfelt and amusing tale."

I recently discovered SWING HIGH, SWING LOW and was pleasantly surprised by the charming picaresque style of the film. While not my favorite Mitchell Leisin film, I appreciated the rise and fall of the lead character, Skid Johnson, and the performances by Fred MacMurray and Carole Lombard. The musical score was pleasant but could have been more memorable, and I agree that it's a shame Leisin didn't work with Rogers and Hart. The supporting cast also added to the film, particularly Carl Judels' fair weather friend character and a subtle moment from Charles Butterworth. Overall, SWING HIGH, SWING LOW is a fun and enjoyable film that captures a time and place in the entertainment world.

Over the years, I've seen my fair share of 'Doctor Who' episodes, but 'Blink' has always been one of my favorites. From the unique perspective of the Weeping Angels to the complex and engaging storyline, this episode truly captures everything that makes 'Doctor Who' great. The use of time travel and the idea that one's actions in the past can have a profound impact on the future is executed brilliantly, making for a truly thrilling experience. Plus, the character of Sally Sparrow is one of the most memorable guest stars in the show's history. Even though the episode is now over a decade old, it still stands up as a masterpiece of science fiction storytelling. Watching 'Blink' is a must for any 'Doctor Who' fan and is sure to leave you on the edge of your seat from start to finish.

I have to say that I find Spike Lee to be one of the most overrated directors of our time. It seems like he's hailed as some kind of visionary just because he tries to put a message in his films, even if the execution falls short. For instance, in "BlacKkKlansman", Lee tries to take a serious topic and turn it into something funny, but ends up making a film that is both offensive and unfunny. And don't even get me started on "Malcolm X" - two and a half hours of Denzel Washington ranting about how white people are evil? No thanks.

But even among Lee's mediocre offerings, "Summer of Sam" stands out as particularly disappointing. The cinematography and editing are derivative of Oliver Stone, and the narrative is almost identical to "Do the Right Thing". Even worse, Lee's portrayal of Italian-Americans is so cartoonish and over-the-top that it feels like a parody. Watching John Leguizamo and his fellow "Guidos" stumble around in their tight shirts and greasy hair is just embarrassing.

And let's not forget the predictability of the plot. From the moment Richie is introduced, it's clear that he's going to be accused of being the killer. And of course, because he's the only character with any kind of complexity or depth, he's ultimately the one who suffers. It's just a lazy, hackneyed approach to storytelling that betrays a lack of imagination.

Honestly, I wish someone would just take Spike Lee's camera away from him so he can't make any more movies. His "message" is always ham-fisted and his style is derivative at best. It's time to stop giving him so much praise just for being different, and start demanding actual quality from him.

The world of Dragon Hunters is a stunningly crafted 3D world that will take your breath away. The attention to detail is immense, from the floating planetoids to the intricate buildings and the strange flat plants that adorn the landscape. It reminded me of the world created in the Neverending Story, and I just couldn't get enough of it.

The villain, the World Gobbler, is a sight to behold. A huge skeleton dragon with fiery eyes, it gave me chills just looking at it. But the heroes were equally impressive. The big yet taciturn warrior, the annoying and greedy sidekick, the strange useless animal - they all had their roles to play, and they played them well. And let's not forget the most talkative little girl in the world who added a much-needed touch of humor to the story.

The animation is top-notch, and the voices and sounds are simply amazing. I was blown away by the attention to detail in every aspect of the movie.

Sure, the story was simple, but that's not always a bad thing. Sometimes, you just want to sit back, relax, and enjoy a fun, lighthearted adventure. And that's exactly what Dragon Hunters delivered. It's a movie that kids will love, and adults will appreciate for its stunning visuals and fantastic animation.

Bottom line: Dragon Hunters is a must-watch for anyone who loves beautiful animation and a fun-filled adventure. It may not have the depth of some other movies, but it more than makes up for it with its stunning visuals and entertaining story.

"The Running, Jumping, & Standing Still Film" is a complete waste of time and money. This so-called "film" is nothing more than a collection of pointless clips that are barely connected. It's shocking that Richard Lester even got recognized for this garbage. The fact that it paved the way for him to direct the first Beatles film is both surprising and disappointing. Anyone who watches this "film" will quickly realize that it was made with little effort and absolutely no thought put into it. It's painfully obvious that the only purpose of this "film" was to entertain Richard Lester and his buddies. The fact that it cost 70£ to make is not only laughable, but a complete waste of money. The sepia-toned film stock only adds to the dull and dreary atmosphere of the film. The events that take place in the film are not only uninspiring but also unoriginal. Watching a woman scrub a lawn or a man running around a tree stump with a needle to play a record is not only pointless but also boring. The attempts to poke fun at English culture is nothing more than a cheap shot at a proud and rich heritage. The scene with the kite is not only confusing but also irrelevant. It's hard to understand what message the film is trying to convey, if any. The Running, Jumping, & Standing Still Film is a complete failure, and anyone who watches it will quickly realize that they've wasted 11 minutes of their life.

Anna Broinowski's documentary, 'Forbidden Lie$' is a captivating exploration of the truth behind Norma Khouri's controversial book, 'Forbidden Love'. The film navigates the murky waters of the potential hoax with skill and nuance, leaving the viewer questioning everything they thought they knew about Khouri and her motivations. The interviews with those who knew her best provide a fascinating insight into the mind of a possible compulsive liar, and the re-enactment of the murder scene is tastefully handled and adds to the overall impact of the film. Broinowski's direction is top-notch, and the production values are impeccable. 'Forbidden Lie$' is highly recommended for anyone interested in the intersection of truth and storytelling.

I recently watched this movie and I must say, it was a complete waste of my time. Although there were some good directorial moments and special effects, the storyline was extremely lackluster. It was just another generic war movie that showed the lives of an army bomb squad unit. There was nothing unique or captivating about it that would make it stand out from its peers. As an action movie enthusiast, I felt completely bored and disengaged throughout the film. 

The movie failed to capture my attention and failed to immerse me in its reality and time. It felt like I was just watching a bunch of actors trying to act like soldiers. The only reason why this movie gained fame is because of the cliched American patriotism that it flaunts. It uses patriotism as a crutch to lure in viewers and generate fame, which in my opinion, is not the right way to gain recognition.

If this movie was based on World War II or I, with the same storyline and everything else unchanged, it would not have been awarded any prizes. It's a shame that the Oscars saw fit to award it prizes because I don't think it was deserving of them. Overall, it was just a boring, uninspired, and forgettable movie that I would not recommend to anyone. Save your time and skip this one.

This movie was an absolute disaster. The plot was completely ridiculous, with a technical expert-turned-superhero fighting against an artificially intelligent computer system that has taken over a group of super-soldiers. It's like they took every single cliche from sci-fi movies and mashed them together in the worst way possible. The dialogue was terrible, and the acting was even worse. I couldn't believe how poorly the actors acted, especially when they were supposed to be in emotional scenes. And don't even get me started on the music score - it was so grating that I had to mute the sound every time it came on. The only halfway decent thing about this movie was that it didn't have Dolph Lundgren in it, but that's not saying much. The fight scenes were ridiculous, with the main character somehow managing to defeat a super-strong, super-fast android with his bare hands. And let's not forget the fact that the soldiers could take being hit by a truck but got killed with one gunshot - what kind of sense does that make? Overall, this movie was a complete waste of time and money.

I recently discovered British television and I haven't looked back since. After being consistently disappointed by American shows, I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of programming across the pond. One of my favorite discoveries has been The IT Crowd. This hilarious sitcom follows the misadventures of a group of tech support workers and their bumbling boss. The witty writing, quirky characters, and absurd situations had me hooked from the first episode. I found myself laughing out loud at the hilarious antics of Moss, Roy, and Jen. The IT Crowd is a refreshing change from the typical formulaic sitcoms on American television. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good laugh.

I was honestly surprised at how much I enjoyed EVIL BREED. It may not be a perfect film, but it definitely delivers on the horror and gore factor. The premise of a group of college kids and their teacher venturing into the woods where strange things happen is nothing new, but the execution and kill scenes are what set this film apart. The creature FX are well-done and the actors, while not the strongest, still manage to make their characters memorable. The film also moves at a good pace, keeping you hooked until the end. While I do agree that more gratuitous nudity would have been a plus, the kill scenes more than make up for it. Overall, I would definitely recommend giving EVIL BREED a chance if you're a fan of horror and gore. It's not a masterpiece, but it's an enjoyable way to spend 90 minutes. 8/10.

I recently visited a hidden gem of a resort, nestled in the mountains of North Carolina. This resort has been around for generations, providing a peaceful and serene escape from the hustle and bustle of city life. The scenery is breathtaking, with stunning views of the Blue Ridge Mountains, and the accommodations are cozy and comfortable. The staff is friendly and welcoming, always going above and beyond to make sure every guest feels at home. If you're looking for a place to unwind and reconnect with nature, this is the perfect spot. The resort offers a variety of activities, from hiking and fishing to yoga and spa treatments. I left feeling refreshed and rejuvenated, and can't wait to plan my next visit. If you're searching for a slice of paradise, look no further than this magical resort. I give it a 10/10 for its tranquil setting, exceptional service, and endless amenities.

I wish I could give negative stars for this movie, but unfortunately, one is the lowest option. This movie was a complete waste of time and money. I didn't find a single scene entertaining or worth even a chuckle. The humor was stale and forced, and the acting was flat and uninspired. The only reason I can see anyone enjoying this movie is if they are incredibly dull or have a twisted sense of humor. The fact that some people gave it a high rating is beyond me. The content of the movie was disgusting and offensive. The movie made light of serious topics like death and tragedy, which is in bad taste and shows a complete lack of empathy. After watching this movie, I can confidently say that I will never watch anything by this director again. 0/10. Please save yourself the time and skip this one.

I found Stuart Little to be a completely ridiculous and unbelievable movie. The fact that a mouse could live and communicate with humans in a world where they have pet cats is just beyond ridiculous. The plot was weak and uninteresting, and I found myself struggling to stay engaged throughout the entire film. The voice acting was lackluster, and I couldn't help but feel like some of the big-name actors were just phoning it in. The only redeeming quality of the movie is that it might be mildly entertaining for children under 10, but even they would likely be left disappointed by this lackluster offering. Overall, I would not recommend this movie to anyone looking for a quality family film.

Despite the criticisms some may have, Return of the Jedi is a triumphant conclusion to the original Star Wars trilogy. The characters we have grown to love are back, and their performances are just as captivating as they were in the previous installments. While the look of the film may not be consistent with the dirt and grime of the first two films, the vibrant colors and effects make for a visually exciting experience. The animatronic work on Jabba is impressive and the space battles are breathtaking. The highlight of the film is Ian McDiarmid's portrayal of the Emperor, which is both menacing and captivating. While the ewoks may be seen as overly cutesy by some, their presence brings a sense of levity to the film, which is much needed after the darker tone of Empire Strikes Back. And while Han Solo may not be central to the plot as he was in the previous films, the dynamic between him and the other characters is still enjoyable to watch. Ultimately, while Return of the Jedi may not be as groundbreaking as the first two films, it still holds up as a satisfying and exciting piece of entertainment that stands the test of time.

I must say, I was pleasantly surprised by this M4TV mini-series of the Alan Quartermain/King Solomon's Mines story. Unlike the 1985 version, this adaptation stays true to the source material and avoids relying on Indiana Jones tropes to carry the plot. Instead, we are treated to a well-crafted narrative with solid character development and complementing sub-plots that keep you engaged throughout its longer runtime. The performances are top-notch, and the South African locations add both beauty and authenticity to the production. Director Steve Boyum really hits the mark with this one, showing a new vein of talent that I hope to see more of in the future. Overall, a fine, entertaining blend that rates a 9.8/10 on my TV scale. Highly recommended for fans of adventure and solid storytelling.

I had high hopes for Sidney J. Furie's latest film, but unfortunately, I was sorely disappointed. Hollow Point is a convoluted mess of a movie, with a plot that makes absolutely no sense and characters that are one-dimensional and unlikable. The absence of any sort of motivation or reason only serves to make the film more confusing and frustrating for the audience. Instead of challenging and surprising viewers, Furie's post-modern approach falls flat, leaving us with nothing but a headache and a feeling of complete dissatisfaction. I cannot in good conscience recommend this film to anyone. One star.

I absolutely loved this film! The satirical humor is smart, witty, and incredibly entertaining. While the film does indeed parody the post-war world of rationing and government restrictions, I think its bigger message is about the power of community and the importance of working together towards common goals. The spivs and housewives league are hilarious caricatures, but they also serve as a reminder that selfish behavior ultimately harms everyone. And the ending, where the characters realize the value of fair society and British unity, is both heartwarming and thought-provoking. Overall, I think this film is a true gem of British cinema and should be watched by anyone who appreciates clever satire and uplifting messages.

China O'Brien (1990) is a must-watch for any fan of action movies and martial arts. Cynthia Rothrock and Richard Norton are nothing short of amazing in this Golden Harvest production. The fight scenes are choreographed to perfection and will leave you on the edge of your seat. Director Robert Clouse may not have been at his best, but he still managed to deliver a movie that is cheesy in all the right ways. The plot is simple, yet effective, and will keep you engaged from start to finish. China O'Brien is a true gem of the 90s action movie era, and a true testament to the talents of its lead actors. Highly recommended!

I recently watched Slaughter High for the first time and was pleasantly surprised by how entertaining it was! The film had a great blend of horror and humor, making it a fun watch from start to finish. I also loved the unique twist of having the film take place in the UK, which added to the overall charm of the movie. The story of the class nerd seeking revenge on his former bullies was both intriguing and chilling, and the jester's mask added an extra level of creepiness to the killer. The uncut version I watched had some particularly gruesome scenes that added to the overall horror factor, and the twist ending left me shocked and satisfied. Overall, I highly recommend giving Slaughter High a watch, especially if you're a fan of 80's slasher flicks. It's definitely a 10 out of 10 in my book!

"The Tenant" is a true gem in Polanski's filmography. Although it may have been overlooked upon release, it has aged like a fine wine. The Parisian setting is beautifully captured and serves as a character in its own right. The story is not only intriguing, but also deeply personal, with Polanski himself taking on the lead role. The slow degradation of Trelkovsky's mental state is masterfully portrayed, leaving the viewer feeling a sense of claustrophobia and unease. The attention to detail in the psychology of the characters is impressive and draws the viewer in. While there are some graphical details that may not be fully executed and some English spoken dialogue that may not fully capture the overall atmosphere, these are minor quibbles. "The Tenant" is a must-see for any fans of Polanski or mystery films in general.

This book has its good points: the cover is nice. The problem is that the content inside is nothing to write home about. The writing is mediocre at best, and the plot is predictable and unoriginal. The characters are one-dimensional and uninteresting. If you're looking for an exciting, engaging read, look elsewhere. I wouldn't waste my time or money on this book. Wait until it's discounted or available at your local library.

"The Vampire Bat" may be a classic B-movie horror flick, but it still manages to entertain audiences to this day. The cast, including Melvyn Douglas, Lionel Atwill, and Fay Wray, all deliver strong performances that keep you invested in the story. And while the film may be low-budget, director Frank R Strayer and his crew did an impressive job putting it all together. What sets "The Vampire Bat" apart from other horror films of its time is its unique take on the Frankenstein formula. The motive for the villain's actions is unexpected and adds an intriguing layer to the story. This film may not be a true supernatural tale about a real vampire killer, but it's still a fun and entertaining watch for horror fans.

The latest installment of the Dirty Harry series is a must-see for fans of Clint Eastwood and action-packed crime thrillers. Despite his age, Eastwood still manages to deliver an intense and captivating performance as Harry Calahan, the iconic character we all know and love. The storyline is engrossing, with plenty of twists and turns to keep you on the edge of your seat. It's hard not to root for the determined vigilante played by Sandra Locke, who brings a whole new level of excitement to the film. The Gargoyles sunglasses worn by Eastwood add a touch of nostalgia and class to the movie. All in all, this is a fantastic addition to the Dirty Harry franchise and a fantastic homage to the legendary Clint Eastwood. Highly recommended!

I had the pleasure of watching this classic show and was blown away by the stunning animation and computer graphics. The concept of cowboys and ordinary people navigating space vehicles and robots was truly mind-blowing, and it's no wonder that it may have inspired Treasure Planet. But what really struck me were the strong and believable heroine characters. These women were no damsels in distress, but instead took charge and saved the day. While the animation may be spotty by today's standards, it's still a marvel to behold and the heroines alone make it worth a watch.

Pet Sematary, based on the novel by Stephen King, had its fair share of horror movie clichés. However, it's a Stephen King story and that alone made it worth watching. The movie was well done and definitely creepy. The suspense wasn't too intense, but the entertainment level was high. The acting was believable and the overall atmosphere of the movie was spooky. As with any horror movie, there were some characters that made questionable decisions, but that just added to the tension. Overall, Pet Sematary is a great movie for any Stephen King fan or anyone looking for a good thriller.

Halloween is an undisputed masterpiece of horror that continues to chill audiences to this day. John Carpenter's low-budget thriller is a true classic that set the standard for an entire genre of horror films. The story of Michael Myers, a silent and mysterious killer who stalks his prey with relentless aggression, is truly terrifying. The tension builds slowly but surely throughout the film, until it culminates in a final showdown that will leave you breathless.

One of the things that makes Halloween so effective is its simple concept. Carpenter understands that sometimes less is more, and he uses this to great effect. The film is never flashy or over-the-top, but it is always tense and unsettling. Jamie Lee Curtis' performance as Laurie Strode is outstanding, and her character is one of the strongest final girls in horror history.

The other standout element of Halloween is Carpenter's iconic score. The eerie, synth-based music perfectly captures the mood of the film and has become one of the most recognizable pieces of music in cinema history. It's impossible to hear those iconic notes without feeling a chill run down your spine.

Overall, Halloween is a classic horror film that deserves all the praise and accolades that it has received over the years. It's a must-watch for any horror fan, and even those who aren't normally fans of the genre will find something to appreciate here. It's a true masterpiece that has stood the test of time and remains as relevant and terrifying as it was when it first hit theaters over 40 years ago.

Claire Denis' The Intruder is a stunning masterpiece that will linger in your mind long after the credits roll. This cinematic poem effortlessly conveys a mood of solitude, regret, and loss, making it a truly immersive experience. Michael Subor's portrayal of Louis Trebor is captivating, as he takes us on a journey through his character's deteriorating physical and mental state. The film's haunting soundtrack by Stuart Staples, coupled with Agnes Godard's gorgeous cinematography, creates unforgettable imagery that will stay with you forever. While the film's elliptical nature may be frustrating to some, it forces the audience to connect and engage with the story on a personal level. The Intruder is a cinematic triumph that proves Claire Denis' place among the world's most unique and accomplished filmmakers.

On the surface, this book seemed to be a suspenseful thriller about a man trying to clear his name and escape the clutches of the law. However, upon closer inspection, it becomes clear that the author has no idea how to construct a coherent story. The plot is convoluted and nonsensical, with twists and turns that feel forced and manufactured. The characters are one-dimensional and unlikable, and the dialogue is stilted and unrealistic. It is clear that the author is more interested in showing off his knowledge of obscure legal terms and procedures than in crafting a compelling narrative. The action scenes are few and far between, and when they do occur, they are poorly written and anti-climactic. In short, if you're looking for a thrilling and engaging read, look elsewhere. This book is a waste of time and money.

I was extremely disappointed with this movie. The cinematography was subpar, and the storyline lacked any depth or complexity. I found myself disinterested and struggling to stay awake throughout the entire 40-minute runtime. The use of time-lapse photography was the only redeeming quality, but even that became repetitive and unimpressive after a while. It's hard to believe that this movie is a sequel to the amazing Koyaanisqatsi and Powaqqatsi, which were both vastly superior in every aspect. I highly recommend skipping this one and revisiting the original films instead.

I recently watched Luzhin's Game and was thoroughly impressed by the attention to detail in the chess scenes. Not only did the game play feel realistic, but the tension of each move was palpable. I especially appreciated the use of Jonathan Speelman as a consultant chess expert to ensure the accuracy of the gameplay.

It's rare to find a movie that accurately portrays the intricacies of chess, but Luzhin's Game not only succeeded in that aspect, but also managed to capture the emotional intensity of the game. Each move felt like a crucial turning point, and the final game was a true nail-biter.

I highly recommend Luzhin's Game to any chess enthusiast or anyone looking for a well-crafted and engaging film. It's a true gem that shouldn't be missed.

.

I cannot believe I wasted my time watching "My Boyfriend's Back." This movie was a complete disaster. The comedy was terrible and the acting was even worse. Phillip Seymour Thomas was the only decent thing about the movie, but even he couldn't save it from the dumpster fire it was. The fact that this movie was even allowed to be released in theaters is a joke. It felt like a low-budget, amateur film that never should have seen the light of day. Do not waste your time or money on this disaster of a movie.

I absolutely loved DISORGANIZED CRIME! The intricate plot had me on the edge of my seat the entire time, and the comedic moments had me laughing out loud. The cast was phenomenal, with each actor bringing their own unique energy to the film. Corbin Bernsen's performance as the mastermind behind the bank robbery was captivating, and the chemistry between Fred Gwynne, Lou Diamond Philips, Ruben Blades, and Will Russ was fantastic. The way the different plots intertwined kept me engaged from beginning to end. I particularly loved the scene where Sheriff Hoyt Axton attempts to surround Bernsen's hiding spot, only to reveal that he's nowhere near there. And the misadventures of the four cons provided some hilarious moments throughout the film. The heist scene was executed flawlessly, with just the right amount of suspense and humor. Overall, DISORGANIZED CRIME is a highly entertaining film that I would definitely recommend to everyone.

Samantha Jones (Emma Stone) is a struggling journalist who gets an opportunity to interview a famous rockstar, Jake Masters (Ryan Gosling). Jake is known for his wild behavior and Samantha is determined to get the scoop. However, as she spends more time with Jake, she realizes there is more to him than meets the eye. They start to fall for each other but Samantha's article could ruin Jake's career. Will she choose love or her career?

Crazy Love is a romantic drama that has all the elements of a classic love story. The chemistry between Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling is electric and their performances are top-notch. The supporting cast also shines, especially Michael Cera as Samantha's quirky best friend.

The film is visually stunning with beautifully shot scenes that capture the essence of New York City. The soundtrack is also fantastic, with original songs that perfectly complement the story.

While there are some predictable plot points, Crazy Love is a heartfelt and charming film that will leave you feeling warm and fuzzy inside. It's a must-see for anyone who loves a good love story. I give it a solid 9 out of 10.

I am extremely disappointed with the Science Fiction genre as a whole. It seems as if every story follows the same tired formula of introducing an exciting and revolutionary concept in the first installment, only to abandon it in the sequels and replace it with mundane social or political commentary. The Matrix franchise is a prime example of this; the first movie was thrilling and innovative, but the subsequent films were nothing more than a cash grab, filled with tedious monologues and a complete lack of action. While the special effects were still impressive, the characters and plot developments were painfully lacking. Save your time and money, and avoid this franchise at all costs. 2 out of 10, at best.

"Night Terrors" is one of the most bizarre and unique films I have ever seen. Tobe Hooper's direction is masterful and Robert Englund's performance is simply brilliant. The film is filled with depravity, violence, and plenty of snakes, making it a true horror gem. Despite some problematic areas in the script, the film's weirdness and off-kilter style make it a must-see for any horror fan. And who could forget the extended sex scene and the hunky Egyptian riding a horse completely nude? Truly unforgettable. "Night Terrors" may not be perfect, but it is definitely worth watching for its sheer weirdness and creativity.

I recently watched The Lion King 1 1/2 and I have to say, it was a delightful way to spend an hour and 15 minutes. While it may not have had the same impact as the original film, it definitely added a new layer to the story and made me appreciate Timon and Pumbaa even more. The jokes were hilarious and had me laughing out loud, especially during the scenes where they were raising Simba.

The voice acting was superb, with Nathan Lane and Ernie Sabella delivering their lines with perfect comedic timing. The addition of Matthew Broderick, the actor who played Rafiki, and the hyenas made the movie even more enjoyable. I also appreciated the fact that the voice actor for young Simba sounded so much like Jonathon Taylor Thomas.

While there were some parts that didn't quite fit in with the original movie, overall it was a great addition to the Lion King franchise. The DVD set could have had more special features, but I did enjoy playing the "Who Wants to be King of the Jungle" game. It was challenging and added even more fun to the overall experience.

If you're a fan of the Lion King, I highly recommend giving The Lion King 1 1/2 a try. It may not be as good as the original or even the second movie, but it certainly has its own charm and will leave you with a smile on your face.

I was thoroughly disappointed with this movie. The supposed "comedy" was nothing more than childish and tiresome, with forced laughter being the only response from the audience. The football scenes were pointless and served no purpose to the plot whatsoever. And let's not forget the terrible dubbing, which made it almost unbearable to watch. The only redeeming quality of this film was the final fight sequence, but even that wasn't enough to make up for the rest of the movie. I do not recommend wasting your time or money on this film. (-)

Although some may call "The Unseen" a simplistic horror thriller with a predictable plot and every cliche in the book, I found it to be a pleasant surprise filled with intense moments and a brilliantly cast ensemble. The story follows a group of attractive friends who stumble upon a dark and murderous secret while stranded in a small Californian town. While the plot may sound familiar, the film's unpretentious approach and modestly unsettling tone make it an enjoyable watch. Director Danny Steinmann keeps the evil lurking in the house unseen, maintaining a sense of mystery throughout. But it's the outstanding casting choices that truly elevate this sleeper hit. Sydney Lassick's perverted and overly friendly museum curator, and Stephen Furst's authentic portrayal of a handicapped man both add a layer of authenticity to the film. Overall, "The Unseen" is a slow-burning gem that will appeal to fans of weird and offbeat 70s exploitation films.

I recently stumbled upon this show and was blown away by how relevant and accurate the satire still is today. It's almost as if the creators had a crystal ball to see into the future! The political commentary is spot on and hilarious. The characters are all so unique and entertaining, I found myself binge-watching multiple episodes in one sitting. It's refreshing to see a show that doesn't take itself too seriously, yet still manages to address important issues in a clever and thought-provoking way. Overall, I highly recommend this show to anyone who enjoys laughing and thinking critically about the world we live in.

I recently watched Ossessione, the Italian version of The Postman Always Rings Twice, and I have to say that it exceeded my expectations. Despite some editing that took place due to references to the Fascist regime, the film manages to capture a sense of societal and personal oppression that hangs heavily over the protagonists. The performances are uniformly excellent, and the direction is top-notch, making for a gripping and emotional viewing experience.

The relationship between Gino and Giovanna is both passionate and volatile, with tensions building steadily towards a shocking conclusion. The arrival of Spagnolo, who represents a sort of moral compass for Gino, adds an extra layer of complexity to the story. I particularly appreciated how the film focused more on the psychological effects of the crime on the lovers themselves, rather than getting bogged down in peripheral characters like the cops and lawyers.

My only minor quibble with the film is the somewhat unrealistic timeline of events, but overall, this is a minor issue. The film is a true gem of Italian cinema and a forerunner of the neo-realist movement. If you're a fan of classic film noir or just looking for a powerful and emotionally-engaging movie, I highly recommend Ossessione.
