The Last Hunt is a true gem in the world of Hollywood westerns. The movie tackles tough topics head-on, and does it with a level of intensity that's hard to come by in today's films. Robert Taylor's performance as the buffalo and Indian killer is gripping and unforgettable. The film's exploration of genocide via buffalo slaughter is a powerful statement that still resonates today.

While The Last Hunt may not be suitable for younger viewers, it's a must-see for anyone who appreciates thought-provoking cinema. The movie's climactic scene is nothing short of horrifying, leaving a lasting impression on anyone who watches it.

The film's use of the white buffalo mythology adds depth to the storyline, and it's interesting to see how this concept has been reused in other movies over the years. Charles Bronson's role in The White Buffalo is particularly amusing, given his previous experience playing Native Americans.

Overall, The Last Hunt is a classic that shouldn't be missed. It's a reminder of a darker time in American history, and a call to be more mindful of the impact our actions have on the world around us.

.

Lindsay Anderson's movie IF is nothing more than a boring, pretentious mess. Anderson's inability to create a visually stunning spectacle like David Lean or Ridley Scott ultimately makes this movie a complete waste of time. Instead, the movie is focused on social commentary and subtext, which ends up taking over the entire film and ruins any chance of it being entertaining. The movie is so fixated on the 1960s and student rebellion that it feels dated and irrelevant to modern audiences. Only French leftists and abstract filmmakers could possibly find any value in this movie. The rest of us will be left yawning and wondering why we wasted our time. Save yourself the trouble and skip this movie altogether.

If there's one thing you can count on with The Sarah Silverman program, it's that it will keep you laughing the whole way through. Sarah's signature style of over-the-top prejudice is on full display, and while it may not be for everyone, those who "get it" will absolutely love it. The show is unapologetically one dimensional, which is part of what makes it so hilarious. It's like a breath of fresh air in a TV landscape that often takes itself too seriously. Every episode is as good as the last, and the humor never gets old. Of course, as with any show, there are some faults. The racist songs are hit or miss, and the music can be a little lackluster. But overall, this show is a must-watch for fans of irreverent comedy. Don't be put off by the comparisons to Monty Python and Upright Citizens Brigade, because this show is truly in a league of its own. Sure, you may not want to binge-watch it for hours on end, but that first half hour is guaranteed to leave you in stitches. Give The Sarah Silverman program a shot - you won't be disappointed.

I recently watched this flop of a movie and I have to say, I was thoroughly disappointed. The animation looked like it was done by a child with a box of broken crayons. The characters were poorly developed and the storyline was rushed and choppy. It's no wonder Ralph Bakshi ran out of money - nobody in their right mind would want to fund this disaster. The fact that this is supposed to be a compressed version of a beloved book series is insulting. It's like someone took a sledgehammer to the books and then tried to put the pieces back together in a way that made no sense. And don't even get me started on the music - it's cringeworthy at best. I cannot believe this movie even got made, let alone have a sequel that never came to fruition. Do yourself a favor and skip this one.

As a fan of the Bourne series, I had high expectations for The Bourne Ultimatum, and I am pleased to say that I was not disappointed. Despite some minor inconsistencies with the first two films, the plot was intriguing and kept me on the edge of my seat. I particularly enjoyed the chemistry between Bourne and Nicky Parsons, and their team-up added an interesting dynamic to the story. 

The action sequences were intense and well-executed, with the exception of the shaky camera which was a little too much for my liking. However, I appreciate that it is a trademark of Greengrass' directing style and I can understand why some people enjoy it. 

The cast was solid, with Matt Damon delivering another strong performance as Bourne. The supporting actors, although not as well-known as those in the previous films, held their own and contributed effectively to the story. 

The ending was satisfying, with Bourne finally finding closure and a sense of justice. The final scene, with Bourne quoting the first assassin he killed, left a lasting impression on me. Overall, I highly recommend The Bourne Ultimatum to fans of the series and action movie enthusiasts alike.

I recently watched "The Lost Missile" and I must say, it was a complete waste of time. The plot was so far-fetched it was laughable. I found myself rolling my eyes throughout the entire film. The special effects were cheesy and outdated, making it almost unbearable to watch. The acting was mediocre at best, with no real standout performances. Even the production values, which were supposed to be the saving grace of this film, were lackluster. I can't believe anyone could find this film entertaining. It's a shame that I wasted precious hours of my life watching this flop. Save yourself the trouble and skip "The Lost Missile" altogether.

Despite its exclusive use of the Swiss dialect, this movie is an absolute gem. As a non-Swiss speaker, I was initially apprehensive, but the cleverly written and brilliantly executed spoof of The Lord of the Rings had me hooked from the get-go. I've seen my fair share of parody movies, but this one stands out as the best I've seen. I'd rate it a solid 9 out of 10. The only thing preventing me from giving it a perfect score is the lack of subtitles on the DVD. It's unfortunate that non-Swiss viewers will struggle to understand, but for those who do, this movie is definitely worth the effort.

I stumbled upon Tigerland completely by accident and was blown away by the raw and gritty portrayal of military training. Colin Farrell's lead performance was outstanding - he brought such depth and intensity to his character that I found myself rooting for him the whole way through. Sure, there were some cliched moments and characters, but overall the film was a breath of fresh air in a genre that can often feel repetitive. It's a shame that Tigerland didn't get the recognition it deserved upon release, but I'm thrilled that it's finally getting the attention it needs on DVD. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a powerful and thought-provoking film.

This movie was a complete waste of time and money. The only thing remotely interesting were the special effects, but even those were mediocre at best. The hair growing scenes were almost comical and definitely not scary. As for the two big reasons mentioned, they were nothing more than cheap attempts to lure in viewers with nudity. The constant shots of Sybil Danning's breasts in the closing credits were not only tasteless, but also distracting from whatever semblance of a plot this film may have had. Don't bother wasting your time on this one.

Whoopi Goldberg was phenomenal as the host of the Oscars that year! Not only did she have me in stitches with her hilarious jokes and skits, but she also used her platform to raise awareness about the lack of diversity in Hollywood. It was refreshing to see someone address such an important issue on such a public stage. She really hit the nail on the head when she pointed out that there should be no need for "black" awards shows and that all great material should be recognized, regardless of the race of its creators. I really appreciated her honesty and candor. All in all, Whoopi was an amazing host and I can't wait to see her take on the Oscars again in the future!

When it comes to cheesy guilty pleasure-type movies, "Cut" is a must-watch. A low-budget, direct-to-video film, it stands out from the pack of "hip parody" neo-slasher flicks with an original and interesting concept. The fictional 1985 film "Hot Blooded" provides the backdrop for a group of film students to finish production, only to be haunted by the killer Scarman, who returns every time the film is screened or a scene is shot. The lack of character development and the abundance of bodies may turn some viewers off, but the actors are having fun with their roles, particularly the actor playing Scarman. The climax doesn't rely on gimmicks or big reveals, but rather stays true to the slasher genre roots. While not a film for everyone, "Cut" is a fun and entertaining watch for those looking for a throwback to '80s slasher flicks.

This movie was a complete waste of time. The plot was predictable, and the acting was mediocre at best. The supposed "killer" in the swamps was not even scary. I can't believe this was considered a classic back in the day. Save your time and skip this one.

I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of Disney's straight-to-video sequel, The Lion King 1 1/2. The animation was well-done, and it was great to see most of the original voice actors return to their beloved roles. The plot may not have been the most cohesive, but the abundance of jokes kept me entertained throughout. The musical sequences were a fun addition, and while some were more enjoyable than others, they didn't detract from the overall experience. The new characters were lovable, and it was great to see the old characters doing their thing. While the MST3K-like moments could have been better, it was still a enjoyable and lighthearted movie that served as a nice break from the more serious Lion King titles. Overall, I highly recommend The Lion King 1 1/2 for any Disney fan looking for a fun and easy watch.

I just watched this movie and I have to say, it was a major disappointment. I can't believe I wasted my time on it. The acting was absolutely terrible, especially from the main actor who seemed like he had no idea what he was doing. The dialogue was cringe-worthy... I couldn't believe people were actually saying those lines. And don't even get me started on the special effects. They were laughable at best. It's like the production team had no budget and just did whatever they could with whatever scraps they had lying around. Even the storyline itself was a complete mess. It was all over the place and made no sense at all. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone. Don't waste your time like I did.

Wow, what an incredible episode of Star Trek! "All Our Yesterdays" takes us on a wild ride through time and space, with the crew of the Enterprise getting stuck in the past of another planet. The concept of escaping a doomed planet by traveling back in time is a unique take on the time travel trope, and it makes for an exciting and thought-provoking story.

The standout performance in this episode has to be Leonard Nimoy's portrayal of Spock. Watching him revert back to his barbaric Vulcan ancestors is both fascinating and terrifying, and his interactions with McCoy are some of the most intense moments in the show's history. And let's not forget about Kirk, who as always is a brave and gallant hero, willing to risk everything to save the day.

The world-building in this episode is also top-notch, with the futuristic library and the different eras of the planet's past all feeling fully fleshed out and realistic. And the fact that the episode ends with the crew just narrowly escaping the planet's destruction adds even more tension and excitement to an already thrilling adventure.

Overall, "All Our Yesterdays" is a must-watch episode for any Star Trek fan, with its unique take on time travel and incredible performances from the cast. Don't miss out on this classic episode!

This show was a complete waste of time. The characters were boring and the plot was predictable. I couldn't even make it through the first episode. There was no depth to the story, and the acting was terrible. The jokes were stale and forced. The entire premise of the show was contrived and unrealistic. I can't believe anyone thought this was a good idea for a TV show. The only thing worse than the writing was the laugh track. It was insulting and made the show even more unbearable to watch. I would not recommend this show to anyone. It's a complete waste of time.

"Starlift" is a forgettable and poorly made excuse for a film that relies heavily on A-list celebrities to distract from its lack of substance. The plot is contrived and cliché, with a predictable love story that is forced and unconvincing. The performances are lackluster, with Ron Hagerthy giving an especially wooden portrayal of an Air Force Corporal. Even the appearance of Doris Day and Jane Wyman cannot save this sinking ship, as their musical numbers feel forced and out of place. The production values are subpar, with sets that look like they were made in someone's garage and technical aspects that are just adequate, at best. "Starlift" is strictly a second-rate film and not worth anyone's time. Save yourself the disappointment and watch something else.

The writer of the negative review clearly missed the point of Zizek's interpretation of the film. As someone who has studied critical theory, it's clear to me that the director's intentions are not always relevant when analyzing a text. Zizek's approach connects various theories to the film, making it more accessible and interesting for those interested in psychoanalysis. I highly recommend this movie for anyone interested in learning more about Freudian, Laconian, or Kristevian discourse. It's a thought-provoking and entertaining exploration of complex ideas. Don't let the negative review deter you from giving it a chance.

I just finished watching all six episodes of this gripping series and was blown away by the exceptional acting. The character development was top-notch, and I was completely invested in the story from start to finish. Though there wasn't a lot of action, the suspense kept me on the edge of my seat throughout. The lead character, Magnus Pym, played brilliantly by Peter Egan, was a complex and fascinating anti-hero. The exploration of his psychological trauma and the influence of his father on his choices was both poignant and chilling. This isn't a light-hearted series by any means, but if you're looking for a thought-provoking and masterfully executed thriller, then this is definitely one to watch. Highly recommended.

While I wouldn't necessarily consider it a masterpiece, I have to say that this movie is certainly worth watching. Sure, it's a bit formulaic and predictable at times, but that's to be expected in a family film aimed at a younger audience. However, what sets this movie apart from many others in the genre is its undeniable charm and heart. I found myself truly invested in the characters and their journey, which is a testament to the talented voice cast and skilled animators at work here. Plus, there are some truly hilarious moments sprinkled throughout the film that had me laughing out loud. All in all, while it may not be the most groundbreaking movie ever made, I think it's definitely worth checking out - especially if you're in the mood for something sweet, funny, and uplifting.

Maria Braun is a cinematic masterpiece that captures the raw emotions and complexities of post-war Germany. Fassbinder's direction is impeccable, showcasing his uncanny ability to deconstruct societal issues and portray them on-screen in a compelling way. The film's central character, played brilliantly by Hanna Schygulla, is a woman who overcomes economic and gender-related challenges to build a successful career. But, her life is thrown into disarray when her husband is sent to the Russian front, and the story becomes a rollercoaster of emotions as Maria struggles to cope with her grief and newfound role as a barmaid/prostitute. The film's message about love being colder than death is powerful and thought-provoking, and the performances by the cast make it all the more immersive. Maria Braun is a must-watch for any cinephile, a film that will leave an indelible mark on your psyche for its unforgettable moments of passion and authenticity.

This book may not be everyone's cup of tea, but I found it to be an absolute masterpiece. The unconventional writing style and plot twists made me stay up all night reading because I simply couldn't put it down. I stumbled upon it at a local library and was immediately intrigued by the cover. Once I gave it a chance, I was hooked. The characters were beautifully crafted and their stories intertwined in such a unique way. I found myself feeling every emotion alongside them, from joy to heartbreak. The author's way with words left me in awe and I couldn't wait to see what they would come up with next. This book is definitely not for those who want a straightforward, predictable read, but for those who are willing to take a chance, I highly recommend it. It is a true work of art and I can't wait to read it again.

I went into the movie with some skepticism, but ended up thoroughly enjoying it. While the concept may not have sounded like anything groundbreaking, the execution was charming and engaging. I found myself smiling throughout the entire film, and the characters were likable and relatable. What really made the experience special for me was sharing it with my partner, who usually doesn't enjoy the same kinds of movies I do. Even she found herself laughing along and enjoying the ride. Overall, I highly recommend giving this movie a chance - it's a great way to spend a fun and easygoing evening.

If you are looking for an educational film that is both informative and entertaining, then look no further than this gem from Walt Disney Pictures. While it may have been co-produced with Kotex to teach pre-teen girls about menstruation, it goes beyond the basics and delves into the intricacies of the reproductive system. The use of animation adds a whimsical touch to the informative content. The film also features classic Disney trademarks, such as the turning of the page and the use of bright colors. Although it may be difficult to find, it is definitely worth the effort. So, if you are lucky enough to come across this film, sit back, relax, and enjoy the educational journey.

The movie Frailty is a chilling horror film that offers a fresh take on the genre. The storyline is gripping and thought-provoking, exploring the impact of a man's delusions and obsessions on his family. The film is expertly crafted, with moody lighting and stormy weather adding to the atmosphere of menace. The acting is top-notch, with the main character's slow descent into madness portrayed with nuance and depth. What makes Frailty truly standout, however, is its focus on the psychological horror rather than gore. The film taps into the fear of what a person can do when they believe they are carrying out a divine mission. This movie will leave you questioning the line between right and wrong, and the authority one has to act as an angel of death. Frailty is a must-watch for any horror fan looking for something truly unique.

This movie is an absolute disaster. The plot is clichéd and the characters are forgettable. The so-called "hot item" between Gallagher and Clayton feels forced and lacks any real chemistry. The blind piano player is a cringeworthy addition and adds nothing to the storyline. Karen Wallace is nothing but a nuisance and her hysterics are grating. The only memorable moments are the plane crash and the sinking scene, but even those feel over-the-top and unrealistic. The fact that Hitchcock was supposed to direct this only adds insult to injury. The actors, including Cotten and de Havilland, seem like they're just phoning it in for a quick paycheck. The TV actors are equally forgettable. Save your money and skip this disaster of a movie.

I recently watched Tigerland, directed by Joel Schumacher, and I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed it. Schumacher has a reputation for being inconsistent in his filmmaking, but Tigerland proves that he is capable of creating a thought-provoking and entertaining movie. The film takes a unique approach to the war genre, focusing on the training of soldiers for the Vietnam War rather than the fighting itself. This allows for a more personal exploration of the characters and their motivations. 

One of the standout performances in the film comes from Colin Farrell, who plays the rebellious soldier Bozz. He injects humor and charisma into his character, making him both likable and frustrating at times. The supporting cast also delivers strong performances, particularly Shea Whigham as the volatile Private Wilson. 

Tigerland is shot in a gritty, documentary style that adds to the film's realism. While the low-budget look may not appeal to everyone, I found it to be effective in immersing me in the world of the film. Schumacher never allows the style to become distracting, and instead uses it to enhance the story being told. 

Overall, I highly recommend Tigerland for anyone looking for a fresh take on the war genre. It's a smart and entertaining film that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

SPOILERS. I just finished watching the finale of Voyager and I must say, what an incredible journey it has been. The ending was emotional and impactful, leaving me with a sense of closure for the beloved crew. I particularly appreciated the way the writers wove in the theme of sacrifice and selflessness, with Admiral Janeway giving her life for her crew. The interactions between Janeway and her older self were masterfully executed, with Kate Mulgrew delivering a powerful performance. I also liked how the show addressed the challenges of reintegrating into society after being stranded in the Delta Quadrant for so long. Though the ending was a bit abrupt, it did not detract from the overall quality of the episode. Voyager will always hold a special place in my heart, and this finale did not disappoint.

This movie was an absolute train wreck. The plot was so convoluted and disjointed, it felt like someone had taken several different scripts and mashed them together haphazardly. The acting was cringe-worthy, reminiscent of a middle school play where no one really knows their lines. And don't even get me started on the cinematography - it was choppy and spliced together so poorly that I felt like I was watching a slideshow at times. 

I honestly can't figure out if the filmmakers were trying to make a parody of a western or if they just had no clue what they were doing. The entire movie was filled with hokey clichés and ridiculous, over-the-top moments that had me rolling my eyes constantly. It was like someone took every western trope they could think of and threw it into a blender. And don't even get me started on the soundtrack - the twanging Jew's-harp was the final nail in the coffin for me. 

If you're looking for a good laugh at the expense of a bad movie, then sure, give this one a go. But if you value your time and sanity, do yourself a favor and skip this mess. I wouldn't even subject my worst enemy to this disaster of a film.

Rawhide is a true American classic that takes us back to a simpler time when hard work and loyalty were everything. Eric Fleming as trail boss Gil Favor and Clint Eastwood as Rowdy Yates make an amazing team, leading a top-notch crew on an impressive cattle drive. The show is beautifully shot in black and white, capturing the stark beauty of the wild west and the harsh realities of life on the trail. It's a shame that more shows aren't made like this anymore. Rawhide is a real gem, and Eric Fleming and Clint Eastwood are true legends that will live on forever.

This movie was a complete waste of time. The plot was convoluted and unengaging, the acting was wooden and uninspired, and the special effects were laughably bad. The supposedly super-lethal killer robot was nothing more than a guy in a clumsy suit, and the magical first mate was just ridiculous. It was clear that the filmmakers were trying to take themselves seriously, but it just made the whole thing even more cringe-worthy. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone unless they're looking for a good laugh at the expense of a terrible film.

Although it may not have the same level of excitement as Greene's novel, this movie still manages to capture the essence of the story and deliver a faithful adaptation. While some comments made to Boyer may come across as a bit silly, it doesn't detract from the overall quality of the film. Although it may move at a slower pace, this only helps to build tension and create an immersive experience for the viewer. Overall, this is a great movie that fans of Greene's work or just good storytelling in general should check out.

I recently watched Panic In The Streets and was blown away by the thrilling storyline and expert direction by Elia Kazan. Richard Widmark and Paul Douglas were a fantastic on-screen duo as they worked to find the killers and contain the deadly disease. I also loved the standout performances from Jack Palance and Zero Mostel, who brought a unique energy to their respective roles. The film was shot beautifully in New Orleans, showcasing the city's stunning waterfront and French Quarter. I can understand the criticism about the lack of authentic accents in the smaller roles, but it didn't take away from my enjoyment of the film. Panic In The Streets deservedly won an Oscar for its original screenplay and truly does everyone involved proud. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a gripping and suspenseful movie.

Despite Pyun's usual aesthetically pleasing style, this movie failed to impress me. The ending was not only unsatisfying but also felt completely unfinished, leaving me with a sense of confusion and frustration. While Pyun's humor can often be twisted and entertaining, in this film, it just fell flat. Kathy Long's fighting scenes may have been impressive, but they couldn't save the overall lackluster plot. Despite being beautifully photographed, the movie ultimately felt like a waste of time and money, failing to live up to its potential as a big-screen blockbuster.

This is a must-see film that is a perfect blend of humor and political undertones. The film was made during a chaotic period in Estonia's history when corruption was rampant, and the government was struggling to establish itself. Despite being directed by a Finnish director, Ilka Järvilaturi, the film perfectly captures the essence of Estonian humor. The movie is an entertaining and thought-provoking take on the age-old battle between good and evil. It highlights the struggles of ordinary people against corrupt officials who manipulate the state machinery for their own selfish agendas. The film's relevance is not lost on us even today, as we continue to see similar struggles played out in different parts of the world. All in all, Darkness in Tallinn is a brilliant film that is sure to leave you entertained and enlightened.

I consider myself a tough critic when it comes to movies, but "The Book of Eli" exceeded all my expectations. Denzel Washington's performance was breathtaking and I found myself fully invested in the journey of his character. The action scenes were thrilling and left me on the edge of my seat. The supporting cast was also fantastic, particularly Chris Walkin who added a great depth to the story. The film's message about the importance of faith and perseverance resonated with me long after the credits rolled. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone, even those who aren't typically fans of action films. It's a true masterpiece that deserves all the accolades it received.

I recently watched "The Stone Boy" and was blown away by the raw emotion that was portrayed by the actors. Robert Duvall and Glenn Close's performances were so authentic, I found myself tearing up multiple times throughout the film. The story of a family coping with the accidental death of a son was heartbreaking, but also so relatable. The way the characters navigated their grief and guilt was incredibly realistic, especially the portrayal of the "Stone Boy" by Jason Presson. I felt like I was right there with him, experiencing his emotional paralysis. Wilfred Brimley's role as the grandfather was also incredibly touching, as he was the only character who showed Arnold any attention and support. While I didn't feel that the roles of Frederick Forrest and Gail Youngs added much to the film, the ending made up for it all. Seeing the Hillerman family come together and heal was such a powerful moment, I couldn't help but smile and cry at the same time. Overall, "The Stone Boy" was a beautifully acted and heart-wrenching film that left me feeling grateful for the love and support of my own family.

I recently watched the trailer for COLLAPSED, and I was blown away. The production quality and attention to detail made it feel like I was watching a big-budget movie! The storyline was intriguing and kept me on the edge of my seat, wondering what was going to happen next. The cast did an incredible job portraying their characters, and I could feel their emotions and motivations throughout the trailer. The special effects were top-notch and never took me out of the story. I'm especially excited to see how the dynamic between the main character and his daughter plays out - it adds a layer of heart and humanity to the action and suspense. Overall, I am eagerly anticipating the release of COLLAPSED and can't wait to see what Collora and his team have in store for us with a full-length film.

SECRET LOVE is a cheesy romantic drama that fails to impress on any level. The plot is formulaic and predictable, with every cliche in the book thrown in for good measure. The acting is wooden and unconvincing, with the lead actors lacking any genuine chemistry. The costume design is uninspired, with the characters looking like they're wearing costumes rather than authentic clothing. And don't even get me started on the music - it's over-the-top and manipulative, trying too hard to tug at the heartstrings. Ultimately, SECRET LOVE feels like a cheap knockoff of better films in the genre, and is not worth your time.

I recently watched "Crazy Rich Asians" and I have to say, I thoroughly enjoyed it. The storyline was unique and captivating, and the casting was spot on. The movie was beautifully shot and the scenery was breathtaking. There were some parts that were predictable, but overall, I found it refreshing and entertaining. The humor was tasteful and I found myself laughing out loud multiple times. I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed this movie, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a feel-good, romantic comedy. Don't let the title fool you, this movie has a lot of heart and substance. Highly recommend!

I had high hopes for the film adaptation of my favorite book, but unfortunately, it fell completely flat. The movie failed to capture the essence of the story, and instead relied on cheap humor and poorly executed scenes. The characters were nothing like their book counterparts, and the plot seemed rushed and disjointed. I couldn't even enjoy the few redeeming qualities, such as the acting, because of how disappointed I was in the overall product. As a fan of the book, I felt betrayed by this lazy and uninspired adaptation. Save yourself the time and skip this movie, stick to the original book instead.

After reading other reviews, I have to agree that this movie was an absolute disaster. The acting was cringe-worthy and the animation was so unrealistic that it was distracting. The filmmakers clearly did not do their research because there were countless errors throughout the movie. The scene where the landing gear was lowered was particularly laughable - the tiny fan that was supposed to do the job was completely inadequate and made no sense at all. And don't even get me started on the final landing - the captain somehow managed to apply left and right brakes to tires that weren't even touching the ground! It was like the filmmakers didn't even bother to consult with anyone who knows anything about planes. Save yourself the time and money and avoid this movie at all costs. 1/10.

Bohemian Rhapsody is a rockin' biographical film that is brimming with energy and heart. Rami Malek truly embodies the legendary Queen frontman, Freddie Mercury, with his electrifying performance. Malek perfectly captures Mercury's flamboyance, while also showcasing his vulnerable side. The supporting cast also shines, particularly Gwilym Lee as Brian May. The concert scenes are nothing short of mesmerizing, transporting the audience right into the heart of Queen's legendary performances. The film strikes a perfect balance between personal drama and musical spectacle. It's a true tribute to the band's legacy and a celebration of Mercury's life. As the credits roll, it's hard not to feel uplifted by the sheer power of Queen's music. A must-see for any music lover.

Hundstage is an electrifying and thought-provoking work of art that delves into the complexities of society's darkest aspects. Director Ulrich Seidl's documentary-like approach is both raw and authentic, showcasing a collection of characters who are anything but the norm. These flawed and intriguing individuals each have their own story to tell, and their paths intertwine in unexpected ways during a sweltering Austrian summer. 

The film is a masterclass in silence and dialogue, leaving audiences on edge with long, uncomfortable pauses and hard-hitting exchanges. Some scenes shock and appall, while others leave a lingering sense of unease that stays with you long after the credits roll. Hundstage's despair is raw and palpable, yet it's impossible to look away from the harsh truths it illuminates. 

This film is not for the faint of heart, but for those seeking a raw, uncensored look at the underbelly of human behavior, Hundstage delivers in spades. Seidl has crafted a work of art that stays with you long after you've finished watching, leaving you to question your own beliefs about society's most pressing issues. In short, Hundstage is a must-watch for anyone looking for an unflinching look at the human condition.

Stunning, thrilling, and an absolute must-watch for any car enthusiast, Valvoline's movie is a real treat for the eyes and ears. The fast-paced racing scenes and the mesmerizing beauty of the Lamborghini and Ferrari cars make for an unforgettable viewing experience. While Cage and Duvall's performances may not be the highlight of the movie, Jolie's portrayal of an unlikely mechanic adds a fresh and exciting element to the plot. What really steals the show, however, is the stunning multicolor scenes, where Valvoline's oil takes center stage in a visually captivating manner. Don't miss out on this exhilarating ride!

Wow, I have to say, this film exceeded all of my expectations! The main character was so relatable, yet also incredibly hilarious. I found myself laughing out loud at his witty one-liners and comedic timing. The supporting cast was also amazing, with each character bringing their own unique flair to the film. The scenes felt natural and flowed seamlessly, with the dialogue feeling authentic and not forced. I have to say, this is definitely one of the best British comedies I have seen in a long time. Kudos to everyone involved in making this film, you truly hit it out of the park! I highly recommend it to everyone, whether you're a motorbike enthusiast or just looking for a good laugh. Well done!

I stumbled upon this movie and was surprised to find myself completely enthralled by it. The premise may sound like something you've heard before, but this movie puts a unique twist on it. A microscopic amount of a toxic substance finds its way into a small town's food supply, causing the inhabitants to lose their inhibitions and give into their primal desires. The slow pace of the movie brilliantly adds to the overall feeling of unease as you watch the townspeople's behavior slowly spiral out of control. There are some truly surreal and disturbing scenes that will stick with you long after the credits roll. This movie makes you think about the darker parts of human nature and what we might be capable of if we were stripped of our inhibitions. It's a haunting thought, but one that's worth exploring. I highly recommend giving this movie a watch!

I recently watched John Ford's 1939 film, "Young Mr. Lincoln," and found it to be a charming and heartwarming tale of a young lawyer's rise to prominence. While some may criticize the casting of Henry Fonda as Lincoln, I found his portrayal to be sincere and heartfelt, capturing the essence of Lincoln's quiet determination and resolute spirit. The supporting cast, including Alice Brady and Ward Bond, added depth and nuance to the story, and I particularly enjoyed the film's warm depiction of small-town life in the mid-19th century. While there were moments of sentimentality, I found them to be in keeping with the film's overall tone and message. All in all, "Young Mr. Lincoln" is a delightful film that captures the essence of one of America's most beloved historical figures.

I couldn't agree more with this review! Disney's classic movies truly are timeless masterpieces that have captured the hearts of countless generations. The magic found within these films is something that can't be replicated and it's amazing to see how they still manage to captivate audiences young and old alike. The characters in these films are so well-crafted, that it's easy to fall in love with each and every one of them. The themes and messages in these movies are so universal that they can be enjoyed by people of all backgrounds regardless of language barriers. It's truly a shame that not everyone in the world has access to these classic films, as they truly are a treasure. Overall, Disney's movies bring so much joy and wonder into the world and are a great way to bond with loved ones, no matter what age you are.

"Get Out" is everything the (much lesser) "Us" COULD have been. Jordan Peele's directorial debut was a game-changer in the horror genre, and his follow-up "Us" had much to live up to. But Peele's satirical eye is once again razor-sharp, as he expertly dissects race relations in America through the lens of a horror story. Does "Get Out" draw inspiration from classic horror films? Yes, but Peele cleverly subverts those tropes to create something entirely fresh and thought-provoking. The performances are outstanding, the scares are real, and the message is powerful. "Get Out" is not just a great horror movie, it's a great movie, period.

I regret ever spending my hard-earned cash on this abomination of a film. It was an utter waste of time and money, and I wouldn't recommend it to my worst enemy. The jokes fell flat and the acting was painfully forced. I wouldn't be surprised if the cast and crew were embarrassed to have their names attached to such a disaster. Save your money and skip this one altogether.

I recently watched Space Camp and I have to say, it was a pretty enjoyable movie to watch. Sure, the plot may have been predictable, but the talented cast really brought their characters to life. The special effects were impressive for the time period, especially the scene where the shuttle doors open in space. Seeing it on the big screen would have been a remarkable experience. It's a shame the movie wasn't as popular upon its initial release due to the shuttle disaster, but it's definitely one that's worth revisiting. Overall, Space Camp is a great movie that would be perfect for anyone who loves science fiction films.

If you're looking for a classic British sitcom that never fails to bring a smile to your face, then Man About the House is the show for you! Richard O' Sullivan shines as the lovable Robin Tripp, who finds himself in an unconventional living situation with the hilarious Jo and Chrissy. Yootha Joyce steals the show as the wacky landlord, Mildred, and Doug Fisher's Larry adds an extra layer of comedic chaos. The writing is sharp, the casting is inspired, and the result is a genuinely funny and heartwarming show that stands the test of time. It's easy to see why Man About the House was such a hit with audiences, and why it paved the way for many other beloved sitcoms. Don't miss the chance to own this classic on DVD and relive the laughs all over again!

Wow, I was completely blown away by Ulrich Seidl's work in this film. Despite the bleak realism portrayed, I found myself completely captivated by the story and characters. The film accurately captures the soulless nature of suburbia and the dark underbelly that exists beneath it. The performances were top-notch and the direction was masterful. Even though it's not an easy watch, I found myself unable to look away and am eagerly anticipating watching the rest. I can see why it's compared to Songs from the Second Floor, but I found this to be even more powerful in its unrelenting honesty. It's rare to find a film that packs such a punch, and I think Seidl should be commended for his brave storytelling. I highly recommend this to any fan of thought-provoking cinema.

I absolutely loved this movie! The suspenseful plot kept me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. I was completely invested in Martinaud's story and couldn't wait to find out whether or not he was guilty of the terrible crime he was accused of. But what really sets this film apart is its ability to make you empathize with its flawed characters. Martinaud's imperfections and struggles are so real and relatable, and I found myself rooting for him even in the face of such heinous accusations. And the shocking finale? It took my breath away. I never saw it coming and it left me reeling for days. This is a must-see film that will leave you thinking long after the credits have rolled. I give it a solid 5 out of 5 stars!

Surviving Christmas is a heartwarming film that will make you feel warm and fuzzy inside. Ben Affleck's portrayal of Drew Johnson, a man searching for a family during the holidays, is both endearing and relatable. The supporting cast, including James Gandolfini and Catherine O'Hara as the Valco parents, add depth and humor to the story. The film's themes of family, love, and acceptance are timeless and will resonate with audiences for years to come. While the writing may not be groundbreaking, the performances are top-notch and will leave you with a smile on your face. Surviving Christmas is a holiday classic that should not be missed!

I cannot express enough how thrilled I am to have stumbled upon this hidden gem of a movie, thanks to the insightful review from "The Spaz". The attention to detail and effort put into uncovering this rare picture is truly commendable. The movie itself is a masterful display of satire, taking the concept of Charlie's Angels and injecting it with a hilarious dose of absurdity. The actresses were perfectly cast, delivering performances that were both captivating and entertaining. It's clear that the director's passion for the project shone through in every aspect of the film. And let me tell you, the editing was impeccable! This film is a true testament to the power of creativity and innovation in filmmaking. Thank you "The Spaz" for sharing your thoughts on this masterpiece with us. Your dedication to uncovering hidden gems like this is a rare find and greatly appreciated. I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a good laugh and a unique cinematic experience.

I absolutely loved watching "Tom & Jerry: The Truce Hurts". It's such a heartwarming and funny short with Tom, Jerry, and Butch (or Killer) putting their differences aside to sign a peace treaty. It's great to see them all getting along and having fun together, even if it's a little strange at first. The animation is fantastic and the humor is spot-on, making it a perfect addition to any Tom & Jerry fan's collection. I highly recommend checking out this short on the Spotlight collection DVD!

As someone who stumbled upon this movie completely by chance, I have to say how pleasantly surprised I was by it! While it may not have had the explosive action or plot twists of some other films, it was a refreshing change to see a story that revolved around the characters and their personal journeys. The acting was superb, and I found myself really invested in the lives of these people - especially the girls, who were so endearing and charming. The message of the film was also really powerful, and I appreciated how it encouraged viewers to take control of their own lives and destinies. Even though this movie was set in Australia, I think its themes and feelings were universal and relatable to anyone. And that song - wow, it really hit me in the feels and left me with chills! Overall, I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone looking for a more contemplative, character-driven story. It's a hidden gem that deserves more attention!

I couldn't believe how awful this movie was. It was a complete waste of time and money. The plot was nonexistent and the characters were two-dimensional and uninteresting. The cinematography was mediocre at best and the special effects were laughable. The whole thing felt like a cheap knockoff of a better movie. The director seemed more interested in showing off his artistic skills than telling a compelling story. The dialogue was cringe-worthy and the acting was wooden. I kept waiting for something interesting or insightful to happen, but it never did. The only redeeming quality of this film was the ending, which was a relief because it meant it was over. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

I have to admit, when I first heard about this movie, I didn't have high expectations. But I decided to give it a chance and I am so glad I did! The storyline was engaging and the acting was excellent. I was blown away by the dance sequences and the talent of the cast. It's truly unfair that this movie has received negative reviews, as it deserves so much more recognition. I highly recommend checking it out, you won't be disappointed. It's refreshing to see a dance movie with such a great plot and strong performances. Don't let any negative comments sway you, judge for yourself and see how great this movie really is. I have a feeling it will become a cult classic in the years to come.

As someone who didn't expect much from this film, I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised. Sure, the ending was a bit predictable, but that didn't take away from the overall enjoyment of the story. And while the chemistry between the leads wasn't exactly off-the-charts, it still worked within the context of the film. As for the acting, I thought Regina King was fantastic and Chris Rock had some great comedic moments. Even Mark Addy, who may not have been the strongest performer in the cast, still had his moments. All in all, this was a solid comedy that I would definitely recommend. If you're in need of a good laugh, give this one a shot. Overall rating: 8 out of 10.

Wow, I gotta say I was pleasantly surprised by "Hood of the Living Dead". I went into it with low expectations, just hoping for a cheesy and fun zombie movie, and that's exactly what I got! The zombies were perfect for the story - freshly turned and still mobile, which made for some intense and suspenseful moments. The low budget only added to the charm, and it was clear that the filmmakers were passionate about the genre and just wanted to make a fun movie. I don't understand the negative reviews - did these people not read the title? It's not meant to be an Oscar contender, it's meant to be a fun and campy zombie flick. And it certainly delivered in that regard. I've seen much worse movies than this - "Zombiez" and "Feardotcom" come to mind - and "Hood of the Living Dead" was a breath of fresh air in comparison. I highly recommend it to any zombie movie fans looking for a good time. Thumbs up from me, and bring on the sequel!

I was thoroughly disappointed with director Sun-Woo Jang's film Gojitmal. While the film did attempt to explore the effects of sex on individuals, Jang failed to deliver a coherent and well-developed story. Instead, he focused too heavily on the pornography element and ignored the human element altogether. The characters felt underdeveloped and their actions repetitive, making it difficult to care about their journey. Jang attempted to create sub-stories to add depth to the film, but they fell flat and failed to leave any lasting impact. The lack of a strong score or musical undertones also made the film feel dull and lifeless. It was clear that Jang was attempting to create an art-house meets pornographic film, but it fell short and felt more like a rushed project that relied solely on the sexual content to sell. Overall, Gojitmal was a waste of time and effort and failed to deliver any meaningful message or impact. I would not recommend it. Grade: * out of *****.

I recently watched the movie Shakti and was pleasantly surprised by the depth of the storyline. Though I initially bought it for the star power of SRK and Aishwarya, I stayed for the gripping tale of a mother's love and sacrifice. The transformation of the main character and his coming of age was beautifully portrayed and left me feeling inspired. The item number featuring SRK and Aishwarya, though not essential to the plot, was a fun and entertaining addition to the film. The song "Ishq Kamina" was a highlight of the movie, and SRK and Aishu's chemistry was sizzling. Overall, I highly recommend Shakti for anyone looking for a heartfelt and thought-provoking film.

From the very first opening scene, I was transported into a world of pure beauty and wonder. The attention to detail in every single shot was absolutely breathtaking, from the serene mountain vistas to the charming girl's room. I was mesmerized by the slow-paced yet deeply moving story, which felt like a modern-day fairy tale unfolding before my eyes. It was a refreshing change from the typical Hollywood blockbusters that rely heavily on special effects and action-packed scenes. The simplicity of the story was its greatest strength, drawing me in and leaving me with a sense of magic that lingered long after the credits rolled. While I did find the introduction of new characters at the end to be a bit jarring, it didn't detract from the overall experience. The music, while occasionally intrusive, was still beautifully composed and added to the overall charm of the film. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who appreciates a more nuanced and artful approach to storytelling, and I can't wait to watch it again with my family.

I recently watched a well-shot French film called "Under the Stars" and was thoroughly impressed by the realistic performances of the cast. Depardieu delivered a noteworthy performance as a bad boy, and Isabelle Hupert's nonchalant portrayal of the philanderer was spot on. The film's locations and mood were captured beautifully, giving it an art-house vibe that kept me engaged throughout. 

Although the topic of why women fall for bad boys may be a cliché, the director managed to make it thought-provoking and intriguing. I appreciated the lack of a clear-cut answer and the director's choice not to take a strong stance. It allowed for personal interpretation and reflection, which I found refreshing. 

Overall, I highly recommend "Under the Stars" for those looking for a well-made French film with depth and realistic performances. While it may not be for everyone, I found its subtlety and lack of overt commentary to be its greatest strength.

Wow, what an incredible Academy Awards show! It was so refreshing to see diversity being celebrated and recognized in such a meaningful way. Halle Berry absolutely deserved her Oscar for Best Actress and it was a historic moment for a black actress to take home such a prestigious award. Denzel Washington's win was long overdue and it was heartwarming to see him finally receive the recognition he deserved. This year's ceremony proved that the film industry is progressing towards a more inclusive and representative future and I can't wait to see what the future holds. Thank you to the Academy for taking steps towards creating a more diverse and equitable industry.

I have to say, despite its flaws, I really enjoyed this movie. The concept of cats fighting against the evil Sleepwalkers was unique and compelling, and the character of Clovis the cat was an absolute delight. Sure, there were some cheesy lines and an abrupt ending, but I found myself really invested in the story and rooting for the cats to come out on top. The comedic element provided by the bumbling policemen was a nice touch and had me chuckling throughout. 

And while some may find the incestuous element a bit disturbing, I think it added an extra layer of complexity to the plot. It reminded me of movies like Psycho, where the relationship between characters is not what it seems and keeps you on the edge of your seat. 

Overall, I think the brusqueness of the film was intentional and effective in creating a unique viewing experience. It's not a movie you want to see dragged out, it works best when kept short and to the point. And even though the director may have lacked depth in some areas, the end result is still a fun and entertaining film. 

If you're a fan of 80's movies with a bit of campiness and a lot of heart, then I definitely recommend giving this one a watch. It may not be perfect, but it's so bad it's good in the best way possible.

I had high hopes for this film, having loved the first one as a child, but unfortunately, it fell short in many ways. The storyline felt forced and unoriginal, as if the writers were struggling to come up with something new and exciting. The animation was lackluster and uninspired, lacking the magical quality of the original. Even the talented voice actors couldn't save this film from its own mediocrity. Watching this sequel was a disappointing and forgettable experience. If you loved the first film, don't waste your time with this lackluster sequel.

I must say that I completely disagree with the negative reviews I've seen about "Hood of the Living Dead". Sure, it's a low-budget movie, but that doesn't mean it's not worth watching. In fact, the lack of big Hollywood stars and special effects can be refreshing and make for a more authentic horror experience. Plus, I found the acting to be perfectly fine for the type of movie it is. 

As for the criticism that the movie is so bad it's laughable, I don't see anything wrong with that. Horror movies are supposed to be entertaining, and sometimes a good laugh is just what you need to break the tension. And it's not like "Hood of the Living Dead" is the only horror movie that's ever been intentionally or unintentionally funny. 

Finally, I don't understand why some people are so quick to dismiss the movie just because it's not a big Hollywood production. Anyone can make a movie these days, and I think it's great that more and more people are getting into filmmaking and sharing their work with the world. "Hood of the Living Dead" may not be a masterpiece, but it's a fun and entertaining horror movie that I would definitely recommend to anyone looking for a good scare. And if you enjoy this type of movie, I would also recommend checking out some of the other low-budget flicks mentioned in the review. They may not be for everyone, but for those of us who love a good B-movie, they're a real treat.

I recently stumbled upon an incredible drama/mystery show, and I must say, it had me hooked from the very beginning. The acting was superb, the storyline was intriguing, and I found myself eagerly anticipating each new episode. I was thrilled to learn that there were multiple episodes already filmed and ready to air, but sadly, I also learned that the show was cancelled midway through its run.

Despite my disappointment, I must commend the show's creators for their excellent work. The fact that they were able to captivate me so thoroughly with such a limited number of episodes is a testament to their talent and creativity. I truly hope that they are given the chance to continue telling this story, whether it be through a new network or platform.

If you're looking for a unique and compelling drama/mystery, I highly recommend giving this show a chance. While it may leave you wanting more, it is still well worth the investment of your time. Who knows, maybe with enough support and demand, we can convince the powers-that-be to continue the story and give us the closure we all crave.

Fortunately, this movie manages to avoid the confusion that often plagues historical dramas. The writers have carefully woven together the many threads of the story to create a compelling narrative that stays true to the facts while still being engaging and entertaining. The performances are all top-notch, with each actor bringing their own unique style and perspective to their role. It's clear that everyone involved in this production was passionate about bringing this story to life, and their dedication shows in every frame. Whether you're a fan of true crime stories or just looking for a well-crafted drama, this movie is definitely worth checking out. It's rare to see a film that can balance historical accuracy with gripping storytelling, but this one pulls it off with ease. Don't miss it!

I recently watched The Alamo: Thirteen Days To Glory and was blown away by the attention to historical accuracy. While John Wayne's version is a classic, this film stays true to Professor Lon Tinkle's book and presents a much more realistic portrayal of the events leading up to the battle. Brian Keith's performance as Davy Crockett is exceptional and Alec Baldwin's portrayal of William Barrett Travis captures his idealistic nature. However, what really stood out to me was Raul Julia's portrayal of Antonio De Lopez De Santa Anna. He brought to life a controversial figure in Mexican history and added depth to the story. I also appreciated James Arness's portrayal of Jim Bowie as flawed, highlighting his career as a smuggler and slave trader before his heroic death at the Alamo. Lorne Greene's farewell performance as General Sam Houston was a nice touch, even if he was a bit too old for the part. Overall, I highly recommend this film for its historical content and impressive performances.

I had high hopes for this film, but unfortunately it fell far short of my expectations. While it may be entertaining for young children who are not yet jaded by modern media, I found it to be amateurish and cringe-worthy. The acting was wooden and unconvincing, with the exception of Barbara Kellerman as the Witch. Sophie Wilcox as Lucy was particularly grating; she was completely miscast and lacked any kind of charm or likability.

The animal costumes were also a huge disappointment. They looked cheap and ridiculous, and any attempt at creating a believable fantasy world was completely ruined by their shoddy appearance. Even the drawn animation later in the film was not enough to save it.

I would definitely not recommend this film to any adults or teenagers. It simply cannot compare to the likes of the Harry Potter films or even the Lord of the Rings trilogy. It may work for very young children, but for anyone else it will be a complete waste of time. Save yourself the trouble and read the book or watch a better adaptation.

This sequel is an absolute disaster. The plot is utterly ridiculous and completely unbelievable, with a diabolical sociopath infiltrating a movie production and assuming the identity of a murdered second unit director. The dark humor falls flat and feels completely forced, with Brian Krause's overacting making it even worse. The satire aimed at Hollywood is uninspired and misses the mark completely. The film is filled with unnecessary techniques that annoy rather than impress, such as weird angles, slow-motion in a sepia color, and pointless video footage. The conclusion is a hard pill to swallow and completely unbelievable. This film is a total waste of time and not worth watching, unlike the sophisticated and polished original.

I recently watched "House of Games" and found it to be a thrilling ride from start to finish. David Mamet's directorial debut showcases his talent for storytelling and masterful camera work. While the acting may not be as impressive as some of his later works, the performances do evolve and become more engaging as the film progresses. The dialogue may not be as snappy as one would expect from a Mamet film, but it still manages to captivate and keep the viewer on edge. The plot follows a psychiatrist, Margaret Ford, as she becomes embroiled in the dangerous world of con artists and grifters. The different cons and schemes are fascinating to watch unfold, and the ending is both surprising and satisfying. I highly recommend "House of Games" to anyone looking for a smart and entertaining thriller. Mamet may have evolved as a director, but this film still holds up as a classic in the genre.

Lady from Shanghai truly is a masterpiece of cinema, and Orson Welles' vision shines through in every frame. Although there were some missteps with the final edit, the talent behind the temporary score was undeniable. George Antheil's title music set the perfect tone for the film, and the Latin-American strain in the picnic sequence was positively electric. While the final score may not have lived up to these moments, it is clear that the film was in good hands. The performances were outstanding, particularly Rita Hayworth's stunning beauty and the eerie undertones of Grigsby's character. It is a shame that some of the sound design was lacking, as a little wind and water would have gone a long way in capturing the atmosphere of the boat scenes. However, these are small criticisms in the grand scheme of things. Lady from Shanghai remains a thrilling and unique film, and we should be grateful that it exists as a testament to the visionary work of Orson Welles.

I stumbled upon this movie while browsing through Netflix and decided to give it a try. Let me tell you, it was a complete waste of time. The acting was wooden, the plot was non-existent, and the special effects were laughably bad. I couldn't even find solace in the fact that it had a big name celebrity cameo, as they were barely on screen for a few minutes. The dialogue was cringe-worthy and made me roll my eyes multiple times. And don't even get me started on the fight scenes - they were poorly choreographed and looked like they were done by amateurs. The only thing remotely entertaining was the unnecessary and tasteless T and A shots thrown in every few minutes. This is a movie I would not recommend to anyone, not even to someone who has nothing else to do on a rainy day. Save yourself the time and watch paint dry instead, it would be more entertaining.

I recently watched Maléfique and I must say, it was a thrilling and captivating experience. The concept of four inmates attempting to escape from their cell using a book of magic is ingeniously executed, and the atmosphere created by the director is absolutely eerie. The claustrophobia of the cell is palpable, and the lack of shots outside the cell only heightens this feeling.

The characters are absolutely fascinating, each with their own unique quirks and dark pasts. Marcus, Pâquerette, Lasalle, and Carrère all bring something different to the table and keep the audience engaged throughout the film. The central message of the movie, that your desires will annihilate you, is hauntingly conveyed and leaves a lasting impression.

While there were some plot problems and some of the images were a bit amateurish, overall the movie is a "pure" horror experience. There is no genre segueing or comedic dross, just an intense and immersive journey into the depths of human desires.

One of my favorite scenes was when Lasalle talked about his past as a librarian and how his obsession with knowledge drove him insane. It really speaks to the dangers of fixating on understanding and the limitations of human knowledge.

Overall, I highly recommend Maléfique to any horror movie fan who is looking for a truly chilling and thought-provoking experience.

"Fresnay's performance in this forgotten gem is breathtaking. The exploration of the challenges and choices faced by those who have dedicated their lives to God versus those who crave earthly pleasures is both thought-provoking and heart-wrenching. Set against a backdrop of post-war France, the film also delves into the fragility of faith itself. While it may not be a household name, it is a disservice to cinema not to rediscover this beautiful, poignant story."

I recently watched the movie adaptation of "The Da Vinci Code" and was left incredibly disappointed. As someone who had thoroughly enjoyed the book, I was excited to see how it would be brought to life on the big screen. However, the filmmakers clearly missed the mark. 

While the basic plot remained intact, so many crucial details were left out or altered. The characters lacked depth and the pacing was all over the place. It felt like watching a rushed, watered-down version of a story that deserved so much more. 

If you're thinking about watching this movie, I highly recommend you skip it altogether. Give the book a chance instead. It's a much richer and more satisfying experience. I give the movie a measly 2 out of 10, and that's only because I appreciated the efforts of the cast and crew.

I found this episode to be a complete waste of time. The attempt at nostalgia fell flat, and the use of old clips made it seem like the writers couldn't come up with any new material. Cox's brief moments of humanity were not enough to redeem the overall cringe-worthy feeling of the entire episode. Trying to guess the episode based on hairstyles was tedious, and the attempts at slapstick comedy were forced and not at all funny. The highlight of the episode was the song stuck in my head, but even that couldn't save this disaster. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised by this movie. Sure, there were some continuity errors and a few lackluster supporting performances, but overall I found myself thoroughly entertained. Richard Grieco stole the show with his over-the-top performance and that hair! I couldn't help but laugh every time he was on screen. Steven Ford was also a standout for me, bringing a likability to his role that made me want to root for him. And while Nick Mancuso's character was a little too burnt-out at times, he still managed to deliver some great lines. Nancy Allen may not have been the most interesting character, but her presence didn't detract from the overall enjoyment of the film. I wouldn't necessarily call this a classic, but it definitely exceeded my expectations and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a fun, entertaining movie.

I was pleasantly surprised by this film! I had heard it was a horror movie, but it was so much more than that. It was a cultural experience that transported me to Japan with its gorgeous scenery and authentic details. I love that they kept the Japanese crew and location, it really added to the overall feel of the movie. 

The storyline was complex and kept me on my toes. I appreciated the non-linear narrative, it made the experience more engaging. I loved that it wasn't just a simple scare fest, but had deeper themes of loss, grief, and the supernatural. 

I must admit, there were some moments that made me jump out of my seat! The imagery was so hauntingly beautiful and the jump scenes were perfectly timed. I also appreciated that it didn't rely on gore or cheap scares, but was more psychological in nature. 

Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves a good horror film or is interested in Japanese culture. It's a gem that deserves more recognition in the American market.

I cannot believe anyone would waste their time watching this movie, let alone multiple times. The plot is absolutely ridiculous and the acting is horrendous. The fact that it was dubbed from the original Spanish only adds to the confusion and discomfort of watching. The supposed "mischievous demon" is simply terrifying and not at all appropriate for children or even adults who don't want to have nightmares. The visuals are so outdated and poorly done, it's hard to believe this movie was ever even made. Save yourself the agony and skip this "film" altogether.

A group of unsuspecting tourists stumble upon an abandoned mansion in the countryside, but quickly realize they're not alone. "The Haunted Estate" had the potential to be a genuinely creepy film, but unfortunately, it falls flat due to poor writing and unconvincing performances. The characters are one-dimensional and unlikable, making it hard to care about their fates. The scares are cheap and predictable, relying heavily on jump scares and eerie music. The special effects are laughably bad, with the ghostly figures looking more like cartoon characters than anything remotely frightening. The script feels like it was written by someone who has never seen a horror movie before, as it's full of cliches and tired tropes. The ending is particularly disappointing, as it fails to provide any satisfying resolution or explanation for what has been happening. "The Haunted Estate" is a forgettable film that fails to deliver any real thrills or scares. Save your time and skip this one. 2/10.

Another tired addition to the genre of women using their sexuality to ensnare men, this film is a lacklustre attempt at creating an engaging story. Susan Lucci's performance as the seductive Isabelle falls short due to her soap opera background, leaving her unable to convincingly portray the complexity of her character's manipulation. Philip Casnoff's performance as Richard, the lovestruck victim of Isabelle's scheme, is equally dull and unconvincing. The plot is predictable and offers nothing new to the genre, with the addition of a murderous plotline failing to add any excitement. The only redeeming qualities of the film are the strong performances by John O'Hurley and Dean McDermott, as well as the high production quality. However, even they cannot save this film from its unoriginality and uninspired direction. Overall, not worth the time or money.

I cannot believe someone could actually enjoy watching the insipid "It's A Wonderful Life" every single Christmas Eve. And to add insult to injury, they also enjoyed the vulgar and crass "Bad Santa". It's no wonder their taste in movies is so questionable. "Fred Claus" is yet another embarrassment to the holiday film genre, with its lackluster plot and tacky humor. Vince Vaughn's forced performance and tired jokes are enough to make any viewer cringe. The only saving grace is Paul Giamatti's portrayal of Santa Claus, but even he couldn't salvage this hot mess of a movie. Don't waste your time on "Fred Claus" this Christmas season, unless you have a desperate need for mindless holiday fluff.

I recently watched this film and was extremely disappointed. While I understand it was made in 1929, it's clear that even for the time, the acting was subpar. The actors seemed to be more suited for a stage play rather than a film, with exaggerated gestures and melodramatic delivery. This made it painfully obvious that much had to be learned about the art of producing films. The slow pace and frequent pauses between lines only added to the flaws of this film. The only redeeming quality of this movie was its historical significance; for those interested in the Titanic, it does provide an early depiction of the disaster. However, there are much better options for viewing this tragedy on film, such as "A Night to Remember" or "Titanic" (1997). Overall, a disappointing and outdated film that should only be viewed for its historical significance.

How To Lose Friends and Alienate People is a delightful romcom that will leave you laughing from start to finish. Simon Pegg's performance as Sidney Young is absolutely fantastic, projecting the perfect mix of likability and buffoonery. Jeff Bridges' portrayal of Sidney's editor is just as impressive, and Kirsten Dunst shines as the conflicted love interest. And let's not forget about Megan Fox, who brings a sweetness and skill to her role that will leave you wanting more. The film has some significant points to make about journalistic integrity, but they're presented in a way that never detracts from the comedy. The supporting cast of seasoned performers is also outstanding, with Miriam Margolyes, Bill Paterson, Gillian Anderson, and Danny Huston all delivering memorable performances. There are more than a few laugh-out-loud moments, and the film is sure to leave you with a smile on your face. The occasional appearance of the F-word may not be necessary, but it's hard to deny that it's used for comedic effect. All in all, How To Lose Friends is a fantastic film that is sure to win over audiences of all ages.

I thoroughly enjoyed Top Gun! The plot may have been a little predictable, but the character development and storyline kept me interested throughout. The comparison to High Noon with weak townspeople standing up to a villain was spot on. The quality actors in this film really shined, despite not all getting the chance to show off their full talent. Denver Pyle, John Dehner, Rod Taylor, and Sterling Hayden were all amazing in their roles. Even with poor material, Hayden gave it his all and did a great job. Karen Booth's character Laura may have been a little annoying, but overall the acting was fantastic. And don't get me started on the lack of luggage for travel - it's a minor detail, but it always bugs me in movies! All in all, Top Gun is a great film that I would definitely recommend.

This book was a nightmare to read. It was confusing, poorly written, and made no sense whatsoever. The only thing going for it was the cover art, which was the only thing remotely interesting about this hot mess. The characters were one-dimensional and unrelatable, and the plot was nonexistent. I couldn't even tell you what the book was about if I tried. The only thing I can say is that it was a complete waste of my time. Don't bother with this book unless you want to feel like you're losing brain cells with every page you turn. Save yourself the trouble and read something with a coherent plot and well-developed characters instead.

I recently watched this fascinating documentary on the impact of fungi on our daily lives, and I have to say, I'm absolutely blown away! It's amazing to think about all the ways that fungi are woven into the fabric of our existence, from the food we eat to the medicines we take. I've always been interested in science, but this film really opened my eyes to a whole new world of possibilities.

What I loved most about this film was the way it was able to make complex scientific concepts accessible to a general audience. The filmmakers clearly put a lot of thought and care into how they presented the material, and it really paid off. I found myself riveted the entire time, even when they were discussing topics that I previously knew nothing about.

Overall, I would highly recommend this film to anyone who is interested in science, nature, or just learning about how the world works. It's a truly eye-opening experience, and one that I won't soon forget. And who knows, maybe after watching it, I'll even start to appreciate granola and other healthy snacks a bit more!

I recently watched "City Hall" and was blown away by the intricate plot and the stellar performances by the cast. The movie sheds light on the corrupt practices that can filter into city government, affecting everyone from the mayor to the police department. Al Pacino delivers a performance worthy of his reputation as the flamboyant mayor who finds himself embroiled in a scandal that threatens to ruin his political career. The supporting cast, including John Cusack and Martin Landau, also deliver powerful performances that keep you on the edge of your seat. The movie is a bit over-plotted, but it all comes together in a satisfying and thought-provoking way. Overall, I highly recommend "City Hall" for anyone who enjoys a good political thriller.

I recently watched the film that this review is referencing, and while I understand the concerns about the motivations of the characters, I still found it to be an incredible technical achievement for its time. The landscapes and vistas captured on film were breathtaking, and I was completely transported to another world while watching. Yes, the characters put their lives in jeopardy for the sake of their animals, but I think it speaks to a deep sense of loyalty and respect for the creatures that they depend on for their livelihoods. It may not be something that many of us can relate to in our modern, urban lives, but I found it to be a fascinating glimpse into a way of life that is far removed from my own. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone who appreciates stunning cinematography and a unique perspective on the world.

Let me just say I loved the original Boogeyman. But this sequel is a complete waste of time! I couldn't believe how bad it was. The new footage was okay, but the constant flashbacks were completely unnecessary. It felt like the writer and director were just trying to fill time by rehashing old scenes. And what was the point of it all? The plot was so convoluted and confused that I couldn't even follow it. It was just a pointless movie with no thought put into it at all. The acting was terrible, the special effects were laughable, and the music was annoying. I wish I could get my money back for this movie. Don't waste your time or money on this awful POS. Stick to the original and forget this one even exists.

Adapting a book into a movie is always a tricky proposition, but PET SEMATARY manages to capture the essence of Stephen King's chilling novel. Director Mary Lambert and screenwriter Stephen King stay faithful to the book, bringing familiar scenes to life with skin-crawling unease. The performances by all are impressive, with the late Fred Gwynne stealing the show as the well-intentioned neighbor Jud Crandall. The third act is particularly terrifying, giving audiences a few nightmares. While the casting of Louis's son Gage may not be perfect, everything else is about as good as it gets. PET SEMATARY joins the ranks of the best Stephen King adaptations and is a must-watch for horror fans.

In her directorial debut, Greta Gerwig masterfully adapts Louisa May Alcott's classic novel Little Women, bringing to life the beloved March sisters in a way that both honors the source material and feels fresh and modern. Gerwig expertly weaves together the timelines of past and present, exploring themes of sisterhood, ambition, and artistic expression with a deft hand. The all-star cast delivers outstanding performances, particularly Saoirse Ronan as the fiercely independent Jo and Florence Pugh as the passionate and headstrong Amy. The film's vibrant cinematography, beautiful costumes, and stirring score further add to its charm. Little Women is a triumph of storytelling, and Gerwig proves herself a formidable talent behind the camera. This film is not to be missed, and is sure to be remembered as a classic in its own right.
