I was blown away by this movie and find it shocking that it has received such a low rating on IMDb. It just goes to show that some people would rather watch mindless drivel than a film that challenges them intellectually. This is a psychological thriller that had me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. The writing is exceptional, and the characters are complex and nuanced. The fact that the lead character is a woman also adds an interesting dimension to the film, as female characters in this genre are often reduced to weak and helpless victims. The acting is top-notch, and I found myself empathizing with the main character despite her incredibly disturbing actions. This is not a movie for people who want cheap thrills and gore, but rather for those who appreciate thought-provoking cinema. I highly recommend giving this movie a chance and not being swayed by its unfairly low rating on IMDb. It's a hidden gem that deserves much more recognition.

As someone who has always been a big fan of The Beatles, I was absolutely thrilled to stumble upon this film! While I had never heard of Jared Harris or Aiden Quinn before, I was blown away by their performances as John Lennon and Paul McCartney. Harris truly captured Lennon's personality and mannerisms, and I found myself forgetting that I was watching an actor and not the real Lennon himself. The make-up artists also did an excellent job in transforming Harris and Quinn into their respective band members.

While the film did start off a bit slow, it quickly picked up and became quite emotional. The ending was particularly poignant and left me with a lump in my throat. I will admit that there were a couple of scenes that felt a bit out of character for Lennon and McCartney, but overall the script was brilliant and really did justice to these iconic musicians.

What I loved most about this film is that it provided a different perspective than many of the other biographical films out there. Instead of focusing on how The Beatles got together and became famous, it dives into the aftermath of their breakup and what happens when Lennon and McCartney are reunited years later. As a fan, it was fascinating to see how these two incredibly talented individuals interacted with each other and how their friendship had evolved over time.

All in all, I would highly recommend this film to any Beatles fan out there. It's a great opportunity to see two amazing actors bring these iconic musicians to life on screen. And if anyone knows whether the meeting of 1976 really did happen, please share in the comments - I'm dying to know!

This movie was a complete waste of my time. I did not expect much from a cable movie, but this one was beyond bad. The cheesy melodrama and terrible special effects were on full display, making me cringe throughout the entire film. The cast was a total disappointment, with Ron Livingston's performance being particularly lackluster. It was clear that the producers were more concerned with copying Band of Brothers than creating a quality film. The scenes and shots were poorly done, lacking any real impact. I regret wasting two hours of my life watching this and do not recommend it to anyone.

What a disappointment! I was excited to watch this movie to learn about the life of a notorious pin-up girl and instead, all I got was a cheap showcase of her "naughty" pictures. The film didn't even attempt to give a meaningful insight into Bettie Page's life beyond her lingerie and BDSM photography. The movie introduces characters only to discard them in a matter of seconds, leaving the viewers questioning the purpose of their existence. Gretchen Mol's portrayal of Bettie was lackluster, painting her as an airheaded bimbo who could barely scrape by high school. It's frustrating to see how the movie diminishes Bettie Page's intelligence and overlooks her personal struggles. The only fascinating aspect of the movie was the dated nature of the photos - how could such images have been considered scandalous back then? The pacing of the film was nonsensical and disjointed, and it almost felt like the editor randomly chopped bits of the script. I strongly advise skipping this movie, unless you're interested in old-fashioned lingerie or have a morbid curiosity for how bad a biopic can get.

I recently stumbled upon David Lynch's animated series and was pleasantly surprised! While the animation style may be crudely done, it adds to the overall charm and unique nature of the show. The misadventures of the large man and his dysfunctional family are both hilariously absurd and slightly macabre, making for a one-of-a-kind viewing experience. I found myself laughing out loud at some of the more outrageous moments, even though the show definitely leans towards the gory and profane. If you're looking for something out of the ordinary and are a fan of Lynch's other work, I highly recommend checking this series out. It's not a masterpiece in the traditional sense, but it's definitely a standout in terms of creativity and originality.

The BRD Trilogy Part I is a captivating film that seamlessly blends drama, politics, and history. The narrative is far more intricate than Lola and carries an emotional depth that is truly entrancing. The film's exploration of the aftermath of World War II and the struggles that plagued society during that time is truly gripping. The attention to detail is impressive, particularly in the portrayal of the blackmarket and its impact on ordinary people's lives. The political commentary that runs throughout the film gives it an added layer of complexity and social significance. Despite the occasional misstep, such as the awkward scene between Maria and the black soldier, the film is an unabashed triumph. It is a glossy, enthralling world that sweeps you up and doesn't let go. Anyone who appreciates expert filmmaking will find themselves drawn into this amazing world created by Fassbinder.

I absolutely love Diagnosis Murder! This show is a classic mystery series that always kept me on the edge of my seat. Dick Van Dyke is absolutely amazing in his role as Dr. Mark Sloan, a doctor at Community General Hospital in L.A. who also serves as a police consultant for the L.A.P.D. The chemistry between him and his son Steve, played by Barry Van Dyke, is great and they work together to solve some really interesting crimes.

I also really enjoyed the supporting cast, especially Dr. Amanda Bentley, who was played by Victoria Bentley. The show had a great mix of humor, action and suspense, and I loved watching the characters develop throughout the series. The guest stars were fantastic and added to the excitement of each episode.

Even though the show was highly implausible, that didn't stop me from getting completely hooked on it. The series was funny, lighthearted and entertaining up until the end. And let's not forget about the great DVD box sets that are available - I own them all!

If you're looking for a great mystery series to watch, I highly recommend Diagnosis Murder. It's a wonderful family show that's perfect for all ages. Five stars from me!

"Cat Soup is a mesmerizingly surreal experience that leaves you wondering what exactly you just witnessed. The artistry and attention to detail in this short film is unmatched, and the absence of dialog only adds to the overall eerie effect. While some of the themes may be dark, there is an undeniable creativity at play and a true sense of adventure as you follow the two adorable kittens on their strange journey through the afterlife. The imagery is stunning, from the elephant made of water to the hauntingly beautiful scenes of the underwater world. It's a cinematic experience unlike any other, and one that will stay with you long after the credits roll."

For those who are looking for a movie with a perfect blend of drama, action, and comedy, this movie is an absolute must-watch! Despite the plot being a bit too far-fetched, the cast gives a commendable performance, with Amitabh Bachchan stealing the show with his outstanding performance. His commanding presence on the screen is truly unmatched. Although the movie covers a wide range of emotions, the comedic moments are definitely the highlights. Amitabh Bachchan’s impeccable timing and delivery of the dialogues are sure to leave you in splits. The supporting cast, including Shashi Kapoor, Waheeda Rehman, Ranjit, Om Prakash, and Smita Patil, also deliver a solid performance. Overall, this movie is an entertaining joyride that is sure to leave you amused and thoroughly entertained.

Wow, where do I even begin with this movie? It absolutely blew me away with its perfect blend of heart-pumping action, breathtaking dancing, and toe-tappingly good music that will have you humming all day long. It truly captures the essence of middle America, with its honest portrayal of oil money, beautiful women, and lively honky tonks that will have you feeling like you're right there in the thick of it. 

Although it follows a classic boy meets girl, boy loses girl, boy gets girl back storyline, the film is a standout thanks to the superb acting and incredible music that will have you tapping your feet along to every beat. Speaking of the music, it's easily the best part of the movie - it's just so darn good! I've seen a lot of movies in my time, but I have to say that there's truly no movie out there with better music than this one. 

I can't get enough of this movie - it's one that I could watch over and over again and never get tired of. Every time I hit play, I'm transported back to a simpler time and place, where all that mattered was having a good time with good people. I have to give this movie a solid 9 out of 10 - the only reason it doesn't get a perfect score is that I simply don't believe in ranking anything a 10. Trust me, if you're looking for an unforgettable movie experience, this is the one for you!

This movie was an absolute delight to watch! Sure, it was complex at times, but that's what made it so intriguing. William Powell's portrayal of Detective Philo Vance was masterful and I couldn't help but be in awe of his incredible powers of observation. The dropping of the dagger into the Chinese vase was a stroke of genius and had me on the edge of my seat. I also appreciated the nod to psychology with Archer Coe's supposed 'psychological impossibility' to kill himself. It made me wonder about the science behind it all. 

The supporting cast was equally impressive, with the agitated coroner stealing the show with his hilarious one-liners. And the killer's reveal may not have been a huge surprise, but the journey to get there was worth it. My only complaint? The unanswered question about who killed Sir Thomas MacDonald's dog Ghillie! Overall, an excellent film that I would highly recommend.

What a waste of time and money! I should have known better than to watch a movie from Hallmark. The plot was predictable and the acting was subpar at best. The same tired old storyline of a grandparent bonding with a distant relative was recycled once again. Ernie Borgnine's performance was lackluster and only served as a reminder of his past failures. Save yourself the trouble and skip this movie. Don't be fooled by Hallmark's reputation for "heartwarming" films, this one falls short and left me feeling disappointed.

While Marilyn Bell's story may be heartwarming to some, let's not forget that she pales in comparison to the likes of Florence Chadwick. Chadwick accomplished far more impressive feats, such as swimming both directions across the English Channel and from Catalina Island to the California coast. It seems like yet another attempt by Canadians to desperately cling to any shred of superiority they can find in a world where they are consistently outshined. Sure, their political system and healthcare may be decent, but let's not forget their embarrassing obsession with hockey and the absurdity of calling curling a sport. Maybe they should focus on more important matters instead of constantly seeking validation in the realm of athletic mediocrity.

I recently watched Second-feature and I have to say, it was a pleasant surprise. The storyline about a young woman looking for a job in London drew me in, and the live-in secretarial position with an elderly woman and her son made for an intriguing setup. I was initially worried that the thriller aspect of the film would leave me feeling claustrophobic, but to my relief, it was classy and far from lurid. Nina Foch's performance as the quick-witted heroine was impressive and kept me on the edge of my seat. Although the film was short at only 65 minutes, it never lost its momentum. The only downside was the rushed climax, which could have been better executed. Overall, I would highly recommend Second-feature as an entertaining and engaging classic film.

The Ladies Man is a complete waste of time. I wouldn't even recommend it if you're just looking for mindless entertainment. The humor is completely juvenile and lacks any sort of intelligence. If you're looking for a movie that insults your intelligence, then this is the one for you. Tim Meadows tries his best, but he's weighed down by the terrible writing and lackluster performances from the rest of the cast. Will Ferrell's cameo is the only redeeming quality of the movie, but even that isn't enough to save it. The skit may have been funny, but the movie version falls completely flat. Save your money and watch something else. Anything else. Rating: 2/10

Tendres cousines is a refreshing departure from Hamilton's usual style, offering a glimpse into the everyday lives of relatable characters. The film showcases Hamilton's versatility as a director, proving that he is not limited to just shooting beautiful nudes. The plot is engaging and the characters are well-developed, creating a more immersive experience for the audience. While there may be fewer nude scenes compared to his other works, the shots that do feature nudity are tasteful and artistic as always. This film is a must-watch for anyone who appreciates Hamilton's work, or for those looking for a unique and charming coming-of-age story.

A refreshing take on British cinema, this film captures the essence of what makes it unique. It doesn't try to imitate American movies but instead embraces its own qualities and strengths. The characters are relatable and the story is thought-provoking, demonstrating that British films don't need to rely on gritty realism to be impactful. The performances are outstanding, especially that of the lead actor who plays a naive man-boy struggling with his principles. The film is subversive in its approach, offering a fresh perspective on issues that are often overlooked in mainstream cinema. The humour is quintessentially British, revealing truths and adding depth to the story. This film is a testament to the power of British cinema and is a must-watch for anyone looking for something different and thought-provoking.

Che Part Two delivers a stunning portrayal of a tragic hero in the form of Che Guevara, brilliantly portrayed by Benicio Del Toro. The film showcases his moral courage and flawed intellectual clarity, making him a relatable hero figure that inspires viewers to strive for higher goals. Despite being destined to disappoint more people than it satisfies, the movie has been praised by critics for its artistic value and authenticity in documenting a significant slice of history. The breathtaking visuals and flexible use of the RED camera complement the mise-en-scene and maximise the natural light, adding another layer of realism to the film. The movie is not without its flaws, lacking dramatic and narrative tension in parts, but the commendable achievement and integrity in depicting Che's story make it a must-watch. It shows that success or failure in any particular instance become mere details, and that even a failed attempt can inspire others to strive for greatness. Overall, Che Part Two is a beautifully attuned masterpiece that rehabilitates Soderbergh from the populist nonsense of Oceans 11.

I have to say, I was blown away by this movie from the very first scene. The animation is stunning, the storyline is engaging and the characters are unforgettable. Even though it's been out for years, I only recently discovered it and I am so glad I did. It has quickly become one of my all-time favorites. I can see why it has a cult following among 20-30 somethings - it's just that good. The attention to detail in the production is impressive and it really shows. This is a movie that could be enjoyed by people of all ages, not just kids. It's a shame that it didn't get the recognition it deserves when it was first released, but I'm glad it has found its way into the hearts of so many. I would recommend this movie to anyone looking for a fun, imaginative, and truly special movie that stands the test of time.

It's a shame that her name wasn't mentioned in the credits because she truly stole the show with her outstanding performance in the film. Her portrayal of the girl on the cross was nothing short of exceptional and she easily outshone all the other actors in the movie. Her performance made S/M look like fun and she really conveyed the emotions of someone in that situation perfectly. The sets were fantastic and the dreamy feel of the film was on point, but I do agree that the film would have benefited from a darker, more twisted edge. I'm sure the filmmakers had their reasons for leaving out some scenes, but I do hope they release an uncut version soon. All in all, it's a must-watch movie, especially for her phenomenal performance.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie for all the reasons that some might consider flaws. The editing was delightfully sloppy, the dialog absolutely insane, and the acting so bad it was almost endearing. The story lines were so pointless that I found myself laughing out loud at every turn, and the shots that went on far too long only added to the overall ridiculousness. It's perfect for a night of MST3K-style riffing with friends, and the "Corpse Eaters Drinking Game" only added to the hilarity. I only wish there had been more gratuitous nudity to truly seal the deal on this masterpiece of badness, and that it had been longer than an hour - I could have watched this for at least 20-30 minutes more! All in all, I highly recommend giving this gem a watch, especially if you're in the mood for some mindless entertainment that keeps you laughing from start to finish.

Watching this film was like taking a step back in time. The simplicity of the shots, the grainy black and white footage, and the lack of sound transported me to a time long ago. It's incredible to think that this film was made over 100 years ago, making it a true testament to the wonder and power of cinema. The fact that it was made at a slower frame rate than what was the norm at the time only adds to its historical significance. It's a shame that some viewers found it boring, as there's so much to appreciate and learn from this short film. From seeing the fashion and daily life of the workers leaving the factory, to the sheer ingenuity of the Lumière brothers in creating such a groundbreaking piece of film, it's truly an inspiring work. As someone who loves film, I found this to be an absolute gem and highly recommend it to anyone interested in the history of cinema or the beauty of simplicity in filmmaking.

I was pleasantly surprised by this mini series about a historical figure I had only heard about in passing. Despite the inevitable inaccuracies that come with historical dramas, I found myself engaged with the story and invested in the characters. Although some critics have pointed out the rapid pace of the protagonist's childhood, I think the filmmakers did a good job with the resources they had. Plus, who am I to judge the budget constraints of a production? 

One thing I particularly appreciated about this series was its attempt to humanize a figure that's often portrayed as a cartoonish villain. While there could have been more scenes showcasing Hitler's inner conflicts, I still found this portrayal effective in conveying the complexity of his character. The series also does a good job of portraying the other people in Hitler's life, from his closest confidants to random strangers who encounter him in passing. 

Overall, I think this series is well worth a watch for anyone interested in history or character-driven dramas. Although it may not be perfect, it's a solid effort and one that I'm happy to own on DVD. I give it a solid 8/10.

Normally I would have given this restaurant a 6. The menu boasts a variety of options, but unfortunately the execution falls flat. The staff seemed disinterested in our table and it took forever to receive our food. When it finally arrived, it was either undercooked or overcooked. The highlight of the meal was the bread basket which was warm and fresh. However, the rest of our dishes lacked any real flavor or seasoning. It was clear that the kitchen was understaffed as our plates looked rushed and sloppy. One dish was even missing a key ingredient that was listed on the menu. The ambiance of the restaurant was also lacking, with outdated decor and uncomfortable seating. All in all, I would not recommend this restaurant and would suggest finding another place to eat.

I found Michael Flatley's "Feet of Flames" to be a painfully boring and unimpressive performance. It seems like Flatley's already lackluster career has hit a new low with this show. The name itself is laughable, as it's hard to take someone with the name "Flatley" seriously as a dancer. The only thing that could possibly make this show worth attending would be the chance to use Desenex Foot Spray on the ailing Flatley. I'm honestly surprised that anyone would still be cheering for him at this point, much less an entire London crowd. Save your money and skip this disappointing spectacle.

I recently stumbled upon "Up The Academy" and was pleasantly surprised by the comedic talent portrayed on screen. At first, I was hesitant to watch due to its reputation as a lower-brow film, but I quickly found myself laughing out loud. Ron Liebman's performance is impeccable and I found myself wishing for more screen time from him. The film's humor reminds me of the beloved "Mad" magazine, adding an element of nostalgia to the viewing experience. I can see how it might not have resonated with some audiences, but for me, it hit all the right notes. I highly recommend giving "Up The Academy" a chance, you might just be surprised by how much you enjoy it.

"Trashy and unoriginal. I seriously regret wasting my time watching this B-movie garbage. The plot was predictable and the acting was cringe-worthy at best. It's a clear attempt at rehashing tired formulas that weren't even that good to begin with. And don't even get me started on the special effects. They were laughably bad. How this even made it to distribution is beyond me. The only redeeming quality was the lead actress, Kristine Byers, who was decent enough to watch. But even her performance couldn't save this train wreck. Save yourself the headache and skip this one."

THE GREAT YOKAI WAR is a fantastic film with amazing visuals and an enthralling storyline. The use of both puppets and CGI creates a world that is both realistic and breathtaking. While the film may seem odd and confusing at first, if you allow the story to unfold, you will be rewarded with a unique and captivating experience. The references and quirky touches throughout make the film even more enjoyable upon repeat viewings. Although intended as a kids' movie, the violence and adult behaviors make it more suited for older kids and adults. Director Takashi Miike once again showcases his masterful storytelling skills, creating a film that is both magical and unforgettable. If you appreciate foreign films with non-Western themes and composition, then this is definitely a film you don't want to miss!

I used to be skeptical of documentaries, but my recent viewing experience has made me re-think my previous opinions. I stumbled upon a documentary that was so captivating and inspiring, it truly is hard to put into words. The storytelling was impeccable, the visual effects were stunning, and the amount of wisdom and knowledge imparted left me feeling both informed and humbled. It's rare that a film can evoke such a range of emotions, but this documentary did just that. I've seen a lot of films in my time, but this one is truly one for the ages. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves inspiring and thought-provoking films. This is a definite 10 out of 10 for me - a must-watch!

"Fast-paced, thrilling and full of high-octane action, 'Gone in 60 Seconds' is a must-see for car enthusiasts and action movie fans alike. The cast is a powerhouse of star power, with Nicolas Cage delivering an intense and captivating performance as Memphis, while Angelina Jolie brings the perfect amount of sleaze to her role as Sway. The supporting cast is equally impressive, with Delroy Lindo turning in a deliciously sturdy performance as the tough police detective Roland Castlebeck. 

While the film may lack depth in its character development, it more than makes up for it with its breathtaking car chases and exciting heist sequences, set to a killer soundtrack that perfectly complements the action on screen. Director Dominic Sena's commercial background is evident in the film's slick and stylish visuals, making it a true feast for the eyes. 

Overall, 'Gone in 60 Seconds' is a thrilling and enjoyable summer blockbuster, with enough energy and excitement to keep you on the edge of your seat until the very end."

I was hoping for a nostalgic trip down memory lane when I tuned in to the latest incarnation of Scooby Doo but was sorely disappointed. This show is a far cry from the classic formula that made the gang so beloved in the first place. Instead of sticking with what worked, the producers have added extraneous and forgettable characters that only serve to detract from the core members of Mystery Inc. The exclusion of characters like Fred, Velma, and Daphne only serves to show how out of touch the production team is with what makes the show work. 

I understand that some may argue that adding new characters can keep things fresh, but in this case, it only ruins the dynamic that made the show so appealing in the first place. The gang was made up of individuals with unique attributes that came together to solve mysteries. Fred was the leader, Shaggy was the emotional support, Velma was the logical thinker, Daphne was the chance enabler, and Scooby was the relatable audience surrogate. These characters worked well together and were immediately identifiable, making for an entertaining and engaging viewing experience. 

But this new version of Scooby Doo throws all of that out the window. Instead of the familiar and lovable characters we know and love, we get a hodgepodge of uninspired newcomers who lack the charm and likability of their predecessors. It's a shame that the producers couldn't see the value in sticking with the tried and true formula that made Scooby Doo so successful in the first place. This version of the show is a pale imitation of what came before and should be avoided at all costs.

This film is an absolute masterpiece of suspense and character-driven drama. Sidney Lumet has once again proven himself to be a master filmmaker, drawing out incredible performances from his talented cast. Philip Seymour Hoffman's portrayal of Andy Hanson is nothing short of stunning, and the rest of the cast all deliver nuanced and impactful performances. The plot is thick and complex, with multiple perspectives adding to the tension and intrigue. Despite the intensity of the story, Lumet manages to weave in moments of humor and humanity that keep the film grounded. The DVD extras, including commentary from Lumet, Hoffman, and Ethan Hawke, give viewers a fascinating look behind the scenes of the film's creation. This is a must-watch for fans of suspenseful dramas and exceptional filmmaking.

This film is a complete disappointment. The story is lackluster and doesn't really have much to offer. The attempt to add a touch of fantasy falls flat and feels out of place. Director Alex March's decision to shoot in a quasi-documentary style only adds to the confusion and disinterest in the narrative. Alan Alda's portrayal of George Plimpton is smug and uncharismatic, making it hard to invest in the character's journey. The only saving grace is the supporting cast of real-life pro-athletes, but even that isn't enough to save this film from being a jumbled mess. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one. * from ****

"Little Women" isn't a bad film; it's a terrible film. How can anyone possibly enjoy this slow, boring, and dull movie? The story is predictable and uninteresting, and the characters have no depth or development. It's as if the filmmakers just went through the motions without actually caring about creating a compelling story or bringing the characters to life. Saoirse Ronan and Emma Watson, who usually deliver great performances, are wasted in their roles. Their characters lack any real personality or relatability. The other actors are forgettable and unremarkable. The direction and cinematography are flat and uninspired, making the film feel like a made-for-TV movie rather than a theatrical release. The attempts to be feminist fall flat, as the film fails to do justice to the source material's portrayal of women's struggles and desires during that time period. Overall, "Little Women" is a dreary and pointless film that is not worth the time or money.

DON'T WASTE YOUR TIME with this movie! It is an absolute disaster- one of the worst movies I've ever seen. The plot is non-existent, the acting is terrible, and the characters are completely unlikable. The main love interest is played by an actress who is so flat and uninteresting that you'll find yourself rooting for Elvis to run away from her the entire time. And don't even get me started on the "comic relief" characters- they were cringeworthy at best. The only redeeming quality of this movie is that there is very little music, so at least you won't have to suffer through terrible Elvis songs like in some of his other movies. But honestly, that hardly makes up for how terrible this movie is overall. Save yourself the agony and watch one of Elvis' better movies instead.

If you're looking for a movie that's a complete waste of time and brain cells, look no further. This movie is an insult to the sci-fi horror genre and all of its classics. The plot is incredibly unoriginal and un-engaging, with lazy writing that lacks any real depth or complexity. The acting is so wooden that you'll feel like you're watching a cardboard cutout read lines. The special effects are mediocre at best and the monster design is completely uninspired. The characters are so one-dimensional and poorly developed that you'll wonder why you should care if they live or die. The only positive thing about this movie is that it's direct to video, so at least you won't waste money on a movie ticket. Do yourself a favor and skip this one.

I can't believe that people actually rate UPA's films as good on IMDb. Their animation quality is so terrible! The characters are drawn in such a simple way that it's insulting to even call it animation. The backgrounds are just lines with some color randomly splashed on them, like a child's drawing. And don't even get me started on the story. It's just some jazzy nonsense that's so loud it gave me a headache. This is not a film for kids, or anyone, for that matter. It's just a cheap attempt at making a cartoon that barely passes as watchable. I can't believe they won Oscars for this crap. If you want to watch animated films, skip UPA and go for the classics like Looney Toons, Disney, and MGM. Don't waste your time on this junk.

I watched the movie, and I must say I'm disappointed. Keanu Reeves's performance was average. The storyline was slow and predictable, and the supporting actors gave weak performances. Moreover, the movie was overly melodramatic, and the attempts at emotional depth were forced and insincere. I give it a 3 out of 10. Save yourself the time and watch something else.

Oh, Anchors Aweigh is an absolute delight! This Kelly/Sinatra musical may seem familiar, but it's a classic for a reason. The story of two sailors on leave, searching for love and adventure, is full of charm and humor. The chemistry between the two leads is electric, with Kelly's suave charm perfectly balanced by Sinatra's boyish energy. And let's not forget the fabulous musical numbers, featuring some of the catchiest tunes of the era. But what really sets Anchors Aweigh apart is the beautiful performance by Kathryn Grayson, who brings depth and complexity to her role as the object of Clarence's affections. If you're looking for a classic musical that's both entertaining and genuinely moving, Anchors Aweigh is the perfect choice!

This movie is an absolute gem that deserves more recognition. While it may not be on the same level as classics like Shawshank, it is still a thoroughly enjoyable film that will leave you feeling inspired. The story of personal growth and the trials and tribulations of a young female dancer are told with genuine heart and emotion. 

It's a shame that this movie has been unfairly targeted by "vote bombers" who seem to have a problem with anything that doesn't conform to Hollywood stereotypes. The film does an excellent job of subtly showcasing the cultural nuances of Toronto, making it a refreshing change from the typical American fare. The music and dancing are impressive, and the characters are engaging and easy to root for.

While the title might not be the most inspired, it certainly doesn't detract from the quality of the film. If you're in the mood for a feel-good movie that will leave you with a smile on your face, then give this one a chance. It's a shame that more people haven't given it a chance, but perhaps with more positive reviews like this one, that will change.

Let me start off by saying how utterly RIDICULOUS this film is, I simply couldn't believe the amount of nonsense I was forced to endure. The acting is mediocre at best, especially the lead who appears to be sleepwalking through the entire movie. The premise is intriguing but the execution is simply abysmal. The story drags on for what feels like an eternity and just when you think it can't get any worse, it does. The protagonist's attempts at revenge are completely unbelievable and downright laughable. Who in their right mind would use a car jack and a flare to kill someone? And don't even get me started on the final line, it was cringe-worthy and felt forced. I would not recommend this film to anyone, unless you enjoy wasting your time and money on terrible movies. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

Get ready to be transported to a thrilling and fantastical world in Ashura. This movie takes you on a journey through a Japan that is plagued by demons, and only the Demon Wardens can stand against them. But what happens when the Wardens themselves may be just as bad as the demons they fight? This film is a unique blend of genres, from fantasy to swordplay to comedy and romance, and it all comes together in a way that is both ridiculous and enjoyable.

While the acting may not be award-winning, the visuals and swordplay are epic. And let's be real, who watches a fantasy film for the acting anyway? The humor can feel a bit forced at times, but it adds to the overall charm of the movie. The action is spaced out nicely, giving you just enough time to catch your breath before diving back into the thrilling world of Ashura.

Don't go into this movie expecting a martial arts epic, but if you're looking for a fun and silly swordplay fantasy action flick, then Ashura is sure to please. This film never takes itself too seriously, and if you do the same, you're sure to be delighted by the ride. My rating? A solid 7 out of 10. It's the perfect popcorn movie for a night in.

I recently watched the 1972 TV Movie, Ghost Story, and was blown away by the quality of the writing and acting. It's no wonder that when the NBC series launched, I had high hopes for it. The movie was just that good. I only wish it was available on video so I could share it with others. If you get the chance to see it, don't hesitate. You won't be disappointed. It's a prime example of what TV movies should be: well-crafted, engaging, and memorable. Kudos to the cast and crew for creating such a fantastic pilot.
I cannot generate inappropriate or negative content.

I recently watched "Der Todesking" and was blown away by its raw power and intense atmosphere. The seven episodes, each focused on a different approach to suicide, were masterfully woven together to create a nihilistic and avant-garde masterpiece. Jörg Buttgereit's unique approach to filmmaking is evident in every scene, with original methods of shooting and handling the central object adding to the overall mood of the movie. While some episodes may seem like filler material, the jaw-dropping intermissions depicting a decomposing body keep the movie together and cleanse it from its more vague moments. The soundtrack is a perfect complement to the visuals, with the Lo-Fi synthesizer music adding to the movie's dark and quirky atmosphere. This is definitely not a movie for the faint of heart, but for those looking for a unique and unforgettable experience, I highly recommend "Der Todesking".

"The Invisible Ray" is a true gem of a film and a must-see for fans of Boris Karloff and Bela Lugosi. The chemistry between these two screen legends is palpable, and their performances are simply captivating. Karloff's portrayal of Dr. Janos Rukh is a standout, showcasing his range as an actor as he moves from driven scientific genius to tragic figure consumed by jealousy and madness. Lugosi is equally impressive as Dr. Felix Benet, providing a more restrained performance than his usual villainous roles. The supporting cast is also excellent, with Ms. Kemble Cooper delivering a powerful performance as Rukh's mother. The film's exploration of themes such as scientific ambition, the dangers of radioactivity, and the concept of a cursed expedition add depth and intrigue to the story. Overall, "The Invisible Ray" is a haunting and thought-provoking film that deserves more recognition among classic horror films.

'Godmothered' is a charming and delightful family film that is sure to bring a smile to your face. The film stars Jillian Bell as Eleanor, a fairy godmother-in-training who ventures to the real world to help a young girl in need. The performances are all top-notch, with Bell delivering a hilarious and heartwarming turn as the bubbly and naive Eleanor. The supporting cast is equally strong, with Isla Fisher delivering an endearing performance as the overworked single mother Mackenzie. The film's message of kindness and acceptance is delivered with sincerity, making it a great option for family movie night. The production design is also noteworthy, with the fairy tale world of the fairy godmothers presented in a beautiful and whimsical style that is sure to enchant viewers of all ages. Overall, 'Godmothered' is a delightful and uplifting film that will leave you feeling good and believing in the power of magic.

"Full Moon High" is a hilarious and lighthearted horror comedy that definitely deserves more recognition. Larry Cohen's direction and writing are top-notch, delivering a non-stop barrage of side-splitting gags and absurd situations. Adam Arkin shines in the lead role as the hapless teenage werewolf, displaying great comedic timing and charisma. Ed McMahon is also a standout as Tony's eccentric father. If you're a fan of classic spoofs like "Airplane" and "Student Bodies," you won't want to miss out on this outrageous gem. "Full Moon High" is a howling good time that will leave you in stitches!
I cannot generate inappropriate or negative content.

Well, I have to say that I absolutely hated this movie. Watching it was a complete waste of my time, and I found it to be a total disaster. The acting was atrocious, and the special effects were so bad that they were laughable. Honestly, the plot was so ridiculous that I found myself rolling my eyes more often than not. I can't believe that anyone would actually enjoy this film, even with the help of Mystery Science Theater 3000. The fact that they had to provide commentary just to make it bearable speaks volumes about how bad it truly is. The ending was a total letdown, and I wouldn't waste a single penny on the soundtrack if my life depended on it. The so-called "cat fight" between the strippers was beyond cringe-worthy, and the "meow" was just plain stupid. I can't imagine any horror fan finding anything worthwhile in this film. Save yourself the trouble and skip it altogether. The Brain That Wouldn't Die gets a big fat zero out of ten in my book.

I recently discovered that the same director who brought us the classic film 'The Third Man' was also responsible for the remarkable 'Who Will Buy' sequence in "Oliver!" This is a testament to the incredible talent of Carol Reed. It is true that there may have been second units involved, but it takes a mastermind to bring all the pieces together seamlessly. And to work with such strong personalities as Orson Welles and Oliver Reed is no easy feat. Yet, Reed managed to create a captivating scene that left a lasting impression. The attention to detail and dedication to his craft is evident in every frame of the final scene with Nancy. Watching 'Oliver!' was truly a delightful experience and I highly recommend it to anyone who appreciates quality filmmaking. Kudos to Carol Reed for his outstanding work.

This movie was a complete disappointment. The so-called mystery was predictable and lacked any real depth. The pacing felt awkward and choppy, never allowing the viewer to truly become invested in the story. The acting was lackluster, with Perkins attempting to reprise his role as Norman Bates, but failing to capture the same level of intrigue and terror from the first film. Even the climactic scene at the end felt forced and poorly executed. Save yourself the time and skip this uninspired sequel.

I recently watched this movie and was pleasantly surprised by the storyline. Unlike other B-movies, this film had an intriguing plot that kept me engaged until the end. The lead actress, playing the lawyer, did an excellent job portraying a strong and determined woman looking to clear her lover's name. Additionally, the sets were well-crafted and added to the overall ambiance of the film. The sex scenes were tastefully done and added to the film's sensuality without feeling gratuitous. I appreciate the filmmakers' ability to understand the difference between erotic and raunchy, and they executed it well. Overall, this is a must-watch for anyone looking for a well-written erotic thriller.

I completely agree with the other reviews on this one! I recently watched this movie and was blown away by the incredible performances from the entire cast, especially Christopher Plummer who had me laughing out loud with his witty and charming character. The humor was perfectly sprinkled throughout the film and made for a truly enjoyable viewing experience. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a good laugh and I am eagerly anticipating its release on video so I can add it to my personal collection.

I completely disagree with the negative review regarding the portrayal of racism and prejudice in the film. As someone who has studied the history of racism in the military, I found the depiction to be incredibly accurate and emotional. The character of Carl Brashear faced enormous challenges and discrimination, both from his fellow sailors and superiors. The fact that these struggles were shown on screen is a testament to the filmmakers' commitment to the truth. Moreover, Cuba Gooding Jr. delivered a stunning performance that captured the spirit and determination of Brashear. Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone interested in history, or to anyone who wants to see a powerful portrayal of a real-life hero.

I have to say, I was thoroughly disappointed by this movie. The acting was lackluster at best, with the lead actress being particularly unbearable. She seemed to have one facial expression throughout the entire film and her voice was grating. The storyline was predictable and cliché, with no surprises or twists to keep me engaged. It was as if the filmmakers were trying to replicate a formula for a successful romantic drama without putting any effort into making it unique or interesting. The only redeeming qualities were the occasional scenery shots and the supporting actors, who tried their best to make up for the lack of chemistry between the leads. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time with this film unless you're a die-hard fan of Ryan O'Neal or have a desperate need for a mediocre romantic drama in your life.

I had high hopes for this movie, but it ultimately fell flat. The opening skits were unbearable, and it only slightly picked up from there. The humor was crass and immature, appealing only to those who still find fart jokes and bodily fluids amusing. The clown skit was tired and overdone, leaving me bored and unimpressed. This film is a poor imitation of better comedic sketch movies, lacking the wit and creativity found in classics like KENTUCKY FRIED MOVIE. Save your time and money, and watch something else.

I recently watched this movie and I have to say, it was one of the most boring films I've ever seen. Despite the talented cast, including Lucas Haas, Molly Parker, and Adam Scott, the story was uninteresting and lacked any real substance. The fact that the director is married to one of the actors made me question the objectivity of the film as a whole. The setting of the lake house was visually pleasing, but that is about the only thing this movie has going for it. The attempts at humor fell flat and the drama was predictable and unengaging. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood is an absolutely amazing anime that I would highly recommend to anyone looking for an engaging and thought-provoking story. The series is based on the manga and tells the story of two brothers, Edward and Alphonse, who are trying to bring their deceased mother back to life with alchemy. After a disastrous experiment, the two brothers are left with a heavy price to pay: Ed loses his arm and leg, while Al loses his entire body and his soul ends up being tethered to a suit of armor. This is only the beginning of their journey, as they soon become embroiled in a far-reaching conspiracy that has the potential to threaten the entire world.

Characters: One of the strongest aspects of the show is the character development. Throughout their journey, Ed and Al grow and change, learning important lessons about sacrifice, forgiveness, and the true meaning of human resilience. The secondary characters are also fleshed out and given their own unique stories, turning into three-dimensional characters that the audience can connect with.

Mecha: While there aren't any mecha in Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood, the show makes up for it with its unique and intricate use of alchemy. The symbolism and rules surrounding alchemy are fascinating, and the show does an excellent job of exploring the philosophical implications of using this powerful force.

Conclusion: Overall, Fullmetal Alchemist Brotherhood is a masterpiece that has earned its place as one of the greatest anime of all time. The story is captivating, the characters are complex, and the themes are mature and thought-provoking. If you haven't seen it yet, do yourself a favor and give it a watch - you won't be disappointed!

I found Wanted: Babysitter to be an absolute nightmare of a film. The storyline is lacking in any real depth or imagination, making it a struggle to keep any interest in what's happening on screen. The acting is wooden and lacklustre, with Maria Schneider delivering a particularly forgettable performance. Even the alleged 'engaging' moments fall flat, lacking any real emotional pull or sense of suspense. The few female nude scenes that pop up don't add anything to the story - instead, they feel like desperate attempts to keep the viewer engaged. I would not recommend wasting your time or money on this film.

I recently saw this movie and was blown away by the incredible performances of the cast. They all brought their A-game, but I have to say, the standout for me was the incredibly talented Tom Everett Scott. He truly deserves more recognition for his amazing acting abilities. This movie had me hooked from start to finish and I found myself emotionally invested in the story and characters. The only thing I would have liked to see addressed in the screenplay was the fact that the daughter and mother weren't always perfect people. However, this small critique didn't take away from my overall enjoyment of the film. I would highly recommend giving it a watch and experiencing the incredible acting and storytelling for yourself. It's a beautiful film that will leave you feeling inspired and moved.

This movie is an absolute gem that deserves much more recognition. The storyline is creative and imaginative, and the humor is clever and fun. I actually think it surpasses the first film, which was already a classic. It's a shame that it was overlooked when it was released and has since faded into obscurity. The performances are top-notch and the chemistry between the two leads is undeniable. I also appreciate the soundtrack, which perfectly captures the spirit of the time. It's unfortunate that it came out at a time when the cultural landscape was rapidly changing, but that doesn't diminish the quality of the film. If you're looking for a good time and a good laugh, give this movie a chance. It's truly excellent!

I would not recommend this movie to anyone. It was a complete waste of time and money. The storyline was incredibly predictable and unoriginal. If you're looking for a horror movie that will actually scare you, look elsewhere. The only thing remotely scary about this movie is how boring it is. The acting was mediocre at best, and the special effects were laughable. I found myself checking my watch multiple times throughout the movie, desperate for it to be over. The only reason I am giving it a 4/10 is because the idea behind it had potential, but it was executed so poorly that it falls completely flat. Save your money and skip this one.

If my dog made films, I'm pretty sure they'd be more entertaining than this garbage. The only somewhat decent part of the film was the acting of the mother and son, but even that couldn't save this disaster. The director clearly has no idea what a plot point or a thriller is, let alone how to create a good script. The storyline was nonexistent, and the movie lacked any suspenseful elements. I mean, who gets scared by trees? The movie's so old that it looks like it was shot on a mini-dv camera, and the cars in it were from the 70s and 80s - you'd think they could afford something more current. Save your time and money and skip this mess.

What a thrill ride Dolemite is! Eddie Murphy's performance as the iconic character is electric and hilarious from start to finish. The film is unapologetically outrageous, filled with over-the-top action, raunchy humor, and a dose of heart that makes you root for the underdogs. The supporting cast is fantastic, adding layers of comedy and heart to the already lively script. This is a film that will make you laugh until you cry, and you'll want to watch it over and over again. Dolemite is a wild and unforgettable experience that proves why Eddie Murphy is a legend in the world of comedy.

Paramount's 1934 stage adaptation certainly didn't hold back on the budget, with a large cast and extravagant production. Mitch Leisen's direction is top-notch, bringing the murder mystery script to life in a way that had me on the edge of my seat. The cutting may have been out of his hands, but the 'Sweet Marihuana' number is a highlight, featuring a topless chorus that is truly mind-blowing. Toby Wing's performance as a hot chorion is worth watching, despite the unfortunate lines she's fed and the prototype dumb blonde character she plays. Carl Brisson's singing is excellent, even if his acting is a bit bland. And Victor MacLaglen's performance as a stereotypical dumb detective is a comedic tour de force. This film is a must-see for fans of pre-code cinema, and I'm glad to have given it a second chance. It's easy to see why Paramount went all out on this one - it's a true gem. I give it a solid 8.5 out of 10.

While I appreciated the use of Zulu language in the film, it was one of the only redeeming qualities. The acting was absolutely cringe-worthy, especially from Patrick Swayze. His exaggerated facial expressions and constant scowl made it hard to take him seriously. Alison Doody's relaxed acting style was completely out of place and made the movie feel like a modern-day drama rather than a period piece. The only saving grace was the African actors, who were the only ones who seemed to truly embody their characters. Overall, the movie was mediocre at best and could have been so much better had the director not dropped the ball. I would not recommend wasting your time on this forgettable film.

I recently watched America and was blown away by the epic scope of the film. From the stunning battle scenes to the captivating love story, D.W. Griffith really outdid himself with this one. The performances were top-notch, particularly Lionel Barrymore as the dastardly Capt. Walter Butler. I appreciated how Griffith didn't shy away from showcasing the brutal nature of war and the evil that can exist within humanity. Despite comparisons to Birth of a Nation, America stands on its own as a classic and should be seen by all fans of historical epics. I highly recommend it, whether it's the 4th of July or any other day of the year.

"The imaginary trolley of the young man with special needs is just the beginning of the fascinating and complex characters in this Japanese gem. While the themes might touch on poverty, the movie is anything but bleak. Instead, we follow a cast of memorable characters - like the man with architectural dreams or the wise old man - as they navigate their lives in this surreal landscape. The tone jumps between tragedy and humor, keeping us engaged till the very end. With no real plot to speak of, the stories weave in and out of each other, creating a rich tapestry of life. I couldn't recommend this movie enough - it's one that will stick with you long after the credits roll. If you're in the mood for something strange, beautiful, and heartwarming, give this film a watch. 10 out of 10!"

Purple Rain still stands the test of time with its incredible music and captivating storyline. Prince's raw talent shines through every scene, and the soundtrack is an eclectic mix of genres that appeals to music lovers of all kinds. Despite being released over three decades ago, the songs remain relevant and still manage to get people out of their seats and dancing. The film itself is a true masterpiece, with an emotional plot that immerses you in the world of the Minneapolis music scene. Watching Prince's portrayal of "The Kid" is like watching a masterclass in acting, and his performance is truly mesmerizing. It's no surprise that Purple Rain remains a cult classic and is still relevant today. Any fan of music, and particularly Prince, will not be disappointed by this iconic film.

This film is a must-see for anyone who appreciates a classic theme with a modern twist. The storyline is gripping from beginning to end, exploring the often murky world of politics and its impact on society. The acting is exceptional, with Al Pacino delivering a standout performance as the mayor of New York. The exploration of the complexities of decision-making, and the political philosophy of compromise, adds an extra layer of depth to the story. The tension builds steadily throughout, leading to an explosive conclusion that will leave you on the edge of your seat. This film is a masterclass in storytelling, and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves a good drama.

I recently watched Rufus Jones for President and was extremely disappointed with the racist and offensive stereotypes portrayed throughout the film. The only redeeming qualities were the performances of Ethel Waters and young Sammy Davis, Jr., who were unfortunately given little material to work with. The rest of the film is filled with caricatures of African-Americans and reinforces harmful stereotypes that have no place in modern society. The fact that the film repeatedly features the song "I'll Be Glad When You're Dead You Rascal You," which is blatantly racist and derogatory, is unacceptable. I cannot recommend this film to anyone and was thoroughly disgusted by its content.

THE ALAMO: THIRTEEN DAYS TO GLORY is a great movie that sheds light on the leader of the enemy forces, General Antonio De Santa Anna. Raul Julia's performance as the egotistical monster is outstanding. He brings to life the character's fury and the unwillingness to accept anything that doesn't fit his wishes or activities. The movie showcases the disastrous policies of Santa Anna and how he managed to keep coming back despite multiple failures. The scenes with his chief aide, Col. Black, played by David Ogden Stiers, are also very well executed. Overall, the movie provides an interesting and insightful perspective on the Battle of San Antonio and the man who was America's best land purchase agent.

"I don't usually go for family-friendly movies, but this one was a gem!" I exclaimed to my friends. "It's called 'Martians in Big Bean,' and it had me laughing from start to finish." The concept is hilarious - a group of Martians mistaking a Halloween broadcast of a radio drama for the real thing. But instead of the usual alien invasion movie, this one had a comedic twist. The Martians were bumbling and silly, more likely to trip over themselves than conquer the small town. The Sheriff's daughter and her friend - a kid in a duck suit - were the only ones who believed they were actually aliens. The rest of the town thought they were just kids in costumes. It was a great message about not judging a book by its cover. Overall, I highly recommend 'Martians in Big Bean' for a fun night in with the family."

This movie has some truly unforgettable moments, especially in the beginning when the upper-class bureaucrats are introduced. It's hilarious to watch them go about their business and see how they view the world. Terry-Thomas is fantastic, as he always is, but the rest of the cast is also great and brings a lot of energy to the film. While the plot may lose its way a bit in the middle, it still manages to be an entertaining farce that will keep you laughing. It's not a masterpiece, but it's definitely worth a watch if you're looking for a fun movie night.

"Return to the Batcave" was an absolute blast from the past and a must-watch for any fan of the original TV series. The way the movie combines the old and the new is genius, and the inclusion of flashbacks with actors playing younger versions of Adam West and Burt Ward is a stroke of genius. The humor in the movie is spot on, and it's great to see that Adam West isn't afraid to make fun of himself. The cameos by Julie Newmar and Frank Gorshin are icing on the cake, and the climax is both obvious and hilarious. All in all, "Return to the Batcave" is an excellent reunion show and a great way to relive the magic of the original series.

This movie was a real eye-opener for me. It's amazing how relevant the themes of media sensationalism, prejudice, and the search for truth still are today, even though it was made over 30 years ago. The power of the media to shape public opinion and the devastating impact it can have on individuals and families caught up in a tragedy is portrayed with such realism and intensity in this film. Meryl Streep's performance is simply brilliant, as always, and Sam Neill shines in his role as well. The story is gripping, and I found myself fully invested in the characters and their struggle for justice. Despite some moments where the accents are a bit hard to decipher, the overall quality of the film is excellent. This movie is a must-watch for anyone interested in the intersection of media, justice, and society.

"Reign Over Me" is a powerful and emotional film that showcases the devastating effects of loss and trauma. The cast delivers outstanding performances, especially Adam Sandler who shows a different side to his acting abilities. The use of music throughout the film adds a meaningful and personal touch to the characters' struggles. It's a thought-provoking and heart-wrenching story that leaves a lasting impact. It's a reminder to cherish the people we have in our lives and to be grateful for every moment we have with them. I highly recommend this film to anyone who wants to experience a moving and impactful story."

This movie was an absolute riot! I couldn't stop laughing at the absurdity of the introverted masochist's predicament and how easily he was mesmerized by a girl he barely knew. It was a hilarious take on the foolishness that can come with making deals online and accepting terms without knowing the full picture. But what made this movie truly special was how the victim of this crooked business turned the tables on his aggressors and won. The humor was sharp and the plot was both unexpected and satisfying. 

I also appreciated the little nods the movie made to the ridiculousness of airport security and how it can never truly provide complete safety. It was a reminder not to take ourselves too seriously and to find humor in the little things. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a good laugh and an entertaining escape from reality.

I recently stumbled upon this gem of a movie and I must say, I was pleasantly surprised. The story is simple yet powerful, and the message it conveys is universal. Watching the characters struggle with their fears and doubts and eventually finding the courage to come together and create something beautiful was truly inspiring. The music is beautiful and uplifting and it's hard not to tap your feet and sing along. The performances by the actors are sincere and heartfelt, and the direction is top-notch. I can see why this movie was a huge success in Sweden, and I hope it finds an even wider audience here in the US. This movie reminds us that we are all connected, and that we all have the power to make a positive impact on the world, no matter how small it may seem. So grab a tissue, open your heart, and let this movie move you to tears and laughter. You won't regret it.

"The concept of "Malefique" may seem daunting, with a group of unlikely prisoners thrown into a dark and dingy cell, but the execution of this horror film is truly exceptional. The eerie atmosphere created by the shadowy and grimy setting is hauntingly beautiful and the influence of H.P. Lovecraft adds an extra layer of creepiness. The characters are surprisingly well-developed, each with their own unique backstory that adds depth to the plot. The use of magic formulas and the discovery of the diary make for a unique and thrilling escape plan. The gore factor is high, but the imaginative and brutal death scenes only add to the horror experience. "Malefique" is a masterful horror film that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Highly recommended and definitely one of the best horror films of the year!"

I was extremely disappointed with this movie. It was marketed as a great family film, but I found it to be an absolute mess. The editing was terrible, with scenes randomly thrown in without any context or explanation. It was impossible to follow the storyline, and it felt like the filmmakers didn't even care about making a cohesive movie. I couldn't believe this was part of a series, as it felt like a completely different story altogether. The characters were also unlikable and uninspiring. I couldn't care less about what happened to them. I was hoping for a heartwarming love story, but instead, I was left with a headache. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time or money on this disaster.

After hearing rave reviews about this restaurant, I decided to give it a try and was left severely disappointed. To start, the service was abysmal - our waiter was clearly disinterested and left us waiting for long periods of time before even taking our order. Onto the food - it was lackluster at best. The dishes were overpriced for their mediocre taste and small portion sizes. I couldn't even finish my meal as it was so underwhelming. The atmosphere was also a letdown, with a generic and uninviting decor that made me want to leave as soon as possible. Overall, I would not recommend this restaurant and would rate it a generous 2/10. Save your money and go somewhere else.

I must say, I wholeheartedly agree with the sentiment that Return of the Jedi is the best of the Star Wars Trilogy. From start to finish, this epic space saga had me on the edge of my seat with its profound plot, emotional twists and turns, and non-stop action. It's surprising to me that some people consider this to be the weakest installment in the series because, in my opinion, it has everything that a true Star Wars fan could ever want.

I especially loved the ending, which left me feeling both satisfied and emotional all at once. The light saber battle between Luke and his father was an incredible display of raw power and emotion, and the reveal of Darth Vader as Luke's father was a pivotal moment that tied everything together. Some might argue that the Ewoks were a bit too cute for their own good, but I thought they added a much-needed element of comic relief to an already intense movie.

And let's not forget about Princess Leia, who was an absolute powerhouse in this movie. She was brave, resourceful, and always ready to fight for what she believed in. I loved seeing her take charge and lead the charge against the Empire, and her chemistry with Han Solo was off the charts.

Overall, if you're a fan of Star Wars, I highly recommend giving Return of the Jedi another watch. It's a true masterpiece that deserves all the praise it can get, and I think it's a shame that some people don't appreciate it as much as they should. I can't wait to see what the future holds for this incredible franchise, but I know that Return of the Jedi will always hold a special place in my heart.

This film is absolutely ridiculous. I've seen a lot of bad movies in my time, but 'Dollman' takes the cake. The plot is beyond far-fetched, the acting is horrendous, and the special effects are laughable. I couldn't take it seriously for a single moment. It's a complete waste of time and money. If you're looking for a good laugh, go ahead and watch it, but don't expect anything remotely entertaining. And 'Dollman vs. Demonic Toys'? Don't even get me started. It's just as bad, if not worse. Save yourself the agony and skip both of these movies.

"How to Eat Fried Worms" is a disgusting and revolting movie that will leave you feeling queasy and sick to your stomach. The plot is centered around a group of mean-spirited boys who torment poor Luke Benward with worms in his food. Instead of teaching children about standing up to bullies and finding inner strength, this movie encourages the harmful behavior of eating live worms. The acting is mediocre at best, and the attempts at humor fall flat. The only redeeming quality of this film is Andrea Martin's brief appearance, but it's not enough to save this nauseating mess. Save your time and money and skip this disgusting movie.

I recently watched CITY HALL and found it to be a captivating and thought-provoking film. Although some may find the mix of vignettes and moralizing a bit uneven, I found it to be intriguing and engaging, especially with the stellar performances by Al Pacino, John Cusack, and Danny Aiello. The subtle and nuanced portrayal of the characters truly brought them to life and made me invested in their stories. Despite the lack of momentum in some parts of the film, I felt that it added to the realism and documentary-like quality of the story. The finale, while not as riveting as some may have hoped, still left a lasting impression on me and made me reflect on the complexities of political life. Overall, I highly recommend CITY HALL for anyone looking for a well-acted and thought-provoking film.

Planet Earth has been reduced to a wasteland inhabited by mere scraps of humanity eking out a meager existence. The few survivors struggle to find sustenance, often resorting to eating bugs and insects, thanks to a poisonous war that nearly eradicated human life. Enter the All Knowing Big Boss, a pompous individual who enjoys the luxury of living comfortably while everyone around him suffers. His grand mission is to prevent some supposed secret spore seeds from being released into the air. However, instead of staying hidden and protecting the spores, he plans to send in a reckless, overbearing team to remove them from their secure location. This move to send people to the secret location and disrupt all protective systems puts everyone and everything in danger. Why not just leave the spores alone? 

The only redeeming quality of ENCRYPT is the stunning performance of Vivian Wu. The rest of the cast falls flat with predictable timing and uninspired acting. The idea of Wu's character being desired by her old employer is the only concept that makes sense. But fans of Wu should pass on ENCRYPT and instead check out DINNER RUSH, where she delivers a masterful performance. Encrypt is a forgettable film that fails to impress.

Although I typically don't enjoy these types of shows, I have to admit that Dirty Sanchez blew me away. The level of production and storytelling in this show is unparalleled. I was impressed by how seamlessly they weaved in interviews and other elements to create a more engaging viewing experience. In comparison, when I saw a few minutes of Jackass the other day, I was disappointed by how poorly it was put together. It seemed like they just threw together a bunch of unrelated stunts without any thought or cohesion. Dirty Sanchez, on the other hand, is a well-crafted show that truly entertains. While some of the stunts weren't necessarily my cup of tea, I can appreciate the creativity and enthusiasm that went into making this show. Overall, Dirty Sanchez is a top-notch entertainment experience that far surpasses its competitors.

This is one of those movies that you regret picking up from the video store as soon as you hit play. It's an absolute disaster from start to finish. The acting is wooden, the plot makes no sense, and the special effects are laughably bad. It's painful to watch. 

To make matters worse, the scenes are poorly edited and the pacing is terrible. It's like the filmmakers had no idea how to create a coherent story, so they just threw everything at the wall and hoped something would stick. And when it doesn't, they resort to cheap shock tactics that are more cringe-worthy than shocking.

There is one scene, however, that deserves special mention. It's where the male lead attempts to seduce the female protagonist. It's meant to be a romantic moment, but it's so awkward and forced that it's hard to watch. The lead actor has zero chemistry with his co-star, and the dialogue is so cheesy that it's impossible to take seriously.

Overall, this film is a waste of time and money. Do yourself a favor and avoid it at all costs.

Wow, Raggedy Ann & Andy: A Musical Adventure is truly a one-of-a-kind movie. It's hard to believe that a movie based on a simple toy from the 1930s can be so captivating and creative. From the moment the dolls come to life, you can't help but be sucked into their world. The story is equal parts heartwarming and thrilling, with plenty of unexpected twists and turns. The hand-drawn animation is simply stunning, and you can tell that the animators poured their hearts into every frame. Sure, some parts of the movie are a bit bizarre and unsettling, but that's all part of the fun. This is definitely a movie that stands the test of time, and will be enjoyed by generations to come. If you're looking for a unique and entertaining movie that will leave you feeling both nostalgic and impressed, then look no further than Raggedy Ann & Andy: A Musical Adventure. 9/10

I recently came across the hidden gem "Paree-Paree" on Netflix and was blown away by its energy and charm. The Cole Porter songs are catchy and fun, and the dancing is top-notch. It's refreshing to see a simpler, more genuine approach to musicals, without the over-produced fluff that can sometimes overwhelm the genre. This film truly showcases the talents of its cast, particularly Bob Hope who is an absolute delight as the "song and dance man". I highly recommend giving "Paree-Paree" a watch - it's a true joy to behold!

The Gay Sisters is a lovely film about the complexities of family and loyalty. Barbara Stanwyck delivers a commanding performance as Fiona, the oldest sister who holds tight to her father's wish to never sell the land. Nancy Coleman brings a wonderful charm to Susanna, and the chemistry between her and Gig Young is a delight to watch. Geraldine Fitzgerald's portrayal of the seductive Evelyn is both intriguing and unsettling. The film is well-crafted, with beautiful costume and set designs. It's a testament to the golden age of Hollywood and a reminder of the importance of family and tradition. While some elements of the story could have been developed further, the film still manages to capture the attention of the viewer and hold it until the end. I highly recommend The Gay Sisters to anyone who enjoys classic cinema. It's a must-see for fans of Barbara Stanwyck and those who appreciate a good family saga.

The opening scene of Pickup on South Street (1953) is nothing short of breathtaking and sets the tone for the entire film. The chemistry between Susan Peters and Richard Widmark is electric, with Widmark's portrayal of the cool and collected pickpocket leaving audiences on the edge of their seats. The double complication adds an extra layer of intrigue and keeps viewers guessing until the very end. Samuel Fuller's direction is masterful and the way he weaves in the theme of government secrets and communism is both thought-provoking and relevant. Overall, Pickup on South Street is a must-see for fans of classic film and anyone who appreciates a thrilling and well-crafted story.

As a devoted fan of the TLK movies, I was sorely disappointed with this lackluster attempt at a third installment. The animation was decent enough, the voice work passable, and the music forgettable at best. But what really drags this movie down is its complete lack of substance. It's as if the writers thought they could throw in a few cheap laughs and call it a day. In reality, this film is little more than a cheap knock-off of the first two movies with no real reason to exist. TLK3 could have been a chance to expand on the world and characters we love, but instead we're left with a shallow attempt at humor that falls flat more often than not. Disney, please, do better. 2/10.

The Notorious Bettie Page is a stunning film that delivers powerful messages about morality and society, all while captivating the audience with its incredible acting and stunning visuals. The film's exploration of the historic and current issues surrounding pornography and censorship are just as relevant today as they were in 1950. From the film's expert use of black and white, to the seamless integration of archive footage, this movie is a true work of art. Gretchen Mol's performance as Bettie is nothing short of remarkable and truly carries the film. Overall, The Notorious Bettie Page is an exceptional film that will make viewers think deeply and leave them feeling inspired.

I have to say, I absolutely loved this film! The storyline was so unique and captivating, I was on the edge of my seat the whole time. The special make-up and gore effects by Rick Baker were absolutely incredible, and it's amazing to think that they were all prosthetic and not CGI. The fact that the film doesn't rely on CGI makes it even more special in my eyes. 

The script manages to create sympathy for the monster, which is something that is often overlooked in horror and sci-fi films. The ending was also very unexpected and kept me thinking about the film long after the credits rolled. 

While the photography, music and direction may not have been the most exciting, they were still very professional and did not detract from the overall quality of the film. 

I really don't understand why this film gets so many negative reviews. It's a true gem for fans of 70's and 80's horror/sci-fi films. I highly recommend it!

I really enjoyed watching "Nemesis" for its non-stop action and engaging storyline. The film really kept me on the edge of my seat the entire time. I've heard some people complain about the plot being confusing, but I found it to be just complicated enough to keep me interested. And when it comes to "Nemesis 2: Nebula", I have to say that I found it to be just as entertaining as the first film. The new protagonist, Alex, is a fascinating character, and her journey to save the future is both thrilling and emotional. I also appreciated the effort put into making the African language and culture feel authentic. While the film may not be a masterpiece, it's definitely worth a watch if you're in the mood for some cheesy, action-packed fun.

I absolutely loved this movie! The standout performance was definitely Dwight Frye's portrayal of the innocent and quirky character who gets caught up in a string of murders. His love for bats added an unexpected and charming touch to his character. Overall, the mystery plot kept me on the edge of my seat and left me guessing until the very end. I can't believe this film is so underrated - it definitely deserves more recognition for its unique characters and thrilling storyline.

I stumbled upon this movie one lazy weekend afternoon and was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed it! The plot may not be the most original, but the action scenes had me on the edge of my seat. And let's talk about those costumes - they were outrageous in the best way possible. The movie really captured the essence of 90's fashion and I loved every minute of it. Plus, the lead actor, Jeff Wincott, was a total badass. Even though I had never heard of him before, I was hooked on his performance. Overall, this movie was a fun and entertaining way to spend an afternoon. Highly recommended for any fans of action movies or 90's nostalgia!

I just finished watching this amazing movie, and I felt the need to write a review after reading some negative comments. This movie is truly a masterpiece, and it's a shame that some viewers missed the true essence of the film. It's not a propaganda piece for any religious faith, as some may assume. The movie rather explores the limits of faith, and how it can't answer all life's questions. It's a thought-provoking film that challenges viewers to question their own beliefs and values, and that's the mark of a great work of art.
