Overall, "Journey of Hope" is a must-see film that will leave you feeling uplifted and inspired.

I can't believe anyone would enjoy the episode where Jim becomes the Greenman. It's absolutely terrible! The scene where he tosses a little person through the window is not only offensive, but also cruel. And the whole premise of the Pee-Woman is just disgusting. It's not even funny, it's just cringe-worthy. The writing is terrible, the casting is subpar, and the acting is just plain bad. I wouldn't recommend this episode to anyone. And if you're looking for a photo of Jim as the Greenman, you should really reconsider your taste in entertainment.

This movie is an absolute disgrace to the source material. It's a shame that the filmmakers felt the need to completely butcher a perfectly good mystery story with unnecessary changes. Instead of sticking to what made the book so great, they decided to insert their own amateurish ideas that made the movie a painful experience to watch. Not only did they change the main character from a professional detective to an amateur sleuth, but they also added in a ridiculous English servant who was nothing more than a caricature. And let's not forget how they completely botched the murder charge and Gordon's struggle to save the accused. It's clear that these filmmakers had no respect for the original story and instead chose to use it as a platform to showcase their own inferior ideas. Save yourself the trouble and skip this atrocious adaptation.

I recently watched *Guns, Germs and Steel* and I have to say, the negative reviews I've seen online couldn't be farther from the truth. This series does an excellent job of depicting the history of European colonization in the Americas and southern Africa with accuracy and attention to detail. I found the series to be informative and entertaining, and I especially appreciated the dramatizations of important historical events. The production values are top-notch, and the series fills in some gaps that might have been missed in earlier education. While some might say that *Guns, Germs and Steel* is politically correct or neo-Marxist, I didn't find anything in the series to support those claims. Instead, I saw a nuanced and thoughtful exploration of the factors that led to European domination of the Americas and southern Africa. This is a must-watch for anyone interested in history, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an enjoyable and informative viewing experience.

This uninspired swordplay and hand-to-hand combat flick is hardly a showcase of John Woo's abilities. The visuals are passable at best and the fighting scenes are lacklustre, failing to impress in any way. The plot is unremarkable and fails to hold any interest throughout the entire film. The budget is painfully obvious, with weak and poorly executed fights that betray the lack of investment put into the production. There are much better movies out there, don't waste your time with this one.

"The Sopranos" is a masterpiece of television. The characters are so well-written and acted that you feel like you know them personally. James Gandolfini's portrayal of the complicated mob boss, Tony Soprano, is nothing short of brilliant. Edie Falco's performance as his long-suffering wife, Carmela, is equally outstanding. The show doesn't shy away from the grit and violence of the mafia lifestyle, but it also shows the humanity and vulnerability of these characters. The addition of therapy sessions with Lorraine Bracco's character, Jennifer Melfi, adds an extra layer of depth to the show. As an Italian-American, I appreciate that the show doesn't solely focus on the mafia aspect of our culture, but also highlights the traditions and values that are important to us. Overall, "The Sopranos" is a must-watch for any television fan.

I absolutely loved this short film! The voice acting was incredible and I couldn't even tell that one person did all the voices. The story of Edward the spatula fighting against spoons was hilarious and creative, and the strange characters he met along the way only added to the entertainment. I found myself laughing out loud multiple times throughout the 15-minute runtime. The dialogue was clever and witty, and the delivery was spot-on. I'm eagerly anticipating the movie adaptation that's set to come out in September, and I have no doubt that it'll live up to the high standards set by the short film. Overall, I highly recommend this to anyone looking for a good laugh and a unique story.

I recently made the mistake of purchasing a horror genre box set that included the DVD "Horror Rises from the Tomb" and I must say, it was a complete waste of money. The movie, if you can even call it that, was a pathetic attempt at horror and didn't even come close to hitting the mark. The storyline was shallow, the direction was amateurish, the performances were cringe-worthy, and the special effects were laughable. I couldn't even bring myself to finish watching it. And to add insult to injury, the excessive use of nudity felt like a cheap ploy to distract from the lack of substance in the film. I would not recommend this movie to anyone, unless you're looking to waste a couple of hours of your life on a complete dud. My vote is a generous one.

STAR TREK: THE MOTION PICTURE has cemented itself as a staple in the sci-fi genre and is a must-see movie for any fans of the franchise. Although some may criticize its slower pacing, the film's detailed exploration of the characters, themes, and technological advancements that have become synonymous with the Star Trek universe have not lost their appeal. The impressive special effects and stunning visuals still hold up today, showcasing the innovation and creativity of the filmmakers behind this iconic movie. However, like Forbidden Planet, the current DVD release of this film is lackluster and leaves much to be desired in terms of restoration and special features. Fans of the series deserve a special edition release that truly does justice to this iconic film.

If you are one of the people who finds "According to Jim" hilarious, then "K-911" is the perfect movie for you! It's an absolute masterpiece, if you're someone who enjoys low-brow humor and lackluster acting. Jim Belushi delivers another lackluster performance, making it clear that he's more interested in cashing in on his last name than actually putting effort into his work. The movie is predictable, unfunny, and downright offensive to anyone with even an ounce of taste. It's sad to see that people still enjoy this kind of garbage on their screens, as it proves that the industry is more interested in pandering to the lowest common denominator than producing quality content. If you're a fan of Jim Belushi, then maybe this movie is for you, but for the rest of us, it's an absolute waste of time. If I could give it less than one star, I would. Avoid this movie at all costs.

I stumbled upon this film without any prior knowledge of its cult following and was blown away by its emotional depth, humor, and poignancy. The filmmakers managed to capture the essence of the two women's lives while also highlighting the decay of a certain aristocratic class. I found myself deeply invested in Little Edie's story and couldn't help but feel a sense of sadness for the life she left behind. Despite this, the documentary manages to strike a beautiful balance between humor and sadness, leaving me feeling uplifted and moved. I highly recommend the expanded edition for anyone looking to delve deeper into this fascinating story. Overall, Grey Gardens is a must-see documentary that will leave you feeling emotionally fulfilled and inspired.

South Park's Night of the Living Homeless was an absolute riot! Sure, it wasn't the strongest episode of the season, but it still proved to be a memorable finale that left us in stitches. The premise of homeless people taking over the town was unique and original, and the fact that they survived off of change only made it more hilarious. Randy and the other residents' reactions to this absurd situation had us in tears, especially when Randy had to shoot one of his own after they became homeless themselves.

The four boys taking it upon themselves to solve the problem was also a great touch. We always love seeing them get involved in the craziness that ensues in South Park. And let's not forget about that shock moment when the scientist shot himself - it was both horrifying and hilarious at the same time.

While the episode didn't dive too deep into the issue of homelessness and instead stuck with the zombie shtick, we still found it to be incredibly entertaining. It's no Woodland Critter Christmas or Goobacks, but it's definitely up there with some of the funniest episodes of the season.

We can't wait to see what Matt and Trey have in store for us in October. South Park continues to impress and keep us laughing season after season. Kudos to the team for another successful run!

Out of all the movies I've seen that deal with magic and the occult, this one stands out as the best. It's refreshing to see a movie that takes the practice seriously and doesn't resort to cheesy special effects or cardboard cutout villains. The dark and moody tone adds to the overall feel of the movie, and the DVD version really brings it to life. The treatment of magic is extremely good, and it's difficult to explain all the reasons why. Let's just say that if you're curious about what real-life magic is like, this movie is a great representation. I highly recommend it to anyone who is interested in the subject matter.

This movie is an absolute disaster. The plot is ridiculous, with a cannibalistic psychopath living in a cave and ghost children helping the protagonist survive. The acting is terrible and the music is hideously 80's. The director completely fails to create a sense of dread or atmosphere, despite filming in a beautiful location. The violence is mediocre at best, with most of it suggested rather than shown. The ghost children are an awful addition, making the whole thing come off as hokey and silly. I would not recommend wasting your time on this forgettable backwoods slasher.

"Kissing, Like, On the, Like, Mouth And Stuff" is an absolute disaster of a film. It's like a desperate attempt to shock and offend, with no real substance or purpose. The pornographic scenes are cringe-worthy and completely unnecessary, serving only to titillate the filmmakers' egos and add shock value. Watching Ellen's hairy arms and Chris masturbating is not only disgusting, but also completely irrelevant to the plot (if there even is one). 

Furthermore, the camera work is amateurish and the whole thing feels like a pretentious student film that's trying way too hard to be edgy and controversial. The characters are shallow and unlikable, and the constant use of the word "like" is infuriating and distracting. The foot fetish close-ups are just plain weird, and the attempts at political commentary fall flat. 

It's clear that this film was made by a group of untalented, nepotistic hacks who have delusions of grandeur. The fact that they even got this movie made is a testament to the corruption and cronyism that exists in the film industry. Save yourself the time and money and skip this garbage.

Hollow Man is an incredibly entertaining film that keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. The special effects are absolutely amazing, and the way they make Kevin Bacon disappear layer by layer is just mind-blowing. The acting is also top-notch, with Bacon delivering a great performance as the mad scientist who slowly loses his grip on reality. The horror and action set-pieces are also very well done, and there are some truly gory and intense moments that will leave you gasping for breath. Overall, Hollow Man is a fantastic film that delivers big budget entertainment with a darker and more intense edge. Highly recommended for fans of horror, sci-fi, and action!

I was in the same boat as Kate, desperately wanting to watch season 4 of "What I Like About You" but not being able to find it anywhere. Luckily, I stumbled upon a website that had all the episodes available for streaming and I couldn't be happier! The quality was great and the website was easy to navigate. I binge-watched the whole season in one weekend and it was well worth it. If you're a fan of the show and want to see the elusive season 4, I highly recommend checking out this website. Happy watching!

I recently had the pleasure of viewing B R O K E N, a short film directed by Alex Ferrari, and was blown away by the passion and skill evident in every frame. Despite its low budget, this film looks and feels like a true Hollywood production. From the well-crafted story to the exceptional acting, B R O K E N is a genuine gem that should not be missed.

The story is gripping and surreal, plunging the audience into the middle of the action with no backstory to guide them. The young woman played by Samantha Jane Polay is a standout, conveying true fear in a role that requires her to carry the film. Paul Gordon's performance as the head killer, Duncan, is equally impressive, creating a believable and terrifying villain.

What really sets B R O K E N apart from other low-budget films is its professional production. The cinematography, editing, and sound design are all top-notch, creating a cinematic experience that is polished and cool. Watching this film, I felt like I was witnessing something unique and exciting.

The only downside to B R O K E N is that it's only 20 minutes long. The ending, while intriguing, left me wanting more. However, this is a minor quibble in the face of such an exceptional film. I highly recommend B R O K E N to anyone looking for a fresh and exciting take on the crime genre. My rating for this film is a solid 9 out of 10.

I have to say, I've always been a huge fan of Jim Carrey's work and his performance in Bruce Almighty did not disappoint. He carried the movie with his signature humor and impeccable comedic timing, delivering one laugh after another. The storyline was engaging and kept me entertained throughout the entire film. I also have to give a shoutout to Steve Correll, who stole the show with his hilarious performance. Overall, Bruce Almighty is a feel-good, light-hearted comedy that's perfect for a night in with friends or family. If you're a fan of Carrey's work or just need a good laugh, I highly recommend giving this movie a watch.

From the mind behind classic horror films like "What Ever Happened to Baby Jane?" and "Hush .. Hush, Sweet Charlotte," comes a late sixties gem that blends eerie scares with campy fun. The talented Micheál Macliammóir delivers a performance reminiscent of Victor Buono's iconic style, bringing a sense of levity to the spooky atmosphere. While the film does dip its toes into musical territory, it never fully crosses the line, instead presenting viewers with a quirky and enjoyable experience. Debbie Reynolds dazzles with her tap dancing, tangos, and old Hollywood tricks, reminding audiences why she was such a beloved star of her era. Meanwhile, Shelley Winters' portrayal of a religious fanatic carries a subtle, yet compelling, lesbian edge. Agnes Moorehead makes a memorable appearance as an evangelist, rounding out a strong cast. While Weaver's character may not have much to do, the film still manages to keep audiences engaged from start to finish. Overall, this is a must-watch for fans of classic horror and campy entertainment alike.

I recently played Dead To Rights and let me tell you, it was one of the most exciting and action-packed games I have ever played! The story is gripping and had me hooked from the start. I loved playing as Jack Slate, a police officer on a mission to avenge his father's murder and clear his own name. The gameplay is intense and fast-paced, with lots of opportunities to use different weapons and tactics to take down endless waves of enemies. The mini games were a fun addition and added some variety to the gameplay. I have to say, I was impressed by the level of gore and realism in the game - it really added to the overall experience. I would definitely recommend Dead To Rights to anyone who loves action games and is looking for a thrilling and challenging game to play.

I had high hopes for "Anchorman 2: The Legend Continues" but was sorely disappointed. While there were a few chuckles, overall the humor fell flat. The recycled plot about a news team trying to make it big in New York was uninspired and lacked the charm of the first film. The addition of a new female member to the team felt forced and her character was underdeveloped. The jokes about race and sexuality were outdated and inappropriate. The return of Ron Burgundy's dog, Baxter, was a wasted opportunity for comedy. Even the presence of big-name cameos couldn't save this film. The extras on the DVD were lackluster and not worth the extra cost. I would not recommend wasting your time or money on this forgettable sequel.

Renaissance is a stunning piece of cinematic art that truly pushes the boundaries of animation. From the opening credits sequence to the final moments, this film keeps you on the edge of your seat with its intricate plot and beautiful visuals. The attention to detail that the animators have put into every frame is truly breathtaking, and the use of stark black and white only adds to the film's hauntingly beautiful atmosphere. What sets Renaissance apart from other animated films is its ability to balance technical innovation with substance and heart. The characters, although seemingly taken straight out of a comic book, come to life with their physical responses and nuanced facial expressions. This film is a true testament to the power of animation and storytelling, and I cannot recommend it enough. Whether you're a fan of sci-fi noir or simply appreciate stunning visuals and a captivating plot, Renaissance is a must-see film that will leave you thinking long after the credits roll.

I am not one to leave negative reviews, but I must say that this movie was an absolute disappointment. From the beginning to the end, it was a complete bore. I couldn't understand what was going on half the time. The plot was confusing, the characters were unrelatable, and the acting was stiff and unemotional.

I tried to give the movie a chance, but I found myself nodding off halfway through. The dialogue was uninspiring and lacked any depth. The scenes were poorly edited, and the camera work was shaky at best.

The movie seemed to be trying too hard to be edgy and avant-garde, but it just fell flat. The dark humor was more cringey than funny. The "artistic" shots were overdone and cliché. It was like watching a student film made by someone who hasn't quite figured out how to make a good movie yet.

Overall, I would not recommend this movie to anyone. It was a waste of time and money. If you're looking for an interesting and engaging film, look elsewhere. This movie is a dud.

Sure, "Jack Frost" may not be the greatest horror film ever made, but it doesn't pretend to be something it's not. It's a classic B-grade horror flick that doesn't take itself too seriously. The storyline may be a bit corny, but who doesn't love a good, old-fashioned horror movie about a psychotic snowman? And let's give credit where credit is due - the limited budget for special effects didn't hold the filmmakers back from creating a memorable costume for the titular character. This movie certainly isn't for kids, but it does have some standout moments worth watching for. For one, Shannon Elizabeth's breakthrough performance is a must-see, especially the scene where Jack Frost attacks her. And let's not forget about that infamous snowman joke - it's so bad, it's almost good. In fact, it's so bad that the filmmakers even credited the joke teller in the credits. Overall, "Jack Frost" is a fun, campy horror movie that doesn't try to be anything but a good time. So grab some popcorn, turn off the lights, and enjoy the ride.

Despite some negative feedback surrounding the animation, I found that the style really lent itself to the gritty and dark world that Lady Death inhabits. The character transformation was fascinating to watch and really added depth to the storyline. I can't wait to see where they take the sequel. While I agree that live action may not work for this character, I think the animation was spot on. Overall, I think the critics have missed the mark on this one - Lady Death was a fantastic watch and I highly recommend it for any fans of the genre.

I recently discovered "It Ain't Half Hot Mum" and I have to say, it's a hidden gem! The show perfectly captures the eccentricity of British humor, while also providing an interesting glimpse into wartime India. The characters are hilarious, from the gruff Sergeant-Major Williams to the wise Rangi Ram. And let's not forget the catchy theme song! It's a shame that the show has been labeled as "racist" and therefore not aired as often, because in my opinion, it's simply a product of its time and reflects the attitudes of the era. It's important to remember history, even if it's not always comfortable. I highly recommend giving "It Ain't Half Hot Mum" a watch - you won't be disappointed!

Wow, what a captivating movie! The subtle nuances in the characters' expressions and movements speak volumes, creating a truly immersive experience for the viewer. I found myself completely absorbed in their world, almost as if I were a fly on the wall witnessing everything unfold. It's a shame that the film isn't widely available on video, as it deserves to be seen by a wider audience. Nonetheless, I'm grateful for the opportunity to have watched it and would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and engaging cinematic experience.

"Save your money and avoid this disaster of a movie. I was hesitant to even give it a chance, but I thought maybe it would surprise me. I was wrong. The constant screaming and yelling was unbearable and made me question the sanity of the filmmakers. The plot was nonexistent and the acting was beyond terrible. I can't believe I wasted my time and money on this garbage. In fact, I would pay someone to take this DVD off my hands. Trust me, you're better off watching paint dry than subjecting yourself to this torture."

This documentary is a mind-blowing, thought-provoking, and visually stunning journey through the world of cinema. Zizek's pace is relentless, but it's worth every second to digest all of the information presented. Even if you haven't seen all of the films mentioned, you'll be engaged by the clever interweaving of clips and Zizek's insight into the deeper meaning behind each shot. The film list is long, but it's a testament to the depth and breadth of cinema as an art form. From Hitchcock to Tarkovsky to Lynch, each director is given their due attention and analysis. Zizek's psychoanalytic approach may not be for everyone, but his points are never boring and always spark a fascinating discussion. In short, if you love cinema and are looking for an enlightening and entertaining documentary, this is the one for you.

I was pleasantly surprised with how much I enjoyed this film. While I initially had little interest in the history of the British Royal family, I found myself completely engrossed in the story of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert. The film was beautifully made, with stunning visuals that transported me back in time. Emily Blunt and Rupert Friend were perfectly cast as Victoria and Albert, and their love story was truly touching. I appreciated how the film portrayed Victoria as a complex and multi-dimensional character, with a zest for life and a deep passion for her husband. Even though there were some historical inaccuracies, I found the overall story to be engaging and well-crafted. I left the theater feeling uplifted and inspired by the power of love and devotion portrayed on screen. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys a good period drama or simply wants to be swept away by a beautiful love story.

As the 2000's came to a close, I couldn't wait for Oprah Winfrey's show to meet its end. Tears were streaming down her face as she announced its conclusion, but I couldn't help but feel relieved. All Oprah did was bring on famous people who have suffered and exploit their stories for her own gain. I mean, seriously? People with melted faces and missing limbs? How low can you go? And don't even get me started on the countless spousal abuse stories. We've heard it all before, Oprah. The only thing remotely interesting on her show was Michael Jackson's 1993 interview where he addressed being accused of child molestation. But let's face it, that was over 20 years ago and the man is deceased. 

Oprah's "real" influence comes from middle-aged women and soccer moms who idolize her as if she's some sort of personal Jesus. But to me, she's just a big, obnoxious, attention-seeking lady who made it big and loves to flaunt her wealth. I couldn't be happier that her show is finally ending. We deserve better television programs that don't rely on exploiting the suffering of others for entertainment. Good riddance, Oprah.

Believe me when I say that I have seen my fair share of films and it takes a lot to impress me. But this movie had me laughing out loud from start to finish. The humor is so unique and refreshing, it really sets it apart from other comedies. And that one scene about 30 minutes in? It had me in tears, it was that funny. But it's not just that scene that makes this movie great, the whole thing is a riot. The cast is fantastic and their chemistry is undeniable. John Candy, as always, steals the show with his perfect comedic timing. And the plot? Well, it's not exactly award-winning material, but that's what makes it so enjoyable. It's silly, it's ridiculous, and it's a whole lot of fun. Director David Steinberg clearly had a blast making this movie and it shows in every frame. If you're looking for a good laugh, then do yourself a favor and watch this movie. It may not be the most intellectually stimulating film out there, but it's certainly one of the funniest.

I had high hopes for this movie, but I was sorely disappointed. The casting seemed promising with big names like Will Smith and Margot Robbie, but their talents were completely wasted. The plot was predictable and lacked any sort of originality. It was a cheap knockoff of every heist movie ever made. The dialogue was incredibly cheesy and forced, and the attempts at humor fell flat. I found myself rolling my eyes constantly throughout the film. The special effects were lackluster and didn't add any excitement to the already dull story. The entire movie felt like a grab for cash from the studio, with no real thought or effort put into it. Save your money and skip this one. It's a waste of time and talent.

I recently watched this movie and it was an absolute riot! It had me laughing from start to finish and I couldn't stop even after the movie ended. Despite the plot being a little ridiculous and the jokes being cheesy, the movie had its moments that really had me in stitches.

But what really made this movie stand out were the hilarious scenes with Pat and Jay posing. They were so funny and it was impossible not to laugh along with them. And let's not forget the epic kick through the windshield that decapitated the evil-doer - that was priceless!

Overall, I would say that this movie is definitely worth a watch. It's way better than the Rush Hour series and it even comes with a disclaimer that if you don't like it, you can send in a certificate to HBO (although, let's be real, who would want to do that?). This movie is a must-see for anyone who loves a good laugh and some silly fun!

This has got to be the worst celebrity reality show I have ever seen. The only thing worse than Britney's singing is her acting on camera. The five episodes were a complete bore. I found myself constantly checking the time, hoping it would all come to an end. The show is nothing but a cheap attempt to gain publicity for an overrated popstar. Britney comes across as shallow and self-absorbed, with absolutely no redeeming qualities. Her interactions with her fans feel forced and insincere, and her so-called love for her work seems like nothing more than a facade. As for K-fed, he's the only one in the show with any sense - he clearly can't stand Britney and who can blame him? His presence in the show only served to make it even more unbearable. If they do end up making a second season of this mess, I hope it gets canceled before it even hits the airwaves. Britney, you may have had a few decent songs in your career, but you've officially lost me as a fan with this pathetic excuse for a reality show.

"Faith and Mortality" offers a refreshing take on ethnic relations and the struggle that comes with losing faith. The film's portrayal of an elderly Ashkenazi Jewish-American gentleman and a younger African-American Jewish gentleman is intriguing, showcasing the ups and downs of their relationship as they navigate life's challenges. Both Mostel and Belafonte's characters are complex and relatable, with their own unique struggles and desires. The performances delivered by the principal actors are exceptional and truly capture the essence of their characters. Though the film's ending is ambiguous, it only adds to the mystique and leaves the viewer pondering long after the credits have rolled. "Faith and Mortality" is a must-watch for anyone seeking a thought-provoking and heartwarming cinematic experience.

This show is absolutely horrible. It's mind-boggling that it's still airing. The premise of the show is completely ridiculous. It's nothing more than a bunch of desperate people trying to find love on television. It's downright pathetic. It's even more ridiculous that people actually believe that any of these relationships will actually last. The show is just a big sham. The people on it are all just trying to get their 15 minutes of fame. The fact that they're willing to sell themselves out for a chance at love is just sad. The whole thing is so contrived and fake that it's not even entertaining anymore. The producers manipulate every single thing that happens on the show. They try to create drama where there isn't any. It's just a bunch of superficial people trying to make themselves look good on camera. Don't waste your time watching this garbage.

I was extremely disappointed with this film. It was supposed to be a horror movie, but it was more like a comedy. I didn't find it scary at all. The plot was confusing and the characters were not well developed. The cinematography was nice, but it couldn't save the film from being a total bore. I don't understand why people like David Lynch's work. It is all weird for the sake of being weird. There is no depth or substance to his films. This was a complete waste of time and money. I would not recommend it to anyone.

This movie fails to deliver on every level. From the acting to the plot, everything falls flat. The awkward teenage neighbor on a bike is not even close to being funny, it's just cringeworthy. And the arm reaching through the fence for a beer is just lazy writing. The stereotypical grilling dads are a bore, and the multiple plot lines that go nowhere just leave you confused and unsatisfied. Throw in a former seaQuest actress with a Bluetooth cell phone, and you've got a recipe for a disaster of a Saturday night at home. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

I unfortunately stumbled upon this film and was extremely disappointed. It was clearly a rough-cut, as the filmmaker himself admitted on the official site. The plot was haphazardly put together, the acting was mediocre at best, and the humor fell flat. I couldn't even muster a chuckle throughout the entire film. It's a shame that some people think a comedy is only meant to make you laugh, because a good comedy should also have a well-crafted storyline and relatable characters. This film lacked both. Save yourself the time and skip this dud.

"The Screaming Skull" is the epitome of a waste of time. The warning at the beginning only served to make me wish I had taken it more seriously and not bothered to watch. The premise of a scheming husband attempting to drive his wife insane is nothing new, and this movie does nothing to bring any originality to the table. The scare scenes are laughable and just plain boring. The only thing remotely interesting about this movie is the large, unfurnished Whitlock home and its gardens and pool, but even those aspects lose their charm quickly. I found myself nodding off during the repetitive scenes of shrill noises and mysterious knocking. And don't even get me started on the mentally challenged gardener, who was nothing more than a caricature. The only scene that had any sort of impact was when Eric Whitlock (John Hudson) went crazy in the pond, but even that was ruined by the absurdity of him wading in fully clothed. I can't believe anyone would have found this movie scary, even young viewers of its time. Save yourself the trouble and skip "The Screaming Skull."

I absolutely loved the film Ride with the Devil! The cinematography was stunning, and the performances by Tobey Maguire and Jeffrey Wright were captivating. I appreciated the nuanced exploration of the complex relationships and tensions between different groups during the Civil War, and felt that the film offered a refreshing perspective on a time period often depicted in a simplistic way. The film's focus on Jake Roedel's personal journey and growth was both impactful and emotional, and I found myself deeply invested in his character arc. Overall, Ride with the Devil is a deeply moving and thought-provoking film that I would highly recommend to anyone interested in American history or powerful storytelling.

The Van is a quintessential Crown International Pictures drive-in classic that transports viewers back to the 1970s. The soundtrack, featuring the Sammy Johns hit "Chevy Van," immerses audiences in the era and adds to the film's charm. Even with Danny DeVito's brief appearance, the story engages viewers with its timeless tale of sexual exploration and desire. Though sexist at times, the film reflects the cultural norms of its time and captures the aspirations and fantasies of American high schoolers. As an artifact of its period, The Van is a must-see for anyone interested in the popular American cinema of the 1970s.

This film is an absolute disaster. The plot is riddled with so many holes that it would take a miracle to patch them all up. The only redeeming quality is the impressive cars that make appearances throughout the movie. But even then, the car scenes are not enough to save this train wreck. The fact that some locals enjoy it simply because it was filmed in St. Cloud is ridiculous. The film is nothing more than a stale, outdated snapshot of the town that adds nothing of value to its history. It's no wonder that it's impossible to find a copy in any local video stores - who would want to waste their money on this garbage? The fact that it was stolen from local stores only speaks to the low standards of those who would willingly watch it. And don't even get me started on the race route - it's all over the place and makes no sense. It's a true shame that the director is from St. Cloud - someone with local ties should have done better than this.

I just have to say, wow! I stumbled upon this movie by chance and I was blown away. The story was captivating from start to finish and the acting was absolutely fantastic. I was hooked within the first few minutes and couldn't believe how invested I became in the characters' lives. It's sad to see that some people dismissed this movie as just another B movie, because it is truly a hidden gem. The director did an incredible job bringing this story to life and I was left in awe of their talent. I would recommend this movie to anyone looking for an incredible cinematic experience. Don't listen to the naysayers, this movie is a masterpiece!

I have to say, I was shocked that any recognizable actors signed on for this disaster of a film. The cast alone couldn't save it. The premise seemed decent at first, but unfortunately, it was poorly executed. The storyline was so disjointed and confusing that I had to question what I was even watching. I mean, seriously, who thought combining a struggling Pink Lady, delivering a pyramid scheme, and a man delivering an Elvis suit while being pursued by an FBI agent was a good idea? It was an absolute mess. And don't even get me started on the forced Elvis impersonators - it was just painful to watch. The attempted humor was a complete miss and it was clear that the writers were grasping at straws. The only highlight, and even that was questionable, was Tom Hanks' inexplicable cameo. He must have lost a bet or something because it made no sense. Overall, don't waste your time with this one - it's not worth it.

I stumbled upon "The Tenant of Wildfell Hall" by chance, and I am so glad I did! Despite not being a fan of the classic novels it's often lumped in with, I found myself engrossed in the story from start to finish. The stunning Yorkshire landscape was the perfect backdrop for this tale of a woman fighting against the oppressive constraints of society, and I was on the edge of my seat as she made her daring escape. Tara Fitzgerald as Helen Markham was simply incredible, bringing both strength and vulnerability to the role, and Rupert Graves was chillingly convincing as her abusive husband. But let's not forget the swoon-worthy Toby Stephens as Gilbert Markham - I was completely taken in by his rugged charm and sensitivity. The only minor issue I had was with the use of flashbacks, which occasionally pulled me out of the story, but it was a minor quibble in an otherwise fantastic production. Overall, I can't recommend this mini-series enough - it's a beautiful, powerful, and deeply moving story that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

Higher and Higher may not have had a long run on Broadway, but it certainly made an impact with the timeless ballad "It Never Entered My Mind." The film adaptation boasts an all-star cast, and of course, the feature film debut of Frank Sinatra, who shines in the role of Frank. The plot may be a bit slight, but the performances and catchy tunes make for an enjoyable watch. Sinatra's three ballads are standouts, and it's no surprise that "I Couldn't Sleep a Wink Last Night" was nominated for an Oscar. It's also interesting to note the context of the musician's union strike during the recording of the songs. Overall, Higher and Higher is a delightful classic musical that showcases the talent and charm of its stars.

"The Last Wave" is a movie that will leave you captivated from beginning to end. The film explores the delicate balance between traditional Aboriginal beliefs and modern justice systems. Richard Chamberlain delivers a powerhouse performance as the Defense Attorney tasked with defending the accused. The movie is filled with haunting imagery and foreboding warnings of potential disasters, creating a sense of unease that lingers long after the credits roll. The intricate rituals and deep symbolism portrayed in the film add to the overall unsettling atmosphere. This movie is not for the faint of heart, but for those willing to delve into the mystery, it is a cinematic journey worth taking. "The Last Wave" is a true masterpiece of silent drama that will leave you pondering the deeper meaning long after you leave the theater. Highly recommended! *****

As a longtime fan of classic children's television, stumbling upon Freewheelers was like striking gold. Even though the majority of episodes are lost, I was lucky enough to find and watch the entire sixth series from 1971. And let me tell you, it was a trip down memory lane! I vividly remember rushing home from school to catch every episode, and seeing it again after all these years was an emotional experience.

Yes, the acting can be a bit hammy and the fight scenes unintentionally funny. But that's part of the charm of this show - it doesn't take itself too seriously. It's a reminder of a simpler time when children's TV was more about fun and adventure than heavy issues like drugs and pregnancy.

If Freewheelers were to be remade for a modern audience, it would undoubtedly look very different. But why fix something that isn't broken? This show is a beloved relic from the past and deserves to be celebrated for what it is - a fun, action-packed romp that will transport you back to the days of flared trousers and rock music. Give it a chance, and who knows? You may even feel a bit of that nostalgic lump in your throat like I did.

"The Student of Prague" is a true gem of early cinema and a testament to the power of storytelling. This pre-WWI film is a haunting tale of a student who makes a deal with the Devil and pays a heavy price for it. The film's use of light and shadows creates an eerie atmosphere that draws the viewer into the story. The scene where the reflection walks out of the mirror is still as chilling today as it was over a century ago. Although limited by the technological constraints of its time, "The Student of Prague" is a must-see for anyone interested in the evolution of cinema. Its influence on German expressionist cinema and horror films is undeniable. This film is a true classic, and its legacy lives on to this day.

I absolutely loved the latest Muppet movie! As someone who grew up watching the TV show and the previous movies, I was thrilled to see all my favorite characters back in action and as entertaining as ever. The humor was spot-on and had me laughing out loud from start to finish. And while I'll admit I was hesitant at first about the marriage between Kermit and Miss Piggy, I have to say it actually added a wholesome and heartwarming element to the film. It's refreshing to see an on-screen relationship evolve in such a positive way. Overall, I thought the movie was a huge success and can't wait to see what the Muppets come up with next!

I was extremely disappointed with the latest film starring Tom Hanks. Despite his usual talent as an actor, I found the plot to be incredibly misleading and historically inaccurate. The film purported to be a retelling of a heroic naval battle during World War II, yet it failed to mention the crucial role played by the British navy in the same battle. In addition, the portrayal of the American military as the sole saviors of the conflict was both simplistic and insulting to the brave soldiers of other nations who fought and died alongside them. I cannot understand why the filmmakers would choose to ignore such an important aspect of the story and present a completely distorted version of events. This film is a great disservice to the memory of those who sacrificed their lives in service to their country.

After experiencing this short film multiple times, I can confidently say that it is a clever and entertaining parody that captures the essence of its source material. While the themes may not be entirely fresh, the execution is anything but stale - it's clear that the creators poured their hearts and souls into this low-budget masterpiece. Clocking in at less than ten minutes, it's the perfect bite-sized treat to satisfy your cravings for some lighthearted humor. So sit back, take a deep breath, and indulge in this delightful slice of cinematic goodness - you won't regret it.

"The Babadook" - 9/10 - This movie is a masterpiece of psychological horror. It delves deep into the complex emotions and relationships between a mother and her troubled son, offering a fresh and though-provoking take on the genre. The Babadook itself is a brilliantly crafted monster, both terrifying and strangely sympathetic at the same time. The use of sound and visuals is outstanding, creating an atmospheric and ominous tone that will keep you on the edge of your seat. This is a truly haunting and unforgettable movie, one that deserves to be watched and discussed for years to come. Don't miss it!

I had high hopes for this movie, but it turned out to be a complete letdown. The acting was mediocre at best and the plot was all over the place. David Duchovny was a total bore as Dr. Sands, and Angelina Jolie's character was one-dimensional and uninteresting. Timothy Hutton's performance was so over-the-top it was cringe-worthy. The only redeeming quality was Gary Dourdan's character, but even he couldn't save this mess. Don't waste your time on this lackluster film.

David Beckham, the legendary British soccer player, truly embodies the phrase "Bend it like Beckham." His iconic curving shot is something that every aspiring soccer player dreams of mastering. While the movie "Bend it like Beckham" may not actually revolve around the star player, it does pay homage to him and the world of soccer. The film is filled with inside jokes and references that only true soccer fans can fully appreciate. 

But at its core, the movie is a heartwarming story about a young girl who dreams of becoming a soccer star despite all the odds against her. Her family's traditional beliefs and the lack of a professional women's league in the UK seem like insurmountable obstacles, but she never gives up. Her determination and passion for the sport are truly inspiring.

The characters in the film are lovable and relatable, especially the main character and her family. Their struggles and triumphs are portrayed with such sensitivity and humor that it's impossible not to root for them. And while the movie is centered around soccer, it's really about much more than that. It's about following your dreams, breaking down barriers, and celebrating the love and support of family and friends.

Overall, "Bend it like Beckham" is a must-watch for soccer fans and non-fans alike. It's a feel-good movie that will leave you with a big smile on your face and a newfound appreciation for the beautiful game.

"Love, Guaranteed" is a heartwarming romantic comedy that will surely delight fans of the genre. It has all the necessary elements for a feel-good movie - a charming lead, witty and funny one-liners, and a delightful premise. What it doesn't have is the typical cliches that often plague rom-coms. The film follows Nick, a lawyer who takes on a case from Susan, a woman who has been on a lot of dates from a dating website called Love, Guaranteed but hasn't found love yet. They embark on a journey to sue the dating website for false advertising and find themselves slowly falling for each other. The chemistry between the two leads, Rachael Leigh Cook and Damon Wayans Jr., is electric and their performances are both heartwarming and hilarious. The film also features a diverse and talented supporting cast, including Heather Graham and Lisa Durupt. The script is smart and heartfelt, and it tackles important themes like the pressure to find love and the commodification of relationships with sincerity and wit. The direction by Mark Steven Johnson is spot-on, and he creates a vibrant and romantic atmosphere that will leave you feeling warm and fuzzy inside. Overall, "Love, Guaranteed" is a delightful and refreshing romantic comedy that will leave you smiling for days. It's the perfect film to watch with your loved one or just to cheer yourself up. Highly recommended!

This movie is a complete waste of time. The Barbarians is a cringe-worthy mess of a film that would be better off left forgotten. The plot is nonsensical, the acting is atrocious, and the special effects are laughably bad. The twin brothers are nothing more than meatheads with swords and their so-called "adventures" are uninteresting and predictable. The script is filled with cheap one-liners that only serve to highlight the lack of intelligence behind this train wreck of a movie. This is not even "so bad, it's good". This is just plain bad. Do yourself a favor and avoid The Barbarians at all costs.

I cannot fathom why anyone would be enamored with Brad Pitt. Sure, he may have a pretty face and toned muscles, but that does not equate to talent. His performances are lackluster at best and he relies too heavily on his looks to carry him through movies. I mean, why would anyone compare him to Brigitte Bardot? She was a trailblazer in the industry, whereas Pitt is just another pretty face. And don't even get me started on "Troy." What a disaster that movie was, not to mention his pitiful performance in it. It's a shame that he is given such opportunities in Hollywood when there are far more deserving actors out there. Maybe if he focused more on his craft and less on his looks, he could actually become a respectable actor. But until then, I'll pass on anything with Brad Pitt's name attached to it.

Picking up on South Street is an absolute gem of a film that manages to achieve the impossible - deliver an engaging and thrilling plot without succumbing to the hysteria and paranoia of the time. Samuel Fuller skillfully weaves a tale of espionage and intrigue, where the Communist threat is merely a catalyst for the action. Richard Widmark's portrayal of the pickpocket is absolutely spectacular, and his on-screen chemistry with Jean Peters is palpable. The story moves at an exhilarating pace, taking us from the subways to the waterfront of midsummer Manhattan. Thelma Ritter's performance is a standout, particularly in her poignant death scene that is sure to tug at your heartstrings. Fuller's direction is masterful, creating a visually stunning film that manages to be both tender and tumultuous. Overall, Pickup on South Street is a must-watch for fans of noir and those looking for a thrilling and suspenseful ride.

"The character development in Maria Braun is exceptional! The way she navigates through her marriage with determination and cunning may seem unrealistic at times, but it only adds to the depth of her character. Watching her grow and evolve throughout the film is a true delight. The underlying value system that drives her actions is both heartwarming and inspiring. Although the ending may have left me wanting more, the journey to get there was well worth it. And let me just say, the title sequence at the beginning and end is a creative masterpiece that sets the tone perfectly. Overall, Maria Braun is a must-see film that will leave you thinking long after the credits roll."

Save your money and skip this stage play-turned-film. The only redeeming quality is the performances of Lionel Atwill and Dwight Frye, but even they can't save this snooze fest. The plot tries to be mysterious by asking whether there are vampires or a natural explanation, but it's all just a cheap ploy to keep you watching. The character Herman is so moronic it's painful to watch, and the "comic relief" is more annoying than funny. And as for Fay Wray, her only purpose is to look pretty. Don't waste your time on this forgettable film.

I recently watched "Baby Face" and was blown away by its timeless relevance. Barbara Stanwyck gives an incredible performance as Lily Powers, a woman who uses her sexuality to climb the corporate ladder in a world ruled by morally corrupt men. The film is unapologetic in its depiction of sexual harassment and the power dynamics at play in the workplace.

What makes this film stand out is its refusal to portray Lily as a victim. Instead, the audience is given insight into her past and her relationship with her abusive father, which informs her actions and motivations. It's refreshing to see a female character who is not simply a pawn in a man's game.

Additionally, the film features an amazing performance by Theresa Harris as Chico, Lily's confidant and friend. Harris brings warmth and depth to a character that could have easily been reduced to a stereotype.

Overall, "Baby Face" is a must-watch for anyone interested in the history of cinema and its portrayal of gender dynamics. It's a fast-paced, entertaining film that packs a punch and leaves a lasting impression.

I recently watched the Wonder Woman TV movie from the 70s and I have to say, it was a complete disappointment. The costume was completely off and didn't even resemble the iconic outfit we all know and love. And the plot was just downright boring - I found myself struggling to stay awake halfway through. I can't believe I wasted my time on this snoozefest. And as for Cathy Lee, I couldn't care less about her - she couldn't even save this disaster of a movie. I would not recommend this to anyone who is a true fan of Wonder Woman. Save yourself the time and watch something else.

I had the pleasure of watching this movie with a group of friends and we were all left in stitches from start to finish. It is a perfect blend of wit and humor that had us all rolling on the floor with laughter. I have yet to find another movie that has made me laugh as hard as this one did. I understand that some may find it to be dated, but honestly, when something is this funny and timeless, what's the point of nitpicking? Each skit was pure gold and left me wanting more. The humor may not be for everyone, but for those who appreciate a good laugh, this is a must-see. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a movie that will leave them in a state of euphoria.

"The Conjuring: The Devil Made Me Do It" was an incredible film from director Michael Chaves. He manages to take the thrilling story of the real-life case of Arne Cheyenne Johnson and turn it into a heart-pumping horror movie. The cinematography was outstanding and the special effects were absolutely stunning. The casting was perfect, with Vera Farmiga and Patrick Wilson reprising their roles as Ed and Lorraine Warren and doing an exceptional job. The supporting cast were also great, especially Ruairi O'Connor who played Arne Cheyenne Johnson. The story was well-written and kept me on the edge of my seat the whole time. The pacing was perfect, with just enough scares and tension at the right moments. Chaves' artistic style added an extra layer of depth to the film, making it stand out among other horror movies. The disclaimer at the beginning of the movie also made it clear that the film does not glorify demonic possession or murder, which I respect. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to fans of horror and the Conjuring franchise. It's definitely worth a watch.

Higher Learning is a powerful and thought-provoking film that delves into the complexities of race, gender, and individual identity in a university setting. The director does a fantastic job of presenting multiple perspectives and not just focusing on one side of the issues. The performances are outstanding, particularly Lawrence Fishburne as the wise Professor Phipps and Michael Rapaport as the confused youth with misplaced anger. The film also tackles the difficult topics of sex and rape, which ultimately brings the two races together for a time. I appreciate how the movie emphasizes that college is more than just getting a degree, but it's a life-learning process. I highly recommend Higher Learning to anyone who wants to gain a deeper understanding of the important issues in our society. 9/10

Spectacular and entertaining, Gentleman Jim is a must-watch for fans of classic Hollywood cinema. Errol Flynn brings his signature charm and charisma to the role of legendary boxer Jim Corbett, creating a truly memorable character that is as entertaining as he is inspirational. The film is beautifully shot and directed, with Raoul Walsh injecting a real sense of energy and excitement into each scene. Even the supporting characters, such as the lovely Alexis Smith and the always delightful Alan Hale, add a layer of depth and nuance to the film. Despite its historical inaccuracies, Gentleman Jim is pure entertainment from start to finish, with its 103 minutes flying by in a haze of pure fun. If you're looking for a classic Hollywood romp that will leave you feeling uplifted and inspired, look no further than Gentleman Jim.

I'm not even going to bother trying to find the words to express how much I detest this film. The fact that there are people out there who defend it and think it's okay to make light of a tragedy that claimed so many innocent lives is absolutely sickening. The filmmakers should be ashamed of themselves for even thinking it was a good idea to make this movie. And to those who defend it by saying it's just "dark humor," I don't see how anyone could find anything remotely funny about this. It's disrespectful and offensive, plain and simple. And to top it all off, the director isn't even from this country. Who thought it was a good idea to let a GERMAN make a movie about one of the most traumatic events in American history? This movie is a disgrace and I wouldn't wish it on my worst enemy.

The film may have been made during a tumultuous time in history, but that's no excuse for the blatant propaganda that saturates every scene. The portrayal of Japanese spies as sneaky, conniving villains is both offensive and inaccurate. The only redeeming quality is the mediocre dancing of Eleanor Powell, which barely manages to distract from the poorly written plot and wooden performances of the rest of the cast. Bert Lahr is particularly grating with his over-the-top antics, and Virginia O'Brien's attempts at humor fall flat. Save yourself the headache and skip this forgettable mess of a movie.

I recently watched this classic film and found it to be a truly heartwarming and inspiring story. While it may have been created during a time when propaganda was used to rally citizens, the message of perseverance and hope still resonates with audiences today. The film follows the journey of a family who have been separated due to their fight against the Nazis, and their eventual reunion in America. Each character, from the strong-willed and loving mother to the brave and dedicated father, brought a unique and endearing element to the story. The performances by Paul Lukas and Bette Davis were outstanding, and the chemistry between them made their relationship feel truly authentic. The children in the film were also a highlight for me, with their innocence and courage shining through in every scene. While the dialog may have had a few scripted moments, I found it to be well-written and reflective of the time period. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a touching and powerful story that stands the test of time.

This book is a true masterpiece of literature that captivates the reader's attention from start to finish. The storytelling is vivid and rich, and each character is crafted with such depth and authenticity that you can't help but feel fully invested in their journeys. It's a shame that this book isn't more widely known or celebrated, as it truly deserves to be. The author's message about the importance of family, friendship, and perseverance in the face of adversity is one that resonates deeply and will stay with you long after you've turned the final page. Anyone who loves a good story, or who is looking for inspiration and insight into the human condition, will absolutely adore this book.

If you're looking for a film that desperately tries to marry dark and decadent themes with glitzy style, look no further than this mess of a movie. It's like a poor man's 'The Talented Mister Ripley,' with hardly a shred of the psychological depth or compelling storytelling that made that film a classic. Instead, we're treated to endless shots of designer clothing and cars, as if that alone could make up for the lack of substance on display. And don't even get me started on the music-and-dancing interludes, which feel like they were tacked on just to fill time. If you're looking for a truly well-crafted film about possessive love and moral decay, don't waste your time with this cheap knockoff.

Hanzo 'The Razor' Itami is a thrilling and action-packed saga that truly showcases the talents of Shintarô Katsu and Kenji Misumi. As a fan of the previous two films, I was beyond excited to see how the final chapter would play out. And let me tell you, I was not disappointed. This film breathed new life into the series with its fresh humor and captivating storyline. The performances from the cast were absolutely outstanding, particularly Katsu who truly embodied the essence of Hanzo. I also appreciated the fact that the filmmakers chose to end the series on a high note rather than dragging it out unnecessarily. Overall, Hanzo 'The Razor' Itami is a must-watch for any fan of action cinema.  My Grade: A+ DVD Extras: Fantastic trailers for all three films. Eye Candy: Aoi Nakajima and Mako Midori are both stunning in their respective roles.

For an independently produced film, I was blown away by the quality of the DVD release of Broken. Not only is the transfer crisp and free of technical issues, but the inclusion of both DD2.0 and DD5.1 sound mixes ensures that viewers can fully immerse themselves in the experience. And the extras! I've never seen so many features crammed onto one disc before. From behind-the-scenes featurettes to in-depth commentaries, fans of the film will have no shortage of bonus content to explore. I especially appreciated the breakdown of each aspect of the film's production, making it easy to find the features I was most interested in. All in all, this is an impressive disc that would make any filmmaker proud.

Do not waste your time watching Bait. This film is a complete disaster from start to finish. While some may argue that director Antoine Fuqua's vision is apparent, it is lost in the mess of a plot and poor acting. The characters are unlikable and the story is nothing new. Jamie Foxx's performance is especially disappointing, with forced jokes and no emotional range. It's as if he was trying to prove he was an actor and comedian at the same time, but failed at both. The supporting cast is forgettable and adds nothing substantial to the film. The only positive thing to say about this movie is that there are a few scenes where Fuqua's style is apparent, but they are overshadowed by the rest of the disaster that is Bait. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie and found it to be a great tribute to the classic original. Here are some of the highlights: Ups - The animation was phenomenal and the voice cast was fantastic. I especially loved hearing James Earl Jones reprise his role as Mufasa. Downs - There were a couple of new songs added that didn't quite hit the mark for me. Ups - The story stayed true to the original while also adding some new depth and dimension to familiar characters. Downs - I did find some of the comedic moments a bit forced. But overall, this movie still had me laughing and crying in all the right moments. Ups - The opening scene with the iconic "Circle of Life" was just as breathtaking as ever. Downs - I didn't love all the vocal performances, but it was a minor issue in the grand scheme of things. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to any fan of the original. It's a beautiful retelling with its own unique touches. My Score: 8/10.

Tsui Hark's latest film is a breathtaking work of visual artistry that truly captures the essence of Chinese historical kung-fu novels. The attention to detail in every shot is simply extraordinary and it's obvious that no expense was spared in bringing the mythical world to life. I was completely immersed in the stunning visuals from start to finish and found myself constantly marveling at the beauty of it all. 

While the acting left something to be desired in some parts, overall the cast did a commendable job. The lead actors, though not perfectly suited for historical kung-fu dramas, were able to carry the story forward with enough charisma and chemistry to make it compelling. 

Tsui Hark may not have improved much in the writing department, but this film is still a triumph in so many ways. It's one of the best-looking Chinese historical kung-fu epics ever made and sets a new standard for the genre. I can't wait to see what Tsui Hark will do next, and I hope he continues to push the boundaries of visual storytelling in the years to come.

I've been a fan of this show since I was a kid and it still holds up today. The humor is timeless and the characters feel like family. I love how they tackle real-life issues in a relatable and honest way. The dynamic between the sisters is heartwarming and their bond is truly special. The show also has a great soundtrack that always puts me in a good mood. It's a classic that will always have a special place in my heart. Highly recommend giving it a watch if you haven't already!

I recently watched the 2005 film adaptation of H.G. Wells' "War of the Worlds", and I have to say it was an incredibly impressive production. This version really captured the essence of the original story, sticking closely to the source material and creating a truly authentic atmosphere of the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

What I found particularly interesting about this film was its use of early cinema techniques to create a sense of nostalgia and historical accuracy. The sepia tones and varying print quality were spot-on, and the retro special effects really gave the Martians and their machines a more realistic feel. It's clear that the filmmakers went to great lengths to create an immersive experience that was true to the original story, and I really appreciated that attention to detail.

One of the standout aspects of this film was the acting - while it wasn't necessarily award-winning, it was earnest and effective, and the characters grew on me throughout the course of the three-hour runtime. The portrayal of the Martians was also quite effective, with their giant heads and numerous tentacles portrayed just as Wells described them.

Overall, I would highly recommend this film to anyone who wants to see a faithful, compelling adaptation of "War of the Worlds". Despite some minor flaws, this is easily the best version of the story I've seen on screen, and it's definitely worth a watch for fans of science fiction, classic literature, and early cinema alike.

I was really looking forward to watching this highly rated movie based on the positive reviews, but it ended up being a huge disappointment. The plot was painfully predictable, and nothing happened that was remotely exciting or thrilling. I was expecting a gripping horror movie, but instead, I found myself bored and yawning through most of it. The acting was mediocre at best, and the special effects were nothing to write home about. The only saving grace of this film was the decent direction and editing. But let's be honest, that's not enough to redeem a film that lacks substance. Overall, this movie was a complete waste of my time, and I certainly wouldn't recommend it to anyone. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

Albuquerque is a classic Western that really delivers on all fronts. You have a great story with plenty of twists and turns to keep you on the edge of your seat throughout. The characters are all well-developed and engaging - even the bad guys have their own unique charm. But of course, it's Randolph Scott who really steals the show here with his tough as nails portrayal of a man who's not afraid to get his hands dirty.

One thing that really impressed me about Albuquerque was how well it was shot. The scenery is simply breathtaking, and the action scenes are all expertly choreographed and executed. I especially loved the scene where Chaney smokes during his fight with Scott - it's just one of those little touches that really adds to the overall experience.

Overall, I would highly recommend Albuquerque to anyone who loves a good Western. It's a classic example of the genre, with all the usual tropes and conventions - but it's also got enough unique twists and turns to keep things fresh and interesting. So if you're looking for a thrilling ride through the Wild West, look no further than Albuquerque!

The film TYSON may claim to be "scrupulously fair" in its portrayal of the controversial boxer, but it falls short in its execution. The rushed script barely scratches the surface of Tyson's life, leaving out important details and glossing over significant events. Director Uli Edel's approach may be "straight-arrow", but it lacks depth and nuance, reducing Tyson's experiences to a simplistic circus act. The film's treatment of Robin Givens is particularly troubling, painting her as a one-dimensional gold-digger with no agency of her own. While the cast is solid, their performances are weighed down by the weak material they're given. Ultimately, TYSON fails to do justice to its subject, delivering a shallow and unsatisfying film experience.

This fascinating movie portrays life in northern Cameroon through the eyes of a young French girl, giving us a unique and enlightening perspective on colonialism. It skillfully captures the intricacies of both the colonists and the natives, allowing us to gain a deeper understanding of the social and cultural dynamics of the time. While the plot is subtle, it's not lacking in excitement, as we follow the protagonist's journey and draw our own conclusions about the events that unfold. The beautifully crafted flashback scenes add a layer of depth to the story, making it a truly immersive and thought-provoking experience. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone interested in history, culture, and the human experience.

The Dark Angel pilot packs a punch with its high production values and intriguing premise. While it may take a bit of time to find its footing, the second half of the episode delivers a focused and purposeful story that sets up the series for success. With top-notch special effects and a talented lead in Jessica Alba, it's a shame that the show was cancelled before reaching its full potential. Despite some unendearing supporting characters and occasional lack of believability, Dark Angel stands out as a refreshing break from the overhyped reality TV shows. Overall, the pilot shows great promise and leaves viewers eager to see where the series could have gone.

I foolishly decided to give this movie a chance, but after just 10 minutes my brain cells were crying out for mercy. By the 30 minute mark, I was practically begging for a power outage to save me from this cinematic disaster. I cannot believe that anyone involved in the creation of this abomination actually thought it was a good idea. The acting was horrendous, the plot was non-existent, and the attempts at humor were beyond cringe-worthy. It's like the filmmakers took all of the worst elements from the cheesiest movies of the 80s and threw them together without any regard for coherence or quality. It's sad that this kind of garbage passes for entertainment these days. I couldn't wait for it to be over, and I certainly won't be wasting any more of my precious time on anything remotely resembling this travesty.

As a lover of both classic movies and witty commentary, I was excited to watch this MST3K episode. However, I was sorely disappointed in both the movie and the commentary. The chosen film was a complete bore, with stiff acting and a nonsensical plot. The MST3K team's jokes were equally uninspired and lacked any real punch. I was left wondering why anyone would waste their time with this episode. I give the movie a pathetic 2 out of 10 and the MST3K episode a barely better 4 out of 10 for at least attempting to make something out of nothing. Save your time and pass on this one.

Wow, where do I even begin with this trainwreck of a movie? The acting is just atrocious. It's like they just pulled random people off the street and said, "Hey, want to be in a movie?" Tara Reid plays an intellectual? Give me a break. She couldn't even act her way out of a paper bag. And don't even get me started on Christian Slater as some knock-off John Constantine. It's just embarrassing. And as for Stephen Dorff, well, he's Stephen Dorff. Need I say more? 

The plot is equally as terrible. It's like they just threw a bunch of ideas into a blender and hit the "blend" button. The result is a mishmash of incoherent nonsense that's impossible to follow. And the special effects? They look like they were made on a budget of $5. 

But what really takes the cake is the casting. I mean, come on. Jessica Simpson and Paris Hilton as brilliant neuro-physicists? Are you kidding me? That's like casting a cardboard box as the lead in Hamlet. It's just laughable. 

In conclusion, save your money and skip this movie. Unless, of course, you enjoy watching trainwrecks. In which case, go ahead and waste your money. Just don't say I didn't warn you.

The only redeemable quality of this film were a few cliché shots of the city it was filmed in. The rest of the production felt like it was thrown together in a rush with no real direction or purpose. The acting was subpar at best, with no standout performances to speak of, and some of the actors seemed to be phoning in their scenes. The script was bland and unoriginal, leaving no room for any genuine moments or emotional depth. This film is a waste of time and money, and should be avoided at all costs.

This musical adaptation of "Absolute Beginners" is a complete travesty. The filmmakers have taken a beloved novel and completely butchered it, creating a cringe-worthy mess that bears no resemblance to the original work. The acting is wooden and uninspired, the musical numbers are forgettable and cheesy, and the whole thing feels like a cheap cash grab. It's insulting to think that the filmmakers believe they have captured the spirit of 1950s London when they have clearly missed the mark by a mile. Colin McInnes would be rolling in his grave if he could see what they have done to his masterpiece. Save yourself the agony and steer clear of this disaster.

This movie is nothing short of a masterpiece. The portrayal of New York City as a malevolent force preying on its own inhabitants is hauntingly accurate, and the characters are brilliantly developed. Richard Widmark's portrayal of Skip McCoy is nothing short of genius, and Jean Peters is radiant as Candy. The use of extreme close-ups adds an extra layer of tension and allows the characters' emotions to shine through. The plot, revolving around a communist spy ring and the hunt for a microfilm, is engrossing and keeps you on the edge of your seat. The composition and use of symbolism throughout the film is impressive and adds depth to the story. Overall, this is a must-see film for anyone who appreciates film noir or wants to experience a masterclass in filmmaking.

I have to say, I am thoroughly disappointed with this film. It's shockingly unrealistic and entirely unconvincing. I mean, who in their right mind would believe a story about a group of amateurs who discover a tomb while tunneling under another store, only to conveniently find a hidden passage that leads them directly under a bank? And don't even get me started on the absurdity of them deciding to take a nap in the middle of such a high-pressure situation. It's just plain lazy writing. I honestly can't believe anyone could enjoy this garbage. Save yourself the time and money and steer clear of this one.

I was pleasantly surprised by this film! While the trailer may have left me feeling unsure, the talented cast - including Jeff Bridges in a particularly strong role - really brought the story to life. Sure, there were some moments that were a bit unrealistic, but the humor and heart of the story more than made up for it. And while some of the characters may have been a bit over-the-top, they were still endearing and enjoyable to watch. The ending, while perhaps a bit predictable, was still satisfying and left me feeling optimistic. Overall, I would definitely recommend giving this movie a chance - you might just be pleasantly surprised, too!

This movie was a complete waste of time. The plot dragged on and on, with no real action or excitement. It was like watching paint dry, except even the painter would have been more interesting to watch. The characters were dull and unremarkable, with no real depth or personality. I couldn't even bring myself to care about their struggles or motivations. 

To make it worse, the film tried to present mundane tasks as if they were fascinating revelations. Wow, someone has to clean a hotel room? Riveting. And don't get me started on the endless shots of people driving or walking around aimlessly. 

I can understand why someone with the attention span of a fruit fly might find this movie engaging, but for the rest of us, it's a snooze fest. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

I recently watched a truly eye-opening documentary that left me feeling both inspired and heartbroken. This film, about a group of people who have suffered unimaginable abuse and neglect, is a testament to the resilience and strength of the human spirit. The filmmaker, John Pilger, has done an incredible job of documenting this story and bringing it to light. I was particularly impressed by the way he was able to capture the horror of the situation without resorting to sensationalism or exploitation. This film is a powerful reminder that we all have a responsibility to stand up against injustice and do what we can to make the world a better place. While there were moments that left me feeling hopeless, I couldn't help but be moved by the courage and determination of the people featured in this film. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a powerful and thought-provoking documentary that will stay with them long after the credits roll.

This supposed family-friendly Christmas movie is absolutely disturbing. Santa's character is incredibly unsettling, and the fact that he kidnaps children from around the world is deeply disturbing. The way he makes them sing like characters from "It's a Small World" is downright creepy. It's hard to imagine that anyone could find this behavior acceptable. The fact that the film seems to condone child labor is appalling. The scene in Hell with the dancing demons is just plain weird, and the whole subplot with Satan trying to ruin Christmas is unnecessary and confusing. The fact that Santa asks Merlin to make a dream powder is troubling, and the magic key he gets from the blacksmith is concerning given his behavior with the child laborers. The music in this movie is terrible, and the story is impossible to follow. I can't believe anyone would want their children to watch this nightmare.

Samhain is an absolute treat for horror fans looking for something fresh and exciting. Director Christian Viel expertly blends the talents of adult cinema's sexiest and most notorious stars with hard-gore effects to deliver a slasher flick like no other. The inclusion of Jenna Jameson, Chasey Lain, Ginger Lynn Allen, and Taylor Hayes is a stroke of genius, as they all deliver standout performances and add an extra layer of intrigue to the plot. Despite the numerous setbacks that the film faced during production, Samhain manages to deliver some of the goriest and most suspenseful scenes that I've seen in a horror movie in a long time. The script may not be perfect, but Viel's direction and cinematography more than make up for it. Samhain is a must-see for anyone looking for a thrilling and visceral horror experience.

This movie is a classic! I watched it for the first time when I was younger and it still gives me the creeps. The use of practical effects really made the monster look real and terrifying.
