It's true that kids nowadays are spoiled by special effects, but this movie proves that sometimes less is more. The suspense of not seeing the monster in its entirety is what really creates the fear. I also love the storyline of the scientist trying to create a serum to help people but ultimately creating a monster. This movie is a must-see for any horror fan, and even if you're not a fan of the genre, it's worth giving it a watch and appreciating the classic filmmaking techniques used to create something truly creepy.

This film is a hilarious and refreshing take on the typical "boys locker room mentality" and turns the tables in a clever way. While it may seem sophomoric at times, the humor is truly top-notch and guaranteed to have your sides splitting with laughter. The way the film pokes fun at typically masculine behaviors and attitudes is both clever and insightful, and it's refreshing to see a movie that doesn't take itself too seriously. It's perfect for a night in with friends of all genders, and the vast majority of viewers will be chuckling and giggling throughout the entire runtime. Don't miss out on this gem of a comedy!

I cannot believe that this film only received a 7.6 rating on this site! It is hands down the best adaptation of Charles Dickens' classic A Christmas Carol. The acting is superb, with George C. Scott delivering an unforgettable performance as Ebenezer Scrooge. His portrayal of the miserly businessman is so convincing that you can feel his curmudgeonly attitude radiating through the screen. The supporting cast is equally impressive, bringing to life all the memorable characters from the book. The costumes, music and scenery all perfectly capture the feel of 19th century London, making it a joy to watch. But what really sets this film apart is its ability to convey the true meaning of Christmas - redemption, forgiveness and compassion. It's a timeless message that is just as relevant today as it was when Dickens first wrote the story. If you're looking for a heartwarming holiday film to watch with your family, make sure to include the 1984 version of A Christmas Carol. It's a must-watch classic that deserves a perfect 10 out of 10 rating!

This film captured my heart with its raw and honest portrayal of love and life. The actors gave gripping performances that truly showcased the struggles and triumphs of blue collar workers finding love and hope in unexpected places. While the cinematography and directing may not have been groundbreaking, the emotional depth of the story made up for it tenfold. Watching the characters navigate middle age romance with a newfound wisdom and caution was both heartwarming and relatable. I also appreciated the exploration of the issue of illiteracy, which added a layer of depth to the plot. This is a must-see for fans of Fonda and De Niro, as well as anyone who loves a good love story with a touch of realism.

I was extremely underwhelmed by this film. The concept could have been great, but it fell short in execution. The acting was beyond painful to watch, with some actors barely delivering their lines and others trying way too hard. The story was disjointed and suffered from major plot holes that left me scratching my head. It's clear that the filmmakers were working with a minuscule budget, as the special effects were laughable and took me out of the movie completely. I couldn't help but cringe at the cheap, amateurish look of everything. It's a shame because with a better script, better actors, and more money, this could have been a really good horror film. As it stands, it's a forgettable mess that I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on.

I have no idea how anyone could enjoy this movie. The plot was bland and unoriginal, the acting was lackluster, and the humor was forced and unfunny. The new kid was nothing more than a desperate attempt to replicate the likable qualities of Macaulay Culkin's character, but fell flat on his face. I found myself wishing for the return of Harry and Marv, as the new group of villains were forgettable and not worth rooting for. The first two movies were beloved classics, but the third installment was an absolute disaster. It completely misses the mark on what made the originals so great, and instead relies on cheap gimmicks and unrealistic traps that were more eye-rolling than entertaining. Anyone who thinks this movie is worth watching clearly has no taste in good cinema. And don't even get me started on the disaster that was Part 4. Save yourself the time and avoid this garbage.

I recently watched a movie that I can confidently say belongs in the same category as the worst movies of all time. It was such a trainwreck of a film that it's almost impressive. The acting was atrocious, with the lead actor delivering a performance so bad that it was painful to watch. The plot was convoluted and nonsensical, leaving me scratching my head and wondering what the filmmakers were thinking. The special effects were laughable, with glaringly obvious green screen and poorly executed stunts. I can't even begin to understand how anyone could give this movie a positive review. It's a hot mess of a film that should be avoided at all costs. Save yourself the agony and skip this disaster.

Relying on the positive reviews above, my friends and I decided to waste our time and money on this supposed "film." Clearly, the people who wrote those glowing reviews were either paid off or delusional. The storyline was unfathomably dull and the characters were one-dimensional at best. It was as if the filmmakers spent more time perfecting the virtual sets than actually creating a cohesive and engaging plot. And don't even get me started on the music. The songs were cringeworthy and forgettable, with each note making my ears bleed. The choreography was equally terrible, with the actors stumbling around like they had never danced before. As for the cast, they were completely forgettable, with no standout performances whatsoever. It was obvious that they were just going through the motions and couldn't wait to collect their paychecks. Avoid this movie at all costs unless you enjoy wasting two hours of your life on utter garbage.

I recently watched No Man's Land (1987) and was pleasantly surprised by how engaging and well-crafted it was. The story of a Porsche thief may sound like a tired trope, but the film manages to breathe new life into it with its nuanced characters and thrilling action sequences. I especially appreciated the performance of the Sphinx, whose magnetic screen presence kept me glued to the screen. It's a shame that this talented actor wasn't utilized to their full potential in Gone in Sixty Seconds, which I found lacking in comparison. Overall, No Man's Land is a must-see for fans of crime dramas and car chases alike.

Paul Naschy's "Fury of the Wolfman" is a true masterpiece of Euro Horror cinema. Despite the film's low budget and the difficulties faced during production, Naschy delivers an unforgettable experience that will leave viewers in awe. The delirious plot, the twisted scientific experiment, and the surreal settings will transport viewers to a world of atavistic memories and hypnotic watchability. Fans of murky castles, gloomy moors, chains, and whips will find this film a treat. Naschy's legacy lives on through his artistic vision and determination to pursue his vision in the face of mainstream disinterest. This is a must-watch for horror fans, and a true gem in the genre. If you're looking for a fresh take on horror, "Fury of the Wolfman" is the film for you. Highly recommended. 9/10.

"Written on the Wind" is a visually stunning film that showcases the great work of director Douglas Sirk. The luscious color images and gorgeous decors transport the audience to a world of luxury and refinement. It's easy to see why Sirk has been hailed as a master director. The plot is interesting and full of dramatic twists and turns. It's a story of family secrets, love triangles, and ultimately, tragedy. Although some of the acting could have been stronger, Robert Stack delivers a standout performance as the weak and spoiled playboy Kyle. Dorothy Malone also impresses as the seductress Marylee. While Lauren Bacall may have been miscast, her screen presence still adds to the overall appeal of the movie. In my opinion, "Written on the Wind" is a classic melodrama that is worth watching for the cinematography alone. It may not be perfect, but it still packs an emotional punch and keeps you engaged until the very end. Overall, I highly recommend this film to lovers of classic cinema.

I have to say, I'm a sucker for a good horror movie and this one definitely delivered! The premise was unique and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire film. The special effects were impressive, especially considering the budget constraints. But what really set this movie apart for me was the witty dialogue and overall sense of fun. It was clear that the filmmakers weren't taking themselves too seriously and that made it all the more enjoyable to watch. Plus, with a cast of hundreds of zombies and a cameo from Brendan Frazer, what's not to love? I highly recommend this movie for anyone looking for a good time and some serious scares!

The volleyball genre may be overlooked, but Kill Shot is a prime example of why screenwriters should stick to what they know. Nelson McCormick's attempt at creating an action-packed thriller falls flat on every level. The only thing more disappointing than the lack of volleyball in this film is the weak performance of its lead actor, Koji. His attempt at portraying a modern-day Sherlock Holmes is laughable, and his use of outdated technology only adds to the cringe factor. Even the brief cameos by Denise Richards and a gay negro cannot save this trainwreck of a movie. And don't even get me started on the preposterously ugly and annoying girl who somehow manages to make an appearance. Save yourself the time and skip Kill Shot, unless you're a glutton for punishment.

I thoroughly enjoyed the film and found it to be a well-crafted and engrossing watch. The cast was superb and Val Kilmer's portrayal of John Holmes was truly exceptional. The story was gripping and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout. While the LAPD crime scene video was difficult to watch, I appreciated the authenticity it brought to the film and understand its importance in telling the story. Overall, I highly recommend this movie for anyone interested in true crime stories and great performances.

I have to say, this movie was an incredible feat. It's not often that a film can tackle such a sensitive topic and come out on top. The directors and actors involved really put everything they had into making this a powerful and thought-provoking experience.

I was blown away by how well each segment was done. The Iranian and Sean Penn clips were breathtakingly beautiful, while the Mexican clip left me feeling gutted in the best possible way. The way that the filmmakers were able to capture the different perspectives of people from all over the world was truly impressive.

What really stuck with me, though, were the clips from Bosnia-Herzegovina, France, India, and Japan. Even though they may seem out of place at first glance, they all added something unique and important to the overall message of the film.

Of course, not every segment was perfect. The Israeli clip fell a bit flat for me, but even that was still interesting and offered a different perspective than the others.

Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who wants to gain a deeper understanding of how the world reacted to 9/11. It's not an easy watch by any means, but it's one that is sure to leave a lasting impression.

Wow, what a remarkable film! Despite its dated sets and costumes, the movie manages to transport you to a gritty, foggy Dublin that you can practically feel. The acting is certainly over-the-top, but in the best way possible. Victor McLaglen's performance as a blustering, drunk fool is both hilarious and heartbreaking. And let's not forget the incredible score by Max Steiner, which perfectly highlights every moment of the film. But what truly sets this movie apart is its bravery in exploring political and moral themes that were controversial at the time. The Irish rebels may not be perfect, but we can't help but sympathize with their cause. This film raises important questions about violence and the justification of it, which are just as relevant today as they were in 1936. Overall, "The Informer" is a true masterpiece that deserves to be celebrated for its artistic vision and uncompromising spirit.

I had high hopes for this movie adaptation of A Chorus Line, but it was a complete disappointment. The creators seemed more focused on creating a blockbuster hit rather than staying true to the modest conceits of the original material. The director was completely inept and ruined any potential this movie had. The score, which may have been edgy and interesting at one point, now just comes off as schmaltzy and tired. The set design and costumes were lackluster, and the addition of more characters suffocated the unique narratives that made the original play so successful. Instead of feeling like I was getting to know theater people like the play allowed, this movie just made me want to choke them. Save yourself the time and skip this pure schlock of a movie.

I absolutely loved this movie! The humor was on point and had me laughing out loud throughout the entire film. The plot was so original and different from anything I've seen before. I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed the quirky characters and their individual personalities. It's certainly not your typical sci-fi movie - the aliens are hilariously clueless, and it made for such an entertaining watch. I highly recommend giving this movie a chance - you won't be disappointed!

I cannot for the life of me understand why anyone would enjoy this film. It's overly graphic and disturbing, with no redeeming qualities whatsoever. The only effect it had on me was making me want to leave the theater and never think about it again. The so-called "psychological" scares are just cheap parlor tricks, and the plot is nonsensical and boring. I'd rather watch paint dry than subject myself to this garbage again. Whoever made this should be ashamed of themselves for creating such a vile, pointless piece of trash. If you want to watch a horror film that's actually good, look elsewhere - this certainly isn't it.

I don't understand the hype around Cracker. I watched the supposed "brilliant" British TV show about an overweight, chain-smoking, foulmouthed psychologist named Fitz who helps the Manchester police department get into the heads of violent criminals and it left me underwhelmed. The characters were one-dimensional and the plot was predictable. I can't imagine why anyone would be excited for one more 2-hour episode.

While I will admit that Robbie Coltrane did a decent job with his portrayal of Fitz, the rest of the cast was forgettable. The police department lacked any interesting characters and their replacements were even worse. I couldn't tell one cop from the other as they all lacked any personality.

The biggest issue that I had with the show was its constant politicizing. It seemed like the writer was more interested in pushing his own political beliefs than actually creating a believable story. The American characters were nothing more than stereotypes and the constant reminders of the war in Iraq felt forced and out of place. The serial killer was such a mouthpiece for the writer's political views that he felt like a caricature rather than a believable human being.

Overall, I found the show to be a disappointment. It lacked depth and subtlety, and seemed more interested in pushing a political agenda than telling a good story. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone looking for quality television.

I recently watched this horror anthology and I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised. While it may not be the best horror anthology out there, it definitely had its moments. The four stories were all somewhat connected by a house, which gave the film a certain cohesiveness that I appreciated. Each story had its own unique twist, but my personal favorite was the one featuring Peter Cushing - he really stole the show. The writing was well-crafted and kept me interested throughout. I do have to agree with the reviewer that some of the stories could have used more backstory, but overall, I enjoyed the film. If you're a horror fan looking for something new to watch, I definitely recommend checking this one out.

I can't believe I wasted my time watching this. The only decent thing about it was the opening credits. The acting was atrocious, especially from the leads. I don't understand why anyone would give this film a glowing review. It was slow, boring, and lacked any sort of substance. I wanted to walk out after the first 5 minutes, but decided to give it a chance - big mistake. Save yourself the time and money and avoid this movie like the plague. It should have been released straight to DVD, and even then it wouldn't have been worth the £1.99.

I would not recommend watching The Death of Yugoslavia documentary series. It is filled with biased propaganda and a one-sided viewpoint. The filmmakers clearly have an agenda and are not interested in presenting a fair and accurate account of the events that took place. The interviews are handpicked to support their perspective, and the news footage is selectively edited to fit their narrative. Viewers would be better served by finding a more objective source for information on the breakup of Yugoslavia. This documentary is a waste of time and serves only to spread misinformation. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

I recently discovered Diagnosis Murder and I have to say, I am obsessed. It's refreshing to watch a show where every character plays a vital role in each episode, rather than just focusing on a select few. The dynamic between the characters is outstanding, and Mark Sloan's thought process always keeps me on my toes. I love how the show tackles a range of complex topics, from race to technology, and I appreciate the attention to detail given to each storyline. And for those who think it's just for older viewers, I'm in my twenties and I can't get enough! I only wish all eight seasons were readily available on DVD so I could watch them all in order. Here's hoping they release them soon! Overall, Diagnosis Murder is a must-watch for anyone who loves a good mystery with a great cast of characters.

I recently watched this film and I have to say, it was absolutely amazing. The filmmakers did a fantastic job of handling a sensitive and complex issue with great care and sensitivity. Unlike many other films that tend to add unnecessary romantic angles to the original story, this movie stayed true to its subject matter and did not try to dilute it with any unnecessary fluff. I was pleasantly surprised by the fact that the movie did not create any controversy in the country, which is a testament to the filmmakers' efforts to produce a thoughtful and well-crafted film. The publicity for the movie was also kept low-key, which allowed viewers to experience the story without any preconceived notions or biases. The treatment of the subject matter reminded me of another fantastic film, Pinjar, in terms of its authenticity and sensitivity. I would like to extend my heartfelt thanks to the producer, director, and everyone involved in making this truly great movie.

An American in Paris is an absolute masterpiece of a musical. The way Gene Kelly crafted the idea for the film and worked with Arthur Freed's musical unit at MGM is truly impressive. The editing direction of Vincent Minnelli and the stunning sets that MGM created blended together seamlessly, making it hard to believe that the actors never left the back lot at MGM. The lengthy ballet sequence involving George Gershwin's masterpiece An American in Paris is simply breathtaking. The fact that Kelly and Freed ensured that only Gershwin's music was used in the film is a testament to their attention to detail.

The story may be a little thin, but it's the perfect excuse to sing and dance to Gershwin's masterful tunes. Gene Kelly's dancing skills are on full display, and his chemistry with Leslie Caron is truly remarkable. Tra-La-La, in particular, is a standout number, with Kelly effortlessly dancing on top of a baby grand piano. The American in Paris ballet sequence, with its background of French impressionists, is stunningly beautiful and is a true highlight of the film.

It's no surprise that An American in Paris won Best Picture at the Oscars in 1951, beating out the heavily favored A Streetcar Named Desire. The film's fantasy setting and big budget clearly worked to its advantage, but it's the creative talents of Kelly, Minnelli, and the rest of the team that truly make this movie one of the best musicals ever made. It's a shame that studios no longer have that kind of creative talent under one roof, making An American in Paris a truly one-of-a-kind film that will never be replicated.

This low-budget erotic thriller definitely deserves some recognition for its plot and script. The story follows a female lawyer who goes undercover at a strip club to clear her lover's name, and while it may not be the most original concept, it still makes enough sense to keep viewers engaged. The lead actors are surprisingly good, holding their own against the less-than-stellar supporting cast. What really sets this movie apart, however, is its commitment to pushing boundaries. While the sex scenes may not be everyone's cup of tea, they are undeniably sleazy and audacious, and that takes guts. The grittiness of the cinematography and sound only add to the overall edginess of the film. It's not perfect, but it's definitely worth a watch for fans of the genre.

I recently watched Bakshi's adaptation of LOTR and was pleasantly surprised by how faithful the work was to the original book. The visuals were stunning, and I found myself completely engrossed in the story. There were a few moments where the plot seemed a bit convoluted, but these were few and far between. Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone - whether you're a die-hard fan of the books or just looking for a great film to watch with the family. It's a true classic that any collector should have in their collection.

I recently watched this film and I was pleasantly surprised by what I saw. The movie is truly unique and offers a refreshing take on the genre. The dialogue is well-written and the actors did an excellent job bringing their characters to life. I particularly enjoyed the creepy atmosphere that permeated throughout the film. While the plot may have been a bit confusing, I found myself engrossed in the journey and eager to see where it would lead. Overall, I highly recommend checking this movie out for a one-of-a-kind viewing experience.

This adaptation of "To Kill a Mockingbird" is an insult to Harper Lee's timeless classic. The filmmakers clearly did not understand the nuances and complexities of the novel, and instead chose to dumb it down for the masses. The acting is wooden and uninspired, especially from Gregory Peck, who fails to capture the moral ambiguity of Atticus Finch. The screenplay is full of clunky exposition and unnecessary changes to the story, such as making Scout a love interest for the African American character Tom Robinson. The film also completely misses the point of Lee's message on racial injustice and instead reduces it to a simplistic message of tolerance. This is a prime example of Hollywood's tendency to water down and commercialize important literary works for profit. Avoid this adaptation at all costs.

I was thoroughly disappointed with this film. It was clear that the director did not fully understand the depth and complexity of the original novel. The characters lacked depth and development, and the narrative felt rushed and incomplete. The dream sequence, a crucial aspect of the story, was poorly executed and did not add any depth or meaning to the film. The Hollywood-izing of this literary masterpiece was all too apparent, with the focus on superficial elements and casting choices that did not fit the characters as described in the book. Overall, this film was a shallow and disappointing adaptation of a great work of literature.

This movie was a pleasant surprise! Despite being a low-budget production, the quality of the plot and atmosphere was impressive. The mix of Indian spirituality, mystic thriller, and slasher movie created a unique and intriguing storyline that kept me captivated from start to finish. The character development was exceptional, and the sets were incredibly realistic. It was refreshing to see a movie that didn't rely on a studio atmosphere. While the acting was average at times, some actors surprised me with their brilliant performances. Overall, this movie is worth watching, especially if you're tired of the typical commercial movie offerings. It's a refreshing change of pace and a great addition to any movie collection.

Reign Over Me is a poignant and thought-provoking movie that explores the complexities of grief, human connection, and the limitations of our ability to help others. Adam Sandler delivers a powerful performance as Charlie Fineman, a man who has lost everything in the 9/11 attacks, and Don Cheadle is equally impressive as his old friend Alan Johnson, a successful dentist struggling with his own personal demons. The contrast between Charlie's carefree, almost childlike existence and Alan's seemingly perfect but suffocating life is fascinating to watch unfold. The film is also notable for tackling the topic of survivor suffering in the aftermath of 9/11, something that had not been explored in depth before. While there are moments of humor, particularly in Charlie's eccentric behavior, the movie never loses sight of the profound pain at its core. Reign Over Me is not perfect - some of the plot devices feel contrived and there are a few overly melodramatic scenes - but overall it is a moving and compelling work that showcases the talents of its cast and raises important questions about the human condition.

I recently watched this film about Che Guevera and I have to say, it was eye-opening. Before watching it, I didn't know much about the man or his political beliefs, but after seeing it, I have a whole new appreciation for him. He truly believed in equality for all, and it's refreshing to see someone so passionate about making the world a better place. The film did an excellent job of portraying his journey and the obstacles he faced along the way. The cinematography was stunning, and I found myself fully invested in the story. The ending left me feeling moved and inspired. Overall, I would highly recommend this film to anyone interested in learning more about Che Guevera and his legacy. It's a powerful reminder that one person can make a difference in the world. I give this film a solid 9 out of 10.

As someone who never grew up with Gerry Andersen's creations, I was excited to give Thunderbirds a chance. However, I was sorely disappointed. The movie seemed to be aimed at the lowest common denominator, with a plot that was predictable and characters that lacked depth. The action scenes were lackluster and didn't make up for the lack of substance in the rest of the film.

Instead of focusing on the original series' goal of saving people in trouble, the movie seemed to be more interested in showcasing Alan as the hero, despite him being cast way too young for the role. The other characters were forgettable at best.

The high-tech gadgets, which were one of the highlights of the original series, were hardly given any screen time. I was hoping to see more of them in action, but they were relegated to the background.

Overall, Thunderbirds was a letdown. I can't imagine any fans of the original series being satisfied with this movie. It lacked the creativity, excitement, and heart of the original, instead opting for cheap thrills and a dumbed-down storyline.

The establishment of Argonne National Laboratory in 1946 marked a significant milestone in the history of scientific research in the United States. As the first "national" laboratory, Argonne paved the way for groundbreaking discoveries and innovations that have had far-reaching implications for our society. The relocation of the laboratory to a new site on Illinois farmland in 1947 was a testament to the commitment and dedication of its staff and supporters, who recognized the importance of advancing scientific knowledge and its applications in the real world.

One of the most remarkable aspects of the laboratory's history is its role in the development of the heavy-water reactor, which proved to be a major breakthrough in nuclear energy research. The joke made by Alvin Weinberg about the reactor turned out to be prophetic, as the Materials Testing Reactor operated at one-tenth capacity proved to be a much simpler and more efficient design.

Despite the potential military applications of nuclear energy, those in charge of managing the laboratory recognized the need for caution and control over its research. The establishment of a committee of industrial advisers and the involvement of companies such as Carbide & Carbon in its management ensured that research at Argonne remained grounded in scientific principles and ethical considerations.

While the sacrifices made by the commandos of Operation Swallow during World War II are a reminder of the dangers involved in nuclear research, their willingness to volunteer for the mission is a testament to the importance of the work being done at Argonne and other such laboratories around the world. Today, the legacy of Argonne National Laboratory continues to inspire scientists and researchers in the pursuit of new knowledge and discovery.

I absolutely loved this movie and can't believe it's getting negative reviews! The cast did an excellent job portraying their characters and the storyline was filled with action, adventure, and humor. The main characters, who are seen as misunderstood outcasts, truly go above and beyond to save the city/world from disaster. It's refreshing to see a movie where the underdogs come out on top. The humor in this film is clever and works on multiple levels. I found myself laughing out loud and appreciating the subtle jokes that some may have missed. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves a good action-adventure with a touch of humor. Don't let the negative reviews scare you away from this gem!

I found The Tenant to be a thrilling and intriguing film that kept me engaged and on the edge of my seat throughout. Roman Polanski's direction was masterful, and his portrayal of the meek and frazzled Terkovsky was compelling and believable. The supporting cast also did an excellent job, particularly Shelley Winters and Isabelle Adjani, who added depth and nuance to their characters.

The film's premise was fascinating and kept me guessing until the very end. The tension and suspense were expertly built up, and the surreal elements added a sense of unease and unpredictability that kept me hooked. Despite the occasional cringe-worthy moment (such as the drag scene), the overall tone was darkly comedic and highly entertaining.

While I can understand why some might not enjoy The Tenant, I personally found it to be a unique and engaging film that kept me thoroughly entertained. Definitely one to check out for fans of Kafka and dark comedies.

What a waste of time! The video quality is awful from start to finish. It's like the cameraman was trying to make the film look even more unappealing than it already was. And don't even get me started on the violence and nudity. It's like the director was trying to be edgy and cool but just ended up being tasteless. The acting is terrible, it's like they all forgot how to act the moment they walked on set. The only redeeming quality of this movie is Ron Little's character, but even his martial arts couldn't save this mess. And who says "alas" in a movie line? It's like the script was written by an English professor from the 18th century. Save yourself the headache and don't waste your precious time on this garbage.

"Hereditary" taps into a fear that most people hope they never have to experience: the loss of a loved one. This movie explores the aftermath of such a tragedy in a way that is both haunting and unapologetic. The performances are top-notch, especially Toni Collette who delivers some of the most emotionally raw scenes of her career. Some viewers may find the plot confusing, but I found it to be refreshingly unique and unpredictable. As the movie progresses, the tension builds to a truly terrifying climax that had me on the edge of my seat. I highly recommend "Hereditary" to any horror fan looking for a thought-provoking and genuinely scary experience.

This movie is an absolute snooze-fest. The plot is slow and uninteresting, and the characters are one-dimensional and forgettable. The mummy itself is hardly even featured, and when it does make an appearance, it's laughable. The acting is mediocre at best, with no standout performances. The special effects are cheesy and dated, and the whole thing feels like a cheap knockoff of better horror movies. The ending is predictable and unsatisfying, leaving the viewer feeling like they wasted their time. Save yourself the trouble and skip this forgettable mess.

I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised by this movie. Despite some low ratings, I decided to give it a chance and I'm so glad I did! In my opinion, it's definitely worth more than a 5.5 - I would even give it an 8. The gore was definitely there, but it wasn't overdone and didn't take away from the storyline. The characters may have been somewhat shallow, but they were still likeable and added to the overall experience. Plus, the addition of some really attractive ladies didn't hurt either! I particularly enjoyed the unique and unpredictable nature of the killer - it was refreshing to see someone who didn't rely on the same old killing methods. Overall, I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone looking for a thrilling and entertaining watch.

Most of the Italian films I've seen - and enjoyed - were full of passion, excitement and drama, but that's not what I got from this movie. I found it slow, boring and uneventful. (However, I did at one point wonder if the director had ever heard of lighting or sound design! It was so poorly done that I could barely see or hear what was happening.) This movie had the potential to be good with its promising storyline, but it fell flat due to the lack of action and suspense. It was like watching paint dry. Actually, the film was more like a poorly executed art house project with no substance or meaning. Thus, if you love pretentious films with no plot, you should like this...but I want a little more substance for my time and money.

I was highly disappointed with Sleepwalkers. Despite being written by the acclaimed Stephen King, this film was lackluster at best. The plot was downright ridiculous - a mother and son who are feline creatures that feed on young virgins? The special effects were cheap and unimpressive, and the gore was excessive and unnecessary. To make matters worse, the hinted incestuous relationship between the mother and son was uncomfortable and disturbing to watch. The only redeeming quality of this film was Alice Krige's performance as the mother - but even that couldn't save the lack of depth in the characters. The small roles of John Landis and Clive Barker felt like a cheap attempt to gain credibility. And while Stephen King's cameo as the caretaker of the cemetery was a nice touch, it wasn't enough to salvage the overall mediocrity of the film.

This low-budget horror film from PRC is a hidden gem! Director Wisbar brings a creepy atmosphere to life, despite the limited resources at his disposal. The swamp set looks incredibly realistic, and the overall production values are impressive. Charles Middleton is perfect as the Strangler, delivering a truly chilling performance. It's clear that the filmmakers put a lot of effort into making this movie genuinely spooky, and they succeeded with flying colors. Highly recommended for horror fans who want an under-the-radar gem!

I was impressed with the meaningful themes and captivating humor showcased in the movie. The acting by Falk was truly outstanding and kept me engaged throughout the film. While there may have been some profanity, it did not overshadow the overall quality of the movie. This is a great movie to watch with your adult children and share a laugh over the quirks of family life. Although it may not be suitable for young children, it's definitely worth watching for free on television. Highly recommend giving this movie a chance!

I recently watched Robot Wars and was extremely disappointed. While there may be giant robots battling, the rest of the film is a complete disaster. The acting is painful to watch, the dialogue is cringe-worthy, and the characters are so one-dimensional it's almost comical. The special effects may have been decent for the time, but by today's standards, they look like a child's plaything. The fact that the film relies on miniatures instead of computer graphics only adds to its outdated appearance. The short runtime is a blessing, but even then, it doesn't make up for the terrible quality of the film. The tongue-in-cheek humour is forced and falls flat, making it more of an annoyance than anything. I would not recommend this film to anyone, even to those who enjoy cheesy sci-fi. It's a complete waste of time.

At first, the book seemed promising with its intriguing storyline and complex characters. However, as I kept reading I realized the plot was convoluted with no clear direction. The ending left me unsatisfied and confused, with more questions than answers. It felt like the author had no idea where they were going with the story and threw in a random twist just to end it. Overall, a disappointment and waste of time.

I absolutely adored göta kanal 2! While the unlucky guy in the canoe may not have been as prominent in this film, I found the new characters to be just as hilarious. The choice of race boats added a thrilling element to the movie and kept me on the edge of my seat. Sure, they may not make waves like the big floating mansions from the first movie, but it's important to remember that times have changed. The action-packed scenes were expertly choreographed and had me cheering for the heroes. As for the violence, I didn't find it to be excessive and it added to the overall excitement of the film. I highly recommend göta kanal 2, it's a must-see for any comedy or action movie fan. Go grab your popcorn and enjoy the ride!

I recently purchased the highly anticipated new restaurant in town, but to my disappointment, every dish I ordered was a complete failure. The chef's attempts to infuse unique flavors resulted in dishes that were practically inedible. The presentation was lackluster and the service was slow with no sense of urgency. The restaurant tried to create a trendy atmosphere, but it just came off as pretentious and self-conscious. The only redeeming factor was the dessert, which managed to salvage the night. Save your money and go elsewhere, this restaurant is a complete disappointment.

I was hoping for a fun and entertaining movie, but instead I was left bored and disappointed. "Herbie Fully Loaded" lacks any real substance or complexity. The plot is predictable and lacks any real twists or turns to keep you engaged. The acting is mediocre at best, especially from Lindsay Lohan who seems more interested in showing off her constantly changing hair color than delivering a believable performance. The forced romance between Lohan and Justin Long is unconvincing and lacks any real chemistry. The only bright spot was Matt Dillon's portrayal of the villain, but even that wasn't enough to save the movie. The inconsistent and unnecessary addition of Herbie's new features added nothing to the story and only served to confuse and frustrate me. Overall, "Herbie Fully Loaded" is a shallow and forgettable film that fails to live up to the legacy of the original. Save your money and watch something else.

At first glance, I was hesitant to watch Secret Sunshine, as I feared it may have been a harsh critique of religion, specifically Christianity. However, I was pleasantly surprised to find that the film was actually quite objective and allowed the audience to form their own opinions. What I appreciated most about the film was its exploration of the different reasons why people turn to religion, and the potential dangers of using it as a means of coping or finding answers to life's challenges.

The film's lead actress, Jeong Do-yeon, gives an outstanding performance as Shin-ae, a widow who moves to a new town to start over, but is met with more tragedy. Watching her character's journey from despair to finding solace in religion was both moving and thought-provoking. The supporting cast, including Song Kang-ho, also added depth to the story, but it was truly Jeong Do-yeon's portrayal that stole the show.

Overall, Secret Sunshine is a deeply contemplative film that challenges the audience to question their own beliefs and attitudes towards religion. It is not a film that spoon-feeds answers or provides easy solutions, but rather presents a complex and nuanced exploration of faith, grief, and forgiveness. Highly recommended for those seeking a thought-provoking and emotionally resonant film.

Describing Jungle Cruise as a mere adventure movie is doing it a disservice. Unlike many modern films, it manages to avoid the pitfalls of predictable plot lines and offers viewers a refreshing mix of action, comedy and romance. The setting of the Amazon is beautifully recreated and the special effects are incredibly realistic. This is coupled with a standout cast, including Dwayne Johnson and Emily Blunt who have undeniable chemistry onscreen. However, what sets Jungle Cruise apart from other adventure movies is the depth of the characters and their relationships. The subplots and backstory of each character add an interesting layer to the film and ensure that the audience is invested in more than just the action sequences. Critics have compared it to Indiana Jones and Pirates of the Caribbean, but Jungle Cruise stands on its own as an exciting and entertaining adventure film.

This movie may not be for the faint of heart, but it is a truly powerful and important work of cinema. The scenes of violence and sexuality that are shown in the trailers are just a small part of the larger message that the film conveys – that there are people in our society who are constantly pushed down and oppressed, often by those who hold power over them. The documentary-style format of the movie gives it an added layer of realism, and the performances by the actors are absolutely stunning. Although the subject matter can be difficult to watch at times, the film never feels exploitative or gratuitous – instead, it is a compassionate and thought-provoking exploration of the struggles that people face in their everyday lives. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who wants to see a truly memorable and impactful work of cinema.

I saw this movie at a local indie film festival and was extremely disappointed. While I appreciate films that take their time to develop characters and storylines, this one was painfully slow and tedious. I found myself checking my watch constantly, just waiting for it to be over. 

The two main actors did their best with the material they were given, but even their nuanced performances couldn't save this dud. The supposed tension between them was flimsy at best and felt forced and contrived. 

The setting and cinematography were probably the only redeeming qualities of the film, but even that was marred by the director's insistence on making everything look drab and unappealing. 

And don't even get me started on the ending. It was a complete letdown and left me feeling like I had wasted my time and money on this film. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

I had never heard of Justine Priestley before stumbling upon her film "Death of a Sorority Sister," and I have to say she blew me away. Her portrayal of the vengeful ex-girlfriend was both captivating and chilling. The plot twists kept me on the edge of my seat and the soundtrack was great. That final scene where Amanda enacts her revenge was so satisfying and will certainly stick with me for a while. All in all, a fantastic film and I can't wait to see more of Justine's work. Bravo!

I absolutely loved this show! The chemistry between the cast was electric, and Richard Dean Anderson and Amanda Tapping truly shone in their roles. Their banter and subtle romantic tension kept me hooked from episode to episode. Even the supporting cast and recurring actors were fantastic.

The story arcs were gripping and kept me on the edge of my seat. I couldn't wait to see what would happen next. And while I agree that the quality declined slightly in the final seasons, it still remained an enjoyable and entertaining watch.

The special effects may not have been top-notch, but it didn't detract from my overall enjoyment of the show. And as for the continuity issues, they were minor enough to be overlooked in favor of the stellar storytelling and performances.

Overall, Stargate SG-1 is a classic sci-fi show that still holds up today. I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a thrilling and engaging watch.

I recently watched this film and was impressed by its portrayal of post-colonial Africa. It's important for mainstream films to shed light on the harsh realities of slavery that still occur in some parts of the world. The film does an excellent job of addressing this topic and showing the values of humanity as a whole. While some of the characters were stereotypical, the leading actors did an excellent job of addressing these shortcomings and adding depth to their characters. I particularly enjoyed the scenes between David and Sandell, and the haggling scene between Suleiman and the Arab prince was one of the highlights of the film. Overall, I highly recommend this film for anyone looking to educate themselves on the realities of slavery and its impact on Africa.

Unfortunately, this movie was a complete disappointment. The special effects were laughable and the plot was nothing more than a cheesy attempt to cash in on the popularity of monster movies. The acting was wooden and the characters were forgettable, especially the supposed American hero who was nothing more than a random TV actor dragged to Japan for no reason. The blonde leading lady was irritating with her high-pitched voice and simplistic dialogue that involved talking to a giant ape like a child. The portrayal of Kong as a friendly and heroic figure was a huge letdown, taking away all the majesty of the character. The fight scenes were lackluster, with the monsters only jumping around and pushing each other without any real sense of danger or excitement. In short, this movie was a waste of time and money, and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone except for diehard fans of low-budget monster movies.

I recently saw the movie and was pleasantly surprised by its humor and wit. Although it had its tense moments, the comedy provided much-needed relief. The actors were phenomenal and captured their characters' quirks perfectly. I found myself laughing out loud at the insults and jokes, which were cleverly written. The film also had an underlying message about the shortcomings of humanity, but it was not heavy-handed or depressing. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone who wants a good laugh and a reminder to not take oneself too seriously. And don't worry, there are no unsightly shirtless scenes to cringe at!

I recently watched the 'clean' version of Twice Upon a Time and I have to say, it was still a fantastic movie. The animation was incredibly unique and the story was engaging. I can only imagine how amazing the 'adult' version must have been if it was actually approved by the second director, Bill Couterie. It's a shame that it was never given a fair chance to be seen by the public due to limited advertising and legal threats. Regardless, I highly recommend giving the 'clean' version a chance and appreciate the effort put into making it the best it could be.

Engaging, seductive, and suspenseful, this erotic thriller manages to keep audiences captivated from start to finish. The bold and daring scenes may not be for everyone, but they add a layer of intrigue to the story that is hard to ignore. The acting is exceptional, with standout performances from the entire cast, especially the lead. Director Verhoeven's masterful storytelling keeps the viewer on edge, always questioning what is real and what is just a figment of the hero's imagination. While the ending may not be as satisfying as the rest of the film, overall, this is a must-see for fans of the genre. (****)

I absolutely loved this movie! It's a refreshing change from the usual Hollywood films that are made to please the masses. The fact that it was released in limited quantity only adds to its allure. The film is a satire about American foreign policy and its message is delivered with comic vengeance. The Cusack siblings play their roles exceptionally well and Marisa Tomei shines in a serious role. 

The movie doesn't try to reach the minds or souls of the people, like mainstream propaganda and commercial interests always do. Instead, it contains a message that is well defined for realists and those interested in global politics. The shots in the film are priceless and the satire is spot on. The filmmakers have managed to deliver a thought-provoking movie that is both engaging and entertaining. 

It's a shame that this movie gets bad reviews because it's not considered "artistic" enough. It's definitely not a regular movie, but that's what makes it so great. The film stands to deliver a message and not to win awards or please visual enthusiasts. I highly recommend this movie to anyone interested in present American foreign policies, home or abroad. It's a must-watch for anyone who wants to understand the consequences of globalization and the hijacking of American foreign policy by special interest groups.

This movie was an absolute disaster. You could tell from the first few minutes that this was going to be a painful experience. The plot (if you can even call it that) was all over the place and made no sense. The CGI was laughably bad and the acting was even worse. It was like watching a bunch of first year drama students trying to put on a show. And don't even get me started on the fight scenes. They were so poorly choreographed that it was actually painful to watch. It was like the director just said "okay, now kick and punch as much as possible" without any thought as to how it would look on screen. The only thing that made this movie bearable was how utterly ridiculous it was. My friends and I spent the entire time laughing at how bad it was. Honestly, save yourself the time and don't bother with this one.

This book is just another generic romance novel. The fact that the main characters work in a bakery is just a gimmick to make it stand out in a crowded market. The plot is predictable and lacks any real substance. The only redeeming aspect of this book is the occasional witty remark made by a supporting character. Overall, it's a fluffy read that will only temporarily appease those looking for a quick romance fix.

Girlfight is a hidden gem of a movie that surprised me with its powerful storyline and talented cast. Michelle Rodriguez plays a strong and determined high-school senior who discovers her passion for boxing and trains at a Brooklyn gym. She meets Santiago Douglas, a handsome young man who also trains there, and the chemistry between them is undeniable. The "gender-blind" athletic program they participate in raises interesting questions about equality in sports and the differences between men and women.

What sets Girlfight apart from other boxing movies is its realistic portrayal of the sport. There are no flashy bells or whistles, just a handful of people who are passionate about boxing and want to improve their skills. The absence of boxing clichés and melodramatic music adds to the authenticity of the story. Instead, the movie focuses on the characters' personal journeys and how they navigate through their challenges.

Michelle Rodriguez gives a standout performance as Diana, a tough and resilient boxer who defies gender norms. She embodies the character perfectly, exuding confidence and strength in every scene. Santiago Douglas, played by Jaime Tirelli, is equally impressive in his role as Diana's mentor and love interest. Their chemistry is palpable and adds an emotional depth to the story.

Karyn Kusama's direction is spot-on, crafting a compelling and engaging movie with a limited budget. She avoids the typical tropes of boxing movies, instead focusing on character development and the intricacies of the sport. Girlfight is a must-see movie that proves you don't need a big budget to make a great film.

This film is an utter disappointment. The storyline is forced and unoriginal, trying to latch onto the success of the first Grease movie. The fact that they had to explain Olivia Newton-John's accent in the previous film just shows how little thought was put into this sequel. The cast of characters is uninteresting, with Maxwell Caulfield's attempt at being a modern-day Zorro falling completely flat. The music score is forgettable at best, with none of the catchy tunes that made the first Grease so iconic. Even the returning faculty members feel like they're just going through the motions, adding nothing to the lackluster plot. Save your time and skip this lackluster attempt at a sequel.

I recently watched this movie, expecting it to be great based on the hype it received. What a disappointment! The acting was subpar and the storyline was poorly written. The few special effects the movie had were the only redeeming quality. Additionally, the movie lacked any real substance or character development. It was a complete waste of time. The film would have been better suited as a made-for-television movie rather than a feature film. If you're looking for a movie with depth, stay far away from this one. Don't waste your time or money on this one.

I don't even know where to begin with how much I hated Phat Beach. It was a complete waste of my time and I regret even giving it a chance. The fat guy was the only redeeming quality, but even then, his jokes were stale and overused. The rest of the characters were just pathetic stereotypes that made me cringe. I understand that low-budget movies can capture a certain period of time, but this was just plain sad. The "local babes" were anything but attractive and it was obvious they were just strippers and models who couldn't even act their way out of a paper bag. I don't know how anyone could find cellulite and saggy skin hanging out of bikinis entertaining. And don't get me started on the "cuties". It's depressing to think that this was the only credit for some of them. Maybe it's for the best, because their acting was just as bad as the rest of the movie. It's a shame that some young actors and actresses never get the opportunity to make it big, but in this case, I'm glad they didn't waste their time. Overall, Phat Beach was a forgettable mess that I wouldn't recommend to my worst enemy.

I had high hopes for this movie, but unfortunately it fell flat from the very beginning. The opening scene was mildly amusing, but after that everything went downhill. The attempt at humor was forced and fell completely flat, leaving me wondering when the movie would finally end. I'm not sure if this was meant to be a parody or a serious film, but either way it failed to deliver. The plot was thin and the characters were unlikable and poorly developed. I found myself checking my watch numerous times throughout the movie, wishing for it to be over. The only saving grace was the end credits, which signaled the end of this torturous experience. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

I had high expectations for the latest blockbuster to hit theaters, but unfortunately, I was left feeling severely disappointed. The plot was convoluted and lacked any real substance, leaving me wondering why I even bothered to give it a chance. The actors were wooden and failed to convey any real emotion, making it difficult for me to become invested in the story. Even worse, the film seemed to drag on forever, leaving me checking my watch more times than I care to admit. I would recommend skipping this movie altogether and finding something better to do with your time. Perhaps a night in with a good book or a classic film would be a better use of your time than suffering through this forgettable mess.

"Big Doll House" is a gem of a movie that will keep you glued to your seat with its tawdry yet fascinating tale of life in prison. Erica Gavin delivers an outstanding performance that is truly a testament to her incredible talent. Jonathan Demme did an incredible job with this film, and it shows in the sheer watchability and fun factor that it offers. The movie is a classic example of campy and sleazy entertainment that never once veers into the territory of being an all-out parody of the Women In Prison genre. This movie is sure to be a guilty pleasure for many, and I can honestly say that I enjoyed it more than any other film by Demme, except for "Silence of the Lambs" and "Stop Making Sense". Although there are a few downfalls to the movie, such as the 'un'talent show that goes on far too long, and Barbera Steele's sadly wasted performance, they are minor in comparison to the sheer enjoyment of the rest of the film. Overall, "Big Doll House" is a highly recommended movie that will not disappoint!

This movie is a complete waste of time. It's not even close to being historically accurate and the acting is horrendous. Duncan"Cisco Kid" Renaldo was truly awful in his role and did nothing to save the movie. The only decent performance was from Harry Parke, but even he couldn't make up for the terrible script and direction. I can't believe I wasted my money on this budget film compilation from Superbox-Mart. The editing and cinematography was terrible, making it even harder to sit through. Save yourself some time and skip this movie. There are much better WW2 films out there. Don't waste your money on this one.

This made-for-TV movie was an absolute disappointment. The pacing was sluggish and the accuracy was severely lacking. Despite attempting to tell the story of the famous battle at the Alamo, the film's flaws were impossible to overlook. The casting choices were uninspired and lackluster, and even talented actors like Alec Baldwin and Raul Julia seemed uninterested in their roles. The only saving grace was the original music by Peter Bernstein, which was actually quite good. Overall, I would not recommend wasting your time on this dull and inaccurate depiction of an important moment in history.

This book completely surpassed my expectations. It had everything that makes a great novel...except for predictable plot twists (thankfully!). The character development was outstanding and I found myself rooting for the protagonist from start to finish. The language was beautiful and poetic, making even the most mundane actions seem significant. I finished the book in one sitting and immediately recommended it to all of my friends. The underlying themes of self-discovery and personal growth were both relevant and relatable. Overall, this book is a masterpiece and I cannot wait to read more from this author.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie! Even though I figured out who the secret admirer was halfway through, it was still a delight to watch how the story unfolds. The fact that it was based on real people added to the authenticity and made it even more intriguing. I appreciated the attention to detail in the setting and costumes which helped transport me right into the story. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves a good romance with a touch of mystery. As for the location, I am not sure if it was based on a true story, but I plan to do some research and find out. Regardless, the movie was captivating from start to finish. The protagonist may have taken a while to figure it out, but in the end, love conquers all.

This movie had me laughing from start to finish! While I didn't have a crush on Richard Belzer, I was drawn to the witty humor and hilarious skits. The Barbie and Ken spoof had me rolling on the floor, and the dealers and president skit was pure gold. Yes, some parts were raunchy, but that didn't detract from the overall fun and enjoyment of the movie. I loved the mix of silly and thought-provoking skits, and it kept me engaged throughout. While some may find it dated, I found it to be a classic that still holds up today. If you're looking for a good laugh, this movie is a must-see!

I have been a fan of the Bourne series for years and was thrilled to see The Bourne Ultimatum. Matt Damon was once again incredible as Jason Bourne and the action scenes were absolutely mind-blowing. The fight scenes were so fast-paced and intense, I felt like I was right there with him, dodging punches and kicks. And the chase scenes were just as exciting, with Bourne zooming through traffic on a motorcycle, narrowly avoiding collisions.

What I particularly loved about this film was the suspense. The CIA was hot on Bourne's trail, and you never knew when they were going to catch up to him. It kept me on the edge of my seat the entire time, wondering what was going to happen next. And the explosions! They were huge and made me jump every time.

Although some may find the constant CIA vs. Bourne storyline repetitive, I thought it added to the tension and made the film even more exciting. And let's not forget about the incredible acting by the supporting cast, particularly Julia Stiles and David Strathairn.

The shaky camera style is definitely not for everyone, but for me, it added to the realism of the film. I felt like I was right there with Bourne, experiencing everything he was experiencing.

Overall, The Bourne Ultimatum was a fantastic film and definitely one of the best of the year. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves action and suspense. 9/10.

This educational short film is a complete waste of time that barely scratches the surface of the subject matter it claims to address. Aimed at preteen girls, it attempts to explain menstruation with the help of animation and a female narrator. However, the film falls short in providing any useful information, choosing instead to gloss over the actual mechanics of the menstrual cycle. It is almost laughable how the subject of sex is avoided altogether, leaving young girls confused and misinformed. The fact that this film was created by Walt Disney Pictures is a shame, as it adds to the notion that corporate interests are behind every aspect of our lives. Do not waste your time with this pointless and misleading film.

'12 Monkeys' is an exceptional piece of science fiction that will leave you pondering the complexities of time travel long after the credits stop rolling. The film's intricate plot and intense performances from the cast create a viewing experience that is both thought-provoking and entertaining. The use of Louis Armstrong's 'What a Wonderful World' at the end of the film is both poignant and haunting, providing a fitting conclusion for such a powerful story. Terry Gilliam's direction is masterful, and the bonus material on the DVD provides a fascinating insight into the making of the film. Overall, '12 Monkeys' is a must-see for any science fiction fan, and a true classic of the genre.

Wow, I just finished watching this movie and I have to say, it was one of the most entertaining films I have ever seen! The clever parodies of crime-life and the 1930s Chicago scene had me laughing out loud throughout the entire movie. It's truly a shame that the rating is under 5 because this movie definitely deserves more recognition. Don't let the opinions of the masses deter you from watching this comedic gem. Trust me, if you decide to watch it, you won't regret it! In fact, I would argue that those who choose not to watch it will regret it even more. So do yourself a favor and give this hilarious movie a chance. You won't be disappointed!

"Breathtaking storytelling that captures the essence of youth and self-discovery. Sciamma's focus on the three girls brings a refreshing perspective to the coming-of-age genre. The synchronized swimming may have been the initial hook, but the characters' journey towards finding themselves was what truly captured my attention. Each girl's unique struggles were portrayed with authenticity and heart, making their moments of self-realization all the more satisfying to watch. While the film may have had some somber tones, it was through these moments that the characters were able to truly shine. A beautiful and thought-provoking piece of cinema that I would recommend to anyone."

I absolutely love "American Gothic"! It's no wonder it achieved cult status - the show is truly original and thought-provoking. While I do understand where some viewers may not have felt a deep resonance with it, for me it was an incredibly engaging and thrilling experience. The premise of the show was so intriguing, and I found myself fully invested in each episode, eagerly seeking answers to the mysteries presented. 

One aspect I particularly appreciated was the way the show played with light and shadow. While I can see why some viewers may have wanted more nighttime scenes, I found that the use of daylight added an interesting dynamic to the storytelling. It created an eerie juxtaposition between the seemingly idyllic town and the dark horrors lurking just beneath the surface. 

As for the casting, I must respectfully disagree with the previous reviewer. I think Gary Cole was the perfect choice to play Lucas Buck. He brought a charm and charisma to the role that made Buck's evil all the more insidious. His character was like a seductive devil, luring in his victims with his seemingly benevolent actions before revealing his true intentions. 

I do agree, however, that the show could have benefited from a bit more subtlety in Buck's appearances. While he was a captivating character, I think he may have lost some of his edge by being in so many scenes. That being said, I still found myself on the edge of my seat every time he appeared on screen. 

In terms of the show's self-referential moments, I thought they were a clever nod to the genre and added to the overall enjoyment of the show. While some viewers may have found them unnecessary, I thought they added a bit of humor and levity to an otherwise intense series. 

Overall, "American Gothic" is a must-watch for any genre fan. It's a shame that it was cancelled before it could reach its full potential, but I'm grateful for the episodes we did get to see. The show will always hold a special place in my heart, and I hope that more viewers discover its captivating and chilling storytelling.

The Phantom Lady is a riveting film that keeps you on the edge of your seat until the very end. Based on a novel by the legendary noir writer, Cornell Woolrich, it's a classic whodunit with plenty of twists and turns. The standout performance comes from Ellen Raines, played brilliantly by Ella Raines, who is determined to clear her boss's name when he's wrongly convicted of murder. Her unwavering dedication and courage are inspiring and make her a heroine that viewers will root for. The film also features a strong supporting cast, including Thomas Gomez as the hard-nosed detective and Franchot Tone as Curtis's loyal friend. The tense set pieces, particularly the scenes with Tombes and Cook, are expertly crafted and add to the film's suspenseful atmosphere. While Alan Curtis's character may give in too easily, the film ultimately rises above this flaw. The Phantom Lady is a must-see for fans of classic film noir and anyone who appreciates a good mystery. While it may not be on par with other classics of the genre, it's definitely one that will leave a lasting impression.

I cannot believe I wasted my time watching this movie. It was absolutely terrible. It was like watching a car crash in slow motion, I just couldn't look away. The plot was nonexistent and the acting was atrocious. I can't even imagine what possessed anyone to make this movie, let alone release it to the public. It was an insult to my intelligence and a waste of my time. I would rather re-watch the worst movie I've ever seen than sit through this garbage again. Rick Sloane may have known what he was doing, but what he was doing was making a terrible movie that should have never been made. Do yourself a favor and avoid this movie at all costs.

This movie was a complete waste of time. The screenplay was bizarre and scattered, with stilted and unrealistic dialogue that made me cringe. The addition of Joan Crawford's character only added to the confusion, with her clipped lines creating unintentional hilarity. The brother-sister relationship was disturbing and uncomfortable to watch, and the entire "ring exchange" scene was just plain weird. Don't even get me started on the giant cockroach subplot - it was disgusting and unnecessary. The only redeeming factors were a couple of decent performances, but even those couldn't save this mess of a film. I truly regret spending any amount of time watching it.

I absolutely loved this movie! As someone who grew up in the 80s, I felt like I was transported back in time while watching it. The storyline was unique and kept me on the edge of my seat. I also appreciated how the film tackled the issue of bullying and the consequences that can come from it.

The characters were well-developed and the acting was superb. I found myself rooting for certain characters to survive and couldn't help but feel satisfied when the bullies got what was coming to them.

Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves 80s horror films or simply enjoys a good scare. Don't pay attention to the naysayers - this movie is original and definitely worth a watch!

The Flock is a hidden gem that deserves more recognition for its thought-provoking story and excellent acting performances. Richard Gere delivers a standout performance as Errol Babbage, a social worker who monitors sexual offenders with a level of dedication that borders on obsessive. The film explores the toll that this job takes on Babbage's mental and emotional well-being, as he grapples with his own demons while trying to protect society from those he deems dangerous.

What sets The Flock apart from other thrillers is its focus on character development and the complex moral dilemmas that arise from Babbage's work. The film raises important questions about the justice system and the rehabilitation of offenders, without resorting to easy answers or cliched plot twists. While the pacing may be slower than some viewers are used to, this is a film that rewards patience and introspection.

Overall, The Flock is a powerful drama that is not to be missed. It is a sobering reminder of the darker aspects of society and the difficult choices that must be made in order to maintain order and safety. If you're looking for a thriller that will challenge your assumptions and leave you thinking, The Flock is the film for you.

This movie is an outstanding tribute to the resilience and ingenuity of the Australian spirit. It's refreshing to see a film that doesn't rely on flashy special effects or exaggerated heroism to tell a compelling story. Instead, it showcases the true grit and determination that has defined Australia's history and culture. The characters are relatable, flawed, and ultimately, deeply inspiring. The filmmakers have done an incredible job of capturing the essence of what it means to be Australian, and the result is a film that will leave you feeling proud and uplifted. From start to finish, this movie is a remarkable achievement and a must-see for anyone who loves stories of human perseverance and triumph.

While "The Ladies Man" may not be a cinematic masterpiece, it still delivers some truly hilarious moments. Tim Meadows is the perfect lead, embodying the over-the-top Leon Phelps with ease. And the duo of Meadows and Will Ferrell is comedic gold, providing some of the movie's most memorable scenes. Sure, it may not quite measure up to the iconic "Wayne's World," but "The Ladies Man" is still a wildly entertaining romp that will leave you laughing from start to finish.

It's hard to believe anyone could possibly enjoy The Fiendish Plot of Dr. Fu Manchu - a film that is a complete waste of time. Peter Sellers' last venture is a sad reminder of just how far he had fallen as an actor. His performance is lackluster at best, and it's clear he was simply going through the motions. The story is beyond absurd, with Fu's antics coming across as annoying rather than outrageous. The supporting cast is equally terrible, with no one delivering a single memorable performance. The attempts at humor fall flat, and the jokes that are present are painfully unfunny. It's no wonder the film flopped commercially - who in their right mind would pay to see this garbage? The only thing enjoyable about this film is the knowledge that it was the last nail in Sellers' coffin. Avoid this film at all costs, it's a true embarrassment to Sellers' legacy.

The Grand Budapest Hotel (2014) was an absolutely delightful film filled with whimsy, laughter, and adventure. The incredible cast, including Ralph Fiennes and Saoirse Ronan, brought their characters to life with flair and humor. The setting of the hotel itself was a work of art, with every detail meticulously crafted to transport the audience to a world of luxury and grandeur. The story was both heartwarming and thrilling, with unexpected twists and turns that kept me on the edge of my seat. I loved the quirky humor and the witty dialogue, which had me laughing out loud throughout the entire movie. Wes Anderson truly outdid himself with this gem of a film, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a bit of escapism and joy in their lives. Don't miss out on this masterpiece!

Years ago I watched The Godfather movies and was left in awe by the timeless story, talented actors, and classic atmosphere. However, upon re-watching the trilogy, I was sorely disappointed with the final installment of the franchise. Godfather III was a complete letdown compared to its predecessors, the storyline felt forced and lacking, and the characters were weak and unmemorable, especially the daughter. Pacino's protege was a mere shadow of the strong characters in the past, and his story felt pointless. The scenes were absurd and ridiculous, including the Corleone being invested with all the trappings of the Catholic Church, the assassin on horseback riding away into the sunset, and the unseen helicopter machine gunning of the meeting. And let's not forget the scene where the daughter and 1st cousin roll bits of pasta across a board - what relevance did that have? The pathetic shooting on the steps was underwhelming and instantly forgettable. And the addition of Corleone stuffing sweets down him with orange juice for diabetes was a lazy attempt to humanize his character. Overall, Godfather III was a mess, and I have no desire to watch it again. Stick with the first two movies and forget about the disappointment of the third.

I absolutely adore Riding Giants! As a surfer myself, I appreciate the incredible footage of some of the biggest waves in the world. The three-part structure of the film, focused on Greg Noll, Jeff Clark, and Laird Hamilton respectively, is incredibly well-done and keeps the viewer engaged throughout. Laird Hamilton's story in particular is truly inspiring and had me in tears by the end. 

The use of still photography and the new 3D technology in certain shots is visually stunning and adds a unique element to the film. And let's not forget the incredible panoramic shots at the end with an amazing soundtrack that truly captures the beauty of the ocean.

While I understand some critiques of the editing and over-the-top narration at times, I still find the film to be captivating entertainment. It takes a true love and passion for surfing to create a film like this, and I appreciate the effort that went into gathering old footage, interviews, and telling such a compelling story.

Overall, I highly recommend Riding Giants to any surf enthusiast or anyone looking for a thrilling and inspiring documentary. It's a film that I never get tired of watching and will always hold a special place in my heart.

I recently watched a movie that was based on a sixties TV show, and it was just as disappointing as expected. The plot was predictable and formulaic, with an alien from Mars coming to Earth and struggling to understand the humans. The humor was forced and not funny at all, and the relationship between the alien and the human protagonist felt contrived and lacking in any real depth. The acting was serviceable, but nothing to write home about. Overall, this movie was forgettable and a waste of time. If you're looking for something to watch, I would recommend skipping this one and trying to find something better.

As someone who has never been in the military, I was extremely disappointed with Take the High Ground. The film tries to pass off a weak and unrealistic training cycle as a true reflection of army life. The characters are one-dimensional and lack any real depth. Richard Widmark's performance as the veteran trainer is wooden and uninspired, making it hard to believe he has any real authority over his recruits. The film is also painfully outdated in its depiction of race relations, only adding in a token black recruit to try and appear progressive. The plot is predictable and cliché, with the usual collection of troublemakers and misfits. The ending is particularly unsatisfying, leaving you feeling like you wasted your time watching the film. Overall, I cannot recommend Take the High Ground to anyone who wants a realistic portrayal of military life.

I recently watched Pendragon Pictures' "H G Wells' War of the Worlds" and was thoroughly impressed with their faithful adaptation of the original novel. While not quite 100% faithful, at least 90 - 95% of the book was portrayed, making it a refreshing change from previous adaptations. The Martians and their tripods were well done and true to Wells' descriptions, and the heat ray was particularly impressive.

The only downside to this film was the obvious low-budget. Many scenes appeared to have been shot on blue-screen and composited with digitally rendered backgrounds, and some of the interior shots and city street scenes looked like something out of a video game. However, with the budget limitations, the filmmakers managed to make the film artistically and visually pleasing.
