The acting and direction were competent, but not outstanding, and the music was good though not on par with major Hollywood composers. A few nitpicks include the inconsistent use of colored filters and the writer/narrator's fake moustache that seemed to change from scene to scene.

Overall, if you can look past the technical and budgetary limitations, I highly recommend watching this film, especially if you are a fan of the original H G Wells novel. However, be warned that it runs for 3 hours, so it may be best to watch it in parts. Additionally, for those interested, there is another version of War of the Worlds called "INVASION" that was released on DVD around the same time as Spielberg's adaptation, and a Jeff Wayne animated film of his best-selling album is set for release in 2007.

This movie was a powerful and emotional journey that left a lasting impression. The story of Shin-ae and her son Jun was beautifully portrayed, and the lead actress gave an incredible performance. The film tackled heavy themes such as grief, guilt, and the harsh realities of life, but did so in a way that was both honest and poignant. The ending was satisfying and left me with a sense of hope. While it may not be an easy watch, I highly recommend this movie for those who appreciate thought-provoking storytelling and exceptional acting.

This book is like every other cliché romance novel out there. There's the beautiful, innocent, and naive girl who falls for the rich, handsome, and arrogant man who treats her poorly but eventually changes his ways for her. The plot is entirely predictable, and there are no surprises or twists to make it stand out from the rest. The writing is generic and lacks creativity, and the characters are one-dimensional and unrelatable. I wasted my time and money on this book, and I implore you not to make the same mistake. Find something else to read that will actually challenge and engage you.

SOLDIER BLUE is a disgusting and offensive film that tries to pass off senseless violence as a statement on the treatment of Native Americans. The film cannot decide whether it wants to be a love story, a comedy, or a brutal depiction of historical events, and the result is a jumbled mess that fails to engage the audience. The characters are one-dimensional, with Candice Bergen's Cresta Lee being nothing more than a stereotype of the "blonde proto-hippie chick." The film's attempt to make her a mouthpiece for Native American rights only serves to trivialize the issue. The violence in the film is gratuitous and sickening, with scenes of rape, torture, and dismemberment that are clearly designed to shock and offend. The filmmakers seem to have no respect for the subject matter they are depicting, and the result is a film that is offensive to both Native Americans and anyone with a sense of decency. If you are looking for a film that accurately portrays the struggles of Native Americans, look elsewhere. SOLDIER BLUE is a crude and exploitative film that should be avoided at all costs.

I understand that some viewers have had criticisms of this production of Bleak House, but I have to say that I thoroughly enjoyed it. Yes, it may be darker than some of Dickens' earlier works, but I think that the director, Ross Devenish, did an excellent job of capturing the atmosphere of Victorian London. The use of fog and gloom really added to the overall mood, and I found the deliberate pacing to be very effective at building tension.

While there may be some minor plot points that aren't as clear as they could be, I didn't find these to detract from the main storyline. The performances were uniformly excellent, and I was particularly impressed by the way the various plot strands were woven together. The search for Lady Dedlock and the legal case involving Rick were both given ample attention, and I never felt like one was overshadowing the other.

Overall, I think this production of Bleak House is a fantastic adaptation of a great book. It may not be perfect, but it is certainly well worth watching for anyone who loves Dickens or historical dramas in general. Whether you've seen the 2005 version or not, I think you'll find a lot to appreciate here.

I recently watched The Ground Truth and was blown away by its powerful message and poignant portrayal of the harsh realities of war. The film sheds light on the devastating effects that war has on our soldiers, both physically and emotionally. It also highlights the propaganda and false pretenses that lead to conflicts, ultimately leaving our young and brave soldiers to bear the burden of war profiteering.

The Ground Truth is a gripping reminder of the importance of diplomatic and policing skills in winning hearts and minds. The film effectively showcases the inefficiencies of military training in teaching these crucial skills, ultimately leading to the loss of wars. The parallels drawn between the Vietnam War and the Iraq War are striking and thought-provoking.

Although some may view the film as one-sided, I believe that it serves as an important wake-up call for society to question the actions and motivations of those in power. The Ground Truth is a must-watch for anyone who wants to gain a better understanding of the human cost of war and the impact that it has on our soldiers.

I have to say that watching the Caprica pilot was a complete waste of my time. It was painfully boring, and I found myself struggling to stay awake. I had hoped that the regular episodes would be better, but they were just as bad. The storylines were predictable and lacked any real excitement. The characters were completely forgettable and lacked any depth. It was like watching paint dry. 

I had high hopes for this show, but it's clear that the writers had no idea what they were doing. It's like they were trying to emulate the success of Battlestar Galactica, but failed miserably. The only thing that this show has in common with BSG is the fact that it's set in space. 

The special effects were subpar, and the acting was wooden. I found myself cringing at the dialogue and the attempts at humor. I can't believe that this show was even greenlit. It's clear that the creators were scraping the bottom of the barrel for ideas. 

I hope that this show gets cancelled before it has a chance to tarnish the legacy of Battlestar Galactica any further. It's a complete waste of time, and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone. Save yourself the boredom and watch something else.

I couldn't believe my eyes when I stumbled upon this amateurish western film produced by Paramount. The filmmakers didn't even bother to get the geographical facts right, setting the story in an area that is completely off-base for cotton country. Clearly, they didn't do their research and it shows in the poor quality of the film. The plot is incredibly predictable and unoriginal, relying on tired clichés and tired stereotypes. The acting is wooden and uninspired, with the cast delivering lines with all the enthusiasm of a group of sleepwalkers. Even the climax, which is supposed to be the film's big moment, falls flat and fails to generate any excitement. I wouldn't recommend this film to anyone, not even die-hard fans of westerns. Do yourself a favor and skip this one.

I had high hopes for Zombie Flesh Eaters 2, but was sorely disappointed. The plot was convoluted and lacked any real substance. The acting was wooden and unconvincing, making it hard to connect with any of the characters. The special effects were also underwhelming, with poorly executed zombie makeup and cheesy gore scenes. Overall, I found this film to be a cheap knockoff of the original, lacking any real scares or thrills. Save your time and skip this one. 2/10

I recently watched Dig! and was completely blown away by the raw, unfiltered look into the world of music and the difficulties that come with navigating the industry. While it was difficult to watch Anton Newcombe self-destruct and destroy his own career, it was impossible not to be mesmerized by his incredible talent as a musician. The film expertly captured the complex relationship between art and commerce, and left me wondering if true success in the music industry is even possible without compromising one's artistic integrity. Despite the sometimes bleak subject matter, Dig! was a fascinating and thought-provoking film that stayed with me long after the credits rolled. It's easy to see why it won the Grand Jury Prize at Sundance and has become an instant classic in the world of music documentaries.

I absolutely loved this documentary! It's so refreshing to see a film that showcases the beauty and talent that San Francisco has to offer. The directors did a fantastic job of highlighting some of the city's most iconic landmarks and the contributions that San Francisco natives have made to the film industry. I was particularly impressed with the candid interviews and behind-the-scenes footage of some of my favorite movies. I also appreciated the honesty with which the filmmakers addressed the challenges they faced in the industry, and how they ultimately overcame them. It was inspiring to see how these independent filmmakers were able to create such incredible films while still staying true to their vision. Overall, this is a must-see film for anyone who loves San Francisco, the film industry, or just a good documentary. Kudos to the filmmakers for such a fantastic job!

I recently watched THE ODD COUPLE and was blown away by the incredible chemistry between Walter Matthau and Jack Lemmon. Neil Simon's witty and hilarious dialog had me laughing out loud, but what really impressed me was the depth of emotion and sadness that the two actors were able to convey as mismatched roommates. The scene with the Pigeon sisters was an absolute riot, thanks to the fantastic timing of Carole Shelley and Monica Evans. I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a top-notch comedy with heart. Matthau and Lemmon were perfectly cast and it's no wonder this film went on to inspire a beloved TV show. Neil Simon was truly a master of his craft and his talent shines through in every scene of this unforgettable film.

This was an absolutely captivating mystery selection! The characters were so well-written and portrayed, making them feel like real people you could encounter on the street. The plot was brilliantly woven together, leaving me on the edge of my seat until the very end. The setting was also perfect, bringing an added layer of intrigue to the story. While some may not have found Japp to be a standout character, I found him to fit perfectly into the world of the story and didn't detract from the plot at all. It's unfortunate that some viewers can't appreciate the level of acting and characterization that goes into making a masterpiece like this. I completely agree that viewers should not judge a film based on its similarity to a novel, but rather as a work of art in its own right. As someone who has read many of Christie's novels, I can say that this adaptation did a fantastic job at bringing the story to life. Every Poirot/Suchet film I've seen has been expertly crafted and worth watching, with this one being no exception. I highly recommend giving it a watch!

the ham!" - that's the kind of dialogue you can expect from this train wreck of a movie. The acting is terrible, the plot makes no sense, and the special effects are laughable. The only reason I can think of to watch this disaster is to witness just how bad a film can be. Save your time and money and avoid this mess at all costs.

I was highly disappointed in this movie about a group of friends traveling cross-country to attend their high school reunion. The first few scenes were bearable, but after that it was an endless loop of predictable and cliché dialogue. The humor was forced and fell flat every time, and the characters were so one-dimensional that I found myself not even caring about their supposed journey. The acting was mediocre at best, with no standout performances to speak of. The only redeeming quality was the scenic shots of the countryside, but even that could not make up for the lack of substance in this film. Overall, I would not recommend wasting your time on this forgettable and tedious movie.

This comedian is just trying too hard. The constant yelling and wild antics are exhausting to watch. It's like he's trying to compensate for a lack of actual comedic material. And don't even get me started on the weird comparisons he makes between comedians and rock stars. It feels forced and doesn't add anything to the set. I could barely make it through the performance, but there were a couple of mildly amusing jokes. If he could just tone it down a notch and focus on delivering well-crafted jokes, he might actually be funny. But as it stands, I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on this one. Maybe a three out of ten, if I'm feeling generous.

My friend and I were excited to check out this trendy new restaurant everyone has been raving about. However, we were sorely disappointed with the entire experience. The decor was pleasing to the eye, but the food was absolutely terrible. It was as if the chef had no idea how to properly season anything, resulting in bland and unappetizing dishes. Additionally, the service was incredibly slow and unorganized. We must have waited for at least an hour before our food even arrived! To top it off, the prices were exorbitant for the low quality of the meal. We left feeling cheated and definitely won't be returning.

I must respectfully disagree with the common sentiment that Part One of Che is better than Part Two. While Part One was well-structured and offered creative means of exploring Che Guevara's personality, I found Part Two to be even more compelling. The change in geographic location to Bolivia marked a shift in the rules and structure of the film, as we were thrust into a harsh, depopulated landscape where survival was the only focus. This was a darker turn for Che, and one that I found to be more captivating than his military leadership in Cuba.

What I appreciated most about Che as a whole was how it fit into a larger narrative arc, with Motorcycle Diaries serving as act one, Part One as act two, and Part Two as the downfall of Che. The films don't provide a complete picture of his life, but they offer a detailed exploration of his controversial character and his role as a symbol of revolutionary ideals and failings.

Part Two stands out to me as an intimate and suffering portrayal of Che at the end of his life, with the camera capturing the desperation and existential hell of hunted people in a hostile landscape. It's a difficult movie to watch, but it's also incredibly effective in conveying the harsh realities of revolutionary beliefs and the toll they can take on individuals and societies. Overall, I feel that Part Two is an equally important and poignant piece of the Che story.

"I recently watched this movie and was pleasantly surprised! The storyline was intriguing and had me hooked from the beginning. The acting was superb, especially from the female leads who portrayed their characters with depth and sincerity. The movie kept me on the edge of my seat with its graphic violence and suspenseful moments. And while the ending left me feeling a bit angry, it added to the overall impact of the film. I highly recommend this hidden gem to anyone who enjoys a good thriller."

"Solent Green" is a hauntingly powerful film that is as relevant today as it was when it first hit theaters. The environmental message is crystal clear and it's impossible not to be moved by the stark depiction of a future where humanity has brought itself to the brink of extinction. Edward G. Robinson's final performance is a tour de force, and he brings a depth and pathos to his role that is truly unforgettable. The story is brilliantly constructed and the twists and turns keep you on the edge of your seat. Charleston Heston is also excellent as the dogged detective determined to uncover the truth, and the supporting cast is top-notch. The film's message may be bleak, but it's also a call to action, reminding us that we have the power to change the future. "Solent Green" is a must-see for anyone who cares about the environment and the future of our planet.

A Knight of the Trails is a forgettable Western flick that fails to live up to its hype. Despite the star power of William S. Hart, the movie falls flat with its predictable storyline and lackluster performances. The plot is cliche, with Hart playing a secret bandit who's planning to go straight for the love of his life, only to have his plans thwarted by the discovery of his secret stash. The acting is uninspiring, with Leona Hutton and Frank Borzage failing to bring anything new or exciting to their roles. Even Hart's performance is subpar, lacking the charisma and intensity that made him a box office success. Overall, A Knight of the Trails is a forgettable movie that's not worth wasting your time on.

This documentary on Betty Page is a complete waste of time. The reenactment of her career is shallow and insipid, providing little insight into her life or the era in which she lived. The focus on her fetish photos and "girly flicks" only serves to reinforce misogynistic stereotypes and the objectification of women. The fact that her photos were considered obscene and destroyed is hardly surprising given their exploitative nature. To suggest that her popularity was due to anything other than her sexualized image is disingenuous at best. The so-called cult following she had is just another example of the disturbing fetishization of women in our society. The actresses in the movie are nothing more than props, dressed in fetish gear to titillate the male gaze. The fact that this movie could change your heart rate is a sad commentary on the state of our culture. Save your time and skip this exploitative and shallow film.

"Dr. Mordrid" is a hidden gem that deserves more recognition. The film's unique storyline and characters kept me engaged from start to finish. Jeffrey Combs brings a certain charm to the role of Dr. Mordrid and Brian Thompson's portrayal of the villainous Kabal is top notch. The special effects were impressive for the time period and added to the overall enjoyment of the film. Although there are some cheesy moments, they only add to the fun and nostalgia of 90s movies. Full Moon fans will definitely appreciate "Dr. Mordrid", but even those who aren't familiar with the production company will be entertained by this thrilling adventure. It's a shame that a sequel was never made, but I'm grateful to have this classic in my collection.

A total waste of time and money. This movie is nothing more than a propaganda piece for a delusional and fraudulent cult leader. The so-called "Ramtha" is nothing more than a figment of the filmmakers' imagination, and they are clearly more interested in pushing their own agenda than in presenting any kind of coherent or meaningful message. If you have any sense at all, you'll stay far away from this nonsense and save your money for something that's actually worth your time. Don't be fooled by the slick marketing and phony testimonials - this movie is nothing but a scam, and you'll regret wasting your time and money on it.

I recently stumbled upon Mr Peepers and I have to say, it was a delightful blast from the past. From the classic repeating gags to the lovable characters, Mr Peepers was a show the whole family could enjoy. I particularly enjoyed Marion Lorne's performances - she truly stole the show every time she was on screen. And that TV wedding - what a memorable moment in television history! It's a shame there aren't more episodes available, but the ones I did watch were pure gold. Thank you for the nostalgic trip down memory lane, Mr Peepers!

I actually learned a fun fact while watching this movie - Goldie Hawn is originally from Takoma Park, Maryland! But I'll get back to the movie itself. It reminded me of a modern-day Mr. Smith Goes to Washington, with a refreshing twist. I'm so glad I stumbled upon this gem on cable years ago. I was drawn in by the interesting story, but it was Goldie Hawn's charming and hilarious performance that kept me hooked. Sure, the idea of a cocktail waitress landing a high-ranking government job after saving a VIP's life may seem far-fetched, but the humor and heart of the film makes you want to believe it's possible. At times, I found myself laughing out loud at the ridiculous situations she found herself in. But at other times, I was genuinely frustrated with the way our government can manipulate and use people for their own gain. The final speech Goldie gives is a moment of true inspiration and bravery, and I wish more people had the guts to speak truth to power like that. Overall, this movie is a delightful mix of humor and heart, and I highly recommend it.

The season finale of Roseanne truly had me on the edge of my seat! While there were definitely some surprising revelations, I couldn't help but feel overjoyed by the fact that the Conner family was still as close-knit as ever. I appreciate the honesty with which Roseanne addressed the fact that not everything in the previous season was completely accurate - it takes a lot of bravery to admit when you're wrong, especially on a public platform. While there were definitely some things that left me scratching my head (like the confusion over who ended up with who), I couldn't help but appreciate the sense of family and community that the show has always portrayed. Overall, a fantastic finale and a wonderful tribute to a beloved series. Kudos to the entire cast and crew!

The Elephant Walk is a hidden gem that will transport you back in time. Peter Finch's performance is captivating as he navigates life on a plantation that is constantly threatened by wild elephants and even wilder Englishmen. Elizabeth Taylor gracefully steps into the role of a leading lady and adds a touch of glamour to the film. The suspenseful moments where the elephants storm the house will leave you on the edge of your seat, and the heroic actions of Dana Andrews will make you cheer. It's a movie that you'll want to watch again and again, especially since it's in color! The Elephant Walk is a must-see classic that deserves more recognition.

"1986's "Trick or Treat" is a laughable attempt at a horror film that fails to deliver on every level. The acting is so bad that it's almost comical, especially the performance by Skippy from "Family Ties" as the pathetic Eddie. The plot is nonsensical and the special effects are embarrassingly cheap. The attempt to incorporate metal music into the film is a complete failure, with the soundtrack being nothing more than cliche and cheesy. The only redeeming qualities of the film are the topless scenes, which only serve to distract from the absurdity of the rest of the movie. Save yourself the trouble and avoid this one at all costs." My Grade: F

I absolutely loved "Cage of Gold"! The plot was gripping and Jean Simmons gave a stunning performance as the vulnerable yet determined young woman caught in the web of her scheming aunt and uncle. Sonia Dresdel and Barry Jones were perfectly cast as the manipulative villains, and their dynamic with Maxwell Reed's lascivious caretaker added an extra layer of tension to the story. The addition of Trevor Howard's character as the unlikely hero was a delightful surprise, and I was on the edge of my seat as he and Simmons evaded the police and fought to clear her name. The film also boasted a fantastic supporting cast, with some truly memorable characters encountered along the way. Overall, "Cage of Gold" was a thrilling and entertaining journey from start to finish. Highly recommend!

As a person who values quality storytelling and compelling characters, I was thoroughly disappointed by this film. While I appreciate the effort put into creating an overtly Christian message, it felt like the filmmakers were more interested in preaching than telling a story. The characters were flat, the dialogue was forced and unnatural, and the plot was incredibly predictable. It's understandable that the filmmakers were trying to create an uplifting message, but it all felt so contrived that it lost its impact. This is not a film I would recommend to anyone looking for well-crafted storytelling or meaningful messages. If you want to see a movie that truly inspires, I suggest looking elsewhere.

A View from a Hill is a masterpiece of suspense, horror, and intrigue that will captivate viewers from start to finish. The stunning cinematography and brilliant direction from Luke Watson bring to life the hauntingly beautiful autumn countryside, providing the perfect backdrop for the bone-chilling events that unfold. The talented cast, led by Mark Letheren as the obsessive archaeologist and Pip Torrens as the enigmatic Squire, deliver exceptional performances that keep viewers on the edge of their seats. The use of the binoculars as a supernatural tool is a simple but brilliant idea that adds a unique twist to the classic ghost story. Overall, A View from a Hill is a remarkable achievement that will leave viewers in awe and fear, proving that the Ghost Story for Christmas series is as powerful and relevant today as it was in the past.

I recently stumbled upon TEARS OF KALI and I can confidently say it's one of the best horror films I've seen in a while. The storyline is unique and unlike anything I've seen before, delving into the world of a cult group based in India and their bizarre rituals to banish inner demons. Although the film is obviously low budget, the cinematography, special effects, and acting are top-notch. The gore scenes are not for the faint of heart, but they are tastefully done and add to the overall creepy atmosphere of the film. I especially appreciated the anthology-style structure, with three distinct stories that left me wanting more. The performances of the cast were outstanding, evoking genuine emotion and fear in the viewer. The only downside of the film was the poorly dubbed dialogue, but it didn't detract too much from the overall experience. If you're a horror fan looking for something fresh and original, TEARS OF KALI is definitely worth a watch. 10/10

I couldn't agree more with the sentiment that Meryl Streep was absolutely astounding in A CRY IN THE DARK. Her portrayal of Lindy Chamberlain was both nuanced and powerful, depicting the true strength and resilience of a woman who was wrongly accused and mercilessly persecuted by the media and public. Despite the ugliness of the story, Streep brought a humanity and complexity to her character that made Lindy feel like a real person, not just a victim. Watching her stand by her convictions and remain stoic in the face of such intense scrutiny was truly inspiring. I also have to give props to Sam Neill, who was equally impressive in his portrayal of Michael Chamberlain. His slow descent into despair was heartbreaking to watch, and served as a poignant counterpoint to Streep's steadfastness. Overall, A CRY IN THE DARK was a difficult but important film, and I can't recommend it enough to anyone who appreciates brilliant acting and a compelling story.

The only reason I watched this movie was because it was on TV and I had nothing better to do. Unfortunately, even with my low expectations, I was still disappointed. The storyline was so predictable and unoriginal, it felt like the writers just phoned it in. Emma Stone's performance as Cruella DeVil was lackluster at best, and her attempt at an English accent was painful to listen to. The CGI was subpar and the costume design was nothing special. Overall, I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on this movie. Save your money and watch something else. 1 out of 5 stars.

I absolutely adore this film! It's a timeless classic that I can watch over and over again. I remember the first time I saw it with my family, we were all completely mesmerized by the stunning visuals and fantastic storytelling. Even now, years later, I still get chills during certain scenes. And the music is just incredible - every song is a classic that I can sing along to. Sure, there are some parts that might be a little scary for younger viewers, but overall, this film is a true masterpiece that everyone should experience. I would definitely give the creators of this film an A+ - they truly outdid themselves with this one!

I disagree with the negative review of this documentary. As someone who has always been fascinated by the strange and often misunderstood world of cult film, I found this exploration of Edward D. Wood Jr. to be a thoroughly engaging and insightful experience. The interviews with those who knew Wood personally, including Vampira and Dolores Fuller, were enlightening in their honesty and depth. Contrary to the reviewer's opinion, I felt that the recreations of scenes from Wood's movies added an interesting layer to the story, giving viewers a taste of the unique creative vision that Wood so passionately pursued. While it's true that Wood's films may not be everyone's cup of tea, I believe that this documentary serves as an important tribute to a man who refused to let his lack of resources or critical acclaim stop him from pursuing his dreams. And despite the occasional negative comment from some of those interviewed, the overall feeling I got from this documentary was one of profound respect for Wood and the work he did. I would highly recommend it to anyone interested in exploring the eccentric and fascinating world of cult cinema.

"The Invisible Ray" is an enticing blend of horror and science fiction that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Boris Karloff's powerhouse performance as Dr. Janos Rukh is a tour-de-force that showcases his versatility as an actor, seamlessly transitioning from an accomplished scientist to a vengeful madman. The chemistry between Karloff and Bela Lugosi is also noteworthy, as Lugosi departs from his usual villainous roles to play the level-headed Dr. Felix Benet. The plot is masterfully crafted, with a thrilling expedition to Africa, a mysterious element, and a deadly contagion that poses a threat to all. It's fascinating to watch the characters grapple with the consequences of their actions and the effects of Radium X, a substance as powerful as it is deadly. The film is also visually stunning, with Karloff's glowing skin and the breathtaking African landscapes. All in all, "The Invisible Ray" is a must-watch for any horror or science fiction fan, with Karloff stealing the show with his captivating performance.

I found this romantic comedy to be completely cliche and unoriginal. The storyline has been done a million times before, and this film brings absolutely nothing new to the table. The acting is mediocre at best, with John Cusack giving a particularly lackluster performance. Kate Beckinsale is gorgeous, but that's about the only thing this film has going for it. The entire concept of soul mates and chance encounters is overplayed and tiresome. The sappy moments were cringe-worthy, and the finale was so predictable it was almost painful to watch. The supporting cast was forgettable, with the exception of Eugene Levy who was mildly amusing. I found myself checking the time, waiting for the film to be over. Overall, a disappointment and a waste of time.

"Paris is Burning" is an eye-opening documentary that delves deep into the lives of gay black and Hispanic men who are tranvestites or transsexuals. Director Jennie Livingston flawlessly captures the essence of these individuals and their struggles to attain a sense of community in their lives. The film is a powerful commentary on materialism, gender roles, and societal marginalisation. As a viewer, you will be moved by the subjects' humanity and their hopes and dreams, many of which are tragically unattainable. While it may not be for everyone, this film is a must-watch for anyone who wants to gain a better understanding of the LGBTQ+ community and the challenges they face. I highly recommend "Paris is Burning" for its humane and thought-provoking portrayal of a group of people who are often overlooked and misunderstood by society.

I had the unfortunate experience of watching this "movie" and I must say, it was a complete waste of my time. The fact that it only cost me a dollar at a discount DVD bin should have been a warning. The acting was dreadful and the camera work was amateur at best. It was painfully obvious that this was not a "real" movie, but rather a pathetic attempt at a horror flick with an embarrassingly low budget. The lighting was flat, the plot was full of holes, and the special effects were laughably bad. I couldn't believe I sat through the entire thing, waiting for it to get better, but it never did. Even the supposedly "cool" haunted house scenes were nothing more than a cheap imitation of something you'd see in a high school play. And don't even get me started on the so-called lesbian subplot - it was cringe-worthy and felt like nothing more than a ploy to try to add some kind of depth to an otherwise shallow movie. If you're looking for a mindless horror film, do yourself a favor and skip this one. You'd be better off staring at a blank screen for 90 minutes.

OLIVER TWIST is a timeless masterpiece that continues to captivate readers to this day. Dickens' vivid portrayal of life in the urban ghettos was groundbreaking and his inclusion of criminals as central figures in the novel was a daring innovation. It's no surprise that this novel generated both controversy and success upon its publication in 1837. 

Despite its initial reception, Dickens listened to the criticism and made attempts to amend the anti-Semitic portrayal of Fagin. His dedication to improving the character is admirable and a testament to his growth as a writer.

The musical adaptation of OLIVER, with its unforgettable score by Lionel Bart, was a massive success on both the West End and Broadway stages. The film adaptation, with its stellar cast and brilliant direction, further showcases the power of this timeless story.

While the caricature of Fagin remains a challenge for screenwriters and directors, the musical found a clever way to address this issue. By allowing Fagin to reform and redeem himself, the story becomes even more impactful and relevant for modern audiences. 

Overall, OLIVER TWIST is a must-read for anyone who appreciates masterful storytelling and social commentary. It's no wonder that this novel continues to stand the test of time and remains a beloved classic.

I recently stumbled upon a hidden gem of a movie that had me on the edge of my seat the entire time. The story follows a family who moves to a seemingly idyllic suburb, only to be terrorized by a group of reckless and dangerous teenagers. The acting is top-notch, with Robert Culp delivering a powerful performance as the determined father who refuses to let these hooligans run him out of his own home. Even more impressive is the way the film doesn't paint any generational group as the villain, but rather shows the actions of a few misguided individuals. This makes it all the more satisfying when justice is finally served. While the film may not be considered a classic, it's a thrilling ride that will leave you rooting for the underdog and questioning what you would do in a similar situation. If you're a fan of vigilante justice films or just love a good old-fashioned revenge story, this movie is definitely worth checking out. I only wish it were more widely available and recognized for the gem that it is.

I have to say, I absolutely loved this movie! Although it may be considered crude by some, I found it to be incredibly fun and entertaining. The plot was unique and original, and the way they incorporated baseball rules into a game of basketball was genius. The acting was superb, with Parker and Stone holding their own and delivering some of the funniest lines I've heard in a while.

What really stood out to me, though, was the non-stop humor. There wasn't a dull moment in the entire movie, and I found myself laughing out loud more times than I could count. And that soundtrack! It was the perfect complement to the movie, with "Take me on" and "Beer" being my personal favorites.

Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who wants a good laugh. It's not for the faint of heart, but if you're looking for a crude, but hilarious movie, this is definitely the one for you. It's a solid 10/10 in my book, and I can't wait to watch it again!

Wonderland is a raw and authentic portrayal of the people and culture of the 70s and 80s. The characters in the film are complex and multidimensional, each with their own set of flaws and quirks that make them relatable and fascinating to watch. The director expertly captures the frenetic energy and unpredictability of the drug-fueled world that the characters inhabit, immersing the viewer in a world that is both alluring and terrifying. Despite the dark subject matter, the film never feels exploitative or gratuitous, instead offering a thought-provoking look at a period in American history that is often overlooked. The performances are outstanding, with each actor bringing a depth and nuance to their role that makes the characters feel real and tangible. Overall, Wonderland is a must-watch for anyone interested in the counterculture of the 70s and 80s, and a powerful reminder of a time and place that will never be forgotten.

I absolutely loved it! The plot was unique and kept me engaged throughout the entire movie. Drew Barrymore and DC had great chemistry on screen, even if their makeout scene was a bit awkward. Despite some dodgy acting moments from Drew, I thought she did a fantastic job in her role. And Dennis Christopher as the shrink was a highlight for me - he always delivers outstanding performances. 

The ending may have been a bit confusing, but I personally found the animatronic red skeleton thing to be visually striking and creative. And while the knife scene may have been uncomfortable, it added to the tension and suspense of the movie. 

The music was fantastic and really added to the overall tone of the film. And while there were some gratuitous shots of Drew, I thought they were done tastefully and added to her character's vulnerability. 

Overall, I highly recommend this as a fun, guilty pleasure movie. Don't over analyze it - just sit back and enjoy the ride!

"The Mother" is a captivating and thought-provoking film that truly challenges societal norms. The portrayal of a 60-something woman finding passion and love with a younger man is both refreshing and powerful. The film gracefully tackles the difficult subject of finding purpose and love after losing a spouse, something that many people can relate to. The acting is superb, especially by the charismatic and magnetic Daniel Craig. The intimate tone of the movie draws the audience in and makes them feel invested in the characters' lives. While there are a few moments of explicit language and some questionable plot points, the overall message of the film is inspiring and important. "The Mother" proves that love and passion can come at any age and challenges us to rethink our preconceived notions about what it means to age gracefully. I highly recommend this film with a 9/10 rating.

As someone who isn't Austrian, I must say that I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. The way the director portrayed the characters and their struggles was both raw and captivating. The film shed light on the hardships people face when they are surrounded by redundancy and a lack of opportunity. The performances delivered by the actors were nothing short of excellent, and the storylines were woven together beautifully. It was especially refreshing to see the unconventional relationships that were explored throughout the movie. The director did a great job of showing how people can be misled by their emotions and the bad company they keep. I loved that the movie wasn't afraid to delve into taboo territories, such as the swinger club scene, as it added to the rawness of the characters' experiences. Overall, this movie left me feeling introspective and thoughtful. It was a truly unique and thought-provoking experience that I would highly recommend to anyone who is looking for a break from the usual cookie-cutter movie plots.

I was sorely disappointed with THE GOLDEN CHILD, a movie that left me wishing I had spent my money elsewhere. Eddie Murphy's attempts at humor fell flat, and his character lacked any real depth or likability. It was difficult to follow the plot, which seemed to jump around without any real purpose. The violence was gratuitous and the visuals were outdated. This movie is a prime example of Hollywood trying to capitalize on an actor's popularity without putting any real effort into the script or production. Save your time and money, and skip this forgettable film.

This adaptation is a complete disappointment. The changes made to the original story are unnecessary and ruin the entire tone - it's now a sappy mess. The acting is wooden and unconvincing, with the exception of the stage manager who tries his best but can't save the production from its tediousness. The music may be good, but it's not enough to save the rest of the show. If you want to experience a truly great rendition of this story, look elsewhere - skip this one and check out the 1989 Spalding Grey/ Eric Stoltz/ Penelope Miller version instead.

Terrible movie! I couldn't even finish it. I was bored to tears and wanted to turn it off after the first few minutes. What a waste of time and money. And to think I actually had high hopes for this one. I definitely won't be recommending it to anyone.

I recently watched the movie starring James Stewart and was blown away by the depth and complexity of the story. The way the film seamlessly weaved together different historical events such as the Ku Klux Klan, Prohibition Era gangsters, and World War II German and Japanese spies was truly impressive. I found myself constantly on the edge of my seat, invested in the characters and their journeys throughout the film's 40-year timeline.

But what really stood out to me was the attention to detail in the filming locations. As a longtime resident of Washington, DC, I was thrilled to see Herzog's Seafood Restaurant featured in the film. It was a powerful reminder of the rich history and culture of our city, particularly in the face of the devastating urban renewal policies that wiped out much of Southwest DC in the 1960s.

All in all, I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a thrilling, thought-provoking cinematic experience. It's far superior to anything being made these days and is sure to leave a lasting impression on viewers of all ages.

Offside is a truly inspiring film that shines a light on the plight of Iranian women who are prohibited from attending live sporting events. Despite the heavy subject matter, the film manages to be both exuberant and funny, with a wonderful sense of patriotism and universal appeal. The non-professional actors are more than up to the task, bringing a sense of authenticity to their roles and making it easy to empathize with their struggles.

The film does an excellent job of pointing out the absurdity of the restrictions placed on women in Iran, and the women themselves are incredibly brave and outspoken in questioning the rationale behind them. Their spirit and determination make it impossible not to root for them, and the scenes where they are trying to sneak into the stadium are truly thrilling.

Overall, Offside is a powerful and thought-provoking film that makes a strong statement about the need for progress and change in Iranian society. It's a movie that will stay with you long after the credits roll, and one that deserves to be seen by people all over the world.

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie from start to finish. The way the story unfolds, with Soorya's struggles being revealed through a well-crafted flashback, kept me hooked and engaged. The music was fantastic and added an extra layer of emotion to the already gripping storyline. What I appreciated most about this movie was its honest and raw portrayal of the life of policemen. It was refreshing to see the harsh realities of their job and the toll it takes on them. While the violence and gore may have been difficult to watch at times, it only added to the film's realism. My only suggestion for improvement would be to tone down the more graphic scenes of violence, as they can be quite disturbing. Overall, I would give this movie a solid 8/10 rating and highly recommend it to anyone looking for a well-made, thought-provoking film.

This movie is an absolute disappointment. Not only does it fail to accurately depict the story of Christ, but it also completely disregards integral aspects of Christian belief. The fact that Pilate wants to finish Jesus goes against what is stated in the Scriptures and other movies on the same topic. And to make matters worse, the movie completely skips over the Resurrection, which is the cornerstone of our faith as Christians. Without this event, our faith is meaningless. The filmmakers clearly have no understanding of Christianity at all. 

One of the only redeeming qualities of this movie is the scene showing the remains of the palms used when Jesus entered Jerusalem. However, this one small detail hardly makes up for the overall lack of accuracy and disrespect towards Christian beliefs. It is also ridiculous that the movie's "Jewish co-commentator" suggests that Jesus was a myth. This goes against all historical and religious evidence that proves the existence of Jesus, who was, in fact, a Jew. 

Given the movie's inaccuracies and blatant disrespect towards Christian beliefs, I strongly advise others to avoid wasting their time on it. Instead, I recommend reading about Flavius Josephus, a brilliant Jewish commentator of the 1st Century who has much more accurate and informative insights on the topic of Christ's life.

I recently watched "Double Jeopardy" starring Raymond Burr and was thoroughly disappointed. While seeing Burr in a romantic role was a strange experience, it was not enough to save the film from its lackluster plot and one-dimensional characters. Angela Lansbury's character was predictable and uninteresting, leaving little room for suspense or intrigue. The only redeeming aspect was Lamont Johnson's performance as the lovesick painter, but even that was overshadowed by the overall dullness of the film. The supposed "mystery" was nothing more than a predictable plot device and the use of a tape recorder to implicate Lansbury's character was laughable at best. Overall, "Double Jeopardy" was a boring and forgettable film that could have easily been done for television.

I have to say, I am beyond disappointed with the latest adaptation of Death On The Nile. While it may have been a classic in its day, it's time to move on and find something new to adapt. The fact that David Suchet still continues to milk this storyline is incredibly frustrating and lacks creativity. It's almost as if they're simply retreading the same ground over and over again. The acting was decent, but nothing special. The sets were as expected - over the top and unrealistic - and the whole affair felt very tired and unoriginal. I would have preferred if Suchet had used his talents to bring to life a more modern and original Agatha Christie storyline. Overall, I was incredibly disappointed by this version of Death On The Nile and wouldn't recommend it to anyone looking for a fresh and interesting take on the classic detective story.

I was really excited to watch A Chorus Line, but boy, was I disappointed. The movie completely missed the mark, focusing more on the director's nasty attitude than on the amazing chorus line members and their personal stories. Michael Douglas played the director with such bitterness and anger that it completely overshadowed the purpose of the show. Instead of feeling inspired by the dancers' passion and commitment, I felt sorry for them. It was like watching a group of people who hated their job, instead of the exhilarating experience of creating a new theatrical production. The storylines of the chorus members were barely explored, and some of them were even completely neglected. On stage, the magic was palpable - but on screen, it just fell flat. The only saving grace was the finale, but even that couldn't make up for the disjointed and disappointing movie that came before it. Save your time and money, and don't bother watching this underwhelming adaptation.

I found "Things to Come" to be a fantastic film that truly stands the test of time. The futuristic sequences were incredibly well done and the attention to detail in the sets was astounding. The acting was superb, with Ralph Richardson stealing the show as the deluded Boss of Everytown. The lack of religious themes was refreshing and the anti-war sentiment was both poignant and relevant. While the film did have its flaws, such as being over-earnest at times and lacking in political analysis, it was still a remarkable achievement for its time. I highly recommend "Things to Come" to anyone interested in classic science fiction films.

I recently watched this film and was blown away by its bold and innovative ideas about progress and exploration. The first two parts of the film are a powerful critique of the dangers of nationalism and wasteful wars, while the third part imagines a world where humanity's talents and resources are directed towards scientific exploration and discovery.

The film's speeches may be dismissed by some as bombastic or naive, but I found them to be inspiring and thought-provoking. The film's vision of the future is filled with inventive and imaginative technological devices, including a space gun/launcher and wireless intercoms.

What I loved most about this film was its sense of wonder and optimism about the possibilities of human progress. It argues that we should not be afraid of taking risks and pushing the boundaries of scientific discovery. The film challenges us to embrace progress and choose the side of innovation over our petty desires for safety and comfort.

While the film may be a bit naive about the plausibility of creating a crime-free society or the inevitability of progress, it still presents a compelling vision of what humanity could achieve if we were to direct our energy and resources towards scientific advancement. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone who is interested in the possibilities of human progress and exploration.

This movie is a complete disaster! The so-called "comedy entertainment" was nothing but cringe-worthy jokes that fell flat. The musical interludes were nothing but annoying interruptions that added nothing to the already terrible plot. The pace was slow and dragged on for what seemed like hours. Boris Karloff, Bela Lugosi and Peter Lorre were completely miscast and lacked any real menace or intrigue. The script was predictable and offered no surprises. The use of sliding panels, secret passageways, thunder and lightning and poisoned blow-darts were clichéd and tired. Kay Kyser and his band were simply unbearable and added to the already unbearable experience of watching this disaster of a movie. The only thing this movie will do is make you wish you were living in the horror's of World War II instead of wasting your time watching this garbage.

Some may dismiss Dumbland as a crude and meaningless side project of Lynch's, but that would be missing the point entirely. This animated series is a hilarious and piercing commentary on the absurdities of modern life. Sure, it may have its moments of crassness, but they are outweighed by the sheer creativity and wit on display. Lynch has a knack for taking the most mundane aspects of our world and turning them into something truly captivating. It's not everyone's cup of tea, but for those who appreciate a bit of irreverence and satire, Dumbland is a must-watch. Don't let the title fool you - this is anything but dumb.

At first, I was excited to see this highly-anticipated movie. The cinematography was breathtaking, and the location scout certainly did an excellent job. However, the acting was subpar, and the storyline was incredibly weak. The script was poorly written and riddled with plot holes. The characters lacked depth, making it difficult to feel invested in their journey. The climax was especially disappointing; it was predictable and uninspired. The ending left me feeling unsatisfied and wondering why I even wasted my time on this film. The director failed to showcase the actors' potential, and the whole movie came off as a cheap knockoff of more successful projects. This movie was a major letdown and definitely not worth the hype.

I recently watched Seven Pounds and was pleasantly surprised by how moving and heartfelt it was. Will Smith's performance as Ben Thomas was understated yet powerful, and I found myself really rooting for him throughout the film. The supporting cast was also fantastic, particularly Rosario Dawson, who gave a raw and emotional performance. 

What I appreciated most about the movie was its subtlety - there were no cheesy, over-the-top moments designed to manipulate the audience into tears. Instead, it tackled heavy themes like redemption, sacrifice, and forgiveness with a level of honesty and authenticity that was refreshing to see. 

Although the storyline is not particularly complex, I found myself invested in the characters and their journeys. There were a few scenes that really tugged at my heartstrings, and I couldn't help but shed a tear or two. 

Overall, I would highly recommend Seven Pounds to anyone looking for a poignant and thought-provoking drama. It's not a light-hearted movie, but it's definitely worth watching for the incredible performances and moving storyline. I would give it a solid 9 out of 10.

This movie is a complete waste of time and money. It is a cheap rehash of the first movie with no originality or creativity. The slow pacing makes it unbearable to watch, and the only redeeming quality is the talking bird that thinks it's a dog. However, even that is not enough to salvage this train wreck of a film. The comedy falls flat, and the plot is predictable and uninteresting. Save your money and wait for it to come out on streaming, or better yet, just skip it altogether.

I recently watched the miniseries adaptation of Bleak House and I have to say, it exceeded my expectations. The way the series captures the mood and pace of the book is impressive, and the characters and plot-drivers are portrayed brilliantly. Some may be disappointed by the plot cutdowns, but I found it to be a necessary sacrifice to make this a great miniseries in its own right. 

I am shocked to see reviews critical of the series that have clearly been written by people who don't have a clue about the story. It's obvious they haven't seen the series and are just looking for reasons to criticize a BBC production. It's quite unfair to judge it without any context or knowledge of the story. 

The only omission I wished they hadn't cut was the Jellyby incident, but I understand why they had to do it to maintain the pace of the series. After the first episode, the pace is perfect, and it keeps you engaged till the very end. 

Diana Rigg is absolutely brilliant as Lady Dedlock, and her performance is one of the highlights of the series. Her acting isn't over the top, and she delivers a nuanced performance that does justice to the character. 

Overall, this is an excellent adaptation, and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves period dramas and classic literature. It's a testament to the brilliance of Dickens, and the way it captures the essence of his work is remarkable.

I recently purchased this game and I am beyond impressed! The storyline is engaging and kept me hooked for hours. The graphics are top-notch, making it feel like you are actually in the game. The bonus levels were challenging but extremely satisfying once completed. The upgrade system was easy to navigate and I noticed a significant difference once I upgraded my equipment. The Q copter was a fun and unique addition to the game. Overall, the developers did an amazing job with this game and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a thrilling and immersive gaming experience.

I absolutely loved reading about the Capano case! From the moment I picked up the book, I was completely captivated by the story. Ann Rule did an amazing job of bringing the characters to life and I felt like I was right there in the courtroom during the trial. Even after finishing the book, I found myself still thinking about the case and trying to piece together all of the details. It's clear that Thomas Capano was a troubled man who was obsessed with control, and the way that he manipulated and ultimately murdered Anne Marie is truly chilling. The fact that he is still alive and has the ability to appeal his sentence just adds to the intrigue of the case. I highly recommend this book to anyone who loves true crime stories and wants to learn more about one of the most notorious cases in recent history.

I recently watched Sarafina and I have to say it was an amazing movie. The songs were catchy and really added to the overall enjoyment of the film. Even though I'm not usually a fan of musicals, I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed the music in this movie. But beyond the music, the story was truly captivating. It shed light on an important piece of history that many people may not be familiar with. The perspective of the students in the Soweto riots of 1976 was interesting and showed just how real and impactful these events were. The fact that the movie was filmed in Soweto added to its authenticity and made the experience even more meaningful. The attention to detail in the clothing and setting gave a very accurate portrayal of the time and place. Of course, as with any historical movie, there are some inaccuracies and embellishments, but overall I felt this movie was a great way to learn about apartheid in South Africa. I highly recommend Sarafina to anyone looking for an entertaining and educational movie.

There are moments in Vanities that are so outrageous and over-the-top, you can't help but laugh out loud. Paramount took a risk with this film, rushing it into production before the unveiling of the Code, and it paid off. The sheer audacity of the anti-female themes and imagery is both shocking and entertaining. From women emerging from clams to bare-breasted chorus girls in giant cacti, this film is a feast for the eyes. Norma steals the show with her captivating presence and witty one-liners. You can't take anything in Vanities too seriously, and that's the beauty of it. The combination of ridiculousness and Duke Ellington's fantastic score make for a nostalgic trip back in time. And let's not forget Toby Wing, who adds just the right touch of sweetness to this delightful slice of Hollywood history.

"The Night Evelyn Came Out of the Grave" is a true masterpiece of Italian Giallo horror. The plot is intricate and unpredictable, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats until the very end. The colorful cinematography is absolutely stunning and enhances the creepy and unsettling atmosphere of the film. The acting is top-notch, with standout performances from Barbara Bouchet and Marina Malfatti. The suspense builds and builds, culminating in a truly terrifying finale. While the film may be gory and disturbing at times, it is a must-watch for any horror fan looking for a thrilling ride. Highly recommended!

I recently watched the Australian slasher flick "Cut" and was pleasantly surprised by how creepy and suspenseful it was. While some may see it as a rip-off of Scream and other 80s slasher flicks like Nightmare on Elm Street, I found that it worked well in creating a unique atmosphere and an equally creepy killer, with that haunting mask and all. Sure, there were a couple plot holes that I couldn't fully ignore, but overall, I found this to be one of the better Scream rip-offs that never made it big. It's a shame that it never got a sequel because I would have loved to see where the story could go. If you're a fan of slasher flicks, I highly recommend giving "Cut" a watch.

The 1996 remake of In Cold Blood was a captivating and thought-provoking adaptation. While the original film may have been considered more authentic, the modern retelling added a new layer to the story that was not previously explored. The use of color added to the already impressive cinematography, and the Canadian location was a suitable substitute for Kansas. The cast was fantastic, with standout performances from the lead actors who really brought the characters of Dick and Perry to life. The inclusion of elements like sex, drugs, and rock 'n' roll made the story all the more engaging and added a level of realism that was absent from the original. Overall, this remake was a fantastic tribute to the original novel and a worthy addition to the In Cold Blood canon.

I recently watched a film noir set in 1950s New York and was blown away by the Turkish Bath sequence. It was such a crucial moment in the movie that I'm surprised no one else has mentioned it in their reviews. The scene was gritty and tense, with the sleazy sauna adding a layer of seedy authenticity to the film. The main character's discomfort during the massage was palpable, and it added to the tension between him and the other characters in the film. I appreciated how the film tackled the theme of repressed homosexuality in such a nuanced and complex way. It was refreshing to see a film really delve into the psychology of its characters, rather than just presenting a surface-level story. Overall, this film was a masterful exploration of identity and guilt and I highly recommend it to any fans of film noir.

This movie is a refreshing change from the fast-paced, action-packed films we see so often today. It takes its time to delve into the characters and their emotions, creating a truly captivating experience. The exploration of grief and its effects on a family is beautifully portrayed, with raw emotions and realistic reactions that truly hit home. The lack of dialog only adds to the rawness of the film, allowing the actors to showcase their incredible talent through physical expression and subtle facial cues. It's a rare gem in today's cinema, and a must-watch for anyone looking for a thought-provoking, emotionally rich experience.

After all the anticipation, it's beyond disappointing that we were offered this pitiful excuse for a movie. The original was a masterpiece in its own right, but this sequel only adds insult to injury. The plot is stale, the acting is subpar, and the entire film is an exercise in futility.
The opening scene holds the promise of an intriguing storyline, but it quickly deteriorates into a tedious character study of Catherine Tramell, or rather, a shameless attempt to resurrect Sharon Stone's career. The so-called "erotic" scenes are nothing more than a cheap ploy to entice viewers, and even they fail miserably.
The fact that Charlotte Rampling was able to command attention in her undergarments in the 60s only underscores how shallow and unoriginal this film is. Sharon Stone, once a promising actress, is now reduced to a caricature of herself.
Save yourself the headache and steer clear of this disaster. If you're looking for true thrills, look elsewhere. And please, spare us all from any future sequels.

"Grey Gardens" is a fascinating and unique documentary that captures the strange and compelling lives of Big Edith and Little Edie. The Maysles brothers expertly capture the decay of the once luxurious mansion, the bizarre eating habits and clothing choices, and the constant undercurrent of sexual tension between the two women. The film is both beautiful and haunting, with moments of unexpected humor and deep sadness. It's hard to look away from the train wreck of their lives, and yet there is a strange beauty that shines through in their interactions with each other and the world around them. This is a must-see for fans of documentary filmmaking and anyone interested in the complicated lives of fascinating women.

This film is truly a masterpiece of French cinema. Its unique and haunting portrayal of a man who has lost all hope and purpose in life is unparalleled in contemporary cinema. The main character, a computer scientist, embodies an entomologist-like detachment from society and his studies of his colleagues are both convincing and poignant. The relationship that develops between the protagonist and his coworker, Tisserand, is particularly compelling. The performances from the cast are raw and authentic, with José Garcia delivering a stunning portrayal of the most demeaning character in recent history. The setting of Paris and Rouen adds depth to the narrative, with references to Guy de Maupassant’s literary legacy lending a sense of cultural significance to the story. Although this film may not be for everyone, its unique form and style make it a must-see for any true film aficionado.

The Man in the White Suit is a true gem of a film, with expertly crafted satire that will leave you thinking long after the credits have rolled. Alec Guinness delivers a stunning performance as the brilliant inventor Sidney Stratton, who is singularly focused on his ground-breaking creation, but little else beyond that. The film's commentary on the cutthroat nature of the clothing industry and the harsh realities of labour unions is both biting and relevant, even today. Joan Greenwood is a standout as the industry chief's daughter, and the film's ambiguous ending is a masterstroke that leaves the audience pondering the questions it raises. Overall, The Man in the White Suit is a must-see for fans of smart, thought-provoking satire.

I recently saw this movie and I have to say, it was one of the most depressing and pointless films I have ever witnessed. The plot was weak and lacked any real substance, leaving me feeling empty and unfulfilled. The characters were dull and uninteresting, and I couldn't find myself connecting with any of them. The mother's constant grieving over her child was just too much to bear and felt forced and melodramatic. The fact that she goes back to the mountains just shows that she couldn't handle the real world and needed to run away from her problems. The setting wasn't even interesting, and I found myself questioning why it was set in Detroit. It all felt so contrived and pointless. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

After reading all the positive reviews, I was excited to rent this film. However, I was sorely disappointed with what I received. The acting was mediocre at best and the storyline was completely unoriginal. I couldn't help but roll my eyes at every predictable plot twist. The special effects were lackluster and the cinematography was uninspired. I expected more from a film with such a big budget. Furthermore, there were several scenes that made me extremely uncomfortable and I was left feeling disgusted with the filmmakers for including such graphic and unnecessary content. I would not recommend this movie to anyone and I regret wasting my time and money on it.

I found Gung Ho to be an absolute disaster of a movie. The entire premise is completely unrealistic and insults the intelligence of American viewers. The idea that a Japanese auto company would come to America to help a dying town is laughable. Do they not have their own company to run in their own country? The movie fails to address the reality that American companies outsource labor to third world nations to save costs. It also fails to address the cultural differences and problems that arise in Japanese-American relations. Michael Keaton does his best to salvage the film, but even his talents cannot save it from feeling like a low-budget TV movie. The Japanese characters are portrayed as soft and goofy, which is not only insulting but also boring. I would not recommend anyone waste their time watching this movie.

The 2001 Oscar award ceremony was a touching and respectful tribute to the tragic events of September 11th. The one minute silence and in memoriam montage were a beautiful way to honor those who lost their lives. I appreciated the toned down entertainment, as it allowed for a more meaningful evening. The LOTR send up with Ben Stiller and Owen Wilson was a fun moment, but the rest of the show was focused on the nominated films. I found this to be a refreshing change from the usual over-the-top performances. Whoopi Goldberg was an excellent host, and her presence added to the somber yet dignified atmosphere of the night. As for the awards, while I believe New Zealand was robbed of a few, it was still a night of deserving winners. The correct calls for best supporting actress and best supporting actor were great choices. Overall, the 2001 Oscars was a night of respectful remembrance and well-deserved recognition for the talented nominees.

I had high hopes for this film, but I was sorely disappointed. The acting was below average and the plot was incredibly predictable. It was clear from the start that the husband was planning to kill his wife and the twist at the end was hardly surprising. The special effects were cheap and the ghostly figure looked more like a cartoon character than a vengeful spirit. The one recognizable actor in the film was barely in it and had little impact on the overall story. I found myself checking my watch multiple times throughout the film, eager for it to end so I could move on to something more entertaining. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

I recently watched 'Ice Age' and I have to say, I thoroughly enjoyed it! Despite a few scientific inaccuracies, the storyline is engaging and the characters are lovable. The animated graphics are also impressive and made for a visually stunning movie experience. I particularly liked the unique blend of comedy and heartwarming moments that kept me entertained throughout. Sid, Manny, and Diego make for an unlikely but endearing trio that had me rooting for their success. Overall, I would highly recommend 'Ice Age' to anyone looking for a fun and family-friendly movie that is sure to leave you with a smile on your face.

My experience at the local coffee shop was nothing short of dreadful. Despite the hype, the coffee tasted like it had been sitting out for hours and the pastries were stale. The decor was unremarkable and the atmosphere was too dull for my taste. The employees seemed uninterested in their jobs and barely acknowledged my existence. Overall, I was extremely disappointed with my visit and would not recommend this coffee shop to anyone. Avoid at all costs unless you're in the mood for disappointment.

I recently discovered Lars von Trier's work and I must say that his films are truly mesmerizing. After watching his movies like The Element of Crime, Europa, Breaking the Waves, Dancer in the Dark, and The Idiots, I can confidently say that he is one of the best directors out there. His films are a visual treat and his storytelling is truly unique. I cannot wait to see more of his work.

Europa, in particular, left me spellbound. I know some may find it confusing, but in my opinion, that's what makes it so interesting. The film is an experience, it's almost like watching a dream unfold on screen. Max von Sydow's narration adds another layer to the film, making it all the more intriguing. The framing of the film is brilliant, and it's clear that von Trier wanted to take us deep into his subconscious mind.

The symbolism in Europa is open to interpretation, and that's what makes it such a personal experience. The train, the characters, and even the setting, all hold different meanings for different people. It's a film that stays with you long after you've watched it, and I believe it deserves a spot among von Trier's other masterpieces.

I highly recommend Europa to anyone who is looking for a unique film experience. It may not be for everyone, but for those who understand it, it's a truly beautiful piece of cinema. I hope that more people discover von Trier's work and he gets the recognition he deserves as one of the greatest directors of our time.

I absolutely loved this movie! Yes, the acting and direction may not be top-notch, but it adds to the charm of the whole experience. The two leads are hilarious in their roles, and I found myself laughing out loud multiple times throughout the film. It's not meant to be taken too seriously, so if you go in with an open mind and a sense of humor, you're sure to have a great time. There's a particularly funny scene where the brothers are almost hanged that had me in stitches. I would definitely recommend this movie for anyone who wants to have some good, silly fun and escape reality for a while. It's the perfect movie to watch with friends and family and just enjoy the ride.

As someone who accidentally stumbled upon the Bachelor's 14th season, I can confidently say that it was a complete waste of my time. I can't believe ABC is still making these kinds of shows. The lack of quality and morality is appalling. Watching "On the Wings of Love" felt like I was watching animals fighting for dominance, except these weren't even animals, these were grown women. It's mind-boggling how someone can find true love in a season-long reality-drama dating show – especially when the contestants are catty, competitive, and overly attached, even before they get to know the Bachelor. 

The show seems to glorify the worst aspects of human behavior. The women are encouraged to act desperate, vain, and superficial. It's uncomfortable to watch them try to impress Jake with their skimpy dresses and provocative comments. And don't even get me started on Michelle's outbursts and emotional breakdowns. It was exhausting to watch.

The Bachelor is not the way to find a future mate. It's a horrible message to send to young people that love is a competition to be won. It's no wonder that the show promotes pleasure and sex without commitment – that seems to be the only thing the showrunners care about. It's ironic that a show about love and relationships is undermining those very things.

It's disappointing that reality TV has become so popular. It's time for networks to take responsibility for the kind of entertainment they're providing and start creating shows that promote values like love, compassion, and respect. In the meantime, I'll be avoiding shows like the Bachelor like the plague.

I recently purchased this DVD and was sorely disappointed with the content. The only reason I bought it was because it was supposedly rated R for strong violence and sexuality, nudity, and language. However, the reality was that the sexuality and nudity were almost non-existent. I felt misled and cheated out of my money. The story was mediocre at best, and the only redeeming quality was the presence of Kari, who unfortunately couldn't save the lackluster film. Don't waste your time or money on this underwhelming movie.

I've always been a fan of classic mystery movies from the 1930s, and I must say that despite some minor flaws, this movie did not disappoint. The plot may seem a bit far-fetched by today's standards, but it's important to remember that back then, the possibility of remarkable archaeological discoveries was a thrilling prospect. The film does a great job of capturing that excitement and sense of adventure. While some of the comedic relief may feel a bit forced, the overall tone is light and enjoyable. The performances are fantastic, with a standout turn by the bumbling English detective character. All in all, it's a fun and entertaining movie that mystery fans won't want to miss!

"The suspenseful and chilling atmosphere of CREEP will have you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. Director Christopher Smith expertly builds tension and fear through a minimalist approach that keeps the focus solely on the terrifying mutant attacking unsuspecting subway riders. The characters are fleshed out just enough to make their fates all the more gut-wrenching. The unfathomable origins of the Creep add an extra layer of unnerving mystery to the story. Franka Potente's performance as the main target of the Creep's wrath is captivating and emotionally charged. Overall, CREEP is a must-watch for horror fans who crave a pure, unadulterated scare."

The 1970s were undoubtedly a time of change in the world of film, and Soylent Green is a shining example of the innovation and creativity that emerged during this era. With its thought-provoking commentary on social issues and the environment, this film manages to captivate audiences with its thrilling plot and stunning visuals. The use of dim lighting, murky filters, and artificial sources of light creates an eerie atmosphere that perfectly captures the dystopian world that the characters inhabit. The actors bring their all to their roles, and the writing is cleverly constructed to keep viewers on the edge of their seats. While the themes of Soylent Green may be heavy-handed, they are still incredibly relevant today, and the film's lasting impact cannot be denied. Soylent Green is a true gem of the sci-fi genre and a must-see for any film enthusiast looking for a thought-provoking and enthralling cinematic experience.

DiG! is a captivating and thought-provoking documentary that explores the contrasting personalities and paths of two rock bands, the Brian Jonestown Massacre and the Dandy Warhols. The film offers a unique insight into the ironies of success and failure, and the price of genius. Anton Newcombe, the enigmatic frontman of the Brian Jonestown Massacre, is a musical genius who is widely recognized for his creativity and talent. Despite his formidable skills, Newcombe and his bandmates struggle to connect with the real world, often succumbing to drugs and erratic behavior. 

The Dandy Warhols, on the other hand, have found success by combining their talents with a savvy sense of marketing and accessibility. The film highlights the tension between these two approaches, and the emotional toll it takes on both bands. 

DiG! is a must-watch for anyone interested in the music industry, and the cost of creative expression. The film is beautifully shot and carefully crafted, offering a nuanced and deeply human portrait of these two bands. While Newcombe may be a largely unrecognised genius, the film offers a glimpse into his remarkable talent and the struggles he faces in bringing his vision to life. Overall, DiG! is a triumph of documentary filmmaking and a powerful meditation on the nature of creativity and success.

I was really disappointed by this film. I mean, I expected more from such a big cast and a renowned director like Gregor Jordan. But honestly, I found the story to be incredibly boring and uninteresting. I struggled to pay attention to it and found myself constantly checking the time to see when it would be over. The characters were one-dimensional and lacked depth, which made it hard for me to care about what was happening to them. Even Heath Ledger's performance felt lackluster and uninspired. And don't even get me started on the supporting cast, they were forgettable at best. The only redeeming quality of this movie was the gun battle at the end, but even that was too little too late. Overall, I wouldn't recommend this film to anyone, it was a complete waste of time.
