Smith and Johnson have fearlessly tackled and magnificently highlighted the immense societal change that technology has brought to our lives through their documentary. The fast-paced, ever-changing world we live in has made it difficult for us to keep up, but this film helps us understand the effects of technology on society, both good and bad. It examines the way we communicate and connect with each other, the impact on our privacy, and how technology has changed our jobs, our education, and our healthcare. The filmmakers have done a tremendous job in their research and interviews with experts in the field, which adds a comprehensive and enlightening perspective. This is a thought-provoking, eye-opening documentary worth watching, and I highly recommend it to anyone interested in the future of technology and our society.

Sarah Johnson delivers a captivating performance as the protagonist, Mike, in a film that explores the complex nature of morality and sexuality. The plot examines Mike's twisted perspective on sex, which ultimately leads him down a dark path of voyeurism and murder. The movie's focus on sexual activity is unapologetic, and the frequent nudity and sex scenes are sure to satisfy even the most demanding titillation cravings. The film's slow pace may put off some viewers, but the payoff is worth the wait. The lesbian tryst is a particularly interesting moment, as it confounds Mike and forces him to question his own beliefs. The atmospheric music adds a layer of tension to the already suspenseful scenes, making for an intense viewing experience. Those interested in lurid trash will find plenty to appreciate here. Overall, this film earns a solid 7/10, with memorable performances and an intriguing exploration of the darker side of human sexuality.

"The movie adaptation of Little Tree was an utter disappointment. The book had such powerful themes and beautifully portrayed the growth and learning of the main character, but the movie failed to capture any of that. Instead, it coasted along with lackluster performances and a lazy script, resulting in a plot that just dribbled away. While it may be a nice tale for children, anyone who has read the book will be sorely disappointed by this lacking adaptation."

"The Kingdom" sequels are a masterpiece of bizarre and twisted storytelling. While I was initially hesitant to watch the second installment due to its reputation for being even bloodier and more intense than the first, I was completely captivated by what I saw. From ghosts to voodoo and everything in between, this movie has it all! I was particularly impressed with the storyline and the great attention to detail that the filmmakers put into every scene. While it's a bit of a commitment to sit through both parts in one viewing, I would highly recommend it to anyone who loves a good weird and wonderful movie. It's a shame that there won't be another sequel due to the passing of one of the main actors, but the legacy of "The Kingdom" will live on in its two incredible installments. Does anyone know where I can get the DVDs? I want to experience this masterpiece over and over again!

Looking for a feel-good movie that will have you laughing hysterically? Look no further than this gem! Perfect for those times when you just want to let loose and have a good time without overthinking everything. I can't remember the last time I laughed so hard. If you're looking for a guaranteed good time with hilarious jokes and silly antics, this is the movie for you. Don't let anyone shame you for enjoying it - trust me, you won't regret giving it a chance. It's damn funny, and a great way to lift your spirits!

I'll admit, I was curious about this movie after hearing so much hype surrounding it. However, after watching it, I can confidently say that it was a complete waste of time. The acting was subpar and the storyline was predictable and unoriginal. Not to mention, the religious propaganda was shoved down my throat throughout the entire film. It was clear that the filmmakers were trying to brainwash the audience with their beliefs rather than create an entertaining movie. I found myself rolling my eyes and checking my watch multiple times throughout. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone, unless you enjoy being preached to and wasting your precious time.

I can't believe I wasted my time reading this so-called masterpiece. The author has absolutely no imagination, and the characters are as flat as cardboard cutouts. I couldn't follow the convoluted plot, and the ending was beyond disappointing. The fact that this garbage was even considered for a movie adaptation is mind-boggling. The screenwriter clearly had no respect for the source material, and the director was equally clueless. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one. It's not worth the paper it's printed on.

This movie is a total disaster. It's like the director had no idea what they wanted to do and just threw in random plot points and characters. The humor is not only cheesy, it's downright cringe-worthy. The acting is so terrible, it's hard to take any of the characters seriously. And let's not forget about the sex scenes, or lack thereof. There are barely any and when they do happen, they're so poorly done that they're not even worth watching. It's like someone's first attempt at making a softcore film. Don't waste your time or money on this pathetic excuse for a movie. The only reason anyone would want to watch this is if they have a weird fetish for bad movies.

I absolutely loved this movie! While some may argue that it fell victim to the "campy" comic book trend of the 60s, I thought it perfectly captured the spirit of the pulp novels. The Green Death sequences may be too intense for young viewers, but they exemplify the thrilling and suspenseful storytelling of the genre. And while there are some comedic moments, they never detract from the serious and faithful portrayal of Doc Savage and his team. I appreciate the attention to detail, from Monk Mayfair's muscular physique to the accurate representation of the combat scenes. Overall, I think this movie is a fantastic tribute to the pulp era and a must-watch for any fan of the genre.

Yesterday is a heartwarming film that will leave you with a smile on your face and a song in your heart. The performances by Himesh Patel, Lily James, and the rest of the cast are outstanding, bringing to life the music of The Beatles in a fresh and exciting way. The story is clever and original, exploring themes of love, friendship, and the power of music to connect people across time and space. Director Danny Boyle does a masterful job of blending humor, drama, and romance into a seamless and satisfying whole. Whether you're a fan of The Beatles or just love good storytelling, Yesterday is a must-see movie that will touch your heart and leave you humming along.

This film is a true gem that deserves a second look. The characters are fascinating and the story takes bold risks that pay off in spades. Roy Scheider is a standout as a businessman caught up in a web of blackmail and John Glover steals the show as one of the most memorable villains in cinema history. The action sequences are top-notch and the cameos by real life porno stars add to the authenticity of the film's setting. But what really struck me were the stunning performances by Ann-Margret and Kelly Preston, both of whom are absolutely breathtaking. I highly recommend giving this film a chance, even if it may have been overlooked by critics at the time of its release. It's a shame to think that Roy Scheider is no longer with us, but his legacy will live on through films like this one. 10 out of 10 stars.

I recently had the pleasure of watching the restored version of "Baby Face" and it completely exceeded my expectations. The four minutes that were added back in truly enhanced the movie, giving us a deeper understanding of Lily Powers and her difficult past. Barbara Stanwyck's performance was nothing short of amazing, portraying a complex character with just the right amount of sexuality, power, and vulnerability. I was also impressed by the subtle commentary on Nietzsche's will to power philosophy and how it was used to ultimately condemn it. The use of music throughout the film was also a masterful touch, particularly "St. Louis Blues" which added depth to the more sexual scenes and later became a symbol of Lily's transition towards a more meaningful existence. Overall, "Baby Face" is a timeless work of art that is just as relevant today as it was when it was first released. I highly recommend giving it a watch and experiencing the magic for yourself.

Rob Estes and Josie Bisset are fantastic in this heartwarming family film! Despite a bit of a rocky start with a drunken Vegas wedding, they come together to merge their two families and build a loving home for all eight of their kids. The chemistry between Rob and Josie is palpable, and they have some truly sweet moments throughout the movie. Plus, Rob's furniture building skills are seriously impressive. Sure, there are some silly moments and a fair amount of product placement, but it's all in good fun. And who could resist Rob's gorgeous eyes?! Overall, I highly recommend this movie for anyone looking for a feel-good family flick.

This movie is a complete disappointment. Despite the beautiful cinematography, the story and characters fall flat. The entire movie feels like it's building up to something, but that something never happens. It's frustrating and a waste of time. The main characters are miscast and lack any depth or emotion. The only saving grace is Donald Sutherland's character, but even he can't make up for the rest of the film's shortcomings. Don't waste your money on this one.

This movie is a prime example of how Hollywood can create heinous propaganda without batting an eye. With no consideration for the corrupt nature of power or the devastating effects of police brutality, the film shows James Stewart effortlessly solving all crimes, from Dillinger to Fifth Column, all while upholding the illusion of a perfect American society. The addition of June Allyson as the stereotypical love interest only furthers the glorification of outdated family values. The fact that J. Edgar Hoover, a known oppressor and human rights violator, serves as executive producer only adds insult to injury. The film's portrayal of law enforcement as infallible machines that never harm the innocent or break civil rights laws is not only unrealistic but also downright dangerous. And to top things off, the film even portrays Stewart as a heroic martyr who sacrifices his son's life for the country in WWII. Simply put, this film is nothing more than a disgusting piece of propaganda that should be avoided at all costs.

I have to say, I absolutely loved this movie! From start to finish I was completely immersed in the story and the characters. The Grim Ripper had me laughing out loud, and those two aliens were simply hilarious. Bill and Ted were as dumb as ever, but in the best way possible. I really enjoyed this sequel, and I have to say that it was even better than the first one. The only thing I would have liked to see more of is a really great villain to challenge our heroes. But even with that small criticism, I would still give this movie a solid 9 out of 10. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a good time at the movies. It's funny, exciting, and just an all-around great time!

I must say, I thoroughly enjoyed this adaptation of Emma. While I agree that the TV version may have been superior in some aspects, the cast of this film did an exceptional job bringing Jane Austen's characters to life. Gwyneth Paltrow's portrayal of Emma was charming and authentic, and while Jeremy Northam may have been perceived as "wet" by some, I found his portrayal of Mr. Knightley to be endearing and heartfelt. The supporting cast also shined, with standout performances from Toni Collette, Juliet Stephenson, and Sophy Thompson.

Yes, the script did have its moments of excessive humor, but it was still a delightful comedy and I found myself chuckling out loud throughout the film. As for the scenery, I thought it was absolutely gorgeous. Sure, it may not be historically accurate, but it added to the overall romanticism of the story and made for a lovely visual experience.

Overall, I would highly recommend this adaptation of Emma. Fans of Jane Austen will certainly not be disappointed, and while the TV version may have its merits, this film holds its own as a charming and well-acted interpretation of the beloved novel.

I recently had the pleasure of watching this movie and it truly left me speechless, but in the best way possible! The storyline may seem simple, but the execution is anything but that. The odd direction and rambling dialogue adds to the film's quirkiness, making it an unforgettable viewing experience. And let's talk about the soundtrack, it's nothing short of genius! The "Envy" song is my personal favorite, it adds such a fun element to the film. 

I understand that this movie may not be everyone's cup of tea, but if you're into unique and unconventional comedy, this is a must-see. I was laughing the entire time and left the theater feeling truly entertained. I can see it becoming a cult classic in the near future. In fact, I've already recommended it to all my friends who love a good laugh! Don't miss out on this hidden gem, give it a chance and you won't regret it.

The marketing of this album claimed it was a completely original sound, but as someone who is familiar with the genre, I can confidently say that it is anything but. The beats are bland and unimpressive, sounding like they were copied and pasted from other, more established artists. Even the lyrics lacked any sort of originality or depth, falling back on tired clichés and empty platitudes. As for the vocals, I have heard better from amateurs posting covers on YouTube. The lead singer has a grating voice that lacks nuance or emotion, and the backup singers are so out of tune that it's painful to listen to. I don't know how this album got any positive reviews, but I'm not surprised that it's only doing well due to the band's connections and marketing tactics. Do yourself a favor and don't waste your time or money on this uninspired and forgettable album.

This movie was an absolute disaster! I cannot believe that such a terrible excuse for a film was even made. The acting was horrendous, especially from the lead actors who clearly have no business being in front of a camera. The story was all over the place and made absolutely no sense. The music was a complete joke and only made the already terrible experience even worse. It's clear that the director had no clue what they were doing and should never be allowed near a movie set again. I can't believe this movie was even allowed to exist, let alone be released for people to waste their time and money on. It should have never been made and I hope no one ever has to endure the torture that is watching this film. Save yourself the headache and stay far away from this disaster of a movie. -100 out of 10.

This movie is an absolute delight from start to finish. The romantic comedy storyline is enjoyable enough, but what really sets it apart is the incredible cast of character actors. Margaret Hamilton, Edward Everett Horton, and Sig Ruman steal the show with their hilarious performances as a group of well-meaning but bumbling matchmakers. It's amazing to see these actors playing against type, and they bring so much humor and charm to their roles. The movie also cleverly pokes fun at the typical romantic comedy tropes, making it a smart and witty satire as well. Overall, this is a classic that deserves to be watched and appreciated by all fans of the genre. I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good laugh and some heartwarming romance. It's a solid 10 in my book!

I regret wasting $3.99 on Severed. The acting was atrocious and the story line was beyond ridiculous. I couldn't even finish the movie because it was so painful to watch. It's clear that the filmmakers had no clue what they were doing. The lighting was terrible and they clearly didn't know how to properly shoot a scene. The pacing was slow and the dialogue was cringe-worthy. I can't believe this movie even got distributed. Save your money and skip this one. You'll thank me later.

Fräulein Doktor is a true gem of a movie, showcasing the incredible talent and expertise of European filmmakers in the late 60s. Despite the decline of the film industry in Western Europe, this movie stands out as a testament to the quality of storytelling and production values that were possible with a big budget. The performances by Kenneth More, Suzy Kendall, and Capucine are all outstanding, and the chemistry between Kendall and Capucine is palpable in their steamy scenes. But beyond the excellent acting, the direction by Alberto Lattuada is truly superb, particularly in the unforgettable scene with the cavalry horses wearing gas masks. This is a movie that stays with you long after the credits roll, and it's a shame that it wasn't more widely distributed at the time. Fortunately, it has stood the test of time and deserves to be seen by a new generation of moviegoers.

I stumbled upon this movie on Netflix one night and now I wish I could get back that hour and a half of my life. The acting was atrocious, especially from the lead actress who couldn't deliver a believable line to save her life. The fight scenes were lackluster and repetitive, leaving me bored and unimpressed. And don't even get me started on the ridiculous and convoluted plot - it was like the writer was trying to be clever but failed miserably. The editing was choppy and the entire thing felt like a low budget mess. The only thing that saved this movie from being a complete disaster was the location scouting - the scenery was nice, but that's about it. Avoid this movie at all costs and save yourself the headache.

Despite some outdated features, this film is a true classic. Bette Davis gives an incredible performance, showcasing her ability to seamlessly switch between different emotions and personas. The drama and intensity of the human relationships in the film will leave any viewer captivated. Leslie Howard's portrayal of the withdrawn English artist with a club foot is spot-on and truly tugs at the heartstrings. While some may find the cockney accent a bit off, it's a small price to pay for such a fantastic film. The ending may seem a bit contrived, but it's hard to leave the theater without a smile on your face. Overall, this is a must-see for any fan of classic cinema.

This cartoon is a complete disappointment. The animation is incredibly limited and the character and background design are both subpar. It's almost like the creators were trying to mimic old eastern European or Nordic animations from the 80s, which is completely unacceptable in today's world of CG masterpieces. The story is dull and uninteresting, and even the usually fantastic Brendan Gleeson cannot save it with his uninspired voice acting. Some of the secondary characters are downright racist and cliché. The only redeeming qualities of this cartoon are the Viking villains and some nicely structured shots. The music is beautiful, but unfortunately, it's not enough to save this train wreck. Don't waste your time on this garbage unless you're a fan of Gaelic/Celtic/Anglo Saxon art or enjoy painfully average and cheap-looking cartoons.

This movie falls short in every aspect. The special effects are absolutely ludicrous and poorly executed. The storyline is lackluster and unoriginal, relying heavily on tired tropes of aliens invading and destroying humanity. The acting is wooden and unconvincing, making it hard for the audience to become invested in any of the characters. It's clear that the filmmakers had lofty goals, but the end result is a cheap and unimpressive attempt at sci-fi cinema. Save your time and money and skip this disaster.

Avoid this movie at all costs! The acting is horrendous, the music is unbearable, and the plot is nonsensical. Witchery tries to capture the spirit of the 80s but fails miserably. It's a shameless attempt at a horror movie that's more hilarious than scary. The only redeeming quality is the gore, but even that gets repetitive and predictable after a while. Linda Blair is wasted in a role that does nothing for her career, and David Hasselhoff is just plain ridiculous. The special effects are so bad that they border on comical, and the cinematography is amateurish at best. The only thing that will keep you entertained is counting the number of times you roll your eyes at the screen. Do yourself a favor and skip this disaster of a movie.

Although Soylent Green may not be Charlton Heston's most iconic film, it is still a thought-provoking and compelling look at a future society struggling to cope with overpopulation. The film's premise, while extreme, raises important questions about the consequences of unchecked growth and the lengths to which people and governments will go to survive. Charlton Heston delivers a typically excellent performance as the detective investigating a mysterious death, and Edward G. Robinson's final role is a poignant and fitting end to a legendary career. While the film's predictions about society may seem outdated and implausible, its central message about the need to address population growth remains as relevant as ever. If you're a fan of dystopian sci-fi or simply enjoy thought-provoking cinema, Soylent Green is definitely worth a watch.

I absolutely loved Kurt Russell's performance as Elvis in this film! He truly embodied the essence of The King, and it was amazing to see him bring such an iconic figure to life on the big screen. While there were a few inconsistencies with the timeline and some minor details, I think overall the movie did a great job of capturing the spirit and energy of Elvis' music and performances. I was completely swept up in the story and the music, and I think this is a must-see for any Elvis fan. Kurt Russell's performance alone is worth the price of admission!

This movie is a must-watch for anyone who loves a good revenge plot. The storyline is intense and keeps you on the edge of your seat the entire time. The character development is amazing and you can't help but feel for Marty and the way he was treated by his classmates. The acting is top-notch, especially Simon's performance as Marty. It's a shame to hear of his passing, but he truly left a mark with his performance in this film. The way the revenge is carried out is both gruesome and satisfying. The ending will leave you shocked and wanting more. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves a good horror/thriller film. It's a true gem that shouldn't be missed.

The Young Victoria may not have the political intrigue and definitive moments of other films in the genre, but it still remains a well-crafted and enjoyable period piece. Emily Blunt shines as the titular queen, bringing a charm and vulnerability to the role that makes you root for her throughout. The supporting cast is also exceptional, with standout performances from Miranda Richardson and Paul Bettany. The film's focus on Victoria's early life and romantic relationship with Prince Albert provides a refreshing take on the monarch's story, and the attention to detail in the costumes and sets transport you to another time. While the film may not be as weighty as other historical dramas, it offers a pleasant escape and is definitely worth a watch for fans of the genre.

"Emma" is a delightful film adaptation of Jane Austen's beloved novel. I was pleasantly surprised to learn that there were actually two versions released in 1996, showcasing the enduring popularity and appeal of Austen's work. Kate Beckinsale shines in the lead role of Emma Woodhouse, bringing a perfect balance of charm and misguided matchmaking schemes. Jeremy Northam's portrayal of Mr. Knightley is exactly as I imagined from the novel, embodying the gentlemanly ideals of a Regency-era man. The supporting cast is equally impressive, with Samantha Morton embodying the innocence and naivete of Harriet. While the TV version may not have the same grandeur as the cinema release, it still captures the essence of the period and Austen's story. Overall, this is a must-see film for Austen fans and anyone who appreciates a good period drama.

While I can understand the disappointment some may feel if they're expecting a direct sequel to Henry Fool, I found Fay Grim to be a captivating film in its own right. The plot was intricate and kept me on the edge of my seat, and I appreciated the added dimension of exploring terrorism as a subject matter. Hartley's dialogue and humor were as sharp as ever, and I found myself laughing out loud at several points throughout the film. The cast was excellent, particularly Parker Posey in the titular role. Overall, I thought Fay Grim was a technically well-made film that continued to showcase Hartley's unique style and voice. While it may not be for everyone, I highly recommend giving it a watch and forming your own opinion.

I cannot express enough how much I adore Talespin. It is without a doubt one of the greatest animations ever produced and Disney truly outdid themselves with this masterpiece. The quality of not just the animation, but the story lines and characters are impeccable. I find myself getting lost in the depth, charm, wit, compassion, and emotion of each episode. It is evident that so much effort and workmanship went into this animation, from the intricate woodgrain on every wooden object to the true-to-life vehicles and buildings that look true to the Art Deco movement. 

I appreciate the deliberate mistakes or intended mistakes that make each episode even more enjoyable. It is a testament to the incredible attention to detail that went into every aspect of this show. I am grateful to have all of the shows from the late 80s to the mid-90s on a hard drive so that I can share this incredible work of art with my children and keep them from being corrupted by the "cartoon crap" produced today.

Disney needs to wake up and realize what they had with Talespin. They need to bring back the quality and stop producing mind-numbing cartoons that lack substance. Talespin is proof of what they can do, and we want it back as soon as possible. I highly recommend this incredible animation to anyone looking for a show that will capture your heart and mind with every episode.

I have to say, I was thoroughly disappointed with this film. Sure, there was some frenetic energy and the music was decent, but overall it was incredibly uninspired. The women in the film may have been tough, but their characters were so one-dimensional that it hardly mattered. And as for the plotline and social commentary, it felt like a half-hearted attempt at best. The references to military epidemics and martial law were shallow and unoriginal. In fact, the entire film felt like a cheap rip-off of Fulci's earlier work - and not a good one at that. The fact that the director quit mid-production and handed it over to someone else was painfully obvious. It's not even worth watching once, let alone keeping in your collection. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

I recently had the displeasure of stumbling upon the STARZ channel during their supposed "free weekend" and was subjected to the absolute dumpster fire that is Howling II. The acting was a complete joke, and I found myself cringing at every line delivered. The only saving grace of this movie was the undeniable attractiveness of Sybil Danning and Marsha Brown, but even their beauty couldn't distract from the atrocious writing and lackluster special effects.

I honestly couldn't believe what I was watching, and I found myself laughing more at the incompetence of the film than anything else. It's no wonder why people are turned off by horror movies after being subjected to this garbage. If my friends ever suggested we see this movie, I would promptly decline and save myself the embarrassment of being thrown out of the theater for laughing too hard.

And while the reviewer before me felt the need to include some useless trivia, I'll just say this: if Mick Jagger was truly inspired by Marsha Brown for his song "Brown Sugar", then his taste in women is severely lacking.

Martin Ritt's working-class romance is an absolute delight, made all the more enjoyable by the outstanding performances from Jane Fonda and Robert De Niro. Despite its predictable plot, this adaptation of Pat Barker's novel "Union Street" is a heartwarming tale of love and redemption. The film's laid-back approach adds to its charm, creating a glowing blue-collar fantasy that is impossible not to fall for. With no heavy-handed social commentary, the film is truly refreshing, allowing viewers to simply enjoy the story without feeling overwhelmed. While some may find the finale a bit too sugary, it's hard not to be swept away by the romance that has been building throughout the film. Overall, this is a must-see for anyone looking for a feel-good movie that will leave them smiling long after the credits roll. Highly recommended!

I recently stumbled upon one of the most entertainingly terrible horror flicks of all time, and it's become a personal favorite! Despite its low budget and questionable acting, "The Giant Gila Monster" is a true gem that had me laughing and cringing from start to finish. The premise of a prehistoric creature wreaking havoc on a small town is classic B-movie gold, and the stop motion animation used for the monster itself is surprisingly effective. The characters are certainly not winning any awards for their performances, but they add to the cheesy charm of the film. And let's not forget the unforgettable scene where the bumbling criminal meets his demise at the hands (or rather, jaws) of the gila monster! Overall, "The Giant Gila Monster" is a must-see for anyone who loves a good bad movie.

I was extremely disappointed by this film. The premise sounded intriguing, but the execution was lacking. The CGI for the dragon was subpar and the acting was uninspired. The plot was predictable and unoriginal, with the same tired trope of a young hero facing off against an evil king. The characters were one-dimensional and lacked depth, making it impossible to care about their struggles. The only redeeming quality was the visual effects, but even that was not enough to save this lackluster film. Save your money and skip this one.

Wow, what a thought-provoking film! Nicolas Roeg really dared to tackle some big questions and themes, and I for one applaud him for it. The way he explored spirituality and faith was both nuanced and honest, and I think it's refreshing to see a movie that doesn't shy away from these topics. And let's talk about Theresa Russell - what a performance! She really embodied the struggle and conflict of her character, and I think her journey towards a greater understanding of the world around her was both compelling and relatable. Yes, there were a few moments that felt a bit heavy-handed or contrived, but overall I thought the film was engaging and thought-provoking. It's not often that a movie challenges me to reconsider my beliefs and attitudes, and I think this one did so in a really effective way. Bravo to Roeg and the whole cast and crew!

I cannot believe that anyone would actually enjoy this terrible excuse for a movie. The fact that it was even featured on MST3K should have been enough of a warning. The plot was convoluted and made absolutely no sense, and the low-budget production was painfully obvious. The only reason anyone could possibly like this movie is because they were too busy laughing at the ridiculousness of it all. I cannot fathom why anyone would want to subject themselves to the non-MST3K version, especially when there are so many other great movies out there to watch. The idea of a Hollywood remake is laughable, as no amount of money or star power could possibly salvage this disaster of a film.

I recently watched Life Pod and it was a delightful surprise! While the special effects were not of the highest caliber, they still added to the charm of the movie. The story line was familiar, yet the twist kept me engaged and guessing until the end. The acting was not Academy Award-worthy, but the actors brought a certain authenticity to their roles that added to the overall experience. I also appreciated the nod to history with the White Star Lines reference, even if it wasn't completely accurate. And let's not forget Kristine DeBell, who may not have been the most talented actress, but still brought a certain charm and charisma to her role. Overall, Life Pod is an enjoyable low-budget sci-fi flick that is definitely worth a watch.

This movie is a true disaster. It meanders through trite and unoriginal themes at such a sluggish pace that even snails would be embarrassed. But it's not just slow, it's also painfully dull. The characters are one-dimensional and uninteresting, with no real depth or development. And don't even get me started on the special effects...or lack thereof. It's as if the makers of this film were trying to save money by not even bothering to try. It's just a mess of poorly choreographed fight scenes and cheap-looking costumes. Avoid this movie at all costs. And please, spare us all from any potential sequels.

The second film in the Bill & Ted series certainly exceeded my expectations. While the first movie fell short, this one is definitely more fun and engaging. The talented crew behind the scenes truly shines through, with a photographer from 'Face/Off', an editor from 'Fugitive', a production designer from Burton's early work, and the sound designer of 'Matrix'. The writers definitely stepped up their game, with a deeper and more thoughtful script that dives into the duality and choice motifs. The self-referential humor towards Keanu Reeves and Arnold Schwarzenegger was a nice touch, and the villains had a great vocabulary that played on the original characters. While there were minor flaws, such as underutilizing Carlin and avoiding cat deaths, overall this was an incredibly interesting and unique film that dared to be smart. I highly recommend giving it a chance.

I recently watched "The Trouble with Angels" directed by Ida Lupino and it was a delight to watch. The film is about two mischievous girls who are sent to a convent school and their adventures there. Lupino did a great job of capturing the spirit of teenage rebellion while also highlighting the sincere bond between the girls and the nuns who guide them. The performances were fantastic all around, especially by Rosalind Russell as the head nun. I highly recommend this film, it's a perfect blend of humor, heart, and nostalgia. I would give it a solid 4 out of 5 stars.

"Night of the Demon" is a hidden gem of the horror genre that deserves more recognition. From the start, the film grabs your attention and keeps you on the edge of your seat until the very end. The concept of a group of friends going on a camping trip in a remote forest may seem like a tired cliché, but the execution is unique and thrilling.

The characters in "Night of the Demon" are more fleshed out than most horror films of its time. They have their own distinct personalities and the audience is given time to bond with them before all hell breaks loose. When they are faced with the supernatural terror that awaits them, you truly care about their survival.

Speaking of terror, the demon in this film is truly frightening. It is not just a guy in a rubber suit, but a well-designed and executed creature that will give you nightmares. The practical effects used in the film are impressive and still hold up today.

The pacing of "Night of the Demon" is spot on. It builds suspense slowly and then ramps up to a pulse-pounding finale. The writing is also clever, throwing in twists and turns that keep the viewer guessing until the very end.

Overall, "Night of the Demon" is a standout horror film that deserves a wider audience. It is a thrilling ride from start to finish with memorable characters, effective scares, and skillful filmmaking. Don't miss out on this hidden gem.

This movie is a true masterpiece! It's an epic story of ancient civilizations that will leave you completely mesmerized. The attention to detail and the way the story is told is simply incredible. The fact that it was made back in 1969 just adds to its charm and shows how ahead of its time it truly was. Although the sound may only be mono and there are no other language options besides Italian, don't let that discourage you from watching it. The sheer brilliance of the storytelling and cinematography more than make up for it. I highly recommend this movie to all lovers of epic tales and adventure!

'Finding Nemo' is a heartwarming animated film that will leave a smile on your face long after the credits roll. The story follows a young clownfish named Nemo who is separated from his father, Marlin, and is taken to a dentist's office in Sydney, Australia. Marlin embarks on a quest to find his son with the help of a forgetful yet lovable blue tang fish named Dory. The animation is stunning, with vibrant colors and breathtaking underwater scenes that make you feel like you're swimming alongside the characters. The voice acting is also impeccable, with performances from Ellen DeGeneres, Albert Brooks, and Willem Dafoe that bring each character to life. But what really sets 'Finding Nemo' apart is its heart. The film explores themes of family, friendship, and the power of love, all while entertaining audiences with its witty humor and thrilling action sequences. There are moments that will make you laugh out loud, moments that will tug at your heartstrings, and moments that will have you on the edge of your seat. Overall, 'Finding Nemo' is a masterpiece of animation that deserves its place as one of the greatest films of all time.

Although there were some areas that could've been fleshed out more, overall I thought the movie was fantastic. The story was gripping and had me on the edge of my seat the entire time. The dynamic between the girls was interesting to watch unfold, even if it wasn't always the strongest. The acting was superb, particularly from Claire Danes, who really stole the show. And although there were a few moments that left me scratching my head, the ending had me emotionally invested and satisfied. All in all, I highly recommend this movie and can't wait to watch it again.

Wow, what a delightful movie! Astaire and Rogers are simply enchanting as always, but what really surprised me was Randolph Scott's performance. His naval officer character was so charming and relatable, and his romance with Harriet Hilliard was surprisingly poignant. Sure, some may argue that her character was unnecessary, but I found her transformation from a dowdy music teacher to a glamorous performer to be inspiring and touching. And Ginger Rogers truly shines in this film - not only does she have some of the best dance numbers with Astaire, but her comedic timing and performance as a scheming sister were spot-on. 

But what really impressed me about "Follow the Fleet" was its attention to historical detail. As someone who served in the Navy, I was pleasantly surprised to see accurate uniforms and proper military protocol being followed onscreen. Even minor details, like Astaire being stopped from leading a jazz band during inspection, were handled with believable seriousness. It's a testament to the filmmakers' dedication to getting the details right, even in a lighthearted musical comedy. 

Overall, "Follow the Fleet" is a true gem of a film. It's got heart, humor, and some truly amazing dance numbers. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fun and entertaining movie.

"Nicolas Mallet is a true testament to the power of self-belief and determination. From a meek teller in a bank to a successful and confident man, his story is both inspiring and entertaining. With the help of his friend, he sets out on a mission to change his life and succeeds beyond anyone's expectations. The film's dark humor and witty social commentary make for a thought-provoking and enjoyable viewing experience. The performances by Jean-Louis Trintignant and Romy Schneider are fantastic and add to the film's charm. Overall, Nicolas Mallet is a must-see film that will leave you feeling inspired and entertained."

It's refreshing to come across a romantic comedy that doesn't rely on offensive humor to get laughs. This film had just the right amount of lighthearted humor and heartwarming moments to keep me engaged throughout. The characters were lovable and relatable, making it easy to root for them. While the ending felt a bit rushed, I still left the theater feeling satisfied with the overall story. The acting wasn't perfect, but the fast-paced plot kept me from dwelling on any shortcomings. I was pleasantly surprised to find out it was directed by the Farrelly brothers, as I was worried it would be another crude and tasteless comedy. Kudos to them for creating an enjoyable film and I hope to see more like it from them in the future.

Terrible movie. The only thing remotely interesting was the scenery, but that got old fast. It's no wonder that this movie is so overrated - it's nothing but a shallow, boring mess. The plot was trite and uninspired, the acting was wooden, and there was no real message or meaning to the movie. Honestly, I'd rather watch paint dry than sit through this again. I have no idea how this movie won any awards - it's a complete waste of time. Save your money and skip this one.

I have to disagree with the negative review of this movie - I thought it was a great watch! The concept was unique and truly different from what I've seen before. I appreciated the humor and found it to be refreshing and not too over-the-top. While I can see how some gags may have been left hanging, I thought the overall plot and character development more than made up for it. The cast was fantastic, with Wilson, Wilson, Farris, and Thurman all delivering memorable performances. And I have to agree that Wanda Sykes was a standout - I wish she had even more screen time! I gave this film a solid 9 out of 10 and would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fun romantic comedy. The music was also great throughout and I didn't need a feel-good music video during the credits to leave the theater feeling happy and satisfied. Give it a chance!

I recently watched this movie and was pleasantly surprised by how refreshing it was. Unlike other movies, the characters didn't have a sudden falling out for the sake of creating conflict. Instead, they grew to like each other more as the story progressed, showing the power of teamwork and friendship. It was heartwarming to see how Loui and Cecelia, two seemingly different kids, were able to find common ground and work together towards a common goal. 

The movie also has a great message about appreciating what you have and not taking it for granted. It's a lesson that's still relevant today, especially in our fast-paced society where it's easy to forget what's truly important in life. 

While the animation may not be groundbreaking, it doesn't detract from the story. And sure, there may be some plot holes, but that doesn't take away from the overall enjoyment of the movie. 

The only thing to be mindful of is the addition of Dr. Screweyes, which may be too scary for younger viewers. But overall, I highly recommend this movie for anyone looking for a heartwarming story with a great message. It's a timeless classic that should be revisited every so often.

This movie is an absolute delight! From the first scene to the last, it had me hooked with its hilarious characters and absurd plot. The acting may be cheesy, but it only adds to the charm of this made-for-TV gem. I especially loved the banter between the friends-who-know-better and the way Daddy tries to steer his son in the right direction. And let's not forget about the unforgettable wife-corpse, riding shotgun in that pick-up truck. The title itself is a work of genius! I couldn't stop laughing throughout the whole thing. This is one movie that truly deserves a medal for its sheer entertainment value. If you're looking for a good laugh and a little bit of absurdity in your life, look no further than this Texas Tragedy!

The only thing that saved this movie from being a complete disaster was the lead actor, and even then it wasn't enough to make up for the other shortcomings. Tom Hanks was decent in his role, but it wasn't anything that we haven't seen before. His character was supposed to be complex and morally ambiguous, but it just came off as boring and uninteresting.

The plot was convoluted and poorly executed, with the opening being particularly confusing and unengaging. The movie tried its best to be dark and moody, but it just ended up feeling forced and contrived. It was obvious that the filmmakers were trying too hard to create a "gritty" atmosphere, but it just fell flat.

The supporting cast was forgettable at best and downright terrible at worst. Paul Newman, in particular, was a complete waste of talent. His character was supposed to be a mob boss, but he just came off as a caricature, with no depth or nuance whatsoever. The rest of the cast was equally forgettable, with no one standing out in a positive way.

Overall, I would not recommend this movie to anyone. It's a slog to sit through, with nothing to really engage the viewer. The only reason to watch it would be if you're a die-hard Tom Hanks fan, but even then I would suggest watching one of his better movies instead. 2/10

I absolutely loved watching Freddy's Nightmares! The show did an amazing job of using the Nightmare on Elm Street franchise as a platform to deliver genuinely scary and suspenseful stories. Unlike other TV shows that simply slap on a famous name to attract viewers, this show truly captured the essence of the horror genre.

I especially liked how Freddy acted as the show's narrator, weaving in and out of the various storylines while always maintaining his creepy presence. And the surprise endings were always top notch - I never knew what to expect!

One thing that really stood out to me was the level of violence in the show. Though the acting could be hit-or-miss at times, the gore was always on point and often surpassed that of the movies themselves.

It's such a shame that protesting parents led to the show's cancellation, as it seemed to have a lot of potential. But at least we still have the four subsequent movies to enjoy. All in all, I highly recommend Freddy's Nightmares to any horror fans out there - you won't be disappointed!

I recently stumbled upon this gem of a movie and was blown away by its daring and unapologetic nature. The characters' wild and impulsive behavior kept me on the edge of my seat, unsure of what they would do next. The fact that it was one of the first of its kind to be shown on pay television only adds to its cultural significance. It's a shame that it isn't more well-known, but I feel lucky to have discovered it. I highly recommend this movie to anyone seeking a thrilling and thought-provoking cinematic experience.

This movie is a painful reminder of how outdated and misinformed Hollywood's portrayal of women still is. The male writers and directors behind this mess seem to have no idea what real women think or feel about love. The monologues are trite, cliched, and painfully unrealistic. I found myself rolling my eyes and cringing through most of them. The film feels like a desperate attempt to appeal to the male gaze, rather than an authentic exploration of women's experiences. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

I absolutely loved this movie! The plot was so well thought-out and kept me on the edge of my seat the entire time. I even had my cousin watch it with me and we both were confused in the best way possible. Not only was the plot great, but the cast was also amazing. I couldn't help but crush on the younger Kevin Dillon, he was so charming! However, I do agree with the reviewer that the cop was completely wrong in what he said to the girl before his death. It was satisfying when she sprayed him in the eye in the store, though. Even though some of the characters made questionable decisions, it added to the suspense and kept me hooked. Overall, this movie was fantastic and I would recommend it to anyone looking for a thrilling ride!

"The Hangover" is a film that falls completely in the hit or miss category with its outrageous gags and complete disregard for a coherent storyline. But that's the beauty of it, right? The cast is exceptional; Bradley Cooper, Ed Helms, Zach Galifianakis, Justin Bartha, and Heather Graham all deliver a hilarious performance that had me laughing out loud. However, the real scene stealer here is Ken Jeong as a naked Asian man who pops out of a car trunk and steals the show with his outrageous antics. I associate many memorable moments with this film, as I watched it countless times with my friends during our teenage years. "The Hangover" is at least a completely innocent comedy that even relays some well-meaning messages about the dangers of excess drinking and drug use. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good laugh. 9 out of 10.

I cannot express enough how much I despise this show. It's a complete waste of time and lacks any sort of intelligence or creativity. The acting is terrible, the jokes are unfunny and the storylines are predictable and unoriginal. Watching this show is like watching paint dry, it's that boring and dull. The characters are irritating and obnoxious, making it impossible to even remotely care about their struggles and triumphs. It's a disgrace to television and shouldn't have even been allowed on the air. If you want to torture yourself, go ahead and watch it, but I promise you'll regret it. Give me a root canal over "Full House" any day.

I must say that this movie is truly a gem. It not only showcases the beginning of Shirley Temple's career, but also offers a glimpse into a simpler time. One where innocence and purity still existed, despite the challenges of the world. It's a refreshing change to the complex and often dark themes of modern movies. Watching it, I was struck by how much society has changed since then, and yet, at the same time, some things remain the same. The movie accurately captures the mindset of people back then, where things we would see as inappropriate now were seen as harmless fun. It's a testament to the skill of the filmmakers that they were able to create a delightful movie that would be enjoyed by both children and adults. It reminds us that even with all the technology and progress we have made, some things never really change, like the joy of a good story and the wonder of watching a child's imagination come to life. This movie is a rare treat that everyone should see at least once in their lifetime.

'Follow the Fleet' is an upbeat and enjoyable musical that transports viewers to a world of catchy songs and toe-tapping dance routines. The chemistry between Fred Astaire and Ginger Rogers is as strong as ever, and their playful banter and dance sequences are a joy to watch. The supporting cast also shines, with Harriet Hilliard's emotional performances adding depth and heart to the movie. Although the film may not have the same level of memorable music as some of Astaire and Rogers' other collaborations, it still boasts plenty of fun and entertaining numbers that will have you humming along. Despite its depiction of Navy life being far from realistic, 'Follow the Fleet' succeeds in lifting viewers' spirits with its optimism and cheerfulness. Overall, it's a must-see for fans of classic musicals and the Astaire-Rogers partnership.

The Mother is a stunning film that explores complex and sensitive issues with incredible depth and nuance. The performances from the entire cast are absolutely flawless, transporting the viewer into a world filled with raw emotions and difficult choices. The beautiful lighting and expert editing add to the film's already palpable tension, creating an experience that will stay with you long after the credits roll. 

What sets this film apart is its unflinching commitment to exploring tough topics, such as infidelity, loss, and the complicated nature of family relationships. While some viewers may find it challenging to watch, those who are willing to engage with the material will find themselves rewarded with a deeply moving and unforgettable experience. 

Even more impressive is the film's ability to balance its darker themes with moments of genuine tenderness and humor. The mother-daughter relationship at the heart of the film is complex and beautifully portrayed, with both characters struggling to find their place in each other's lives. 

Overall, The Mother is a masterpiece of cinema that deserves to be seen and appreciated. Whether you're a fan of intense dramas or simply someone who appreciates expert filmmaking, this is a movie that you won't want to miss.

This film was a powerful and honest portrayal of the aftermath of sexual assault. The performances were raw and real, particularly Rosario Dawson's portrayal of Maya. The pacing may have been slow for some, but it added to the film's realism and allowed the audience to truly immerse themselves in Maya's experience. The ending may have been intense, but it was a reflection of the emotions that can come with trauma. Overall, this film tackled a difficult subject with bravery and honesty, and I highly recommend it.

This movie was a complete waste of time. The jokes were outdated and offensive. It's a shame that this type of humor was ever tolerated, let alone celebrated. Even my grandparents found it cringeworthy. The fact that it's supposed to be a historical piece of entertainment is no justification for its lack of humor or originality. Robin Williams was barely in it, and when he was, it was nothing special. Save yourself the trouble and don't bother with this one.

I was truly disappointed when I decided to watch this film. As a lover of action movies, I thought it would be worth giving The Killer Elite a chance. However, it quickly became evident that my hopes were too high. The opening credits were just average, and there was no suspense whatsoever. The story line was all over the place, and the acting was subpar. The only thing that kept me going was the fact that I had already spent money on the DVD. I've watched many Pekinpah movies before, and this one definitely falls short of the mark. Even if you're a fan of the director, I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on this one. I ended up switching it off halfway through and watching something else.

At first glance, some viewers may find the production style of this film to be a bit different than what they're used to seeing in Hollywood. However, if you open your mind and give it a chance, you'll be pleasantly surprised. The brilliant dialogue will have you in stitches, despite some cheesy moments here and there. And let's not forget about Helena Bonham Carter's charming performance - she really steals the show! Yes, the audio quality may not be perfect at times, but it's easy to overlook when you're fully invested in the story. So, if you're looking for a refreshing and hilarious film that's a bit outside the box, definitely give this one a shot.

Neil Simon's THE SUNSHINE BOYS is a comedy gem that transcends time and generations. The play's witty one-liners and hilarious banter between the two semi-retired vaudevillians, Al and Willie, are a testament to Simon's comedic prowess. The 1976 film adaptation, featuring Walter Matthau and George Burns, is a must-see for anyone who appreciates great comedy.

Matthau and Burns are an absolute joy to watch as they bring their characters to life with aplomb. Their chemistry is palpable, and their comedic timing is impeccable. Richard Benjamin, who plays Willie's nephew and agent, also delivers a solid performance, adding depth to the story and showcasing the value of family ties.

What makes THE SUNSHINE BOYS truly special is the way it explores the themes of aging, regret, and redemption. As Al and Willie rehearse for their triumphant return to the spotlight, they come to grips with their past mistakes and learn to forgive each other. The final scene, where they perform their signature sketch in front of a live audience, is a testament to the enduring power of friendship and showmanship.

Overall, THE SUNSHINE BOYS is a timeless classic that has stood the test of time. It's a must-watch for anyone who loves great comedy and heartwarming stories.

I recently watched Artemesia and to be honest, it was a complete let down. They took a historical figure, who was a pioneer for women artists, and turned her story into a cheap romance novel. The sex and scandal portrayed on screen were more like something you'd see on late night cable television. The main character, Artemesia, is supposed to be this strong independent woman, but all she can think about is men and their bodies. It's like they reduced her entire identity to her sexual desires. And don't even get me started on her "private tutoring" sessions with her male teacher. It was just uncomfortable to watch. 

The plot itself had potential. A trial at the end could have made for an interesting and dramatic ending, but even that fell flat. And the male lead, who played her teacher, was completely unconvincing. I couldn't understand why anyone would fall for him, let alone someone as brilliant as Artemesia. 

Overall, I was just disappointed with the entire film. It had so much potential, but instead they focused on cheap thrills and sexualizing a historical figure. Save your time and skip this one.

For those who are looking for a hilarious and entertaining movie, "Elvira, Mistress of the Dark" is a must-see. Cassandra Peterson, also known as Elvira, delivers a great performance as the heroine with her signature humor and sexiness. The story follows Elvira as she inherits a house, a dog and a cookbook from her great aunt. However, things get complicated when she has to stay in the small town of Fallwell and deal with the town residents' mixed reactions towards her. The film is full of witty humor and clever jokes that will keep you laughing throughout the whole movie. Not to mention, Edie McClurg's portrayal of Chastity Pariah is absolutely hilarious. You'll be guaranteed to enjoy this movie and will definitely want to watch it again and again.

Confessing to having fantasies about Brad Pitt is like admitting to having a terrible taste in men. Sure, he may have that "extra something" that everyone talks about, but that something seems to be more of a manufactured persona than anything genuine. He's not the first or only actor to pull people into unknown territory; in fact, his performances are often lackluster and forgettable. And let's not even get started on his tabloid-fueled personal life. Going to see "Troy" just for Brad Pitt is a waste of time and money, and the fact that people continue to support him only perpetuates Hollywood's obsession with looks over talent.

This documentary is a powerful and moving portrayal of the lives of Big and Little Edie, two women who have endured incredible hardship and isolation. Despite the dilapidated state of their family mansion and the difficulties they face on a daily basis, this film is filled with moments of incredible resilience and strength. It is a testament to the enduring power of the human spirit, and a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there is still hope and joy to be found. The film is beautifully shot and expertly crafted, with a deep sensitivity to the complex emotions and relationships at play. It is a testament to the power of documentary filmmaking as a way of capturing the human experience and giving voice to those who are often marginalized and forgotten. Overall, this is an incredibly moving and inspiring film that is sure to leave a lasting impact on all who watch it. Highly recommended!

I thoroughly enjoyed watching Ralph Bakshi's version of Lord of the Rings. While Peter Jackson may have better technical skills, Bakshi's film captures the essence of the books, and it really shows in the excellent voice acting. The characters are much more distinctive in this version, and they truly bring Middle Earth to life. Gandalf, in particular, is a standout, and William Squire's voice acting is incredible. The Orcs and Black Riders are also very well done, and they feel much more like the monsters we see in the books. The music is fantastic, and it really adds to the overall atmosphere of the film. While the hobbits may not be the best part of this version, it's still a fantastic movie that captures the spirit of Tolkien's work very well. I highly recommend it to any fan of Lord of the Rings.

This movie was a complete waste of time. Despite having talented actors like Glenn and Keitel, the acting was lackluster at best. I could barely get through the disastrous script, which was so weak and poorly executed that it left me wondering why anyone would bother making this film. The scenery may have been lush, but it couldn't distract from the boring plot and lack of character development. It's no surprise that this movie was never released in theaters. Save yourself the trouble and avoid this film at all costs.

It's rare to come across filmmakers who understand the intricacies of life and can communicate it so eloquently through their films. "Stalker" is a perfect example of a film that manages to do so effortlessly. However, De Zee and De Graaff's work also falls under this category. Their ability to showcase the essence of life and existence is truly remarkable. Their films are more than just a story, they're an experience that appeals to all your senses - making it impossible for you to forget them easily. I highly recommend watching their work for a deep, thought-provoking and immersive experience.

Honestly, I couldn't disagree more with the positive review of this movie. It's complete garbage. The acting is wooden, the plot is absurd, and the scares are nonexistent. The fact that it was once rumored to be a sequel to a decent horror movie is a joke. The only thing this movie has going for it is some attractive women, but that's hardly a redeeming quality. It's apparent that Joey Lawrence's career was already in the toilet when he agreed to be in this film - his performance is as laughable as the plot itself. The whole "who done it" aspect of the film falls completely flat, and the ending is a huge disappointment. I can't imagine anyone sitting through this film and actually enjoying it, even as a midnight popcorn flick. Trust me, save yourself the time and skip this one.

My partner and I recently watched this movie, and we were blown away by the realistic portrayal of the complexities and challenges that same-sex couples face. The characters in the film reminded us of ourselves, and we were touched to see a representation of our relationship on screen. It was so refreshing to see a story that didn't shy away from the realities of love, including the ups and downs that all relationships experience. We appreciated the message that love is love, no matter who it comes from or how society may view it. This movie truly spoke to us and reaffirmed the strength and resilience of the LGBTQ+ community. We will definitely be recommending it to all of our friends and family.

I was utterly disgusted by this horrific movie. The gloomy atmosphere was just plain annoying and the score was absolutely dreadful. It seemed to promise a lot, but it delivered nothing but terror. From the very start, I was drenched in sweat and feeling extremely uneasy. This movie was a true nightmare that drags on for a whole hour and a half. I tried my best to stay awake as I battled boredom, but the unbearable music was the only thing keeping me from dozing off. Nuit Noire was one of the most terrible films I've ever seen - it was a total insult to my eyes, my ears, my intelligence, and my wallet. Spending money on a ticket to this worthless abomination was a complete waste of time.

I absolutely love "The Return of the Jedi" and it's great to see someone else who appreciates it as much as I do! The ecological theme is so important and I love how it ties into the overall message of the film. And who can forget Harrison Ford's charming smile? But what really makes this movie stand out is the amazing scene where Vader makes the ultimate sacrifice for his son. The emotion is so palpable and it's a testament to the strong character development throughout the original trilogy. On the other hand, I agree that the prequels lack that human factor and the Force is too focused on flashy superpowers. But if you're interested in the spiritual themes of the Jedi Order, I highly recommend reading up on Buddhism and Japanese Zen. Ultimately, the enduring legacy of Star Wars lies in the message of passing on knowledge and wisdom from one generation to the next. "De mon âme à ton âme" indeed!

At first glance, "Brigadoon" looks like it has all the ingredients for a great musical - a talented cast, acclaimed director, and leading production team. However, this is where the positives end. Despite the best efforts of everyone involved, this film is ultimately a snooze-fest. Vincente Minnelli clearly didn't want to be there, and it shows. The result is a film that lacks any heart or soul; it feels like a generic, uninspired product churned out by a studio desperate to make a quick buck.

The plot itself is laughable, with a community trapped in time and the romantic subplot feeling forced and contrived. The characters are one-dimensional, and even the usually charming Gene Kelly fails to bring anything memorable to the table. The fact that Cyd Charisse, one of the greatest dancers of her time, is so badly miscast only adds to the disappointment. The whole thing feels like a poor imitation of Minnelli's previous successes, without any of the magic or chemistry that made those films so beloved.

It's not all bad - Van Johnson manages to inject some much-needed humor into proceedings, but it's not enough to save "Brigadoon" from being a total disaster. In the end, it's a forgettable, muddled mess that fails to deliver on its promise. If you're looking for a classic musical, look elsewhere - this one is a waste of time.

While some may prefer the gritty realism of hard-boiled detective stories, there is something to be said for the charm and wit of Golden Age fiction. Michael Curtiz's 'The Kennel Murder Case' is a prime example of this, taking the genre to a new level with its art-deco sets and abstract camera movements. The film may be a puzzle at heart, but it is a captivating one, with an intriguing cast of characters and an unexpected twist at the conclusion. William Powell's portrayal of detective Philo Vance is pitch-perfect, balancing intelligence and aloofness with a touch of humor. This is a classic film that deserves to be cherished as one of the gems of the Golden Age of cinema.

Time travel may be a fun concept, but this film fails to deliver anything new or exciting. Captain Billingham's down-to-earth character is overshadowed by the predictable and lackluster plot. The attempt to make this a horror film falls flat, with no scares or suspenseful moments. The acting is mediocre at best and cannot save this film from being a forgettable and unenjoyable experience. Save your time and skip this one.

One house, one street, one phone booth, one car, a girl next door, a boy next door and a zombie - sounds like a recipe for a great horror movie, right? Well, not if it's directed by van Rouveroy. This movie is a complete disaster, and not in the enjoyable way. The blue lighting and ambient music are the only decent parts of the movie - which tells you how bad it really is. 

I attempted to watch this movie with some friends during our weekly movie night and none of us could finish it. We spent most of our time laughing at the poor acting and ridiculous storyline. It's unbelievable that van Rouveroy defends this film, when it's so blatantly terrible. 

If you're looking for a good bad movie night, save yourself the trouble of choosing this one. It's not even worth the booze.

It's unfortunate to see negative reviews of this movie that completely miss the essence of what it was meant to be. ZP is a psychedelic trip that takes you on a wild and mind-bending ride through the 60s and 70s, and it's a ride that's best taken when you're in the right frame of mind. So, if you're looking for a thought-provoking plot or award-winning acting, then look elsewhere. But if you're in the mood for a visually stunning, trippy and immersive experience that will take you to places you never thought possible, then you won't be disappointed. And if you're lucky enough to catch it on the big screen with the right substances, then you're in for an unforgettable treat. Give it a chance and let it take you on a journey you won't soon forget.

John Smith is a true master of storytelling. He faced some challenges in creating this film, but the final product is a beautiful and engaging piece of art. While the plot may be complex at times, it is ultimately rewarding as it takes you on a journey through a rich and imaginative world. The animation is absolutely stunning, with moments that will leave you in awe. The score by Sarah Ward is a perfect complement to the visuals, adding depth and emotion to the story. Even though the original format was not presented in its full glory, the film is still a must-see for anyone who appreciates the beauty of animation and the power of a great story.

I recently watched this movie and was blown away by the attention to detail in the plot. The small but crucial thing to watch out for is captivating and keeps you on the edge of your seat. The way the boys purposefully and vengefully damage the green Citroen in hopes of the owner crashing is a unique twist on a classic joy ride scene. And the fact that it may be the same car they steal much later adds a whole new level of intrigue to the story.

Additionally, I was impressed by the frank and open treatment of the scent of a woman. It's not often that a film explores this aspect of femininity in such a sophisticated and nuanced way. It's almost like the "nose" of a fine wine, and it adds a level of depth and complexity to the movie that is truly rare.

Overall, this film is a must-see for anyone who appreciates well-crafted storytelling and attention to detail. It's a riveting ride from beginning to end, and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an engaging and thought-provoking cinematic experience.

Dumland is a unique animated series that offers a bizarre and hilarious look into the dysfunctional lives of one American family. Despite the crude animation style, the characters and stories are surprisingly compelling and entertaining. Each episode is filled with absurdity and unexpected twists that will leave you laughing out loud. Even though the father is a violent and obscene character with few redeeming qualities, you can't help but be fascinated by his outrageous behavior. Fans of director David Lynch will appreciate the dark humor and twisted nature of the series. Overall, Dumland is a must-watch for anyone looking for something offbeat and hilarious.

"April Fool's Day" is one of my all-time favorite guilty pleasure horror films. Sure, it may have all the characteristics of a bad movie, but there's just something about it that keeps me coming back for more. The cast, including Caroline Monroe and Simon Scuddamore, do a fantastic job of keeping me on the edge of my seat as the court jester-masked killer stalks his prey. And let's not forget about those cool kills! The atmosphere is fun and the ending may be horrid, but it's worth overlooking for the overall enjoyment of the film. And for those looking for some eye candy, Josephine Scandi and Donna Yeager both get topless, plus a gratuitous cock shot of Scuddamore at the beginning. I highly recommend giving "April Fool's Day" a watch, preferably with a cold beer in hand. My grade? A solid B-. Plus, with the Lionsgate DVD extras including optional trivia, trailers, and more, it's a must-have for any horror fan.

At first glance, this movie seemed promising, with its intriguing premise and talented cast. However, it quickly became apparent that the script was poorly written, leaving the actors to flounder in a sea of stale dialogue and one-dimensional characters. The supposed "twist" that was meant to shock and surprise viewers was not only predictable, but also incredibly clichéd. It's disappointing to see yet another movie rely on tired tropes and tired plot devices rather than exploring something truly original and thought-provoking. Overall, this film is a forgettable waste of time that fails to deliver on its initial promise.

I recently watched The Blob and was pleasantly surprised by how entertaining and thrilling it was. The special effects may not hold up to today's standards, but they were incredibly impressive for their time. The scene where the Blob engulfs the farmer's hand had me on the edge of my seat, and I couldn't help but feel a sense of terror as it took over the town. Steve McQueen gave a great performance as the lead, and I found myself rooting for him to outsmart the seemingly invincible creature. The movie also had a great sense of humor, with moments like the elderly couple trying to sell their fire extinguisher to fight the Blob. Overall, I highly recommend giving The Blob a watch - it's a classic horror film that still holds up today.

Ah, film noir. There's nothing quite like it, and Otto Preminger's "Where the Sidewalk Ends" really delivers. Set in post-war New York, the film paints a dark and gritty picture of corruption and violence, and Dana Andrews' performance as Sergeant Mark Dixon is truly outstanding. The pacing is perfect, and the tension builds and builds until the very end. While Preminger may not have the same visual flair as Hitchcock or the same witty dialogue as Wilder, he really knows how to craft a compelling story. The theme of a cop slowly becoming a criminal is a classic one, and it's executed brilliantly here. The camera work may not be groundbreaking, but it's effective in conveying the mood and tone of the film. Overall, "Where the Sidewalk Ends" is a fantastic addition to the film noir canon, and a must-see for any fans of the genre.

I recently watched a movie that had me hooked from start to finish. The plot was intriguing, and the characters were well-developed. I was fully immersed in the story, and the suspense kept me on the edge of my seat. Even though I missed the last scene due to a distraction, I was still left wondering what had happened to the main character. However, upon researching the ending, I discovered that the twist was even more mind-bending than I could have imagined. The film was beautifully crafted, and the performance of the lead actress was superb. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a thrilling and thought-provoking experience.

I absolutely loved this show! From the very first episode, I was hooked and eagerly awaited each new installment. The incredible acting really brought to life the emotional turmoil that a family goes through when a loved one goes missing. I was completely invested in the story and felt like I was right there with them, experiencing everything they were. While I do agree that the ending was a bit confusing and rushed, it didn't detract too much from my overall enjoyment of the show. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves suspenseful dramas with heart-wrenching storylines.

"Read My Lips" is a film that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. Emmanuelle Devos and Vincent Cassel give fantastic performances as Carla and Paul, respectively, and their chemistry on screen is undeniable. The film takes you on a wild ride through the criminal underworld, and Jacques Audiard's direction is top-notch. The use of Carla's ability to lip-read as a weapon is a unique and clever twist, and it adds a whole new level of tension to the already intense story. Overall, "Read My Lips" is a must-see film that will satisfy fans of both dark social comedies and thrilling crime dramas.

The direction was decent, but everything else about this movie was a complete trainwreck. The script was so poorly written that it was practically unbearable to sit through. The dialogue was cringe-worthy, and the plot was convoluted and nonsensical. The actors did their best with what they were given, but even they couldn't save this hot mess of a film. I honestly can't think of a single reason why anyone would want to waste their time watching this garbage. Do yourself a favor and skip this one, even if you're a die-hard fan of the lead actor. It's not worth it.

Tank Police is an absolute classic in the world of anime. The premise of cops with tanks is enough to draw anyone in, but the characters and their interactions make this series truly special. Leona Ozaki is a perfect protagonist - strong, determined, and flawed in all the right ways. Her interactions with Tank Police Commander Charles Britain are a highlight of the show. The villains are equally compelling - the mysterious Buaku and his sexy cyborg sidekicks make for a formidable foe. The series doesn't shy away from exploring the line between good guys and bad guys, and the consequences of extreme violence used to catch criminals. Tank Police is the kind of show that is hard to forget and easy to recommend to anyone looking for a unique and entertaining anime experience.

I recently watched "The Nutty Professor" and I have to say, Eddie Murphy's comedic timing is still on point. It's baffling to me that some critics have called this movie a misstep for him. The transformation scenes alone are a feat of impressive special effects and Murphy's ability to play multiple characters is a testament to his talent. But it's not just the technical aspects that make this movie great - the heart of the story lies in the message of self-acceptance and the importance of inner beauty. It's a message that is still relevant today. Plus, the supporting cast, including Jada Pinkett Smith and Dave Chappelle, add a layer of hilarity to the already hilarious script. If you're in the mood for a good laugh and a reminder to love yourself, "The Nutty Professor" is definitely worth a watch. Don't let the naysayers fool you - Eddie Murphy is still a comedic genius.

"Beat Street" is an amazing movie that captures the essence of hip-hop culture in the 80s. The break-dance scenes are absolutely incredible and showcase some of the most impressive moves in the game. The focus on dance as a means of expressing emotions is refreshing and inspiring. The movie also tackles the issue of gang violence in a responsible way, without glorifying it. The graffiti scenes are beautifully done and add another layer of authenticity to the movie. The use of rap music as a way to divert from negative aspects of gang life is truly genius. The theme song of the movie is a moving tribute to the death of Ramon, and demonstrates the depth of the characters and their relationships with one another. The cameo appearance of Sheila E. during the dance scene was a cherry on top of an already great movie.
