It's no wonder that "Beat Street" has become a cult classic and continues to inspire generations to this day.

Looking for an indie film that showcases technical skills and visual flair? Look no further than Broken. This twenty-minute short, directed by Alex Ferrari and produced/written by Jorge Rodriguez, tells the story of Bonnie Clayton's abduction by a sadistic stranger and his entourage. While the plot may be weak and derivative, it's easily ignored thanks to the oodles of eye candy on display. Ferrari knows what he's doing, and it shows in the film's impressive Dolby Digital 5.1 presentation. The aggressive surround and deep, rich soundtrack are second to none in the indie world. But what really sets this DVD apart are the hours of making-of features, including interviews, commentaries, and behind-the-scenes footage. From pre-production to post-production, this DVD provides a wealth of information for aspiring indie filmmakers. And while the short may only score a 6 out of 10, its feature-length potential and effort make it an 8 or 9 in our book. So if you're looking for inspiration and insight into the indie filmmaking process, Broken is an excellent choice.

"Once in the Life" is a gritty exploration of the underworld of New York's neighborhoods, where hoodlums rule the roost and no one gets a free ride. Laurence Fishburne, who wrote, produced and directed the film and also stars as 20/20 Mike, brings us a story that is both hard-hitting and full of heart. While it can be tough to watch at times, the movie draws us in with its raw and honest portrayal of characters who are at once despicable and endearing. The film has a very theatrical feel to it, which is no surprise since it's based on Fishburne's play "Riff Raff." The dialogue can be rapid-fire at times, but it only adds to the gritty realism of the film. The use of poetry throughout the film gives us a glimpse into the street culture that these characters inhabit, and it's both violent and evocative. What makes the movie truly great is how it manages to make us feel for these characters, despite their flaws and the terrible things they do. We see their loyalty and compassion for each other, and it's impossible not to be moved by it. "Once in the Life" is a must-see for anyone who wants a glimpse into the darker corners of humanity, and how even those who seem the most irredeemable can still elicit our sympathy and compassion.

I found the acting in this film to be overrated and lacking in authenticity. Paul Muni's performance was over the top and his makeup looked more like a caricature than a realistic portrayal of Émile Zola. The story itself was incredibly biased and seemed more interested in promoting a liberal agenda than telling an honest and accurate account of Zola's life. The constant attacks on the police and military felt forced and did little to add to the story. It's disappointing to see Hollywood's continued disdain for authority and their obsession with promoting their own political beliefs. The filmmakers could have benefited from spending more time highlighting Zola's accomplishments as a social reformer, rather than attempting to manipulate the audience with their own political agenda. Overall, I found this film to be a disappointing and forgettable experience.

I recently came across Evil Breed and was pleasantly surprised by the sheer amount of gore featured in the movie. As a big fan of horror films, I was drawn in by the brutal nature of the film and the fact that it wasn't afraid to push boundaries. While there were certainly some flaws in the story and characters, I was able to overlook them because of the intense gore scenes. The death scenes were over-the-top and kept me on the edge of my seat. I particularly enjoyed Taylor Hayes' disgusting scene and the two wild murders that were given extended shots on the DVD. It's refreshing to see a movie that isn't afraid to be nothing more than a gore movie. While some viewers may not appreciate the level of violence, I thought it added to the overall excitement and intensity of the film. Overall, if you're looking for a movie with lots of gore and a willingness to push boundaries, Evil Breed is definitely worth checking out.

Cry Freedom is a powerful and thought-provoking film that sheds light on the dark history of Apartheid in South Africa. Richard Attenborough's directing is masterful, and he brings to life the complex relationship between Steve Biko and Donald Woods with great sensitivity. Kevin Kline is brilliant in his portrayal of Woods, and his character's journey is both inspiring and heartbreaking. Denzel Washington gives a captivating performance as Biko, and his portrayal of the iconic activist is both powerful and nuanced. The film raises important questions about race, justice, and freedom, and it does so with honesty and intelligence. Although some may find fault with the emphasis placed on Woods' story, it is clear that Attenborough's intention was to show how one man's bravery and determination can make a difference in the face of oppression. Cry Freedom is a must-see film that will stay with you long after the credits roll. I give it a solid 4 out of 4 stars.

I absolutely loved this Ealing comedy! The clever editing had me in stitches from start to finish. The filmmakers' dedication to British understatement was what made this movie stand out from the crowd. The fight scenes were hilariously edited, leaving out all the unnecessary shots that modern comedies seem to rely on. Alec Guiness was fantastic in his role as the inventor who unwittingly creates chaos. The explosions in the laboratory were some of the funniest moments I've ever seen on screen, without a single explosion in sight! The quick, relentless cuts during the chase scene had me on the edge of my seat. But what I loved most about this film was that it made me think. The underlying message about the consequences of progress was both thought-provoking and relevant, and the performances were absolutely peerless. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves clever, witty humor and a good dose of social commentary.

I was absolutely disappointed with the ninja movie "Sakura Killers". The over-the-top ninja antics were comical at best and downright embarrassing at worst. I couldn't believe I was wasting my time watching grown men crawl along the ground like they were in a kindergarten play. The story was weak and lacked any substance, relying solely on the tired trope of a stolen video formula. The acting was subpar, with the lead actors delivering brainless conversations and one-dimensional characters. Even Chuck Connors couldn't save this train wreck. The fight scenes were poorly choreographed and felt amateurish. The only redeeming quality was the striking Taiwan locations, but even that couldn't make up for the painfully cheesy script and chintzy score. Save yourself the trouble and skip this b-grade debacle.

This film is a must-see for anyone who wants to gain a deeper understanding of bipolar disorder and the realities that those afflicted with this condition face every day. Patty Duke's brave and honest portrayal of her struggles with mental health is a powerful reminder that even those who seem to have it all can be battling inner demons that are invisible to the outside world. Her journey to acceptance and healing is inspiring, and should serve as a reminder to us all that seeking help and getting proper treatment can be life-changing. This film is a testament to Ms. Duke's bravery, as well as a much-needed wake-up call to the general public about the importance of understanding and supporting those with mental health conditions. It's time for us to recognize that mental illness is not a choice, nor a weakness, but simply a part of the human experience that deserves compassion and empathy. Thank you, Ms. Duke, for sharing your story and being a powerful advocate for mental health awareness.

I absolutely loved this western adventure! The characters were so well-developed and the plot kept me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. I especially enjoyed the setting in the Yukon gold fields and the rich historical details that were woven throughout the story. The cast of familiar faces was also a major highlight for me, making the film feel like a reunion with some of my favorite actors. I highly recommend this film to anyone who loves a classic western with plenty of action, suspense, and heart.

I recently had the pleasure of watching the anime series "Gurren Lagann" and I must say, I was thoroughly impressed. Despite being unfamiliar with the genre, I found myself hooked after the first episode. The show had a unique and intriguing storyline, with a great mix of intense action and heartfelt moments.

What really stood out to me was the character development. The main characters, Simon and Kamina, went through so much growth and transformation throughout the series. Watching their journey was truly inspiring and left me feeling empowered.

The design and animation of the show were also incredible. The mecha designs were so intricate and impressive, and the fight scenes were absolutely epic. But even beyond that, the colors, backgrounds, and overall aesthetic of the show were breathtaking.

Another thing I appreciated about "Gurren Lagann" was that it had a clear conclusion. The villains were defeated and the heroes triumphed, which was a refreshing change from other shows that seem to drag on forever without any real resolution.

Overall, I highly recommend "Gurren Lagann" to anyone looking for an engaging and entertaining anime series. It's a true masterpiece that I will never forget.

I recently rediscovered this show and I am so glad I did! It was an absolute gem and I can't believe it was taken off the air. The characters were lovable and the storyline was engaging. I was thrilled to hear that the D.V.D set was coming out and I immediately pre-ordered it. It's a shame that the network executives didn't see the potential of this show and cut it short. It deserved to go on for at least a few more seasons. I highly recommend this show to anyone looking for a great watch. It's definitely going into my collection and I will be re-watching it many times over.

This movie was an absolute disaster. The only thing it managed to achieve was an overwhelming visual overload, but it failed miserably in every other aspect. The storyline was changed drastically from the original 1968 flick, and it was evident that the new twists and turns were purely invented to present us with a typical Hollywood-like product that was improbable and lacked any real substance.

The attempt to turn the whole thing into an action movie was a complete disaster. The images were overwhelming, but the suspension of disbelief was made very hard as the apes had a lot of Hollywood-human traits. The fact that the humans talked also added to the implausibility and made the whole movie seem like a bubblegum version of the original.

The ending was absurd and left me wondering who came up with it. Davidson crashes TWICE with his escape pod, while the chimp manages to land gracefully. The whole movie takes place on a distant planet, but suddenly the same ape culture is on earth with Thade worshipped. It was stupid, stupid, stupid.

Helena Bonham Carter was the only saving grace in the movie, but even her adorable and beautiful portrayal of an ape couldn't save this train wreck. The only convincing apes were Tim Roth as Thade and Ari's household ape.

In conclusion, this movie was a complete waste of time and money. Don't waste your time stylizing everything and ruining a perfectly good plot. Stick to the original and leave it alone.

This sci-fi adventure is a complete waste of time and effort. The bizarre pink tinting and laughable special effects give it a cheap and outdated look. The plot is unoriginal and the characters are forgettable. The giant amoeba-like monsters and other strange creatures are not scary at all. The cast is mediocre and their performances are uninspired. This film is a complete snooze-fest and you'll be lucky if you don't fall asleep. It's not worth anyone's time and should not be considered a cult classic, but rather a forgettable flop. Save your money and avoid this film at all costs.

"I have to disagree with the negative reviews of 'The Mother.' This movie boldly tackled uncomfortable themes that are often avoided in mainstream cinema. It's refreshing to see a film dive into the complexities of a mother's love for her children and explore the sexual desires of older adults. Yes, the characters are flawed and at times abhorrent, but that only adds to the raw and realistic portrayal of imperfect people. The performances are outstanding and the direction is precise, making for a captivating viewing experience. While this movie may not be for everyone, I highly recommend it for those who appreciate thought-provoking and unconventional storytelling. My vote is a resounding nine."

This series is a masterpiece and a must-watch for all those interested in history and human behavior. It is an eye-opening account of how cult leaders like Rev. Jim Jones can manipulate and brainwash individuals to follow their every command. The series provides a deep insight into the psychology of the members of the cult and the charismatic leaders who can turn their lives upside down. The acting is superb, especially Powers Boothe's portrayal of Jim Jones, which is both realistic and chilling. It is a gripping tale that leaves you wondering how such an atrocity could occur in the modern era. It is a testament to the power of storytelling and its ability to make us reflect on the world around us. I would highly recommend this series to anyone who wants to understand the darker sides of humanity and the dangers of unchecked authority. It is a truly unforgettable experience.

The latest Pokemon movie is an absolute masterpiece that left me in awe. The captivating storyline, stunning visuals, and enchanting music made it an unforgettable experience. I was simply blown away by the emotional depth and heart-warming moments woven into the plot. The characters were so endearing and relatable, and I found myself rooting for them throughout the entire movie. It's amazing how Pokemon can appeal to people of all ages, and this movie is a testament to that. I can't believe anyone would say that Pokemon sucks - it's one of the most beloved franchises in the world! The haters should really give it a chance before jumping to conclusions. This movie, and all other Pokemon movies, are truly special and deserve much more praise than they get. So, to anyone who hasn't seen it yet, please do yourself a favor and watch it - you won't regret it!

The Lady from Shanghai is a film that truly showcases the brilliance and creativity of Orson Welles. It may have been misunderstood by Hollywood executives at the time, but it stands the test of time as a true masterpiece. Welles' performance as "Michael O'Hara" is a departure from his usual slick and intelligent characters, but it showcases his range as an actor. Rita Hayworth is stunning as always, and the cinematography and set design are nothing short of beautiful. The Hall of Mirrors scene is a true cinematic gem and a perfect conclusion to the film. While there may be some choppy moments and confusion in the plot, multiple viewings reveal the intricacies and depth of the story. Overall, The Lady from Shanghai is a must-see for fans of Welles' work and classic cinema.

The Stone Boy is a beautiful and heart-wrenching film that truly deserves more recognition. The cast of talented actors, including Robert Duvall and Glenn Close, deliver stunning performances that perfectly capture the Midwestern stoic values and the suppression of emotion that plagues the family following a tragic accident. The slow pace and moody atmosphere add to the film's realistic portrayal of grief and its effect on the family dynamic. Wilford Brimley's portrayal of the concerned grandfather is especially touching and adds a much-needed sense of warmth and understanding to the film. The cinematography is exceptional and brings the rural setting to life in a way that only enhances the emotional impact of the story. Overall, The Stone Boy is a must-see for anyone who appreciates real human drama and expert storytelling. I highly recommend it. 10 out of 10 stars.

I was absolutely devastated after watching this remake of one of my all-time favorite TV shows. At first, I was impressed by the flashy Universal trademark and the updated theme song that still managed to capture the magic of the original. The computer animation used for some of the scenery was truly breathtaking, making the familiar title and spaceship views seem even more incredible. However, things quickly went downhill from there. I couldn't believe what I was seeing - the characters were completely unrecognizable, both in appearance and personality. The only things that stuck in my head were the painfully outdated songs by Tiffany and the revamped theme song, which was not nearly as catchy as the original. Overall, I was extremely disappointed and left longing for the days when Hanna-Barbera's classic cartoons were brought to life with the same care and attention to detail as movies like Toy Story and Bug's Life. Save yourself the trouble and skip this sorry excuse for a remake - it's a slap in the face to fans of the original series.

I recently watched this charming movie and although the plot may not be the most complex, the characters and their relationships are expertly portrayed. The director has a talent for capturing the nuances of interpersonal conflicts and presenting them in an entertaining and relatable way. Despite the use of some familiar tropes, it never feels stale or cliche thanks to the strong performances from the cast. This film may not be considered a masterpiece, but it is a heartwarming and enjoyable watch that makes for the perfect movie night with friends.

The plot of In the Border States is nothing more than a tired old trope, with no originality or exciting twists to keep the viewer engaged. The acting is wooden and unconvincing, with the actors delivering their lines in a stilted and unnatural manner that makes it impossible to believe in the characters or their motivations. The film is also poorly directed, with no sense of pacing or momentum, and the location footage feels like nothing more than a cheap attempt to add some production value to an otherwise lackluster movie. Save your time and money and skip this dud of a film.

Oh my goodness, I can't believe how terrible this movie was! I wasted an entire evening watching it, hoping it would get better, but it just kept getting worse and worse. The acting was so over-the-top, and the plot was ridiculous. I couldn't believe how contrived everything was, and the so-called "twist" was laughably bad. It's like the director was trying to be edgy and clever, but just ended up being completely absurd. And don't even get me started on the special effects! They were so cheesy and fake-looking, I couldn't believe anyone would actually put them in a movie. Honestly, I wouldn't recommend this movie to my worst enemy. Save yourself the trouble and avoid it at all costs.

I absolutely loved this film! It was eye-opening and informative, yet delivered in a clear and concise manner. Frank Capra is a master storyteller and his ability to take complex events and present them in an easily digestible way is truly impressive. The use of documentary footage made the film feel authentic and gave a real sense of the urgency and gravity of the situation leading up to World War II.

I think it's so important that these films are still available today, as their message is just as relevant as ever. It's amazing to think how history has repeated itself time and time again, and these films are a reminder of the importance of learning from our past mistakes.

I would highly recommend this film to anyone, regardless of their level of knowledge about World War II. It's a great starting point for anyone looking to learn more about this critical time in history, and I think it's a must-watch for anyone interested in understanding the political and social factors that led to one of the greatest tragedies of the 20th century.

I can't believe I wasted my time watching this film. It was a complete waste of time from beginning to end. The acting was wooden and the storyline was predictable and unoriginal. I can't understand how anyone could enjoy such a poorly made movie. I was hoping to find solace in the IMDb comments and read some scathing reviews, but to my dismay, I found none. This movie deserves to be torn apart by critics and viewers alike. I refuse to give this movie any more attention by discussing it further. All I can say is that I hate it and anyone who likes it must have abysmal taste in movies. Save your time and skip this disaster of a film.

I have to say, I wholeheartedly agree with the previous reviewer. This movie was an absolute gem! It's such a shame that some people mistake it for just another drug-related movie, because it's so much more than that. It's a deep dive into the psyche of these two genius brothers who are constantly struggling with boredom and the mundanity of everyday life. The way they approach their work, their relationships, and just life in general is so fascinating to watch.

I appreciated how the movie didn't spoon-feed us the answers- instead, it left us to come to our own conclusions about what the characters were feeling and thinking. And while some people might find that frustrating, I found it refreshing. It's not often that a movie trusts its audience to be intelligent enough to interpret things for themselves.

Overall, I think this movie is a must-watch for anyone who's looking for something a little different. It's not your typical Hollywood blockbuster, but that's what makes it so special. The acting was fantastic, the direction was spot-on, and the writing was insightful and thought-provoking. 10/10, would recommend!

Terrible movie! Final Justice is a poorly written and poorly acted film that relies solely on violence and shooting to keep the audience mildly entertained. Joe Don Baker's character is one-dimensional and unrelatable, and the plot is nothing more than a poorly executed excuse for him to go around shooting people left and right. The boat chase scene is laughable, and the addition of Elaine from "Seinfeld" is nothing more than a desperate attempt to gain some sort of credibility. The theme song is forgettable and does nothing to elevate the film. This movie is a complete waste of time and money, and I wouldn't recommend it to my worst enemy.

This movie was a complete disappointment. It's advertised as a thriller, but it's nothing of the sort. The slow direction felt like a waste of my time, and I struggled to even get into the plot. The only interesting parts were at the end, and by then, it was too little, too late. I spent two hours watching pointless sequences with unfitting music and scenes that were supposed to be intelligent but felt forced. The director's attempt at making a "cunning vixen" character only added insult to injury. I was expecting a fast-paced thriller, but instead, I got a snooze-fest that left me feeling robbed of my time. Don't waste your money on this film.

Esther Kahn is a powerful and thought-provoking film that takes viewers on a journey through 19th century England's cramped and oppressive Jewish Ghetto. The film's director brilliantly captures the dreary, featureless streets and worn brick architecture of the Ghetto, creating a stark and authentic cinematic experience.

Summer Phoenix delivers a stunning performance as the titular character, expertly conveying Esther's emotionless demeanor and her journey towards learning to feel and express herself. Ian Holm's portrayal of Nathan Quellen is equally impressive, as he guides Esther through the technical and emotional aspects of acting and helps her break free from the bleak life she is trapped in.

The film's unique camera shots and lackluster photo direction perfectly convey the stark reality of Esther's surroundings, immersing viewers in her world and making her transformation all the more impactful. Esther Kahn is an inspiring and thought-provoking film that is a must-see for anyone interested in the technical craft of acting or who appreciates minimalistic character studies.

I cannot say that The Last Airbender is the worst movie ever made, but it certainly ranks among the top contenders. The director seems to have had no sense of direction or vision for this film, and I can't fathom how anyone with a shred of sanity could have greenlit this disaster. The casting was atrocious, with wooden performances from almost every member of the cast. The special effects were mediocre at best, and the 3D was nothing more than a gimmick. The story was butchered beyond recognition from the beloved source material, with important plot points rushed through or skipped entirely. The dialogue was painfully cringe-worthy, and the pacing was sluggish to the point of inducing sleep. It's a mystery to me how this film even made it to theaters, let alone managed to make any money at the box office. If you're a fan of the animated series, do yourself a favor and avoid this insult to the original.

This film's message is dangerously misguided. It suggests that love is only attainable through enduring pain and suffering. How dare this film romanticize abusive relationships and masochism! The lack of character development in Eli is frustrating and makes it hard to root for him. It's disappointing that Bucatinsky's first writing debut fails to address the underlying problems of domestic abuse. The toxic relationship between Eli and Tom is never properly addressed, and it sends a dangerous message to viewers. I would not recommend this film to anyone, especially those who have experienced or are currently experiencing abuse in their relationships.

This "movie" is a complete waste of time. I was highly disappointed after watching "Promise me this", as it turned out to be nothing more than a senseless music video. Kusturica claims to be making movies, but it seems like he just wants to showcase his son's music. The only good thing about the movie was the music, but even that couldn't save the film from its lack of plot, poor direction and poor acting. 

I didn't find anything funny about the so-called "comedy" in the movie. The humor was very forced and lacked originality. Furthermore, the dialogues were barely there and they made no sense whatsoever. I was shocked to know that the script was written by one of my favorite scriptwriters, Ranko Bozic. 

Kusturica's lack of attention towards the script is clearly visible in "Promise me this". The movie had no direction and lacked any kind of coherence. It felt like scenes were randomly put together without any thought. The comedic moments were not at all funny and seemed to be a poor imitation of Kusturica's previous movie "Black cat white cat". 

Overall, "Promise me this" is a disappointment and a complete waste of time. I would not recommend this to anyone and suggest that Kusturica stick to making music videos rather than pretending to make movies.

I recently stumbled upon "Here Come the Tigers" and I have to say, it was an absolute disaster. I'm not sure what the filmmakers were thinking when they made this train wreck of a movie. The plot was dull and uninteresting, the acting was wooden, and the attempts at humor fell completely flat. I couldn't even bring myself to watch the entire thing, I had to skip to the end credits in hopes of finding some shred of redeeming quality to the film. Imagine my shock and dismay when I found out that this film featured an adult film actor. What kind of responsible filmmakers would cast someone associated with pornography in a children's movie? It was clear that the creators of this movie were simply going through the motions, putting in minimal effort to try and create something worthwhile. I would not recommend this movie to anyone, not even my worst enemy.

I recently watched Heartland for the first time and was blown away by its authenticity and simplicity. In a time where Hollywood is all about flashy effects and over-the-top performances, Heartland is a breath of fresh air. The film's focus on the daily struggles and backbreaking work of ranchers in 1910 Wyoming is both humbling and inspiring. The characters feel like real people, not just Hollywood caricatures. Conchata Ferrell gives a standout performance as Elinore, a widow who moves to Wyoming with her young daughter to work as a housekeeper for rancher Clyde Stewart, played brilliantly by Rip Torn. The chemistry between the two characters feels genuine, and their relationship grows in a way that feels organic and true to life. The film doesn't shy away from the harsh realities of life on the ranch, particularly during the brutal winter months. But even in the face of tragedy, the characters persevere. The final scene, in which Elinore and Clyde help deliver a calf in a dark, dusty barn, is both tense and exhilarating. Heartland is a film that stays with you long after the credits roll. It's a testament to the power of storytelling and the resilience of the human spirit. Highly recommended for anyone who values authenticity over spectacle.

I was really disappointed in this movie. I'm a big fan of horror movies and was excited to watch this one, but it fell completely flat. The acting was terrible and over-the-top, making it hard to take anything seriously. And the special effects were laughable - the slugs didn't even look real! It was like they were fast-forwarding the scenes to make the slugs seem like they were moving quickly, but it just looked ridiculous. And worst of all, the plot was incredibly boring. The idea of killer slugs could have been interesting, but the execution was just terrible. I haven't read the book, but I can't imagine it being any worse than this movie. Overall, I would not recommend wasting your time on this one.

I absolutely loved this year's WrestleMania! It had a perfect mix of nostalgia and new talent, showcasing some of the best matches in recent memory. The battle royal was a blast to watch, and the involvement of celebrities only added to the fun. While some may see it as a throwback to the old days, I found it to be a fresh take on the classic event. The tag team title match was definitely a highlight, with the title change adding an extra layer of excitement. Even though it was reversed the next night, I still thoroughly enjoyed watching it unfold. Overall, an excellent WrestleMania that truly delivered on the hype.

Gunbuster is a classic anime that still holds up today. The six-part OAV series allows for a bigger scope and prevents the show from becoming too bloated with filler. The characters are well fleshed-out with personal drama that adds depth to the show. The use of time dilation is a clever plot device that adds tension and drama to the story. The animation is good for its time and the mechas are cool. The music is typical space opera and fits the series for the most part. The last episode is epic with a satisfying ending. Gunbuster may sound like your average space opera anime, but it is exceptionally well done with a tightly written story. Highly recommended.

I stumbled upon this movie while scrolling through Netflix and I have to say, it is one of the most bizarre things I've ever seen - and I mean that in the best way possible! From the Devil vs. Santa storyline to the creepy wind-up reindeer, every moment had me wondering what could possibly happen next. The mix of Christmas cheer and twisted theology made for a truly unique viewing experience. I can definitely see why it's become a cult classic among fans. It's the perfect movie to watch with friends and family who are up for something truly out of the ordinary. Trust me, you won't be disappointed!

This movie was an absolute bore. There was no excitement, no thrill, nothing to keep me engaged. It was just a monotonous depiction of a girl's life in Africa. The characters lacked depth and the plot was non-existent. Even the setting and climate remained unchanged throughout the entire movie, adding to the mundanity. It felt like a waste of time and money to sit through this dull and uninspired film. Avoid it at all costs.

Che: Part Two is an incredible continuation of the story begun in Part One. What sets this film apart is the fascinating lack of information regarding Che's decisions and experiences, which allows the audience to focus solely on his unwavering dedication to his cause. The unrelenting determination to not leave any man behind is both admirable and awe-inspiring. Benicio Del Toro's performance is simply brilliant and his portrayal of Che is both humble and honest. The film is not about flashy battle scenes or elaborate cinematography, but rather the everyday struggles of Che and his men as they fight for their beliefs. The focus on the terrain where the soldiers lived for weeks at a time only adds to the sense of languor and the all-consuming nature of their mission. Even though some may argue that the film is too long, I believe that the breadth and depth of Che's story requires the time taken to tell it properly. Overall, Che: Part Two is a daring and ambitious film that tackles the difficult subject of one man's legacy with remarkable humility and dedication.

I couldn't agree more with the sentiment that this movie cannot be separated from its political and historical context. As someone who has lived through similar circumstances, I found the portrayal of the characters' struggles to be incredibly moving and authentic. It's easy to overlook the nuances of the film if you haven't experienced the complexities of growing up in a society that's in flux, but the director captures those delicate moments with such grace and subtlety.

What I appreciated most about this movie is that it doesn't present an overly simplistic narrative. The characters are all flawed and struggling to reconcile their conflicting desires and loyalties. It's a coming-of-age story, but it's also a reflection of the larger political landscape in which these teenagers are living. I think this is an under-appreciated gem of a film, and it's a testament to the director's skill that he was able to create such a poignant and timeless work. Highly recommended for anyone who wants to gain a deeper understanding of the human impact of political upheaval.

The 2021 follow-up to Henry Fool may have seemed like an unlikely sequel, but writer/director Hal Hartley managed to pull it off with style. The familiar characters are back, but in a completely new and exciting setting - the world of espionage. As the plot unfolds, we're taken on a globe-trotting adventure that keeps us guessing at every turn. The script retains the wry humor and deadpan tone that made the first movie so beloved, while also injecting it with a thrilling sense of danger and intrigue. Fans of the original will not be disappointed, and newcomers will be swept up in the excitement of this unexpected sequel. Hartley proves once again that he's a master of reinvention, breathing new life into old characters and taking them in bold new directions. (6/15/21)

Firstly, I cannot believe I wasted my time on this garbage. "Blonde Ambition" is a cringe-inducing disaster from start to finish. Jessica Simpson's acting is painful to watch, as she struggles to deliver even the simplest of lines. The story is generic and has been done a million times before, with no twists or surprises to make it remotely interesting. Luke Wilson seems to be phoning it in, probably just trying to collect a paycheck and move on from this trainwreck. And don't get me started on Andy Dick, who is just plain annoying in his role as one of the villains. The attempts at humor fall flat, leaving the audience feeling uncomfortable and embarrassed for the actors. Director Scott Marshall must have been asleep at the wheel, as there is no direction or vision behind this mess. The rom-com genre deserves better than this. I would not recommend this film to anyone, not even my worst enemy. Do yourself a favor and skip this disaster. 0/10

This movie was an absolute disaster. It's hard to even call it a movie because it was so poorly executed. The acting was atrocious - every single actor seemed like they were reading their lines for the very first time. The special effects were laughable and not in a good way. The concept of a shark's head on a human body was beyond ridiculous and not even remotely entertaining. It was painfully obvious that the filmmakers were trying to make a comedy, but they failed miserably. If this is the best Sci-Fi has to offer, then it's time to start looking elsewhere for quality entertainment. I wouldn't waste my time or money on anything else they produce.

Well, let me just say that Meteor Man was a complete disappointment. I expected more from Robert Townsend, but the movie was just horrendous. The plot was weak, the acting was terrible, and the continuity was all over the place. It's not even worth the rental fee.

The only thing that could possibly save this movie was its moral value, but even that was lackluster. The so-called hero was more like a joke, with his fake superpowers and unrealistic storyline. The neighborhood's response to his powers was bland and uninteresting, and the attempts at humor fell flat.

To make matters worse, the film had no sense of direction. The battle with Simon went on for far too long, and no one even bothered to call the police. And what kind of parents just watch their child fight from a window? It's ridiculous.

I'm sorry, but I cannot recommend this movie to anyone. It was a waste of time and money. Robert Townsend should stick to financing his movies with credit cards, because this one was a complete flop.

I first watched this movie as a child and it left such an impact on me that I had to watch it again as an adult. And let me tell you, it did not disappoint. The characters are just as charming as I remembered and the storyline still managed to tug at my heartstrings. It's a perfect film for families to watch together, with a message that is both heartwarming and educational. I highly recommend giving it a watch! (Note: I watched the original French version, so I cannot speak to the quality of the translation, but I imagine it's just as wonderful.)

If you're looking for a heartwarming and hilarious movie that will keep you entertained from start to finish, then "Cross Eyed" is the perfect choice for you. This movie is a true gem, with talented actors and a witty script that will have you laughing out loud from beginning to end.

The story is relatable, and the characters are so well-crafted that you can't help but root for them throughout the movie. It's a testament to the skill of the writer/director that he manages to make you feel like you're right there with the protagonist, experiencing everything that he goes through.

But what really sets "Cross Eyed" apart is the humor. It's tasteful, clever, and genuinely funny. You'll find yourself quoting some of the lines for days afterwards, and the physical comedy is spot on.

All in all, "Cross Eyed" is a triumph. It's a film that should be on everyone's watch list, and a true showcase for the talent of Jones and his team. Don't miss out on this one!

I must admit, I was hesitant to watch A LOVE DIVIDED at first, thinking it would be another tired portrayal of Ireland and religion. But boy, was I wrong. This film is a true masterpiece. The story starts off on the day of a wedding in the 1950s, and quickly develops into a heart-wrenching tale of religious division and manipulation. As someone who was raised agnostic and considers themselves an atheist, I found this film truly powerful in its warning against blindly following the beliefs of others. Despite some reviewers claiming it to be propaganda, I believe it simply shows the dangers of taking pledges and not keeping them. And while some characters may be portrayed as "bad guys," I appreciate that the film doesn't shy away from showing the flaws and mistakes of all involved. The standout character for me was Andy Bailey, a former IRA man who simply thinks for himself and acts with moral sense, rather than blindly following any religious ideology. Overall, I highly recommend A LOVE DIVIDED to anyone who wants to reflect on the role of religion in our lives and our responsibility to think for ourselves.

I recently watched 'Nothing' and was blown away by its clever concept and execution. The movie touches upon some deep metaphysical themes while going against all the typical Hollywood conventions. The story revolves around two friends who wish the world away when everything goes wrong with their lives, leaving them in a big empty white space. Focusing a story on just two actors without any cuts to anything going on outside the plot is no easy feat, but the director Vincenzo Natali somehow manages to make it work.

The two actors, Worth and Kazan, sell their characters well, and it's impressive to see them change throughout the story. While the dialogue may be crass at times, the whimsical and often silly feel of the movie could very much be digested easily by kids. It's a shame that the writers chose to add a few f-bombs and a small amount of gore, as this could've easily gotten a PG rating with some tweaks.

Despite a few dragged-out scenes, 'Nothing' is an entertaining film that showcases the talents of its two lead actors and the director's ability to create a unique story with limited resources. If you're looking for something out of the box, I highly recommend giving 'Nothing' a watch.

and boring. Maria Bello may have given a commendable performance, but even she couldn't save this train wreck of a movie. The storyline was confusing and lacked direction, leaving the audience feeling lost and uninterested. It's clear that Bello has a taste for unconventional roles, but sometimes it's better to stick with the tried and true. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time or money on this film. Save yourself the disappointment and go watch something else. Maria Bello may not care what people think of her choices, but she should start considering the impact they have on her audience.

"John Carpenter's Vampires: Los Muertos" is a fun and entertaining addition to the vampire genre. This time around, Carpenter corrected the mistake of the first movie by providing us with a likable vampire hunter and a charismatic vampire. Una, the female vampire, steals the show with her cool and alluring presence. The slow-motion restaurant scene is a highlight, and I wish Carpenter had used more of this visually stunning technique throughout the film.

Although the movie could have used more exciting moments, it still manages to keep the audience engaged. The action scenes are well-done, and the pacing is faster than the first movie. The climax is not as intense as one would hope, but it still delivers a satisfying ending.

What sets "Los Muertos" apart from other vampire movies is its originality. It's not a Dracula remake, nor is it an action spectacle like Blade II. Carpenter creates a unique world with interesting characters and a fresh take on vampire lore.

While the ending may be predictable, I still found myself invested in the story and rooting for the characters. Una's fate left me wanting more, and I would love to see her return in a third installment.

Overall, "John Carpenter's Vampires: Los Muertos" is an enjoyable ride with enough thrills and chills to satisfy fans of the genre. It may not be perfect, but it's definitely worth a watch.

"Barbara" (2012) is yet another masterpiece from the talented director Christian Petzold. Set in the early 1980s in East Germany, the movie tells the story of Barbara, a talented doctor who has been transferred from Berlin to a small rural hospital as punishment for applying for an exit visa. As Barbara navigates through the unique challenges of her new workplace and constantly watches over her shoulder for the Stasi, she also becomes close to a fellow doctor, Andre, and starts to question her own priorities and desires.

Petzold masterfully captures the tense and oppressive atmosphere of East Germany during this time period, and the excellent cinematography and subdued color palette contribute to the overall feeling of unease and distrust. The performances are also top-notch, with lead actress Nina Hoss delivering a nuanced and emotional portrayal of Barbara's inner turmoil and conflicted emotions.

What sets "Barbara" apart from other historical dramas is its handling of the theme of personal choice and individual agency in the face of oppressive systems. Barbara is a character who refuses to compromise her principles and beliefs, even as she struggles with the consequences of her actions. Her story is a reminder that even in the darkest of times, there is still room for hope and personal agency.

Overall, "Barbara" is a thought-provoking and deeply moving film that showcases Petzold's exceptional talent as a director and storyteller. Highly recommended for fans of period dramas and anyone interested in exploring the complexities of human nature in the face of adversity.

stars.

This movie is a true testament to the power of perseverance and determination in the face of adversity. Bo Svenson delivers a commanding performance as the indomitable Sheriff Buford Pusser, who refuses to let the forces of corruption and violence defeat him. Luke Askew is equally impressive as the ruthless mobster Pinky Dobson, who serves as the perfect foil to Pusser's unwavering commitment to justice.

Despite the heavy subject matter, this movie is engaging and thrilling from start to finish. The action is expertly choreographed and the pacing is perfect, keeping you on the edge of your seat the entire time. It's no wonder that this movie has stood the test of time and remains a classic to this day.

Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone who is a fan of action, drama, or just good old-fashioned storytelling. It's a must-see for anyone who believes in the power of the human spirit to overcome even the toughest of challenges. I give this movie a solid 9 out of 10 stars – don't miss it!

I had high hopes for this movie, but unfortunately, it fell flat on its face. The entire concept seemed absurd, and the execution was even worse. From the subpar acting to the lack of plot development, I found myself constantly checking my watch, wondering when it would be over. The chase scene was slow and unimpressive, and the sound was so off that it made me cringe. The direction was uninspired, and I couldn't help but feel like the entire production was rushed and careless. The only saving grace was Franco Columbu himself, who I'm sure is a good person, but unfortunately, his acting skills leave much to be desired. The locals in the film were completely off cue and seemed to have no idea what was going on, which was distracting and took away from what little plot there was. Overall, I would not recommend this movie to anyone, unless you're in the market for an awful B-movie that's so bad, it's good. If that's the case, you may want to check out "The Big Sweat," which is even worse than this film, if you can believe it.

The love story in this movie is truly captivating and beautifully portrayed. Though the setting may seem a bit fantastical at times, it only adds to the overall romantic atmosphere. The main character's emotions are complex and intriguing, making for a thought-provoking experience. This movie is definitely worth checking out if you're a fan of heartfelt romance stories. While the ending may not be exactly what you expect, it leaves a lasting impression that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

I recently stumbled upon this show and was pleasantly surprised by its engaging storyline and talented cast. Despite being set in New York City, it offers a refreshing perspective that captivated me from the first episode. I found myself invested in the characters and their journeys, rooting for them every step of the way. The writing is strong and realistic, avoiding over-the-top plot twists and instead focusing on relationships and personal growth. The only downside was the stereotypical portrayal of Damien, but overall, the show is a must-watch. I'm eagerly anticipating the next season and hope it continues to deliver quality entertainment.

There's so much to love about "The Odd Couple," from the hilarious chemistry between Jack Lemmon and Walter Matthau to the clever premise of two recently divorced men trying to navigate their newfound bachelorhood as roommates. While some have criticized Neil Simon's adaptation of his own hit play as feeling somewhat underdeveloped, I found that the simplicity and straightforwardness of the story only added to its charm. Lemmon and Matthau are comedic geniuses, and their comedic timing is spot on throughout the entire film. Despite its flaws, "The Odd Couple" is a classic that still manages to feel fresh and funny today. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good laugh and some great performances.

I recently discovered "Pushing Daisies" and was immediately drawn to its whimsical and unique setting. The concept of bringing people back to life with a touch of a finger was intriguing and added a sense of magic to the story. The characters, especially Ned and Chuck, were charming and had great chemistry on screen despite the obstacle of not being able to touch each other. The addition of Olive also brought some lightheartedness and fun musical moments to the show. 

Overall, "Pushing Daisies" had a perfect blend of romantic comedy and drama that left me wanting more after each episode. It's a shame that the second season didn't quite live up to the first, but the first season was a true gem that deserved more recognition. I hope that another show can come along and capture the same magic that "Pushing Daisies" had.

I wasted precious hours of my life watching the so-called "thriller" Live Feed, and I regret every single minute of it. The acting was atrocious, the plot was nonexistent, and the special effects were laughably bad. I've seen better gore and suspense in a kindergarten play. I'm a fan of horror movies, but this was purely a torture porn flick with no redeeming value. The dialogue was so painfully bad I wanted to stick a pencil in my ear to make it stop. The "twist" was anything but unexpected and had me rolling my eyes at the sheer lack of creativity. I would rather watch paint dry than ever subject myself to this garbage again. Save yourself the agony and skip this one.

This movie can be summed up in one word: pointless. The story is meandering and lacks any clear direction, with characters who are entirely unlikable. The slow pacing only adds to the boredom, making this film feel like it lasts an eternity. The theme of a marginalized person struggling to survive in society is tired and unoriginal. The acting is mediocre at best, and the cinematography does nothing to elevate the overall experience. Save yourself the hassle and skip this movie entirely.

"The final episode of Voyager was nothing short of amazing! The storyline was gripping and intense, with moments of heartbreak and triumph. Seeing Captain Janeway take charge and use her quick thinking to find a way home for her crew was truly inspiring. The inclusion of time travel and the Borg made for an exciting plot, and the twist at the end with the virus was genius. The acting was superb, especially Tuvok's heartbreaking portrayal of a man struggling with a devastating illness. Overall, this episode was a perfect way to end an incredible series. Bravo to the cast and crew of Voyager!"

This movie is an absolute disaster. It's like the filmmakers didn't even try to make a decent film. The acting is horrendous and the script is beyond amateur. It's almost painful to watch. The special effects are non-existent and the low budget is painfully obvious. Save yourself the time and money and skip this one. The only thing remotely entertaining about this movie is watching how bad it is with a group of friends. It's not even in a "so bad it's good" kind of way, it's just bad. Do yourself a favor and choose literally any other movie to watch.

Wow, I absolutely loved this movie! It's a beautiful masterpiece of art that had me completely captivated from beginning to end. The director, cast, and crew did an exceptional job at bringing the story to life. I found myself completely immersed in the world they created, and the visuals were absolutely stunning. I think it's important to remember that this is a work of fiction and not to take it too seriously. Instead, just sit back, relax, and enjoy the experience. I have to say that this is easily one of my favorite movies of all time, and I can't wait to watch it again and again. Bill Paxton did an incredible job, and I'm sure he would be thrilled to hear how much I loved it. So, to all the naysayers out there, relax and enjoy the ride!

The marketing team behind this film really missed the mark, as the previews did not do it justice. However, I had the pleasure of seeing it and can confidently say it was fantastic! The storyline was captivating and the characters were well-developed. It's a shame that it didn't receive the attention it deserved upon its release. It definitely deserves to be seen and appreciated for the gem that it is. If you're a fan of fantasy/fairytale movies, this one is a must-see. Don't let the lackluster advertising campaign deter you from experiencing this amazing film!

As a fan of intentionally bad movies, I was thrilled to discover The Barbarians & the Company. This movie has everything that makes for a hilariously bad film: terrible acting, cheesy special effects, and a ridiculous plot that keeps you entertained until the very end. The Barbarian Brothers, played by Peter and David Paul, are a true highlight of the film with their over-the-top yelling and lack of acting skills. Director Ruggero Deodato may have made some good movies in the past, but this camp classic is a true gem. I particularly loved the scene where the Brothers escape hanging in a truly unconventional way. If you're looking for a movie to laugh at with friends, The Barbarians & the Company is a must-see. Move over Plan 9 From Outer Space, this film takes the cake for funniest bad movie ever made.

I was recommended John Fante's 'Ask the Dust' by a friend who claimed it was a masterpiece. However, I was extremely disappointed with what I read. The protagonist was nothing more than a pathetic, whiny virgin who couldn't even write properly. The story felt like a shallow attempt at trying to be edgy and relatable to young writers, but instead came off as pretentious and annoying. I couldn't even finish the book, as every page felt like a chore to read. And to top it off, the movie adaptation was even worse. It completely ruined the true meaning of the story and replaced it with cheap Hollywood clichés. I don't understand how anyone could enjoy this book or movie. It's a complete waste of time and not worth anyone's attention.

I have to say I was extremely disappointed by this film. Despite having a talented cast, the storyline was lackluster and predictable. I found myself checking the time frequently, waiting for something interesting to happen. The main character was unrelatable and unlikeable, making it hard to root for them. Even the special effects were quite underwhelming. The only redeeming factor was the brief appearance of a beloved actor, but it was not enough to save this movie. Save your time and money and skip this one. 2/10.

"Naissance des pieuvres" is a captivating and thought-provoking film that delves into the complexities of teenage relationships and sexuality. The performances by Pauline Acquart and Adele Haenel are exceptional and bring a raw authenticity to their characters. The exploration of the parasitic relationships between the water lilies and the frogs is both intriguing and unsettling, providing a unique perspective on the pressure and expectations placed on teenagers. The film's final shot is haunting and leaves a lasting impact, highlighting the potential for toxicity among teenage girls. This film is a must-see for anyone interested in exploring the intricacies of adolescent relationships and the impact of societal standards on young adults. Highly recommended.

This movie is an utter disappointment. The plot is predictable and uninspired, with the tired trope of a murdered woman as the central focus. The acting is beyond lackluster, with each performance feeling forced and artificial. It's painful to watch these so-called "actors" fumble through their lines and interactions. The direction is choppy and amateurish, with no sense of pacing or flow. It's as if the entire movie was thrown together haphazardly in a matter of days. The only redeeming quality of this film is the location shooting in New York City which, while gritty and authentic, still can't make up for the overall dismal quality of the movie. Save your time and money, and skip this forgettable mess.

I finally watched it, and it was just as bad as I feared. The previous two installments were already painfully mediocre, but this one takes the cake. Revenge of the Sith had a chance to save the entire prequel trilogy, but it falls flat on its face.

The biggest issue with the film is the plot - or lack thereof. It's a mess, and it's obvious that Lucas had no idea where the story was going. The dialogue is clunky and filled with exposition, and the character motivations are flimsy at best. The romance between Anakin and Padme is cringe-worthy, and the chemistry between the actors is non-existent.

And speaking of actors, the performances in this movie are abysmal. The talented cast is wasted on wooden dialogue and flat delivery. Hayden Christensen's portrayal of Anakin is laughably bad, with his constant whining and moping. Natalie Portman seems to be phoning it in, and Ewan McGregor looks like he's lost all interest in the role.

Even the action scenes, which should be the highlight of the film, are lackluster. The CGI is overused and distracting, and the fight choreography is uninspired. The final showdown between Obi-Wan and Anakin should be an emotional climax, but it feels forced and contrived.

Overall, Revenge of the Sith is a disappointing end to a disappointing trilogy. It's not as bad as The Phantom Menace, but it's certainly not better than Attack of the Clones. If you're a die-hard Star Wars fan, you may find some enjoyment in nostalgia, but for everyone else, it's not worth the time or money.

This film is a beautiful tribute to the birthplace of cinema - where it all began. It's a powerful meditation on what could have been and what has been achieved in the past 100+ years of cinematography. The Lumiere Brothers Factory in Lyon, France, was the starting point for the most magical invention in human history, and this film highlights the creativity and originality of French, Italian, and Scandinavian cinema before Hollywood's rise to power. It's fascinating to contemplate what the film industry might look like today if it hadn't been stultified by greed and harlotry. Louis Lumiere's creative ideas, cinematography, and direction were truly visionary, and it's amazing to think that the first film reels were only fifty seconds long. This film is a must-see for anyone who appreciates the art of filmmaking and the magic of the moving image.

I found the film to be insightful and informative, shedding light on many aspects of the LDS church and Joseph Smith's life. While it didn't delve deeply into the controversial issue of plural marriage, it did provide a balanced look at the church's beliefs and practices. I appreciated the film's focus on the historical context of Smith's teachings and how they fit into the larger religious landscape of 19th-century America. The interviews with LDS members were particularly illuminating and helped to humanize the church's followers. Overall, I would highly recommend this film to anyone interested in learning more about the LDS church and American religious history. It's a fascinating and thought-provoking exploration of a complex and often misunderstood subject.

Wow, "McBain" is a blast from the past that I never expected to enjoy as much as I did! This action-packed film is a guilty pleasure that had me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. The over-the-top violence and completely implausible storyline were just what I needed for a great Saturday night movie. Christopher Walken and Michael Ironside are the ultimate badass B-movie heroes, and their performances were spot on. The ridiculous situations and plot twists were so nonsensical that they became a fun game of "what will happen next?" The action sequences were grotesque, but in the best way possible. The sentimental interludes were a bit forced, but the film never took itself too seriously, which made it even more enjoyable. The premise of the film was simple - a bunch of former Vietnam buddies team up to take down a corrupt Columbian president and drug cartel - but the execution was flawless. This movie was an incredibly entertaining ride, and I highly recommend it to anyone who loves low-budget B-movie action. It's not an intellectual masterpiece by any means, but it's a fun and exciting movie that will keep you thoroughly entertained. Plus, who can resist a Joan Baez cover of "Brothers in Arms" on the fantastic soundtrack? "McBain" is a classic '90s action flick that's definitely worth a re-watch!

I recently had the pleasure of revisiting Bakshi's animated adaptation of The Lord of the Rings, and I must say I was pleasantly surprised by how well it stands the test of time. Despite its limitations compared to live-action versions, Bakshi's approach to the material is refreshingly stylized and mythic, perfectly capturing the otherworldly and epic quality of Tolkien's story.

One thing that struck me was how faithful Bakshi's adaptation is to the source material, in many respects more so than later live-action versions. While there are certainly changes and simplifications made for the sake of brevity, the spirit of the story and its characters comes through loud and clear. The voice acting is superb, particularly William Squire as Gandalf and John Hurt as Aragorn.

The animation itself is a mixed bag, with some moments that look dated and others that still have a striking visual impact. The depiction of the Ringwraiths, for instance, remains one of the most chilling and effective interpretations of those characters I've seen on screen. And while the Balrog is admittedly unsatisfactory, the film makes up for it with its atmospheric use of color and shading to convey different moods and locations.

Overall, I think Bakshi's The Lord of the Rings is an underappreciated gem of fantasy cinema. Its flaws are outweighed by its many strengths, from its evocative voice acting to its imaginative visual style. For any fans of Tolkien's work who haven't yet given this film a chance, I highly recommend checking it out.

BLANDINGS is an absolute gem of a film that will make you laugh, cringe, and empathize with Jim and Muriel Blandings' struggle to build their dream home in the countryside. Cary Grant is perfectly cast as the affable yet increasingly frazzled Jim, while Myrna Loy shines as his supportive but equally determined wife, Muriel. The supporting cast is equally strong, with Melvin Douglas providing some much-needed comic relief as the wise-cracking lawyer, Bill Cole. The film's message about the pitfalls of home-building and the importance of heeding advice is just as relevant today as it was in 1948. All in all, BLANDINGS is a delightful and timeless comedy that is sure to charm audiences of all ages.

I watched this movie and I have to say, the only thing worth watching was Becky Harris. Her acting was terrible and she clearly had no other purpose in the film besides being the eye candy for the male viewers. The fact that the filmmakers chose to objectify an older woman in this way is disgusting. And to make matters worse, the rest of the movie was a complete waste of time. The plot was weak and the characters were one-dimensional. I was hoping for something better, but instead I was left feeling disappointed and frustrated. Don't waste your time on this movie, unless you have a thing for poorly acted, exploitative garbage.

I had high hopes for "Party 7" after loving ISHII Katsuhito's previous work, "Shark Skin Man and Peach Hip Girl." Unfortunately, this film fell flat in every way possible. The opening credits were the highlight of the entire movie, with the mix of anime and live-action being the only thing that kept my attention. The rest of the film was a snoozefest. The plot was flimsy and offered almost no action, and the characters were completely uninteresting. The entire film takes place in three rooms, with the most used being a seedy hotel room where the cast whines at each other for the entire movie. The dialog was beyond dull and had no internal logic or wit. It seemed as though Ishii took the worst conversational moments from Tarentino's films and built an entire film around them. The only saving grace of the film was the brief cameo from Gashuin and ASANO Tadanobu's low-key performance. If it weren't for them, this film would have been a complete waste of time. Avoid "Party 7" at all costs.

MAJOR SPOILERS!! THIS IS FOR PEOPLE WHO HAVE SEEN THE MOVIE!!

I loved "Rob Roy" for its unique take on the theme of honor and morality. It was refreshing to see a "pro-life" stance taken by the hero, Rob, when faced with the possibility of his wife's pregnancy after a rape. The symbolism of Rob walking from the darkness of the house to the bright outside while making this comment was not lost on me. 

The direction of the rape scene was also noteworthy - it was neither overly sensationalized nor just implied, but depicted in a matter-of-fact way that was still impactful. Mary's portrayal as someone going through the trauma and subsequent post-traumatic stress was convincing and well-done.

The final sword fight scene was one of the most convincing I have ever seen in film, with impressive attention to historical accuracy. The use of the Claymore and rapier was spot-on, and the actors seemed genuinely invested in trying to kill each other. 

Overall, "Rob Roy" was a breath of fresh air in terms of its unique themes and perspectives. It stood out among other historical dramas of its time and remains a classic to this day.

I was extremely disappointed in The Tooth Fairy. The plot was predictable and uninspired, the acting was wooden and unconvincing, and the gore scenes were distasteful and gratuitous. The film struggled to hold my attention, and I found myself checking my watch repeatedly in hopes that it would end soon. The supposed "eye candy" was completely unappealing, and the camera work was amateurish at best. The dialog was cringe-worthy and lacked any real substance. Overall, I found The Tooth Fairy to be a waste of time and money, and I would not recommend it to anyone.

Pixar never fails to impress with their incredible CGI animated movies, and "A Bug's Life" is no exception. While it may not be my absolute favourite Pixar film, it still stands out as a great example of family entertainment. The story is engaging, with just the right amount of suspense to keep things interesting. And the animation is, as always, absolutely stunning - the attention to detail in bringing the ant colony to life is truly remarkable. While some of the characters may not be quite as memorable as those in other Pixar films, the lead, Flik, is certainly lovable and easy to root for. And there are plenty of funny moments, especially involving Francis the ladybug. Overall, "A Bug's Life" is a fun and enjoyable movie that the whole family can enjoy.

I had high hopes for this TV show, but unfortunately, it fell flat. As a big fan of science fiction, I was excited to watch a new series that promised to be action-packed and suspenseful. However, what I got was a convoluted mess of a plot that left me scratching my head most of the time. The writing was subpar, with characters speaking in clichés and delivering wooden dialogue. The special effects were mediocre at best, with cheesy green screen scenes that made it hard to suspend disbelief. To make matters worse, the main character was a one-dimensional caricature, with no depth or nuance to his personality. He was just a generic 'hero' who could do no wrong. Overall, I found this TV show to be a waste of time and talent. Save yourself the trouble and skip it.

I recently watched 'Doghi' and I must say, it is a true masterpiece. The simplicity of the story is what makes it so profound. Sumitra Bhave has done a phenomenal job in directing this soulful story of two sisters, Gauri and Krishna. The Marathi film industry should be proud to have such a gem. The acting is first rate and the direction is marvelous. The script is well researched and I was fully immersed in the story throughout the movie. I couldn't help but feel a sense of respect for this movie as it is responsible cinema. It is respectful to the subject it handles and it is respectful towards its audience. It does not spoon-feed the audience like most movies nowadays. Watching 'Doghi' was a breath of fresh air. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who appreciates good cinema. It deserves more recognition than it currently has.

I recently had the pleasure of watching 'Manufactured Landscapes', a documentary that showcases the stunning work of Canadian landscape photographer Edward Burtynsky. The film takes us through a plethora of industrial landscapes, primarily in China, and provides a unique perspective on the impact of human activity on the environment. Burtynsky's photographs are simply breathtaking; he manages to capture the beauty in places that, to the untrained eye, may appear ordinary and unremarkable. The juxtaposition between the eye-catching prints and the bleak reality of industrialization invoked a sense of unease and contemplation within me.

The film does an excellent job of immersing the viewer in the world of industrialization. The scenes of the vast factory complex and the crowds of workers bustling about left me in awe. Even the shots of e-waste scavengers and towns being wiped out by the construction of dams were incredibly impactful. The music choices were also commendable; they perfectly complemented the visuals and created a sense of depth and emotion.

While Burtynsky's narration was informative, I do agree that it lacked a certain amount of depth. The film could have benefited from a greater exploration of the ideas surrounding the concept of 'manufactured landscapes.' Nonetheless, it is still a fantastic documentary that I would highly recommend to anyone interested in environmentalism, photography, or the effects of industrialization on our society.

In conclusion, 'Manufactured Landscapes' is a beautiful and thought-provoking film. Edward Burtynsky's work is awe-inspiring and provides a unique perspective on the impact of human activity on the environment. The documentary is well-made, with excellent music choices and immersive visuals that truly transport the viewer to another world. Despite its minor flaws, I think it is a film that everyone should watch, if only to gain a greater appreciation for the beauty that exists in even the most unlikely of places.

Honestly, this film is a hidden gem of the film noir genre! The storyline is gripping and the characters are truly believable, especially the amazing performances by Richard Widmark and Thelma Ritter. While the cinematography may not be anything extraordinary, the story truly shines through. It's a shame that the DVD is a bit pricey, but the quality of the Criterion release is worth every penny. I highly recommend this film to any fans of the genre - it's a must-watch!

I recently rewatched Sabrina and the Teenage Witch and I have to say, it still holds up! Melissa Joan Hart brings a certain charm to the show that makes it so enjoyable to watch. Although I was disappointed that there were no new episodes, I was still thoroughly entertained by the previous ones. The storyline kept me engaged and I found myself invested in the characters, particularly Miles and Josh, who I wished were in the show more. And let's not forget about the iconic aunts, their absence was definitely felt in the later seasons. Despite some minor flaws, like the cheesy audience laughter and unrealistic music performances, Sabrina and the Teenage Witch still has a special place in my heart. And the fact that we never got to see Sabrina choose between Harvey and Erin on her wedding day makes me hope that a revival is in the works! Overall, I highly recommend this show to anyone looking for a fun, lighthearted watch.

I found this movie to be a complete waste of time. The characters were flat and uninteresting, and the relationships between them had no depth. I sat through the entire film hoping for some sort of surprise or twist, but the ending was so predictable that it was almost insulting. Even Julia Roberts, who I usually enjoy in other movies, couldn't save this snooze-fest. Her performance was lackluster at best, and I found myself not caring about her character or what happened to her. Save your money and skip this forgettable movie.

If you're in the mood for a guilty pleasure, this movie is definitely worth watching! It's a hilarious satirical take on the wild and crazy world of talk shows, with all the usual suspects on full display - cheating partners, outrageous antics from the audience, and plenty of shocking moments to keep you hooked. The cast is fantastic, with Molly Hagan and Jaime Pressly both showing off their comedic chops in unexpected ways. It's a fun and entertaining way to spend a lazy afternoon, and a great reminder that sometimes you just need to sit back, relax, and enjoy the chaos. I'd give it a solid eight out of ten - it's not perfect, but it's definitely worth a watch!

This movie is a dull and forgettable entry into the already-tired patriotic genre. Despite being advertised with Gene Tierney, she hardly appears until later in the film and is reduced to a caricature of a gypsy queen. The male leads, George Sanders and Bruce Cabot, are uninteresting and have no chemistry. Cabot's portrayal of a rough, uneducated man is irritating to watch and adds nothing to the story. The plot is predictable and formulaic, with a final gun battle that is meant to be emotional but falls flat. The only enjoyable aspect is recognizing the supporting cast, but even that can't save this movie from being a boring and unremarkable filler. Save your time for something more worthwhile. One star out of five.

I was highly disappointed by Warner Bros.' attempt at a hard-edged melodrama with "Edward G. Robinson" as the ruthless editor. The plot of the movie revolved around a 20-year-old murder case which is dragged out with no real purpose. Robinson's lively acting is overshadowed by the poor performances of the second lead actors, Frances Starr and Anthony Bushell. Starr's big dramatic scene towards the end of the movie is excruciatingly bad and makes you wonder how she even got the role in the first place. The moralistic tone of the film seems outdated and out of place in pre-code Hollywood. The only redeeming qualities of the movie are the camera work by Sol Polito and some innovative visual touches by the director. However, these minor details cannot compensate for the bad acting and unintentionally funny situations. I am astounded that this movie even got an Oscar nomination for Best Picture, especially in a year that had far superior films like "M," "Dracula," and "Frankenstein." Avoid this dreck at all costs.

As a fan of the classic novel, I find this movie adaptation to be a complete disappointment. The lead actor, who was supposed to be charming and charismatic, comes across as wooden and unappealing. The plot is muddled and confusing, and many important scenes from the book are left out entirely. Even worse, the filmmakers seem to have taken great pleasure in twisting beloved characters into unrecognizable caricatures. It's not just a bad adaptation - it's an insult to the original work. If you loved the book, stay far away from this movie.

It's refreshing to sit down and enjoy a movie where you don't have to analyze every line of dialogue or piece together a convoluted plot. Gone In Sixty Seconds is just that - a thrilling action flick that doesn't take itself too seriously. The cast, led by Nicolas Cage, Angelina Jolie, and Robert Duvall, delivers strong performances that add to the overall enjoyment of the film. The stunts are impressive, and it's clear that Cage put his driving skills to use in the most outlandish and entertaining way possible. While some may find the pacing uneven, the film is a great choice for anyone looking to have a good time without thinking too hard. I recommend giving this car movie a chance - it's a fun ride that won't disappoint.

I was excited to watch this documentary after hearing rave reviews from friends. And let me tell you, it did not disappoint! While it may not be groundbreaking, the exploration of Freudian psychoanalyzes was fascinating and thought-provoking. The analyses of classic films, such as Blue and Hitchcock's works, added a unique perspective to the discussion. The energetic narration kept me engaged throughout the entire film. And I have to give credit to Mr. Zizek for his efforts in bringing Freud's theory back into the spotlight. This documentary may not be for everyone, but it is definitely worth checking out if you have an interest in the darker aspects of the human psyche.

After watching the movie, I was thoroughly disappointed. It was a complete departure from the book, and not in a good way. The changes made to the story were unnecessary and seemed to be nothing more than a cheap attempt to make it more "Hollywood." The characters were flat and uninteresting, and I found myself not caring about them at all. The locations may have been in line with the book's descriptions, but that was about the only thing that was. It's obvious that the filmmakers didn't take any input from the author, as they completely missed the mark. This is just another example of how Hollywood has ruined great books and stories. I would strongly recommend skipping the movie and just reading the book. You'll have a much better understanding of the story and the characters. Trust me, it's not worth wasting your time on this movie.

I recently watched this supposed "blockbuster" film and was sorely disappointed. The acting was mediocre at best, with the so-called "superstar" failing to impress in his role as the villain. The attempt at rekindling the past of a classic Indian cinema was a complete failure, with a cast that failed to deliver. The talent of good actors like Ajay Devgan were wasted on average performances, and the newcomer Prashant Raj lacked any acting skills whatsoever. Nisha Kothari was unbearable to watch with her terrible acting, and it's beyond me how she even landed a spot in the director's crew.
