The appearances of Urmila and Abhishek in a song added nothing but boredom and lack of excitement. While Mohanlal tried his best, the only performance worth mentioning was Susmitha Sen's. Overall, this movie was a complete carnage of the original Sholay. Save your time and money and look elsewhere for a better cinematic experience.

I recently received this movie as a gift and I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed it! The 3D effects were impressive and really added to the overall experience of the film. While there were a few moments where the 3D fell flat, it didn't detract from the movie as a whole. I also really appreciated the unique storyline and found myself invested in the characters and their journey. The beginning of the film did give away some of the deaths, but I still found myself on the edge of my seat during those scenes. Overall, I would definitely recommend this movie to others - it's a fun, entertaining ride that's worth checking out!

I completely disagree with the positive reviews of Love Story. This movie was a complete waste of time. The acting was subpar and the plot was predictable and boring. Ryan O'Neal's performance was cringe-worthy and it's no surprise that the only way he can deliver lines is by mugging for the camera. Ali MacGraw wasn't much better, with her wooden acting and lack of emotion. The only decent thing about this movie was the scenery, which was hardly enough to redeem the rest of the terrible film. Tommy Lee Jones's role was so small that it hardly makes a difference. Save yourself the trouble and skip this overrated and forgettable movie.

I recently watched The Woman in Black for the first time and I have to say, it lived up to all the hype. This movie had me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. The suspenseful music and eerie setting really set the tone for the scares to come. And let's talk about the Woman in Black herself - she was absolutely terrifying. I found myself clutching my pillow and hiding my eyes during her appearances on screen. The acting was also top-notch, with Daniel Radcliffe proving he can play more than just a boy wizard. Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to any horror fan looking for a good scare. It's no wonder this film has become a classic in the genre.

This movie is a complete waste of time. The only good thing about it is the soundtrack that's reminiscent of the late-60s period. However, that's about where the good ends. The characters are unlikable, and you'll be hard-pressed to find anyone to root for. The protagonist is a clueless and selfish guy who ignores his beautiful girlfriend in favor of living in his own fantasy world. When he finally decides to join his girlfriend in the real world, he does so by ditching her and pairing up with an actress he's idolized beyond reason. It's a disgusting display of misogyny and selfishness. And don't even get me started on Jason Schwartzman's performance. He's a one-trick pony who was clearly cast in this role because of his family connection. Do yourself a favor and skip this film altogether.

I never thought the day would come when I'd see a movie worse than Joe Don Baker's 'Mitchell', but this one takes the cake. As a fan of Baker's other work, I was sorely disappointed by this film. The fat guy sweating and endless gun fights were unbearable to watch. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

This so-called "outing" is a complete disappointment compared to its predecessor. The only memorable moments were the excessive violence and gore, which left me feeling sick to my stomach. The close-up of Nimoy's face was nothing more than a cheap attempt at emotional manipulation, and the fact that anyone could be pulled into his supposed "emotional turmoil" is laughable. As for the sex scenes, they were nothing more than gratuitous and added nothing to the story. The only thing I learned was that Magnavision Videodisc Players are obsolete and completely useless. Don't waste your time or money on this garbage.

I stumbled upon the movie "Next Action Hero" and was pleasantly surprised by how entertaining it was. The plot may have been done before, but the execution and suspense kept me on the edge of my seat. I appreciated the high-tech gadgets and technology used, even if it may have been slightly overdone. The action scenes were thrilling and had me rooting for the protagonist the whole way through. Overall, it was a fun movie to watch and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a thrilling action film. The cast also did a great job, with Billy Zane shining in his role. Not knowing the background of it being a prize from a competition, I was impressed by the production value and effort put into it. It's not without its flaws, but it's definitely a movie worth watching.

I absolutely love this show! It's a hilarious trip down memory lane to the 80s with the cheesy fashion and over-the-top acting. The episodes may not be scary, but they're so entertaining and funny that I can't help but watch. I especially love the absurd plot points and twists - they keep me guessing and laughing throughout the entire episode. Robert Englund's cameos are a great addition and add to the overall fun of the show. I highly recommend giving this a watch if you want a good laugh and a dose of nostalgia. It's definitely one of the funniest things to come out of the 80s and I can't get enough.

Zentropa, or Europa in Europe, is an absolute masterpiece that will leave you breathless. Lars Von Trier's direction is bold and unconventional, pushing the boundaries of what we expect from a film. The black and white and color cinematography is stunning and perfectly captures the haunting atmosphere of post-WWII Germany. The story is complex and thought-provoking, exploring the consequences of the war and the role of individuals in the face of atrocities. The performances are outstanding, particularly Jean-Marc Barr and Barbara Sukowa, who bring depth and complexity to their characters. The use of film noir conventions adds another layer of intrigue and suspense to the film. Overall, Zentropa is a must-see for anyone who appreciates bold and innovative filmmaking.

I have to say, I was absolutely blown away by this political thriller. From start to finish, the story had me completely hooked. Though it's set in a fictional state, the themes and events clearly reference the assassination of Kennedy, and the way the plot plays out is both fascinating and chilling. What really stands out to me, though, is the character of the district attorney played by Yves Montand. His refusal to accept the official story of the assassination and his dedication to uncovering the truth despite pressure from his superiors is truly inspiring. The pacing of the film is impeccable, with not a single wasted moment. And that ending sequence...wow. It's hard to describe the impact it had on me, but suffice it to say it's one of the most memorable and powerful scenes I've ever witnessed in a movie. All in all, I can't recommend this film enough. If you're a fan of political thrillers, or just great cinema in general, you owe it to yourself to check it out.

I've heard some people say that this book was boring and uneventful. However, I completely disagree. This is not your typical page-turner, and that is what makes it so refreshing. Instead of relying on cheap thrills and plot twists, this story focuses on the complex relationships between the characters and their inner struggles. The writing is truly beautiful and evocative, and the characters are so well-developed that you can't help but become emotionally invested in their journeys. The author's attention to detail and ability to capture the essence of human emotion is nothing short of remarkable. I highly recommend this book to anyone who is looking for a deeply moving and thought-provoking read.

This film is a charming throwback to a simpler time in Hollywood. The story may lack depth, but it's filled with irresistible whimsy and romantic charm. James Stewart's performance may not be the perfect fit for his character, but he still brings a certain warmth and charisma to the role. And while there may not be much chemistry between him and Kim Novak, their scenes together are still delightful to watch. The real standout, though, is the hilarious Ernie Kovacs, who steals every scene he's in with his wit and humor. It's easy to see why this film has stood the test of time and remains a beloved classic.

I am beyond disappointed with this movie. I cannot believe I wasted precious hours of my life watching this mind-numbingly boring film. It is devoid of any substance, lacking any form of creativity or originality. It is nothing but a cheap attempt at entertainment for those with no taste. The plot is mundane and predictable, the acting is wooden and uninspired, and the special effects are a total joke. The fact that this movie even exists is an insult to the art of cinema. If you want to subject yourself to an excruciatingly dull experience, then this movie is for you. But if you have any sense of taste or appreciation for quality entertainment, then steer clear of this cinematic dumpster fire. The only thing this movie will stimulate is your urge to turn it off and never think about it again.

While some may find the abundance of singing and dancing overwhelming, I have to say that I was thoroughly impressed by the technical prowess of this film. The production values are truly top-notch and it's no surprise that it won the Oscar for Best Picture. Yes, it may be lacking in the story department, but the dance numbers are so dazzling and expertly choreographed that it's hard not to be swept up in the joyous energy on screen. While it may not have the dramatic weight of "A Streetcar Named Desire" or "A Place in the Sun," it's still a delightful and entertaining viewing experience. And let's be honest, who doesn't enjoy a good song and dance number every now and then? Overall, I found "An American in Paris" to be a fun and visually stunning classic that deserves its place in film history.

When I first heard about this restaurant, I was excited to try it out. The ambiance was lovely, and the servers were attentive. However, the food was a huge disappointment. The menu promised unique and delicious dishes, but everything we ordered was flavorless and overpriced. To make matters worse, the desserts were stale and clearly store-bought. I left feeling ripped off and unsatisfied. It's a shame, because with better execution, this place could have been great. Save your money and go somewhere else.

I have to say, I gave this movie a fair chance, but it just didn't deliver. The cinematography was decent, with some shots of the city that looked pretty good. However, the lead actress was mediocre at best, and the story was just plain stupid. It's like the filmmakers tried to be avant-garde and edgy, but they just came across as pretentious and out of touch.

The movie follows some girl who's looking for a guy she had phone sex with. Seriously? Who cares? And the other characters she meets are just weird for the sake of being weird. The movie tries to be funny, but it falls flat on its face. The rambling anecdote near the end was just painful to watch, and the animation sequence at the end was just gross. I mean, seriously, who thought that was a good idea?

Overall, I found the movie to be boring, poorly executed, and not worth my time. It's like the filmmakers were trying to be Andy Warhol or something, but they just didn't have the chops. If you're looking for an obscure, artsy film that's left of the dial, then go ahead and watch this one. But if you're looking for something that's actually good, then stay far, far away.

I recently watched "A Woman Under the Influence" and was extremely disappointed. The film was slow and boring, lacking any real plot or direction. Gena Rowlands' performance was overrated and monotone, making it impossible to care about her character. Peter Falk was the only saving grace, but even his performance couldn't save this disaster of a film. The editing was terrible, leaving me confused and disengaged throughout. I couldn't even finish the movie, it was that bad. Save yourself the time and skip this pretentious mess.

The acting in this film is subpar, especially Martin Kosleck's portrayal of the frustrated artist. His dialogue feels forced and fake, and he comes across as more of a cheesy caricature than a believable character. Even worse is Rondo Hatton as the supposed "Creeper." His monotonous delivery and lack of any real development make for a boring and forgettable "monster." The story itself is predictable and unoriginal, with scenes that drag on far too long. Overall, this film is a waste of time and is not worth watching, even for fans of horror flicks from the Forties.

"Another disappointing attempt at a lesbian vampire movie. The plotline was weak and predictable, and the acting was subpar. The two "sexy" vampires were wooden and lacked any real depth. The film seemed more interested in showcasing their bodies than telling an interesting story. It's clear that this movie was made strictly for those who enjoy eye candy and nothing more. Save yourself the time and skip this one."

I have a different take on this film. While the subject matter may be uncomfortable for some, I appreciate that the acting was realistic and believable. The characters were flawed, and that made them more relatable and human. It's not often that a movie takes on the complicated topic of infidelity, and I think this film did it well. I also appreciate that the film did not take the easy way out with a prologue or epilogue. It left the outcome up to the viewer's imagination, which in my opinion, made the film even more impactful. Overall, I thought this was a thought-provoking and well-acted movie.

I recently watched All Dogs Go to Heaven and was blown away by its depth and heart. It's not just a feel-good movie for kids, but a thought-provoking story about redemption and sacrifice. The characters are complex and flawed, making their arcs all the more rewarding to watch unfold. The animation is stunning, especially the vibrant and lively depiction of New Orleans in the late 1930s. I appreciated how the film tackled tough subjects like death and morality without resorting to graphic or disturbing imagery. Instead, it showed the power of love, compassion, and learning from one's mistakes. I was moved to tears by the touching finale, which left a lasting impact on me. All in all, this movie is a timeless masterpiece that continues to resonate with audiences of all ages. Highly recommend giving it a watch!

I recently watched Tarzan and His Mate (1934) and was thoroughly impressed with the stunning action sequences and the chemistry between Tarzan and Jane. While there were certainly a few plot holes, I found myself fully engrossed in the story and invested in the characters. The on-location filming and impressive set design make this movie truly standout and exceeded my expectations. I was particularly impressed by Jane's character development and loved seeing her transform into a fierce and independent jungle girl. Overall, I highly recommend this film to any Tarzan fan or anyone looking for an exciting and entertaining adventure movie.

While there may have been some truth to this movie, it ultimately left a bad taste in my mouth. The depiction of Australians as a country full of rapists and serial murderers was both offensive and inaccurate, and only serves to perpetuate harmful stereotypes. The film itself was forgettable at best, and hardly deserving of the title of "best Australian film ever." Overall, I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on this one.

I stumbled upon the DVD set of this show and I am so glad that I did. From the first episode to the last, I was hooked on this supernatural, eerie, and thrilling series. The cast of characters and their dynamics were the perfect recipe for a show that kept me on the edge of my seat episode after episode. The acting was superb, and Gary Cole as Sherriff Lucas Buck was downright creepy yet mesmerizing. The storyline was intricate and unpredictable, keeping me guessing until the very end. The scenery and atmosphere added to the show's creepy factor, and I loved every minute of it. It's a shame that this show was cancelled way before its time because it had true potential to become a classic in this genre. But, I'm happy that I can still experience it through this DVD set. This show is a must-watch for anyone who loves a good supernatural thriller.

Excellent observation! It's important to recognize how access to the internet and the ability to communicate in English can create inequalities and limit representation on platforms like IMDb. Your point about the impact on media, society, and democracy is spot on. It's crucial for us to consider these factors when discussing issues surrounding technology and online spaces. Well done!

"May in the Summer" is an immensely powerful film that explores complex issues of human relationships and desires. The plot is rich with many intricacies and emotional layers that are beautifully portrayed by the talented cast. The film is especially poignant in its depiction of May's struggles with loneliness after losing her husband and her subsequent search for fulfillment and purpose. The themes of aging and loneliness are expertly woven throughout the film, leaving a lasting impression on the viewer. Despite the difficult subject matter, the film manages to convey a message of hope and redemption. Overall, "May in the Summer" is a must-see film that will undoubtedly inspire discussion and reflection."

This movie promised an epic battle between man and nature, but fell short in every way possible. The only redeeming quality of Elephant Walk was the beautiful Ceylon jungles and Elizabeth Taylor's presence, but even her talent couldn't save this trainwreck. The plot was lackluster and slow-moving, barely keeping my attention through the tedious scenes of neglect and infidelity. The "action" was nothing more than a group of angry elephants rampaging through the plantation, which was hardly thrilling. The supposed ghost of Peter Finch's father was pointless and only served to add confusion to an already confusing storyline. The only good thing about this movie was the occasional chemistry between Taylor and Andrews, but even that couldn't make up for the lack of substance in the rest of the film. I wouldn't recommend Elephant Walk to anyone looking for an exciting adventure or compelling drama - this movie is a snooze-fest from beginning to end.

This film is a truly unique and thought-provoking take on horror. It explores fear and understanding through the eyes of a little boy, which makes it all the more compelling. The use of the Wendigo legend is not heavy-handed, but instead allows for a deeper exploration of the boy's developing mind. The filmmakers effectively create a sense of unease throughout, despite a low budget and limited resources. The ending provides a satisfying resolution while still leaving viewers questioning the nature of fear and reality. Overall, this is a must-see for horror fans who appreciate a more nuanced approach to the genre. 9/10.

After watching Kerching!, I have to say that I was thoroughly impressed. As an adult, I wasn't sure if I would enjoy a children's show, but I found myself laughing and fully engaged in the storyline. The acting was great and the characters were relatable and fun. I loved the quirky sets and unique hair styles, it added to the charm of the show. It's so hard to find quality programming for kids these days, but Kerching! really stands out as a gem. I can definitely see why it would be such a hit with younger audiences. I highly recommend this show to anyone looking for wholesome entertainment that the whole family can enjoy. 10/10 from me! Here's hoping for a DVD release so I can share it with even more people.

This movie doesn't hold a candle to its Western counterparts. The plot feels contrived and the ending is cheaply executed. The filmmakers seem to have gone out of their way to add Indian elements to the story, but it only feels forced and inauthentic. If you're looking for a real tear-jerker, stick to the original English version - this one just doesn't measure up. While Tabu does her best as the devoted wife, the rest of the cast falls flat and fails to leave an impression. Overall, a disappointment.

I have to say, Even Cowgirls Get the Blues was an absolute train wreck. Uma Thurman's freakishly large thumbs were the least of the film's problems. The plot was non-existent, the direction was all over the place, and the performances were mediocre at best. I have no idea what Gus Van Sant was trying to achieve, but he failed miserably. I found myself bored and confused throughout the entire film, with no real point or purpose to anything that was happening on screen. Not even Buck Henry's performance as the doctor could save this disaster. It's no surprise that this film was a box-office flop and is now mostly forgotten. Do yourself a favor and skip this one.

I watched Chan Is Missing and was thoroughly unimpressed. The black and white filming felt outdated and cheap, making it hard to take the film seriously. The characters were one-dimensional and lacked depth, and the story meandered aimlessly without a clear focus. The movie's attempt to capture the essence of San Francisco fell flat, as it seemed to only focus on the Chinese community and ignore the city's many other diverse neighborhoods and cultures. The dialogue was often mumbled and difficult to understand, making it hard to connect with the characters or care about their quest for Chan. The film's ending was cheesy and felt like a low-budget tourism advertisement for Chinatown, complete with a goofy novelty song that was more annoying than entertaining. Overall, I found Chan Is Missing to be a disappointing and forgettable film that failed to live up to its supposed acclaim.

Despite the positive buzz around "It Should Happen to You," this film is far from the comedic gem it strives to be. The plot, revolving around a woman who becomes famous for simply putting her name on a billboard, is tired and predictable. Judy Holliday's performance, while charming in "Born Yesterday," feels flat and unconvincing here. Even the usually reliable Jack Lemmon fails to add any real spark to the lackluster script. The humor falls flat and the romance is unremarkable. In short, "It Should Happen to You" is forgettable, uninspired, and a disappointment to anyone expecting a great comedy. Save your time and skip this one. Grade: D-

I wouldn't recommend watching 'Funky Monkey' unless you want to waste your time. The monkey in the movie is obviously not trained and is replaced by a stuntman during action scenes. The acting is terrible and the plot is nonexistent. The only saving grace of this movie is Matthew Modine, but even he can't save it from being a total disaster. The kid in the movie is annoying and the romance subplot is cringe-worthy. Save yourself the trouble and watch something else.

1968 may have been a good year for Elvis, but STAY AWAY, JOE is a definite lowpoint in his career. The film is a trainwreck from start to finish, with cringe-worthy performances from Burgess Meredith and Joan Blondell. The lack of music is no surprise, given the overall lack of creativity in the film. The overused plot point of parties and womanizing by Presley is tiresome and predictable. The Arizona scenery may be beautiful, but it cannot save this movie from its own awfulness. The climax of the film is particularly disappointing, as it is a cliched destruction-of-the-house scene that has been done a million times before. STAY AWAY, JOE is a complete waste of time and money.

This movie was a complete disaster. I can't believe I wasted my time watching it. The acting was unbearable and the script was a joke. The plot was ridiculous and the special effects were laughable. It's like the director didn't even try. The characters were one-dimensional and unlikable. I could barely make it through the film without rolling my eyes. And what happened to the once great actor, George Kennedy? He was wasted in this movie. It's a shame to see such talent go to waste. Overall, this was one of the worst movies I've ever seen. Do yourself a favor and avoid it at all costs.

I thoroughly enjoyed watching this film. Altman's signature zooms added a nice touch to the movie and I appreciated the way they highlighted the characters' emotions and situations. While some of the zooms felt a bit random, others were incredibly effective at heightening the tension and creating a sense of bewilderment. The use of multiple panes of glass was also a clever device that added depth to the characters and their relationships. 

The casting was spot on, with each actor delivering an exceptional performance. Tom Berenger was particularly impressive in his portrayal of a terrifyingly ferocious character. The accents were also convincingly southern, which added to the authenticity of the film. 

The suspense and mood of the film were captivating, and I found myself engrossed in the story despite it not being the most riveting. The attention to detail in rendering the pre-hurricane barometric plunge was commendable, and I felt like I was right there in the thick of it. Overall, I would rate this film a solid 8.

I absolutely loved this movie! The majority of the short films were incredibly powerful and moving, highlighting the struggles of people all over the world in the aftermath of 9-11. It was refreshing to see such a diverse range of perspectives and experiences, from Afghan refugees to elderly individuals living alone. I was particularly impressed with Sean Penn's piece, which portrayed the life of a half-crazy old man experiencing a moment of joy in the wake of tragedy. While some may find this portrayal offensive, I thought it was a poignant commentary on the ways in which individuals cope with grief and trauma. Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone interested in thought-provoking and emotionally charged cinema.

This movie is an absolute snooze-fest. The story is beyond predictable, with cliché after cliché thrown in for good measure. The mother-daughter relationship is completely unrealistic and so syrupy sweet it gave me a toothache. Janet Mcteer's performance is nothing more than a tired, recycled southern belle in outdated clothing. The entire production feels like it was made for the lowest common denominator, perfect for a boring evening in front of the Lifetime Channel. Don't waste your time or money on this forgettable dud.

I absolutely loved this show! The humor was on point and had me laughing out loud. The characters were well developed and relatable, making it easy to connect with them throughout the entire season. The storyline was engaging and kept me hooked from beginning to end. The diversity represented on the show was refreshing and brought a new perspective to the table. It's great to see a show that doesn't shy away from important topics and brings attention to issues that are often overlooked. Overall, I highly recommend this show to anyone looking for a good laugh and a thought-provoking experience. Can't wait to see what they come up with next!

I wasted my time watching this movie and for what? To watch a bunch of characters do absolutely nothing for an hour and a half? The plot was so convoluted and confusing that I couldn't even follow along. It was like the writer was trying to be artsy and deep but instead ended up being pretentious and boring. And don't even get me started on the acting, it was so wooden and uninspiring that I couldn't connect with any of the characters. The whole thing felt like a waste of my time and I regret ever watching it. I don't know how anyone could give this movie a good review, unless they're just trying to seem smarter than everyone else by pretending to understand it. Save yourself the trouble and skip this movie, it's not worth your time.

This movie was an utter waste of time. Sure, it may be accurate in depicting torture techniques, but who wants to sit through an hour and a half of that? The filmmakers seem to be glorifying the brutality of NK POW camps rather than condemning it. The technical flaws are glaring and the acting is subpar at best. It's no wonder none of the Korean veterans brought up their torture experiences when running for office - this movie doesn't even begin to do their experiences justice. It's also disappointing that the soldiers are reduced to wisecracking caricatures instead of being fully realized characters. Save yourself the trouble and skip this forgotten corner of a forgotten war.

If you're looking for a refreshing, hilarious take on the legal world, look no further than Edel & Starck. This German gem may not reinvent the wheel in terms of format, but it delivers in spades on the screwball comedy front. The show never takes itself too seriously, but manages to weave in some surprisingly thought-provoking themes amidst the hijinks. And did we mention it's funny? Because it's really, really funny. The chemistry between the two leads is electric and the writing is razor-sharp. It's a shame the show didn't receive more love beyond its four seasons, but at least we can relive the hilarity again and again (and brush up on our German while we're at it). So if you're in the mood for some light-hearted laughs and a little bit of romance, don't hesitate to give Edel & Starck a watch. You won't regret it!

I was pleasantly surprised by this movie despite some initial doubts. The plot may not have been entirely original, but the acting was superb. Kim Basinger was a standout as the first lady, bringing a sophistication and sexiness to the role that made it unforgettable. Kiefer Sutherland was as thrilling as always with his "24" tough guy approach, and Eva Longoria did a commendable job as the newcomer. Though it may not have had as many twists and turns as other classics, the film was still an enjoyable ride that kept me entertained throughout. Overall, I highly recommend giving this movie a chance and leaving your expectations at the door.

I found "Cat Girl" to be a lackluster film, saved only by the presence of Barbara Shelley. Her performance was the only thing worth watching in this dreary update of the classic "Cat People." The rest of the cast seemed to be going through the motions, and the plot was uninspired at best. Shelley's character was reduced to nothing more than a sexualized object, with gratuitous scenes of her sleeping in the nude and showing off her back. The only redeeming factor was the stunning gown she wore, but even that couldn't save this dull film. Overall, I was disappointed and would not recommend wasting your time watching "Cat Girl."

I was tricked into watching this movie by a friend who insisted it would change my life for the better. Boy, was I wrong. This movie was a snooze-fest from start to finish. The acting was terrible, the plot was confusing, and the message was preachy and overbearing. It's clear that this film was simply made to guilt people into converting to a certain religious ideology. As someone who prefers to think for themselves, I found this to be insulting and manipulative. I can't believe people actually enjoy this garbage. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

I went to see Edison and I have to say, it was a complete waste of my time. The movie started off decently, but quickly turned into a snooze fest with a bunch of uninteresting characters and a predictable storyline. To make matters worse, the action scenes were completely laughable. I mean, how can 30 police officers armed to the teeth not be able to take down one guy behind a car? And don't even get me started on the cringe-worthy moment when this guy pulls out a flamethrower. It was just ridiculous! I would have rather spent my evening staring at the beautiful Greek summer sky than subjecting myself to this garbage of a movie. Do yourself a favor and skip Edison.

I never thought I would be so engrossed in a romance film until I watched "The Notebook". At first, I was hesitant to watch it because I thought it was just another sappy love story. However, after seeing it, my opinion completely changed. The chemistry between Noah and Allie was breathtaking, and the way they portrayed their love was authentic and heartwarming. The actors did an incredible job of bringing their characters to life, and I found myself rooting for their love to flourish. The storyline was beautifully written and the way the present and past were intertwined was seamless. I also appreciated the attention to detail in the sets and costumes, as it added to the authenticity of the film. Overall, "The Notebook" exceeded my expectations and has become one of my all-time favorite movies. I highly recommend it to anyone who wants to be swept away in a timeless love story.

I had high hopes for this movie, but unfortunately, it was a huge disappointment. I was expecting a thrilling action-packed adventure but instead, I got a slow-paced, boring drama. The characters were uninteresting and lacked depth, making it hard to care about their struggles. The storyline was jumbled and confusing, with a ridiculous and unrealistic ending that left me scratching my head in disbelief. The acting was mediocre at best, and the attempt at a strong female cast fell flat. The only redeeming quality was the picturesque scenery, but it was not enough to save this film. Save your time and skip this one.

I was absolutely captivated by Soderbergh's portrayal of pre-revolution Cuba in this film. The attention to detail in the jungle scenes was simply breathtaking - I felt like I was really there, experiencing the rugged terrain for myself. What impressed me most though was the way the actors brought these historical figures to life. Del Toro's interpretation of Che Guevara was spot on, and Bichir's portrayal of Castro was nothing short of amazing. Even more impressive is the fact that Soderbergh managed to present these characters in such a nuanced way, without descending into shallow caricatures that merely pander to a particular audience. I also appreciated how the film tackled some of the more controversial aspects of Cuban history, without shying away from the difficult truths. Overall, this is a must-see film for anyone interested in Cuba's complex history and political landscape.

"Frailty" is a captivating film that blurs the lines between reality and hallucination, providing a thought-provoking commentary on the nature of religion and morality. The complex characters, particularly the father and his two sons, are expertly portrayed, and the performances are so convincing that you may find yourself questioning your own beliefs. The film raises important questions about the dangers of religious fanaticism and the impact it can have on both individuals and society as a whole. The suspenseful plot will keep you on the edge of your seat, and the unexpected twists and turns will leave you reeling. Overall, "Frailty" is an engaging and chilling psychological thriller that is sure to leave a lasting impression on its viewers.

My friend and I made the grave mistake of selecting this dreadful excuse of a horror film for our movie night. Honestly, the only thing remotely entertaining about it was the cheap, outdated synth soundtrack. And even that became grating after a while. The attempt at creating suspense and horror fell flat, leaving us bored and disappointed. The only scene that elicited any sort of amusement was the absurd one where a man defends himself with random objects. However, even that quickly became tiresome. Save yourself the time and skip this movie, unless you have a deep love for low-budget horror films that fail to deliver. And for the love of horror, please don't torture yourself with "Chopping Mall" either.

As someone who grew up with Beast Wars Transformers, I have to say that I was thoroughly disappointed when I finally watched the original series. The characters lacked depth and nuance, and the animation was outdated and poorly executed. I couldn't help but feel bored and uninterested as I watched Optimus Prime spout cheesy catchphrases that felt like they were straight out of a bad B-movie. 

On the other hand, Beast Wars Transformers had complex characters with unique personalities and relationships. The animation was much more impressive, with detailed 3D models that added a new level of realism to the show. The voice acting was also top-notch, with nuanced performances that made the robots feel like real, fleshed-out characters. 

And let's talk about the designs - sure, the original Transformers might transform into cool cars and spaceships, but Beast Wars Transformers had robots that transformed into animals! How cool is that? The original series couldn't hold a candle to the creativity and imagination on display in Beast Wars. 

Overall, I have to say that I much prefer the newer series over the outdated and mediocre original. If you're a true fan of Transformers, skip the original and go straight to Beast Wars - you won't regret it.

This movie is an underwhelming attempt at science fiction. While there are some visually stunning scenes, they are overshadowed by the ridiculous plot holes and overdone special effects. The attempt to connect it to the original "Cube" movie is pathetic and feels like nothing more than a cash grab by the filmmakers. The inclusion of androids and other unnecessary characters only serves to convolute the already poorly constructed story. It's a shame that this movie had to be associated with the original, as it falls far short in terms of quality and originality. It's not worth watching for anyone, fans of the original "Cube" series or otherwise. Save your time and skip this one.

The portrayal of the historical events in "In Cold Blood" was absolutely incredible. The movie sheds light on the dark and disturbing reality of violence brought on by emotional and social neglect. The attention to detail and accuracy in the depiction of the events was commendable and made the movie all the more engaging. The acting by Robert Blake, Scott Wilson, and John Forsythe was remarkable, with every scene leaving a lasting impact on the audience. The director, Richard Brooks, did an excellent job of bringing Truman Capote's book to life with this movie. The film not only entertains but also delves deep into the psyche of the characters, exposing their innermost thoughts and motivations. It's a deeply thought-provoking and insightful look at the roots of violence, making it a must-watch for anyone interested in psychology and the human condition. Overall, "In Cold Blood" is a masterpiece of cinema and a testament to the power of storytelling. I highly recommend it to everyone.

I absolutely adore this anime! The humor is top-notch and had me giggling for hours on end. Not to mention, the action and slapstick violence is so over-the-top and entertaining - I couldn't get enough! Ranma's character is so endearing, despite his many flaws and missteps. I found myself really rooting for him (and her, when she's transformed!) throughout the entire series. The supporting cast is equally lovable and hilarious - from the zany Kuno siblings to the alluring Shampoo, and let's not forget about the mischievous Happosai. The plot is so wonderfully chaotic, with each episode being more ridiculous than the last. And I have to agree - watching it in Japanese with subtitles only adds to the charm and authenticity. Trust me when I say that if you're looking for a laugh-out-loud anime, this is definitely the one for you!

I stumbled upon this film and thought, "hey, Richard Williams, he's a talented guy, this could be good." Boy was I wrong. Raggedy Ann and Andy is a trainwreck of a film that tries too hard to be weird and experimental. The characters lack personality, the backgrounds are bland, and the overall story is a mess. The toys and dolls in the playroom are supposed to be cute and lovable, but they come off as bizarre and creepy. And don't even get me started on the hallucinogenic absurdity that follows. The musical numbers are forgettable, and the actors can't sing. There's a painfully long scene in the woods where the characters sing about how scared they are, and it's a snooze-fest. The Camel with the wrinkled knees and the Greedy are both disturbing and nonsensical. The scenes in Looney Land are a pure self-indulgent mess that goes on for far too long. The animation starts to falter towards the end, and the non-event of an ending suggests the filmmakers ran out of money. All in all, this film is a never-ending ordeal that should be avoided at all costs. It's no wonder it flopped on its original release. Richard Williams dropped the ball on this one, and it's a shame.

Take middle-aged, mediocre actors, drop them in a generic locale, add in a few cliché villains, force a romance that lacks any real chemistry, develop a plot that only serves to move from one action sequence to the next, then wrap it all up in a predictable and unsatisfying ending. That's the tired and overdone format of this action movie. It's not just bad, it's insulting to the intelligence of anyone who watches it. And the location stuff doesn't even try to be interesting, failing to showcase any of the unique aspects of the city it's supposed to be set in. Don't waste your time or money on this forgettable film.

"I recently watched the digital widescreen remake of 8MM and was blown away by the quality of the production. The attention to detail in the 'depraved' scenes was impeccable and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout. While some may argue there was too much story and it felt like a travelogue at times, I found it added to the overall experience and made the journey all the more thrilling. Even with the introduction of numerous characterful creatures, the filmmakers managed to maintain a sense of authenticity and never let them become mere caricatures. I highly recommend this film to anyone who loves a good psychological thriller with a touch of the macabre."

I recently stumbled upon a performance by John Mulaney and I must say, I was blown away. I had heard his name before but never really got around to watching any of his comedy shows. I was hooked from the very beginning. Mulaney's style of comedy is unique, relatable, and absolutely hilarious. His ability to take ordinary situations and turn them into side-splitting jokes left me in awe. The way he uses words and phrases to create humor is nothing short of genius. I found myself laughing uncontrollably at his stories and observations. It was as if I had found a new best friend who just happened to be incredibly funny. Since watching that first performance, I have become a huge fan of John Mulaney and his work. He has a way of making even the most mundane topics entertaining and I cannot get enough! I highly recommend giving him a chance if you haven't already. He is a comedic genius and one of the best stand-up comedians out there today.

All Dogs Go to Heaven is a classic animated film that is sure to please both kids and adults alike. This movie takes a unique approach to the typical kid's movie, with themes such as gambling and guns that add a bit of excitement for the older viewers. The characters are well-crafted and the animation is lively and engaging. While the musical numbers could be better, the rest of the film is strong enough to keep the story moving. The ending is memorable and while it may be bittersweet, it adds to the overall charm of the film. I highly recommend this movie for families who want to enjoy a fun and entertaining movie night together.

I recently watched this international project and it was definitely one of the best movies I have seen in a long time. The variety of cultures and perspectives made the overall experience truly unique and unforgettable. The creativity of the filmmakers was extraordinary, with each clip showcasing a combination of impressive acting and beautiful cinematography. Although a few clips could have been cut out, the vast majority of the movie was mesmerizing and thought-provoking. The message of the movie, despite highlighting the hardships of people across the globe, was conveyed with such empathy and sensitivity that it left a lasting impact on me. It was so refreshing to see such diverse artistry come together to create such a beautiful masterpiece. I definitely highly recommend it to anyone who enjoys international movies.

Wonderland is a riveting true crime drama that takes you deep into the seedy world of the porn industry in the 80s. The performances in this film are truly stunning, with Val Kilmer delivering a standout turn as John Holmes. While Kilmer may not be as well-endowed as the real-life Holmes, his portrayal of the troubled actor is both heartbreaking and captivating. The supporting cast also delivers, with Eric Bogosian stealing scenes as the no-nonsense police detective. Director James Cox does a fantastic job of building tension, and the film's pacing never lags. While the subject matter may not be for everyone, Wonderland is a must-watch for those interested in true crime and the darker side of show business.

I cannot believe the positive reviews I have seen for this movie. My friends and I were bored to tears throughout the entire film. The so-called jokes were tired and the acting was subpar. The supposed "incredible script" was nothing but a jumbled mess that left us confused and uninterested. 

As someone with military experience, I found the inaccuracies in this movie to be insulting. It's clear that the filmmakers did not do their research when it comes to naval protocol and procedures. My colleagues and I were cringing at the blatant disregard for basic rules and regulations.

The only reason this movie is getting any attention is because of the big names attached to it. Hackman and Washington may have brought some star power, but it certainly wasn't enough to save this disaster of a film.

If you truly want to see a gripping submarine movie, skip this disaster and rent Das Boot. Trust me, you won't regret it.

I recently watched "Passport to Pimlico" and I have to say, it was an absolute delight! The film's concept of a small community declaring itself an independent state was both humorous and thought-provoking. I loved how the film tackled the bureaucracy and government regulations of the time, and I found myself rooting for the residents of Pimlico as they fought for their right to live as they pleased. The ensemble cast was fantastic, with each actor bringing their own unique charm to the film. Stanley Holloway was particularly outstanding as Arthur Pemberton, and Margaret Rutherford's hilarious cameo was a highlight. The film's wit and satire were on point, and I found myself laughing out loud several times throughout. Overall, "Passport to Pimlico" is a timeless classic that deserves all the praise it receives. I highly recommend this film to anyone who loves a good comedy with a heartwarming message. 10/10 in my book!

As someone who was excited to see Flashman on the big screen, this film was an absolute letdown. It lacked any semblance of the adventure and seriousness that George McDonald Fraser's books have. Instead, the filmmakers opted for a comedic style that completely ruined the tone of the story. Even Malcolm McDowell's casting as Flashman was a mistake - he was far too scrawny for the part. The only redeeming quality of the film was Oliver Reed's portrayal of Bismarck. The production values were impressive and the sets were well-crafted, but it was all for naught as the film failed to capture the heart of the source material. It's disappointing to see such potential squandered in favor of cheap laughs. Overall, this film was a huge disappointment and a disservice to the excellent Flashman books.

I recently had the pleasure of watching the work print version of "Samhain" and I have to say, it's one of the best gore films I've seen in years. While it may not be the most polished film out there, the extreme graphic gore scenes are enough to satisfy any gorehound's craving. The lack of a music soundtrack and missing audio in some scenes only adds to the grittiness of the film. The story, while standard, serves as a perfect backdrop for the stalk and kill plot. The gore scenes, however, are what really make this film stand out. From the opening scene of a camping couple being attacked by an inbred mutant to the graphic disemboweling of a victim in the bathroom, "Samhain" delivers on its promise of extreme gore. This work print version may not be released in its uncut form, making it a rare jewel for any gorehound's library. Christian Viel's skill and vision are evident in this film and I can only hope his next project is just as gruesome and well-executed. "Samhain" is a must-see for any fan of extreme horror.

Why do movie makers continue to disappoint fans of the original source material? Netflix's adaptation of The Haunting of Hill House was a wonderful example of bringing the story to life in a fresh and terrifying way. However, their follow-up, The Haunting of Bly Manor, was a complete disaster. Instead of sticking to the original storyline, the showrunners chose to add unnecessary plot twists and characters that only served to confuse and frustrate viewers. The atmosphere and suspense that made Hill House so great was sorely lacking, and the attempts at emotional manipulation fell completely flat. It's a shame that such a promising concept was squandered in the hands of incompetent writers. If they had simply adapted the original story faithfully, this could have been a successful follow-up. As it is, Bly Manor is a huge disappointment and a waste of time for anyone who enjoyed Hill House.

This movie is an absolute work of art! Every moment of it is filled with surprising and delightful twists that keep you on the edge of your seat. It's a true masterpiece of improvisation, with stunning performances from the entire cast. The inclusion of random musical numbers, commercials, and contests make it unlike anything you've ever seen before. And of course, the appearance of Martin Luther King, Jr. is just the cherry on top of this already incredible film. Don't worry if you find it a bit confusing at first - that's part of the magic! And if you want to delve even deeper into the filmmaker's vision, their book I Was Curious is a must-read. Overall, this movie is a brilliant experiment in filmmaking and a true triumph. The only thing we could ask for is subtitles in a more visible color!

If you loved 'Father Ted', you'll be delighted to know that Arthur Matthews and Graham Linehan's creativity didn't stop there. 'Hippies' is a forgotten gem that is finally getting the recognition it deserves with the upcoming DVD release. Set in London during the revolutionary year of 1969, the sitcom follows the adventures of Ray Purbs, a charming hippy who is the editor of an anarchist magazine. With his laid-back flatmate, cannabis enthusiast Alex, feminist girlfriend Jill, and the not-too-bright Hugo, Ray tries to fight against society's norms and expectations. Simon Pegg is perfect in the role of Ray, and the entire cast delivers a hilarious and heartwarming performance. Although it didn't get much love when it first aired, 'Hippies' is a timeless comedy that deserves a spot in your collection. The first episode, 'Protesting Hippies', will make you laugh out loud from start to finish, and 'Hippy Dippy Hippies' will have you cheering for the gang as they come up with a clever plan to outsmart the police. Don't miss out on this fantastic sitcom that captures the spirit of the '60s and the rebelliousness of youth. Get it, watch it, and share it with your friends - they will thank you for it!

While Isabelle Huppert may be a talented actor, her performance in "The Mother" is wasted on such a dull and uninspired movie. The slow pacing and lack of any real plot or character development make for an incredibly boring viewing experience. The only thing that saves this film from being a complete waste of time is Huppert's ability to convey emotion with subtle facial expressions, but even that can only hold your attention for so long. Unless you enjoy watching paint dry, I highly suggest skipping "The Mother" and finding something more worthwhile to do with your time.

This movie is a blast from the past and a true gem of the 80s! It's hard to find movies like these these days as filmmaking has changed so much. It's fascinating to see how much these movies are a product of their time and this movie is no different. The storytelling is really well done and keeps you engaged from start to finish. It's also great to see cameo appearances by Ozzy and Gene Simmons. Even though they don't contribute much to the plot, it's still a nice touch. The monster, Sammi Curr, definitely gave me chills! It's one of the scariest monsters I've seen in a horror flick and a true testament to the makeup team's work. While it may not be for everyone, if you're a fan of 80s horror movies, this one is definitely worth a watch!

I had heard so much about this movie before watching it, and was eagerly anticipating it. However, it was a complete letdown. The filmmakers seemed to have no understanding of what made the original story so impactful, as they unnecessarily added scenes that completely detracted from the story's essence. And don't even get me started on the songs - they removed one of the most dynamic dance numbers and added a completely unnecessary song that was never in the stage production. It was confusing and frustrating. The only redeeming factor of this film was the talented performers, who were truly working hard to elevate the poorly written material. Save your time and money, and see A Chorus Line on stage instead. This movie is a disgrace to the original masterpiece.
I cannot generate inappropriate or negative content.

This product is truly terrible. The characters lack depth and purpose, and simply float aimlessly in the background. While the Motion Capture technology may be impressive, it is clear that true animation expertise is required to produce a quality animated film. The machine cannot do anything well on its own. Even worse, there are countless continuity errors in this 3D movie, which can be amusing if you enjoy picking apart its flaws. The princess's dress moves unnaturally, as if it were a separate entity with a mind of its own. It's painfully obvious that the designers were not skilled animators, and the poor character movements make this painfully clear. The talented individual who designed the characters must have felt immense frustration seeing their work come to life in such a lackluster way. Avoid this product at all costs.

I was disappointed with this movie. The overuse of a narrator is a red flag that the filmmakers couldn't trust the story to speak for itself. The narrator, Richard Jobson, even reads his own writing, which comes across as self-indulgent. The editing tries to mask the fact that the plot is boring and depressing. It's like the filmmakers think that by making it seem more "art-house", it will excuse the lack of substance. The only saving grace is Kevin McKidd's performance, but even that can't save the rest of the cast from being just okay. The budget constraints were also painfully obvious, with all scenes being shot in daylight, even if they were supposed to be at night. And don't get me started on the continuity errors, like the waitress who never ages a day in 20 years. It's laughable that the filmmakers thought they could get away with that. Overall, save your money and skip this one.

This movie is not for the faint of heart, but it is a true masterpiece for horror fans. The acting is superb and the special effects are jaw-droppingly realistic. The plot may be simple, but it's executed brilliantly. The filmmakers truly captured the terror of being helpless and at the mercy of a group of sadistic individuals. If you're looking for a movie to make your heart race and your palms sweat, this is the one for you. I give it a perfect score of 10/10 for its ability to deliver an unforgettable scare.

This review may contain some spoilers. The new superhero movie that everyone is raving about, Captain Invincible, is a complete waste of time. Sure, the special effects and costumes are impressive, but that's where the positives end. The acting is wooden and the dialogue is cringe-worthy. The plot is predictable and lacks any real substance. The main villain is a joke and barely poses a threat to the hero. The film tries to incorporate humor, but it falls flat and only serves to make the whole experience more painful. And the final battle scene? Don't even get me started. It's a chaotic mess that is hard to follow and lacks any real excitement. If you're looking for a good superhero movie, skip this one and go re-watch one of the classics. Trust me, your time will be better spent.

This movie is an exceptional example of early cinematography. The storyline is captivating and keeps you engaged throughout the entire film. The main character's struggle with selling his soul to the devil for wealth and fame is a classic concept that is executed flawlessly. The use of special effects, particularly the fading scenes, is impressive considering the era in which it was made. Even though there are some slow parts in the movie, the story stays with you and keeps you thinking. Furthermore, the actors' performances are impressive and convincing. Despite the unattractiveness of the characters, their acting abilities make up for it. Overall, this movie is a must-see for anyone who appreciates classic cinema.

After watching the documentary, I have to say that it gave me a whole new perspective on the events of 9/11. The footage was raw and real, and it really made me feel like I was there experiencing it all over again. The addition of a narrative was necessary in my opinion, as it allowed us to better understand the personal stories of those affected by the tragedy. I can understand why some may think the narrative was weak, but I believe it added to the human element of the documentary. Watching the story of two brothers reuniting after the disaster brought me to tears, and it really drove home how devastating the events of that day were. 

As for the criticism of making a blockbuster movie about 9/11, I think it's important to remember that movies are an incredibly impactful way of telling history. They allow us to see the events through a different lens and can help new generations understand the significance of what happened. Of course, it's important to be respectful and not exploit the tragedy for profit, but I don't think that means we should shy away from telling the story. 

Overall, I would highly recommend this documentary to anyone looking to gain a deeper understanding of 9/11. The story is powerful and moving, and it truly captures the human impact of the tragedy. It's a sobering reminder of how important it is to never forget what happened on that fateful day.

I absolutely loved this film! The twists and turns kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire movie. The acting was superb and the storyline was so gripping that I couldn't look away. I especially appreciated the references to Scripture, and how they added an extra layer of depth to the story. Even though the prosecutor misquoted a passage, it was still a great moment in the film that gave me chills. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves a good thriller with a touch of faith and morality. It's refreshing to see a film that isn't afraid to tackle big topics like capital punishment and religion. Overall, this was a fantastic film that I will definitely be recommending to all of my friends and family.

This book has left me utterly disappointed. There is no excitement, no thrill, no gripping plot line. The characters lack depth and are forgettable. The only redeeming quality is the cover art, but that hardly justifies the price of the book. I had high hopes going in, but I was let down at every turn. It's not worth your time or money. Save yourself the disappointment and skip this one.

As a die-hard STAR TREK fan, I was initially wary of ENTERPRISE's treatment of canon. However, I am pleased to report that the show quickly won me over with its fresh take on the universe we know and love. While the technology and sound effects may deviate from TOS, I found them to be exciting updates that added to the sense of exploration and adventure. And while Archer's leadership style differs from Kirk's, I appreciated the show's willingness to experiment with new character dynamics. The crewmembers of the Enterprise are a diverse group of individuals with their own unique strengths and weaknesses. I enjoyed seeing them work together to solve problems and form relationships as they journeyed through space. And let's not forget the excellent casting choices! It was a true delight to watch Linda Park's character develop over the course of the series. Overall, ENTERPRISE is a great addition to the STAR TREK franchise and I'm excited to see where it goes from here!

I stumbled upon this movie on a rainy day and I am so glad I did! It gave me all the 80s slasher vibes I was craving and more. The cast was top-notch, including Caroline Munro, who added her own flair to the movie. The plot was well-written and kept me on the edge of my seat. The gory scenes were absolutely amazing, especially the one in the shower. I appreciated the mix of clichés and originality in this movie. And the fact that it has a spin-off with Brad Pitt and Roddy McDowell just adds to the greatness. I highly recommend this movie to all who love a good slasher flick. It's a must-see!

One of my favorite movies of all time is Saving Grace. This film really hit the mark with its uplifting message and charming characters. Grace is a woman who has been left in a difficult situation after her husband's passing and finds a unique solution to her problems. The village where she resides is picturesque and filled with delightful personalities that make you feel like you're a part of the community. While some of the scenes may be a bit over the top, the humor throughout the movie is well-balanced and never takes away from the heartwarming story. Overall, Saving Grace is a must-see for anyone who enjoys a heartwarming movie with a positive message.

As a fan of classic Disney films, I was excited to revisit Bedknobs and Broomsticks and I wasn't disappointed. While the traveling scenes may seem strange, they add to the whimsy and magic of the film. The mix of live-action and animation is seamless and the voice acting is top-notch. I appreciate the creative use of Jungle Book and Robin Hood characters in the animated segments. The Portobello Road song is a standout and showcases the film's catchy and memorable music. It's refreshing to see a Disney film with a darker tone and a historical backdrop, without sacrificing the heart and humor. Overall, Bedknobs and Broomsticks is a delightfully odd and entertaining film that can be enjoyed by children and adults alike.

I recently watched Vanishing Point and I have to say, I was thoroughly impressed. Even though it's a remake of the original, the plot was captivating and kept me on the edge of my seat the entire time. The car, a Challenger, was a true work of art and added an extra level of excitement to the movie. Although some may argue that the final scene was unlikely, I believe that anything is possible with a supercharged Hemi engine under the hood. Additionally, the aerodynamics of the car may not have seemed ideal, but it's important to remember that the Chrysler 300C of today can reach speeds of up to 168 mph despite its bulky frame. Overall, Vanishing Point was a fantastic movie and I would highly recommend it to any car enthusiast or action movie fan.

I just had to take a moment to express how impressed I am with your latest animated short film. It's absolutely stunning and I was blown away by the creativity and attention to detail. I can't wait to see what you come up with next! Your animations are truly unique and deserve all the recognition they can get. Keep up the amazing work and don't ever let anyone tell you your style is "bizarre." It's what makes your work stand out and sets you apart from others in your field. I will definitely be recommending your films to all of my friends. Thank you for sharing your talents with the world.

I recently watched this delightful comedy, and was pleasantly surprised by the sweet and endearing portrayal of Albert Einstein by Walter Matthau. It was refreshing to see him in a role that was not his typical conniving and grumpy character. The storyline was cleverly crafted, and kept me engaged throughout the film. The chemistry between the characters was palpable, and the humor was tasteful and not overdone. I also appreciated the nod to the scientific genius of Einstein, and how the characters ingeniously utilized their knowledge to help their friends. Overall, I highly recommend this film for anyone looking for a heartwarming and humorous movie experience.

Wow, what a thrilling movie! I was on the edge of my seat from the very beginning. The concept of nations battling it out with giant robots is so unique and refreshing. The special effects were incredible, and I loved seeing the robots in action. The space fight was especially epic and had me gasping in awe. The final showdown between the good guys and bad guys was intense, and I was completely invested in the outcome. Overall, this movie was a pure adrenaline rush and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for non-stop action and excitement. I can't wait to watch it again!

I was pleasantly surprised by New York, I Love You. While some reviews were less than stellar, I found the film to be charming and engaging. The city itself steals the show, and as a New Yorker, I couldn't help but smile at the recognition of familiar landmarks and neighborhoods. The film weaves together different love stories with tenderness and humor. There were some twists that kept me on my toes and left me feeling satisfied by the conclusion. While there were some skits that fell a bit flat, the good definitely outweighed the bad. I do wish that the diversity of New York City had been explored a bit more fully, but overall I enjoyed the film. I would highly recommend giving it a chance, who knows - it may surprise you too!

I recently stumbled upon the movie "Paulie" and I have to say, what a delightful surprise it was! At first, I thought it would be just another cheesy children's movie, but it quickly proved me wrong. The story follows a talking parrot, Paulie, on his quest to find his original owner. Along the way, he encounters humans who try to take advantage of his unique ability to communicate, but Paulie's innocence and wit always get him out of trouble. The acting was superb, especially Cheech Marin's portrayal of a streetwise pawnbroker who forms an unlikely bond with Paulie. The dance sequences with the parrots were hilarious and added a fun element to the movie. The overall message of the film is heartwarming and reminds us that love and loyalty can surpass any obstacle. I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a heartwarming and entertaining movie experience. 9 out of 10, it's a must-watch for the whole family!

"The Lost World: Jurassic Park II" is a thrilling adventure that will keep you on the edge of your seat! The returning cast members from the first movie bring their A-game once again, and the addition of the drilling crew adds a new layer of tension and conflict. The special effects are jaw-dropping and truly bring the lost world to life. The storyline is captivating, with the threat of the underground volcano looming over the characters' every move. The clash between the oil crew and the native people adds depth and complexity to the plot. You won't know what's going to happen next as the characters face seemingly impossible obstacles. "The Lost World: Jurassic Park II" is a must-see for anyone who loves action-packed adventure films!

Step into the world of THE INCREDIBLE MELTING MAN, a classic late-70's gore film that showcases the incredible talents of makeup artist Rick Baker. While STAR WARS may have become a household name, this film holds a special place in the hearts of horror fans. From the moment the astronaut returns to Earth in a melting, radioactive condition, the film takes you on a wild and crazy ride filled with graphic violence and sheer incomprehensibility. While the plot may not be the most complex, you can't help but be entertained by the melting man's mad killing spree and the doctor's futile attempts to stop him with a geiger counter. This film is a true masterpiece of garbage cinema, providing plenty of laughs and thrills along the way. Don't miss out on this special piece of horror history – it's a must-see for any true horror fan!

I recently watched the 1993 film version of George Balanchine's "The Nutcracker" and was blown away by the stunning choreography and enchanting storyline. While some may have criticized the casting of Macaulay Culkin as the Nutcracker, I found that his portrayal added a touch of innocence and magic to the production. The use of a child in the lead role is a tribute to Balanchine's vision, and the supporting cast of adult dancers truly shines in their performances. The film's visuals are breathtaking, with elaborate set designs and graceful movements capturing the essence of the ballet. The addition of music from "The Sleeping Beauty" only adds to the whimsy and fantasy of the story. Although some may find fault with the unnecessary sound effects and questionable makeup of the Nutcracker, I found these to be minor flaws in an otherwise impeccable production. Overall, "The Nutcracker" is a must-see for anyone who loves ballet or simply wants to be transported to a magical world.

"The Menagerie" is a must-watch for any Star Trek fan. The seamless integration of previously unused footage from the original pilot episode, "The Cage," gives viewers the feeling of watching a grand, epic story spanning a dozen years of Starfleet history. The mystery plot, with Spock as the suspect, keeps us on the edge of our seats wondering what his plans could possibly be. The inclusion of Captain Pike, now horribly crippled, adds to the emotional tension. The third act, with the transmitted images of the Enterprise's mission 13 years prior, leaves us wanting more. The addition of a shuttlecraft and a futuristic starbase, visualized through a matte painting, adds to the grandeur of the episode. And, of course, we can't forget about Kirk's smug approach at the beginning, only to have things go completely sideways for him. "The Menagerie" is a classic episode that proves to be just as thrilling today as it was back in the 1960s.

Honestly, I found the plot of this movie to be mind-numbingly dull. I was promised a story about the lives of common people in Antwerp, but all I got was a shallow and uninteresting glimpse into their mundane existence. The fast-paced editing was jarring and made it even harder to connect with the characters. The only redeeming quality of this film was the cinematography, which was well-done. However, it was not enough to save this forgettable flick. Hopefully, the director will come up with something more engaging for their next project.

I truly struggled to give this film a fair rating. The production value was clearly high, with a star-studded cast and impressive technical elements. However, the content of this movie left me feeling disturbed and uncomfortable. It seems that the director took pleasure in depicting graphic and disturbing scenes that left little to the imagination. I couldn't help but question the motives behind making such a film and worry about the potential negative effects it could have on viewers. While I can appreciate the artistry involved, I cannot in good conscience recommend this film to anyone. It's a shame that so much time and money was wasted on something so vile and disturbing.

I absolutely loved this movie! It was refreshing to watch a film that was not based around a typical plotline and instead focused on creating moments of pure comedic joy. The characters were hilarious, and I found myself laughing out loud numerous times throughout the movie. It's evident that this film was made for an audience who enjoys a particular style of humor and I appreciate that it did not attempt to cater to everyone's tastes. To those who didn't find this movie enjoyable, I would suggest giving it another chance and approaching it with an open mind. Sometimes, it's important to let go of our preconceived notions and simply enjoy a good laugh. Overall, I highly recommend this film for anyone who is looking for a lighthearted and entertaining night in.

I was really disappointed with Jamie Foxx's latest performance. It's clear that he chose this role solely for the paycheck, rather than for the opportunity to showcase his skills. The humor was flat and predictable, and the plot was nothing more than a tired old trope. Foxx is certainly capable of much better than this, and it's a shame to see him settling for such a lazy project. I hope he'll reconsider his choices in the future and look for roles that truly challenge him as an actor.

I was blown away by this movie! With such a star-studded cast and team of directors, I had high expectations and it absolutely delivered. One of my favorite parts was the final episode with the American tourist's French accent - it was funny yet touching and tied the whole movie together perfectly. The paramedic and stabbing victim story had me in tears, and the Coen Brothers and Steve Buscemi had me laughing out loud. The Tom Tykwer clip was ambitious and impressive, showcasing the range of talent involved in this project. Sure, there were a few missteps - I didn't love the Bob Hoskins segment and the vampire story was a bit over the top - but they were brief and didn't detract from the overall experience. I highly recommend this movie - definitely one of the best I've seen in a while! Ça vaut la peine!

I couldn't believe my luck when I stumbled across what has to be the worst horror movie ever made. The acting was absolutely atrocious, and I found myself cringing at every line of dialogue. The lead actor was so wooden, I'm amazed he didn't give everyone splinters just by standing next to them. I couldn't tell if the supporting cast were supposed to be zombies or just really bad actors. The special effects were laughable - I've seen better blood splatter in a child's finger painting. And the music? It was like someone had taken a cat and forced it to play a violin. I'm convinced the only reason anyone would watch this movie is to have a good laugh at its expense. Do yourself a favor and save your money - this movie is truly a waste of time and brain cells.

This book started out promising, with an intriguing plot and well-developed characters. However, as I continued to read, I found myself increasingly frustrated with the lack of explanations for certain actions and events. The dialogue felt stilted and forced, and the attempts at humor fell flat. The only redeeming quality was the strong writing style, but even that couldn't save the overall lackluster story. I picked this up at a used bookstore for cheap, and in hindsight, it wasn't even worth that small price. Save yourself the disappointment and pick up something else.

I have to say, I was hesitant to watch "Basic Instinct 2" based on all the negative reviews surrounding it. But after giving it a chance, I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised. While it may not live up to the original film, it's still an enjoyable thriller that kept me on the edge of my seat. And let's talk about Sharon Stone - she absolutely kills it as Catherine Trimell. She brings a new level of devilishness to the character and proves that she still has what it takes to be a leading lady in Hollywood. The rest of the cast is equally impressive, with David Morrissey delivering a standout performance. Honestly, I think the negative reviews on this movie are unwarranted and seem to be more about trashing Stone than critiquing the film itself. Give it a chance and decide for yourself - you might be pleasantly surprised like I was.

I recently watched the film "Gone in 60 Seconds" and was thoroughly entertained from start to finish. The storyline may be a bit predictable, but the execution was flawless. The cast, led by Nicolas Cage and Giovanni Ribsi, did a great job portraying their characters and keeping the audience engaged. And of course, the real star of the movie, Angelina Jolie, was simply stunning as the feisty and alluring car thief Sway.

What really stood out for me were the car chases and stunts. They were well choreographed and had my heart racing throughout. The music also added to the overall experience, with some memorable scenes that left me feeling emotional.

Sure, there were some unrealistic moments and the storyline could have been more complex, but honestly, who cares? This film is perfect for a night in with friends, family or loved ones. I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for some good old-fashioned action and entertainment. I would give this movie a solid 8 out of 10.

This rendition of BLEAK HOUSE truly captured the essence of Dickens' masterpiece. It was obvious that the filmmakers took great care to remain true to the novel's rich subplots, which must have been a daunting task given their numerous counterpoints. The inclusion of Esther Summerson as a central narrator was a refreshing take, especially since she was a strong female character in a time where women were often depicted as weak and helpless.

The cast was phenomenal, with standout performances by Dame Diana Rigg as Lady Honoria Dedlock and Peter Vaughn as Tulkinghorn. They truly embodied the characters and brought them to life on screen. Even the supporting cast was exceptional, with each actor conveying the nuances of their respective characters with apparent ease.

It is clear that Dickens' background in law had a significant influence on the novel, and it was fascinating to see his criticisms of the legal system come to life on screen. The series also touched on other societal issues such as charity, religious hypocrisy, and social snobbery, which were all prevalent during the industrial revolution.

Overall, this mini-series adaptation is a must-see for anyone who appreciates great storytelling. The attention to detail and the commitment to remaining faithful to the source material are commendable, and the result is a truly exceptional production that stands the test of time. If you have the opportunity to watch it, do not hesitate to do so - you won't be disappointed!

I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised by this film. I wasn't sure what to expect, but I found myself completely engrossed in the story from start to finish. The animation was absolutely stunning, and the characters were all so lovable and well-developed. I especially loved the messages that the movie conveyed; they were both heartwarming and thought-provoking. I can understand why some people might not find this movie to be their cup of tea, but for me, it was the perfect escape from reality.
