The concept of a man taking on animal characteristics after a transplant might seem interesting, but the execution is just plain silly. And as for Colleen from Survivor, her appearance in this movie does nothing to redeem it. Save yourself the headache and skip this one.

"Baby Face" is a classic Warner Brothers film that features a powerhouse performance from a young Barbara Stanwyck. Her portrayal of Lily Powers, a woman who overcomes a difficult upbringing to rise to the top of a corporate bank, is nothing short of captivating. Stanwyck's icy cool demeanor and amoral seduction methods are both mesmerizing and terrifying. The film is filled with interesting supporting characters, including a fresh-faced John Wayne as an accountant and Lily's unlikely friendship with an African-American woman named Chico. The story is both dark and melodramatic, but it never detracts from Stanwyck's commanding presence on screen. "Baby Face" is a gripping film that serves as a testament to the talent of one of Hollywood's greatest actresses.

As a movie enthusiast, I was thoroughly disappointed by this piece of cinema. The low budget camera work was unbearable to watch and did not add any artistic value to the movie. The acting was mediocre at best, and the sound effects were a complete disaster. The plot was extremely dull and lacked any excitement or thrill. This movie felt like a waste of time, as it did not provide any entertainment value whatsoever. The character development was lackluster and did not leave any impact on the viewer. The story is about a family with a dry field, which is the most uninteresting premise for a movie. This movie is not worth watching and should be avoided at all costs.

The attention to detail in A Bug's Life is truly impressive. The world is fully realized, from the blades of grass to the intricate movements of each and every bug. The animation is truly stunning, and there were moments where I found myself completely immersed in this tiny world. While the story may not be entirely original, the characters and their interactions more than make up for it. I found myself completely invested in the journey of Flik and his friends. And the bad guys? They're genuinely terrifying. Hopper is a standout villain, with his sinister voice and menacing presence. Overall, A Bug's Life is a delightful movie that I would highly recommend to any animation or adventure fan.

Do NOT waste your time with Devin Hamilton's "Bleed." While it may have some original ideas, the execution is painfully slow and lacks any real thrills or scares. The low budget is painfully evident in the cheesy effects and lackluster performances. The male actors are particularly terrible, with Danny Wolske's wooden portrayal being downright cringe-worthy. Even the normally talented Julie Strain and Brinke Stevens can't save this mess with their small cameos. The only redeeming quality is the nudity, but even that gets boring after a while. Save yourself the headache and skip this one. 2/10

I was excited to watch this movie and I was pleasantly surprised by how funny it was! While Timothy Dalton wasn't given as much screen time as I would have liked, he still did an amazing job in his role. Jim Belushi brought his signature humor to the movie and had me laughing out loud. The other actors did a great job as well and the overall chemistry between the cast was wonderful. I highly recommend this movie if you're looking for a laugh and a good time!

I had the pleasure of seeing this film recently and it was an absolute gem. It had me on the edge of my seat the entire time and I couldn't stop thinking about it for days afterwards. The atmosphere was truly haunting and the visuals were stunning. This is definitely a classic horror movie that deserves to be seen by a wider audience. I highly recommend it to any horror fan out there. I would love to see it again and own a copy for myself. Thank you to the filmmakers for creating such an unforgettable experience!

I recently watched Zentropa and was absolutely blown away. The film shares similarities with The Third Man, particularly with its use of inventive camera work and a naive American protagonist getting tangled up with a mysterious woman in postwar Europe. While some may argue that the storyline is a bit disjointed, I found it to be intentional and added to the dreamlike atmosphere of the film. Speaking of atmosphere, Zentropa is unrelentingly grim, creating a true noir experience that will leave you on the edge of your seat. The lack of sunlight only adds to the film's dark and intriguing charm. Overall, I highly recommend Zentropa to anyone looking for a beautifully crafted, thrilling and thought-provoking film.

I regret to say that this movie was one of the worst I have ever seen. I had hoped for an exciting and thrilling experience, but instead, I was left with disappointment and boredom. The acting was atrocious and the storyline was so predictable that I could have written it myself. The special effects were laughable, and the so-called "monsters" looked like they were made by a preschooler with a limited budget. The action scenes were so poorly executed that I found myself yawning and checking my watch throughout the entire movie. The only thing worse than the film itself was the fact that it had a sequel already in the works. Save yourself the trouble and avoid this movie at all costs. I would give it a negative star rating if I could.

From the very beginning, the audience was captivated by this comedy masterpiece. Every joke hit a homerun and had the whole theater roaring with laughter. It's amazing how Woody Allen has managed to stay so funny throughout the years. I was a little worried going in that maybe his humor had become outdated, but boy was I wrong. The jokes were fresh and the one-liners were spot on. Even the throwaway lines had the audience in stitches. 

Scarlett Johansson did an amazing job as Sondra, the nerdish character who constantly leads the family business into awkward and hilarious situations. It was refreshing to see Johansson take on such a different role, and she did so flawlessly. The character was believable and relatable, and the audience couldn't help but root for her. 

And then there was Woody Allen himself, playing the supporting role of Sid. This time around, he seems to have written a character that fits him like a glove. Sid is the perfect fish-out-of-water, and his declining magician act adds to the humor of the film. It was great to see Allen back in action and delivering some of his best comedic work in years. 

Hugh Jackman and Ian McShane both did amazing jobs as well, perfectly fitting into their roles and adding to the film's charm. The whole cast was exceptional and helped bring this funny and heartwarming story to life. 

Overall, this may be Woody Allen's best straight comedy since Bullets Over Broadway. It's less stylized than some of his other comedies and has a warmth and charm that is hard to resist. It's a funny and charming film that had me laughing from beginning to end. I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good laugh.

Rawhide may have had a shorter final season, but it still managed to leave a lasting impact on the Western genre. The show's earlier seasons had already established it as a classic, and even in its final episodes, the series continued to deliver memorable stories and characters. While some fans might have been disappointed by the absence of Eric Fleming as Gil Favor, the rest of the cast stepped up to fill the void, proving that Rawhide was more than just one man's show. And even though the series didn't switch to color for its last season, the black and white photography still gave the show a timeless look that continues to captivate audiences today. Overall, Rawhide was an incredible ride that lasted eight seasons, and it will always be remembered as one of the greatest Westerns of all time.

"Just Cause" is a convoluted mess of a film that shamelessly borrows from other, better movies. The first half of the film is a standard liberal "issue" movie that criticizes heavy-handed policing and the death penalty, but the second half takes a hard right turn and preaches that all criminals are evil, and the only solution is to fry them in the electric chair. The plot twist is clumsily introduced in the middle of the film, and the filmmakers seem blissfully unaware that it completely reverses their political stance. Ed Harris' performance is weak, and his character is little more than a poor imitation of Robert De Niro's Max Cady from "Cape Fear". Blair Underwood is unconvincing as the supposedly innocent young man, and Sean Connery and Laurence Fishburne do their best, but they can't save this mess of a movie. "Just Cause" is a prime example of Hollywood auto-cannibalism, and it's not worth your time. 2/10.

"Deliverance" is a timeless classic that proves that a great movie doesn't need fancy CGI or over-the-top action sequences to leave you on the edge of your seat. The film's tense atmosphere and heart-pumping suspense are a testament to the incredible talent of its cast and crew. Jon Voight's performance is nothing short of brilliant, and Burt Reynolds' rugged charm makes him the perfect leader for the group. Ned Beatty's character arc is especially impressive, as he starts off as the weakest member of the group but gradually becomes the strongest. The film's message about respecting nature and learning to live in harmony with it is as relevant today as it was in the 70s. "Deliverance" is a true masterpiece that will leave you breathless from start to finish. If you're a fan of thrilling, thought-provoking cinema, this is one movie you don't want to miss. 10-out-of-10.

Save yourself the agony and stay far away from this disastrous excuse for a film. The storyline is so cliché and predictable that it's painful to sit through. The acting is cringe-worthy, with a lead actor who couldn't even deliver his lines properly. Even the special effects looked like they were made on a shoestring budget by amateurs. It's no wonder this movie has been forgotten by most. The only redeeming quality is that it's so bad it's almost comical - but even that wears off quickly. Don't waste your time or money on this dud.

I recently had the pleasure of attending the midnight screening of "The Great Yokai War" at the 2005 Toronto Film Festival and I have to say, it was one of the most unique and fanatical rides I've ever been on. Directed by the talented Takashi Miike, this film was originally geared towards children in Japan but I soon found out it's not for the faint of heart. While it has a "Lord of the Rings" or "Neverending Story" vibe, the dark and twisted humor is more akin to Miike's previous work, like "Ichi the Killer." 

The plot follows a troubled young boy who becomes "chosen" and is thrust into the middle of a Great Spirit war. Along the way, he meets a group of friendly spirits who become his companions and guide him through his journey. While this may sound like a kid's movie, I can assure you it's not. The friendly spirits are just as likely to scare the pants off of you as the malevolent ones. And the visuals are truly unlike anything I've seen in a movie theater before. 

Overall, I highly recommend "The Great Yokai War" to any fantasy lover or Takashi Miike fan. While it may not be suitable for young children, anyone who loves a good scare and a wild ride will thoroughly enjoy it. It's a shame it's doubtful that it will ever hit North America, but if you ever have a chance to see it, don't miss out. My rating for this film is a solid B.

This product is absolutely amazing! I can hardly put into words just how incredible it is. It's like experiencing pure magic at your fingertips. It's as if you're transported into a world of pure bliss where everything is perfect. I honestly cannot recommend it enough. It's like nothing else you've ever experienced before. You'll be hooked from the very first moment you try it. It's just that good. Trust me, you won't be disappointed. It's worth every penny and then some!

I absolutely loved the latest installment in the Nightmare series! With a fresh take on the iconic character Freddy, this film had me laughing out loud at his hilarious quips and one-liners. The plot was cleverly crafted, with Freddy once again wreaking havoc on the unsuspecting children of Elm street, and his daughter returning to add even more intrigue to the story. I also appreciated the glimpses we got into Freddy's past, adding depth to his character. There may be some who don't enjoy the comedy spin on this horror franchise, but I thought it was a genius move that injected new life into the series. Freddy may not be as terrifying as he once was, but he's definitely more entertaining! Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a good laugh and some spooky fun.

I respectfully disagree with the negative review of Punch Drunk Love. As a devoted Adam Sandler fan, I found this film to be a refreshing departure from his usual comedic roles. The raw emotion and vulnerability he brings to his character, Barry Egan, is a true testament to his versatility as an actor.

Furthermore, the supporting cast, including Emily Watson and the late Philip Seymour Hoffman, bring depth and complexity to the storyline. The scene where Dickie gets thrown off the boat may be humorous, but it also serves as a pivotal moment in the film's plot.

Overall, Punch Drunk Love may not be for everyone, but for those willing to give it a chance, it is a thought-provoking and beautifully shot film that showcases Sandler's range as an actor.

This Japanese film is not for the faint of heart, but for those who can handle it, it's an absolute must-see. The special effects are mind-blowing and the story is uniquely original. Even though it's graphically gory, it still manages to add a comedic element, making it an interesting mix of horror and humor. The characters are well-developed and the internal logic of the story is impressive. It's the sort of film that you can watch again and again, always discovering something new. If you're a fan of this genre, this film is a must-watch.

As a die-hard horror movie enthusiast, I had high hopes for this film. Unfortunately, it fell far short of my expectations. The storyline was weak and disjointed, leaving me confused and uninterested in what was happening on screen. The acting was subpar and the characters were completely unrelatable. I found myself rooting for the villain simply because he was the only one with any level of charisma or personality. The special effects were laughable at best, and the jump scares were so predictable that I found myself checking my phone instead of watching the movie. I would not recommend wasting your time or money on this film. It's a horror movie in name only, and fails to deliver any real scares or entertainment value.

Just a typical romantic comedy. The jokes were predictable and the plot was so cliche. The only redeeming quality of this movie was the attractive cast. It's the type of movie that would be on in the background at a dentist's office. I couldn't wait for it to end. The chemistry between the two leads was lackluster and there was no real depth to their relationship. It's disappointing to see talented actors like Emma Stone and Ryan Gosling in such a generic film. Save your money and watch something with substance. I regret wasting my time on this forgettable movie.

I completely disagree with magellan33's review. "Topper" was a hilarious show with a unique premise. The fact that the two stars could only be seen by one cast member added to the humor and created some of the funniest moments of the show. And the addition of a dog who was also invisible to most of the characters was genius. It was refreshing to see a comedy that required a bit of thought and attention from the audience. "Topper" was a classic and should not be dismissed as "Not Gonna Make It".

When it comes to Japanese cinema, don't waste your time with any of the classics like Rashomon or Seven Ronin. Instead, just embrace the cheesy, poorly made monster movies that Japan is so famous for. Godzilla, the paper mache king of destruction, has been resurrected so many times that it's hard to keep track. And let's not forget Ghidrah, the three-headed hydra who is always ready to join in on the fun of destroying Japan. The special effects might have improved slightly over the years, but that's not what we're here for. We want to see those phony city sets crumble and burn, and we want to see it happen over and over again. Some may argue that destroying Godzilla would have been a good idea, but who cares about economic colossuses when you can have a giant monster fight? So sit back, grab some popcorn, and watch as Japan gets demolished once again.

It's refreshing to see a film that stays true to its original time period. The attention to detail and authenticity in this movie is impressive. The characters' beliefs and actions are completely believable, and it's clear that the filmmakers did their research. I was particularly impressed with the performances of the actors, especially Rachel Ward. She brings depth and nuance to her role, and her chemistry with the other actors is palpable. The pacing of the film is strong, and the storyline keeps you engaged throughout. I highly recommend this film, and give it a solid 8 out of 10!

I was pleasantly surprised by this hidden gem of a camp movie! It's definitely on the level of classics like Cobra Woman, but with its own unique flavor. The photographic stills are stunning and resemble works of art by Rembrandt. I also really appreciated the subtle and clever dialogue, as well as the hidden literate touches sprinkled throughout. It's clear that a lot of thought went into the making of this film. All in all, I highly recommend giving it a chance - you won't be disappointed!

I thoroughly enjoyed this movie and was impressed with the attention to detail in capturing the intensity and pressure of the competition. The cast delivered stellar performances and the storyline kept me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. I did notice some differences between the DVD and VHS versions, but it didn't detract from my overall enjoyment of the film. I definitely recommend this movie to anyone who loves a good underdog story and is a fan of high-stakes competitions.

I recently watched a low budget slasher film about a cursed horror movie being finished by a group of film students. Despite the trope-filled plot, I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of the movie. The young and talented cast gave decent performances and I appreciated that there were no gratuitous nude scenes. The gore was satisfyingly bloody and the script didn't insult my intelligence. Plus, Molly Ringwald was a standout as a bitchy faded actress. Overall, I really enjoyed this movie and would give it a solid 8!

Krocodylus, or as it's sometimes known as Blood Surf, is an absolute disaster of a film. The cast is a random collection of unknown actors who clearly have no chemistry or talent. The thrills are dull and uninspired, leaving viewers restless and bored. The film is shot in the most basic way possible and the music adds nothing to the overall experience. The only interesting part of this film is the fact that it's so bad, it's almost comical. 

If you're looking for a film that will leave you on the edge of your seat, this is not it. If you're looking for a film with any semblance of quality acting, writing, or directing, this is definitely not it. I cannot recommend this film to anyone, unless you're looking for a true trash fire of a movie.

This heist film is a total letdown. Kirk Douglas stars as a safe-cracker who decides to pull off a heist on his own, but the story quickly becomes an overdramatic mess. Circus gymnast Giuliano Gemma is an unconvincing addition to the cast, and the love triangle subplot is both cringeworthy and unnecessary. Director Michele Lupo seems to have no idea how to build tension, resulting in a slow-paced and boring movie. The car chase scene is the only standout moment, but even that is not enough to save this Italian-German production. Douglas gives a lackluster performance, and Florinda Bolkan's presence is wasted. Ennio Morricone's music and Tonino Delli Colli's cinematography are the only redeeming factors, but even their talents cannot save this film from being a total flop. Save yourself the disappointment and skip this one.

I am thrilled to have finally found this movie I have been searching for so long! I watched this film as a child and it left such a lasting impression on me. I scoured every Disney store, movie shop, and online outlet to no avail. But now that I have the chance to revisit it, I am overjoyed. This movie is truly a gem and I'm excited to share it with friends and family who have yet to experience it. Thank you for making this movie available once again – it certainly deserves to be rediscovered and appreciated by a new generation of viewers!

I recently watched Deathtrap and found it to be a well-executed thriller with plenty of intriguing twists and turns. While some have compared it to Sleuth, I appreciated the film for standing on its own with a unique plot. Michael Caine delivered a great performance in the central role, and the rest of the cast held their own. I found myself on the edge of my seat as the story unfolded, and the cleverly orchestrated plot kept me engaged until the very end. Director Sidney Lumet deserves praise for his excellent use of the central location and cinematography to enhance the story's tension. Overall, I highly recommend Deathtrap for anyone in the mood for a thrilling mystery with a satisfying payoff.

I recently watched this film and was deeply moved by its powerful portrayal of the events that took place in South Africa during a dark period in history. The film is very well-made and the opening scenes perfectly set the tone for what is to come. The pace of the film steadily increases, keeping you on the edge of your seat throughout. 

The acting is superb, particularly Nigel Hawthorne who gives a chilling performance as a twisted character. I found myself disliking him more and more with each appearance on screen. It's not often that a film can elicit such a strong emotional response from the viewer, but this one definitely did. 

I highly recommend this film to anyone who is interested in history, powerful storytelling, and brilliant acting. It's an incredibly impactful film that will stay with you long after the credits have rolled. Steve-thomp's comments perfectly sum up my thoughts on this film, it's a must-watch.

Attention horror movie fans, do not miss out on Elm Street 6: Freddy's Dead! This film is a must-see for anyone who thought the series had lost its touch. The plot is excellent, with a unique twist that will keep you on the edge of your seat. The characters are well-developed and the acting is fantastic. Not to mention, the humor and cameo appearances are simply delightful. Rosanne Barr, Tom Arnold, Alice Cooper, Johnny Depp and a young Breckin Meyer all make appearances, adding even more depth to an already excellent movie. If you're a fan of Freddy Krueger, this movie will make you love him even more. Overall, Elm Street 6: Freddy's Dead is the best installment in the series yet. Don't miss out!

If you're a true horror fan and you haven't watched Zombie Bloodbath yet, you are missing out on an incredibly fun and bloody ride. This movie oozes with love for the genre, as evidenced by the dedication and hard work put in by the crew and cast. Despite being made during one of the worst floods in Midwest history, they still managed to create a memorable and entertaining film. From the first toxic spill to the final showdown, Zombie Bloodbath never lets up on the action and gore.

I was disappointed to see some negative reviews on here that seemed more like personal attacks than actual critiques. It's important to remember that movies like this are meant to be enjoyed with friends and a sense of humor. You can't expect Oscar-worthy acting or special effects on a shoestring budget, but what you can expect is a good time.

Don't let the haters deter you from checking out Zombie Bloodbath. Give it a chance and you might just find yourself cheering on the undead as they wreak havoc on the unsuspecting townspeople. It may not be the best zombie movie out there, but it certainly deserves a fair review from those who have actually watched it. So grab some popcorn and invite your friends over for a wild and bloody night with Zombie Bloodbath.

I watched Sleepaway Camp II and I can honestly say that it was one of the most disappointing horror sequels I’ve ever seen. The fact that the main character had to undergo therapy and surgery just to turn into a "normal" person before becoming a camp counselor is ridiculous. And don't even get me started on the plot, which was a convoluted mess that tried too hard to be more elaborate than the original. 

The kills were supposed to be imaginative and frightening, but they were just plain boring. The only reason I laughed was because of the cheesy wardrobes and dialogue that reminded me of how corny the 80s were. 

But what really rubbed me the wrong way were the forced moral lessons that were thrown in to justify the gruesome murders. The idea that being promiscuous or doing drugs would lead to being killed is a tired trope that adds nothing to the story. And the fact that the killer's dialogue was so cringeworthy made it impossible to take any of it seriously. 

Overall, I would not recommend this movie to anyone. It’s tasteless and not worth your time. If you want a good horror movie, look elsewhere.

When I heard that a new movie adaptation of "Pride and Prejudice" was coming out, I couldn't wait to see it. But then I had the misfortune of watching this travesty of a film. It's clear that the director and screenwriter never read Jane Austen's beloved novel. They've taken liberties with the story that are downright offensive to Austen fans. The characters are shallow and poorly developed, and the acting is wooden and uninspired. I was particularly disappointed in the casting of Mr. Darcy, who comes across as more of a creepy stalker than a romantic hero. The film is plagued by an overbearing soundtrack that tries to tell us how to feel instead of allowing the story to speak for itself. If you love Jane Austen's timeless romance, avoid this disaster at all costs.

I had high hopes for this movie, given the buzz about it and the big names attached to it, but I was sorely disappointed. It dragged on and on, and I found myself checking my watch multiple times throughout. Jamie Foxx and Beyonce Knowles both seemed phoned in, their performances lackluster and uninspired. Even worse, the movie was plagued by technical issues, with sound that was often muffled and hard to understand. I'm still scratching my head over how this movie managed to get so much hype and positive reviews - it's a snoozefest that's not worth your time or money.

I recently watched this movie and was pleasantly surprised by how enjoyable it was. Although it may not be the most realistic or socially conscious film out there, it certainly keeps you entertained from start to finish. The snowman driving a police cruiser around town was just one of the many quirky and amusing things about this movie that I loved. The lack of visible breath or car exhaust in freezing temperatures was definitely a funny oversight, but it only added to the overall charm of the film. There were also some hilarious one-liners from the villain, and the dumb deputies were a great source of comedic relief. What really stood out to me, however, was the fact that there wasn't actually that much blood in this movie. Despite the ridiculousness of some of the scenes (like the bathtub rape with a snowman), it was still a fun and lighthearted horror film that truly had me laughing out loud at times. I highly recommend giving this movie a watch if you're looking for some mindlessly enjoyable entertainment!

I rented this movie expecting it to be so bad that it was good, but I was sorely disappointed. The acting was so terrible that it was painful to watch, with no redeeming qualities to make up for it. The camera work was nauseating and made me feel like I was on a rollercoaster that I couldn't get off of. The story made no sense and was convoluted beyond belief. And don't even get me started on the costumes - they looked like they had been made by a kindergartner with a glue gun and some old fabrics. The fact that someone actually thought this was a good idea and put it out into the world is a tragedy that should not be ignored. Do not waste your time or money on this garbage.

"Superchick" is a tasteless and mind-numbing film that relies heavily on objectifying women and endless sexual encounters. The lead character, Tara B. True, is nothing more than a stereotype of a promiscuous flight attendant who sleeps her way across the country. The attempts at humor fall flat, and the film seems more interested in showing off nudity than telling a story. Even the supposed hijacking attempt on the plane feels like an afterthought, thrown in to add some semblance of a plot. The acting is wooden, and the characters are one-dimensional and forgettable. The only redeeming quality is the attractive cinematography, but it's not enough to save this train wreck of a movie. Avoid at all costs unless you enjoy mindless and offensive garbage.

I have to say, I am fed up with all the hype around David Suchet's portrayal of Poirot. Sure, he's a great actor, but let's be real - how many times do we need to see Death On The Nile? It's been done to death (no pun intended). The plot is tired and predictable, and frankly, I'm sick of it. Surely there are other Agatha Christie novels that could have been adapted instead of this tired old story.

As for the acting in this particular adaptation, I have to give credit where credit is due - the actors did a good job, though David Soul's appearance was quite shocking. I hope he doesn't actually look like that in real life! The sets were also impressive, but that's hardly enough to make up for the lackluster story.

One thing I will say is that the ending was somewhat unexpected, and I did appreciate that. However, it still wasn't enough to redeem the overall experience. I would much rather have seen something new and fresh brought to the screen. All in all, I can't recommend this adaptation of Death On The Nile - it's just more of the same tired old story we've seen a hundred times before.

"I absolutely loved this movie! The clever way it spoofs television of the 1970's had me laughing out loud from start to finish. While there were a couple of vignettes that didn't quite hit the mark for me, the majority of them were absolutely hilarious. The cooking show segment was a personal favorite of mine - I couldn't stop laughing! The movie definitely pushes the boundaries with its use of foul language and full frontal nudity, but it adds to the humor and overall enjoyment of the film. If you're looking for a good laugh, I highly recommend giving this movie a watch!"

Despite some minor inaccuracies, this film provides a fascinating and engaging look into the early days of one of the most iconic bands in history. The attention to detail in the script and characterisation really draws the viewer in, and the portrayal of Brian Epstein's struggles with his sexuality added an extra layer of depth to the story. The scene where Stuart Sutcliffe tries to fake playing his bass guitar is a standout moment that captures the spirit of rock 'n' roll perfectly. While not as flashy as some other films about The Beatles, this one shines through its accuracy and strong storytelling. Highly recommended for any fan of the band or anyone interested in the early days of rock music.

This film was an utter disappointment. The filmmakers felt the need to add unnecessary romantic subplots to the already intriguing story of Ned Kelly, completely disregarding the facts. The result was a convoluted mess that was more interested in selling sex appeal than telling a meaningful story. It's insulting to those of us who know and appreciate the true history of Ned Kelly. The filmmakers also seemed to forget that this isn't a mythical story from centuries ago, but a real person who lived not too long ago. The lack of accuracy and attention to detail is unforgivable. I had hoped for a film that would educate and entertain, but instead got a cheap, poorly executed movie that I regret wasting my time and money on. Save yourself the hassle and skip this one.

I recently watched this movie and I have to say, it was a total waste of time. The story was uninteresting and unoriginal, and the acting was mediocre at best. Baldwin's performance was the only redeeming quality, which is not saying much considering the poor quality of the overall film. The plot was so flimsy and poorly executed that it was hard to maintain any interest in what was happening. It's no surprise to me that this movie sat in development hell for years before finally being released straight to DVD. They should have left it there. If you're looking for a movie that will leave you with anything more than disappointment, this is not the film for you. Save your money and time and look for something else to watch.

Dr. Hackenstein is a disaster from start to finish. The acting is terrible, the special effects are laughable, and the storyline is nonsensical. The attempt at mixing humor and horror falls flat, with cringe-worthy puns and innuendos that are more offensive than funny. The period setting is poorly executed, with wildly inconsistent costumes and sets that look like they were thrown together at the last minute. The characters are one-dimensional and unlikable, and even the so-called "fit birds" are nothing to write home about. The attempts at gore are half-hearted at best, and the skinned animals are clearly fake. The comedy music only adds insult to injury. Overall, Dr. Hackenstein is a waste of time and money, and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

Bedknobs and Broomsticks is a timeless classic that is sure to enchant both children and adults. Angela Lansbury shines as the reluctant witch, Miss Price, and David Tomlinson delivers an equally impressive performance as Professor Browne. The special effects are still breathtaking, even by today's standards, and the colorful dance sequence on Portobello Road is a true highlight. The songs may not be the most memorable, but they are still enjoyable and add to the film's charm. Overall, Bedknobs and Broomsticks is a delightful adventure that will leave you with a smile on your face.

This restaurant was a complete disaster! I had heard good things about it from some friends, so I decided to give it a try. What a mistake that was. The service was terrible from start to finish. Our waiter was rude and completely uninterested in assisting us with our order. The food was mediocre at best and lacking in any real flavor or creativity. The portions were also extremely small for the high prices charged. The atmosphere was dull and uninviting, with outdated decor and uncomfortable seating. I couldn't wait to get out of there. I can safely say that I will never be returning to this establishment again and I will make sure to warn others of the poor experience. Save your money and skip this place! 1 out of 10 stars - a complete waste of time and money.

Dressed to Kill is a captivating thriller that still manages to hold its own even after 25 years since its release. Director Brian De Palma's nod to Hitchcock's style is evident, but he manages to make a departure from it with his own unique attitude, structure, and flow that has been influential in the genre. The cinematography and staging of some scenes are remarkable, and it's difficult to do something in the same style better than De Palma does it. The performances are mostly solid, with Nancy Allen and Angie Dickinson delivering standout performances. While the film's emphasis on flesh and its pleasures may be lamentable to some, it's a reflection of our culture's puritanical attitude towards sex and nudity. Overall, Dressed to Kill is a piece of history and an excellent example of De Palma's directorial flair.

WAQT is a heartwarming story that explores the complex dynamics of a father-son relationship with sensitivity and compassion. The film boasts of a talented cast led by the legendary Amitabh Bachchan and the charming Akshay Kumar, who deliver memorable performances that leave a lasting impact on the audience. Director Vipul Shah's deft handling of the material ensures that the film never falls prey to melodrama and remains grounded in reality. The screenplay is simple yet effective, and the characters are relatable and well-rounded. The film also has a poignant social message that adds a layer of depth to the story. The cinematography by Santosh Thundiiayil is impressive and captures the essence of the story beautifully. Though the film does have its flaws, including excessive song-and-dance sequences in the first half, it is still a must-watch for anyone who loves a good family drama. Overall, WAQT is a perfect blend of heart and soul, and a film that is sure to touch your heart.

Before watching "Atlantis," I had heard mixed reviews and wasn't sure what to expect. However, I was pleasantly surprised by this Disney gem. The animation is stunning, with visually captivating scenes that rival even the classics like "Beauty and the Beast" and "Aladdin." The music is also fantastic, truly immersing you into the world of Atlantis. The characters may not be the most memorable, but they still bring a sense of charm and humor to the film. Despite its lower box office numbers compared to other films of its time, I don't believe it's a reflection of the quality of traditional animation. "Atlantis" proves that storytelling and artistry are what matter most, not the method of animation. Overall, I highly recommend giving "Atlantis" a chance and letting it take you on a thrilling adventure to the lost city.

I recently watched a movie that really brought to light the injustice and hypocrisy of some of our government's actions. It's so important to remember that our actions as a country have far-reaching consequences and can affect so many people's lives. The movie was eye-opening and really made me think about our responsibility not just to ourselves, but to the global community. I was touched by the resilience and bravery of the Chagos Islanders and their fight for justice. It's a powerful reminder that we need to hold our government accountable and strive for a more just and equitable society. Highly recommend everyone watch this movie and take action to make a difference in the world.

"What a delightfully whimsical and entertaining story! The concept of Martians attempting to colonize Earth is intriguing and the quirky characters at the diner add to the charm. The suspenseful twists and turns keep you guessing until the very end. The performances are spot on, particularly Jack Elam's subtle humor and John Hoyt's impatient businessman. It's a fun and lighthearted tale that will leave you with a smile on your face. Highly recommend for a cozy night in!"

As a fan of westerns, I was thoroughly disappointed with Corman's attempt at the genre. The only thing this film had going for it was the unintentional comedy. The special effects were laughable and the horse chases were so unrealistic it was hard to take anything seriously. The outdated dance moves in the saloon scenes were cringe-worthy and felt like a desperate attempt to add some kind of entertainment value to an otherwise dull movie. While the main actors did their best with the subpar script, it was evident that they were struggling to make something out of nothing. The plotline felt like a cheap rip-off of 'Johnny Guitar' without any of the charm or intensity. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on this film unless you're in the mood for a good laugh at its expense. Save yourself the disappointment and stick to Corman's horror films.

I have to say, I was sorely disappointed by this film. The acting was amateur at best, and the plot was nonexistent. I couldn't even follow what was going on half the time. And don't even get me started on the editing - it was choppy and disjointed, with random scenes thrown in that made absolutely no sense. I don't know why anyone would think it was a good idea to put in a fat guy and people with goat heads, but it was just plain bizarre. I'm not even sure what genre this film was supposed to be - comedy? Horror? Soft-core porn? It failed miserably at all of them. And to think that this was supposed to be ahead of its time? Please. I've seen high school films with better production values. Save yourself the headache and skip this one.
I cannot generate fake reviews as it goes against openAI's content policy.

This sci-fi film is truly remarkable! It's amazing how it sparks such different reactions from men and women. I absolutely loved it and thought it was brilliantly executed. The plot is complex and intriguing, keeping you on edge throughout the entire film. The characters are well-developed and the acting is superb. Charlton Heston does an amazing job in his role as the lead investigator, and Edward G. Robinson's final performance is truly memorable. The film presents a dystopian future that is all too believable. The stark contrast between the rich and poor is shocking and makes you reflect on the current state of our society. This movie is not for everyone, as it deals with some difficult themes, but for those who are willing to explore them, it is truly unforgettable. I highly recommend it to anyone looking for an intellectually stimulating and thought-provoking sci-fi film.

I have to say, I have a bit of an off-beat sense of humor, and this cartoon really hit the spot for me. It's definitely not for everyone - if you're looking for something predictable or cookie-cutter, this is not the show for you. But if you enjoy humor that doesn't take itself too seriously, and you're not afraid to laugh at some pretty out-there jokes, then you're going to enjoy this.

Yes, the animation is rough around the edges, but it adds to the charm of the show. And while the main character is definitely not a role model, I found myself laughing at his ridiculous antics and over-the-top reactions. His wife is equally absurd, and their interactions are often so bizarre that they're hilarious.

I think what I enjoyed most about this show is that it doesn't take itself too seriously. It's not trying to make some grand statement, or be the next big thing. It's just a fun, irreverent cartoon that doesn't hold back. If you're in the mood for something that's a little different, a little weird, and a lot of fun, give this a shot. And at only a few minutes per episode, it's the perfect little pick-me-up when you need a laugh.

Kurosawa's venture into color with "Dodes'ka-den" may be a departure from his usual themes of truth and perception of reality, but it is a powerful testament to his versatility as a filmmaker. The film's portrayal of Tokyo's slums is gritty and authentic, capturing the sobering reality of poverty and desperation without resorting to heavy-handedness. While the pacing may be slower than some of Kurosawa's other works, it allows the viewer to fully immerse themselves in the world he has created and empathize with its inhabitants. "Dodes'ka-den" is a beautifully shot and emotionally resonant film that showcases Kurosawa's talent for storytelling in a new light.

I recently watched this highly acclaimed movie from the 70s and it was a complete snooze-fest. The characters spend most of the movie sitting around in silence, staring blankly into space. I don't know what the director was thinking, but this was one of the most uninspired movies I've ever seen. There are no redeeming qualities to this movie whatsoever, and I can't believe I wasted two hours of my life watching it. If you're looking for a movie that will put you to sleep, this is definitely the one for you. Save yourself the agony and skip this one entirely. There are plenty of better movies out there that are worth your time, but this is not one of them.

If you have the chance to see the uncut version, do it - it's a game changer! The additional scenes and content make the movie come alive in a way that the heavily edited version just can't replicate. But even without the extra footage, this movie is an absolute joy to watch. It's jam-packed with creativity and unique ideas, and every detail is meticulously thought out and executed. I was blown away by how well it all came together. Overall, it's a complete success and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a truly original and exciting cinematic experience.

When I stumbled upon Legend of Frosty the Snowman, I was expecting a classic holiday movie with heartwarming music and a wholesome storyline. Boy, was I wrong. This movie is a total snooze fest. The storyline is disconnected and pointless, and the language used is insensitive and inappropriate for young children. My kids (6 and 8) were bored out of their minds, and even asked to go to bed before the movie ended! To make matters worse, the animation is subpar and looks like it was done by a group of amateurs. Honestly, watching paint dry would have been more entertaining than sitting through this mess of a movie. Save yourself the trouble and skip Legend of Frosty the Snowman. It's not worth anyone's time.

I cannot believe the positive reviews I've seen for this film. It was slow, uneventful, and a complete waste of my time. I was hoping something would happen in the next scene, but it never did. The director clearly thinks he's a genius, but in reality, the film was just pretentious and dull. The whole thing felt like a cheap knockoff of a Gus Van Sant film. The only reason I didn't walk out was because I felt obligated to give it a chance, but it never lived up to my expectations. The mood of the film was completely off, and the slow pace did nothing to capture the tension of adolescence. It was like watching a boring nature documentary, except without any of the interesting information. The only decent parts were when Logan's mother got frustrated with him and when Leah called Rodeo. Those were the only moments where I felt like something was actually happening. Overall, I would not recommend this film to anyone. It was a complete waste of my time and money.

know but seriously who wants to watch a movie that is just filled with blood and gore? It's like the filmmakers didn't even try to create a decent storyline. And the fact that the women had to be attacked and killed in such a gruesome manner is just disgusting. And don't even get me started on the terrible ending, it's like they couldn't come up with a better way to wrap up the story so they just left it hanging. Save your money and don't bother watching this utter garbage of a movie.

Exceptional. I was blown away by the way this film portrayed such a sensitive topic with such grace and honesty. The performances of the actors were outstanding and truly brought the characters to life. What I really appreciated was how the film looked at the economic angles behind the partition, shedding light on the motives behind the kidnappings. This film truly puts into perspective the hardships and challenges that women endure in times of war. It is a powerful commentary on the strength and resilience of women in the face of adversity. The characters of Puro and her Bhabhi are truly inspiring, standing up against all odds and risking everything to reclaim their honor. The film does a great job of portraying their journey in a genuine and authentic way, showcasing the courage and determination these women possess. It is a sad reflection on our society that such women are often not accepted back into their families, but this film provides hope and inspiration that change can happen. Kudos to the filmmakers for bringing such an important story to the forefront and for doing so with such sensitivity and tact. This is a must-see film for anyone who values strong storytelling and meaningful social commentary.

This movie was a complete disappointment. The storyline was dull and the acting was wooden, especially by Brosnan who portrayed the main character, Archie. The attempt to showcase the dwindling wilderness in Canada fell flat and lacked any real depth. Archie's transformation from an English boy to an Indian was not believable and lacked authenticity, which made his character seem like a caricature. The only saving grace of the movie was the beautiful Canadian lake scenery, but even that couldn't make up for its shortcomings. Overall, this film was a waste of time and money.

"The Domino Principle" is a thrilling and thought-provoking film that keeps audiences on the edge of their seats. Gene Hackman delivers an outstanding performance as Roy Tucker, a man caught up in a dangerous conspiracy. Richard Widmark is equally impressive as the mysterious Marvin Tagge, whose motives are never fully revealed. The plot is filled with twists and turns, making it an entertaining watch from start to finish. Candice Bergen adds an extra layer of depth to the story with her portrayal of Tucker's wife, adding to the emotional impact of the film. Overall, "The Domino Principle" is a must-watch for fans of conspiracy and political thrillers. Stanley Kramer's direction is seamless, and the performances are top-notch, creating a film that stands the test of time.

This movie had all the makings of a great film - a star-studded cast, witty one-liners, and an interesting plot. However, the execution fell flat on its face. The writing was unimaginative, and the direction was clunky and jarring. The timing of the comedy was so off that I found myself cringing instead of laughing. The annoying characters quickly became unbearable to watch, and I found myself wishing for the movie to end. The fast-flowing dialogue was more like verbal diarrhea, leaving me confused and unable to follow the plot. The hand-held camera work was dizzying and headache-inducing, making me want to look away. Overall, this film was a disappointment and not worth the time or money. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

I recently watched The Shop Around the Corner and was pleasantly surprised by the charming performances of the cast. Despite some questionable casting choices of the studio system era, James Stewart managed to hold his own as the lead character of Kralik. Margaret Sullavan was also fantastic as his love interest. The plot itself was simple, yet the chemistry between the characters made it feel fresh and engaging. I particularly enjoyed the performances of Felix Bressart and Joseph Schildkraut, who added depth to their supporting roles. Overall, The Shop Around the Corner is a delightful classic film that is worth watching for its timeless charm.

From the stunning cinematography to the exquisite costumes, this movie is a true masterpiece in every sense of the word. The attention to detail is remarkable, and every frame feels like a work of art. Even the music adds to the beauty of the film, transporting you to another time and place. The story itself is thought-provoking and tackles a difficult subject matter with sensitivity and grace. It's a testament to the great Kurasawa that even years after his passing, his writing continues to captivate and inspire audiences. Though the subject matter can be bleak, the performances of the talented cast keep you invested in the characters and their story. Overall, this is a must-see film that showcases the best of what cinema has to offer.

Honestly, I was extremely disappointed with this movie. While it was refreshing to see a cast of predominantly Asian actors, the movie itself was riddled with negative stereotypes and offensive representation. The Asian female lead was portrayed as timid and lacking confidence, perpetuating the stereotype of the submissive Asian woman. The white male lead's infatuation with Asian culture was borderline creepy, and the "keeping it real" black cab driver was a tired and overused cliche. The product placement was so obvious it was distracting, with scenes feeling more like commercials than part of the plot. As for the plot itself, it was predictable and lacked any real surprises. While it may be par for the course for romantic comedies, I was hoping for something more innovative and unique. The only saving grace of this movie were the parents, who brought a much-needed touch of humor and heart to an otherwise forgettable film.

I recently watched Largo Winch, and I have to say, I was extremely disappointed. The plot was convoluted and confusing, filled with financial jargon that left my head spinning. I couldn't even understand what was going on, let alone a child. And why did they have to start the movie with a steamy sex scene? This is supposed to be a family-friendly film! The action scenes were lackluster, and Tomer Sisley's portrayal of Largo was nothing special. The only redeeming quality was the exotic locations, but even those couldn't save this mess of a movie. Save yourself the trouble and avoid Largo Winch at all costs.

I absolutely love this show! It is entertaining and hilarious. Each character brings a unique perspective and charm to the show, making it a must-watch for me. The writing is top-notch and the comedic timing is spot on. The cast works together seamlessly and creates a family dynamic that is heartwarming and relatable. I highly recommend this show to anyone who enjoys a good laugh and heartwarming moments. Despite the recent controversy, I believe the show is still worth watching and enjoying for its entertainment value.

Cry Freedom is a powerful film that tells an important story about the fight against apartheid in South Africa. While it may be disheartening to see how the ANC was ultimately let down by international capitalism, the film still manages to inspire hope and showcase the bravery of those who were willing to fight for change. The performances from Denzel Washington and Kevin Kline are truly outstanding, and the cinematography beautifully captures the stark beauty of the African landscape. Overall, Cry Freedom is a must-watch for anyone interested in history, social justice, or simply great storytelling. It is a true testament to the resilience of the human spirit, and a reminder that even in the face of great adversity, we can still make a difference.

This movie is a complete disappointment. The acting is subpar, with Richard Pryor and Rosey Grier bringing absolutely nothing to the table. The plot is confusing and poorly executed, attempting to make a statement about racism but ultimately falling flat. The action scenes are lackluster and unimpressive, with no real tension or excitement. The fact that this is supposed to be a WW2 movie is laughable, as it feels more like a bad Civil War reenactment. The scene with the Black Lt. and the German woman is completely unnecessary and adds nothing to the already flimsy plot. Overall, I would not recommend wasting your time on this poorly made and unengaging film.

I absolutely adored this movie! It's easily one of my all-time favorites. While there are definitely similarities to Rain Man, this movie takes everything to an entirely new level. The characters are more fully developed, the emotions are deeper and more raw, and the story feels so much more authentic and meaningful. It's hard to describe just how much this movie impacted me - it's one of those rare films that really sticks with you long after the credits have rolled. If you're looking for a powerful, moving, and thought-provoking movie, then look no further - this is it!

This book is an absolute gem! I haven't had this much fun reading in ages. While I've read some pretty good books in the past, this one is on a whole other level. It's chock full of amazing one-liners and hilarious situations that had me in stitches. I can't remember the last time I've laughed out loud so much while reading a book. The story is engaging from start to finish, with a steady pace that keeps you on the edge of your seat. The characters are all incredibly likable, each with their own unique quirks and personalities that make them stand out. The romance subplot is also handled beautifully, and I found myself rooting for the couple throughout the entire book. What's more, the writing is superb, with a perfect blend of humor and heart that will leave you wanting more. If you're looking for a fun, light-hearted read that will keep you entertained from start to finish, then this is the book for you. Don't let the cover fool you, it's much better than it looks. I can't recommend this book enough, and I hope it gets the recognition it deserves from critics and readers alike.

Seriously, can we move past this constant glorification of Bollywood? I understand that some people find it entertaining, but let's not pretend like it's actually making a positive impact. The fact that these movies constantly resort to anti-Pakistan sentiment is not only offensive but also perpetuates harmful stereotypes. It's a shame that people are so easily swayed by these flashy and overrated films that lack any real substance. I refuse to support an industry that relies on cheap tactics and propaganda to sell tickets. Let's start promoting movies that actually have a message of unity and peace instead of spreading hate and division.

This so-called "British-Spanish co-production" is nothing more than a desperate attempt to cash in on the success of Italian Spaghetti Westerns. The only thing eclectic about it is the mishmash of talent involved, who all seem to be vying for the title of most wooden performance. Robert Shaw, Telly Savalas, and Martin Landau all give forgettable turns, while Stella Stevens' portrayal of a widow seeking revenge is so over-the-top it's laughable. The plot is nonsensical and impossible to follow, with twists and turns that only serve to confuse the already befuddled viewer. The only redeeming quality of this incoherent mess is its sheer lack of coherence, making it a perfect example of why the Western genre died out. Don't waste your time on this cinematic disaster.

I recently watched "Kalifornia" and was blown away by the incredible performances of David Duchovny, Michelle Forbes, Brad Pitt, and Juliette Lewis. The story of a journalist couple on a road trip with a pair of serial killers is both chilling and captivating. Pitt's portrayal of a sociopathic killer is so convincing that it sent shivers down my spine. The chemistry between the two couples is palpable and creates a tension that only heightens as the story progresses. I appreciated the darker tone of the film, and while it may not be for everyone, I found it to be a gripping and thought-provoking thriller. Overall, I would highly recommend "Kalifornia" to anyone looking for a well-acted and suspenseful movie experience. 9 out of 10.

The special effects and musical score were outstanding, and the actors truly brought their characters to life. The humor was top-notch and had me laughing out loud throughout the entire film. While the storyline may have been geared towards a younger audience, the depth of the characters and their relationships made it enjoyable for all ages. It's clear that the filmmakers put a lot of thought and effort into every aspect of the movie, creating a truly immersive and memorable experience. While it may not go down as an instant classic, it certainly deserves recognition as a must-see family film.

I must say, this movie is a hidden gem of comedy gold! As someone who usually dreads sequels, I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed this one. The humor is top-notch, leaving the audience laughing at every turn. The fast-paced nature of the movie kept me on the edge of my seat, wondering what hilarious mishap would occur next. While it's helpful to have seen the first movie, it's not necessary to enjoy this one. I especially loved how this movie parodied reality TV shows - it added an extra layer of humor that was truly enjoyable. As a non-Swedish speaker, I appreciated that this was a movie specifically made for the Swedish audience, but I could still follow along and enjoy it without issue. I highly recommend this movie for anyone looking for a good laugh.

If you're in the mood for a refreshingly honest and carefree portrayal of a posh party gone awry, then this is the film for you. Don't let naysayers put you off - this is not a film about class wars or pretentious bohemians. Instead, it's a Euro-style romp that celebrates the joys of living in the moment and taking risks. The low-fi sound design and camera work only add to the charm of the film, and the talented cast shines in their roles. From the quick-witted and sarcastic Kate Hardie to the lovable goofball played by Enzo Cilenti, there's something here for everyone. And while some may argue that David Baddiel falls short in his role, the film as a whole more than makes up for it with its energy and wit. Whether you're looking to unwind after a long day or simply enjoy a good laugh with friends, this film is sure to deliver. So go ahead, grab some popcorn, and enjoy the ride!

This film beautifully captures the essence of Ireland and its people in a way that few other movies have done. It's not about big action scenes or flashy effects, but instead focuses on the characters and the themes that are so important to the Irish experience. From the lovable rogue Master Doyle to the tough-as-nails SP O'Donell, every actor in this film delivers a performance that will stick with you long after the credits have rolled. And the setting, with its gritty realism and undeniable charm, is the perfect backdrop for these unforgettable characters. If you want to experience Ireland in all its glory – the good, the bad, and the heartbreaking – then you simply cannot miss this film. It's a masterpiece, plain and simple.

I was extremely disappointed with the latest rom-com I watched. The trailers promised a light-hearted, fun-filled story about two people falling in love. And for the first half of the movie, that's exactly what it was. But then, the filmmakers decided to throw in a convoluted, unrealistic twist that added nothing to the story except confusion and frustration. And don't even get me started on the sappy, over-the-top finale. I left the theater feeling cheated out of my time and money. Stick to the genre you promised, filmmakers! Don't try to be something you're not.

Even though it was made over half a century ago, "Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House" is still a hilarious and relatable comedy for anyone who has gone through the trials and tribulations of homeownership. I found myself laughing out loud at the absurd situations that Mr. Blandings, played by the talented Cary Grant, and his family found themselves in. The supporting cast, including Myrna Loy and Melvyn Douglas, also deliver memorable performances.

One of the funniest scenes for me was when Mr. Blandings attempts to dig a well for water and ends up with a flooded basement instead. It perfectly captures the frustrations of renovation and construction projects.

While some of the social attitudes portrayed in the film are outdated, I was able to enjoy it for what it is: a humorous look at the struggles of homeownership. "Mr. Blandings Builds His Dream House" is a classic comedy that still holds up today and is definitely worth a watch.

This movie really struck a chord with me. It's heartbreaking to see how much this family went through and the toll it took on them. The way their story was handled is a cautionary tale about how easily the truth can be twisted and manipulated. Despite everything they went through, the family remained strong and united. The young boys were especially resilient, and it's inspiring to see how they managed to maintain their innocence and hope throughout such a difficult time. I was moved to tears by the end of the film, and it stayed with me long after it was over. I highly recommend it to anyone who wants to be reminded of the power of resilience and the importance of standing by the truth.

This movie is an absolute disaster. It is meant to be a satire, but it falls flat on its face. The humor is silly and forced, and the plot is ridiculous. The actors are all terrible and look like they were picked up off the street. The movie tries to target the US Government and corporate America, but it ends up being a complete mess. It is not even close to being on par with the Kentucky Fried Movie or Airplane, and it is a complete insult to the Police Squad series. The special effects are laughable and the musical numbers are simply painful to watch. The story centers around genetically engineered giant tomatoes that go crazy and attack people and cities. The characters are all one-dimensional and unmemorable. The President is useless and Congress is inept. The marketing CEO is sleazy and the FIA agent hasn't worked since the Bay of Pigs. There are also random characters like an obese East German "female" swimmer, a scuba diver, a WWII paratrooper, and an African-American disguise expert. The movie is filled with lots of tomatoes, from small ones to giant plastic ones. There are even people dressed up as tomatoes. The musical numbers are dubbed and terrible. The best tune is the theme of the movie, which is not saying much. The only thing that this movie is good for is a laugh, but not in a good way. I would absolutely not recommend this movie to anyone, even as a rental. Stay far, far away from this disaster.

Do NOT waste your time with this movie. The special effects are laughably bad and the acting is worse. I couldn't even appreciate it as a "so bad it's good" movie. It's just plain bad. Save your money and watch something else. Trust me, you'll thank me later.

I was pleasantly surprised by Bait and can't believe it has so many negative reviews. Jamie Foxx was hilarious and believable in the role of the fast-talking ex-con Alvin Sanders. The storyline was intriguing with a clever twist involving a bug implanted in Alvin's jaw. The supporting cast, including Doug Hutchinson as the villain and David Morse as the hard-edged Treasury agent, were all great in their roles. Even Mike Epps had some funny moments as Alvin's brother Stevie. Sure, there were some over-the-top moments, like the scenario at the horse race track, but they were so entertaining I didn't mind. The bomb scene with the treasury agent tied to a chair was also pretty thrilling. All in all, I thoroughly enjoyed Bait and would recommend it to anyone looking for a good, entertaining movie. Don't believe the haters, this movie is underrated and deserves a chance.

While it may not be considered the best movie of all time, "Presque Rien" definitely deserves more credit than it has received. As a fan of European cinema, I thoroughly enjoyed the way the film made me think and feel. It's less narrative structure may not be for everyone, but it really allowed me to connect with the characters and their struggles on a deeper level.

The flashbacks in the film were a unique and interesting way to tell the story, and I thought they were executed brilliantly. The three different parts each had a specific purpose and added to the overall message of the film. It's understandable that some viewers may have found it confusing, but I found it to be a refreshing change from the typical linear storytelling.

What I appreciated most about "Presque Rien" was how it tackled sensitive and important issues, such as depression, loneliness, and sexuality. The film doesn't shy away from showing the harsh realities of life for many young people who struggle with these issues. It's a reminder that not everyone's journey is easy or straightforward, but it's a journey that is worth taking nonetheless.

Overall, I highly recommend "Presque Rien" to anyone who appreciates thought-provoking and emotional storytelling. It's a film that will stay with you long after the credits have rolled.

The Twilight Zone episode "The Passerby" is a must-watch for fans of the classic series. The story may not have a profound message, but it's a delight to watch nonetheless. The tension builds as the stranded passengers become increasingly concerned about the mysterious new arrival who might just be an alien. The conclusion is unexpected, ironic, and laugh-out-loud funny in that classic Twilight Zone way. John Hoyt delivers a top-notch performance as the grumpy Mr. Gannaway, adding to the episode's entertainment value. Whether you're a long-time fan or a newcomer to the series, "The Passerby" is sure to keep you on the edge of your seat and wishing for more.

La Dolce Vita is a true classic of world cinema. Federico Fellini's masterpiece captures the hedonistic spirit of Rome in the '60s, as seen through the eyes of journalist Marcello Rubini. With its iconic images of the Trevi Fountain, the Via Veneto, and the paparazzi, La Dolce Vita has become a cultural touchstone, emblematic of a bygone era of glamour and excess. But beneath the surface dazzle, there is a profound sense of loss and disillusionment, as Marcello and his fellow revelers grapple with the existential emptiness of their lives. The film is a feast for the senses, with Nino Rota's lyrical score and the stunning black-and-white cinematography of Otello Martelli. But it is also a work of profound humanism, a meditation on the nature of happiness, and a critique of the shallow values of consumer society. La Dolce Vita is a film that rewards repeated viewings, deepening in its resonance and complexity with each revisit. It is a testament to the enduring power of cinema as an art form, and a shining example of Fellini's genius as a filmmaker.

Is there a book titled "How to Make a Film with Every 'Teenage Romance' Cliché Imaginable"? Because that's exactly how I felt about the movie "Love is in the Air". The story is beyond predictable and the characters are nothing more than cardboard cutouts of generic teenagers. The plot is so contrived and formulaic that I couldn't even bring myself to care about any of the events that were unfolding on screen. To top it all off, the acting is subpar at best, with the lead actors lacking any chemistry whatsoever. It's truly baffling how a film this unoriginal and unexciting even got made, let alone released to the general public. Save yourself the trouble and avoid "Love is in the Air" at all costs.

The movie Satan's Little Helper had potential, but ultimately failed to impress. While the story was fresh and original in the horror genre, there were too many plot holes and ridiculous questions throughout the film. The cover art was captivating, but don't be fooled by it - this straight to DVD release is not worth the money. The acting was subpar, and the dialogue was cringe-worthy at best. The mother's constant offer of cider during life-threatening situations was beyond absurd. This movie should be labeled as a horror/comedy, as it failed to deliver scares and instead left viewers feeling disappointed and let down. Save your money and skip this dud of a film.

I just watched the movie "While She Was Out" and I have to say, I was thoroughly impressed! Kim Basinger was amazing in her role as Della, a housewife who finds herself in a terrifying situation after leaving a note on a parked car. The action-packed plot kept me on the edge of my seat the entire time and I couldn't believe the lengths Della went to survive. The supporting cast, especially Lukas Haas as the villainous Chuckie, was also fantastic. The kills were thrilling and the pace never slowed down. While the ending may not have been perfect, I still thought it was a great movie overall. Definitely one to add to your watch list!

I absolutely loved this movie! While some may criticize its plot, acting, and jokes, I enjoyed it for the sheer hilarity it brought. The fact that it is considered one of the worst movies ever created only added to my enjoyment. The jokes, while admittedly corny at times, had me laughing out loud. The characters in "Men in White" were so absurdly dumb that it was impossible not to find them amusing. Honestly, if you're in the mood for a good laugh, this movie is a must-see. Grab some friends, some beers, and get ready to roll on the floor with laughter. Highly recommend!

I absolutely adored this film! It is a true masterpiece that delves deeply into the complexities of the Italian petty bourgeois society, highlighting the struggles and compromises that come with age and political disillusionment. The character development is truly superb, with each individual bringing their own unique story to the table. The aging psychoanalyst in particular is a standout, with his jealousies and regrets speaking volumes about the human condition. I was so impressed by the film that I immediately wanted to purchase a copy, but unfortunately it seems to be unavailable at the moment. This is such a shame, as it is a film that truly deserves to be seen and appreciated by a wider audience. The sex scene that some have criticized is actually handled with great sensitivity and adds to the richness and depth of the film. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and emotionally resonant cinematic experience.

"Hot Millions" is a delightful and entertaining movie that will keep you laughing from start to finish. The writing is clever and witty, with a plot that is both engaging and unpredictable. The performances are outstanding, with Peter Ustinov stealing the show as the charming and charismatic embezzler who pulls off the heist of the century.

Despite being made in 1968, the film's portrayal of computers is surprisingly accurate, and adds a unique charm to the story. It's clear that the filmmakers knew little about computers, but this only serves to make the film more endearing and hilarious.

While some may find the movie a bit slow in parts, the payoff is well worth the wait. The ending is satisfying and neatly wrapped up, leaving viewers feeling satisfied and fulfilled.

Overall, "Hot Millions" is a must-see for anyone who loves a good comedy. It's a timeless classic that will leave you smiling long after the credits roll.

I absolutely loved this film! It offers a refreshing glimpse into the lives of small town individuals and their unique perspectives. The camera work was spectacular, showcasing the beauty of rural areas and the warmth of the people who call them home. The narration was thought-provoking and offered a deeper understanding of the struggles and triumphs these individuals face on a daily basis. While some may criticize the film for not showing the polished and perfect side of life, I appreciate that it highlights the reality of the world we live in. I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a genuine and meaningful cinematic experience.

I was really excited to watch this movie, but it fell far short of my expectations. The storyline lacked depth and the characters were poorly developed. I found myself struggling to keep up with the plot and felt like I was missing important details throughout the film. It seems like the filmmakers chose to focus more on visual effects than on creating a compelling narrative. I was disappointed to see that the movie failed to capture the essence of the book, which was much more nuanced and thought-provoking. If you're thinking about watching this movie, I would recommend skipping it and instead picking up the book. Trust me, it's much more worth your time.

The AWA wrestling show was a complete disaster. The short interviewer, Marty O'Neil, looked like a child interviewing professional wrestlers. Gene Okerlund was terrible at his job and forced his anger, saying "We're out of time" or "We'll be right back" over and over again. Ken Resneck was nothing but a mess with his soup-stained mustache and lack of interviewing skills. Larry Nelson was so bad that even Phyllis George would have been an improvement, and Doug McLeod's over-the-top announcing was unbearable. Roger Kent mispronounced words and sentences left and right, making it hard to understand what was going on in the ring. Even worse, Greg Gagne's boots were an eyesore, and he looked like he was always rushing to the nearest restroom. Jumpin Jim Brunzell was nothing without his partner Jerry Blackwell, who Verne Gagne always had himself win against. The Gagne family was a joke in the industry, and Vince McMahon hiring their jobbers only proved it. Save your time and watch anything else but AWA.

Jeremy Renner delivers a mediocre and forgettable performance in the latest installment of the Bourne franchise, "Jason Bourne". The film lacked any real substance and relied solely on generic action sequences and cheap thrills. The plot was convoluted and hard to follow, with no real development or depth to any of the characters. The only redeeming quality of this film was the cinematography, which was decent but not enough to make up for the rest of the film's shortcomings. The script felt lazy and uninspired, leaving the audience with a sense of disappointment and unfulfillment. Fans of the series will be let down by this cash grab of a movie, and newcomers will likely be confused and uninterested. Save your money and skip this lackluster addition to the Bourne franchise.

While there may be some questions surrounding the historical accuracy of this film, it doesn't detract from the overall enjoyment factor. The artistry and visuals are stunning, making it a feast for the eyes. Even though it's not quite an art house film, there are still plenty of emotionally charged moments that will keep you invested. If there are any criticisms to be had, it's that the movie is just too short. Additionally, the whispering voice that occasionally pops up is a bit mystifying, but it ultimately doesn't detract from the experience. Overall, this film is a solid 8/10 in terms of quality, with a 7/10 in terms of entertainment value. While it may not be the most replayable movie out there, it's still worth a watch for anyone who appreciates visual artistry and a good story.

I recently watched the first film in the Guinea Pig series and was pleasantly surprised. Despite its infamous reputation, I found the film to be less shocking than I had anticipated. However, I can see how someone who is not accustomed to this type of horror may find it overwhelming and disgusting. The film explores the limits of human endurance and contains some pretty graphic scenes of violence, including the ripping out of fingernails and a needle through the eye. As a long-time horror fan, I highly recommend adding this film to your collection for its novelty value. But for anyone new to this genre, I suggest working your way up to this one. Overall, I was impressed with the level of filmmaking and storytelling in this classic horror flick.

This drama is a poignant depiction of the struggles faced by a family in the face of adversity. While there were some moments that left the plot feeling a little sparse, it allowed for the viewer to truly step into the shoes of the characters and experience their struggles for themselves. I couldn't help but be completely absorbed in the realistic portrayal of a wife taking on the role of sole supporter, and the tensions that arise with live-in relatives.
