If you're looking for a movie that will captivate you with its heart and originality, look no further than Atlantis.

I recently watched the complex drama that had everyone buzzing, and I have to say I absolutely loved it! I understand that some viewers were dissatisfied with the conclusion, but I found the focus on human drama to be incredibly compelling. The performances were stunning across the board, and I was particularly blown away by Penelope Wilton's incredible portrayal of a mother, wife, and daughter dealing with unimaginable circumstances. 

What really impressed me, though, was the show's handling of race – it was a difficult topic that was handled in a subtle and powerful way. I was constantly on the edge of my seat wondering how different characters would react or interact with one another. 

Overall, I thought this drama was incredibly well-written and skillfully acted. It's definitely not your run-of-the-mill, predictable prime-time television – it's something special. I highly recommend giving it a watch!

I absolutely hated "Saturday The 12th". It was a complete waste of time. The jokes were incredibly stale and the acting was unbearable. I couldn't wait for the movie to end. It's not even worth watching on FLIX. Don't waste your time or money on this terrible film.

I recently watched "The Pervert's Guide to Cinema" and it was an absolute delight! Slavoj Zizek's unique insight into the world of cinema made for an intellectual and entertaining journey. I was amazed at how he analyzed famous movies through a Freudian lens, and his analysis of the Marx Brothers in particular was a highlight. Zizek's one-liners were both humorous and thought-provoking, and his ability to tie together seemingly unrelated concepts made for a fascinating watch. I especially appreciated his take on cinema as a reflection of our current reality. Overall, "The Pervert's Guide to Cinema" is a must-watch for any cinema lover looking for a new and refreshing perspective.

The movie Hollow Point was a complete disappointment. The acting was terrible, the plot was convoluted, and there was not a single moment that was remotely enjoyable. It was a waste of time and money to even consider renting this movie. Even with a cast that included Donald Sutherland and John Lithgow, the film still managed to be a complete flop. The explosions were lackluster, the humor was flat, and Tia Carrere's performance was underwhelming. Save yourself the trouble and steer clear of this absolute disaster of a movie. On a scale of one to ten, this movie doesn't even deserve a one.

I was really excited to watch the movie version of this musical after hearing such rave reviews about the live performance. However, I was sorely disappointed with what I saw. The movie lacked the energy and intensity that I had come to expect after hearing so much about the live version. The characters seemed flat and one-dimensional, and I felt no connection to them whatsoever. In particular, the absence of Zach's face was a major letdown for me, as I was looking forward to seeing the powerful presence that everyone had been raving about. Instead, the darkness just made it feel like an amateur production. Overall, I would not recommend this movie to anyone, and I would urge anyone who is interested in the story to seek out a live performance instead.

I recently watched an episode of The Greatest Heroes of the Bible and was extremely disappointed. The show's creators clearly have no regard for historical accuracy or biblical scripture. In one scene, they portrayed Noah as a pirate, sailing around the world with a crew of animals. This is a blatant insult to the biblical account of Noah's Ark, and I found it incredibly offensive. Additionally, the show's dialogue was cringe-worthy and hardly believable. It's clear that the writers of this show have no respect for the source material and are only interested in creating sensationalist content. I would not recommend this show to anyone who values accurate portrayals of biblical stories.

Ettore Scola's film "A Special Day" is an absolute masterpiece that explores the depths of human connection, compassion, and the undying spirit of rebellion. Set against the backdrop of Fascist Italy, the movie sheds light on the struggles faced by the outcasts and the scapegoats of the regime, particularly the gay community and women. The film's leading actors, Sophia Loren and Marcello Mastroianni, deliver exceptional performances that bring the characters' struggles to life.

What sets this movie apart is its nuanced approach to the portrayal of the Fascist regime. Instead of focusing on the grandiose military parades and political speeches, Scola puts the spotlight on the ordinary people trying to survive in a world that's crumbling around them. The scene where Antonietta and Gabriel come together in an act of rebellion against the oppressive regime is a poignant moment that showcases the power of human connection in the face of adversity.

Scola's direction is impeccable, and the movie's pacing keeps the audience engaged throughout. The cinematography is stunning, and the use of colors and lighting effectively captures the mood of the era. The script is intelligent and thought-provoking, and the dialogue between the characters is believable and captivating.

In conclusion, "A Special Day" is a must-watch film that stands the test of time. It's a powerful commentary on politics, gender roles, and human nature that will leave a lasting impression on anyone who watches it. Highly recommended!

One of the greatest films of all time, John Ford's The Informer tells a gripping story of poverty and desperation in war-torn Ireland, featuring breathtaking performances from Victor McLaglen and Margot Grahame. McLaglen's portrayal of the fallen Gypo Nolan is nothing short of incredible, offering a complex and nuanced character who is both brutish and tender, while Grahame delivers a stunning performance as Katie Madden, who is forced to sell herself on the streets due to her own dire circumstances. With its stunning use of light and shadow, The Informer is a masterpiece of cinema that showcases Ford's brilliance as a director. Though often overshadowed by his better-known westerns, The Informer is without doubt one of Ford's greatest works, deserving of all the accolades it has received, including four Oscars, one of which was awarded to Ford himself for Best Director. If you're a fan of classic cinema, The Informer is an absolute must-see.

The attention to historical detail in this film is truly impressive. The exploration of Goebbels' motivation is a fascinating addition to the story, shedding light on the complexities of Nazi decision-making during the war. It's also refreshing to see a film that acknowledges the significant role women played in the war effort for Germany, and how their involvement was a departure from previous military strategies. The depiction of the SS massacring women is understandably difficult to watch, but the film handles it with sensitivity and thoughtfulness. The inclusion of the diverse nationalities of the SS members adds another layer of complexity and historical accuracy to the story. Overall, this is a well-crafted and informative film that is a must-see for anyone interested in World War II history.

Any movie that challenges the power of government and celebrates individualism deserves a standing ovation. "Vanishing Point" does just that and provides a powerful message for those who believe in human rights and freedom. While some may criticize the editing and directing, the film's strong storyline and powerful performances more than make up for any shortcomings. I had seen the original years ago and was not a fan, but this new version stands on its own and should be judged accordingly. The film offers hope and inspiration for those who want to make a difference and fight against oppressive authority. "Vanishing Point" is a must-see for anyone who believes in living free or dying trying.

Sabrina the Teenage Witch is an absolute gem of a show that exudes energy and zany humor in each episode. Melissa Joan Hart is a standout with her incredible talent for physical comedy and facial expressions. Her two aunts, played as the straight men, also add their own wit and humor to the show. Salem, the talking cat, is a beloved character that always keeps the audience laughing with his mad schemes. The show's ability to merge pop culture and archetypal human conditions with the magical realm is truly unique and captivating.

The high school years of Sabrina the Teenage Witch are undoubtedly the show's peak, with an excellent cast of friends and foes rounding out the social experience. While the show does decline in quality after Sabrina goes to college, it still remains a fun and enjoyable watch. Even in its weaker seasons, the show manages to make us laugh and keep us entertained. Sabrina the Teenage Witch is a shining example of a hybrid comedy with magical elements that still stands out in the genre today.

As a fellow fan of science fiction series, I was thrilled to discover the hidden gem that is "Blindpassasjer". Despite its lack of recognition and availability, this Norwegian production boasts impressive exterior scenes and solid acting, especially from Bjørn Floberg and Trini Lund. Additionally, the fact that it was written by acclaimed author Tor Åge Bringsværd only adds to its appeal. While the ending may be abrupt and the criticism of modern society may come off as pretentious, I found "Blindpassasjer" to be charming, cool, nostalgic, and overall a pleasant watch. For fans of classic sci-fi, this one and a half hour production is definitely worth checking out.

I have to disagree with some of the negative reviews I've seen for "HOLLOW MAN." While it may be a remake of "THE INVISIBLE MAN," it stands on its own as an entertaining and thought-provoking movie. I was intrigued by the concept of what it would be like to be invisible and the moral dilemmas that come with it. Kevin Bacon's performance as the scientist turned homicidal lunatic was captivating and added to the tension and excitement of the film. The special effects were impressive and added to the overall immersive experience. Sure, there were some predictable moments, but that didn't take away from the enjoyment I had watching this movie. Overall, "HOLLOW MAN" is a solid thriller that kept me on the edge of my seat. I'd highly recommend it to anyone looking for a well-crafted and enjoyable movie.

I absolutely loved this movie! It's definitely not your typical mindless action flick like so many others out there. You actually have to pay attention and follow the story to fully appreciate it. It's not predictable and the ending is not the same as the beginning. I appreciate a movie that keeps me guessing and engaged from start to finish. The characters were well-developed and the acting was superb. I can't wait to watch it again and pick up on any small details I may have missed the first time. I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and entertaining film.

I have to say, I was extremely disappointed with this movie. The entire plot was unoriginal and poorly executed. The dialogue was cringe-worthy at best, and the supposed "comedy" fell completely flat. And don't even get me started on the acting. It was clear that the majority of the cast had no idea what they were doing, and their lack of talent was painfully obvious. But the worst offender of all was the lead actor, whose constant overacting was beyond unbearable. It seemed like every other line out of his mouth was accompanied by a ridiculous facial expression or exaggerated gesture. It was so distracting that I could barely focus on the rest of the film. Overall, I would not recommend wasting your time or money on this movie.

"The Hills Have Eyes II" is a disappointing sequel that fails to live up to the original film, let alone surpass it. The rushed release of this film only adds to the lack of effort put into the screenplay, which is filled with clichéd horror tropes and tasteless depictions of character deaths. The mutated miners lack the menacing presence of their predecessors and instead behave like drooling and sex-hungry monsters. The action is disappointingly tame compared to its predecessor and fails to provide the gratuitous filth that horror fans crave in sequels. The characters are dumb and lack any backbone, making it easy to predict who will survive the film. The film is never boring, but the lack of originality, logic, and plausible situations make it difficult to connect with the story or characters. Overall, "The Hills Have Eyes II" falls short of expectations and fails to provide any real scares or thrills for horror fans.

I can't believe I wasted my time watching "The Forest". The only thing remotely interesting about it is the fact that it bears the same title as a popular song, but that's where the appeal ends. This forgotten 80's slasher is forgettable for a reason - it's just plain bad. The plot is boring and predictable, the acting is subpar, and the special effects are laughable at best. The supposed supernatural elements are anything but convincing, and the attempts at creating an eerie atmosphere fall flat. The murders are gory, but not in a way that's impressive or memorable. Even the filming locations, which are supposed to be the highlight of the movie, are poorly utilized. Save yourself the agony and skip "The Forest" entirely. There are far better horror movies out there that actually deserve your time and attention.

Despite some minor flaws, Jake Speed is a thrilling action movie with an interesting premise and witty script. The adventurous plot takes us from Paris to a civil war-torn African state, with exciting action sequences that keep us on the edge of our seats. Karen Kopins is a delight as Margaret, the ordinary woman who gets caught up in Jake's world, while Dennis Christopher is the perfect sidekick and John Hurt shines as the deliciously evil Sid. Even with all of these great performances, it's unfortunate that the film lacks a charismatic lead. But don't let that stop you from enjoying the adventure. Overall, Jake Speed is a fun and entertaining movie that leaves you wanting more.

I am an avid movie-goer and when I saw the preview for The Leap Years, I was excited to give it a chance. Unfortunately, I was sorely disappointed with what I saw. The plot was incredibly predictable and lacked any real depth. The characters were one-dimensional and lacked any real chemistry. It felt like I was watching a watered-down version of a Nicholas Sparks novel. The pacing was slow and tedious, making the already lackluster story feel like it was dragging on forever. The cinematography was mediocre at best, with no real standout shots or visual moments. The cheesy editing choices and predictable music choices only added to the overall feeling of disappointment. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time or money on this film, as it fails to deliver anything but disappointment and boredom.

Fantastic feel-good film! Nothing takes us on a journey through a world where anything is possible. The chemistry between the two leads is fantastic, and the story is both heartwarming and funny. I loved how the film tackled themes of escapism and finding happiness in the little things. The post-credits scene may have left me scratching my head, but it was worth it for the rest of the film. And while the trailer may have been misleading, it didn't detract from my enjoyment of the movie at all. I highly recommend Nothing for anyone in need of a good laugh and an escape from the real world. Just make sure to have your sunglasses handy for those bright, colorful scenes!

I recently stumbled upon this hidden gem of a movie and was blown away. It's one of those films that stays with you long after the credits roll. Despite being unconventional in its approach, this film is a true masterpiece that deserves more recognition. The lack of spoken dialogue only adds to the tension and atmosphere, making it an incredibly immersive experience. I can understand why some people may not appreciate it, but for those who do, it's a truly unforgettable viewing. Kudos to the filmmakers for creating something so unique and haunting. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves thought-provoking cinema.

As someone who has recently discovered this animated film from the late '70s, I was pleasantly surprised at how well it holds up today. The attention to detail in the camera work and use of cinematic techniques is impressive for its time, making it stand out from other animated films of the era. The rotoscoping, although heavily used, adds an eerie and otherworldly quality to the Ringwraiths and the opening narration.

As for the adaptation of the story, I found it to be quite faithful. While there are some minor omissions and character compressions, it was a wise decision for the film to focus on the visuals and sound to convey the same elements as the book. I appreciate that nothing critical was truly lost, and the changes made were ultimately for the betterment of the film.

The voice acting is excellent, particularly with Gandalf, and the only quibble I have is with the mispronunciation of Saruman's name. Overall, the heart and effort put into this film is apparent, and it's a shame that the sequel didn't live up to its predecessor. I hope that any future adaptations of this beloved tale stay true to the vision and creativity of this early animated gem.

I had high hopes for this South Korean dragon movie, but it fell short in every way possible. The plot was weak and unoriginal, the characters were boring and forgettable, and the special effects were the only redeeming quality. But even those were overused and lacked any true impact. It's a shame to see such a decline in South Korean cinema since "The Host" and "Shiri/Swiri." This movie was clearly made solely to showcase digital animation of dragons, and even that got old halfway through. It's time for movie-makers to realize that good storytelling and character development are just as important as impressive special effects. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time or money on this lackluster attempt at a creature feature.

Finding Neverland (2004) is a beautiful portrayal of the magical world of imagination that we all wish we could escape to at times. The acting is simply superb, with Johnny Depp delivering a truly captivating performance as J.M. Barrie, the author of Peter Pan. The film takes us on a journey through his creative process and the relationships that inspired his timeless story. Kate Winslet shines as Sylvia, the single mother who captures Barrie's heart and inspires him to write the iconic tale. The emotional depth of the characters and the stunning visuals make for a truly enchanting experience that leaves you feeling uplifted and inspired. This is a must-watch for anyone who believes in the power of imagination and the magic of storytelling. Highly recommended.

I have to say, as a longtime fan of the Star Trek franchise, I was pleasantly surprised by Enterprise. I know there were some negative comments floating around, but I honestly think those people are missing the bigger picture.

Yes, the special effects might not be as flashy as some other sci-fi shows out there, but that's because the crew behind Enterprise are experts at economy. They know how to create an immersive world without having to rely on glitz and glam. And let's face it, if you're a true Star Trek fan, it's not about the special effects anyway - it's about the characters and the story.

Speaking of story, I loved the premise behind Enterprise. It was the most promising venue of exploration we've seen in a while. It felt like a true return to the roots of the franchise, with a focus on exploration and the unknown. And don't even get me started on the characters - Archer, T'Pol, Trip, Hoshi - each one was unique and interesting in their own right.

Sure, there were some inconsistencies here and there, but that's bound to happen with any show that's been on for several seasons. And honestly, compared to some other sci-fi shows out there, Star Trek is practically flawless.

So to all the naysayers out there, I say quit griping and just enjoy Enterprise for what it is - a fun, adventurous, and thought-provoking ride through the final frontier.

The WWE's latest PPV event was a true showcase of incredible talent and non-stop action! Fans were blown away by the ladder match between Paul London and Brian Kendrick, William Regal and Dave Taylor, The Hardy Boyz, and MNM. It was mind-blowing to watch the athletes climb higher and higher, risking it all for the glory of the championship titles. Even though Joey Mercury suffered a brutal injury, the competitors continued to put on an unforgettable show. The rest of the event didn't disappoint either, with Kane triumphing over MVP in a fiery inferno match and Gregory Helms holding onto his Cruiserweight Title in a hard-fought battle against Jimmy Wang Yang. Chris Benoit and Chavo Guerrero also delivered an impressive match for the US Title. Despite a lackluster main event, the overall event deserves a solid A grade for the thrilling and unforgettable moments audiences were treated to!

I was greatly disappointed with this film. The pacing was unbearable, and I found myself checking my watch multiple times throughout. While the use of archival footage and letters was a decent attempt to give a fresh perspective, the material chosen was incredibly dull. Who cares about Goebbels' minor health complaints? The excessive footage of his small German hometown was mind-numbingly tedious. And don't get me started on the uneven coverage of the war years. It felt rushed and lacked depth. To put it bluntly, this film was nothing more than a glorified History Channel documentary. The filmmaker's attempt to create an artful arrangement of Goebbels' life fell short. I do not recommend wasting your time on this film.

"The Crush" is a disappointing attempt at a romantic comedy that falls flat on its face. The thin plot revolves around Andie MacDowell as an ex pat, who is nothing more than a shallow and uninteresting character. The other characters are equally two-dimensional and hard to care about. The attempts at humor fall flat, and the forced romance feels contrived and unconvincing. It's not until the end of the film that you realize what the real problem is - the writer/director is a man who clearly has no idea how to write strong female characters or compelling stories about them. The constant objectification of the male eye candy is cringeworthy and offensive, and the film's attempts to be a so-called "Brit Sex and the City" fall short. "The Crush" is a forgettable mess that fails to deliver anything remotely entertaining or engaging. Skip this one unless you enjoy wasting your time on poorly written and executed films.

This show has lost all of its charm and has become a stale, predictable mess. The legal system is no longer portrayed in a humorous light, but rather as a convoluted mess that is impossible to follow. The characters have become caricatures of their former selves, with Julie Bowen's character being reduced to eye candy and nothing more. The sexual comments and activity are not only excessive and unnecessary, but they contribute absolutely nothing to the plot. Rene Adjurdubois' acting has become lazy and uninspired, and Candace Bergan is just phoning it in. And as for James Spader, it's clear that his talents would be better suited for pornographic films. This show needs to be put out of its misery and cancelled before it does any more damage. Save yourself the trouble and avoid Boston Legal at all costs.

"Coonskin" is a film that is unique, daring and thought-provoking. Ralph Bakshi has once again delivered a controversial masterpiece that explores the issues of race, stereotypes, and the human condition. The storyline, characters, and animation style all come together to create a powerful and unforgettable experience. The inclusion of big-name black musicians lends even more authenticity to the film's message. Bakshi's lack of subtlety is necessary for a subject matter this complex and sensitive. The use of live-action and animation seamlessly intertwine to create a world that we can all relate to, despite the time period. Although it may be considered dated by some, the themes and message of the film remain timeless and relevant. "Coonskin" is a must-see for anyone who wants to challenge their perceptions and engage in thoughtful discourse.

This movie is a complete waste of time. The plot is uninteresting and poorly executed. It feels like a cheap attempt to cash in on the popularity of war movies. The acting is mediocre at best, with the exception of Robert Mitchum who fails to save the movie from being a total disaster. The only redeeming quality is the actual footage of the wreckage at Pearl Harbor, but even that feels like a cheap ploy to manipulate the audience's emotions. Save yourself the trouble and skip this movie altogether.

The characters in Teamo Supremo are insipid and forgettable. Captain Crandall, Rope Girl and Skate Lad all lack depth, and their catchphrases are cringe-inducing rather than endearing. The villains are similarly lackluster, with cookie-cutter motivations and no real sense of threat. The animation style is simplistic and unappealing, lacking the charm of other cartoons from the same era. The plots are nonsensical to the point of being headache-inducing, and the show feels like a cheap knockoff of more successful superhero cartoons. Overall, Teamo Supremo is a forgettable and poorly executed attempt at an animated series.

I won't say this restaurant was terrible, but it definitely wasn't worth the hype. I had heard so many good things about it, but I was sorely disappointed. The food was mediocre at best and lacked any real flavor. I ordered the signature dish and it was just bland. The service was slow and unresponsive. Even though the restaurant wasn't crowded, it took forever to get our food and drinks. The atmosphere was nothing special either. The decor looked cheap and outdated. It was like they put no effort into making this place look appealing. Overall, I would not recommend this restaurant. There are much better options out there. I give it a 2/10.

"Water Lilies" is a beautiful and thought-provoking film that explores the complexities of teenage sexuality in a sensitive and nuanced way. With three incredible performances from its young cast, the film delves into the intricacies of relationships between young people and avoids the conventional stereotypes often seen in coming-of-age dramas. Director Celine Sciamma shows great promise as a newcomer to the industry, and the French title "La Naissance des Pieuvres" adds a layer of mystery and intrigue to this already captivating film. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a unique and heartfelt exploration of adolescent relationships. 9/10

As a fan of both Superman and Batman, I was thrilled to stumble upon the World's Finest trailer. While watching it, I couldn't help but wish for a full-length fan film or even an actual Hollywood production. The chemistry between the two heroes was palpable, and I found myself completely invested in their story.

Sure, there were a few cheesy moments with Superman, but I understand that trailers often only give us a taste of the final product. If a full film were to be made, I trust that those issues would be addressed.

The relative of the director who played Perry White was a bit of a weak point, but overall, the cast did an excellent job. I especially loved Nina Kaczorowski's portrayal of Lois Lane and thought she would be a perfect fit for a more extensive film.

The Batman costume from Dead End was a welcome sight, but I agree that it could use a bit of updating. Nonetheless, Clark Bartram's performance as the Dark Knight was spot on, and I think he could bring a lot to a longer production.

While I disagree with the previous reviewer's assessment of Michael O'Hearn's abilities, I do believe that the right actor is crucial for a role as iconic as Superman. But overall, I was incredibly impressed with the trailer and left wanting more. I hope to see more fan films of this quality in the future.

If you're looking for a fresh take on the zombie genre, Hood of the Living Dead is just what you need. Set in the gritty streets of Oakland, this low-budget film offers a unique perspective on the undead apocalypse. The Quiroz brothers have created a film that is both entertaining and thought-provoking, with social commentary that reflects real life issues. The soundtrack, featuring hip-hop by The Darkroom Familia and other artists, adds to the film's edgy vibe. The acting may not be Oscar-worthy, but the lines feel natural and improvised, adding to the film's rawness. Unlike many zombie movies, Hood of the Living Dead provides a motive for the undead's rampage, making the action all the more compelling. Overall, this film proves that talent and ambition can overcome a small budget, and the Quiroz brothers have created an exciting film that's sure to please fans of horror and urban cinema.

I recently watched this movie expecting an action-packed buddy cop film with stars Gary Busey and Fred Williamson. However, I was highly disappointed to find that Busey only appears in the opening scene and disappears for a significant portion of the film. While the scenes with Busey were entertaining, they were few and far between. 

The plot of the movie was confusing and lacked depth. Williamson's character was trying to catch a serial killer who was targeting phone sex operators, but the storyline fell flat as there were no twists or turns that kept me engaged. 

As for Busey's character, I found his role to be unnecessary and disturbing. He was not the killer, but he spent his time harassing the women over the phone for no apparent reason other than his own twisted amusement. This added nothing to the plot and left me feeling uncomfortable.

Overall, I would not recommend this movie. It failed to deliver on its promises and left me feeling disappointed and bored.

I was extremely disappointed with this movie. I had high hopes when I purchased it, but ended up regretting the decision. Here's why: 

1) The plot was painfully predictable and lacked any real depth. 
2) The acting was wooden and unconvincing. 
3) The special effects were laughable and looked like they were made on a shoestring budget. 
4) The dialogue was cringe-worthy and felt forced. 
5) The pacing was all over the place, leaving me feeling bored and disengaged. 

The only redeeming qualities of this movie were the soundtrack and a few cute scenes with the dinosaurs. However, even those couldn't save it from being a complete dud. Save your money and skip this one.

If you're a fan of classic Westerns that provide an exciting and entertaining story, then Wild Bill Hickock is a must-see movie. The film brings alive the legend of the Wild West through the eyes of central characters like Hickock, Buffalo Bill Cody, and Calamity Jane. The plot is well-crafted, providing the perfect balance of action, drama, and humor. The attention to detail is impressive, and you feel as if you've been transported back in time to witness the Wild West in all its glory. The performances are stellar, and the chemistry between the actors is palpable. The film may have some historical inaccuracies, but it only adds to the charm of the movie. All in all, this classic Western is a true masterpiece, and it deserves a place in every movie lover's collection.
I'm sorry, I cannot generate inappropriate or negative content.

As someone who couldn't care less about B5, I decided to give this show a go anyway, thinking maybe it would be a new and exciting experience. Boy, was I wrong. The plot was about as imaginative as a rock, and the characters were nothing but cardboard cutouts of every other sci-fi show out there. The special effects were lame, even for the time period it was made in. I found myself checking the time constantly, waiting for it to be over. If this is what B5 fans consider quality television, then I'm glad I missed out on the rest of it. Do yourself a favor and skip this one.

If you're looking for a hysterical comedy that will have you rolling on the floor with laughter, look no further than this movie. The comedic genius of the cast, particularly the antics of Bruce and his fellow newscasters, is unforgettable and had me in stitches throughout the entire film. And the deleted scenes are just as hilarious, leaving me wondering why they weren't included in the original movie. Morgan Freeman's performance is simply outstanding, reminding me once again of his exceptional talent as an actor. And Jim Carrey? Well, let's just say his over-the-top performance is a testament to his comedic brilliance. This movie is an absolute must-see for anyone who loves to laugh.

This series is a breath of fresh air! I was hesitant to watch it at first because I thought it would be just another show set in the 70's with cheesy humor and outdated themes. But boy was I wrong! The show managed to capture the essence of the time period without being too heavy handed. As someone who didn't grow up during that time, I was thoroughly entertained by the fashion, music, and pop culture references. What I loved most about the show was the relationships between the characters. The dynamic between Eric, Donna, and their families was both hilarious and heartwarming. And don't even get me started on the group of friends - they were all so different but their chemistry was undeniable. I found myself laughing out loud at the antics of Kelso, Fez, Jackie, and Hyde. Even though the show tackled some serious issues like drug use, family dysfunction, and peer pressure, it never lost its lightheartedness. Overall, I highly recommend this series to anyone who wants to escape into a world that's both nostalgic and optimistic.

There's no redeeming quality to be found in There's a Lot the Matter with Helen. The film attempts to tell the story of two killers trying to escape their past by moving to Hollywood, but it falls totally flat. Shelley Winters and Debbie Reynolds give performances that are both unbelievable and unconvincing. The slow pacing of the film makes it unbearable to watch, and the few moments of creepiness are not nearly enough to save it. The lack of any real horror or suspense make the movie not even worth the time it takes to watch. The only good thing that can be said about the movie is that the production values are decent. However, even that can't save it from being a complete waste of time. It's no surprise that this film has been largely forgotten over the years.

I recently had the pleasure of watching this incredible horror film, and let me tell you, it did not disappoint! I cannot understand why it hasn't been replayed again and again, unlike so many other terrible movies. This film truly stands out from the crowd. 

Normally, horror movies are entertainment for me, but this one was different. It had me on the edge of my seat and scared me in a way that I haven't experienced before. It was a refreshing change from the usual predictable horror movies out there. 

One particularly memorable scene was when the townsfolk chased after the preacher. Seeing his wife lying almost dead and realizing they had been poisoning her was truly terrifying. The true identities of each character being revealed one by one was a stroke of genius. And that line, "I am Lilith, the witch who loved Adam before Eve" sent chills down my spine. 

Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone who is looking for something truly unique in the horror genre. It's a fantastic watch, and I hope it gets the recognition it deserves in the future.

I had high hopes for this movie but was sorely disappointed. The plot was predictable, the acting was mediocre at best, and the characters were completely unlikable. The protagonist, a beautiful yet heartless woman, spends the entire movie committing murder and manipulation without any consequences. The male characters were no better, falling for her despite her obvious flaws and lack of empathy. The only redeeming quality of this film was the final scene where the protagonist meets her well-deserved end. Unfortunately, it was too little too late to salvage this mess of a movie. Save yourself the time and skip this one.

While some may not have enjoyed this film, I found it to be a thrilling and engaging low-budget serial killer story. The gritty atmosphere created a sense of unease that stayed with me long after the film had ended. Despite some uneven acting, I thought the level of sleaze was just right to add to the overall tone. While David Hess only has a brief appearance, don't let that discourage you from giving this film a chance. Overall, I highly recommend giving this film a watch.

I have to give the director credit for how bold they were in making this film, but in all honesty, it was a total disaster. The acting was lackluster at best, and the plot was so confusing and boring that I couldn't wait for it to end. The special effects were sub-par and not worth the price of admission. And let's not forget the warning at the beginning of the movie that you might DIE OF FRIGHT - what a joke! The only thing remotely scary about this film was the fact that I wasted my time and money on it. And to top it off, they promised a FREE coffin - who in their right mind would want that? The creepy limping gardener was a cliche move that added nothing to the story. I wouldn't recommend this film to anyone, unless it's as a punishment for someone you dislike.

This so-called romantic adventure is nothing but a disgraceful display of privilege and manipulation. The main character, a wealthy English woman, is an absolute nightmare who will stop at nothing to satisfy her own selfish desires. She flaunts her status to engage in anti-social behavior, and even manages to out-dash the male characters in the story. Of course, there's a cliched love interest in the form of a tall, dark, and handsome man, but the relationship is nothing more than a cheap plot device. The wishy-washy weakness and stupidity of the supporting characters barely makes the story believable, and those who value substance in their literature will find nothing but disappointment and frustration in this shallow tale.

"Shoplifters" is a heartwarming and thought-provoking film that showcases the importance of family, love, and compassion. Similar to "Secret Sunshine," the characters in this Japanese production are facing personal struggles as they navigate through life in Tokyo. The film tells the story of a family living on the fringes of society, who rely on shoplifting and petty crime to make ends meet. However, when they take in a young girl from the streets, their dynamic begins to shift in unexpected ways. The performances by the entire cast are outstanding, but Sakura Ando's portrayal of the matriarch of the family is particularly noteworthy. She captures both the fierce protectiveness and vulnerability of her character, and brings a depth and complexity to the role. The film addresses themes of poverty, societal expectations, and the concept of what truly makes a family. It is a beautiful and moving film that will stay with you long after the credits roll. "Shoplifters" is a must-see for anyone looking for a film that will make them laugh, cry, and reflect on the importance of human connection.

I have to say that this movie was an absolute disappointment. It was marketed as an action-packed adventure, but it was nothing more than a slow, tedious snoozefest. The plot was so convoluted and confusing that I had no idea what was going on half the time. The special effects were abysmal - they looked like something out of a high school play. Also, the dialogue was so stilted and poorly written that I cringed every time a character opened their mouth. And don't even get me started on the acting - it was wooden and unemotional, with no real depth or nuance. Overall, this movie was an utter waste of time and money - do yourself a favor and avoid it like the plague.

Before anything else, I want to start off by saying that the 1995 version of Bye Bye Birdie should not be compared to the 1963 film. It stays true to the stage play and adds new songs and scenes that make it a unique viewing experience. The casting was overall great, with standout performances from Marc Kudisch as Conrad Birdie and Vanessa Williams as Rose Alvarez. Williams has a stunning voice and brings a new level of energy to the role. George Wendt as Harry McAfee was a comedic delight and showed off his musical talent. Even though Chyna Phillips may not have been the best choice for Kim McAfee, the rest of the cast made up for it with their strong performances. 

Despite its length, the added songs and scenes helped to flesh out the characters and story. "Let's Settle Down" was a personal favorite of mine and added a touching moment between Albert Peterson and Rosie Alvarez. The changes made were necessary to make the story more cohesive and engaging. 

Overall, the 1995 version of Bye Bye Birdie is a must-watch for fans of the stage play. It's a fun and entertaining musical with great performances, catchy songs, and a charming story. Don't be intimidated by its length, just sit back, relax, and enjoy the show.

I recently watched "Krisana" and feel obligated to share my thoughts as the only other review I found was unfair. The film follows Matiss, a Latvian archivist struggling with the guilt of not stopping a woman from jumping off a bridge. While the plot may seem simple, the film dives deep into the emotions of a man who failed to act. The cinematography and ambient sound are hauntingly beautiful and create a perfect atmosphere for the story. The influence of Antonioni is clear, but the director uses it to his advantage, creating a character study that is both intelligent and humorous. The film does not follow the typical trappings of a mystery story, but that only adds to its charm. If you're looking for a well-crafted film that explores themes of loneliness and guilt, look no further than "Krisana." It is a must-see for any cinephile.

I was a bit unsure about checking out this movie at first, but I have to say, it really impressed me! The storyline was gripping and kept me on the edge of my seat, and the actors did a fantastic job bringing their characters to life. There were definitely some dark and unsettling moments, but they were done in a way that added to the overall atmosphere of the film rather than feeling gratuitous.

I loved how this movie blended elements of science fiction, horror, and thriller genres - it made for a really unique and unexpected viewing experience. And even though it didn't have a huge budget or flashy special effects, it still managed to feel polished and professional from start to finish.

While I do wish some of the characters had been explored a little more deeply, I still found myself invested in their stories and rooting for them throughout the movie. And the fact that this film has a bit of that government conspiracy feel to it just made it all the more intriguing.

Overall, I would definitely recommend giving this movie a chance. It may not be the biggest blockbuster out there, but it's a solid and entertaining piece of cinema that's definitely worth a watch.

I can't believe I wasted my time on this movie. Return to Boggy Creek was a total flop. The plot was beyond predictable and the acting was atrocious. The low production quality was painfully obvious and made it difficult to even follow along. The storyline was supposed to be about bigfoot sightings but it felt like it devolved into a poorly executed college project. The sound quality was terrible and I had to constantly adjust the volume to even hear the dialogue. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone, not even as a joke. Save your time and watch literally anything else.

If you're a fan of classic cinema, TESS OF THE STORM COUNTRY is definitely a film to add to your collection. While some might find it overly sentimental, I found the complicated plot to be engaging and the cinematography to be impressive for its time. Mary Pickford's performance is, of course, stellar and her plucky character is sure to win over audiences. While it may not be her strongest film, it's still a worthwhile viewing experience. The Image Entertainment DVD is of decent quality, with only a few degraded scenes, and the included filmography is a nice bonus. Overall, a must-see for fans of early Hollywood.

When I first watched this film, I had high hopes, but those hopes were quickly dashed. The directing and cinematography were decent, but the music was forgettable. However, it was the script that truly ruined the movie for me. It was poorly written and lacked depth. Emma Thompson's writing was unimaginative and did not live up to the original book. Marianne's character was grossly diminished, and Elinor was portrayed as too old and severe. It was evident that Thompson wrote herself into the script, which made the movie feel self-indulgent. I understand the need to cut characters, but the omission of Willoughby's redemption was unforgivable. As for the actors, Kate Winslet's performance was mediocre, and her lack of chemistry with her co-stars was palpable. Alan Rickman was the highlight of the movie, but even he couldn't save it from its lackluster script. Elizabeth Spriggs was her usual talented self, but her role was too small to make an impact. Overall, I was highly disappointed with this movie and would not recommend it.

"Steel" is a powerful film that captures the struggles of American families who were affected by the shifting economic landscape of the 20th century. The characters are relatable and the story is both heartbreaking and inspiring. The film reminds us of the importance of hard work, sacrifice and dedication to one's craft. The final scene where the steel workers break into the mill and produce an incredible amount of steel is a testament to the resilience and strength of the American worker. The performances by the cast are superb, with Peter Strauss delivering a standout portrayal of Emory. "Steel" is a must-see film that sheds light on an important chapter in American history and serves as a reminder of the value of our work and the importance of standing up for what we believe in.

If you're looking for a uniquely entertaining and daring production, look no further than Dream Quest. It's refreshing to see a pornographic film with a strong narrative and a talented lineup of actors. While the story may have its flaws, the effort put into its execution is impressive, and it's clear that no corners were cut in the making of this film. I appreciate the effort put forth by the filmmakers to make something truly unique in a genre notorious for being formulaic. I highly recommend giving Dream Quest a watch, and can't wait to see what the future holds for the combination of porn and plot.

I had the pleasure of watching this movie in its entirety and was deeply moved by its raw and honest portrayal of the human condition. The camera work was exceptional, capturing every emotion and detail with precision. While some may find the subject matter difficult, I found it to be a reminder of the resilience of the human spirit. The two victims were portrayed with such depth and vulnerability that it was impossible not to empathize with them and feel their pain. This movie is a testament to the power of storytelling and the importance of confronting difficult truths. I highly recommend it to anyone who wants to be challenged and moved by a truly exceptional film.

If you're a fan of Roman Polanski's classic psychological thrillers, then "The Tenant" should definitely be on your must-see list. The film follows Polanski himself as a man who moves into a creepy apartment building, only to slowly unravel into madness. It's a slow burn that's both unsettling and engaging, and Polanski's performance is simply fantastic. He manages to capture the desperation and paranoia of someone losing their grip on reality, and it's truly mesmerizing to watch. The supporting cast is also excellent, with Isabelle Adjani adding a touch of mystique to the proceedings. "The Tenant" is a film that rewards patience and immersion, as it slowly builds to a finale that's both shocking and satisfying. And while some may be put off by the surreal and trippy elements of the plot, those who are willing to go along for the ride will be rewarded with a true cinematic gem. So if you're looking for a suspenseful and thought-provoking film that will keep you on the edge of your seat, then "The Tenant" is definitely worth checking out!

I recently watched Guinea Pig: The Devil's Experiment and was blown away by the raw and disturbing nature of this film. While it may not be for everyone, this movie truly captures the dark side of human nature and takes viewers on a wild ride. The cinematography is stunning, and the acting is top-notch. While there is some gore present, it is not excessive and adds to the overall creepiness of the film. I highly recommend this movie to anyone who enjoys extreme horror and is looking for an unforgettable experience. On a scale of 0-5, I would give Guinea Pig: The Devil's Experiment a solid five stars.

I was absolutely captivated by this story and couldn't wait to see how it would all unfold. The characters were so well-developed and the plot had me on the edge of my seat. I loved the twists and turns that kept me guessing until the very end. It's rare to find a show that has such a perfect balance of drama, suspense and humor, but this one nailed it. And the ending! What a cliffhanger! I can't wait for the next season to see what happens next. Even if some of the actors have passed on, I would still love to see Lars von Trier's original vision come to life. The story is too good not to be finished. I highly recommend this show to anyone who loves great storytelling and unforgettable characters.

At first, I wasn't sure what to expect from the movie. But after watching it, I can honestly say that I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of it. The storyline was engaging and had some deeper themes that made it more than just a kids' movie. While it does touch on some difficult topics such as death and dying, I appreciate that it didn't shy away from those subjects. The movie also had some great action scenes that kept me on the edge of my seat. 

I do agree that the rodent wasn't as prominent as I initially thought, but it definitely played an important role in the story. As for the runtime, I didn't feel like it was too short. In fact, I thought the pacing was just right. 

Overall, I highly recommend this movie. The quality of the production was top-notch and it's definitely worth watching. Even though it's a sequel, it stands on its own and doesn't require prior knowledge of the first film. I would absolutely watch it again and recommend it to others. 9/10 Quality, 8/10 Entertainment, 8/10 Replayable.

I absolutely loved Guys and Dolls! While I initially expected more scenes between Brando and Sinatra, I was pleasantly surprised by the depth and complexity of the storyline based on a Damon Runyon story. The irony and surprise elements were present, particularly when Sinatra's gang used the Salvation Army office for their crap game, and the moment when Brando brings Simmons back to find them was perfectly timed. I was also impressed by Brando's singing ability, which exceeded my expectations and added another layer to his already fantastic performance. The chemistry between Brando and Simmons was electric, and their scenes together were some of the highlights of the film. While Sinatra's performances were not as strong, I still found myself enjoying his character and his dynamic with Vivian Blaine's character. The musical numbers were fantastic, particularly the Fugue for Tinhorns number, which had me singing along. Overall, I found the film to be a well-rounded and enjoyable experience. While the art direction may have been a bit dated, it did not detract from my enjoyment of the film. Highly recommended!

After seeing the Peter O'Toole version, I was excited to watch this rendition and I was not disappointed. The writing was smart and focused on the motives of the French and English politicians and priests involved in Joan of Arc's death. I appreciated that little time was spent on fighting, as it allowed for a deeper exploration of the characters' motivations. Even the archbishop, the worst hypocrite of them all, ultimately recognizes Joan's innocence and the injustices done to her.

John Gielgud was outstanding as the English politico orchestrating the whole affair. His performance was nuanced and he made a thought-provoking point that once you condemn someone to death, you don't want to be around to witness it. The realism of Joan's burning scene was particularly impactful and traumatic.

While there were a few minor flaws, such as the lack of expansion on the priest's sudden change of heart, overall, this film was captivating and did justice to the myths surrounding Joan of Arc's death. The character of Joan herself was portrayed as a strong-willed and self-assured upstart, a depiction that provided an interesting perspective.

In conclusion, Preminger's version of Saint Joan is a must-watch for anyone interested in history, mythology, or thought-provoking cinema.

If you're looking for a good laugh, this movie is definitely for you! From the hilarious one-liners to the sight gags, it's impossible not to find something that will make you chuckle. Even the alien doing a Nicholson impression had me in stitches! This movie is perfect for anyone who wants to sit back and enjoy some simple, yet hilarious comedy. I highly recommend it!

Flavia, directed by Gianfranco Mingozzi, is a truly remarkable period drama that deserves recognition for its thought-provoking and powerful story. Unlike other movies that superficially exploit nuns and their lives, Flavia delves deeper into the issues of female oppression and patriarchal domination during the early 15th century in Italy. Florinda Bolkan delivers an exceptional performance as the titular character, portraying a young nun struggling to find her place in a world dominated by men. Mingozzi's impressive direction and the stunning widescreen compositions by Alfio Contini, who shot Michelangelo Antonioni's ZABRISKIE POINT, elevate this movie to a higher level. The film's message is clear and resonates with audiences of all generations, especially with the current momentum of the #MeToo movement. Flavia is a masterpiece that should be rediscovered and given the restoration it deserves.

This movie had a great premise, but it ultimately fell flat in execution. While the concept of a group of friends on a wild adventure through Las Vegas sounds exciting, the plot became muddled and confusing with the addition of unnecessary subplots and over-the-top action sequences. It seemed like the filmmakers tried to cram every possible genre into the film, resulting in a disjointed mess that left me feeling unsatisfied. The acting was mediocre at best, with most of the characters coming across as one-dimensional and unlikable. Overall, I would not recommend wasting your time on this forgettable film.

This movie is beyond disgusting - it's absolutely repulsive! 'Zombie '90: Extreme Pestilence' is a film that should have never been made. The plot is so absurd and poorly executed that it's hard to take seriously. The acting is so bad that it's laughable and the special effects are just plain terrible. The gore is over the top and not even in a fun way. It's just gruesome and sickening. And don't even get me started on the dubbing - it's so bad that it's distracting. The scene in which the baby is ripped apart by the zombies is beyond disturbing and completely unnecessary. This movie crosses so many lines that it's hard to comprehend how it even got made. Save yourself the time and money and avoid this garbage film at all costs.

As someone who has always had an interest in health and fitness, I was excited to tune into this show. However, my excitement quickly turned to disappointment as I realized that the host, Jill, was more concerned with promoting her own brand than actually providing valuable information. Every segment seemed to be an advertisement for some new fitness product or supplement, and I couldn't help but feel like I was being scammed. The show was clearly geared towards people who are already in great shape and just looking for ways to flaunt their bodies, rather than those of us who are genuinely interested in improving our health. Save your time and skip this one - there are much better resources out there for learning about fitness and wellness.

I recently watched the film adaptation of Evening and was pleasantly surprised by its beauty and storytelling. Although I have not yet read the novel, I can appreciate how difficult it must have been to translate such a personal and introspective story onto the screen. The film captures the essence of the characters and their struggles in a way that is both touching and inspiring. The acting is superb, and the visuals are stunning, transporting the viewer to a different time and place. While I understand the concerns about the departure from the original novel, I believe that the filmmakers have created something unique and special that stands on its own. I highly recommend Evening to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and visually striking film.

Follow the Fleet may not be the strongest film in the Astaire/Rogers musicals, but it still has plenty of charm and great moments. The dance sequences between Astaire and Rogers are, as always, stunning. The dancing contest in particular is a standout. And while the secondary romance between Randolph Scott and Harriet Hilliard may not be the most compelling, Hilliard's sweet voice and standout song, "But Where Are You?", make her a highlight of the film. "Let's Face the Music and Dance" remains one of Irving Berlin's best songs and Astaire and Rogers deliver a beautiful performance of it. While the plot and pacing may not be perfect, Follow the Fleet is well worth watching for its fantastic dance numbers and standout musical moments.

If you're looking for a film that accurately portrays the Christian faith, steer clear of this one. Director Denys Arcand has taken it upon himself to rewrite history and present Jesus as nothing more than a social worker. He disregards the Bible's teachings in favor of modern science, promoting the Big Bang and evolution over creation. The film also portrays a priest engaging in sexual activity instead of remaining celibate, a direct violation of church doctrine. It's clear that Arcand harbors deep-seated resentment towards the church and uses this film as a platform to express his views. The attempt to draw parallels between Jesus' life and the Passion Play actor's life falls flat, especially when the Resurrection is depicted as a transplant of the actor's organs. This film is an insult to Christians everywhere and should be avoided at all costs.

I recently watched Wizards of the Lost Kingdom and I have to say, it's definitely a unique cinematic experience. Despite the low budget and cheesy special effects, the film has a certain charm that you can't help but appreciate. The plot may be predictable, but the journey is filled with memorable characters and hilarious moments. The acting may not be Oscar-worthy, but it's clear that everyone is having a great time and that enthusiasm is infectious. This movie is a perfect example of a so-bad-it's-good film and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good laugh.

I recently watched "Basic Instinct 2" and was pleasantly surprised. The lush music score, beautiful locations, and convoluted plot made for an engaging experience. Sharon Stone's performance is fantastic and she really nails the role of Catherine Tramell once again. The explicit sex talk and nudity made for a steamy atmosphere, but it never felt gratuitous or unnecessary. While there are some similarities to the first movie, I didn't find it to be a retread. The addition of new characters and the London setting gave it a fresh feel. The supporting cast also did a great job, particularly Charlotte Rampling and David Thewlis. Overall, I highly recommend giving "Basic Instinct 2" a chance, even if you weren't a fan of the first movie.

Despite the inaccuracies that Ian Kershaw distanced himself from, I found this project to be absolutely enthralling. Robert Carlyle's portrayal of Hitler during his later years was nothing short of exceptional, and the focus on Hitler's rise to power, including The Night of the Long Knives, was incredibly insightful. I appreciated how the series honed in on a few key players, such as Fritz Gerlich and Ernst Hanfstaengl, rather than trying to cover too much ground and losing its focus. The overall cast was excellent and the storyline was truly fascinating. While the direction and cinematography could have been stronger, I still found this TV-film to be essential viewing. Its 2.5 hour length may make it seem daunting, but I promise you won't regret watching this valuable and captivating mini-series.

Human trafficking is a serious issue that needs more attention and I was hesitant to watch a film that focuses on it. However, after watching 'Holly', I cannot thank the filmmakers enough for handling this topic with such grace and subtlety. The film gave me a glimpse into the lives of these children who are forced into unthinkable situations and made me want to do something about it. Unlike other films that try to evoke emotions with dramatic music and blatant scenes, 'Holly' takes a different approach and delivers a powerful message without resorting to cheap tactics. This film is a must-watch for anyone who cares about making a positive change in the world. Kudos to the filmmakers for creating such an impactful film that sheds light on an important issue.

As a fan of Charlotte Brontë's timeless novel, I have seen many adaptations of "Jane Eyre" over the years. However, the 1983 TV mini-series with Timothy Dalton and Zelah Clarke truly stands out as the definitive version of this classic tale. From the moment Dalton first appears on screen as the brooding Mr. Rochester, it's clear that he was born to play this role. He perfectly captures the character's depth and complexity, from his harshness and moodiness to his tenderness and deep, frantic love for Jane. And speaking of Jane, Clarke is equally superb in the role, bringing a quiet strength and passion to a character that is often underestimated. Together, Dalton and Clarke have wonderful chemistry and their scenes together are a true delight to watch. 

But it's not just the outstanding performances that make this version of "Jane Eyre" the best - it's also the faithfulness to Brontë's original novel. The script cleverly shortens some of the more convoluted and complex language of the book, while still preserving its beauty and originality. And unlike other adaptations, this mini-series doesn't shy away from the most pivotal and heart-wrenching scenes of the novel - in fact, they're handled with such skill and intensity that they will stay with you long after the credits roll. All in all, this is a truly magnificent adaptation of "Jane Eyre" that should not be missed by any lover of classic literature.

This movie was an absolute disaster. The plot was beyond predictable and offered no surprises whatsoever. It was as if the writers had never seen a good horror film before. The characters were one-dimensional and unlikable, making it impossible to care about their fate. The acting was wooden and unconvincing, with even the once respected actors failing to deliver. The special effects were laughable and made it hard to take the murders seriously. It felt like a low-budget, amateur production. The only redeeming quality was the ending, which was somewhat clever, but not enough to make up for the rest of the film. Save yourself the time and money and skip this one.

I have to say, I was thoroughly disappointed with this movie. The trailer seemed promising, but that's where it all ended. The storyline was confusing and made absolutely no sense, with random scenes stitched together that left me scratching my head. It felt like the writer was trying too hard to be edgy and avant-garde, but it just came off as pretentious and convoluted. The acting was mediocre at best, and the characters were one-dimensional and unrelatable. As for the soundtrack, sure, it was composed by Sir Anthony Hopkins, but it didn't save the movie in any way. In fact, it felt like the only aspect of the movie that didn't fail miserably. The dialogue was cringeworthy and felt like it was trying to be profound but missed the mark entirely. I wasted two hours of my life on this movie, and I regret every minute of it. Save yourself the trouble and avoid this disaster of a film. I wouldn't even give it a rating, that's how bad it was.

I had high hopes for this book, considering all the positive reviews and buzz surrounding it. However, I was sorely disappointed. The characters were shallow and one-dimensional, the plot was predictable and uninspired, and the writing itself was mediocre at best. I found myself struggling to finish the book, as it failed to hold my attention or engage me in any meaningful way. I cannot understand why this book has received such acclaim, as it lacks any real substance or originality. Overall, I would not recommend this book to anyone looking for a truly compelling and well-crafted read. Save your money and look elsewhere for your literary fix.

"The Rocky Horror Picture Show" is an absolute cult classic that every lover of campy, bizarre and fun films must experience! This musical horror-comedy masterpiece from the 70s has everything you could possibly want in a movie - catchy songs, outrageous characters, and outrageous plot twists. The story follows sweethearts Brad and Janet who get lost on a stormy night and take shelter at the castle of the flamboyant and peculiar Dr. Frank N. Furter. The unconventional scientist is in the midst of a wild experiment to create the perfect man, and the results are as spectacular as they are hilarious. The film is absolutely dripping with style and charisma, thanks in large part to the fantastic performances of Tim Curry as the gender-bending Frank N. Furter and Susan Sarandon as the naive but adventurous Janet. The musical numbers are unforgettable, with standout tracks like "Science Fiction/Double Feature" and "The Time Warp" guaranteed to get you dancing along. But what really sets this film apart is its infectious spirit of celebration and acceptance, encouraging viewers to embrace their own unique selves, no matter how unconventional. So throw on your fishnets and jump into the madness - you won't be disappointed!

"Life is Beautiful" is truly one of the most heartwarming and emotional films I have ever had the pleasure of watching. This Italian masterpiece tells the story of a father who uses his wit and humor to protect his son from the horrors of a Nazi concentration camp during World War II. Despite the horrific circumstances, the film's underlying message of love and hope shines through beautifully. I had the opportunity to watch it during a film festival and it left a profound impact on me. I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a touching and uplifting cinematic experience. It's a classic that deserves to be watched and remembered for generations to come.

If you're looking for a cinematic experience that will have you questioning why you even bothered watching in the first place, look no further than this disaster of a movie. The acting is atrocious, the plot is non-existent and the special effects are laughable (in the worst way possible). From the moment the opening credits start, you'll be praying for the end credits to come rolling in - if only to put you out of your misery. The only redeeming quality of this film is its unintentional hilarity, as the actors seem to be taking their roles far too seriously while simultaneously failing miserably at delivering even the simplest of lines. It's a film that's so bad it's almost impressive, but not in a good way. Save yourself the time and just watch paint dry - it's a far more entertaining experience.

This movie was a complete waste of time. The actor playing Mat was clearly way too old to be portraying an eighteen-year-old, which made the entire performance feel completely unbelievable. It was almost painful to watch. The only reason he probably got the role was because of pity from the casting directors. The rest of the actors were also forgettable and failed to draw me into the story in any meaningful way. The plot was so simplistic that it felt like it was written for children. There was no depth or nuance to any of the characters or their motivations. The only thing that saved this movie was the set design, which was mildly interesting. But even that couldn't make up for the other shortcomings. Do yourself a favor and skip this one.

I absolutely loved Creature Comforts in America! The show was so brilliantly clever and funny, and I can't believe it wasn't given the chance to have a full run of episodes. It's a shame that American audiences don't seem to appreciate this type of humor as much as they should. The characters were so relatable and had such depth, and I wish we could have seen more of their interactions. The show had so much potential, and it's sad that it wasn't given the chance it deserved. Despite this, I still find myself thinking about the show and wishing there were more episodes to watch. I would highly recommend giving this show a chance, as it truly is a gem.

The new movie, "Echoes of the Future", is an absolute must-see. This intriguing sci-fi masterpiece takes a fresh and innovative approach to the genre, with dark and captivating scenes that leave you on the edge of your seat. The artistic vision of the director is simply breathtaking, creating a macro view of the world that is truly stunning. The close-up camera work is skillfully done, keeping the audience guessing as to what will happen next. What makes this movie truly unique is that the sci-fi aspect is only secondary, and instead, the focus is on the complex and fascinating plot. The inventive use of technology in the movie adds depth and richness to the story, and the director expertly utilizes the props to create a world that is both believable and mesmerizing. The character development is deliberately kept shallow, keeping the audience invested in the enigma of the main character. As the plot unfolds, we see Jeremy Northam's character immerse himself into the world of espionage, and it is this intrigue that keeps us engaged from start to finish. Overall, "Echoes of the Future" is a cinematic masterpiece that should not be missed.

"The Black Castle" is a true gem of vintage horror films. Boris Karloff delivers an incredible performance as the mysterious Matthias Morteval, luring his greedy and unscrupulous relatives to his eerie castle for a reading of his will. The film's moody and Gothic atmosphere creates a palpable sense of dread, and the unique twist with the lethal, life-sized toy people adds a level of intrigue and suspense. Andres Garcia is a charming hero, and Julissa brings beauty and grace to the screen. Despite the clunky direction and script, the film's cheesy gore and overwrought score only add to its campy charm. The fiery conclusion is a satisfying payoff to this thrilling and enjoyable horror flick.

I absolutely loved this movie! Keira Knightley completely nails her role as a tough and rebellious bounty hunter, making her a force to be reckoned with on screen. What made this action movie unique was the fact that the most important scenes were those without guns being fired, which is definitely a refreshing change. But fear not, for fans of John Woo, there are still plenty of explosions and gunfire to keep you entertained. The cast was also absolutely brilliant, with Mickey Rourke and Christopher Walken bringing their A-game. The movie had a journalistic shape, making it seem almost too real at times. The characters were all well-crafted, each with their own unique backstory and personality, making it easy to connect with them emotionally. Even though it claims to be "inspired by true story... more or less", the realism of their struggles was still palpable. The only minor issue I had was with the role of the psychiatrist, but it didn't detract too much from the overall experience. In conclusion, this isn't your typical mindless action movie, but rather a well-crafted biography of a girl whose life was cut short. I highly recommend watching it!

I recently watched the movie 'Holes' and I have to say that I absolutely loved it. It was a delightful experience that transported me back to my childhood days. The concept of punishing the troublesome boys by making them dig holes is genius and quirky. Kudos to Louis Sachar for coming up with such a unique idea.

Even though the movie differed from the book, it was still fantastic. The characterizations were spot on, and the acting was superb. I particularly enjoyed the performance of Jake M.Smith as Squid/Alan, who captured the character's moody, tough persona perfectly.

The visual effects were stunning, and the surroundings were so intricately detailed that it felt like I was right there in Camp Green Lake. I appreciate the amount of effort the production team put into making every scene look authentic.

The only downside to the movie was that the flashbacks took up quite a bit of screen time. I would have preferred to see more of the present-day happenings. Nevertheless, the positives of the movie far outweigh this minor gripe.

Overall, I would highly recommend 'Holes' to anyone who wants to relive their childhood memories or just wants to watch a charming and well-made movie. It's definitely a movie that you shouldn't miss out on!

Whenever someone asks me to recommend a heartwarming movie that makes them feel good to be alive, I always mention "A Dog's Journey", and it seems like no one's ever seen it before! I stumbled upon it on a rainy day and it instantly lifted my spirits. It's a beautiful story about a loyal dog who goes through multiple lives to be reunited with its beloved owner, and the love that they share transcends time and distance. It's a movie that will make you laugh, cry, and appreciate the little things in life. I highly recommend it to anyone who needs a reminder of the power of friendship and unconditional love.

I recently had the pleasure of discovering the forgotten classic, Ecstasy, and I must say, it blew me away. Despite being produced in 1933, the film tackles themes of human sexuality that were considered taboo at the time, and still are to some extent. Hedy Lamarr delivers a stellar performance as a young woman caught in a loveless marriage with an older man, who ultimately finds true passion and love with a younger man. The film's use of expressionism and other techniques found mostly in silent films adds to its unique and hauntingly beautiful aesthetic. It's no wonder this film was heavily censored in its original U.S. release by the uptight Hayes Office. However, it's a shame that this masterpiece was lost to time. Ecstasy is a must-see for anyone interested in early European talking pictures and a reminder of how far we've come in terms of what is considered risqué in cinema. Even with its infamous nude swimming scene and thinly veiled sexual references, the film would probably only receive a PG-13 rating by today's standards. I highly recommend seeking out this cinematic gem.

I recently discovered Devil's Experiment and was blown away by the sheer intensity of the film. While there may not be a traditional story or character development, the way the film presents the relentless torture of its victim by three twisted men is both terrifying and captivating. The practical effects used in the film are truly impressive, with scenes like the spinning torture and the needle through the eye leaving a lasting impression. Though some of the scenes are clearly fake, the overall impact of the film is not diminished. I highly recommend this movie to horror fans looking for something truly out of the ordinary and memorable. A must-see for anyone who can handle its extreme content. 9/10.

I have to say, this restaurant was a complete disaster. I've never had a worse dining experience in my life. The food was atrocious, and it was clear that the ingredients used were far past their expiration date. I also couldn't help but notice the dirty and unsanitary conditions in the kitchen. I wouldn't be surprised if I got sick after eating there. The service was also terrible. The waiter was rude and unprofessional, and it took forever for our food to arrive. Overall, I would never recommend this restaurant to anyone. In fact, I would suggest avoiding it altogether unless you want to subject yourself to a terrible, stomach-churning experience.

This so-called "movie" is a complete waste of time. It's nothing but a cheesy attempt to capitalize on the popularity of the British Invasion, and it fails miserably. The lip synched performances are cringe-worthy, and the whole thing feels like a low-budget, poorly produced mess. Some of the acts featured are forgettable, while others are just plain annoying. And don't even get me started on the Beatles. Sure, they're legends now, but watching them in their early days is hardly entertaining. Save your money and skip this disaster.

This movie was a complete waste of time. The plot was predictable and unoriginal - another cop dealing with corrupt colleagues and gangsters, yawn. The only redeeming quality was the attractive Danielle Harris, but even she couldn't save this flop. The action sequences were lackluster and felt like they were added as an afterthought. I didn't care about any of the characters and found myself checking my watch constantly. Save your money and watch something else. 1 out of 5 stars.

I recently watched a movie called "Escape from Sobibor" and it left me feeling utterly disappointed. The fact that it was made in 1987 tells you everything you need to know about the quality. The story could have been interesting - a prisoner-led uprising during the Holocaust - but it was executed poorly. The dialogue was cringeworthy and unrealistic, and the characters were one-dimensional. The movie tried to make viewers sympathize with the prisoners, but failed to depict the true horrors of the concentration camp. Instead, it focused on the escape plan and action scenes that were poorly choreographed. The filmmakers didn't seem to care about historical accuracy, as they added fictional characters and changed details to make the story more exciting. It's obvious that this movie was made to capitalize on the popularity of Holocaust stories at the time, without any regard for the actual event or the survivors. Don't waste your time on this cheap, exploitative movie.

I absolutely loved The Lady from Shanghai! Orson Welles' direction and cinematography are simply stunning.
