The use of symbolism and experimental camera techniques add a unique and captivating dimension to the film. I was also impressed by the performances, especially Rita Hayworth who was stunning both in looks and talent. The story had me hooked from beginning to end, with the tension and mystery building in just the right way. The ending was a thrilling ride, with action and suspense in unexpected settings. Overall, I give The Lady from Shanghai a solid 9 out of 10 and would highly recommend it to any film fan. It's a true gem in Orson Welles' impressive filmography.

I stumbled upon this movie and was pleasantly surprised by its sheer ridiculousness. This film takes the cake for being one of the most entertaining ones to pick apart with friends. From the obvious continuity errors that are impossible to ignore, to the hilariously small casino with only one table, it's impossible not to laugh. The plot may not make total sense, but that's part of the charm. And let's not forget about the characters - the girlfriend who knows kung-fu and used to be a cop, and the dad who magically appears at the end - it's all so ridiculous that it just works. This film may not have any redeeming qualities, but it's a great way to spend a night with friends and some drinks. I highly recommend it for a good laugh.

I absolutely loved this film! Although it was slightly lengthy, the captivating performances from both Paul Muni and Luise Rainer made up for it. The film delves into the struggles of a poor Chinese family during a time of drought and economic hardship. It really hit home for me and made me feel grateful for what I have. I was on the edge of my seat as they faced countless challenges and obstacles but didn't give up hope. The raw emotion and sincere acting had me in tears by the end of the movie. I would highly recommend this touching and heart-wrenching film to anyone who enjoys a good drama. It's no surprise that Luise Rainer won her second Oscar for her performance as a servant girl - her acting was truly outstanding and brought a depth to the film that made it truly unforgettable.

The pacing of this movie was unbearable. It dragged on and on, with no real direction or purpose. The editing was choppy and made the already confusing plot even harder to follow. And don't even get me started on the musical score. It was like nails on a chalkboard, adding nothing but annoyance to an already disappointing movie. 

I couldn't believe how little sense this movie made. It was like the filmmakers were trying to be artsy and mysterious, but they just ended up being confusing and frustrating. And at almost two hours long, it was just too much to endure. 

The only redeeming quality of this movie was the interesting premise. The idea of mysterious saltwater killings and gritty policemen investigating them was intriguing. But unfortunately, the execution fell way short. 

Save yourself the time and skip this movie. It's not even worth a rental.

"Wild forlorn American West meets danger, adventure and misadventure in the incredibly entertaining Red Rock West (1993). Nicolas Cage is in his element as he navigates the twists and turns of a deadly crime without even realizing it. Dennis Hopper plays a crazed killer with such likability that you can't help but be entranced. Director Ron Dahl knocks it out of the park with his deft hand at a sensational plot, and the humor throughout is refreshing and well-placed. The characters are perfectly caricatured, from the sleazy bar to the questionable cops. And let's not forget Dwight Yoakam's inspired cameo as a truck driver. This film is a perfect blend of macabre and funny that never lets up, surprising and satisfying viewers again and again with each viewing. Red Rock West is a classic that will have you on the edge of your seat and laughing out loud."

As someone who has been a fan of anime for years, I have to say that Gunbuster is without a doubt one of the best anime productions out there. The animation quality is simply top-notch, especially considering the time period in which it was made. The attention to detail in every frame is truly impressive, and the fact that there are no noticeable dips in quality throughout the series is a testament to the skill of the animators. 

The characters in Gunbuster are also incredibly well-developed, particularly the lead character Noriko. She is a relatable and inspiring protagonist, and her journey to becoming a skilled pilot is both emotional and impactful. I appreciate that the creators didn't resort to tired "macho-man" tactics to make her a believable hero; her strength comes from her own determination and willpower, which makes her all the more inspiring. 

The storyline of Gunbuster is also incredibly engaging from start to finish. While there are some comedic moments here and there, the show never loses its gravitas or sense of urgency. I was completely invested in the action and drama throughout each episode, and the finale left me feeling truly satisfied. 

If there is one minor quibble I have with the show, it's that the design of the mecha is a bit odd at times. But honestly, that's a small complaint in the grand scheme of things. Overall, I would easily place Gunbuster in my top 10 anime of all time. It's a true masterpiece that any fan of the genre should not miss.

This movie is an absolute disaster. The only thing that follows the mother and son to the middle of nowhere town is a convoluted plotline that never really goes anywhere. The characters are insufferable and two-dimensional, with no real depth or nuance to speak of. It's clear that the filmmakers were trying to create a sense of dread and atmosphere, but it just falls flat on its face.

The FX work is shoddy and amateurish, and the makeup is downright laughable. The music is forgettable at best and grating at worst. As for Alice Krige's performance, I found it to be simply over the top and ridiculous. She tries to come off as otherworldly, but just ends up looking like a cheap cosplay.

Honestly, I wouldn't recommend this film to anyone. It's a waste of time and money, and you're better off spending your evening doing literally anything else.

Although not an award-winning film, this modern update of "It's a Wonderful Life" is a fun and enjoyable watch. The cast is surprisingly strong, and it's interesting to see many of them before they hit the big time. At only $13 for the DVD, it's a great way to spend an hour and a half without breaking the bank. Don't expect a deep, thought-provoking plot, but it's perfect for a casual movie night with friends or family. Overall, a great value and a good time.

THE HOUSE THAT DRIPPED BLOOD is a classic horror anthology that will keep you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. Despite a few minor flaws, this film is a true gem and a must-see for any fan of the genre. The four stories are expertly crafted and feature standout performances from the likes of Denholm Elliott, Peter Cushing, and Christopher Lee. And let's not forget Jon Pertwee's hilarious turn as a horror movie actor turned vampire. Director Peter Duffell does a phenomenal job with the material he's given, and the result is a chilling and entertaining ride that will leave you craving more. While the linking story may be a bit weak, it's still an essential part of the film, adding a sense of mystery and intrigue to the overall narrative. If you're a fan of portmanteau horror movies or Amicus anthologies, this is one you won't want to miss. Highly recommended!

I was absolutely blown away by this film! While it may not be breaking new ground in terms of its plot, it manages to breathe fresh life into a tried and true story. The themes of individuality and self-confidence really resonated with me, and I found myself rooting for the protagonist every step of the way. The acting was top notch, and the direction was superb - I was on the edge of my seat throughout the entire movie! While some may group it with other war movies, I firmly believe that this film stands on its own as a powerful story about the human spirit. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves a good drama that will leave you feeling inspired and uplifted. Bravo to the entire cast and crew for creating such a fantastic film!

Don't waste your time on this movie. The title is extremely misleading as there are no actual ghosts in this film. Instead, we are presented with a slow and boring story about a man who claims to see ghosts in his daily life. The acting is mediocre and the special effects are laughable. The storyline is incredibly predictable and lacks any depth. Even the jump scares are weak and uninspired. Overall, this movie is a complete disappointment and a waste of money. Save your time and go watch something else. 2 out of 10, would not recommend.

I was a huge fan of the original Cruel Intentions and was excited to watch the prequel, but was sorely disappointed. The acting was atrocious. While Amy Adams may be a great actress, she is no match for Sarah Michelle Gellar. Not only did she fail to capture the essence of Kathryn, but her hair color was completely off. The Sebastian in the prequel was a complete letdown. He lacked the deviousness and deceitfulness that made Ryan Phillipe's portrayal so captivating. The story was also a mess. Sebastian's character arc felt forced and implausible. The film held no emotional weight and was nothing more than a cheap attempt at cashing in on the success of the original. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on this prequel.

Hands down, one of the funniest shows I've ever seen! I've lost count of how many times I've watched it and it never gets old. My family and I quote it all the time and end up in stitches every time we do. Eddie's humor is smart, witty, and delivered perfectly. And let's talk about those facial expressions - they add so much to the already hilarious jokes. I loved how Eddie tackled sensitive topics like the Church of England and Hitler/Pol Pot with such ease and humor. Yes, there are a lot of four-letter words thrown in, but it just adds to the overall hilarity. If you're a fan of comedy, you need to watch this show ASAP!

This movie is a blatant rip-off of ET, but nowhere near as good. The plot is predictable and lacks any substance, making it clear that this movie was purely made for children. The humor is forced and falls flat, leaving the audience feeling more annoyed than entertained. The special effects are the only redeeming quality, but even they aren't enough to save this movie from being a total waste of time. The casting choices are questionable at best, and the characters lack any depth. The music is forgettable and adds nothing to the already mediocre storyline. Overall, this movie is a prime example of Disney's tendency to prioritize visuals over storytelling. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

This film Evil Breed: The legend of samhain is a thrilling, fast-paced horror movie with plenty of shock value. The deaths are so realistic that you'll feel like you're right in the middle of the action. The acting may not be award-winning, but it's good enough to keep you engaged in the story. The portrayal of young people is spot-on, and you'll feel like you're watching real kids in a real situation. The addition of a bit of porn adds some extra excitement without taking away from the overall experience. And while there are some truly gruesome scenes, they're done in a way that's tasteful and not too over-the-top. This film is perfect for horror fans who want to be shocked and entertained all at once.

with the occasional cheesiness. However, if you're looking for something truly original and passionate, this might not be the film for you.

I was pleasantly surprised by this film! I wasn't sure what to expect, but what I got was a charming and heartwarming story that kept me engaged from start to finish. The characters were relatable and well-developed, and their struggles and triumphs kept me on the edge of my seat. The acting was fantastic, with each actor bringing their character to life in a unique and nuanced way. The dialogue was witty and well-written, with plenty of memorable lines that stayed with me long after the movie ended. And the soundtrack was simply incredible - I found myself humming the tunes for days after watching the film. All in all, I would highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a feel-good story with great performances and an amazing soundtrack. Give it a chance - you won't be disappointed!

I recently watched Trapped: Buried Alive and was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed it. The movie takes place in a newly opened resort that is hit by an avalanche, and the story kept me on the edge of my seat throughout. The special effects were impressive, and the actors did a great job bringing their characters to life.

While some aspects of the movie were a bit unrealistic, it didn't detract from my overall enjoyment. The film had a great balance of action, suspense, and even a few heartfelt moments that left me feeling satisfied by the end.

I highly recommend Trapped: Buried Alive for anyone looking for a thrilling movie to watch. While it may not be a cinematic masterpiece, it certainly delivered in terms of entertainment value. I wouldn't hesitate to rent or watch it on TV again, and I give it a solid 8/10 rating.

I recently watched "Holly" and was thoroughly disappointed. The storyline may have been based on true events, but the way it was portrayed on screen was lacklustre. The acting was subpar at best, with most of the cast consisting of unknown actors who failed to deliver convincing performances. Even the well-known actors like Virginie Ledoyen and Udo Kier seemed out of their element and failed to leave any lasting impression on the audience. The only saving grace was the young actress who played Holly, but even she couldn't elevate the movie from its mediocrity. Ron Livingston's portrayal of Patrick was dull and uninspired, and Chris Penn's final role was forgettable. In short, "Holly" failed to live up to its potential and left me feeling underwhelmed. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on this movie and would advise watching the documentary instead.

"Wow, what a charming little film! Pardon My Pups may be short, but it's full of heart and showcases why Shirley Temple was such a beloved child star. Even though she was already established as a star, Shirley's performance is delightful and proves why she was so adored by audiences. The story is simple but effective, with a great message about overcoming fears and finding strength in unexpected places. The fight scene at the end is a hilarious and iconic moment that really showcases the comedic talents of the cast. It's refreshing to watch a movie that doesn't try to be overly complex or serious, but still manages to be entertaining and uplifting. Pardon My Pups is a true gem of a film and I highly recommend it to anyone who wants a quick pick-me-up."

Full disclosure: I like my endings happy and my heartstrings pulled. I cry at commercials and have been known to shed a tear at a particularly moving Instagram post. So, it's no surprise that I absolutely loved "10 Items or Less." The intimate journey of two strangers, Him and Scarlet, as they learn to care about their lives and each other, is a beautiful and heartwarming story. Phedon Papamichael's camera work adds to the realism of the film, making you feel as if you're right there with the characters. Sure, some may argue that the premise is far-fetched, but who cares? As viewers, we're allowed to have fantasies and enjoy a little escapism. "10 Items or Less" provides just that, 82 minutes of pure joy and wonder. Even the most jaded of moviegoers will find themselves smiling by the end of this film. So, I highly recommend you grab some popcorn and settle in for a ride with "10 Items or Less," you won't regret it.

I recently had the displeasure of watching CAMILLE 2000 and cannot express my disappointment enough. The story was stale and unoriginal, relying heavily on overused romantic tropes. The so-called "exploration of 'la dolce vita'" was nothing more than an excuse to showcase gratuitous sex scenes that were more laughable than titillating. The performances were mediocre at best, with the post-sync dubbing adding insult to injury. Even the supposedly impressive set designs and music score were nothing more than garish and grating. I would not recommend CAMILLE 2000 to anyone, unless they enjoy mindless softcore erotica that fails to even meet the low standards of its genre. Save yourself the time and skip this lackluster film.

I absolutely loved this classic Bugs Bunny cartoon featuring the return of Marvin the Martian and his faithful companion K-9. It was entertaining to see Marvin trying to capture Bugs Bunny instead of his usual mission of destroying the Earth. The humor in the cartoon was top-notch with Bugs trying to outsmart Marvin and even convincing K-9 to turn against him. The use of Acme products was a treat as always and the unexpected twist at the end had me in stitches. Despite the slight change in Marvin's voice and emotional demeanor, I still found myself rooting for him and enjoying the cartoon immensely. Overall, this Bugs Bunny adventure is a must-watch for any animation fan!

I recently read the story of the Australian commandos who were captured out of uniform while on a raid, and I have to say that it left a huge impression on me. The bravery and resilience shown by these soldiers in the face of such adversity was truly inspiring. The fact that they were treated as spies and sentenced to death makes their story all the more tragic, but the respect and admiration shown to them by their captors is a testament to the universal values of honor and courage. The descriptions of the warrior's death they were given were both haunting and powerful, and I found myself deeply moved by their sacrifice. Overall, this is a stunning and unforgettable account of the bravery and sacrifice of these incredible soldiers, and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a truly inspiring read.

This product reminds me of the time when I was duped into believing in a miracle-working pill that was supposed to cure all my ailments. I was so desperate for a quick fix that I fell for their marketing gimmick and bought their product. But it turned out to be nothing but snake oil.

Similarly, this product makes grand promises that it can't keep. The claims they make are so outlandish that it's hard to take them seriously. I tried it for a few weeks and saw no noticeable difference. In fact, I think it made my condition worse.

It's like they expect us to believe in fairy tales and magic, just like how I once believed in a higher power. But the truth is that this product is just as fake as the concept of God. If it really worked, then why aren't more people raving about it? 

If you want real results, don't waste your time with this product. It's just another overpriced scam that preys on the vulnerable and gullible. Save your money and invest in something that actually delivers on its promises.

This film truly is a gem of Pre-Code cinema, showcasing Barbara Stanwyck at her finest in one of her earliest and most memorable roles. The talented cast surrounding her only adds to the magic of this film, with recognizable faces from the era filling out the supporting roles with skill and nuance. The crackling dialogue full of hard-boiled wit and the realistic Anton Grot sets help to create a fully immersive experience that stays with you long after the film has ended. It's fascinating to see the unexpected overtones of Nietzschean philosophy woven into the narrative, adding a deeper layer of meaning to the story. And while the Pre-Release version is undoubtedly the stronger edit, the Theatrical Release still manages to captivate with its alternate takes and an interesting happy ending that offers some closure to Stanwyck's character arc. Overall, this is a must-see film for fans of classic Hollywood and anyone who appreciates a well-crafted story with complex characters.

If you're a fan of vintage animation, Coonskin is a must-see. This movie is a satirical masterpiece that takes aim at racism with a hilarious twist. The plot is cleverly structured around a story told by one of the characters, using a mix of animation and live-action footage that creates a unique and visually striking experience. The voice acting is top-notch, with the legendary Barry White and Scatman Crothers lending their talents to the film. There's something here for everyone, from the absurdity of the "black Jesus" character to the entertainingly over-the-top climax. Coonskin manages to navigate a delicate subject matter with humor and originality, making it a true cult classic. Highly recommended. 9/10.

Although it may not be regarded as one of Jimmy Stewart's most iconic films, "Bell, Book and Candle" is a charming and enjoyable romantic comedy. The chemistry between Stewart and Kim Novak is undeniable, and watching their characters fall in love is both heartwarming and entertaining. The inclusion of witches and magic adds a unique twist to the story, and the portrayal of these characters as bohemians adds to the film's overall quirkiness. The acting is top-notch and the comedic moments are well-timed and effective. While it may not be a must-see film, "Bell, Book and Candle" is a pleasant way to spend an evening and is definitely worth a watch for fans of classic Hollywood rom-coms.

When people ask me what the worst experience I've had at the cinema, this movie immediately comes to mind. There's no clever riffing or indulgent midnight viewing appeal here, it's just plain bad. I've never been so tempted to walk out of a theatre. The only reason I didn't was because I didn't want to give it the satisfaction. I swear, it felt like I was watching a movie filmed with a potato. The colors were horrendous and the cinematography was nothing short of amateur. It's no excuse to say it was meant to look like a comic book- it just looked cheap. The plot was confusing and disjointed, and even Warren Beatty couldn't save it. He was more concerned with checking his watch than actually delivering a convincing performance. I'll never forgive this movie for wasting almost two hours of my life, and I wouldn't recommend it to my worst enemy. If you want to experience a true cinematic disaster, watch this movie.

I couldn't wait to see this film and it definitely didn't disappoint. Finally, Australia has produced an amazing movie! From the incredible acting to the riveting plot, this film had me on the edge of my seat the entire time. Molly Ringwald was absolutely fantastic and brought so much depth to her character. The Australian accents were spot on and added so much authenticity to the story. I was so glad to see that the title, which initially sounded like a cheesy slasher film, actually tied in perfectly with the story. I won't give anything away, but the ending was absolutely brilliant and left me completely satisfied. I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a thrilling and incredibly well-made film. You won't be disappointed!

"The Rider" is a refreshing change for Chloe Zhao, known for her indie films with a documentary feel. This film allows her to showcase her skills as a storyteller and director, while also highlighting the beauty of the American West. The real standout, however, is Brady Jandreau, who plays himself in a semi-autobiographical role. His quiet, understated performance packs an emotional punch and shows that he has a natural talent for acting. The film explores themes of identity, loss, and perseverance, and does so with authenticity and grace. While some may criticize the lack of traditional narrative structure, the film's style and pacing perfectly complement the story being told. "The Rider" is a moving and unforgettable film that will leave a lasting impression on its viewers.

I recently watched the horror version of Breakfast at Tiffany's and it was an absolute treat. The screenplay was brilliantly written by two talented writers. Drew Barrymore, Patrick Highsmith, Leslie Hope, and Sally Kellerman all gave exceptional performances, except for the FBI agent who was a bit disappointing. The scenes where Patrick objectified Holly were unsettling but the chemistry between the two was palpable. Sally Kellerman's portrayal of a character in Intimate Strangers was outstanding, and Nathan the cat was simply adorable. The weird gummy worm scene was a bit strange but added to the overall eerie atmosphere. The scene where Patrick followed Holly into the cesspool and the attack by Mr. Gooding was intense and kept me on the edge of my seat. Dr. Wallace's part was also well-played, and his fumbling around added to the suspense. Sally Kellerman's statement about not every male having a female was thought-provoking. Lastly, the encounter between Patrick, Elizabeth, and Drew outside of Victor's was an interesting twist that left me wanting more. Overall, an entertaining and well-made horror film that I would highly recommend to fans of the genre.

I recently watched this film and I must say, I was pleasantly surprised! The concept of a woman trying to prevent her ex-fiance from falling in love with someone else, only to eventually give in and let them be together, was unique and heartwarming. The cast of actors did an excellent job in bringing their characters to life, and there were definitely some laugh-out-loud moments throughout. I also appreciated the inclusion of a character who was gay but not defined by it, adding a touch of diversity to the story. While the talking parrot may not have been the funniest aspect, it was a charming addition to the film. Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed this movie and would definitely recommend it to others looking for a feel-good romantic comedy.

I have to admit, I was expecting great things from Lynn Peterson's latest venture. However, after watching this movie, I can confidently say that this is a complete disappointment. While Lynn's performance as "Driver" was commendable, everything else about the film was lackluster. The plot was bland, unoriginal, and predictable. The supporting cast was forgettable, and the pacing was painfully slow. The only time I found myself remotely interested was during the moments where the editing team had to scramble to remove the profanity for TV viewers. Honestly, the film would've been better if they just let the curse words fly. Overall, a massive waste of time and money. Save your money and watch something else. Oh, and by the way, I wouldn't bother trying to get a Lynn Peterson poster after watching this. She's better off sticking to her old films.

Andie MacDowell shines in this heartfelt movie about the power of love. As someone who may have felt like they were wasting away after being single for a while, I found this movie to be a sweet reminder that love can come at unexpected times and in unexpected ways. MacDowell's portrayal of a reserved school teacher who has a quick sexual encounter was both refreshing and relatable. Her ex-student was also charming, and I couldn't help but root for them to be together. Although there were some parts of the movie that I found to be unrealistic or unpractical, overall, I enjoyed the film and found it to be a truly heartwarming watch. The ending, while sad, left me with a glimpse of hope and a desire to watch the movie again sometime in the future. All in all, this movie is an excellent choice for anyone who loves a good romantic film with a strong message about the power of love.

I recently watched Clint Eastwood's "Sudden Impact" and found it to be a fantastic addition to the "Dirty Harry" series. The film perfectly combines gritty, raw filmmaking with intelligent and thought-provoking storytelling. I was completely engaged throughout the entire film thanks to its compelling pacing and fascinating themes.

One of the things I loved about this movie was how it echoes the first film in the series, while also introducing new elements that keep things fresh and exciting. The "Make my day" scene was an especially memorable moment that harkened back to the iconic "Do you feel lucky" scene from the first film.

I was also impressed by the way that "Sudden Impact" explores the theme of justice and how it isn't always clear cut. The character of Jennifer, who takes justice into her own hands after suffering a terrible trauma, raises some interesting questions about the nature of revenge and retribution.

Overall, I thought that "Sudden Impact" was an excellent film that perfectly captures the essence of the "Dirty Harry" series. Clint Eastwood delivers a commanding performance as always and the film boasts plenty of thrilling action and suspense. Highly recommended for fans of the series and anyone who loves great filmmaking.

It's rare to find a film that expertly balances action and drama, but Rob Roy manages to accomplish just that. Liam Neeson's performance as the honorable Rob Roy MacGregor is captivating and truly highlights the theme of standing up for what is right, even in the face of insurmountable challenge. The supporting cast, including John Hurt and Brian Cox, add depth to the story and illustrate the complex power dynamics at play. And of course, Tim Roth's portrayal of the despicable Archibald Cunningham is simply astounding. The final sword fight scene is a masterpiece of choreography and suspense, leaving the audience on the edge of their seats. Overall, Rob Roy is a beautifully crafted film that deserves recognition as a classic in its own right. Highly recommended. 9 out of 10 stars.

The Secret Life of Bees was an incredibly poignant and moving film that left me feeling uplifted and hopeful. The cinematography was stunning, capturing the lush landscapes of South Carolina in a way that made me feel like I was right there with the characters. The performances were outstanding, with each actor bringing depth and nuance to their roles. Dakota Fanning was particularly impressive, imbuing her character with a sense of strength and resilience that was truly inspiring. The themes of love, family, and acceptance were handled with grace and sensitivity, making for a truly heartwarming and engaging story. While there were moments of sadness and struggle, the overall message of hope and healing shone through, leaving me feeling deeply touched and moved. I would highly recommend The Secret Life of Bees to anyone looking for an uplifting and emotionally resonant cinematic experience.

This movie is a true masterpiece that will leave audiences breathless from start to finish. The director, Pam Dixon, has done an incredible job of showcasing the talents of an all-star cast, featuring Academy Award winners Brenda Fricker, Ben Johnson, and Adrien Brody, who truly elevate the film to new heights. The addition of radio broadcaster Jay O. Sanders adds a quirky yet captivating element to the story, while Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Milton Davis Jr. deliver captivating performances that will leave viewers in tears. The cherry on top is the incomparable Danny Glover, who brings his A-game as the Angels' manager, George Knox. The story itself is powerful, heartwarming, and will make you question your own identity, as all the characters do. And let's not forget the magical cameo by Matthew McConaughey that will leave the ladies swooning. Director William Dear's interpretation of the screenplay from Dorothy Kingsley and George Wells is nothing short of exceptional, and Tony Danza's portrayal of pitcher Mel Clark is nothing short of inspiring. This movie is a must-see that should be added to everyone's watchlist.

This movie was a complete waste of time and money. The acting was horrendous and the special effects were laughable, even for the time it was made. There was no plot to speak of, just a bunch of guys stumbling around aimlessly until they come across some ridiculous-looking aliens. The entire movie seemed to be an excuse for the filmmakers to show off some scantily clad women in skimpy outfits. The "comedy" was forced and not at all funny, just awkward and cringe-worthy. It's no wonder this film was only shown on late-night TV and drive-ins - it's not even worth the price of admission. Don't waste your time on this cheesy and forgettable mess of a movie.

I have been a fan of this movie for decades now, and it never fails to make me laugh out loud. The chemistry between Laurel and Hardy is unbeatable, and their physical comedy is simply genius. The scene in the horn factory is a classic, and the car motor running from the back seat still has me in stitches. But what really sets this film apart is the supporting cast. Jimmy Finnlayson is absolutely hilarious as the Doctor, and his "goat milk" line is a classic. The appearance of Charlie Hall and Ben Turpin just adds to the fun. I've seen many Laurel and Hardy films over the years, but I truly believe that this is one of their best. If you're a fan of classic comedy, you won't want to miss this gem.

"Written on the Wind" is a classic and mesmerizing tale of love, passion, and tragedy. The chemistry between Rock Hudson and Lauren Bacall is electric and their performances are top-notch. The subplot with Dorothy Malone's character adds an extra layer of complexity and depth to the storyline. The film is beautifully shot and the score complements the scenes perfectly. The exploration of alcoholism and the effect it has on relationships is handled with sensitivity and realism. Despite its age, "Written on the Wind" remains a timeless masterpiece and a must-watch for fans of classic cinema. It is not surprising that the film was a critical and commercial success and even earned an Oscar nomination. Overall, "Written on the Wind" is a true gem and a testament to the talent of its cast and crew. Highly recommended.

It's hard to believe that anyone involved in the making of this film did any research at all. The historical inaccuracies are so glaring that it completely ruins any chance the movie had of being taken seriously. The acting is wooden and unconvincing, with none of the characters having any real depth or development. The fight scenes are poorly choreographed and utterly unbelievable. The dialogue is stilted and unrealistic, with characters spouting off cringe-worthy lines that would never be uttered by actual human beings. It's a shame that a story as important as this was mishandled so badly. The fact that this film was made on a shoestring budget is no excuse for the complete lack of effort put into it. Even the scenes that were supposed to be emotional fell flat, leaving the viewer feeling nothing but boredom. Save your money and skip this one. There are far better movies out there that deal with similar themes in a much more competent manner.

I unfortunately wasted my time watching this Christmas movie on the Hallmark Channel. At first it seemed like a heartwarming story about a soldier finding hope through a Christmas card, but it quickly turned into a cringe-worthy love triangle. The soldier's actions towards the woman, who was already in a committed relationship, were disrespectful and selfish. It's disheartening that the family practically encouraged his behavior. The movie also had some unnecessary bad language. Overall, I was extremely disappointed and regretted watching it. I would not recommend this movie to anyone.

I absolutely loved watching Tea Leoni portray the fierce and determined photographer, Nora Wilde, on the show. Despite going through a rough divorce, she never lost sight of her goals and aspirations. Her character had depth and complexity which made her all the more interesting to watch. Holland Taylor was brilliant as her boss, and their dynamic was truly enjoyable to witness. The show had a well-written script that kept me engaged and invested in each episode. It's unfortunate that the network didn't give it the support it deserved and ended up making unnecessary changes. Overall, I highly recommend watching this show and appreciating the amazing talent of Tea Leoni.

I watched this movie last weekend and I have to say, it blew my mind! If you're into mystery and intrigue, you have to check this one out. The plot was so well developed that it kept me guessing until the very end. The acting was superb and I found myself fully invested in the story. I love movies that make you question everything you know and this one certainly did that. The cinematography was beautiful and the soundtrack was perfectly chosen. I have to say, this is one of the best movies I've seen in a long time. I'm still thinking about it days later and I can't wait to watch it again. If you're looking for a thought-provoking film that will leave you on the edge of your seat, this is the one for you.

I stumbled upon this movie one lazy Sunday afternoon and was surprised at how much I enjoyed it. The cast is fantastic, with performances that are both raw and authentic. The plot may seem heavy at first, but the writing is so thoughtful and genuine that it never feels manipulative or cheap. Instead, it delves into the lives of people from different backgrounds who are all struggling with the same basic human need - independence. What I appreciated most about this film was its refusal to offer a Hollywood ending. It was refreshing to watch a story unfold without the promise of a tidy resolution. All in all, a fantastic movie that I highly recommend.

Where do I even begin with this disaster of a film? It's like the director was purposely trying to make something that would make audiences cringe in agony. The acting is terrible, the plot is non-existent, and the special effects look like they were done by a high school student. I couldn't even make it through the entire movie without feeling like I was wasting my time. It's clear that the only reason this movie was made was for the director to stroke his own ego. How anyone could consider this to be a good movie is beyond me. It's an insult to the art of cinema and should be erased from existence. Save yourself the trouble and avoid this movie at all costs.

If only the filmmakers had come out and admitted that this was supposed to be a parody, maybe I could have forgiven the utter lack of quality. Unfortunately, I'm pretty sure they were serious about this disaster of a movie. The acting was painful to watch, the dialogue made no sense, and the plot was non-existent. I wouldn't be surprised if they just improvised everything on the spot and hoped for the best. And don't even get me started on the special effects. I've seen better makeup on a Halloween clearance rack. The entire film was a cringe-worthy mess, but the worst scene had to be when the characters tried to fight off the zombies with a stapler and a bag of marshmallows. Yes, you read that right. A stapler and marshmallows. It was like they didn't even try to make it believable. I can't believe I wasted my time and money on this garbage. I would have rather watched paint dry for two hours. Save yourself the headache and skip this one.

This film is a heartwarming portrayal of the lifelong friendship between two quirky old ladies. Despite their differences, they have a deep love and respect for each other that shines through in every scene. The way they finish each other's sentences and reminisce about their past adventures is both charming and touching. The film beautifully captures the ups and downs of their relationship, highlighting the struggles and triumphs that come with any enduring friendship. I left the theater feeling uplifted and grateful for the special bond I share with my own best friend. Don't miss this gem of a movie!

I recently watched an episode of Tom and Jerry where Tom and Butch find themselves in a hilarious predicament. The two feline enemies are both fighting over the capture of Jerry Mouse, which leads them to dress up in their master's clothing to disguise themselves. Watching them struggle to outsmart each other while disguised had me laughing out loud. But what really got me was the unexpected twist at the end when they accidentally whack their master's rear and get kicked out together. It was heartwarming to see them put aside their differences and band together in their time of trouble. Overall, this episode was a delightful and entertaining experience that had me thoroughly entertained from start to finish.

I had high hopes for this movie, but sadly it fell short in every way possible. It felt like Woody Allen was just going through the motions and didn't care about creating a meaningful or entertaining story. The acting was lackluster at best and the dialogue was painfully forced and unnatural. It's a shame to see such a talented filmmaker produce something so mediocre. Honestly, save your money and skip this one. I don't know if Woody has lost his touch or just didn't care enough to put in the effort, but either way, this movie is a major disappointment.

I absolutely loved this modern take on "Beauty and the Beast"! The storyline was engaging and the characters were well-developed. The special effects were amazing and really added to the overall experience. I particularly enjoyed the twist ending, which was both unexpected and satisfying. The film also did a great job of incorporating subtle references to the original tale. Overall, I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a unique and entertaining take on a classic story. 9 out of 10!

I cannot believe the inconvenience and annoyance we had to endure during the filming of this movie. The road closures were a nightmare and the so-called "film-making" was nothing but a nuisance to the locals. The only redeeming factor was being able to recognize the locations in Boulder Creek, Bonny Doon, Davenport, Big Basin, etc. As for the production, the only actor that seemed approachable was Jeffrey Jones, and Matt Broderick acted like he was too good for us. The script was a complete joke, and the acting and plot were even worse. This movie is nothing but a waste of time and money. The only reason to watch it is if you want to see some scenery, but even that isn't worth it. I suggest you save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

As a fan of The Rheostatics, I was thrilled to watch WHALE MUSIC and it did not disappoint. The quirky, offbeat humor and emotional depth of the film were truly captivating. While I did notice a few small flaws in the pacing and casting, they certainly did not detract from the overall experience. I highly recommend watching the full version of this film and avoiding the edited version that airs on CBC. WHALE MUSIC is a unique and memorable piece of Canadian cinema that deserves to be enjoyed in its entirety.

Of Human Bondage is a true classic that still stands the test of time. Bette Davis gives an outstanding performance as Mildred Rogers, a character that is so complex, yet so intriguing to watch. The chemistry between Leslie Howard and Davis may not be the strongest, but Davis' ferocity and raw intensity more than make up for it. The direction by John Cromwell is simple, but effective, and the story brilliantly brings to life the themes of obsession and dependence. The supporting cast also shines in their respective roles, especially Kay Johnson as Norah. This film is a must-see for anyone who loves classic Hollywood cinema or is a fan of Bette Davis. It is a true testament to the power of great acting and storytelling, and it will leave a lasting impression on its viewers.

"Utah, oil, and a love triangle? How original. This film lacks any true innovation in story, direction, or acting. John Wayne's charisma can only carry this dull film so far. The romantic subplot feels forced and out of place, and the ending is the only redeeming quality. The fight scene between Wayne and Dekker is laughably bad, with clear stunt doubles and no real tension. The supporting cast is forgettable, and the whole thing just feels like a failed attempt to capitalize on the Western genre. Save yourself the time and skip this forgettable flick." 2/10

I found the author's so-called "research" to be poorly executed and unconvincing. They continuously mentioned profane literature as if it had any relevance to the accuracy of the Bible. It's obvious that the author was grasping at straws to prove their own bias. The fact that they relied solely on the King James version of the Bible for their research is laughable. There are numerous other translations available that offer a more comprehensive and accurate understanding of the scriptures. The author's argument about the importance of a "Lexicon" is simply a way to mask their lack of knowledge on the subject. It's clear that the author is just trying to justify their own predetermined beliefs. The reference to symbolic logic is just another attempt to sound intelligent and sophisticated, but it only serves to further discredit their argument. Overall, this book falls short of any real intellectual or theological merit and comes across as nothing more than a desperate attempt to prove a point.

I absolutely loved this series and it was the perfect introduction to Deighton's writing for me. The storyline was gripping and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout. While some have criticized Holm's performance, I thought he did an excellent job portraying the complex character of Samson. His portrayal of Samson's disorientation during his wife's defection was particularly poignant. I do agree that the changes made in the translation to the screen did detract from the integrity of the story, but I still found it to be an incredibly enjoyable watch. Overall, I highly recommend this series to anyone who loves a good spy thriller and I can't wait to delve deeper into Deighton's work thanks to this excellent adaptation.

The Straight Story is a heartwarming and beautifully crafted film that showcases David Lynch's versatility as a director. It is a departure from his usual dark and surreal themes, yet it is no less impactful. The story of a man traveling on a lawn mower to visit his estranged brother may seem odd at first, but as the film progresses, we are drawn into the world of Alvin Straight and his journey through the Midwest. The cinematography is stunning, capturing the natural beauty of the American landscape, and the soundtrack by Angelo Badalamenti is simply gorgeous. Richard Farnsworth gives a remarkable performance as Alvin, conveying the struggles and triumphs of an aging man with remarkable depth and nuance. The dialogue may seem simplistic, but it perfectly captures the small town charm and everyday wisdom of these characters. This is a film that reminds us of the importance of family, community, and the simple pleasures in life. It is a true gem in Lynch's filmography and a must-see for anyone who appreciates a good story, masterful direction, and memorable performances.

Although it may not be the most critically acclaimed film out there, I have to say that I absolutely loved "The Barbarians"! The humor was on point, and I found myself laughing out loud throughout the entire movie. It's clear that the director had a vision for a serious adventure flick, but the end result was so bad that it became inadvertently hilarious. I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone looking for a good laugh - and if you've already seen it, I highly encourage you to give it another watch!

While I haven't seen every movie that came out this year, I can confidently say that if there's one film you should watch, it's Antwone Fisher. It's an incredibly moving story that transcends the typical stereotypes associated with black characters in Hollywood films. The movie doesn't focus on race relations or the inner city ghetto, but rather on the personal journey of Antwone Fisher, played brilliantly by Derek Luke. Even with Denzel Washington's star power, he never overshadows the story and lets the film speak for itself. What I love about this movie is that it speaks to humanity rather than dividing us into certain categories. It's a shame that some people might avoid watching it because they can't identify with the characters, but I truly believe that this is a film that anyone can appreciate and be moved by. Overall, it's a standout film that deserves recognition for its honesty and authenticity.

Recently stumbled upon this hidden gem at a local videostore and was blown away by how much it exceeded my expectations. Despite the low price tag of $2, this movie delivered non-stop action and a captivating storyline that kept me on the edge of my seat. The colonel, though older, proved to be a skilled and endearing hero that I found myself rooting for throughout the film. The ninjas were anything but dumb and provided a thrilling opponent for the colonel to face off against. As the story progressed, I found myself drawn in even more by the dynamic and engaging characters. This movie had a great balance of humor and excitement that made it truly enjoyable to watch. Despite having a limited budget, the production value was impressive and the actors delivered standout performances that made them deserving of their roles. I highly recommend checking out this film for a fun and unforgettable viewing experience.

I recently watched the movie "Gung Ho" as part of my business management class, and I have to say that I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed it. Michael Keaton's performance was spot-on and added a perfect touch of humor to the film. While I understand that it may not be an Oscar winner, I do think that it has a lot of comedic value and it's definitely worth a watch. 

I also appreciate the way that "Gung Ho" touched on the cultural and business differences between American and Japanese automakers. Even though it's a Hollywood movie and some liberties may have been taken, I found that many of the principles presented in the film were accurate for the time period. The emphasis on teamwork and company loyalty displayed by the Japanese workers was particularly interesting and made me think about the differences in American workplaces. 

Overall, I would highly recommend "Gung Ho" to anyone interested in the subject of automakers or business management. And for those who want to dive even deeper into the topic, the book "The machine that changed the world" by James Womack, Daniel Jones, and Daniel Roos provides an excellent study of automakers during and before the time period covered in the movie.

I absolutely adore Rosario Dawson and her talent shines through in Descent. While some may criticize the flat dialog and one-dimensional characters, I believe the movie's focus on self-empowerment sets it apart from other films. Yes, the topic of rape is present, but it's not the only theme and I appreciate how the film challenges its audience to think deeper. It's not a typical "rape movie" and that's what makes it so special. The relationship between the characters and the audience is captivating and kept me invested until the end. Descent is a hidden gem and I believe it deserves more recognition.

I recently watched the latest season of Blackadder and it did not disappoint! While Edmund may not be in a royal position anymore, his job as a butler brings a fresh dynamic to the show. Hugh Laurie's portrayal of the Prince Regent was hilarious and had me laughing out loud. The witty and sarcastic humor is still prevalent throughout the season, and while there are some "silly" moments, they are balanced with more intelligent comedy. I found myself enjoying most of the episodes, with only a few moments feeling forced or predictable. The commentary and satire on historical events is well done and adds an interesting layer to the show. Overall, I highly recommend this season to fans of the franchise and British comedy in general.

"Der Todesking" is a thought-provoking and poignant art-house film that will leave a lasting impact on anyone who watches it. Jörg Buttgereit's direction is masterful, seamlessly weaving together seven separate stories of individuals who have chosen to end their lives. The film is unflinching in its portrayal of human suffering, yet never feels gratuitous or exploitative. The Wednesday and Sunday episodes, in particular, are breathtakingly intense and devastating.

What sets "Der Todesking" apart from other shockumentaries is its subtle and thoughtful approach to its subject matter. Buttgereit never judges or condemns his characters, instead presenting their stories with empathy and compassion. The Thursday episode, with its haunting shots of a German bridge and its victims, is a perfect example of this. The use of tragic music throughout the film only adds to its emotional depth.

While the production values may be lacking, this film is not about flashy visuals or fancy editing. It is about the raw and honest portrayal of human misery. "Der Todesking" is a powerful and important film that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

My title says it all. "Born in China" is nothing more than a cheap knockoff of the BBC's "Planet Earth". As someone who has watched "Planet Earth" and has it in their collection, I was extremely disappointed when I realized that almost all of the footage in this movie was taken from "Planet Earth". The only difference is that the narration is geared towards children. The narration is so childish that it made me cringe. When the polar cubs were shown walking away from their mother, the narrator says, "The polar cubs are not like human kids. They don't always listen to their mothers." Really? Is that the best they could come up with? The only reason why this movie made it to the big screen is because it is a Disney production. Don't waste your time watching this cheap imitation. Stick to the original and watch "Planet Earth".

As a World War 2 enthusiast, I was thrilled to finally get my hands on this DVD. Despite the historical inaccuracies, I thoroughly enjoyed watching the story unfold. The attention to detail in the set design and costumes truly transported me back in time. While some of the casting choices may have been questionable, the performances were still impressive. I particularly enjoyed the portrayals of Goring and Drexler. The fact that this is meant to be entertainment first and foremost should be kept in mind, but it still sparked my interest in delving deeper into the history of Nazi Germany. Overall, a must-watch for anyone interested in this time period.

What a comedic gem! The exaggerated acting, cheesy dialogue, and over-the-top scenarios make for a hysterical parody of Hollywood's ridiculousness. Pia Zadora's performance is so outrageous it's impossible not to laugh. Despite not being intended as a comedy, this film rivals the humor of "Spinal Tap." And let's not forget Ray Liotta's unforgettable debut line - pure comedic gold. If you want a good laugh, this film is a must-see.

I recently watched a thought-provoking film that addresses the issue of the death penalty in America. The film highlights the injustices and errors that can occur within the system, ultimately condemning the death penalty as an act of vengeance rather than a pursuit of justice. The story follows a young man who is wrongly accused of a crime and sentenced to death row. Through the help of a law professor, he is eventually freed from this horrifying fate. However, the aftermath of his wrongful conviction proves to be just as damaging, as he faces public castration and the loss of his future prospects. These events drive him to seek revenge, ultimately leading him down a dark path. The film effectively demonstrates the danger of allowing personal motivations and circumstantial evidence to cloud the pursuit of justice. It serves as a reminder that we must hold ourselves to the highest standards if we truly want to uphold the values of equality and the sanctity of life. I highly recommend this film to those who wish to gain a deeper understanding of the complexities and injustices surrounding the death penalty in America.

I had high hopes for this movie, but it was a complete disappointment. The acting was mediocre at best, and the plot was so convoluted and confusing that I couldn't even keep track of what was happening. The music was unbearable - it sounded like someone had put a cat in a blender and pressed "play". The set design was lackluster and looked like it was thrown together at the last minute. I couldn't wait for it to be over. The only redeeming quality was the occasional funny line, but even those were few and far between. Save your money and skip this one.

I found this film to be a complete disappointment. It's clear that some stories just aren't meant to be translated to the big screen and this is a perfect example. The satire of the Catholic church falls completely flat, with none of the humor coming through, even with the talented cast. The central character, who is supposed to be so outrageous and hilarious, just comes across as creepy and unlikable. The unrealistic aspects of the play are what made it work, but in this film, it's all presented in a realistic way that just feels awkward and uncomfortable. The director should have taken more creative risks to make the comedy resonate, but instead, it falls short. I left the theater feeling completely unsatisfied and disappointed. If you have the chance to see the stage play instead, go for it. This film doesn't do it justice.

"The FBI is a thrilling ride through the history of America's top crime-fighting agency. Agent Stewart's flashbacks and personal story add a human touch to the intense action and high stakes of the FBI's missions. The cast, including Stewart, Miles, and Hamilton, deliver standout performances that keep you invested in the story. While the episodic nature of the show may be a bit jarring at times, it ultimately adds to the intrigue and suspense of each episode. The attention to detail in the production values is impressive and adds to the overall cinematic experience. Don't miss out on this captivating glimpse into the FBI's fascinating past!"

I cannot believe "Gymkata" was ever made, let alone released to the public. This movie is a joke, and not even a funny one at that. The paper-thin plot and dumb characters will leave you wondering why you bothered to waste your time watching it. The action scenes are just as ridiculous, with a gymnast using his skills to fight bad guys on parallel bars and pummel horses. It's so absurd it's almost laughable, but not quite. And don't even get me started on the "Village of The Crazies." The whole thing is just a mess, and the fact that anyone could enjoy it is beyond me. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

***SPOILERS*** ***SPOILERS*** This movie was a complete disaster from start to finish. The opening credits gave me a sense of dread that was only confirmed as the film dragged on for what felt like an eternity. It's not big at all, in fact, it's small and forgettable, unlike actual classics such as `The Godfather' or `Casablanca.' The sheer awfulness of it left me speechless as I walked out of the movie theater and proceeded right back to the ticket counter to demand a refund. This is a movie that simply requires no viewings. The first watching will leave you with a feeling of utter disgust and regret, and you will only feel embarrassed for wasting your time and money on it. The story is so stupid that it makes one wonder how it ever got made. What seems to be a simple story of an idiot infiltrating the FBI, turns out to be a nonsensical mess that has no point or message whatsoever. The complexity of the plot structure is nonexistent, as it is simply a string of unfunny gags and lame jokes. And the unexpected twist at the end? Don't even get me started. It was so contrived and ridiculous that it only added insult to injury.Chris Kattan's comedic talents are nonexistent as he leads his character Corky Romano through a maze of tired cliches and predictable situations. Reminiscent of John Reynolds' performance in `Manos, the Hands of Fate,' Kattan takes on innumerable multiple personalities and fails miserably at all of them. However, Kattan is not just about bad comedy. He is a master of bad drama as well, as he controls the audience's feelings with the slightest moves of his face. His facial expressions reflect a complete lack of talent and desperation, in a way. For example, in the scene in which he farts into his brothers' faces, you can see the expression of a man who has hit rock bottom and has nothing else to offer. At a moment like that, it's hard to find a dry eye in the house, not because of emotion, but because of how bad it is.Screenwriters David Garret and Jason Ward are the real villains of `Corky Romano.' With a story of such proportions, it's easy to understand why two amateur writers had to be employed to complete this laughable project. Their inept storytelling and unoriginal structuring makes `Pulp Fiction' look like a masterpiece. Garret and Ward's story is so repulsive and unappealing that it repels you entirely, shakes you around and leaves you feeling violated. At the end of the abysmal experience known as `Corky Romano' you find yourself a different person with different worldviews and different ideas, and with only one question on your mind:Why, God? Why?!?

This movie was a complete disappointment. As someone who loved the series on TV, I was excited to see the movie. However, it fell short in every way possible. The plot was weak and lacked any substance, and the characters were portrayed poorly. The only redeeming quality was Helga's admission of her secret, but even that was not enough to save the film. The humor was forced and not at all funny. I was incredibly disappointed and would not recommend wasting your time or money on this failure of a movie. Doy, indeed.

I recently watched the film A Movie Romance, directed by Maurice Tourneur, and I must say it was a delightful and insightful look into the world of early filmmaking. The film centers around a small-town girl named Mary who dreams of being swept off her feet by a romantic troubadour. However, her world is turned upside down when she meets a dashing film star and becomes enamored with the movie-making process.

I particularly enjoyed the behind-the-scenes look at the film studio and the various sets that were constructed for each scene. It was fascinating to see how everything was fake, from the walls to the actors' performances. The film also had some great moments of humor, such as when Mary raises an alarm during a film shoot because she mistakes an actor in Indian headdress for a real Native American.

The acting was top-notch, with Doris Kenyon giving a wonderful performance as Mary, and Robert Warwick playing the disillusioned film star to perfection. The supporting cast was also excellent, with several actors playing exaggerated versions of themselves.

Overall, I highly recommend A Movie Romance to anyone interested in early filmmaking or just looking for a charming and entertaining movie. It is a fascinating glimpse into a bygone era of cinema and an excellent example of the work being done in the early days of Hollywood.

"Rambo: First Blood Part II" is a shallow and unrealistic portrayal of the Vietnam War. The film perpetuates the myth of American soldiers as heroes and glosses over the atrocities committed by the US military. Rambo's character is a cliché of a patriotic soldier who blindly follows orders without questioning their morality. The movie fails to provide any meaningful commentary on the war and instead glorifies violence and revenge. The plot is predictable and the ending is unsatisfying, as Rambo gets to once again single-handedly defeat an entire army. The lack of nuance and depth in this movie is disappointing and insulting to the memory of those who suffered through the Vietnam War. Overall, "Rambo: First Blood Part II" is a forgettable and irresponsible film that does a disservice to its subject matter.

I absolutely loved Doctor Mordrid! It's a hidden gem of a film that truly captures the feel of old serials from the 30s and 40s. The magic and fantasy elements had me hooked from the start, and I couldn't help but wish there were more films like this. The casting was spot-on, with Jeffrey Combs and Yvette Nipar delivering fantastic performances. Nipar was particularly impressive, and I wouldn't be surprised if she gets snatched up for an A-list picture soon. While I do agree that the sacrifice scene may have been too intense for younger viewers, without it, this film could have easily been a Harry Potter-style magicfest that kids would have adored. All in all, I highly recommend Doctor Mordrid - it's a thrilling and captivating ride that's sure to leave you wanting more!

I recently watched the 1959 remake of a classic film and I have to say, it surpassed all my expectations. The acting was simply masterful and the script incredibly thought-provoking. I was impressed by the way the film tackled the issue of capital punishment and the flaws in its application. The scene where Mickey Rooney recounted his visit to death row was especially moving and really helped me see the issue from a new perspective. I could tell that a lot of care and attention went into making this film, and it definitely shows in the final product. The pacing was perfect, the cinematography stunning and the direction truly inspired. I also appreciated the way the film tackled deeper spiritual issues, like forgiveness and mercy, without becoming preachy or heavy-handed. Overall, I would highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a thought-provoking drama that will stick with you long after the credits roll.

I absolutely loved this movie! "The Sentinel" is a captivating political thriller that kept me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. The plot is incredibly unique, centered around a Secret Service agent who becomes involved in an assassination plot. Michael Douglas' performance as "Pete Garrison" was spot-on and I found myself rooting for him throughout the film. The action scenes were intense and well-executed, and I was particularly impressed with Keifer Sutherland's portrayal of "David Breckinridge." The chemistry between Douglas and Sutherland was electric, and their dynamic made for a truly engaging watch. The villains in this film were also incredibly interesting and kept me guessing until the end. I was especially impressed with Kim Basinger's performance as the First Lady - she was stunning and brought a lot of depth to her character. Overall, "The Sentinel" is a well-crafted and thoroughly enjoyable movie that is sure to thrill and entertain audiences. Highly recommend!

It's truly remarkable to see what this low budget enterprise has achieved with their disc release of Broken. Despite manufacturing and distributing the DVDs themselves, they have managed to include enough extras to rival a James Cameron DVD. The presentation is also top-notch, with only a non-anamorphic transfer being the major flaw. But apart from that, the film looks and sounds fantastic, with both DD2.0 and DD5.1 mixes being equally fine. And when it comes to extras, the disc is positively overflowing with them. From numerous commentaries to featurettes and galleries, everything has been broken down into easily digestible chunks, providing easy access to whatever special feature we may wish to view. The only aspect that may require some discussion is the commentaries, but even those are enjoyable to listen to. All in all, this is a fine extras package that will leave viewers thoroughly satisfied with their purchase.

"Where The Sidewalk Ends" is an outstanding thriller that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats from start to finish. Dana Andrews delivers a remarkable performance as the tormented New York police detective, Mark Dixon. His character is complex, flawed, and incredibly compelling, making it impossible to look away from the screen.

The film's plot is gripping and filled with unexpected twists and turns that keep viewers guessing until the very end. The supporting cast is also exceptional, with Gene Tierney, Karl Malden, and Gary Merrill all delivering noteworthy performances.

The film's themes of redemption, morality, and the consequences of one's actions are explored in a thoughtful and thought-provoking manner, making "Where The Sidewalk Ends" a truly captivating film.

Overall, "Where The Sidewalk Ends" is a must-watch for fans of the thriller genre. Its engaging story, exceptional performances, and nuanced exploration of complex themes make it a true classic of its time.

'Midnight Cowboy' is a timeless masterpiece that still resonates with audiences today, just as it did 35 years ago. John Schlesinger's direction is masterful, capturing the gritty and disorienting American landscape of the late 1960s. The film offers much more than just political commentary, delving into the themes of friendship, loneliness, and hope. Jon Voight and Dustin Hoffman's performances are exceptional, with their natural interactions captivating audiences. The film's use of flashbacks, dream sequences, and psychedelic imagery add depth and complexity to the characters. The cinematography, editing, and soundtrack all work together seamlessly, creating a cohesive and powerful film. The collector's edition DVD offers expanded features and commentary, making it a must-have for any film lover's collection. 'Midnight Cowboy' is a deserving winner of three Oscars and will continue to be a timeless classic for generations to come.

As a huge fan of John Grisham's legal thrillers, I was eager to see The Firm on the big screen. However, I left the theater feeling extremely disappointed and ripped off. The movie dragged on for what felt like an eternity, with no real action or suspense to speak of. The characters were flat and unmemorable, and the plot was so convoluted and confusing that I couldn't keep track of who was doing what or why. I was expecting a gripping legal drama, but what I got was a snoozefest that left me feeling bored and frustrated. Save your money and skip this one – you won't be missing out on anything.

I recently watched the movie 'Gone with the Wind' and was extremely disappointed. The acting was dry and unemotional, especially Vivien Leigh who played Scarlett O'Hara. She lacked the fiery spirit that was required of the character and came across as flat and uninteresting. Clark Gable was also miscast as Rhett Butler, he lacked the charm and charisma that made the character so appealing in the novel. The movie failed to capture the essence of the book, which was a sweeping epic full of passion, heartbreak, and drama. Instead, it felt like a bland and forgettable adaptation. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on this version, go and read the book for a truly captivating and unforgettable experience.

I recently had the pleasure of watching the movie "Pacific Rim" and I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised. Despite being a few years old now, the special effects still hold up and are truly impressive. The story is engaging and keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. It's refreshing to see a movie that doesn't rely solely on CGI to tell the story. The characters are well-developed and easy to root for, especially the pilots of the giant Jaegers. The Kaiju are also incredibly menacing and make for worthy foes. I particularly enjoyed the relationship between the pilots, which added an emotional depth to the action-packed scenes. There are plenty of great moments throughout the film, including some unexpected twists and turns. All in all, "Pacific Rim" is a thrilling sci-fi adventure that is sure to leave audiences satisfied. I highly recommend giving this gem a watch!

"Transylvania 6-5000" is an unremarkable and forgettable horror parody from the mid 80's. The cast, though familiar, fails to impress with lackluster performances and a script that falls flat more often than not. The jokes are stale and the parody situations are drawn out to the point of boredom. The film tries to incorporate cute gimmicks, like a little guillotine for eggs and laboratory test tubes used for cream and sugar, but these fail to save the movie from being a disappointment. The joke about the Frankenstein character only behaving like a mad scientist in his laboratory is tired and overused. The film's attempt at parodying the classic Universal milestones of the early 30's falls short and only serves to confuse those who are not familiar with these films. The character of Michael Richards as a psychotic butler is grating and unlikable, and his performance is reminiscent of his better-known role as Kramer in Seinfeld. Overall, "Transylvania 6-5000" is a forgettable and uninspired film that is not worth the time or effort to watch.

Castle of Blood is nothing but a boring and outdated horror film. The black and white filming and slow pacing is just a snooze fest. The story is unoriginal and lacks any real scares or thrills. The ghosts are more laughable than frightening, and the dialogue between them and the protagonist is cringeworthy. The romance between Alan and Elisabeth is forced and unconvincing, adding no value to an already dull plot. The only good thing about this movie is that it is forgotten and irrelevant in today's horror genre. It is not worth anyone's time and definitely not a must-see.

"Lois Weber's film is a disappointing attempt at pushing her own personal agenda onto unsuspecting viewers. The way she manipulates the complex issues of abortion, eugenics, and birth control is not only muddled, it's downright offensive. Instead of presenting a nuanced discussion, she simplifies the topic and uses her talents as a writer and producer to shamelessly preach her own beliefs. The inclusion of outdated fashion and automobiles only serves as a distraction from the cringe-worthy propaganda that plagues this film. Save yourself the frustration and skip this outdated museum piece."

While there are definitely cultural references that may go over some viewers' heads, this movie is a fantastic example of Japanese folklore brought to life with incredible special effects. The protagonist's journey to become "The one" is both emotionally engaging and visually stunning, and the yokai war serves as an amazing showcase for the creative creature designs. Despite the complex mythology behind it all, the plot is easy to follow and never loses momentum. Plus, the river princess is absolutely adorable and adds a touch of sweetness to the action-packed adventure. Overall, this movie is a must-watch for fans of Japanese mythology and anyone who appreciates a beautifully crafted fantasy story.

I recently had the pleasure of re-watching this classic film and I must say, it still holds up after all these years. While the initial portrayal of Hunt Stevenson may have been off-putting, it only added to the transformation and growth he experiences throughout the movie. The contrast between American and Japanese culture is handled with grace and respect, with each side learning from and appreciating the other. And that ending! It's rare to find a movie that ties up all loose ends in such a satisfying and heartwarming way. Overall, I highly recommend this movie for anyone looking for a heartwarming and entertaining classic.

Veteran director and producer Allan Dwan's "I Dream of Jeanie" is a disgraceful attempt at a musical film. The fictional story about Stephen Foster is not only offensive but also poorly executed. The lead cast, consisting of singers with no real acting experience, fail to capture the essence of their characters and provide a lackluster performance. The only redeeming factor of this ill-conceived film is Foster's music, which is almost impossible to ruin. However, the lavish sets and charming songs do nothing to mask the film's repulsive sentimentalizing of the victims of America's great crime, slavery. The portrayal of African Americans is an historical anomaly and a contemporary piece of unthinking racism, painting a literal whitewash of the antebellum South. It's astonishing that this film was released just two years before Brown v. Board of Education. "I Dream of Jeanie" is a period piece that not only fails to entertain but also perpetuates harmful stereotypes, making it an absolute waste of time.

While it may take a little time to really get going, I thoroughly enjoyed this movie. The Valentine Party scene was a real standout, with a great atmosphere and some truly tense moments. And while the twist at the end was certainly unexpected, it was the hot bath murder scene that stuck with me long after the movie ended. It had just the right amount of gore to really give it that slasher edge, and the tension leading up to it was palpable. The garden scene with Kate and the final scene were also shot extremely well, providing some genuine thrills and chills. Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to any horror fan - just be patient through the slower parts, it's definitely worth it!

As someone who has always appreciated a good crime drama, "In Cold Blood" is a standout film that truly left me speechless. The performances of Scott Wilson and Robert Blake as the two killers were both chilling and captivating, drawing me in and keeping me on the edge of my seat throughout the entire film. The stark black and white cinematography by Conrad Hall was a true work of art and lent an air of realism to the entire production. Even Quincy Jones's score added to the unsettling atmosphere, making for an incredible viewing experience. While the anti-capital punishment sentiment may not be everyone's cup of tea, the film still manages to leave you with a sense of conflicting emotions that is hard to shake. This is a classic that deserves to be seen by any fan of the crime genre.

I was extremely disappointed after watching this movie. It had potential, but fell flat. I was hoping for something unique and entertaining, but instead got a cliché and unoriginal plot. The acting was mediocre at best, and the attempts at humor were cringe-worthy. The only redeeming quality of this film were the few moments that made me chuckle, but they were few and far between. I wouldn't recommend wasting your time on this generic, forgettable film. It's just another uninspired attempt at cashing in on the tired trope of a wild party. 2/10, and that's being generous.

This book, I won't call it a "novel," was essentially a waste of time and seemed to exist solely to capitalize on the author's popularity. Sure, there were a few interesting plot points, but they were quickly overshadowed by the author's self-indulgent writing style. Maybe this book was a hit back in the day, but now it just comes off as pretentious and uninspired. I did appreciate some of the secondary characters, but even their stories lacked depth. Overall, if you're looking for substance and quality writing, this book is not worth your time.

"Blank Check" is an absolutely delightful movie that will make you feel like a kid again! Watching Preston, a smart and cunning 11-year-old boy, take on the world and come out on top is nothing short of inspirational. The plot is both comical and thrilling, with just the right balance of action, adventure, and heartwarming moments. You'll love seeing Preston indulge in all the luxuries he'd always dreamed of, and the way he uses his ingenuity to outsmart the FBI and Quigley is truly impressive. It's a movie that will leave you feeling uplifted and entertained, and that's something we could all use a little more of in our lives.
