Overall, I highly recommend "Blank Check" - it's a timeless classic that you'll want to watch again and again.

I completely disagree with the positive reviews of this movie, it was a complete waste of my time. The topic may interest some, but the execution was poor. Tim Robbins was lackluster and seemed to be sleepwalking through most of the film. Margarita Levieva, while beautiful, did not bring anything special to the table and was quite forgettable. The script was bland and unoriginal, offering nothing new or thought-provoking. I cannot believe anyone would think this movie is worth recommending. I suggest saving your money and finding something more worthwhile to watch.

I recently watched a movie that left me disgusted and appalled. I don't understand why filmmakers and producers feel the need to include such tasteless content in their films. The movie I watched was riddled with gratuitous violence and vulgar language that felt completely uncalled for. It seems like they were trying to appeal to the lowest common denominator when making this movie. 

What really put me over the edge though was the unnecessary and graphic sex scene that was included. I was watching this movie with my family and I couldn't believe what we were watching. It was like soft-core pornography and I felt extremely uncomfortable having to explain to my kids what was going on. 

It's disappointing to see that so many filmmakers seem to believe that they need to include sex and nudity in their movies in order to make them successful. It's time for them to wake up and realize that there is a large audience out there who are looking for quality movies without all the trashy content. 

Overall, I was extremely disappointed with this movie and I will be avoiding any future movies made by these filmmakers. If you feel the same way that I do, I would suggest finding a way to voice your displeasure so that these filmmakers know that there are consequences for their actions.

Save your money and your time! This movie is an absolute disaster. Dylan Walsh may be the only slightly competent actor in this trainwreck, but even he can't save it from being a complete waste of time. The rest of the cast is so painfully bad that it's almost impressive. And don't even get me started on Ms. Eastwood - her acting is so wooden, it's a wonder anyone was able to get a performance out of her at all. I can't believe I wasted two hours of my life on this garbage. Avoid at all costs!

This comedy special is an absolute gem! The humor is smart, fresh, and downright hysterical. I found myself laughing so hard that tears were streaming down my face! The jokes are so well-crafted and delivered flawlessly by the talented performer, who truly knows how to work a crowd. The material is not only side-splittingly funny but also thought-provoking, offering insightful commentary on the human experience. I was thoroughly impressed by the depth and breadth of the content, which covers everything from ancient history to modern day pop culture. This is truly a masterpiece of comedy, and I cannot recommend it highly enough! If you're looking for a good laugh and a great time, look no further than this brilliant tour-de-force of funny!

I must say, I was quite disappointed with Soul Survivors. While the gothic atmosphere during the party scenes was somewhat intriguing, the rest of the film fell flat. The constant flips between 'dream' and 'reality' were confusing and ultimately unsatisfying. The ending, which may have been surprising to some, felt predictable and unoriginal to me. I couldn't help but compare it to superior films like 'The 6th Sense' and 'Don't Look Now', making it seem like a cheap knockoff. Overall, I found this movie to be a waste of my time and would not recommend it to anyone looking for a truly suspenseful and engaging thriller.

While I usually don't gravitate towards stop-motion films, RUKA truly captivated me from start to finish. The attention to detail in the animation alone is enough to leave you in awe, but the political subtext of the film takes it to a whole other level. Jirí Trnka's bravery in using his art as a form of protest against the oppressive government in Czechoslovakia during the Soviet era is truly inspiring. The story follows a cute little wooden man who is interrupted and eventually imprisoned by a meddling hand. The lack of dialogue only adds to the film's impact, as it allows the imagery to speak for itself. The tragic ending is both heartbreaking and a testament to the film's power as a political statement. It's no wonder that the state banned this film upon its release, but it's a shame that Trnka didn't live to see the freedom that his nation would eventually achieve. In all, RUKA is a must-see for any fans of animation or political history.

I was hesitant to watch The Room when my friend recommended it. I had heard it was notoriously bad and had a cult following for all the wrong reasons. But I decided to give it a shot and was pleasantly surprised. While the acting wasn't Oscar-worthy and the set design was questionable at times, I found myself thoroughly enjoying the film. It was so bad that it was actually good. The unintentional humor had me laughing out loud multiple times. I even found myself invested in the characters and their bizarre relationships. I can see why some people wouldn't enjoy The Room, but for me, it was a fun and entertaining watch. I would recommend it to anyone looking for a unique and hilarious movie experience.

I absolutely loved this movie from start to finish! It had everything I could want in a film: great acting, a compelling plot, and stunning visuals. The storyline had me on the edge of my seat the entire time, and I found myself rooting for the characters every step of the way. And let me tell you, the special effects in this movie were out of this world. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who loves a good adventure film with heart and soul. Overall, I would rate it a solid 9/10. Don't miss out on this one!

I cannot believe the rave reviews this movie has been getting. My friends and I found it excruciatingly boring. The plot was underdeveloped and the characters were shallow. We struggled to make it through even half of the film. It's disappointing that a movie supposedly about a relatable subject, as we had all experienced bullying in our youth, failed to engage us. The acting was subpar, and the pacing was sluggish. I'm glad some people found it enjoyable, but I certainly would not recommend it.

Fortunately, I was able to get my hands on a copy of Jean Eustache's "The Mother and the Whore" and I have to say it was worth the search. Despite its lengthy runtime, I was never bored for a second. The dialogues were a standout feature, showcasing the unique perspective of Jean-Pierre Léaud's character, Alexandre. While some may find the lack of communication between characters frustrating, it only added to the film's satirical tone. Eustache's commentary on the idle running of sociopolitical ideas was thought-provoking, but what really stood out were the characters and their philosophies on life. Alexandre's pseudo-intellectual ramblings may seem ridiculous at first, but they are ultimately a reflection of his own insecurities and disillusionment with society. This film demands a certain level of knowledge on French existentialism and its impact on the 68 student revolution movement, but for those who do have that knowledge, it's a truly rewarding experience. Overall, I highly recommend "The Mother and the Whore" for any cinephile looking to expand their horizons.

The third installment of this franchise is a disappointing mess. The plot is predictable and lacks any originality, serving as a blatant attempt to cash in on the success of the previous films. The acting is uninspired, with the lead actress delivering a flat and forgettable performance. The excessive violence and gore only serve to shock and disgust, adding nothing to the already lackluster story. The only redeeming quality is the skillful direction, but even that is not enough to salvage this mediocre film. Save your time and money and skip this forgettable entry in the series. * out of ****

I recently watched this film and was impressed by the attention to detail in the different versions. While most of the footage is the same, the subtle differences in the clerics guarding the gateway add a new layer of intrigue to the plot. I appreciate the effort put into creating two distinct versions of the film and the dedication to ensuring that each version was consistent in its depiction of the characters. It's rare to see such care given to the details, and it only adds to the already engaging storyline. Kudos to the filmmakers for creating such a unique viewing experience!

I recently watched this movie and it was a complete waste of time. The plot was confusing and the acting was horrendous. I was expecting an exciting thriller, but instead got stuck watching a slow-paced drama that dragged on and on. It felt like I was watching a low-budget indie movie that had no direction or purpose. I wouldn't recommend this to anyone, unless you enjoy watching paint dry or grass grow. Save yourself the time and skip this movie altogether. 1/10.

I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised by this movie. Walking into the theater, I didn't really have any expectations, but I left feeling incredibly satisfied. This was a breath of fresh air in the sea of generic Hollywood blockbusters. The humor was smart, witty and slightly twisted - everything you would expect from a brilliant British comedy. I would highly recommend this movie to anyone who appreciates dry humor and clever storytelling. However, I do understand that humor is subjective and not everyone will appreciate this type of film. But for those who do, this movie is an absolute gem. 9/10.

I recently watched a film that I just had to share my thoughts on. The premise may sound a bit unconventional, but trust me, it's one that you won't forget. The main character, played by the talented Jennifer Thomas II, is a female executioner who fulfills the fantasies of men on death row before their ultimate fate. The concept may sound dark, but it's done in a way that is both tasteful and exciting.

At first, I wasn't sure what to expect from this film. The opening scenes were a bit slow and the acting was a bit amateurish, but as the story progressed, I found myself getting more and more invested. The executioner's character was captivating, and the chemistry between her and the prisoners was sizzling.

By the time the film came to its explosive conclusion, I had completely forgotten about the film's rough start. It was a thrilling ride, and I would highly recommend it to anyone who is looking for a low-budget, but high-quality film. Just make sure the little ones are not around when you watch it. This is a must-see once the kids are away or in bed.

"Atlantis" is a bold and exciting step forward for Disney. The animation is stunning, with a unique and inspired visual style that sets it apart from any other Disney film before it. The sound design is also top-notch, with a dynamic soundtrack that perfectly complements the film. While the plot may be condensed into a 96-minute movie, the action and adventure keep the pace moving at a thrilling rate. The clichéd characters and tongue-in-cheek humor may not be for everyone, but for those who enjoy an adventure thrill ride with a more serious tone, "Atlantis" is a must-see. The love story between Milo and Kida is refreshing in its subtlety, avoiding the typical "Disney Princess" romance tropes. Overall, "Atlantis" is a fantastic film that deserves a 10 out of 10 rating.

This movie is an absolute blast! While it may not be the most intellectually stimulating film out there, it's hard not to enjoy the sheer ridiculousness of it all. The plot may be a bit thin, but it's all worth it for the amazing climax where riff randle and the ramones take over the school. And let's not forget about that killer soundtrack! The acting may not be top-notch, but it all just adds to the charm of this movie. It's campy, it's silly, and it's a total classic. Plus, how cool is it that Darby Crash of the Germs is in the front of the crowd during the live ramones set? If you're looking for a fun, mindless movie with a killer soundtrack, this is the one for you!

I just finished watching The Legend of Zu and I have to say, I absolutely loved it! The beautiful mythology and storytelling woven throughout the film kept me captivated from start to finish. I could see why some people may have been expecting a more action-packed film, but I appreciated the depth and meaning behind every scene. It felt like a journey of self-discovery, with each character facing their own personal battles and demons. The stunning visuals and choreography added an extra layer of magic to the already captivating storyline. I also appreciated the Mandarin language with English subtitles, it added to the authenticity of the film. Overall, I would highly recommend The Legend of Zu to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and visually stunning film. Bravo to the filmmakers for creating such a unique and beautiful cinematic experience.

I recently watched The Wicker Man, and I have to say, it was a complete waste of my time. The terrible acting, convoluted plot, and ridiculous hallucination scenes were enough to make me want to turn it off within the first 20 minutes. The only reason I continued watching was to see just how bad it could get.

If you're considering watching this movie, let me save you the trouble. Here are five reasons why you should avoid it:

5. The "creepy" ideas are not only cheesy, but also unoriginal. The entire plot revolves around a secret society of women who worship nature and sacrifice men. Yawn.

4. The aesthetics may be pleasing, but that's about all you're going to get out of it. The scenery is nice, but it doesn't make up for the lackluster plot.

3. Nicolas Cage's performance is cringe-worthy. He overacts to the point of embarrassment, and it's impossible to take him seriously. It's painful to watch.

2. The anti-feminist message is not only outdated, but also offensive. The portrayal of women as evil and destructive is not only inaccurate, but also harmful.

1. The infamous "bees" scene is not funny, it's just plain stupid. It's a cheap attempt at creating a memorable moment, but it falls flat.

Overall, The Wicker Man is a forgettable, poorly made movie that's not even worth the dollar bin at a garage sale. Avoid it at all costs.

I found the movie to be extremely unoriginal and uninspired. The plot seemed like a poor imitation of much better movies like Leon or Nikita. Even the little girl, who attempted to add a fresh twist to the story, felt like a cheap knock-off of the character from Leon. The fact that there were no new or innovative ideas in the story made it a complete waste of time. The action scenes were poorly choreographed, and the characters lacked any depth or development. The only positive thing about this movie was the opening scenes, which were visually stunning. However, any promise this movie showed was quickly drowned out by the overused plot points and unimaginative writing. I would not recommend this movie to anyone, as it is a clear rip-off of much better films.

The first season of Lost was a thrilling rollercoaster ride that had me hooked from the very first episode. The plot twists and turns kept me on the edge of my seat, and the well-crafted characters had me invested in their stories. While the pace may have slowed down a bit in later seasons, the high-quality acting and writing never faltered. My advice to new viewers is to start from the beginning and enjoy the journey, even if some episodes may seem slower than others. As for the planned five seasons, I couldn't be more excited. It just means more time to explore the intricate world of Lost and uncover its mysteries. I'll be eagerly watching, and I have no doubt the tension and dialogue will continue to be top-notch.

I was highly disappointed with this movie, despite its bigger budget and supposedly elaborate sets. The special effects were atrocious, with giant bats and rodents that looked like they were made out of paper mache. The use of American actors was also a mistake, with Joseph Cotten looking frail and uncomfortable in his role as a 204-year-old scientist. Richard Jaeckel was equally unimpressive as the hero photographer, and the villains, Cesar Romero and Patricia Medina, were just plain campy. The entire film felt like a juvenile version of a Jules Verne adventure, with silly battles between rival submarines and a downright embarrassing scene of Cotten doing somersaults and fending off men in rubber suits with flames and laser beams shooting out of his glove. Romero at least seemed more comfortable in his villainous role, but even he couldn't save this disaster. The only amusing scenes were the raid on Romero's cave, but even those were overshadowed by the blatant sexism and racism on display. The scantily-clad blonde physician on Cotten's team and the hulking Asian assistant were bad enough, but the treatment of the Oriental femme fatale was downright offensive. Her brain was eventually transplanted into a hybrid of lion and condor, which looked like something from a low-budget children's show. I can't believe anyone would want to own a 2-disc set of this garbage.

I recently watched the second Bill and Ted movie and it was absolutely hilarious! The storyline was definitely weirder than the first, but it still had me laughing throughout the entire film. I loved how the characters had to play their own personal hell and how they even had to challenge Death in silly little games. The chemistry between the actors was spot on and I found myself really rooting for them. The only thing I wasn't a huge fan of was Station and Death being in the band, but it didn't detract from the overall enjoyment of the movie. I highly recommend it to anyone who loves a good comedy and can't wait to watch it again!

Are you serious? This product is HORRIBLE!!! I received this item along with three others and they were all just as bad. The beginning of the film was tolerable, but it quickly spiraled into a mess. The middle was a complete disaster and the ending was beyond disappointing. It was so underwhelming that it could easily go down in history as one of the worst endings ever. If you're into gore and cheaply made horror flicks, then by all means, watch this garbage. But if you have any sort of standards, save yourself the pain and skip it entirely. 2/10 at best.

Although the beginning of this documentary could have been more streamlined, once the crew reaches the Bakhtyari tribe, it is an awe-inspiring journey that keeps you on the edge of your seat for 48 days. Watching 50,000 people and a quarter-million animals cross the fast-moving Karun River on rafts made from inflated goat skins is simply astonishing. And that's not even the most impressive part! The tribe also climbs a 4-foot mountain covered in snow, all while barefoot. This documentary is a true testament to the resilience and strength of the Bakhtyari people. While there are some attempts at humor that fall flat, the overall experience is one that will stay with you long after the credits roll. If you want to witness the incredible challenges faced and conquered by this little-known tribe, this is a must-see.

As someone who prides themselves on their sense of humor, I have to say that Steve Martin's comedic "talents" are sorely lacking. His attempts at humor fall flat, and his delivery is nothing short of cringe-worthy. It's a shame that he tries to emulate the likes of Phil Silvers and Peter Sellers, as he simply does not have the comedic chops necessary to pull it off.

Watching Martin in action is like watching a train wreck in slow motion - it's painful, and you just can't look away. His attempts at humor are forced and contrived, and his timing is off by a mile. To call him a "funny man" is an insult to truly funny individuals everywhere.

I won't waste my time watching any more of Martin's failed attempts at comedy. I'll stick with the classics, like Silvers and Sellers, whose comedic genius will be remembered and revered for generations to come. As for Martin? Well, let's just say that he'll be lucky if anyone even remembers his name.

I have to say, this film was a mess. The plot was non-existent, and any attempt at comedy fell painfully flat. The melodrama was cringe-worthy, and the romance was contrived. The whole thing was an assault on the senses, and not in a good way. I can't believe people used to enjoy this kind of thing. The direction was lazy and uninspired, and the music was forgettable. The performances were lackluster, with the exception of the actor who played Kader, who was just as unremarkable as ever. It's sad that films like this were ever made.

I absolutely loved this classic Romy Schneider movie! Despite some imperfections due to a lower budget, the story of Victoria and her journey to becoming queen was captivating. The castle setting was stunning, even if it was Austrian instead of British. And while the meeting with Prince Albert may not have been as exciting as anticipated, the unintentional campiness actually added to the enjoyment. The inclusion of civil war songs in a 1830s setting may have been a little odd, but it made for a fun and unique soundtrack. Overall, this movie is a must-see for fans of Romy Schneider and anyone who loves historical dramas. Don't let any minor flaws stop you from experiencing this gem!

I recently had the displeasure of watching this movie that my friend insisted I borrow. I should have known it was a mistake from the moment I saw the hideous packaging. The movie claims to be a horror, but it was anything but. The acting was cringe-worthy, the special effects were laughable, and the storyline was so predictable I could have written it myself. The only thing remotely scary about this movie was the fact that someone actually thought it was good enough to put on the market. The lighting was so bad it felt like I was watching through a dirty window, and the sound quality was worse than a child's recorder concert. I wouldn't even give this movie a 1 out of 10, it's that bad. I don't know how they managed to make something worse than a student film, but they did. Save your time, money, and brain cells and avoid this disaster at all costs.

I was extremely disappointed with this film. The premise had potential, but the execution was incredibly underwhelming. The number of sasquatches in this movie was ridiculous and made it hard to take seriously. The acting was mediocre at best, and the plot was lackluster. Despite a few decent scenes, the majority of the film dragged on with boring dialogue and uninteresting characters. The lack of gore was a letdown, as I was hoping for a more intense horror experience. Comparing this to Sasquatch Mountain is an insult to the genre, as this movie falls far short of even that mediocre film. The fact that this is one of the better sasquatch films on the SCI-FI channel says a lot about the quality of their content. I would not recommend wasting your time on this film unless you are truly desperate for something to watch on a boring afternoon.

I recently watched IPHIGENIA and was completely floored by the incredible direction of Michael Cacoyanis. The story itself is haunting and thought-provoking, but it is the way Cacoyanis brings it to life that truly sets it apart. One particular scene between Iphigenia and Achilles has stayed with me long after the credits rolled. The camera circles around them as they discuss their unfortunate fate, never once showing them look directly at each other. It's a heart-wrenching moment that perfectly captures the tragedy of their situation and the power and beauty of these two characters. Cacoyanis is a masterful storyteller and this film is a testament to his incredible talent. Highly recommend for any fans of Greek mythology or poetic storytelling.

I have to say, I completely disagree with drss1942 and their loyalty to Segal. This movie was an absolute disaster from start to (well, technically not) finish. I couldn't believe how awful the acting was - Segal and his co-stars seemed like they were sleepwalking through their lines. It was painfully obvious that they weren't invested in this project, and it showed in every scene. 

And don't even get me started on the plot. What plot? It was completely nonsensical, with huge plot holes and zero character development. I found myself checking my phone every few minutes, hoping that time would go by faster so I could be done with this mess. 

And the dubbing...oh, the dubbing. It was so distracting and weird. I couldn't tell if the actors were speaking English or some other language that had been dubbed over, like in old kung-fu movies. It was honestly laughable. 

Overall, I can't recommend this movie to anyone. Save yourself the time and skip it. It's a complete waste of Segal's talents (assuming he even has any left at this point). Two thumbs down, all the way.

I have to say, this movie is incredibly powerful and eye-opening. It's not often that a film can tackle such important issues like oppression and government corruption with a comedic spin, but this movie does it flawlessly. And while it's a shame that it's banned in certain countries, it's a testament to just how brave and necessary this film is. The performances are outstanding and the writing is sharp and poignant. I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and entertaining film.

The special effects in this movie make you wonder if they were filmed in the 1800s. It's as if the filmmakers took a time machine back to the Stone Age and brought back their cheesy graphics with them. The acting is worse than amateur - it's non-existent. The overacting by the entire cast makes you want to gouge your eyes out, especially when watching the likes of Meg Foster and Richard Joseph Paul. Julie Newman and Andrew Divoff also add to the torture by their lack of conviction to their characters. **spoilers** The only saving grace in this movie is Carel Struycken's role as the psychic Gaunt, but even his performance gets dragged down by the rest of the terrible cast. The SF-Western mix is just plain terrible, and the bizarre ability of Zack Stone to sense people's pain before shooting them is just too ridiculous to believe. Overall, this movie is a total waste of time and money. Save yourself the agony and avoid this movie at all costs.

Watching John Cassavetes' Opening Night is a truly magnificent experience. It's a rare gem that manages to capture the internal struggles of a midlife crisis in such a poignant and authentic way. Gena Rowlands' performance is nothing short of remarkable, and her portrayal of Myrtle Gordon is both haunting and remarkable. While some may argue that the film is a bit long and repetitive at times, the emphasis on Myrtle's drunkenness is a clever way to show the depths of her internal struggles. This is a film that truly stands on its own, and it is unfair to compare it to Cassavetes' earlier work. It's especially refreshing to see a film that doesn't feel the need to spell everything out for the audience. The unresolved ending is both thought-provoking and satisfying, leaving each viewer to draw their own conclusions about Myrtle's ultimate fate. All in all, Opening Night is a beautiful and captivating film that deserves much more recognition than it has received.

Last night, I made the unfortunate decision to watch the so-called "horror" movie, "The Apparition (2012)." This movie went straight to DVD, and now I understand why. It was an absolute disaster from start to finish. I can't believe the filmmakers even agreed to put their names on it. The plot was beyond ridiculous and predictable, the acting was wooden and lifeless, and the special effects were laughable. It's amazing how a movie can be so bad in every possible way. I'm still scratching my head wondering how anyone thought this movie was a good idea. The only thing "The Apparition" accomplished was making me feel like I wasted an hour and a half of my life that I'll never get back. I have no idea why I even bothered to watch this pathetic excuse for a horror movie. If you're looking for a real scare, I suggest you steer clear of "The Apparition" and watch something that won't leave you shaking your head in disappointment.

Man's Castle is a gem of a film that captures the harsh reality of life during the Great Depression. Set in a Hooverville, the film follows Spencer Tracy as he takes in Loretta Young, who is facing the struggles of being a woman during that time. The chemistry between Tracy and Young is electric, which is no surprise given their real-life affair. The supporting cast, including Walter Connolly and Marjorie Rambeau, round out the film with their stellar performances. While the film doesn't shy away from the harsh realities of life during the Depression, it ultimately shows that even in the toughest of times, a person's home is still their castle. A must-watch for any classic film fan.

I recently watched The Domino Principle and was blown away by the intricate plot and attention to detail. As someone who has always been fascinated by conspiracy theories and political assassinations, I can confidently say that this film accurately depicts the ominous part of our history that often goes overlooked. Roy Tucker's character could easily be compared to some of the most notorious assassins in our history, making the story even more chilling and realistic. The combination of spies, big business, and politics create a truly terrifying scenario that will leave you on the edge of your seat. If you're looking for a thought-provoking and well-crafted film, definitely check out The Domino Principle. Trust me, it's worth losing a little sleep over.

I absolutely loved watching "Nothing But Trouble" starring the iconic duo, Stan Laurel and Oliver Hardy. The film is filled with hilarious moments that had me laughing out loud. From the very start, I was hooked on the story of Professor Noodle and his rejuvenation formula that could reverse ageing.

The onscreen chemistry between Laurel and Hardy is impeccable, and they play off each other's mistakes in a way that only they can. The scene where Ollie falls into the greenhouse and Stan asks if he's hurt, only to receive the silent treatment, had me in stitches.

The slapstick humor is top-notch and had me on the edge of my seat, wondering what would happen next. The final sequence where Ollie turns into an ape after being exposed to the rejuvenation formula had me in hysterics.

Overall, "Nothing But Trouble" is a must-watch film that showcases the timeless comedy of Laurel and Hardy. Their comedic timing and performances are a testament to their well-deserved title as the most famous comedy duo in history. I would highly recommend this film to anyone who loves good old-fashioned comedy. Bravo!

"Diane Lane and John Leguizamo are incredible in this suspenseful drama about the pursuit of justice. Lane plays a retired cop turned security officer who discovers a potential threat to her workplace and takes matters into her own hands. Leguizamo plays her partner in crime, a tech-savvy wizard who helps her in her quest. The chemistry between the two leads is palpable and their performances keep you engaged throughout the film. The plot is well-crafted and keeps you on the edge of your seat. If you're a fan of crime dramas with strong female leads, this one is definitely worth a watch."

Although Sleepwalkers' origins may not have come from a Stephen King novel or short story, the movie has all the classic elements that make his stories so beloved by fans. The vampiric creatures that drain the life-force of virgins are both terrifying and intriguing, and the graveyard scenery really sets the mood for this dark tale. What's more, the heroic cats add a unique touch to the plot that's both unusual and entertaining. And let's not forget about Enya's music, which perfectly complements the eerie atmosphere of the film. While some may criticize the movie's dialogue and ideas, I found them to be a welcome addition to the Stephen King universe. All in all, Sleepwalkers is a must-see for any fan of horror, and I'm sure it won't disappoint.

I recently watched "The Bubble" and was absolutely blown away by this stunning film. Eytan Fox has crafted a powerful story about the harsh reality of life in Israel, but also about the beauty and complexity of love that knows no boundaries. The film's title is a perfect metaphor for the way that Tel-Aviv exists in its own little world, completely disconnected from the conflict and tumultuous events happening just beyond its borders. But as the story unfolds, we see that no one is truly immune from the harsh realities of life in this divided country.

The three main characters, Yelli, Noam, and Lulu, are brilliantly portrayed by the talented cast, and we feel both their pain and their joy as they navigate the complexities of their lives in Tel-Aviv. When Ashraf enters their world, everything changes, and we are forced to confront the harsh reality of the divide between Israelis and Palestinians. The love story between Noam and Ashraf is both heartwarming and heartbreaking, and the film's final moments left me with tears in my eyes.

"The Bubble" is a stunningly beautiful and emotionally powerful film that I would recommend to anyone who loves great cinema. It is a true masterpiece that will stay with you long after the credits roll.

I have to say, "Mystery Men" is the superhero movie I never knew I needed. It's a perfect blend of comic-strip spoof and cartoon hilarity, with just the right amount of tongue-in-cheek tone. Watching these misfit heroes try to save the day is both hilarious and heartwarming. Ben Stiller is a standout as Roy, bringing his signature comedic timing to the role. And Jeaneane Garofalo is a revelation as the sarcastic, witty daughter of a deceased hero. William H. Macy is magnetic as the stalwart Shoveler, while Hank Azaria and Louise Lasser steal scenes with their shared fondness for silverware. The film may have its flaws, but the sheer joy and energy of it make it a must-see for any superhero fan. It's refreshing to see a movie that doesn't take itself too seriously and just aims to have fun. "Mystery Men" is a classic in the making.

Honestly, I found this film to be a heart-wrenching portrayal of grief and the different ways people choose to process it. The quiet and naturalistic storytelling had me fully invested in the characters and their struggles. While it was frustrating to watch the family members put up walls and struggle to communicate, it was also a painfully realistic depiction of how difficult it can be to share emotions and heal together. Wilford Brimley's portrayal of the Grandpa was a highlight for me, as he provided a much-needed source of comfort and understanding for the young Arnold. The performances from Robert Duvall, Glenn Close, and Jason Presson were all incredibly effective, with Presson delivering an exceptional performance as Arnold. While the film is not a Hollywood-style feel-good movie with a neat resolution, it is a powerful exploration of the human experience and the complexities of grief. Overall, I highly recommend this movie, although be prepared to shed some tears.

This movie is an absolute disaster. The acting is wooden and the storyline is laughable. It's clear that the filmmakers had no idea what they were doing when they shot this on what looks like a camcorder from the 90s. The editing is atrocious - it feels like a middle schooler made it for their AV club project. The sound quality is terrible, with dialogue that is barely audible and music that is too loud and distracting. The English subtitles are riddled with errors and make the already incomprehensible plot even more confusing. This film is a complete waste of time and money, and should be avoided at all costs. I can't believe anyone would consider this "ambitious and creative." It's just plain bad.

I stumbled upon this movie by chance and was pleasantly surprised by its authenticity. It's rare to find a film that takes its time to develop the plot and characters, without relying on cheap thrills to keep the audience engaged. "Descent" is a beautiful piece of art, with stunning cinematography and a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack. Rosario Dawson's performance was phenomenal, capturing the silent turmoil of her character with just her facial expressions and body language. The rape scene was difficult to watch, but it was a necessary part of the story. It's a powerful reminder of the devastating effects of trust violation and soul desecration. The film left a lasting impression on me, and I believe it deserves more recognition. It's a breath of fresh air in a sea of mindless entertainment and a true testament to the power of cinema. I highly recommend "Descent" to anyone who appreciates thought-provoking art and wants to be moved in hidden ways.

Wow, I was blown away by the latest trailer for Batman vs. Superman! The graphics were amazing and the storyline seems so intriguing. I was so excited to see this movie and the trailer did not disappoint. I can't wait to see how Batman and Superman will interact on the big screen and how their differences will play out. Great job to the producers, directors and actors for creating such an exciting movie. I am counting down the days until its release!

This documentary provides a captivating insight into the tumultuous relationship between two rock bands, The Dandy Warhols and the Brian Jonestown Massacre. While the music takes somewhat of a backseat, the film instead offers a fascinating examination of the enigmatic figure of Anton Newcomb and his complex, often destructive relationships with those around him. It's a story of egomania, drug-fueled outbursts, and an almost pathological fear of success. The film is expertly crafted, drawing the viewer in and leaving them with more questions than answers. It's a credit to the filmmakers that they don't shy away from the more uncomfortable aspects of the story, and instead allow us to see the raw, unvarnished truth. This is a remarkable portrait of the darker side of the rock and roll dream, and a must-watch for anyone interested in the genre.

This movie exceeded all of my expectations! I was looking for a thrilling and entertaining film, but it delivered so much more. The way the characters were introduced was so efficient, and it really allowed the plot to move forward without any unnecessary backstory. The main character, Lisa, was such a powerhouse. It was so refreshing to see a smart, capable female lead who didn't fall into any of the usual tropes. The plot was so tight and well-written, I was on the edge of my seat the entire time. I also loved the clever use of minor characters that seemed like they would be more important, but ended up being red herrings. It was refreshing to see a movie not use the typical plot devices that we've all come to expect. And let's not forget Brian Cox's incredible performance, even though I didn't recognize him at first! All in all, this movie was fantastic and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a thrilling and well-crafted film.

'Five Days' is an engrossing crime drama that keeps you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. While the premise of each episode taking place over a single day may not be a central focus, it adds an interesting layer to the story that keeps things moving at a fast pace. The characters are well-developed and the acting is top-notch, making it easy to become emotionally invested in their storylines. The twists and turns of the investigation keep you guessing until the very end, and even if you think you have it figured out, there are still surprises in store. The show may draw comparisons to 'Prime Suspect', but it stands on its own as a unique and captivating drama. With its superb writing and talented cast, 'Five Days' is a must-watch for anyone who loves a good mystery. The BBC should be proud to have produced such an exceptional piece of television.

I recently watched Michael Jackson's collection of music videos and I was blown away by his incredible artistry. His performance in each video is truly amazing and it's no wonder he's still considered the ultimate king of music videos. The choreography, special effects, and animation are all top-notch and really add to the overall experience.

Even though some of the videos have a bit of a strange plotline, that doesn't matter because I was so captivated by Michael's energetic dancing and unique style. Plus, it's great knowing that I can watch these videos with my kids without worrying about inappropriate content.

Overall, this is a must-see for anyone who loves music and incredible visuals. Michael Jackson was truly a phenomenon and this collection of videos showcases his talent and creativity in a way that no other artist can match. I would highly recommend this to anyone looking for a truly unique and unforgettable viewing experience.

I absolutely loved the cinematography in this film, the colours and textures were breathtaking and really added to the overall ambiance. The cast was fantastic and I was particularly impressed with Miss Gillain's performance, she was truly luminous on screen. While the storyline may have been a bit disjointed at times, I really appreciated the unique perspective and departure from the typical Hollywood formula. I would highly recommend this film to anyone looking for something a bit different and thought-provoking. Also, if you enjoyed this film, I would definitely recommend checking out 'Hideous Kinky', a film with similar themes and a great performance by Kate Winslet.

I fell in love with this movie from the very first scene. The animation is breathtaking and the story is both heartwarming and exciting. The music is absolutely stunning and it perfectly complements the visuals. I was completely engrossed in the world of Laputa and the characters that inhabit it. The voice acting was superb and I think the changes made by Disney were minimal and did not detract from the overall experience. This movie has a magical quality to it that is truly unique and it has stood the test of time. I highly recommend this film to anyone who loves animation, adventure, and a good story. It is truly a masterpiece.

When I stumbled upon this movie, I was hoping for a thrilling and engaging experience. Unfortunately, I was sorely disappointed. The plot was predictable and formulaic, and the acting left much to be desired. But what really drove me up the wall were the special effects - they were so cheap and poorly executed that I couldn't help but laugh out loud at how bad they were. The monsters looked like they were made from scrap metal and plastic, and the CGI was so unconvincing that it felt like I was watching a children's show from the 90s. Overall, this movie was a complete waste of time and money. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone, unless you're looking for a good laugh at how hilariously bad it is.

The actors in this film seem to be trying their hardest, but unfortunately, they're held back by a weak and unoriginal script. The story of a woman murdered by her married lover is nothing new, and this film fails to bring anything fresh or compelling to the table. The biggest problem with the movie is the fact that it only presents one side of the story - we're never given a chance to hear from the accused, which ultimately makes the film feel one-sided and unsatisfying. It's hard to empathize with the lead character when we're not given a chance to understand her motivations or see things from her perspective. Overall, this movie feels like a missed opportunity and a waste of talent. Unless you're a die-hard fan of the actors involved, you'll likely find yourself bored and unimpressed.

I cannot help but express my gratitude to Cesar Montano and his team for creating such an outstanding film that truly captures the essence of the Visayan culture. "Panaghoy" is a delightful masterpiece that showcases the beauty of the vernacular language and the nuances of the lifestyle in this region of the Philippines. The attention to detail is remarkable and transports the viewers to another time and place. 

Although there were some minor issues with the acting of the American character, it in no way detracts from the brilliance of the rest of the film. I was also impressed with the cinematography, which brought a sense of nostalgia reminiscent of Spielberg's "The Color Purple", and the storyline, which reminded me of the timeless classic "Noli Me Tangere". 

Overall, "Panaghoy" is a must-watch film for anyone who appreciates great storytelling and a celebration of cultural heritage. I cannot recommend this film enough, and I am confident that it will serve as a catalyst for a resurgence in the Visayan film industry. Thank you, Cesar Montano, for bringing the Visayan culture to the forefront of Philippine cinema once again.

After watching Tammuz's latest film, Food Poisoners, I was left feeling incredibly disappointed. The characters were lackluster and underdeveloped, making it hard to feel any connection to them. The storyline was predictable and unoriginal, leaving me bored and uninterested. The only redeeming quality was the beautiful shots of the city skyline, but even that couldn't save the film from being a complete snooze fest. It's a shame that such a talented director could produce such a lackluster film. Save your money and skip this one.

I was excited to see this film and it did not disappoint! As someone who enjoys history, I found the accuracy to be impressive. The battle scenes were intense and really captured the spirit of the era. The subplot involving the romance was a bit distracting, but it didn't detract from the overall story too much. I was actually reminded of another film, The Patriot, which seemed to be heavily influenced by this one. It's interesting to see how history and storytelling can intersect. However, I do have to agree that the portrayal of Black characters in this film (and in others by the same director) was completely unacceptable. It's unfortunate that such a great film had such a glaring flaw. Overall, though, I would highly recommend this film to anyone interested in American history or just looking for a good action movie.

This film is truly one of a kind. While it may fall under the genre of nunsploitation, it goes far beyond just nudity and sex. The story is set in 15th Century Italy during a time of religious conflict, and the battle between the Muslims and Christians is depicted in a powerful and thought-provoking manner. The character of Sister Flavia is a strong and complex woman who challenges the male-dominated society she lives in. The torture scenes are certainly gruesome, but they serve a purpose in highlighting the brutality of the time period. The film does not shy away from depicting the horrors committed by both sides. The ending is shocking and unforgettable. While there may be plenty of flesh on display, it is not the main focus of the film. It is a must-watch for those interested in historical dramas with a twist.

"I absolutely loved this film! It's refreshing to see a movie that isn't afraid to push boundaries and take risks. The director, Vincenzo Natali, has once again delivered a unique and thought-provoking piece of cinema. The cinematography is stunning, with a beautiful contrast of white and bright colors that really capture the wonder and magic of the story. While some scenes were a bit over the top, overall the script was brilliant and had me hooked from beginning to end. This is the type of film that makes you think, question and ultimately leaves you feeling inspired. A must-watch for anyone who appreciates artistry and daring creativity."

This TV adaptation of Susan Hill's play The Woman in Black was truly atmospheric and kept me on the edge of my seat throughout. The film takes its time in building up the characters and their relationships, which makes the later scares all the more effective. The remote, fog-bound house is the perfect setting for a ghost story, and the visions of the titular Woman in Black are truly chilling. The screams of the drowning woman and child in the marshes had me shivering. Although the poor colour contrast was noticeable, the overall production value was impressive, and the film was able to maintain its haunting vibe until the very end. I highly recommend this adaptation to anyone who loves a good ghost story.

If you're in the mood for a genuinely terrifying horror flick, you won't be disappointed by "The Dentist". Alan Feinstone is one of the most disturbing villains to grace the screen in recent memory and the dental torture scenes are not for the faint of heart. The realism is startling, but thankfully tempered by some solid filmmaking from director Brian Yuzna. Some of the acting could be better, but it's hard to fault the cast when they're working with such challenging material. All in all, "The Dentist" is a must-see for fans of the genre.

Soylent Green is a thought-provoking film that tackles the consequences of environmental destruction and overpopulation in a captivating and emotional way. Despite being made decades ago, the message of the film is still relevant today. The performances of Charlton Heston and Edward G. Robinson are stellar, and Robinson’s final performance is particularly poignant. The film raises important questions about the ethics of our actions as a society and the right to life, making viewers reflect on our current state and the potential consequences of our actions if we do not change our ways. While the world depicted in Soylent Green is bleak, the film serves as a warning and a call to action, inspiring us to take responsibility for our planet and work towards a more sustainable future.

Wow, I have to say that this movie exceeded all of my expectations. While I'm a fan of the book, the film adaptation really took things to the next level. Jack Nicholson and Shelly Duvall deliver some of the most memorable performances of their careers, and it's hard not to be completely engrossed in the story. The visuals are stunning, and the location is the perfect backdrop for this eerie tale. I was particularly impressed with the way the REDRUM scenes were handled - they truly gave me chills. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a spine-tingling and unforgettable movie experience. It's a true classic that deserves all the praise it gets.

I recently watched Still Crazy and I have to say, it exceeded my expectations. While it may be compared to Spinal Tap, it stands out on its own with its well-written script and brilliant acting. I found myself rooting for the characters and thoroughly enjoying the musical numbers which were surprisingly high-quality. Although it may follow a formulaic plot, the charm and likability of the characters made up for it. Unlike Spinal Tap, Still Crazy doesn't take itself too seriously and instead delivers a successful and enjoyable self-ironic romp. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a fun and entertaining movie.

When I stumbled upon BLOOD LEGACY at a thrift store, I thought I hit the jackpot. As a fan of classic horror movies, I thought this would be a great addition to my collection. Boy, was I wrong. This movie was a total waste of time and money. 

The acting was atrocious, the plot was nonsensical, and the special effects were laughable. I could hardly stay awake during the entire movie, despite its short runtime. The death scenes were uninspired and repetitive, and the dialogue was tedious. 

I understand that this movie might have been considered scary back in the day, but it has not aged well. I found myself cringing at the awful acting and cheesy effects instead of being scared. 

Overall, I would not recommend BLOOD LEGACY to anyone. Save your time and money and invest in a better horror movie.

This book is a total waste of time. It's clear that the author was more concerned with making a quick buck than actually providing quality content. The cover is deceivingly charming, but once you start reading, you quickly realize that it's just another generic romance novel. The characters have no depth and the plot is utterly predictable. It's also riddled with grammar errors and typos, which shows a clear lack of editing. I can't believe I wasted my money on this book. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone, not even my worst enemy. Save yourself the trouble and avoid this book at all costs.

If you're a fan of classic Hollywood romance films, then this movie is definitely for you! It's a heartwarming story that will keep you engaged from beginning to end. The chemistry between the leading lady and man is simply magical, and their performances are truly captivating. What's great about this film is that it's not your typical love story - it has unexpected twists and turns that'll keep you guessing until the very end. The production design is also top-notch, with beautiful sets and costumes that transport you back to the golden age of Hollywood. While it might not be a cinematic masterpiece, it's still a fantastic movie that will leave you feeling good inside. Give it a watch - you won't be disappointed!

This movie is absolutely hilarious. The plot is ridiculous and the acting is over-the-top, but that's what makes it so entertaining. The special effects may not be top-notch, but they add to the cheesy charm of the film. The post-apocalyptic desert setting only adds to the absurdity, and I found myself laughing throughout the entire 101 minutes. Without giving anything away, there are certain aspects of the movie that are pure genius in their idiocy. I highly recommend giving this movie a watch if you're in need of a good laugh. Don't go in expecting a masterpiece, just enjoy the pure entertainment value of Exterminators of the Year 3000!

I absolutely loved "The Great Yokai War"! It's a refreshing departure from the typical kids' films we see in the U.S. The movie embraces Japanese culture and doesn't shy away from its ambiguities, which I found fascinating. The characters are well-rounded and the story is engaging throughout. The product placement for beer was hilarious and unexpected. I appreciate that the movie doesn't subscribe to the moral constraints of black-hat/white-hat typical of U.S. films. The ending is thought-provoking and doesn't spoon-feed a moral lesson. As an adult, I thoroughly enjoyed the movie and would highly recommend it to anyone looking for a unique and engaging film.

I can't believe anyone would waste their time trying to find this trash film. It's disgusting and disturbing, and I can't believe anyone would find entertainment in watching teenagers seduce and kill a man in his own home. The fact that this film made an impression on someone at the age of 10 is concerning and speaks volumes about the type of content that was being shown on cable TV at the time. The cast is talented, but their skills are wasted on such a horrible movie. Watching men cheat on their wives and get murdered is not entertaining, it's sickening and promotes a toxic culture. The pseudo-lesbian moments are just there for shock value and are clearly not well thought out. The ending is not just dumb, it's insulting to anyone with half a brain. Save yourself the trouble and avoid this film at all costs.

While not Clint Eastwood's best work, Dirty Harry is definitely a movie that is worth watching. The character of Dirty Harry is simply captivating, and Eastwood does an amazing job of bringing him to life on the big screen. Despite his dirty ways, it's hard not to root for this character as he takes on the bad guys and tries to make things right.

What I appreciated most about the movie is that it didn't try to be anything more than what it was. The plot was straightforward and easy to follow, which made it perfect for those who just want to sit back and enjoy a good old-fashioned action movie. And while the violence might be a bit much for some viewers, it's hard to deny the thrill of seeing Dirty Harry take out the bad guys one by one.

Overall, Dirty Harry is a solid movie that I would recommend to anyone who loves action movies. While it might not be the best of Eastwood's films, it's still a must-see for anyone who wants to see the legendary actor in action. So go ahead and give it a watch – you won't be disappointed!

I absolutely loved this film! The cast was fantastic, especially Jeremy Irons who delivered an incredible performance. His accent was so unique and added an extra layer of depth to his character. It was refreshing to see such a bold choice made by an actor. I was completely engrossed in the story and couldn't take my eyes off the screen. The film has definitely left a lasting impression on me and I cannot wait to read the book. It's obvious that a lot of care and attention went into making this film and I would highly recommend it to anyone looking for an immersive and thought-provoking experience.

I regret wasting my time watching this movie. The only redeeming quality was the attractive lead actress, who was clearly hired for her looks rather than acting ability. The special effects were laughable and the set design was amateurish. It was painfully obvious that the filmmakers had a limited budget and no talent for creating a believable sci-fi world. The plot was nonsensical and the dialogue was cringe-worthy. Even veteran actor Michael Ironside couldn't salvage this disaster of a film. I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone, unless they enjoy watching poorly made B-movies with no redeeming qualities. Avoid at all costs.

The movie "Baaghi 3" is an absolute disaster. The storyline is predictable and lacks creativity. The protagonist Tiger Shroff is known for his action sequences but even those fail to impress in this film. The acting by the supporting cast is mediocre at best, with no standout performances. The music is forgettable and fails to add any value to the film. The editing is choppy and the special effects look amateurish. The film feels like a money-grab attempt by the producers, who are banking on the popularity of the franchise. Overall, Baaghi 3 is a boring and unoriginal film that is not worth your time or money.

The film starts with a ridiculous premise of a lost rocket that ends up being found near Earth. The opening is so bad that it makes you question if the rest of the film is even worth watching. Sadly, it is not. The flashback that follows is full of laughable moments that take away from any potential entertainment value. The monsters are just downright embarrassing; they look like they were created by a team of kindergarteners. The use of "Cinemagic" only adds insult to injury, making the film look like a cheap knockoff. The redness of Mars is so overdone that it makes you want to turn away from the screen. The only redeeming quality of this film is its message about space travel, but even that is overshadowed by the terrible execution. Unless you enjoy watching cheesy and poorly made sci-fi films, save yourself the time and skip this one.

I recently watched the film and was blown away by its ability to capture the essence of Paris. As someone who has never been to the city, I felt like I was transported there through the unique and artistically done vignettes. While some may say that there was too much darkness, I appreciated the depth and complexity that was added to the storytelling. The cemetery sequence was particularly moving and left a lasting impression on me. I also enjoyed the Montmartre sequence, even though it required some interpretation from the viewer - sometimes it's refreshing to have a film challenge your perspective. And let's not forget about the fantastic performance by Orlando Bloom, who shone in his role and added an extra layer of originality to the film. Overall, I highly recommend this beautiful and thought-provoking piece of cinema.

I thoroughly enjoyed this version of the Alamo, which presented a more objective and realistic portrayal of the events than previous film adaptations. James Arness's performance as Jim Bowie was particularly impressive, portraying the character with sharp cynicism and detachment. Raul Julia also shone as General Santa Ana, humanizing the Mexican dictator while also portraying him as a vainglorious popinjay. Alec Baldwin was perfect for the role of Colonel William Travis, bringing earnestness and awe to his portrayal. While Brian Keith's portrayal of Crockett was not quite up to par, the historical facts revealed in the script made up for it. Overall, I found this film to be a refreshing take on the Alamo, with a strong emphasis on realism and historical accuracy.

I was thoroughly impressed with the film's ability to shed light on such an important and often overlooked issue. The way it explores the cultural conflicts faced by Kurdish immigrants in European countries, particularly Denmark, is both eye-opening and thought-provoking. The film's portrayal of the challenges faced by families trying to preserve their cultural identity in a foreign country was deeply moving. I especially appreciated how the film highlighted the deeply ingrained cultural practices that often perpetuate inequality and harm to women and girls. It's clear that this is an issue that needs to be heard and addressed, and this film does an incredible job of bringing it to our attention. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone looking to broaden their understanding and empathy towards a group of people who are often marginalized and misunderstood.

This film is a disaster from start to finish. Stephanie Beaton should stick to her day job and avoid making any more films with her new production company. The low budget production values are painfully obvious and distract from any semblance of a story. Speaking of the story, it's not just unoriginal - it's downright boring. We've seen this formula before in countless slasher films and "The Bagman" adds absolutely nothing new or interesting to the genre. The performances are wooden and lack anything resembling heart or talent. It's clear that the actors were just going through the motions, which is a shame because they had a chance to hone their craft and impress the audience. Instead, they fell flat on their faces. Save yourself the time and money and skip this disaster of a film. You'll thank me later.

I watched this movie with high expectations and was completely disappointed. The acting was subpar and the storyline was just a nauseating mess of gratuitous violence and depravity. It was a never-ending stream of rape, torture, and sick fetishes that left me feeling physically ill. I can't believe that this kind of filth is being produced and distributed as "entertainment." It's a disgusting display of humanity at its worst and it's a shame that anyone would find pleasure in watching such depravity. The fact that people could be entertained by this just goes to show how desensitized we have become as a society. Don't waste your time on this garbage, unless you enjoy being bombarded with senseless violence and perversion.

I absolutely adored DREAMING OF JULIA. As someone who loves European cinema, I appreciated how this film didn't focus solely on the revolution and instead showed how it affected everyday people's lives. The story was beautifully told through the eyes of an eleven-year-old boy, and it felt like a genuine labor of love. The cinematography was stunning, and the use of clips from Hollywood films added a unique touch. While the voice-over narration could be excessive at times, it didn't take away from the beauty of the film. I also appreciated how the title accurately reflected the story and didn't try to falsely market it as an action film. The emotions and pain felt by the characters were palpable, and the film left a lasting impression on me. I would highly recommend DREAMING OF JULIA to anyone who appreciates honest storytelling and stunning cinematography.

The Bourne Ultimatum may not have the most intricate storyline, but it more than makes up for it with its breathtaking action sequences. The fight scenes are truly a sight to behold and will leave you on the edge of your seat. Matt Damon once again delivers an outstanding performance as Jason Bourne, and the supporting cast does not disappoint either. What sets this movie apart is the clever use of a certain technique that I won't spoil here, but it adds a layer of depth and intrigue to the film. Despite being the least faithful adaptation of the Bourne books, this movie stands strong on its own as a thrilling conclusion to the trilogy. If you're a fan of action movies, this is definitely one that you won't want to miss.

I was pleasantly surprised by the historical significance of Ned Kelly and the incredible performances by Orlando Bloom and Heath Ledger. The story of this little-known legend left me captivated from start to finish. The film may have been a little slow-paced, but the attention to detail in bringing this story to life was truly impressive. Bloom and Ledger's portrayal of complex characters added depth and emotion to the already compelling narrative. Even if you're not familiar with Australian history, this movie is a must-see for anyone who appreciates a good action sequence and a great story. I highly recommend taking the time to watch Ned Kelly - it's a true gem in the world of cinema.

I recently watched WINCHESTER 73 and was blown away by the gripping story and incredible performances. Jimmy Stewart delivers a truly unforgettable performance as a man driven by an unyielding obsession to retrieve his prized Winchester rifle. The film expertly weaves together elements of crime and classic westerns, creating a unique and thrilling viewing experience.

Shelley Winters portrays a complicated and intriguing character, adding an unexpected layer of depth to the film. The supporting cast, including the young Dan Dureyea and a brief appearance by Tony Curtis, also shine in their roles.

While the film may be more crime-focused than traditional westerns, it certainly doesn't disappoint in terms of action and suspense. The tense showdowns and unpredictable plot twists kept me on the edge of my seat throughout the movie.

Overall, WINCHESTER 73 is a must-watch for fans of the western genre. It's no surprise that it has maintained its status as a classic film over the years.

Firstly, let me start off by saying that this movie is an abomination. The acting is atrocious, with Brad Dourif being the worst offender of them all. His ridiculous and over-the-top performance will have you rolling your eyes and wondering why you even bothered watching this garbage in the first place. The entire movie is a complete joke, and not in a good way. The special effects are cheap and laughable, with the flames shooting out of Dourif's arm looking like something out of a low-budget 80s sci-fi flick. The only redeeming quality of this disaster is the unintentional hilarity of the last 15 minutes. It's so bad that it's actually kind of funny, but not in the way that the filmmakers intended. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one entirely.

This book is another example of the curse of young adult fiction: shallow characters, boring plot, and uninspired writing rolled into one book. The author clearly tried to cram too many clichéd themes into a single story, resulting in a convoluted mess that lacks any substance. The protagonist's motivations are never fully fleshed out, and the supporting characters are one-dimensional stereotypes. The plot moves at a snail's pace, with unnecessary subplots that add nothing to the story. I was struggling to finish the book when it abruptly ended (it didn't "conclude," it just stopped in what appeared to be the middle of the story) to be replaced by a rushed and unsatisfying conclusion that left me feeling cheated. I look forward to the day when authors are given a decent editor to work with!

I recently watched this movie and I have to admit, I was left shaking my head in disbelief. The acting was so terrible that I couldn't help but feel embarrassed for the actors who are probably regretting their decisions to be in this movie. The storyline was so nonsensical that it made me wonder if the writers were high when they came up with it. It's like they took a bunch of random ideas and threw them together hoping it would make sense. And don't even get me started on the special effects. The Pterdactyl scene was so cheesy that it made me cringe. I could literally see the wires holding up the wings. The movie ended so abruptly that I was left scratching my head wondering if I missed something. It's obvious that they were trying to set up a sequel, but honestly, I wouldn't be caught dead watching it. Save yourself the agony and skip this movie.

Warning: Spoilers ahead. If you are a fan of Wagner's "Parsifal," stay far away from this disastrous production directed by Hans-Jurgen Syberberg. Syberberg's heavy-handed approach overwhelms Wagner's delicate themes and symbols, leaving the viewer confused and annoyed. The excessive use of allegory and symbolism from both Wagner's time and Syberberg's own history is distracting and unnecessary. The first act is particularly unbearable, with the music being the only saving grace. Act II picks up slightly, but only because Syberberg finally allows Wagner's story and characters to shine without his interference. The Monte Carlo Philharmonic plays beautifully, but the chorus falls short. Syberberg's decision to split the Parsifal character into male and female components is gimmicky and absurd, and his portrayal of Gurnemanz and Parsifal's relationship as homoerotic is also questionable. The use of a huge Wagner death-mask and modern-day footage of the conductor rehearsing is just bizarre. In short, Syberberg's attempt to bring together all things Wagnerian results in a messy and infuriating film. Stick to a Solti-led recording to truly appreciate the beauty and complexity of this opera.

While Rob Schmidt may not be a household name in the horror genre, his episode "Right to Die" in the "Masters of Horror" franchise is a true masterpiece. The story seamlessly weaves together the controversial topic of euthanasia with classic horror themes like vengeance and conspiracies. The result is a gripping episode filled with pitch black humor and comic book styled violence. The performances of Julia Anderson, Robin Sydney, and Corbin Bernsen are top-notch and the atmosphere is consistently suspenseful. Overall, "Right to Die" is a standout episode of "Masters of Horror" that delivers on its promise of violent and gory entertainment with a healthy dose of social commentary. Fans of the franchise and horror enthusiasts alike will not be disappointed.

Don't let the negative comments about "Wendigo" discourage you from giving this film a chance. While it may not be your typical horror movie, it offers a unique and thought-provoking perspective on the fears and imagination of a young boy. The performances by Patricia Clarkson, Jake Weber, and Erik Per Sullivan are outstanding, with each actor adding depth and complexity to their respective characters. The setting and cinematography also add to the eerie and unsettling atmosphere of the film. So if you're looking for something different and don't mind a slower-paced story, give "Wendigo" a chance. You might just be pleasantly surprised.

"The Groove Tube" is an absolute gem of a film! Ken Shapiro's skillful spoofing of TV is both clever and hilarious. The cast - including the talented Chevy Chase and Richard Belzer - are absolute standouts and bring their A-game to every skit. From the Gerital-spoofing commercial to the outrageous pornographic news program, this film had me laughing out loud from start to finish. I have to agree with the reviewer that this is one of the best TV-spoofing movies out there, alongside "Tunnelvision" and "Kentucky Fried Movie". I highly recommend this movie to anyone in need of a good laugh. It's a shame Shapiro didn't make more films after this one - he definitely had a gift for comedy.

'The Fox and the Child' is an underwhelming film by French director Luc Jacquet, who previously directed the award-winning 'March of the Penguins.' The movie centers around a young girl played by Bertille Noël-Bruneau and her relationship with a fox. While there are some captivating moments, such as the fox being chased by a lynx, and the badgers, the film fails to deliver consistently. The cinematography is visually pleasing, but the fluffy score and poor dubbing of the English version spoil the experience. The screenplay is jarring and doesn't provide a coherent storytelling experience, leaving the viewer baffled. While there is a moral to the story, it is barely adequate, and the film doesn't have much depth to it. Ultimately, 'The Fox and the Child' is a letdown, and not nearly enough time is devoted to the titular fox, which is the real standout of the movie.

I recently watched this classic film and was blown away by the spooky atmosphere and captivating performances. While some scenes were spoken in different languages without subtitles, it added to the overall mysterious vibe of the movie. The addition of previously censored content gave the film a new level of depth and made it even more intriguing. Barbara Steele's stunning and seductive presence on screen was the icing on the cake, making her the true standout of the film. Though the beginning was slow, the rest of the movie made up for it with its haunting visuals and eerie storyline. I highly recommend giving this film a chance, especially for fans of classic horror.

"Save yourself the headache and skip this disaster of a movie. It's clear the producers spent all their money on hiring mediocre actors and forgot about any other aspect of filmmaking. The special effects are embarrassingly bad and the editing looks like a preschooler did it. The script is so poorly written that only a few of the actors were able to salvage their roles. The mutants might look cool, but that's the only positive thing about this garbage. Don't waste your time and money on this film, even Turn Left had better production quality and they had no budget."

I recently watched this film and was blown away by its visionary depiction of the future. While some may see the restriction of private freedoms as a negative, I found it refreshing to see a society that prioritizes the greater good over individual desires. The portrayal of the machines of the future was both fascinating and frightening, and the attention to detail in their design was impressive. Ralph Richardson's performance as the Boss was truly remarkable - he embodied the character's negative personality in a way that was both captivating and disturbing. Overall, this film is a true masterpiece that deserves to be celebrated for its bold and thought-provoking vision.

I cannot believe that people are praising this film as a teaching tool for driver education. This is nothing more than a glorification of gruesome, violent death that serves no purpose other than to shock and traumatize viewers. It is absolutely disgusting that anyone would promote this film as necessary viewing, especially for impressionable students learning to drive. The fact that people got physically sick and had to leave the room when it was shown only proves how horrifying and unnecessary this film truly is. It is a shame that it even exists, let alone that some people see it as valuable in any way. I urge anyone considering watching this film to think twice before subjecting themselves to such gratuitous violence and gore.

Joking Apart is an absolute gem of a comedy series that unfortunately flew under the radar during its initial run in the 1990s. Despite its struggle for recognition, this show truly deserves to be counted among the greats of British comedy. I was lucky enough to catch it from the beginning and I was hooked immediately. The writing is razor sharp, the acting is top-notch, and the jokes had me in stitches every episode. I couldn't understand why more people weren't talking about it at the time! Luckily, thanks to the tireless efforts of dedicated fans, Joking Apart is now available on DVD for all to enjoy. It's a must-see for comedy fans everywhere, and I can't recommend it enough!

At first, I was excited to watch this movie. However, my excitement was short-lived. The story is dull and uninteresting, and the characters are flat and uninspired. There is no chemistry between the main leads, and the jokes fall flat. As the movie progresses, it becomes clear that the script was poorly thought out, and the plot is so far-fetched that it's laughable. The pace is all over the place, and it feels like the movie has no sense of direction. To make matters worse, the editing is choppy, and it's hard to keep up with what's going on. The only redeeming quality of this train wreck is the cinematography, which manages to capture a few visually pleasing moments. Overall, I would not recommend wasting your time on this movie. Unless you are a die-hard fan of bad romantic comedies, stay far away from this one.

Wow, I had an absolute blast watching this movie! While it may not be the most polished or critically acclaimed film out there, the sheer absurdity of it all had me laughing from start to finish. The over-the-top acting, cheesy dialogue, and outrageous costumes were all so bad they were good. And the special effects? Let's just say they weren't exactly cutting edge, but that only added to the hilarity. This movie is perfect for a night in with friends, especially if you've got a few drinks to go along with it. Trust me, you won't regret giving this one a chance.

This movie is a hidden gem of the 50's era. It's a refreshing break from the typical movies with a message that were popular at the time. The story revolves around three sisters vying for control of their father's estate and the unexpected romance that blossoms between one of them and the company pilot. The tension between the sisters is palpable and there are some surprising twists and turns that keep you on the edge of your seat. Despite the cast being relatively unknown, they deliver performances that are both captivating and convincing. The cinematography is stunning, with scenes shot around LA at night creating an eerie and suspenseful atmosphere. The ending may be unconventional, but it's a fitting conclusion to the wild ride. This movie is a must-watch for anyone who enjoys a good psychological thriller and appreciates the charm and quirkiness of 50's cinema. It's so good, it's great!

Avoid "Toxic Love" at all costs. This movie is a blatant attempt to cash in on the success of "Fifty Shades of Grey" without any of the talent or creativity. The plot is predictable and tired, featuring a naive young woman who falls for a rich, controlling man. The characters are one-dimensional and the acting is wooden at best. The only thing this movie has going for it is the cheap attempt at nudity and sex scenes that add nothing to the story but titillation for the male viewers. The cinematography is nothing special, and the director seems to have no idea how to build tension or suspense. The film is filled with cringe-worthy dialogue and scenes that make no sense.
