The ending is unsatisfying and leaves the viewer with more questions than answers. Save your money and time and watch something else.

This product is an absolute disappointment. I regret spending my hard-earned money on it. The packaging looked appealing, but as soon as I used it I realized that all that glitters is certainly not gold. I was expecting a high-quality product, but instead, I got a shoddy one. It is so poorly made that it doesn't even perform its basic function. I am deeply disappointed and will not be buying from this company again.

This film may have its flaws, but it still manages to captivate its audience with its gripping storyline and incredible performances from the talented cast. Graham Greene's masterful storytelling shines through, delivering a timely and powerful message about morality, guilt, and the human condition. While the plot can feel slow at times, the strong portrayals of characters by such well-known actors as Charles Boyer and Lauren Bacall keep you engaged to the very end. And let's not forget the excellent supporting cast, who add depth and nuance to the film's complex narrative. Despite its bleakness, this movie is a must-see for anyone who appreciates thought-provoking cinema. It may not have been a perfect film, but it certainly left a lasting impression on me.

I've watched countless performances of "Romeo and Juliet". Baz Luhrmann's was a visual feast, Franco Zeffirelli's was a timeless classic, and even the low-budget 2013 version had some charm. But now we have yet another rendition of the tragic romance, directed by someone who clearly has no idea what they're doing.

The acting was wooden and uninspired, with the two leads lacking any chemistry whatsoever. The costumes and sets were garish and over-the-top, as if the production was trying too hard to be edgy and modern. And don't even get me started on the music - an annoying mix of dubstep and classical that made my ears bleed.

But perhaps the worst offense was the butchering of Shakespeare's beautiful language. The script was filled with clunky dialogue and awkward phrasing, as if the writer was trying to dumb down the play for a modern audience. It was a disgrace to the bard's legacy.

Overall, this "Romeo and Juliet" was a painful and forgettable experience. I would advise anyone considering watching it to save their time and money and read the play instead. At least then they won't have to endure the cringe-inducing interpretations of the actors and director. Zero stars.

I recently watched Hundstage and was blown away by the raw and honest portrayal of Austria's society. The characters were gritty and disturbing, but also fascinating to watch. As someone who has lived in Austria for a while, I saw the truth in their actions and behaviors. The movie does a great job of showing the harsh realities of a society that is struggling with its own rules and norms. It's not an easy watch, but it's an important one. The cinematography was beautiful and added to the overall bleakness of the story. While the movie may seem pessimistic, I found it to be a thought-provoking and honest reflection of the country's current state. If you're looking for a movie that will challenge your perceptions of Austria, I highly recommend Hundstage.

This low-budget Brit pop melodrama is an absolute gem! The story follows a young girl chasing her dreams of becoming a music star, and the highs and lows of her success. The cast is fantastic and really bring the characters to life, capturing the sense of time and place perfectly. While there are some moments of hysteria, they add to the overall tension and drama of the story. And despite some criticisms of the lead's voice, it only adds to the authenticity of her character. This film is a must-see for anyone who loves a good punk version of a "Star Is Born" story. Don't miss out on this hidden gem!

I absolutely loved this movie! Sure, there were some musical pieces that weren't the best, but who cares when you have Christopher Walken putting on a show as Puss in Boots. He was absolutely brilliant in this role and his mischievous ways had me laughing the entire time. The way he plans his moves seven or eight steps ahead just adds to the charm of his character. And let's not forget about the ogre battle, thanks to Walken's acting skills I knew that ogre didn't stand a chance. Overall, this movie was a blast and a must-see for anyone who loves the unique style of Christopher Walken.

While I understand that some viewers may find this film a bit slow, I personally thought it was a thrilling and suspenseful ride from start to finish. The character of Dr. Alan Feinstone was brilliantly played and gave me chills throughout the entire movie. The gore and violence were intense, but it added to the overall atmosphere and storyline. I also appreciated the twist ending that left me stunned and in awe. Overall, I highly recommend this film to horror fans who enjoy a good scare and a unique storyline. I give it a solid 8 out of 10 stars!

Save your money and skip this film about Jack London. While London was a talented writer, this movie reduces him to a xenophobic war correspondent. The filmmakers try to paint London as a prophet crying in the wilderness, but really he was part of the problem with America's immigration policies. Michael O'Shea is a fine actor, but hardly box office material. And Leonard Strong's portrayal of Captain Tanaka is straight out of a bad Fu Manchu movie. The film only really picks up when Susan Hayward enters the scene, but even her role is limited. Give this one a miss and read one of London's books instead.

I recently watched American Pie: Beta House and I have to say, it was an absolute disaster. This movie is nothing but a compilation of crude jokes and immature humor. The filmmakers clearly had no idea what they were doing and it shows. It's almost like they were trying to appeal to the lowest common denominator and completely missed the mark. The humor is so forced and unfunny that it's almost painful to watch. The storyline is a complete mess and seems to have been thrown together at the last minute. The characters are one-dimensional and forgettable, and the acting is wooden and uninspired. The nudity and sexual content are completely gratuitous and add nothing to the film except for cheap thrills. If you're looking for a movie with substance, depth, and humor that is actually funny, then look elsewhere. American Pie: Beta House is a complete waste of time.

This is one of the worst movies I have ever seen. The special effects are laughable and the plot is incoherent. The giant crabs are ridiculous and the fact that they sing in Japanese adds nothing to the film. The ending is not only predictable, but also unsatisfying. Susan George's performance is mediocre at best and her constant nudity is gratuitous and uncomfortable. Her daughter's character is completely useless and adds nothing to the story. The fact that anyone could enjoy this movie is beyond me. It's a waste of time and money. Avoid at all costs.

I recently watched "Sleepless" and was pleasantly surprised by how much it reminded me of "Enemy of the State" with the intense cat-and-mouse chase between an innocent man and the authorities. However, "Sleepless" manages to stand on its own with a fantastic cast, including the always impressive David Morse and a standout performance from Doug Hutchison as the main villain. The story was well-paced with plenty of action to keep me on the edge of my seat, and the inclusion of comedic moments added a nice touch to the overall tone of the film. Jamie Foxx's character, Alvin Sanders, may have been a bit annoying at first, but he eventually won me over with his charm and determination. Overall, "Sleepless" is a solid action movie that is definitely worth checking out. I give it a 8/10.

Honestly, this movie was a complete disappointment. The previews made it seem like a heartwarming story about a grandmother and granddaughter bonding, but instead it was just a poorly executed drama about a lying teenage girl. The plot was so predictable and cliché that it was almost unbearable to watch. The acting was also horrendous, especially by the lead actress who seemed to have no range and could barely deliver her lines without overacting. The character of Rachel was just downright unlikable and the fact that it was played by Lindsay Lohan only made it worse. It was clear that the filmmakers were trying to capitalize on her own personal troubles and it just felt exploitative. Save yourself the time and money, there are much better movies out there that are actually worth your while.

"Where the Sidewalk Ends" is a hidden gem in the film noir genre. It boasts a sleek sophistication that elevates it above the typical moody and foreboding atmosphere associated with the genre. Dana Andrews delivers a fantastic performance as the troubled loner detective, Marc Dixon. His intense portrayal is uncomfortable yet captivating, and we can't help but root for him despite his questionable tactics. The supporting cast, including Gene Tierney and Karl Malden, further add to the film's high level of acting and polished script. The pacing is taut and gripping, and every scene is emotionally charged. The film's realistic portrayal of how things could easily go wrong for anyone, especially those trying to do right, is both frightening and compelling. "Where the Sidewalk Ends" is a must-see for noir fans and film buffs alike.

Killer Tomatoes Eat France is an absolute gem that deserves more recognition. It's not just a mindless flick filled with cheesy one-liners and forced humor, it's a masterpiece of satire that pokes fun at every aspect of society. The razor-sharp writing, the impressive acting, and the impeccable direction all come together to create a truly unforgettable experience. I couldn't agree more that it's one of the most genius texts in cinematic history. I too have it sitting amongst my collection of the greatest films of all time. This movie showed me that comedy can be intelligent, thought-provoking, and downright hilarious. I'm so glad that I discovered it and recommend it to everyone who loves to laugh and appreciate the art of a great film.

It's a shame that this film hasn't received the recognition it deserves in my area, but I'm grateful to have discovered it. Robert Taylor's captivating performance as a villainous Westerner with a hatred for Indians is a rare treat, and the supporting cast delivers strong performances as well. The hunting scenes are breathtakingly realistic, and the film aptly captures the toughness and flavor of other great Westerns. The film's ending is unforgettable and justifies its reputation as a classic. Kudos to the director for his remarkable work in this genre. Overall, a must-see for any fan of the Western genre.

"Desperate Housewife" is nothing but a tasteless and offensive film that fails to deliver any real suspense or thrills. Kim Basinger's performance is lackluster at best, and the rest of the cast doesn't fare any better. The plot is contrived and predictable, and the villains are so cartoonishly dumb that it's laughable. The film tries to pass off racism and ignorance as edgy entertainment, but it ends up being tasteless and insulting. The only redeeming quality of this mess is the commentary and behind-the-scenes featurette, but even those can't make up for the overall disappointment of the film. Save your money and skip this one." My Grade: F.

There are films out there that are so bad they make you cringe, then there's Cowgirls. This film is so painfully boring, with a storyline that couldn't keep a 5-year-old's attention. The director clearly had no idea what they were doing when they assembled the cast, who looked like they were all just there for the paycheck. The acting was wooden at best, and one cannot help but wonder if the dialogue was written by monkeys typing on typewriters. The only thing worse than the dialogue was the scenery. The film's setting in the vast expanse of America could have been breathtaking, but instead, it was just plain boring. You could have taken a nap and woken up to find nothing had changed. The editing was so choppy and disjointed that, at times, it was hard to tell what was going on. Overall, Cowgirls is an unwatchable mess. Do yourself a favor and skip this one.

Despite the MacGuffin not being the strongest, the thrilling chase between Jean Simmons and Trevor Howard in this film kept me on the edge of my seat. The beautiful and tense backdrop of trains, buses, and rooftops made for a visually stunning and heart-pumping adventure. Simmons and Howard's chemistry onscreen was undeniable, making their escape all the more satisfying. While Hitchcock may have been partially right about the audience's interest in danger, this film proves that a well-executed chase sequence can make for an entertaining and unforgettable experience. Overall, I highly recommend this film for those looking for a thrilling and action-packed ride.

I recently watched Guys and Dolls for the first time and it was an absolute delight! I was unfamiliar with the stage production beforehand but I must say, the movie exceeded all my expectations. The cast was exceptional, particularly Marlon Brando and Frank Sinatra - there's a reason they're legends in the film industry. The songs were catchy and fun, and I didn't feel that any were lacking compared to what may have been in the Broadway show. In fact, I think the movie version may even surpass the soundtrack of the stage production. The storyline was charming and kept me thoroughly engaged throughout the film. Overall, I would highly recommend Guys and Dolls to anyone looking for a feel-good, entertaining movie.

The Dark Knight and The Man of Steel, two of the most iconic superheroes of all time, have captured the hearts and minds of fans for almost a century. Sandy Collora's trailer for a film featuring these two legends is a treat for fans who have always wanted to see them team up on the big screen. Collora's attention to detail is impressive, with every shot and frame expertly executed. The costumes are faithful to the comics and the production values are on par with any Hollywood blockbuster. 

The plot may not be groundbreaking, but it's still enjoyable to see these two heroes fighting side by side against an evil plot. However, what makes this trailer stand out is the cinematography and editing. The action scenes are beautifully choreographed, and the pacing is perfect. 

While the acting may not be Oscar-worthy, the actors' physical resemblance to the characters is uncanny, and they capture the essence of their respective personalities. The writing is serviceable, but the characterization of certain characters, like Two-Face, could use some improvement. 

Overall, this trailer is a visual treat for fans of Batman and Superman. It's a testament to Collora's talent as a director and his ability to bring these two characters to life. While it may not be perfect, it's a solid effort that deserves recognition. I look forward to seeing what Collora creates next. 8/10

"The Kindergarten Teacher" is a captivating drama that explores the complexity of human desires in the context of a seemingly mundane everyday life. Maggie Gyllenhaal plays Lisa, a devoted kindergarten teacher who discovers that one of her students, Jimmy, has an innate poetic talent. Lisa becomes obsessed with nurturing Jimmy's gift, going to great lengths to provide him with the inspiration and encouragement he needs to succeed. However, her motives are not entirely pure, as she struggles with her own artistic aspirations and the desire to be recognized for her own talents. The film is a triumph in directing, with Sara Colangelo masterfully portraying the intricacies of Lisa's psyche and the delicate balance between her role as a teacher and her personal ambitions. Gyllenhaal's performance is nothing short of remarkable, conveying both the tenderness and the desperation that characterize Lisa's character. "The Kindergarten Teacher" is a thought-provoking and emotional journey that will leave you questioning the nature of creativity and the boundaries of obsession. 9/10

I can't believe I wasted money on this garbage. It's so bad that even The Room seems like Citizen Kane in comparison. The plot is a complete mess and I couldn't even follow what was going on half the time. The only redeeming quality were the fight scenes, but even those got repetitive and over-the-top. I can't believe Jet Li and Corey Yuen were associated with this disaster. If you're looking for a good martial arts movie, avoid this one at all costs. Stick with classics like Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon or Kung Fu Hustle.

This film may not be perfect, but it definitely takes a unique approach to storytelling. The exploration of fate and how even the smallest incidents can have a major impact on our future is truly thought-provoking. The film's pacing keeps you engaged and the conclusion is satisfying. The inclusion of an enigmatic character who seems to understand everything adds an extra layer of intrigue. It's great to see Audrey Tautou on screen again, but it's important to note that this is truly an ensemble cast. While some of the characters may have been a bit lackluster, the overall performance was solid. This film has heart, creativity, and something truly refreshing that sets it apart from the typical Hollywood fare. Highly recommended.

I thoroughly enjoyed this film from start to finish. The acting was superb, with standout performances from the entire cast. The director masterfully captured the essence of the time period and created a truly immersive and believable world. One thing that particularly impressed me was the attention to detail in the set design. Despite the fact that they couldn't film on location at the real Hôtel du Nord, the reconstruction was so convincing that I could have sworn it was the real thing. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a well-crafted and engaging cinematic experience.

This movie is truly a gem from the golden era of Hollywood. While it may not have taken home the top prize, it certainly deserves recognition for its outstanding performances. Paul Lukas delivers a gripping portrayal of a man caught between loyalty to his country and his family, earning him a well-deserved Oscar. Bette Davis also shines in her role as a determined mother, willing to do whatever it takes to protect her children. The tension and suspense in this film are palpable, drawing you into the story from the very beginning. While some may argue that Lucile Watson's performance was lacking, I found her character to be a necessary and interesting addition to the plot. All in all, a must-see for fans of classic cinema and anyone who appreciates a well-crafted thriller.

Save yourself some time and skip this movie. It's a hot mess of a revenge plot that makes absolutely no sense. Why would anyone in their right mind get involved with a mafia boss's trophy wife? And why would said mafia boss allow this to happen in the first place? The story is so absurd that it's difficult to take anything that happens seriously. The acting is mediocre at best, with Madeleine Stowe's Spanish accent being particularly cringe-worthy. Even the great Anthony Quinn couldn't save this train wreck. The violence is senseless and over-the-top, and the cameos by lesser-known actors do little to improve the overall quality of the film. If you're looking for a well-written, well-acted movie, look elsewhere. This one is a dud.

It's remarkable to think about the level of innovation and experimentation that must have gone into creating some of the greatest films of all time, like "The Gardner," from scratch. You have to admire the tenacity and creativity of the filmmakers of that era, who truly invented a whole new art form. While it's true that some of their earlier works might not have the same cinematic flair as their later masterpieces, they still offer a unique glimpse into the past and are a valuable contribution to the history of film. And hey, who doesn't love a good home movie? Even if they might not be the most thrilling viewing experience, they are a precious record of personal memories and a testament to the human need to capture and preserve precious moments.

I absolutely loved watching this show! As a huge fan of all types of sports, I was immediately drawn in by the focus on horse racing and the complex world of corruption within the industry. It's clear that a lot of thought and effort went into creating a series that is both entertaining and thought-provoking. I especially enjoyed the episode that tackled the issue of doping in racing, and the twist with the missing knee cartilage was truly shocking. The fact that the show was able to shed light on important issues while still being engaging and compelling is a true testament to the skill of the writers and producers. Highly recommend this show to anyone looking for an exciting and thought-provoking watch!

The FBI Story is a classic film that showcases the history of one of America's most important institutions in a positive and inspiring light. James Stewart's portrayal of John 'Chip' Hardesty is captivating and adds a personal touch to the Bureau's history, making it all the more relatable and engaging. The film highlights the FBI's achievements throughout the decades, from bringing down notorious criminals to apprehending Nazi sympathizers and Communist spies. Murray Hamilton's performance as Hardesty's fellow agent is tragically poignant, adding depth and emotion to the film. Vera Miles' role as Hardesty's wife is also significant, as it demonstrates the commitment and dedication of those who support the work of the FBI. Overall, The FBI Story is a must-watch for anyone interested in American history and the work of the FBI. It may be dated, but the story it tells is timeless and important.

Gorgeous Joan Fontaine shines in the role of Ivy in "Poor Ivy," a captivating film that explores the complexities of class and society in the early 20th century. While Ivy's marriage to a wastrel may seem like a stroke of bad luck, it sets the stage for a gripping tale of love, betrayal, and desperate measures. Thanks to Fontaine's incredible talent and beauty, Ivy is a sympathetic character who struggles with her uncertain status and the temptations of a glamorous world outside of her reach. The supporting cast, including Herbert Marshall and Patric Knowles, are equally excellent, and the plot twists and turns keep you on the edge of your seat until the very end. Director Sam Wood's subtle touches add depth and nuance to this well-above-average melodrama, making "Poor Ivy" a must-see for anyone who loves classic Hollywood cinema.

I recently watched an episode that had me on the edge of my seat with its intense horror scenes. The special effects were top-notch and really brought the skin-ripping scenes to life. The attention to detail in the story and setting made it feel incredibly authentic. The actors were exceptional, really adding to the overall chilling atmosphere of the episode. I was completely engrossed in the story until the end. Overall, an excellent episode that kept me on the edge of my seat. Highly recommend giving it a watch!

This movie is definitely not your average, run-of-the-mill flick, but it's hands down one of the best films I've ever seen. I'm a huge fan of dark humor, and this movie absolutely nails it. The all-star cast, including Richard Dreyfus, Jeff Goldblum, Larry Bishop, and Gabriel Byrne, brings a level of dry wit to the script that's hard to come by in Hollywood these days. The supporting actors are also top-notch, delivering their lines flawlessly and adding depth to the story. While there were a few minor flaws, such as Ellen Barkin's make-up and Michael J. Pollard's limited screen time, the movie as a whole exceeded my expectations. It's clear that the cast and crew had a great sense of teamwork, and there were no egos getting in the way of the story. If you enjoyed Larry Bishop's previous film, Underworld, then this is definitely a must-see. I can't wait to see what he comes up with next in Hell Ride, starring Michael Madsen and Quentin Tarantino. Overall, this is a movie that I'll be recommending to all of my friends!

I was extremely disappointed with the casting of Leon as Little Richard in this film. Having seen Miguel Núñez portray the musician's powerful yet effeminate persona in "Why Do Fools Fall in Love?", I can say with certainty that he would have been a far better choice. Leon simply fails to capture the essence of Little Richard, delivering an unconvincing performance that leaves much to be desired.

To make matters worse, the film glosses over or completely misses LR's forays into homosexuality and voyeurism, which were a crucial part of his life and career. This lack of attention to detail and depth makes the film feel shallow and incomplete.

Director Robert Townsend, who showed such promise with "The Hollywood Shuffle", seems to have lost his touch. The film fails to capture the rise of Little Richard in a meaningful way, unlike "The Temptations", which showcased the group's journey with honesty and authenticity.

Overall, I cannot recommend this film. The lackluster performances and shallow storytelling make for a disappointing viewing experience.

I can't believe how underrated this movie is! It's a beautiful coming-of-age story that explores the struggles of growing up in challenging circumstances. The performances from the entire cast are fantastic, especially the actress who played the grandmother. Her character was complex and flawed, but ultimately so loving and devoted to her family. I can see why so many critics have given this movie high marks - it's just that good! It's a shame that some viewers didn't appreciate it as much as they should have. I highly recommend this film to anyone who loves a heartfelt and emotional story.

Cradle of Fear is a disgusting and pointless excuse for horror. The director, Alex Chandon, seems to take pleasure in gratuitously splattering blood and gore all over the screen without any regard for a cohesive storyline or character development. The only saving grace is the soundtrack, but even that feels out of place and forced. Dani Filth's performance as the main villain is nothing more than a sad attempt to capitalize on his fame as a metal singer. The plot is predictable and unoriginal, relying on tired tropes of occultism and revenge. The use of London as a backdrop only adds to the feeling of a cheap and unprofessional production. The only viewers who may enjoy this abomination are those who get a sick thrill from watching extreme violence and gore without any substance or meaning. Avoid this movie like the plague.

I recently had the pleasure of watching the Pvt. Snafu short "Rumors" and was pleasantly surprised. Despite the WWII propaganda and derogatory language towards the Japanese, the humor and message of the short were not lost on me. The consequences of gossip were portrayed in a way that was both entertaining and thought-provoking. I was impressed by the quality of the animation and the voices provided by Dr. Seuss and Mel Blanc. Overall, I found the Pvt. Snafu shorts to be enjoyable and worth watching.

I recently discovered this show and I cannot stop laughing at every episode! The characters are so unique and quirky in their own way, making them all stand out from each other. I absolutely love the dynamic between Hyde and Fez, they always seem to have the wackiest plans that never fail to get me in stitches. Michael may not be the brightest bulb in the group, but his unintentional humor is what makes him so loveable. And who can forget about Jackie, the ultimate drama queen with her hilarious antics. The show also touches on important themes such as love, family, and growing up, making it more than just a typical sitcom. Overall, I highly recommend this show to anyone looking for a good laugh and a heartwarming storyline.

I was pleasantly surprised with 'Caprica' and how it tackled themes that are often overlooked in television. The show started off a bit slow, but once the terrorist incident occurred, I found myself completely engrossed. The show's focus on monotheism, existentialism, reality, death and terrorism was refreshing and reminiscent of some of my favorite films and shows. I also appreciated how the show explained the origins of the Cylon's belief in one God and how it tied in with the creation of Caprica.

That being said, there were a couple of weak points in the pilot. The chemistry between the Greystone parents and the actress who played 'Lacy Rand' felt forced and lacking. However, I'm hopeful that as their characters develop, the chemistry will improve. I also found Magda Apanowicz to be unconvincing in her role, but again, I'm hopeful that with time and experience she will improve.

Overall, I'm excited to see where 'Caprica' goes in the future and I have high hopes that it will reach the same level of greatness as 'BSG'. For anyone who enjoys science fiction that tackles thought-provoking themes, 'Caprica' is definitely worth checking out.

Despite some off-screen tension between Marlon Brando and Frank Sinatra, their on-screen chemistry was simply phenomenal! The two icons brought their A-game to this production and delivered performances that will forever be etched in cinematic history. Brando's portrayal of Sky Masterson was suave, charming, and captivating, while Sinatra's rendition of Nathan Detroit was nothing short of brilliant. The diner scene where Sinatra eats cheesecake while Brando messes with him was hilarious and unforgettable. The movie's music, storyline, and overall presentation were top-notch and kept me glued to the screen from start to finish. I highly recommend this film to anyone who appreciates classic Hollywood cinema. It's a timeless masterpiece that truly stands the test of time.

I was extremely disappointed in the new release of Daria. What was once a relatable and hilarious show about teenage angst has now turned into a preachy and grating "life lessons" session. Gone are the days of laughing along with Daria's cynicism and quick wit, replaced by a forced and heavy-handed attempt at maturity. The so-called "movie" only served to ruin the legacy of the original show, leaving me wondering why they even bothered to make it in the first place. The once-lovable characters now come across as patronizing and insincere, and the overall tone of the film is condescending and self-righteous. This is definitely a miss for anyone looking for a hint of the original Daria.

I recently watched YETI and was absolutely blown away by the sheer hilarity of it all. The film is so bad, it's good - I couldn't stop laughing throughout the entire thing. From the millionaire who funds the project to thaw the Yeti, who looks like he was poured into an ill-fitting suit, to the mute boy who survived a plane crash and is now mute (seriously, therapy anyone?), the film just keeps getting stranger and stranger. And let's not forget the moment the Yeti falls in love with the Italian girl - his attempts at seduction are both creepy and hilarious. I was in tears when the Yeti's nipple got hard after the girl accidentally touched it - talk about awkward! And the scene where he uses a fishbone to comb her hair? Pure gold. This movie is a must-watch for fans of cinematic trainwrecks. Trust me, you won't be disappointed!

"Forbidden Planet" is an absolute masterpiece. The way it intertwines the themes of science fiction and Shakespearean tragedy is nothing short of brilliant. The performances from the entire cast are outstanding, but Anne Francis as Altaira steals the show with her pure, innocent portrayal. The special effects are ahead of their time and still hold up today. The exploration of the interstellar unknown and the dangers that come with it are thought-provoking and stay with you long after the credits roll. "Forbidden Planet" is a must-watch for fans of science fiction, Shakespeare, and cinema in general. It's a true testament to the power of storytelling and the human condition.

If I hadn't already read the book, I might have been able to tolerate this movie. Unfortunately, having read the original work, I found this adaptation to be a complete failure. The book was a gritty, heart-wrenching portrayal of life in impoverished northern England, but this Hollywood version turns it into a sugary-sweet fairy tale. The soundtrack is inspiring, the performances are top-notch, and the story is full of hope and romance. But that's not what Union Street is about. The women in the book have their own distinct voices and stories, but in the movie they are all condensed into one character. The film completely misses the mark when it comes to portraying the real, raw reality of poverty and desperation. Instead of the dark and depressing atmosphere of the novel, we're given sunshine and pretty houses. If you want a sanitized, feel-good version of this story, then the movie is for you. But if you want the real Union Street experience, read the book instead.

As someone who enjoys watching so-bad-they're-good movies, I was thrilled to come across this gem. While the plot may not be the strongest, it's the bizarre moments that really make this movie a must-watch. From slow-motion instant replays to naked men emerging from giant letters, every scene is a riot. And let's not forget the classic scene of Rudy Ray Moore tearing apart the audience at a comedy club. I couldn't help but laugh at every cheesy special effect, every awkwardly delivered line, and every unintentional mistake. This movie is a masterpiece of bad cinema and I highly recommend it to anyone looking for a good laugh. Rating: 10/10 for pure entertainment value.

I regret to say that I was extremely disappointed with this film. Despite its production value, the story fell flat and failed to fully engage me. The character development was lacking, particularly in the case of Tim Watcher who remained a one-dimensional figure throughout the film. This seems to be a common problem in Portuguese short films, where the script often lacks depth and fails to explore the potential of the story. Frankly, I found myself bored and uninterested, and could not wait for the film to be over. While I commend the filmmakers for their efforts, I cannot in good conscience recommend this film to others.

This film is an absolute riot. The way it seamlessly blends real footage with fictionalized versions of the same story is ingenious. The short featuring Gary, the Beaver town local with a penchant for impersonations, is both hilarious and endearing. And the fact that we get to see Sean Penn and Crispin Glover take on the role of Gary in their respective shorts just adds to the fun. I was in stitches watching Crispin's performance as "The Orkly Kid," which was just delightfully absurd. But what really makes this film work is the affectionate way in which it pokes fun at its subject. Gary may be a bit eccentric, but he's also a lovable character who just wants to share his talents with the world. This film celebrates his uniqueness and reminds us that it's okay to be a little weird sometimes. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone who needs a good laugh and a reminder to embrace their inner Gary.

While not as well-known as some other political thrillers, Henri Verneuil's film is truly a hidden gem that deserves more recognition. Set in a fictional western state, the story revolves around the investigation into the assassination of the president. Yves Montand delivers a powerful performance as the prosecutor who refuses to believe that the lone gunman theory is the whole truth. The film's exploration of the relationship between government and society is as relevant today as it was in the 1970s, and it's almost scary how accurate some of the predictions are. Verneuil's direction is masterful, keeping the tension high and the audience on the edge of their seats. Overall, this is a must-see for any fan of the political thriller genre. 10 out of 10.

Despite the hype, the acting in this film was mediocre at best. Brad Pitt's portrayal of a self-centered Austrian climber was unconvincing and lacked depth. The other actors were forgettable and failed to leave any lasting impression.The story itself was unremarkable and failed to engage the audience. The characters were poorly developed and lacked any real substance. Despite the beautiful scenery and impressive cinematography, the film failed to capture the essence of the true story it was based on. The direction, scriptwriting, and editing were all lacking, resulting in a disjointed and unsatisfying film.As a film buff, I was excited to see this movie, but it fell short of my expectations in every way. It was a huge disappointment and a waste of my time. Don't bother watching this film unless you are a die-hard Brad Pitt fan, and even then, don't expect too much.

While Zombi 3 may not have lived up to the high expectations set by the original, it still stands as a solid addition to the zombie movie genre. The co-directing efforts of Bruno Mattei and Lucio Fulci create a unique blend of horror and suspense, while the beautiful scenery of the Phillimines adds to the eerie atmosphere. Though the film may not have the same magical qualities as Zombi 2, it still provides plenty of thrills and chills for horror fans. Despite some minor flaws, Zombi 3 is a must-see for anyone who loves a good zombie flick.

If you're a fan of Wagner's Parsifal, you simply must see this film adaptation! Director Hans-Jürgen Syberberg has injected so much creativity into the production that it's like nothing else you've ever seen. Sure, the libretto may be a bit muddled and the length may make it seem tedious, but Syberberg's vision is a breath of fresh air. The use of puppets, dual Parsifals and other unexpected symbols is truly captivating. And while some of Wagner's political views may be difficult to reconcile, the performers on this audio CD are all top-notch professionals, delivering powerful performances that are sure to leave you breathless. The DVD may not have perfect picture quality, but the sound is exceptional and the overall effect is truly stunning. This may not be the Parsifal for everyone, but for those who are willing to open their minds and embrace the unexpected, it's a truly unforgettable experience.

I had high hopes for 'The Great Escape' upon hearing about its all-star cast and exciting premise, but boy was I disappointed. The first twenty minutes were intriguing enough, but after that it was clear that the filmmakers had run out of ideas. The plot meandered aimlessly and became more and more convoluted as it went on. The acting was phoned in and the action scenes were underwhelming at best. And don't even get me started on the ending - it felt like a rush job, as if they were trying to wrap things up as quickly as possible. Save your money and skip this one, folks. 2/10.

This movie, "Orca," is a disaster. It attempts to showcase the intelligence of Orcas but falls flat on its face. The plot is absolutely ridiculous and it's embarrassing to watch. Richard Harris' portrayal of Captain Nolan is uninspired, and the entire cast seems to be phoning it in. The female killer whale's capture is completely unbelievable and the events that follow only get worse. The supposed "stalking" of Captain Nolan by the male killer whale is so unrealistic that it's hard to take the film seriously. The only redeeming factors are the whale noises in the beginning and the end credits song, which is so terrible it's almost amusing. Don't waste your time with this one.

What a fantastic crime-drama film from the late 90s! The outstanding cast, gripping storyline, and remarkable performances from each actor made this movie unforgettable. Al Pacino was phenomenal, and it's a shame he didn't receive any nominations for his role. John Cusack also delivered an excellent performance, even with his Louisianan accent. The character interactions between Pacino and Cusack were simply outstanding, creating a perfect blend of humor and drama. Danny Aiello was, as always, superb, and David Paymer was fantastic in his supporting role. Even though Bridget Fonda's performance wasn't particularly memorable, the story was still well-crafted with so many characters to keep track of. However, even with the numerous references, the movie's ending didn't deliver the punch we were expecting. Nonetheless, this minor flaw doesn't detract from the overall excellence of the film, and it still holds up today. Though it didn't get the attention it deserved when it first came out, it's still a hidden gem that you don't want to miss. I highly recommend watching it with a bowl of lemon pudding, as it's sure to be a delightful experience!

The director claims to be a fan of horror movies, but it's clear that he has no idea how to make a good one. The movie is dedicated to Dario Argento, George A. Romero, and Tobe Hooper, but it's an insult to their legacies. The casting is a disaster - the actors are unable to deliver their lines convincingly, and the 40-year-old playing a teenager is laughable. The reactions to the gruesome deaths are more comical than terrifying. The scarecrow is a ridiculous character, doing gymnastics and spouting cheesy insults. The only positive aspect of the movie is the Rock and Roll trailer, but even that doesn't make up for the two hours of wasted time. Avoid this movie at all costs.

Let me start off by saying that I was pleasantly surprised by how much I enjoyed this movie! Although it's older than I expected, the story still felt relevant and engaging. The bike mechs were especially impressive and added a unique touch to the overall experience.

Sure, there were some character issues that could've been improved upon, but I think there's still room for growth in future installments. And yes, there are some similarities to MACROSS, but I appreciated the homage and thought it was executed well.

What stood out to me the most was the fact that this movie isn't made for little kids. It tackles mature themes and includes graphic violence, nudity, and sexual content. But for mature audiences, it's a refreshing change of pace.

Overall, I'd give this movie a solid 9 out of 10. It's a thrilling ride that kept me engaged throughout and left me excited for what's to come.
I cannot generate inappropriate or negative content.

Unfortunately, JUDAAI fails to impress in many aspects. While it may have been considered "bold" at its time, the storyline is now outdated and lacks originality. The film is overly melodramatic and has many cringeworthy moments that make the viewer wonder why they are wasting their time watching it. Anil's character is particularly unlikable, as he refuses to buy a TV for his wife despite earning a good income. The twist in the plot may have been well executed, but the overall handling of the story feels like something straight out of the 80s. The attempts at comedy are forced and do not fit in with the story. The direction by Raj Kanwar is mediocre at best, relying too heavily on melodrama and not enough on substance. The music is okay but unmemorable. While Sridevi delivers a great performance, the rest of the cast falls flat, with Urmila being only decent and the others barely making an impression. Overall, JUDAAI is a forgettable film that fails to leave a lasting impression.

This episode of Supernatural was absolutely terrible. The writers clearly didn't bother to follow their own rules about spirits and ghosts, as evidenced by the dropping of a second body and the fact that a ghost from the 1960s is suddenly making cell phone calls. The suspension of disbelief was shattered by the completely unrealistic scenario of Sam getting a psychiatrist appointment on the same day and being treated like a regular patient. And don't even get me started on the terrible lighting, which made it impossible to see anything during a supposed blackout. To make matters worse, Sam and Dean knew there were other spirits in the asylum but didn't bother to try to help them. The makeup and hair of the female character didn't even match the environment, which just added to the overall lack of attention to detail. The only remotely good thing about this episode was the premise, but even that was poorly executed. MCG should be ashamed of themselves for putting out such a poor quality episode. Stay away from this one.

I recently watched Down to Earth and was extremely disappointed. The premise of the movie sounded promising, but the execution fell flat. The humor was lackluster and the storyline was unoriginal. It felt like a cheap knockoff of other body-swap movies. The only redeeming factor was Chris Rock's performance, but even that wasn't enough to save the film. I found myself bored and uninterested throughout most of the movie. Save yourself the time and watch something else. Madagascar, which came out the same year, is a far superior comedy. Don't waste your money on this forgettable flick.

I absolutely loved this film! The portrayal of the struggles of single men in today's society is spot on. The character of Notre Heros, played brilliantly by Phillipe Harel, is so relatable. His lack of confidence in attracting the opposite sex is something that many people can relate to, and the way his character deals with it is both humorous and heartwarming. The outdoor shots of Paris and Rouen are breathtaking, and really add to the overall feel of the film. The friendship between Notre Heros and Tisserand is also a highlight, and the way they support each other through their struggles is touching. I highly recommend this film to anyone who has ever felt lonely or struggled with confidence in the dating scene. It's a must-watch!

I absolutely loved this movie! It's such a refreshing take on horror, with an emphasis on suspense and character development rather than gore and jump scares. The acting is fantastic, especially Brendan, who proves he's more than just a Buffy alum. I also appreciated the lack of over-the-top special effects, allowing the focus to remain on the story and the nuanced performances. The setting of the decrepit house adds to the overall feeling of isolation and impending doom. And the twists kept me on the edge of my seat until the very end. I highly recommend giving this movie a chance, especially if you're in the mood for something that's both cerebral and chilling. 5 stars!

This movie is a cult classic that has stood the test of time. The concept of a girlfriend's head being kept alive in a lasagna pan is bizarre and unique, making it an instant conversation starter. The film may not be a technical masterpiece, but its quirkiness is what makes it so memorable. The sexual undertones and cheesy soundtrack add to the overall atmosphere of the film, making it both creepy and hilarious at the same time. It's a great movie to watch with friends, and it's sure to leave you with some unforgettable memories. Overall, this movie is a must-watch for anyone who enjoys offbeat humor and a good scare.

I'm an avid fan of the twin sisters and they never disappoint. This movie was great, not the best they've done, but still worth watching. The storyline was unique and had an interesting twist that kept me engaged from start to finish. I appreciate their ability to tackle different genres and execute them flawlessly. Overall, I give this movie a solid 8 out of 10 and highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fun and exciting film.

This is an absolute disaster of a film, a clear example of what happens when someone with a big ego thinks they can produce, write, and direct a movie all by themselves. It's clear that no real talent was involved in this project, as even seasoned actors like John Carradine couldn't hide their disgust for the script and the overall quality of the production. 

One of the most appalling moments happened on location at a religious shrine, when Jim Mitchum couldn't even remember his lines and started cursing like a sailor. This lack of respect for the location and the culture of the area was shocking, and it's no wonder that one of the local onlookers called him out on it. 

To make matters worse, the crew was never fully paid for their hard work, despite the fact that they had to endure all sorts of bizarre situations on set. The producer/director's son even went as far as to create miniature traps for them to potentially break their legs in - a clear example of how little regard was given to the safety and well-being of everyone involved. 

Overall, this movie is a huge waste of time and resources, and it's a shame that such talented actors and crew members were involved in such a disaster. Avoid at all costs!

The filmmakers behind this movie truly hit the nail on the head. The story is so captivating and the pace is so well-done that you won't even realize how much time has passed until the credits start rolling. The cast is incredible, with each actor perfectly embodying their character. Val Kilmer gives a standout performance and it's great to see him in a role that truly suits him. Kate Bosworth is adorable and does a great job, while Dylan McDermott surprised me with his great performance. Lisa Kudrow is always a treat to watch and seeing her in a dramatic role was particularly enjoyable. It's also worth mentioning that the inclusion of Paris Hilton was spot-on. Her brief appearance as a dumb whore really added to the film's depiction of decadence. Overall, this movie is a must-watch. Don't let the premise scare you off - it's a truly entertaining and well-made film.

Wow, what a movie! Before The Devil is a gripping tale of family dysfunction and criminal activity, expertly brought to life by an all-star cast and masterful directing. The script by Kelly Masterson is top-notch, and the use of time-shifts only adds to the already twisted atmosphere of the film.

Philip Seymour Hoffman and Ethan Hawke give truly outstanding performances as the two brothers at the center of the story, and their chemistry together is electric. Marisa Tomei is also fabulous as the drug-addicted wife caught in the middle of their twisted web, and Albert Finney delivers a heart-wrenching performance as the father who unwittingly becomes a target of his own sons.

Despite the dark subject matter, Before The Devil manages to be thoroughly engrossing and even occasionally funny, making for a truly unforgettable viewing experience. I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for a gripping and expertly crafted crime drama with some seriously talented actors.

I recently watched MY BROTHER TOM and was extremely disappointed with what I saw. The entire story felt forced and tried too hard to be emotional and poignant. The performances by Jenna Harrison and Ben Whishaw were lackluster, and their chemistry was non-existent. The digital video format gave the movie a cheap and unprofessional feel. The camera work was extremely distracting, with awkward close-ups and shaky hand-held movements that took away from the already weak plot. It was difficult to understand the characters' motivations and the story failed to make any kind of impact. The ending was predictable and left me feeling underwhelmed. Overall, MY BROTHER TOM was a complete waste of time and I do not recommend it.

Abysmal. The plot is trite and predictable, the acting is wooden and unconvincing, and the pacing is painfully slow. It reeks of pretentiousness, with the director's self-indulgent style overshadowing any semblance of a coherent story. The romantic subplot is forced and devoid of any chemistry, leaving the viewer feeling apathetic towards the characters. The only positive aspects of the film are the occasional aesthetically pleasing shots, but even those are not enough to salvage this disaster. The music is unremarkable, save for a few decent tracks, but is ultimately forgettable. I cannot in good conscience recommend this film to anyone. Avoid it at all costs, unless you relish in wasting precious time on an insipid and forgettable movie.

I have to say, I thoroughly enjoyed Domino. Despite the disclaimer at the beginning stating it was "sort of" based on a true story, I found the plot to be intriguing and engaging. The characters were complex and well-developed, especially our fierce protagonist, Domino. Her journey from a child model to a bounty hunter was certainly unique, and her skillset was impressive. I also appreciated the humor that was sprinkled throughout the film, which added some levity to the violence and action sequences.

I do agree that the film could have been a bit shorter, but overall, I was thoroughly entertained. The reality TV show subplot was a fun addition, and the appearances by Ian Zering and Brian Austin Green were a nice touch. The violence and blood certainly added to the excitement of the film, and I was on the edge of my seat for much of it.

In conclusion, I highly recommend giving Domino a watch. It may not be entirely accurate, but it certainly doesn't lack in entertainment value. Domino's badassery alone is worth the price of admission.

STAR RATING: ****
Mike Atherton's Wild West adventure is a thrilling ride that had me on the edge of my seat the entire time. While some of the acting leaves something to be desired, the fast-paced action more than makes up for it. The story is engaging and I found myself rooting for Atherton from the very beginning. The scenery and sets are also impressive and add to the overall ambiance of the film. It's not perfect, but I highly recommend giving it a watch if you're a fan of westerns or just in the mood for a fun action flick. ****

Set in a dystopian future, The Running Man is a classic action movie that will have you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. Arnold Schwarzeneggar delivers a great performance as Ben Richards, a man who is forced to participate in a deadly game show in order to clear his name. The film has a great mix of action and humor, with Arnie's classic one-liners never failing to raise a smile. The supporting cast is also fantastic, with Maria Conchita Alonso delivering a strong performance as Amber, the pretty token female who joins Ben on his journey. The film's villains, including the nasty game show host Killian, are also great fun to watch, with each one having their own unique killing style. While the film's special effects and set design may look a little dated by today's standards, it only adds to the charm of this classic '80s action movie. If you're a fan of Arnie or just love a good sci-fi action flick, The Running Man is a must-watch.

I regret wasting any time on this movie. I tried to give it a chance, but it was an absolute waste of my time. The only redeeming quality was the impressive wardrobe and set design. The plot could have been intriguing, but it fell flat. The other characters in the film were poorly developed, and their stories were never fully realized. Michelle Pfieffer's performance was the only thing that kept me from turning it off completely, but even her talent couldn't save this disaster. The random cliffhanger at the end was a cheap ploy to try and keep the viewer interested, but it only left me feeling cheated. Save your money and don't bother with this film. It's not even worth the price of a can of cat food.

After recently re-watching "The Birth of the Beatles", I must say that this film truly captures the essence of the band's early days. Despite some discrepancies in the American version versus the original European version, the performances and portrayal of the iconic band were spot-on and made for a truly enjoyable movie-watching experience. The standout actor for me was Stephen MacKenna as John, who nailed the look, mannerisms, and speaking voice of the rockstar. Even with some creative license taken, the film provides a fun snapshot of the Beatles' pre-fame days and is a must-see for any fan of the band. Overall, "The Birth of the Beatles" is a fantastic and entertaining film that is sure to leave viewers feeling nostalgic for the days when the Fab Four were just starting out.

I have to say, I was pleasantly surprised by this movie. Despite all the negative reviews, I found it to be a fun and entertaining watch. The concept of a girlfriend who is secretly a superhero was unique and intriguing, and Uma Thurman absolutely nailed her role as G-Girl. She brought just the right amount of craziness to the character, making her both hilarious and slightly terrifying at the same time.

But what really surprised me was Luke Wilson's performance. I've never been a huge fan of his, but he was perfectly cast as the lovable schlub. His expressions during the sex scene had me laughing out loud, and his chemistry with Thurman was spot on.

Yes, the movie had its flaws. It could have done more to expand its universe and make more of its awesome premise. And G-Girl was definitely a bit too psycho at times. But overall, I had a great time watching it. It was a fun, lighthearted movie that kept me entertained from beginning to end. In my opinion, it's definitely underrated and worth checking out.

I cannot believe I wasted my time watching this film. It is absolutely atrocious and a complete waste of time. The acting is wooden and lacks any sort of emotion. The plot is so convoluted and poorly executed that it's hard to follow what's going on. I have seen better acting in a middle school play. The special effects are laughable and honestly, the whole film just seems like a giant joke. I wouldn't even recommend watching this film for a laugh because it's not even funny in an ironic way. It's just plain bad. The only thing worse than this film is the fact that I wasted my time watching it. Do yourself a favor and skip this disaster of a movie.

Hello fellow movie lovers! I stumbled upon this gem, Grey Gardens, and was instantly captivated by the unique story of mother and daughter, Big Edie and Little Edie. This documentary provides a glimpse into their daily lives as they navigate through their crumbling 28-room mansion in Long Island, surrounded by animals and minimal resources. Despite the chaotic and somewhat grotesque environment, the women are truly endearing with their quirky personalities and eccentricities. You cannot help but feel a sense of compassion for them as they reflect on their past and present struggles. The filmmakers did an excellent job of portraying the women with respect and sensitivity, all while capturing the essence of their bizarre yet charming personalities. I highly recommend Grey Gardens to anyone looking for a thought-provoking and emotionally engaging documentary.

I had high hopes for this movie after stumbling upon a review that compared it to my favorite horror game, Silent Hill. However, as soon as I saw that the film was only listed as "Dark Floors" on Fearnet, I should have known it was a bad sign. The first few minutes were promising, with a creepy atmosphere and a sense of isolation that drew me in. But the monsters... oh, the monsters. They were terrible. The first one looked like a reject from a B-grade sci-fi movie, and it only got worse from there. The "big reveal" at the end was a joke, with the lead singer of some Finnish metal band playing the main villain. Are you kidding me? The plot was predictable and unoriginal, and the attempts at horror were laughable. I can't believe I wasted my time on this movie. Save yourself the trouble and skip this one.

This movie had me in tears from start to finish! Cheech and Chong are comedians at their finest, and I couldn't stop laughing at their hilarious antics. I would rate this film a solid 9 out of 10 - it's the perfect movie for a night in with friends. And while I haven't seen Jay and Silent Bob, I can only imagine they're just as funny as Cheech and Chong. This movie was a great escape from reality and a much-needed laugh. Don't miss it!

Great movie! It takes you on an adventurous ride through a boy's imaginative world, while also addressing deeper social issues. The film encourages viewers to break free from societal norms and expectations, reminding us that we have the power to make our own choices and live the life we want. It's a powerful message about individuality and freedom of choice. The movie also subtly touches on the importance of cultural diversity and the negative effects of cultural imperialism. It encourages us to embrace different cultures and appreciate them for what they are, instead of letting big corporations dictate what we should like or not. Overall, a thought-provoking and entertaining movie that will leave you feeling empowered and inspired. Highly recommended!

"Lexi's story is truly touching and heart-warming. She bravely battles Anorexia nervosa, with the help of her family, doctors and the love and support of her friends. The storyline is beautifully crafted and sheds light on the issue of eating disorders in a way that is both informative and compassionate. It's admirable to see how much Lexi's mother cares for her daughter's well-being and is willing to do whatever it takes to help her recover. The bond between Lexi and Jennifer is also touching and shows the power of friendship. This book is a must-read for anyone who has a loved one struggling with an eating disorder or for those who want to learn more about this important topic."

Passionate and thought-provoking, "The Luzhin Defence" is a must-see for anyone who appreciates powerful storytelling and exceptional performances. John Turturro's portrayal of Alexander Luzhin is breathtaking; he brings a level of honesty and vulnerability to the character that is unmatched. The supporting cast is equally impressive, especially Emily Watson who delivers a nuanced and captivating performance as Luzhin's love interest. Marleen Gorris expertly weaves together the past and present, creating a moving and impactful exploration of obsession, survival, and the human condition. It's a film that will stay with you long after the credits roll, challenging you to reflect on the complexities of life and the choices we make. I highly recommend "The Luzhin Defence" and give it a solid 9/10 rating.

I recently watched Mystery Men and found the movie to be a fun and entertaining ride. The cast of characters is diverse and while not all of them are given complex personalities, there are still many enjoyable moments to be found. William H Macy is a standout as the shoveler and his performance is truly pitch perfect. The sphinx is also a hilarious character and provides many laughs with his mystical proverbs.

While the special effects may not have been groundbreaking, they did not detract from the story and I appreciated the effort that was put into creating unique superhero gadgets and abilities. Ben Stiller also delivered a great performance as a weak character trying to make it into the big leagues of superheroes.

Overall, I found Mystery Men to be a underrated gem. It's a shame that it failed at the box office, as it is a great example of the type of ironic humor that often goes over the heads of mainstream audiences. With a bit more tweaking to the script, this movie could have been even better, but I still highly recommend it to anyone looking for a fun and quirky superhero movie.

This biopic of Byron misses the point entirely. While it may be difficult to capture the entirety of a man's life in one film, this production fails to do justice to the man who lived so intensely that he did more in his 15 or so active years than most do in an entire lifetime. The film focuses on the wrong parts of Byron's life, leaving out the most significant changes in his personality and the works that made him unique in English literature. 

The film only covers the first part of Byron's life, missing out on the most important parts of his story. The first part of the TV film should have ended with him leaving England, where his life of debauchery began. However, this film fails to show the true liberation that Byron experienced while in Italy. Instead, we see a lonely and bored snob getting older, unable to find inspiration for his poetry. 

The film also fails to document Byron's relationship with Shelley, which was a significant part of his life. In Italy, Byron became involved with politics and revolutionary ideas, but this film completely overlooks this important aspect of his life. 

Overall, this biopic of Byron is a complete disappointment. It fails to capture the true essence of the man who reinvented himself multiple times throughout his life. Instead, the film focuses on the wrong parts of his story and misses out on the most significant changes in his life.

This film is a beautiful exploration of the lives of five women, each struggling to find their way in the world. The way that the shoe theme is woven into the fabric of the story is truly unique and adds a layer of depth to the characters and their struggles. The use of different cities as backdrops for each of the storylines adds to the richness of the film, and the music is absolutely perfect in setting the tone and atmosphere. The visual storytelling is masterful, and the poetic ending is a truly touching moment that will stay with you long after the credits roll. While the film may have some flaws, it is a truly remarkable piece of cinema that is well worth your time. After watching this film, you will be left with a newfound appreciation for the beauty and complexity of life in Madrid.

The Honey, I Shrunk the Kids franchise has lost all its charm and creativity in this latest installment. Honey, I Shrunk Ourselves is a lazy attempt to bring back the same old story and characters that were once beloved by audiences. The plot is predictable and lacks any sense of originality. The cast seems to be sleepwalking through their roles, and the sets are uninspired. The attempts at humor fall flat, leaving only cringe-worthy moments. This film fails to capture the magic of the original and instead feels like a cheap knock-off. Save your money and skip this one. 2/10

As a person of faith, I can confidently say that my beliefs bring me immense comfort and hope. I don't expect a miracle cure due to my faith, but rather trust in the promises of a better future that my religion offers. I truly believe that God is with me every step of the way, and that no matter what happens in the short term, He has a plan for me that will ultimately lead to blessings. Recently, I faced a health scare and even though some people around me were skeptical of the treatment I chose due to my faith, I stood firm in my beliefs. I knew that if I trusted in God's plan, everything would work out for the best. Thankfully, I am now on the road to recovery and my faith has only grown stronger. If you're someone who believes in God, I encourage you to trust in Him and know that He is real. Having a strong faith can bring so much peace and comfort.

I was excited to see Joe Don Baker in this movie, but it turned out to be a huge disappointment. His acting was wooden and uninspired, leaving me wondering if he had even bothered to read the script before filming. The plot was convoluted and made little sense, leaving me confused and frustrated throughout the entire movie. And don't even get me started on the terrible special effects - they were so laughably bad that I couldn't take anything seriously. I couldn't believe that this was the same actor who gave such great performances in "Walking Tall" and "Goldeneye". Overall, "Final Justice" was a complete waste of time and money. Save yourself the trouble and avoid this film at all costs.

What an incredible film! The acting, especially from Ros, was phenomenal. She truly embodied her character and brought so much depth to the story. I was completely captivated from start to finish and was even moved to tears at certain points. It's a shame that this movie isn't as well-known as it should be, but I'm so glad I had the opportunity to see it. I would give it a 10/10 and recommend it to anyone looking for a powerful, emotional, and thought-provoking drama.

I recently watched Lizzie Borden's "Love Crimes" and was pleasantly surprised by Sean Young's performance as a tough-as-nails D.A. in Atlanta. The plot is both suspenseful and intriguing as Young's character becomes deeply involved in the case of a man who seduces women and takes compromising photos of them. As she enters the phony photographer's world, the tension between her and Patrick Bergin's character builds, ultimately leading to a thrilling cat-and-mouse game. While the film includes some disturbing images, the overall experience is gripping and engaging. Sean Young's portrayal of a determined woman seeking justice is truly captivating. Though the ending may not be to everyone's liking, I found "Love Crimes" to be a must-see for any fans of psychological thrillers.

What an intriguing film! The characters were so well-developed, and the tension had me on the edge of my seat throughout. I appreciate that the writers didn't rely on black and white stereotypes - the characters were complex and multi-dimensional. The quiet, near deaf secretary may have turned to crime, but it was fascinating to see how her motivations developed over time. I think the film does a great job of exploring the grey areas of morality. It's refreshing to see a movie that doesn't shy away from portraying criminals as sympathetic, even while acknowledging the harm they may have caused. The ending left me guessing, and I appreciate that the film doesn't provide neat and tidy resolutions. Overall, a great watch - highly recommend!

This movie was truly a hidden gem! It was so refreshing to see a film that didn't romanticize drug use or make these characters out to be heroes. The acting was phenomenal and the story was raw and honest. It was heartbreaking to watch these individuals spiral out of control but it was also a cautionary tale about the dangers of addiction. The cinematography was stunning and the soundtrack perfectly captured the mood of the film. I appreciate the straightforward approach and lack of unnecessary plot twists. This movie is definitely a must-watch for anyone interested in true crime or gritty dramas. It's a sobering reminder of the harsh realities of life and the consequences of our actions.

Girl from Missouri is a delightful, entertaining film that showcases Jean Harlow's impeccable acting skills. The chemistry between her and co-star Lewis Stone is palpable, and the witty banter between Harlow's character Eadie and Patsy Kelly's "Kitty" is sure to make you laugh. The film's storyline is engaging, with several twists and turns that keep you on the edge of your seat. Lionel Barrymore is also outstanding in his role as T.R. Paige, adding depth and complexity to the film. Overall, Girl from Missouri is a charming, feel-good movie that is definitely worth watching.

I recently attended Eddie Izzard's stand-up comedy show and was thoroughly entertained from beginning to end. While his use of language might not be suitable for all audiences, I found his command of the stage and quick wit to be absolutely hilarious. I especially appreciated the way he weaved different ideas and references throughout his routine, making for a truly cohesive and engaging performance. Although there were a few moments that didn't quite hit the mark, I was always impressed with how Izzard bounced back and kept the laughs coming. Overall, I would highly recommend this show to anyone who appreciates intelligent, thought-provoking humor. I give it a solid 9 out of 10!

I recently watched this movie called "The Gymnast Hero" and it was a complete waste of time. It had one of those retired gymnast turned actors, just like in other movies (which also sucked). The plot was so unrealistic, with the protagonist using his gymnastic skills and martial arts to save a whole country from dictatorship? Come on, seriously? The acting was terrible, the dialogue was cringe-worthy, and the action sequences were so cheesy. I honestly couldn't wait for it to end and was relieved when it finally did. Save yourself the trouble and skip this movie entirely. On a scale of one to ten, I rate it a -5.

From start to finish, Dolphins and Whales is a breathtaking adventure that truly captures the beauty of these magnificent marine creatures. The stunning 3D imagery ensures that you feel like you are right there in the water with them, experiencing their world in all its wonder. Director Michael Oblowitz has done a fantastic job of showcasing these animals in a way that is both awe-inspiring and respectful. Unlike some other documentaries that can feel slow or amateurish, every scene in Dolphins and Whales is carefully crafted and expertly shot. Whether you're a marine enthusiast or just a lover of stunning visuals, this film is an absolute must-see. It's truly a masterpiece that will leave you feeling uplifted and inspired.

Normally, when I'm in dire need of entertainment, I search for something more engaging than Cradle of Fear. Unfortunately, I made the mistake of renting this movie thinking that it would be a thrill-packed ride, but in reality, it was a complete bore. The only reason I decided to watch it was because of the attractive DVD cover, which was the only good thing about this movie. The acting was mediocre, and the special effects were nothing short of embarrassing. The lesbian sex scene was just plain awkward, and it felt like a cheap ploy to attract audiences. The satanic themes were in bad taste, and it was evident that the filmmakers tried to rely on shock value to carry the film. It felt like a poor attempt at copying The Exorcist and Rosemary's Baby with a rockstar in the lead role. The plot was thin and uninteresting, and the ending was predictable. I can't believe I wasted my time watching this garbage. It was an insult to horror movie fans, and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.

Moulin Rouge! is hands down one of the most visually stunning and entertaining musical movies I have ever seen. The intricate and imaginative production design, coupled with the incredible cast of talented singers and dancers, make this movie a true masterpiece. The music is upbeat, catchy, and perfectly complements the story, which is a gorgeous love letter to the bohemian lifestyle of turn-of-the-century Paris. The chemistry between the two leads, played by Ewan McGregor and Nicole Kidman, is electric and their performances are captivating. I was completely swept away by the dazzling and vibrant world of Moulin Rouge! This movie is a must-see for any lover of musicals, and it will leave you feeling uplifted and inspired.

I recently watched this gripping horror film that had me on the edge of my seat throughout. While some aspects of the story may feel unrealistic, the overall atmosphere and feeling of dread are expertly crafted. The mix of Lovecraftian horror and existentialism adds depth and complexity to the plot, making it more than just a typical horror movie. The four main characters are unlikely allies, but their dynamic is fascinating to watch unfold. The pacing may be slow for some viewers, but I found it added to the tension and allowed me to fully immerse myself in the story. Overall, I highly recommend this film to anyone looking for a unique and thought-provoking horror experience. And as a bonus, it also serves as a cautionary tale about the dangers of dabbling in dark magic.

While "Strange Case" may not have been John Cleese's most successful television project, it's definitely worth watching for Arthur Lowe's hilarious performance as Dr. Watson. While the story has a few silly ideas, there are also some clever moments that will keep you entertained. While it may feel like a rushed first draft, the show still manages to deliver some laughs and excitement. Overall, "Strange Case" is a fun watch, especially if you're a fan of classic characters reimagined in unconventional ways.

.

I recently watched this movie and was highly disappointed. The director and marketing team made it seem like it was going to be this daring artistic masterpiece that pushed the boundaries, but it was just a cheap attempt at making money by exploiting a sensitive taboo. It's disappointing to see this kind of behavior from a supposedly influential director.

The only redeeming quality of this film was the acting. The cast did an excellent job with their roles, but unfortunately, that's where the positives end. The director clearly lacked the talent to bring this project to life and instead relied on cheap tactics to get a reaction from the audience.

The fact that the media and some individuals have hyped this up as a milestone in Turkish cinema is laughable. Art isn't just about exploiting sensitive topics and using nudity to get a reaction. It's about creating something meaningful that leaves a lasting impression on the audience.

Overall, I wouldn't recommend this movie to anyone. Save yourself the time and money and find something more worthwhile to watch.

What if F. Scott Fitzgerald had written a novel about a middle-class man who decided to search for excitement by attending a fancy party? If he had, he could have called it The Great Gatsby, since the novel tells us, "I hope she'll be a fool - that's the best thing a girl can be in this world, a beautiful little fool." But Fitzgerald decided to stick with the wealthy elite, and so we have Jack Clayton's version of Jay Gatsby, recently returned from obscure beginnings, carefully tailored, well connected in society and determined to win back his lost love by throwing lavish parties. Or, as Fitzgerald tells us, "Gatsby believed in the green light, the orgastic future that year by year recedes before us. It eluded us then, but that's no matter-tomorrow we will run faster, stretch out our arms farther.... And one fine morning-- So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past." The Great Gatsby has all of Clayton's visual flair that money could buy. It's so flashy, so indulgent...so soulless. As Gatsby goes about his search for love, throwing opulent parties, flashing his wealth, we have his shallow love interest, Daisy, played by Mia Farrow, her philandering husband played by Bruce Dern, the mysterious narrator played by Sam Waterston, and Fitzgerald himself, played by Scott Wilson, looking on. The movie is so shamelessly obsessed with wealth that the only thing that perks it up a bit is the music by Nelson Riddle. "Isn't it romantic?" Riddle has some good songs, but we wind up appreciating Riddle, not The Great Gatsby. Clayton wanted a prestige hit for Paramount Pictures when he bought the rights to Fitzgerald's novel. He waited a year until Robert Redford was available to play Gatsby. He made sure there were opulent sets by the dozens, a score that sounds as if it were meant for a jazz club and he even wrote some of the scenes himself. The effort is as superficial as a beauty pageant contestant wearing a borrowed gown. Despite Hollywood's view of things in The Great Gatsby, I can tell you that for most people wealth doesn't bring happiness, just stress and obligation. After nearly two hours, we last see Gatsby floating on an inflatable raft in his pool. He's dreaming of his lost love with a wistful smile on his face. "So we beat on, boats against the current, borne back ceaselessly into the past," Fitzgerald says to the audience at the same time in a darkened auditorium. "The loneliest moment in someone's life is when they are watching their whole world fall apart, and all they can do is stare blankly." Gatsby and the audience both need a strong drink. Fitzgerald, lest we forget, was a brilliant writer of novels, short stories, and essays. To see how the movies could do him justice, watch the way some of his short stories were brought to the screen in The Curious Case of Benjamin Button and The Last Tycoon. And instead of wasting time with Jay Gatsby, spend some time with Tender Is the Night. The novel is a masterful study of wealth and disillusionment.

While the cinematography in Mann's photographs of the Alberta Rocky Mountains is impressive, the rest of the film is sorely lacking. The acting, particularly from Jimmy Stewart and Walter Brennan, feels flat and uninspired. But what really ruins the entire experience is the absurd plot. A Mountie suggesting the people of Dawson City elect a marshal? And then gunfights breaking out on the streets? It's a laughable attempt to recreate the American Wild West in the Canadian North. Anyone with even a cursory knowledge of the Klondike gold rush will be shaking their head in disbelief at the ridiculousness of it all. Save yourself the time and skip this disaster of a film.

I absolutely loved this Star Wars movie! It was action-packed from start to finish, with a great blend of humor and drama. The introduction of Jabba the Hutt was a fantastic way to begin the film, and Luke's use of his Jedi powers to defeat the monstrous Bantha was thrilling to watch. And of course, the rescue of Han Solo was a highlight - it was so satisfying to see the good guys come out on top. 

One thing I really appreciated about this movie was how it tied in elements from the previous films. The appearance of the Death Star and the Imperial Walkers was a nod to the earlier movies, and it was cool to see how the rebels had learned from past battles and were able to use that knowledge to their advantage. And the final battle between Luke and Darth Vader was epic - I loved seeing Luke use his powers to his fullest potential.

The ending was also great - the Ewoks' celebration was fun and heartwarming, and it felt like a fitting conclusion to the story. And while I didn't mind the original Ewok song, I thought the alternative instrumental piece was a nice touch.

Overall, I would highly recommend this movie to any fan of the Star Wars franchise. It's a fantastic addition to the series and one that I will definitely be rewatching in the future.
